snippets.title: Day 1: The Blind King's Question
snippets.sanskrit:

Dhṛtarāṣṭra uvāca:
Dharmakṣetre kurukṣetre samavetā yuyutsavaḥ

verseTranslations: Dhritarashtra said: "O Sanjaya, assembled on the holy field of Kurukshetra, eager to fight—what did my sons and the sons of Pandu do?"
Sanjaya replied: "Having seen the Pandava army arranged in battle formation, King Duryodhana approached his teacher Drona and spoke."
"O Teacher, look at this great army of Pandu's sons, arranged by the son of Drupada—your wise disciple."
snippets.commentary:
Think about this for a moment: the Bhagavad Gita doesn't begin with Krishna. It doesn't begin with Arjuna. It begins with a blind man asking a question from his palace, miles away from the battlefield.

Dhritarashtra couldn't see. But his blindness wasn't just physical—and that's precisely the point.

The day before this war, the sage Vyasa came to Dhritarashtra and offered him something extraordinary. "I can give you divine sight," Vyasa said. "You can witness everything that happens on this battlefield."

Dhritarashtra's response? "No, thank you. I'm comfortable as I am. But if you're offering, give it to Sanjaya instead."

*I'm comfortable in my blindness.*

How many times have we said the same thing, in different words? We don't want to see what's really happening in our marriage. We don't want to acknowledge what that habit is doing to us. We'd rather not look too closely at how we're living our lives. Chosen blindness feels easier than facing difficult truths.

The Gita begins here because this is where most of us begin—not wanting to see.

Now look at the first words Dhritarashtra speaks: *"Dharmakshetre Kurukshetre"*—at the field of Dharma, at Kurukshetra.

He calls it Dharmakshetra. The field of righteousness. He knows. Somewhere deep down, Dhritarashtra knows exactly which side represents Dharma in this war. He's not confused about right and wrong. He simply can't bring himself to act on what he knows.

This is one of the Gita's earliest teachings, tucked into its very first line: knowing what's right is not the same as doing what's right. Dhritarashtra knew. He just couldn't act.

There's something else hidden in this verse—a single word that reveals everything about why this war is happening. The word is *"Māmakāḥ"*—mine.

"What did *my* sons and *Pandu's* sons do?"

But wait. Weren't they all grandsons of the same man? Weren't the Pandavas also descendants of Kuru? Why aren't they all simply "Kauravas"?

Because Dhritarashtra couldn't see them that way. *My* children versus *their* children. *My* family versus *those people*. This is how he saw the world. This is how the world always divides itself before it goes to war.

We do this too, don't we? My team versus their team. My community versus outsiders. We draw these lines constantly, and then we wonder why there's so much conflict. The Gita is pointing at something fundamental here: this *mine versus yours* thinking is the seed from which all conflict grows.

In verse 2, the scene shifts to the battlefield. Sanjaya begins his narration, and immediately we see something curious: Duryodhana, the mighty king with the larger army, is nervous.

He had eleven akshauhinis—massive military divisions. The Pandavas had only seven. By any calculation, he should win. Yet look at what he does: he rushes to his teacher Drona, not to the commander Bhishma, and starts anxiously pointing out the enemy's strengths.

Why would someone with such an advantage feel so unsettled?

Because numbers aren't everything. Duryodhana knew, in some part of himself, that he was on the wrong side of this fight. He had stolen a kingdom. He had tried to kill his cousins. He had humiliated Draupadi in open court. All the military might in the world couldn't quiet that knowledge.

This is something worth sitting with: when you're doing the right thing, you can face challenges with a certain peace. When you're not, no amount of external advantage makes you feel secure. Duryodhana had everything going for him—except the one thing that would have given him real confidence.

And then comes verse 3, where Duryodhana speaks to Drona. On the surface, he's just pointing out the Pandava formation. But listen to his words more carefully: "Look at this army, arranged by the son of Drupada—*your wise disciple*."

There's an accusation buried in that phrase. *Your* disciple. The one *you* taught. Duryodhana is essentially saying: "This is your fault, teacher. You trained them. You gave them the skills they're now using against us."

This is how it works when we're not willing to own our choices. We blame the teacher, the parents, the circumstances, the system—anyone but ourselves. Duryodhana never once stopped to ask: "How did my own actions lead us here?" Instead, he looked for someone else to hold responsible.

There's a deeper teaching embedded in the structure of these opening verses that often gets overlooked. Notice how Vyasa, the author, chose to begin the text. He could have started with Krishna's teaching. He could have opened with some grand philosophical statement about the nature of reality. Instead, he begins with a question born from anxiety.

Dhritarashtra asks: *"Kim akurvata"*—what did they do? He's desperate to know. He can't bear the uncertainty. And this desperation reveals something crucial about the nature of attachment.

When we are deeply attached to an outcome, uncertainty becomes unbearable. We need to know. We check our phones constantly. We ask the same questions over and over. We cannot rest until we have information that confirms or denies our hopes and fears.

Dhritarashtra is not simply curious about the battle. He is terrified. His whole sense of security—the kingdom he helped his son steal, the dynasty he hoped to establish—depends on the outcome of this war. No wonder he's asking questions before a single arrow has been fired.

The Gita begins this way to show us something about ourselves. How much of our mental activity is driven by this same anxious need to know? How much of our day is spent checking, confirming, seeking reassurance?

Swami Chinmayananda used to point out that Kurukshetra was not just any battlefield—it was considered sacred ground. The name literally means "field of the Kurus," the ancestral dynasty. But it was also called Dharmakshetra because it was a place where great sages had performed austerities and spiritual practices for generations.

There's a profound symbolism here. The battle for dharma—for right living—doesn't happen in some pristine spiritual environment away from the mess of life. It happens right here, on the same ground where our ancestors walked, where our family dramas play out, where the stakes are highest and the relationships most complicated.

You don't get to choose a convenient time and place for your spiritual growth. The battlefield finds you. It might be your workplace, your marriage, your relationship with your aging parents, your own health crisis. The question is never "how do I avoid the battle?" The question is "how do I face it with clarity?"

Consider also the role of Sanjaya in these verses. He's the narrator, the one with divine sight, granted by Vyasa. Throughout the Gita, Sanjaya reports what's happening on the battlefield to the blind king.

Sanjaya represents something important: the possibility of true seeing. Unlike Dhritarashtra, who chose blindness, Sanjaya accepted the gift of vision. He can see the truth, and he reports it faithfully, even when that truth is painful to hear.

Every one of us has access to our own inner Sanjaya—that part of us that knows the truth, that sees clearly, that isn't fooled by our rationalizations. The question is: do we listen to it? Or do we, like Dhritarashtra, prefer to remain comfortable in our blindness?

The Gita is, in one sense, an invitation to become our own Sanjaya—to develop the capacity to see our lives clearly, to witness our own dramas with some degree of objectivity, to tell ourselves the truth even when it's inconvenient.

One more thing worth noting about these opening verses: the emotional tone. There's urgency here. There's anxiety. There's blame. There's defensiveness. The battlefield hasn't even begun, and already we see the full range of human reactivity on display.

This is intentional. The Gita doesn't pretend that we come to spiritual teaching from a place of calm readiness. We come to it desperate, confused, looking for someone to blame, terrified of what might happen. We come to it exactly as Arjuna will come to it in the verses ahead—overwhelmed and unable to function.

And that's okay. That's the starting point. The Gita meets us where we are.

Finally, let's consider the setting of these opening verses from a practical perspective. Here is Duryodhana, about to fight the most important battle of his life, and instead of focusing on strategy or inspiring his troops, he's complaining to his teacher about the enemy's strengths.

This is what anxiety does to us. It makes us focus on threats rather than possibilities. It makes us rehearse worst-case scenarios. It makes us seek validation for our fears rather than courage for our actions.

Duryodhana had assembled the greatest army the world had ever seen. He had legendary warriors on his side—Bhishma, Drona, Karna, Ashwatthama. He had every material advantage. And yet here he is, fixated on what the other side has, unable to appreciate his own resources.

We do this constantly. We have health, relationships, skills, opportunities—and we obsess over what we lack. We have support systems and capabilities—and we fixate on the obstacles. This is the Duryodhana mind at work, and it never leads anywhere good.

The antidote isn't positive thinking or denial of real challenges. The antidote is clarity—seeing what we actually have, what the situation actually requires, and acting from that clear seeing rather than from anxiety and complaint.

That's the journey the Gita will take us on. But it starts here, with recognizing where we are: blind like Dhritarashtra, anxious like Duryodhana, looking for someone to blame. Only when we see this clearly can we begin to move beyond it.
snippets.reflection:
So what do we take from this into our own lives?

First, there's the question of sight. What are you choosing not to see? What uncomfortable truth are you avoiding because ignorance feels easier? Dhritarashtra's tragedy wasn't his blindness—it was his refusal of sight when it was offered. We have that same choice, every day.

Then there's the *mamakah* problem—the way we divide the world into mine and not-mine. Pay attention to this in yourself. Notice how often your thinking draws these boundaries. My department versus theirs. My kind of people versus those others. These divisions feel natural, but they're the source of tremendous suffering.

And finally, there's the matter of confidence. If you find yourself feeling anxious despite having every advantage, it might be worth asking: Am I on the right side of this? Real confidence doesn't come from having more resources or more power. It comes from knowing that what you're doing is aligned with something true.

The Gita opens with a blind king, a nervous prince, and an army poised for destruction. It opens this way because this is where transformation begins—not in some serene mountain retreat, but in the mess of human conflict, fear, and confusion.

The battlefield isn't just Kurukshetra. It's wherever you are right now, facing whatever you're facing. And the question the Gita asks is the same one Dhritarashtra asked: What will you do?

snippets.commentary:
We'll be discussing bhagavad Gita. Chapter 1, Arjuna Vishada Yoga Yoga of Arjuna's Grief. In our scriptural system, there are two types of scripture. They're divided into two major categories. One is called Shruti. The other is called Smriti.

Shruti means herd and Smriti means remembered. So the scriptures which are considered heard by the great sages in their contemplation, in their inspired moments, and then given out to the world, are considered Srutis. And then based on those scriptures, the truths found in those scriptures in Sruti, the system in the society, the laws of society, the customs and traditions of society, they developed by the scriptures, are called smrutis. So Shrutis are typically considered as Prasthana trays. There are three legs of Sridhi. One is the Upanishads, which we have all learned.

They come at the end of the Vedas. Vedas generally describe all types of sciences which are in nature utilitarian or material which one can use in his lifetime. But the end of the Veda, there are dialogues between students and teachers. They are called Upanishads. They deal with this fundamental question we all ask, knowingly or unknowingly, who am I? Is there someone who has control over my life and what is my relationship with that controller?

So they are called openly set. So these are dialogues between students and teachers. But they are set in an environment of a serene Himalayan valleys. And both students and teachers are highly evolved seekers. The teacher is a realized master who has gone through his Sadhana and realize what the truth is. Student is also highly evolved seeker who has gone through Sadhana and now finding his final answers.

The truths in Srutis are immutable. Rather, they cannot be changed over a period of time, from one age to another. The Shruti does not change. The truths revealed in Srutis do not change. Smriti, on the other hand, are the laws created by society, by the leaders of the society. The lawmakers in the society are adaptable to the new environment in the society.

So the two mains we hear about are Parasara and Manusmriti. Mainly manusmriti is the one which we hear most, we heard most about. In fact, if I'm not mistaken, the laws in India before independence and somewhat after the independence were structured based on Manusmriti. Laws for Hindus were Hindu laws and they were based on Manusmriti. And laws for Muslims were based on Syria. So the Manusmriti was considered the code of conduct for the society.

And as we know that we don't apply Manusmriti as is in our society now. Even in India the laws have changed, society has changed. The basic structure may remain what Manusmriti says but lot of things we have updated to fit with our current needs. On the other hand, the facts revealed in Shruti are unchangeable. It is something like I can use mathematics in my life right from my childhood to my old age, depending on my own needs. I'll interpret mathematics accordingly.

But the fundamentals of mathematics do not change. 2/2 remain 4 when I was in my kg, it still remains 4 when I'm an old man and consider myself to be a wise person. The spiritual tenets in Shruti are like those rules which are unchangeable. They remain constant no matter how you look at it, how you try to prove it. But the application of those laws can change according to society. So mathematics, the way I used in my childhood is different than when I used as a high school student, then as a college student and then as a professional are different.

My applications are different based on my own situation. So Smriti are like those adaptable sciences which we can update as we go along in our society. So Manus Smriti, maybe the fundamentals may remain same but the application is completely changed in our society now. So there are three, three aspects of the Sriti Upanishad as we talked about Brahma Sutra. And third is Bhagavad Gita. So Bhagavad Gita is considered Upanishad by itself.

And therefore at the end of every chapter we'll say Upanishadsu Bhagavad Gita. So it's considered Upanishadh by itself because it reveals the truths which are revealed in Smruti. So it's considered part of the Shruti. The uniqueness of Bhagavad Gita is also considered Smriti. It's a combination of Shruti and Smriti. Therefore it has a unique place in Prasthantri.

In Prasthantari, if you just learn Upanishads, they are transcendental. It transcends my day to day life. It really tells me what the ultimate truth is and how it relates to me. And they are set in a very serene environment, as I said before. Bhagavad Gita on the other hand, is completely in a different environment. It's still dialogue between a student and a teacher.

But here the student teacher are also not a great master in a lowly seeker who is now trying to understand. They were two friends with a dialogue between two friends or two cousins. One was great, but he did not act like one when it comes to his friendship with his friend. So it's a dialogue between two equals set in an environment which is completely different from Himalayan valleys. It's on the battlefield. So some commentators think that the whole Mahabharata was written by Bhagavan Ved Vyas.

To have a platform for Bhagavad Gita, to have a Bhagavad Gita, he had to have a proper background to convert that into a scripture which can guide mankind. So entire Mahabharata, which is hundred thousand verses as we now know it, originally started out as book called Jaya and It is only 24,000 verses. But it did have Bhagavad Gita in it. So Bhagavad Gita is the central crown jewel of Mahabharata. Mahabharata became the greatest epic of all times for Hindu culture and for India and for the world because of Bhagavad Gita. You remove Bhagavad Gita and Mahabharata becomes another story of a Kuru clan.

You know, at the same token, you remove Mahabharata and Bhagavad Gita becomes merely a poetry, something similar to Upanishads. So they have a symbiotic relationship, the Mahabharata and Bhagavad Gita. Mahabharata converts Bhagavad Gita into a Smriti which can be used in a day to day life. Mahabharata gives us the background of human society, a human conditions, human aspirations, human shortcomings. So it is generally said that Mahabharata contains all human situations. If you don't find that situation Mahabharata it does not exist.

You may find the situation find in Mahabharata other works of art, but not other way around. So Mahabharata sets the stage and we all know the story so there is nothing really much to talk about how we get to the point where the war was about to begin. We all know the story Kauravadhan Pandav, the cousins they were fighting for the rights and Duryodhan said I'm not giving even a square inch of a land even though rightfully Pandavas were the claimant for that kingdom. The war is about to begin and we are now going to see a dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna because we all know the background story. So in the first chapter called Arjuna Vishadhi Yoga there are no great philosophical revelations so therefore one should not seek for philosophical Explanations in Chapter 1 Bhagavan Shankaracharya in his Gita Bhasya he does not start Bhasya till verse 11 of chapter 2. He didn't think it was worth his time to talk about chapter one and the first 10 verses of chapter two.

But for us common folks context is very important. Without context we lose the meaning of what we are discussing so we need to have context. It is very important to know the context. Chapter one gives us the context for the dialogue which is going to take place between Krishna and Arjuna. So as we now know Krishna and Arjuna are the two main characters in this dialogue but there are two other people who were involved in Bhagavad Gita One is Dhritarashtra and another is Sanjaya Dhritarashtra as we know was the Emperor of Hastinapur or King of Hastinapur and Duryodhan and other 19 and Kauravada his sons and he could have avoided this war by just his own declaration but he did not. He was blind from his birth and therefore he was not considered worthy of being the king but because the situation occurred with Pandu younger son he was made the caretaker king and Duryodhan became the effective king like MBS in Saudi Arabia.

So Duryodhan was the actual guy who was making the decisions and he obviously was not going to give up the kingdom which he has already been enjoying for last so many years. So when the war is about to begin Dhritarashtra is still sitting in the palace because he's not taking part in the war but he's curious about what's going on. He knew that on the Kaurava side there are 11 Akshoni Sena Pandavasa 7 Akshoni Senna so 11 plus 718 so you will see the 18 is the magic number for some reason there are 18. There are 18 books in Mahabharata. The war lasted 18 days. There are 18 chapters in Bhagavad Gita.

And apparently one Aksoni has 21,870 chariots, the same amount of elephants, three times that of horses and five times that of foot soldiers. If you take any of these numbers and add those digits, they will add to 18. You take those numbers 21870 and add up. It will add up to 18. You take multiply that by three and they add up to 18. Again, multiply the five.

So if you do the math, there were about 4 million people on that battlefield. Now I know I've never been to Kurukshetra. I can't tell you they're large enough to hold 4 million people alone. But according to this calculation, the There are about 4 million soldiers ready to fight now. The war is about to begin. Dhritarashtra knew that his side is much stronger, 11 Akshoni say, whereas Pandava is only 7.

But he also knew who is on the right side and who was on the wrong side. So that gives you a little bit of a pause in thinking what is going to happen. He wanted to know what's going on and he had an opportunity. The day before Bhagavan Vidya stops by his palace and said, you really need to see what's happening and I can give you divine vision so that you can see that. But he said, I'm comfortable in my blindness. I really don't want to see.

But if you are really kind enough, give it to my minister Sanjaya the Divyadrasti Sanjay get the divine vision. Now we do not know how all that happened. Maybe Sanjay was on the battlefield and reported back. But it is believed that Sanjay has this divine vision. Not only he can see things which are happening on the battlefield, but he can also see what's going on in people's mind. He can hear, he can see and he can perceive.

Therefore it's called Divya Dashti because he has much greater capacity than average person or even average person who has an ati Drasthi means he can see even further than a normal person. So Dhritarashtra knew that Sanjay can see everything. So the very first verse starts with Dhrutarastra Ovacha. You can see that Bhagavad Gita did not stand with Krishna Vacha or Bhagavan Vacha or Arjuna O Vacha. He started with Dhritarashtra. Dhritarashtra is the blind king These characters are there in Chapter one and in Mahabharata.

So we can identify with the situation. I may not be able to identify Darjun, but I can probably identify Dhritarashtra as a father. Maybe I have done something with Dhritarashtra did and therefore he suffered.
snippets.reflection:
Consider a situation in your own life where you face conflicting duties—where doing right by one person or principle seems to require doing wrong by another. The Gita doesn't offer easy answers to such dilemmas, but it invites us to face them honestly rather than avoiding them.

Today, notice if there's something you're choosing not to see because the truth would be uncomfortable. Dhritarashtra's tragedy wasn't his blindness—it was his refusal of sight when it was offered. What truths are you avoiding? What would happen if you faced them directly?

The battlefield isn't just Kurukshetra. It's wherever you are right now, facing whatever you're facing. And the question the Gita asks is the same one Dhritarashtra asked: What will you do?

snippets.title: Day 3: The Great Heroes
snippets.sanskrit:

snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter one, Arjuna Vishada Yoga Yoga of Arjuna's Grief. As we had discussed before, this is a chapter which gives us the context for the dialogue between Arjuna and Krishna. We have seen that Bhagavad Gita is part of the Prasthanatrei, one of the three legs of our philosophy, the Upanishads, Brahma Sutra and Bhagavad Gita. Bhagavad Gita has a unique place as we have discussed that it is not only a Shruti because it reveals the Brahma Vidya but it is also applicable for a day to day living a social order. Therefore it is also considered Smruti. So in that context we're seeing this chapter one as the study in comparison of how different people react to the same situation.

So we started this Bhagavad Gita with Dhritarashtra's query to Sanjaya what's happening at the battlefield? Dharmakshetra, Kurukshetra, Mamakaha, Pandavaschain. The very first thing we notice is how Dhritarashtra is thinking this world is divided into mine and yours, mine and rest of the world Mamakaha, mine and Pandava's. So this is the one issue which we deal with in philosophy that in our Advaita philosophy the root cause of all our problems is the duality. This duality which I have as I as an island by myself and then world is out there creates this friction between I and the world. So the very first indication, the first word is where we stand in this.

We are in the Dhrutrastra Sthiti. We see this world as I, mine and rest. And then as we further go into the chapter we see Sanjay's narration. Sanjaya starts his narration with what is Duryodhan doing? So we are seeing now the world from Duryodhan's perspective, same situation. The two armies are facing each other.

War is about to be started. We all know the background of why they are there very elaborately. The Mahabharata describes what happened before we came to this point of two armies facing each other. Now Duryodhan is looking at the situation. He sees the situation from a very different perspective. He sees from perspective whether the winnable or not winnable am I in a winning position or am I in a losing position?

The same situation as we say further in the chapter Arjuna looks at it very differently. He looks at it as whether right or wrong to be here. So it gives us various perspectives how we look at our lives when we face any situation depending on my own mental condition we look at the situation that way. Swamiji used to say the Scriptures are nothing but the mirror of our mind. Every time we read the Scriptures we see our own reflection in it. So we have seen that Sanjay first says that looking at the Pandavas army Raja Duryodhan went to Drona and told him thus.

And then he discovered what he told Drona. First of all, as we know the commander in chief on Kaurava's side with Bheeshma Pandava side with Drishtudhumna, Drupad's son. So if Duryodhana had to go to anybody, if he had any question, doubt or explanation he should have gone to Visma and said let's make sure that we are in a winning position. But instead of he goes to Drona who was his teacher. That because it seems he felt that there is a soft spot. Drona is as powerful as Bheeshma and Arjuna in terms of his prowess in warfare.

But he knew that he has soft spot for his students. Every teacher has soft spot for his or her best student. Arjuna was Drona's best student. Not only that, all other people who are the great warriors on the other side are Drona's student. So he is now questioning whether he will be at his best when Drona fights this war. It seems therefore he goes to Drona and tells him look at the army on the Pandava side.

snippets.title: Day 7: Arjuna Surveys the Field
snippets.sanskrit:
स घोषो धार्तराष्ट्राणां हृदयानि व्यदारयत् |

अथ व्यवस्थितान्दृष्ट्वा धार्तराष्ट्रान् कपिध्वजः |

अर्जुन उवाच |
snippets.transliteration:
sa ghoṣo dhārtarāṣṭrāṇāṃ hṛdayāni vyadārayat .

atha vyavasthitāndṛṣṭvā dhārtarāṣṭrān kapidhvajaḥ .

hṛṣīkeśaṃ tadā vākyamidamāha mahīpate .
verseTranslations:
That tumultuous sound rent the hearts of (the members of)
Dhritarashtra's party, making both the heaven and the earth resound.

Then, seeing the people of Dhritarashtra’s party standing
arrayed and the discharge of weapons about to begin, Arjuna, the son of
Pandu, whose ensign was a monkey, took up his bow and said the following
to Krishna, O Lord of the earth.

Arjuna said  In the middle between the two armies, place my chariot,
O krishna, so that I may behold those who stand here desirous to fight,
and know with whom I must fight, when the battle is about to commence.
snippets.commentary:
We are now discussing chapter one, Arjuna Visadhi Yoga Yoga of Arjuna's Grief. So in the first 18 verses we have seen what is the situation with Dhritarashtra and what is the situation with Duryodhan in how Bisma reacted and how the Pandavas reacted. So what we are basically seeing here is anytime someone speaks, we can see his mental state. Unless somebody speaks, we will not know what's going on. So up till now we have seen the very first verse. We have seen Dhritarashtra state of mind.

The Dhritara state of mind is Mamakaha Pandabah. His world is divided between mine and others. Even his own brother's children who he has raised, he does not consider them to be mind. So we know now that this division in our mind about this duality of I and mine in the world which is outside of me creates the conflict. All the conflicts as we have discussed are there because of this sense of duality and then not following our own Dharma. Had Dhritarashtra followed his Dharma, we wouldn't have this war.

So Bhagavan Vedhi Vyas is now painting the picture of how different people are situated in this Mahabharata. As we have heard many times before that all the characters and situations that we encounter in life are already there in the Mahabharata. It is said that if it is not in Mahabharata, it is not worth even knowing or mentioning. So the situation we encounter in our life are already somewhere depicted in Mahabharata. So here up till now we have seen that first Dhritarashtra said what he wanted to say. And we now know that his world is divided into mind and Pandavas.

That's how he saw the world. Then we have seen Sanjay narrating what's happening in the battlefield. Sanjay was the most loyal advisor to Dhritarashtra. He will obviously will never go against Dhritarashtra or anything that will hurt Dhritarashtra. As we know from Mahabharata that even when Dhritarashtra left for the forest after Mahabharata the war Sanjay went with him. He was there till they were caught into the forest fire.

And I think Dhritarashtra asked him to leave. So he leaves and saves himself. But Dhritarashtra and Gandhari decided they are not going to leave. So he was there till the end of his life. But the Sanjay was not the yes man. As somebody said if you hire the next guy don't hire a yes man, you will be in trouble.

So Sanjay was a loyal advisor but not a yes man. So therefore he gave the narration of what's happening as he saw. So as we have seen the first he says how the Duryodhan acted in that situation. He wasn't all confident. He was evaluating what is the strength of each armies whether it's good enough or not good enough. And then we have seen that Bhishma declared the war and Pandavas responded.

But the leader of the Pandavas responding was not one of the General but Madhava himself. The Krishna himself responded first. Krishna had already decided there is no other way but to fight this war to settle the score. So Krishna responded and all Pandavas followed enthusiastically. So you can see that the Pandavas are enthusiastic and confident about their own ability and in their cause. It also gives us an indication.

As long as you are sure about the cause of your pursuits you will be confident. And then we have seen the reaction from Gaurava's side which Sanjay narrates. It's not that we are adding anything here but he never said anything about what happened in the Pandavas side. He only said what's happened on the Dhritarashtra side. And he said this great sound which reverberated between the earth and the sky made the hearts of the people in Dhritarashtra army shiver. He didn't say that for the Pandavas.

Giving indication that if you're not sure about your cause any obstacle will make you unsettled. You will not be then sure about whether this is the right thing to do or not. On Pandava's side Sanjay has not given that indication. He saw only the enthusiastic response to Bismar's call for the war. So we can take few takeaways from here. As long as you're sure about your pursuits no matter what the obstacle would be you will be confident about it and you will pursue your path towards your goal.

If you're not sure even the smallest obstacle will make you rethink Whether it's the right thing to do, am I really putting my energy in the right place? Will I be able to win this situation? Bhagavan Ved Vyas through Sanjaya's narration is painting this picture of how things work. When we are facing this battle of life, after everyone has expressed their opinion by blowing their own conch, then in life each one has to have their own opinion. No matter what other people have said. Sankaan Dadmohu Prathak Prithak each one has to say I support it, I support it or I don't support it.

So one who is not saying anything, we know that he's in the fence. But each one gave their own opinion that I support this pursuit. On Pandava's side we are not seeing that on Kaurava's side Sanjay wants to give the correct report to Dhritarashtra because he is the king. And maybe Bhagavan Ved Vyas had a little bias because Bhagawan Ved Vyas in the beginning wanted to stop this war by convincing Dhritarashtra and the last ditch efforts. But it obviously did not work. So with that Sagoso Dhartra Rashtranam Rudhyani Vridharayat Nabhastrimim Cha Eva Tumuloho Vyanunadayan that sound which reverberated between the sky and the earth made the hearts of the Dhritarashtra army.

Shiva Athavt Vyabasthitan Dristva Dharatra Rastra and Kapid Dhvajah Pravrute Sastra Sampate Dhanuhu Udyamya Pandavah. Sanjay now focuses on Arjuna. We have learned from Mahabharata. Sanjay had this unique vision that not only he can see things, but he can also read people's minds and he can see even things in this. In fact I had read some, even though I have not read Mahabharata that before this war starts, the Sanjaya's vision was tested by the Bhagavan Vedvyasa Dhritarashtra one of them where Sanjay describes the distant land which he had never visited before and the people and the culture and all the fauna and flora of the land. So he had this great ability to see things which are not within his normal perception.

So now he's focusing on Arjuna saying what is Arjuna doing? What he's saying Thus having seen the army of Kaurava arranged in formation Kapid Dvajah. His chariot was called Kapid Dvaja. His emblem on his Flag was Hanuman. Hanuman was very devoted to Bhagavan Ramachandra. Therefore he said, in any age, at any time, where there is Rama, I will be there.

Krishna being Rama's incarnation, Hanman is always there when Krishna is fighting a battle. Arjuna's chariot is called Kapidwaja. Thus, having seen the Kavurava's army now arraigned in formation, Pravrutti Sastra Sampa de All the weapons are ready to be charged Now Dhanuhu Udhyyamya, he picked up his bow, so now he's getting ready. Here Sanjay addresses Dhritarashtra as Mahipate, O Lord of the Earth. Having seen that Arjuna said this to Rishikesha Krishna. Now Arjuna Vacha, anytime somebody speaks or opens his mouth, we know what's going on in his mind.

That's why we have this fear of public speaking. Because as long as I keep my mouth shut, you don't know what's going on. Am I a Democrat or Republican or Independent as soon as I open my mouth. But these days you can also see what channel he's watching. You are saying MSNBC or Fox Channel. So up till now Arjun has not said anything.

He just blew his conch. So we know he is very confident, he is very enthusiastic. I wouldn't call him arrogant, I would call him very confident in his pursuit, in what he is going to do and his ability. He picks up his bow, Ready, I am ready and capable. And then he said, arjuna vacha senayoho ubayoho madhya Ratham stapaya me Achuta O Achyta, Locate this chariot in the midst of the two armies, right in the middle of the two armies. But he addresses Krishna Achita, one who never wavers from his position.

Swamiji reminds us here that this is the iconic image we have of Krishna and Arjuna in the chariot. And this reminds people who are students of Upanishads, the parable of Ratha in Katha Upanishad, that this body is the chariot and the atma is the rider. And this Buddhi is the charioteer. The mind is the reins and the senses are the horses. And the sense objects pave the path for the chariot to move. The sense objects create the path, senses are running on that path, mind is the rain.

But in the hands of Buddhi, along with this senses, the rider becomes the enjoyer of the ego. So ego is the rider and the senses are drawing this chariot towards the sense objects. And as long as that Buddhi is pure and in control. The chariot will be in control. If the Buddhi is not purified, it will let the senses go in the wrong direction. So here Arjuna tells Krishna that put my chariot right in the middle of the two armies.

Because Yavat etan nirikshay Aham Yudhu Kaman Avasthita Kairmaya Saha Yudhavyam Asmin Rana Samudya. Because I want to see who are desirous to fight in this battle. I want to make sure that I know whom I am fighting. It's basically a due diligence. Anytime we have to go for an interview, the first thing might Neil, did you find out who are we competing against? I said I never asked that question because half the time they don't give that answer.

But we are very curious to see who we are competing against. I'm sure Arjuna knew, but he wanted to make sure. Let's see the very first day who are there? Dhartra Rashtra Se Durbudehe Yudde Priya Chikir Savah. I want to see those who are assembled here to fight, wishing to please in the battle. The evil minded son of Dhritarashtra.

We now see the Arjuna state of mind, very confident and he has great animosity toward Duryodhana. He evil minded son of Duryodhan. He also knows that the people who are there not because they're fighting a righteous battle, they just want to please Duryodhana. That's why they are there. Because Duryodhana has the power. He is the person who is in charge of the entire empire.

And they want to be in his good grace, in his good books. And therefore they are there. So let me see who those people are which I'll be fighting. It's basically as simple as that. What we have seen so far.

सञ्जय उवाच |
snippets.transliteration:
yāvadetānnirikṣe.ahaṃ yoddhukāmānavasthitān .

yotsyamānānavekṣe.ahaṃ ya ete.atra samāgatāḥ .

sañjaya uvāca .
verseTranslations:
Arjuna said  In the middle between the two armies, place my chariot,
O krishna, so that I may behold those who stand here desirous to fight,
and know with whom I must fight, when the battle is about to commence.

For I desire to observe those who are assembled here to fight,
wishing to please in battle the evil-minded Duryodhana (the son of Dhritarashtra).

Sanjaya said  Thus addressed by Arjuna, Krishna, having stationed that
best of chariots, O Dhritarashtra, in the midst of the two armies.
snippets.commentary:

So so far we have seen that Sanjay has given us the narration of what's happening, what's happening in the palace, also what's happening at the Kurukshetra in the battlefield. He's basically giving us the mental status of each main character in this conflict. We've seen Dhritarashtra first, then we have seen Duryodhana, then we have seen Arjuna. And then we have also seen that Arjuna told Krishna that Take my chariot and place it in the middle of the two armies. So what we have seen so far is both Arjuna and Duryodhana are having strong egos.

One had negative qualities associated with the ego, others positive qualities associated with the ego. That's the only difference. Therefore we see Arjuna commanding or giving order to Krishna, saying place my chariot in the middle of the two armies. How do you know that the Arjuna had a big ego? But we also seen in Mahabharata Arjuna was the one who objected to compete with Karna. He says Sutaputra I will not compete with him.

When they had this competition, that's what Duryodhan gave Karna kingdom of Angadish. So he became Angaraj Because Duryodhan see an opportunity having someone equivalent to Karna Arjuna in his own side. That's how Arkarna became Duryodhana's best friend. Yotsamana avekhse aham. I want to see ya eta itra sama Gataha the people who are gathered here. Dhartra rashtra syedurbuddehe yudde priyachi kir savah.

Those who are gathered here just to please this evil minded Duryodhana. The very words shows his anger, hatred and his own ego. At this point he sees the army on the other side is one homogeneous mass of evil. Because their leader is evil, Duryodhana is evil and all who are gathered on that side are just there to please Duryodhana there is no other motive. Arjuna can see this is the entire army. On the other side is nothing but people with evil intentions.

They are either themselves an evil or they're just supporting evil for whatever the personal gain or whatever the personal opinion. And now we hear from Sanjay. He gives a very unbiased commentary. He is a commentator just like our news. People claim that all always give is the news. We are not news ourselves.

We are not putting our coloring. Sanjaya, Vaacha, Evam, Uktva, Hrushikeshah, Guda, Keshena. This is what told by Arjuna to Hrishikesha. Hrishikesha is the one who has the control of the senses. That's one interpretation. Other is the one who has the short hair Gudakesha, one who has the control over sleep on his conquered sleep.

Swamiji says that there is no real proof in Mahabharata in Arjuna's biography that he has conquered sleep. The Western scholars said they won with the hair in bundles. Hair in style bundles. Obviously in India we have not seen that hairstyle. But here we can see the African Americans have hair in bundles. So it's possible that Vedvyas Bhagavan is just saying what they look like and not have this deeper meaning.

We have a tendency to find deeper meaning in everything we see in our scriptures. In my first year of architecture there will be simple tasks like design a handle for a window or a doorknob. And then we obviously have very complicated design because otherwise how are you going to impress your teacher? So we have tendency to complicate things and see things in a way that it seems so deep in. It is possible that Bhagawan Vidvya said this is how these two people look. So having spoken by Arjuna to Krishna.

Oh, Bharata Bharada here is addressed to Dhritarashtra because he was the king of Bharatkand. It has been said that Kuru dynasty was the first to organize the society in a statewide society. So Bharata, you are the king of this Bharat Khan Senayoho Ubhayoho Madhya Sapayitva Rathautamam. So we have the confirmation from Sanjay that Krishna followed the order thus ordered by Arjuna. Krishna placed the chariot in the middle of the two armies. Bisma Drona, Pramukhataha, Sarve Samcha, Mahikshitam, Vacha Partha Pasheta, Samavetaan, Kurunithi.

He put it right in front of Bhishma in Drona. He could have put right in front of Duryodhana. And then he said the first sentence uttered by Krishna in Bhagavad Gita. The only time we hear indirectly from Sanjay, otherwise we hear his direct words Sirik Bhagavan, O Vacha. But his Sanjay says what Krishna said to Arjuna. Pasheta, make sure you see all the gurus who are gathered here.

Look at Vishwa and Drona and other kings, but also see all the gurus gathered here. Because what was Arjuna's intention? He just wanted to see who are against him. He wanted to see who are gathered here to please this evil Duryodhana. He very clearly said, that's all I want to see. I want to make sure that I understand who I'm fighting with.

Therefore Krishna put him right in front of the Bhishma Dranada. It's not the homogeneous mass of evil that you're facing that once you wipe out that evil, things will be just well and good. There won't be any problems, no side effects. Everything will be just good. So this is how we also save the world. We think that if we eradicate the evil from this world, well, we have learnt in last few years, eradicating anything doesn't solve anything unless the cause for the evil is eradicated.

Just eradicating the other side completely will not solve the problem. It may create more problems, but you have to be prepared for that. You should know what you are dealing with. Therefore he put Arjuna's cherry right in the Bhishma and Drona because they are clearly not part of evil. But the more important he said, see all the Kurus who are gathered here. Arjuna himself was a Kuru.

He was the descendant of the Kuru dynasty. Both Gauravas and Pandavas are descendants of Kurt dynasty. Up till now we have heard Arjuna referring to Kaurava as Dhartrastranam, Dhritarashtra's sons. His animosity was against Dhritarashtra's son, not against Kuru. Therefore, in the previous time when Arjuna has fought with even Bhishma, there was not really big problem. Basically protecting Virat's kingdom and he fought with Bheeshma.

He didn't have any problem fighting with Bheeshma before. Obviously he didn't try to kill him, but we couldn't kill him anyway. But this time Krishna says, look at all the Kurus. Don't only look at Dhrutrastra's putra. He gives him instruction indirectly. Make sure that you are aware that all your family members are involved on both sides in the next two verses.

Tatra apasyat, sthitan, parthah, pitru, Nathaha, pita, Mahan, acharya, matulan, bhrartran, putran, patran, sakimsthata. So now he is obviously observing on both sides that he doesn't see just the evil and good divided by the line. This is what we do in our life. We divide this world of liking and disliking with an imaginary line in my mind that if I can avoid this which I don't like, the world will be nothing. My life will be nothing but pure happiness. Well, we tend to forget that those are intertwined with each other.

The world which I like and world which I don't like, they intertwined with each other. So some of us in elections are party line voters because we clearly see that this side is a side of good, that side is side of not so good. It's only when you find out that the world is not as clearly divided into good and evil as we like to think. In our childhood we had it's very simple who are bad people, who are good people, cowboys and Indians. But world is not like that. Krishna wants to make sure the Arjuna understands that.

There is also another implication which we heard from lots of commentators that as we have seen that Arjuna's words indicate he has a big ego. Big ego doesn't mean the person is necessarily bad. Good people have big egos. Artists have big egos, architects have big egos. It's actually said in our profession, unless there are any Gita, it's generally said in our profession that you can't have two architects in the same room. Their egos are so big that no room in this world is large enough to contain two egos of the two architects at the same time.

I learned hard way that when we collaborate with other firms, two architects collaborate with each other and it's a lesson in humility. I was fortunate enough to get this lesson very early on in my career when I came here. So when I was in Dallas, when I first came and working with a very large firm, WZMH somewhat specialized in high rise. And we were collaborating IM Pei, an international architect and he was a design architect. WZMH was just basically an architect of record. So I asked my boss, I said Mark, we are capable to design this project and we had the relationship with the developer, why do we have to bring in Im Pei in the mix?

And he said, Neil, 100% of zero is still zero. If you want the whole enchilada, but you're not going to get it. He said you didn't get anything. Is it better to have a portion of an enchilada to devise a situation where at least you have a portion of the pie? So by myself I won't get that project. By themselves, they won't get the project.

Well, let's compromise and say look, we can share this and we have to control our ego. If we share this, then we both get something out of it. So the people with big egos are bipolar in nature. So they go from supreme courage to complete vulnerability in one moment. If they see the world from this side, they will be very courageous. And when they see the competition, they see their own shortcoming.

They will break down very easily. So Krishna saw that Arjuna is overconfident. He thinks he's the best archer in the world. He has fought Bismar before. He has done all these people. There is nothing which can stop me from wiping out this sea of evil which I see in front of me.

But he had to be brought to his senses and brought to humility so that he is really prepared to fight this war. So Krishna said, now look at the Bisma, Drona, all other kings and all the crews, all the Kurus include all the people on his side as well. Now Arjuna sees all the people and individually recognize what his relationship with them. Tatra, Apasyat, Parthaha, Pitrunatha, fatherly relatives, Pita Mahan, also grandfatherly relatives, Acharyan, teachers, Mathulan, maternal relatives, Bratan, Putran, Pautran, Sakimstatha. Both sides he says people who are like his sons and also his grandsons, friends, Tatha, Swasuran, Sruhada, Chaeeva, also in laws, the people who are close to you. Now we have confirmation then not only he looked at the Kaurava's army, he also looked at Pandava's army.

He saw all the people who are dear to him, close to him, related to him. There is no indication he sees evil here. He didn't say oh, I also see Duryodhani. All he saw is the people who are related to him, were closer to him, were dear to him. And therefore he says Krupaya Pariya Vishtaha, Visidantam Idam Abravit. He thus sorrowfully filled with deep pity said this Swamiji says that Sanjay is actually generous in calling him as a deep pity Swamiji actually says that he may be broken down by his own insecurities.

Now he realized that the world is not divided into evil and good, but a mixture of both on all sides. Things which we consider evil and lots of good in it and things we consider good has some evil in it.
snippets.reflection:
Consider a situation in your own life where you face conflicting duties—where doing right by one person or principle seems to require doing wrong by another. The Gita doesn't offer easy answers to such dilemmas, but it invites us to face them honestly rather than avoiding them.

Today, notice if there's something you're choosing not to see because the truth would be uncomfortable. Dhritarashtra's tragedy wasn't his blindness—it was his refusal of sight when it was offered. What truths are you avoiding? What would happen if you faced them directly?

The battlefield isn't just Kurukshetra. It's wherever you are right now, facing whatever you're facing. And the question the Gita asks is the same one Dhritarashtra asked: What will you do?

snippets.title: Day 10: Arjuna's Despair Begins
snippets.sanskrit:
कृपया परयाविष्टो विषीदन्निदमब्रवीत् |

सीदन्ति मम गात्राणि मुखं च परिशुष्यति |

गाण्डीवं स्रंसते हस्तात्त्वक्चैव परिदह्यते |
snippets.transliteration:
kṛpayā parayāviṣṭo viṣīdannidamabravīt .

sīdanti mama gātrāṇi mukhaṃ ca pariśuṣyati .

gāṇḍīvaṃ sraṃsate hastāttvakcaiva paridahyate .
verseTranslations: Arjuna said  Seeing these, my kinsmen, O krishna, arrayed, eager to fight.

My limbs fail and my mouth is parched, my body ivers and
my hair stands on end.

The (bow) Gandiva slips from my hand, and also my skins burns
all over; I am unable even to stand and my mind is reeling, as it were.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter one, Arjuna Vishada Yoga, Yoga of Arjuna's Grief. So we had been seeing various characters involved in this Mahabharata. It reminds me of something I had read somewhere in our scriptural literature which says Yat Pinde Tat Brahmande. That which is at this microcosm is at the macrocosm. If I find something in me, I'll be able to find in the cosmos. The master plan for the microcosm and macrocosm is just one and the same.

So if I find something in macrocosm, I should also be able to find in microcosm, at my individual level, the efficient cause and material cause for the universe. The same efficient cause and material cause for me. Therefore, if I can observe something in the universe, I can also apply that to my own life. Something similar is being said for Mahabharata. As we have discussed before, Mahabharata contains all human situations and characters. So if I find a character in Mahabharata, and if I introspect very carefully, I'll find that character in me too, in my own personality.

Let me find Dhritarashtra in me. Blinded by attachment to his children, he cannot see what is right and wrong when it comes to his children. I can also probably find Duryodhana in me. That Duryodhana, he wanted to keep something which came accidentally to him, but he now doesn't want to give it up. Many Internet millionaires in late 90s and early 2000s, what they went through afterwards, actually know one person in particular who made millions in this technology. And once he got out of that, he made all his efforts to retain that and failed miserably.

That's Duryodhana, Nina. Something came to us accidentally, but I don't want to give it up. We also want Bhishma in US who is very rigidly following the rules but ignoring the principles. When it comes to paying taxes, we are more like Bhishma. If I can find that I meet the IRS criteria in not paying any taxes, even though I am A multi billion dollar corporation, that's perfectly legal. But I completely forget the principle of paying taxes.

It's for the social welfare. If I don't pay anything, I'm not contributing anything to the social welfare. So I may find Bhishma in me who is rigidly following the rules but forgetting the principles. I may find Arjuna in me who is very keen on overcoming the obstacles which are in his path of his happiness, what we think is rightfully his. He wants to get over those obstacles. In this case, Duryodhana.

Duryodhana is in his path of finding that happiness, of getting that kingdom back. We have all enthusiasm to march forward towards our success. And if there is anything in our way, going to get rid of it. But we hope that we also find Krishna in us who says, well, look at it comprehensively. So Krishna said, look at all these people. All the Kurus are gathered here not only on the other side, but also on your side.

The Kurus on your side too. Look at them basically reminding, look at the situation, what you're trying to achieve. How many people have to make what kind of sacrifices for you to achieve your own goal? In our enthusiasm to achieve success and move forward in our life, we completely forget how many people are making sacrifices for us on our own side. From our family, from your friends, from your relative. Lots of people have to do a lot of things so that I can move forward in my life.
