snippets.title: Day 12: The Sin of Killing
snippets.sanskrit:
आचार्याः पितरः पुत्रास्तथैव च पितामहाः |

एतान्न हन्तुमिच्छामि घ्नतोऽपि मधुसूदन |

निहत्य धार्तराष्ट्रान्नः का प्रीतिः स्याज्जनार्दन |
snippets.transliteration:
ācāryāḥ pitaraḥ putrāstathaiva ca pitāmahāḥ .

etānna hantumicchāmi ghnato.api madhusūdana .

nihatya dhārtarāṣṭrānnaḥ kā prītiḥ syājjanārdana .
verseTranslations:
Teachers, fathers, sons and also grandfathers, maternal uncles,
fathers-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law and other relatives,-

These I do not wish to kill, though they kill me, O Krishna,
even for the sake of dominion over the three worlds; leave alone killing
them for the sake of the earth.

By killing these sons of Dhritarashtra, what pleasure can
be ours, O Janardana? Only sin will accrue to us from killing these felons.
snippets.commentary:
The Dhritarashtra asked the question, what's happening in the Dharmakshetra Kurukshetra and what Main and Pandavad are doing? Duryodhana's perspective he was insecure. Even though he had the largest army, he cannot take the winning for granted. Then we have seen Arjuna's request to Krishna to put chariot in the middle of the army. And then we have seen that once Krishna did that. Krishna just said, look at Bheeshma, Drona, all the Kauravas gathered here, ready to fight.

Most of the time we focus on what we are trying to achieve in life. And then when we achieve that, we take all the credit to ourselves. We tend to forget that there are lots of people have to make lots of sacrifices for us to get to that point. So basically the Krishna's message to Arjuna is look at how many people are here to support your cause. Make sure that you acknowledge that, that it's not you who will be capable of winning this war. Arjuna always thought that he can win this war.

He has won it before. You know, he went to fight with Drupada for Drona and earned half his kingdom for Drona. He fought with Gandharvas when they captured Duryodhana. And he also fought Kaurava's army when they attacked Virata's kingdom. And he has won all the time. He has not learned yet what failure is in his life.

So he had his own opinion about what his capabilities are and what he can do. But when he sees both sides, he sees the enormity of the task. That is not as simple as just winning the battle against enemies. Now you are fighting among your own people, in the people who are as capable of himself, Bheeshma and Drona and all other people, Karna and. And he sees that on his side also all his family members are there to help him. That creates confusion in his mind.

So we have seen last few verses that he first had this nervous breakdown. What am I doing here? Is this the right thing to do? Is it really worth fighting this war. And finally he has the delusion about what the situation is all about. So then he obviously starts describing what he's feeling.

So first he said, I can't even stand my body shivering. I can't even hold my Gandiva. The Gandiva is slipping away from my hand. All the physical symptoms of person who is having nervous breakdown. But now he's describing what he thinks the reality is a delusion. Person sees reality as if he's seeing in a dream, an alternate reality.

Other people see reality one way but the person is under delusion. He sees reality differently. He starts describing his reality very differently. The first thing he says, Nimitta ni che pasyami vi paritha ni keshava nacha shreyo anupashyami hatva sajanam ahave. Nothing good is going to come out of this war. I now see that something wrong is happening here.

So we can see now he is having a superstition. My left eye is fluttering. So that's not good, right? I had a surgery on Thursday. We were getting ready and Meena was boiling milk. Now obviously you know what we consider bad omen?

So Mina was very careful. She was standing right in front of the milk and I didn't even know any of that. But I'm just sitting there. And then for one second she turned around to, to wash a cup or something and the milk spilled and she literally screamed, you know, I don't. I said, what happened? I thought that something really bad had really happened.

So I got up from the chair and said, what's happened? That's just the milk. I thought, oh, that's okay. I didn't want this to happen. So I realized inside what's bothering her because we were already double minded going for a surgery because my vision was relatively okay. But doctor said your lens has come loose and it can fall anytime.

So it's good to get it done. I say you can do it whenever you feel like, but it's not going anywhere. But still, like your camera lens is loose. We decided, well, let's get it over with. And I realized what is bothering her, that we are going for surgery and he's a bad omen. So I didn't say a word because I knew what she was bothering her.

But I didn't discuss that because I knew if I discuss that, it will go even further back if I try to say, don't worry, I don't believe in that. Let's even make it worse. I have not Discussed that with her. But I could see clearly what she was worried about. So whenever mind is not seeing the reality clear, then it's a simple milk boiling over. It works as described in physics books.

But we don't see it that way. It's not the laws of physics now we are worried about. We're worried about some metaphysical rules of how things work in this world. So Arjuna now is not seeing reality as is. He said, I'm not seeing. I think logically I come to this country simply.

I just see bad omens. So that's the sign of a delusion. And then he says, Nakank se Vijayam Krishna Nacharajyam Sukha nicha kim no Rajya na Govinda kim bhogi jeevte Nava. I desire no victory, O Krishna. I don't own the kingdom Na Sukhani. I don't any comforts.

What is the purpose of having all this domain to us? Govinda Isham arthe kanksitam nah Rajyam Bhogaha Sukha nicha ta IME Avasthita Yudhte pranam tyaktva Dhananicha. For whom we desire this kingdom and comforts for our own people. Every parent says that we have done this for our children. Nobody said I did it for myself. This is for whom we desire this kingdom and this comfort and all the prosperity.

They are standing here to fight this war. Acharyaha, Pitaraha, Putraha, Tatha, Ivach, Pita Mah. My teachers, my fatherly relatives. Matulaha, Swasuraha, Pautraha, Shyalaha, Samandinisthada. My sons, grandfathers, maternal relatives, Swasuraha in laws, Potraha. My grandchildren, Sialaha in laws again, Sabandin and all other relatives.

Etan ichami Gnatoapi Madhusudana. I do not desire to kill them. Even if I get killed, Even if I get the domain over all three worlds. Some of Puranas describe three worlds. Swargalok, Mrityulok and Patal Lok Mrityulog. Because we are all mortals, things are impermanent.

In Mrityulog, Swargalok, everything is always pristine and serene. Patalok is beyond our world. More like past, present and future. So even if I have the domain of all three worlds, it's not worth it to kill my own people. Then what is the point in fighting for a little piece of Land, this little kingdom on this earth, in this mortal world. So he made his statement very clear.

Now, if these words were his own, after reflection on the situation over a period of time and very intense contemplation, whether this is right or that's right, then he comes to this conclusion. These are very noble words for whom we are desiring all this. If these people are not going to benefit, or these people have to make sacrifice, it's not worth it. But we know that he did not do that before, because just before Bheeshma Parva, there's Udayoga Parva. Bheesma Parva starts when the war starts. The efforts both sides made to avoid this war.

Drupada sends his Brahmin diplomat to go and negotiate it out. Look, this war is not worth. So Drupada's emissary goes to Dhritarashtra's court and makes the argument why it is best for everybody to divide this kingdom into half as it was before, give Pandavas theirs. This enough for both of you to enjoy these kingdoms. Dhritarashtra was pretty much convinced that that's the right thing to do. Bhishma had given his advice that to avoid this war, this is the only way.

Karna interrupted Bhma and said no. Yudhishthira lost his kingdom in this game of dice. Now if he wants this kingdom back, he has to beg. There is no settlement. And Visma actually told Karna that if you don't listen to what the guy just say and don't agree to it, you'll end up in a war. And that's not going to be any good for anybody.

So there are two characters here who are against settlement, Duryodhana and Karna. Karna had his own agenda. He had no interest in who wins this war. You know, his agenda was he wanted to prove he's better than Arjuna. If this war does not occur, Karna had no chance to prove that he is better than Arjuna. So he has his own agenda.

So then I can prove myself that Arjuna is not the best archer in the world. I am the best archer in the world. Then Dhritarashtra sends Sanjaya to Yudhishthira to have his side of proposal for settlement. And that proposal was very simple. War is not good for anybody. Exactly the words which you are hearing from Arjuna.

So Sanjaya made his case. I'm here on behalf of King Dhritarashtra. King is reminding you that my children are spoiled. They are not listening to me. What they are doing is not right. However, you people are good people.

You should know what is right and wrong. It's like two children fighting in a family. You also don't understand being an older one. Exact same message to the Yudhishthira that you are. Dharmaraj, how can you engage in this Adharma of fighting a war against your own cousins? Arjun at the time said give Duryodhan a message that Keshav and I will kill you, the evil Dury and all evil cousins.

Even Indra's army cannot defeat when Krishna and I are together. And he said my Gandiva is twitching, arrows are peeping out of cleaver. So he basically said I'm so anxious. But Dhritarashtra plants the seeds that the war is never good. The result of any war is nothing but hell whether you win the war or lose the war. So the ideas presented were logical.

When you look at it from a very narrow perspective. So here the words which are hearing from Arjuna are literally borrowed from Sanjaya's message, then there is no good coming out of it. Swamiji points out here that this is a case of a rift between your Buddhi and your mind. Buddhi is your subjective mind. This buddhi is available when I'm thinking very rationally and seeking Buddhist guidance. He's already demonstrated that he lost all control over his mind.

So this subjective mind, which is buddhi, an objective mind, objective mind is simply receiving information from outside and trying to interpret. But it does not have much experience. So it has to rely on a Buddha to decide whether this situation is what it is all about and how to react to the situation. So here Arjuna is now one side. He is torn between his desire to win over Duryodhana, set the record straight and get what is rightful his because he's capable of doing so. The other side, he now remembers that everything Sanjaya said is true.

They're all standing right in front of me and I have to fight them and I have to kill them. They may get killed, my people may get killed. But in the end the winning or losing may not mean anything because we have lost our own people. So right now what we are seeing is confusion created by Dhritarashtra. Like the argument we hear recently in our impeachment. Some Republican senators or congressmen said whatever Trump did is not right, but it is not worth impeaching.

We should be sorting this out internally. Dhritarasa sent the same message through Sanjaya. Whatever Duryodhana is doing is not right. But if you people are wise enough.
snippets.reflection:
Consider a situation in your own life where you face conflicting duties—where doing right by one person or principle seems to require doing wrong by another. The Gita doesn't offer easy answers to such dilemmas, but it invites us to face them honestly rather than avoiding them.

Today, notice if there's something you're choosing not to see because the truth would be uncomfortable. Dhritarashtra's tragedy wasn't his blindness—it was his refusal of sight when it was offered. What truths are you avoiding? What would happen if you faced them directly?

The battlefield isn't just Kurukshetra. It's wherever you are right now, facing whatever you're facing. And the question the Gita asks is the same one Dhritarashtra asked: What will you do?

snippets.title: Day 13: Better to Die Unarmed
snippets.sanskrit:
तस्मान्नार्हा वयं हन्तुं धार्तराष्ट्रान्स्वबान्धवान् |
स्वजनं हि कथं हत्वा सुखिनः स्याम माधव ||१-३७||

यद्यप्येते न पश्यन्ति लोभोपहतचेतसः |
कुलक्षयकृतं दोषं मित्रद्रोहे च पातकम् ||१-३८||

कथं न ज्ञेयमस्माभिः पापादस्मान्निवर्तितुम् |
कुलक्षयकृतं दोषं प्रपश्यद्भिर्जनार्दन ||१-३९||
snippets.transliteration:
tasmānnārhā vayaṃ hantuṃ dhārtarāṣṭrānsvabāndhavān |

yadyapyete na paśyanti lobhopahatacetasaḥ |

kathaṃ na jñeyamasmābhiḥ pāpādasmānnivartitum |
verseTranslations: "Therefore, we should not kill the sons of Dhritarashtra, our relatives; for how can we be happy by killing our own people, O Madhava (Krishna)?"
"Though they, with intelligence overpowered by greed, see no evil in the destruction of families, and no sin in hostility to friends,"
"Why should not we who clearly see evil in the destruction of families, learn to turn away from this sin, O Janardana (Krishna)?"
snippets.commentary:
These three verses capture one of the most psychologically acute moments in the entire Gita. Arjuna has moved from describing the horror of what he's about to do to making what seems like a perfectly reasonable moral argument. And this is where things get interesting.

Look at the progression of his thinking: In verse 37, he appeals to Krishna as "Madhava"—a name that emphasizes Krishna's divine nature. He's essentially saying, "You're the Supreme Lord. Surely you understand that killing one's own people cannot lead to happiness." It's a clever move. He's not just expressing despair anymore; he's constructing an argument.

And then comes verse 38, where Arjuna reveals something fascinating about how he sees his opponents. He says that *they*—Duryodhana and his party—are blinded by greed. Their minds are clouded. They cannot see the sin they're committing by destroying families and betraying friends. In other words, they have an excuse: ignorance.

But verse 39 delivers the real punch. Arjuna says: We can see clearly. We understand exactly what's wrong with this situation. And precisely because we see clearly, we have a greater responsibility to turn away from this sin.

This is where Arjuna's argument becomes both compelling and problematic.

On the surface, it makes perfect sense. If I know something is wrong and do it anyway, am I not more culpable than someone who acts from ignorance? Isn't knowledge supposed to guide action? Isn't the wise person supposed to refrain from harmful acts?

Yes—and yet.

Swami Chinmayananda would often point out that Arjuna is using valid spiritual principles to arrive at an invalid conclusion. This is one of the mind's most sophisticated tricks: using dharma to justify adharma, using wisdom to rationalize avoidance, using compassion as a mask for fear.

The key word in verse 38 is *lobha*—greed. Arjuna accuses his enemies of being driven by greed. But wait. What is driving Arjuna right now? Is it pure moral clarity? Or is it something else wearing the clothes of moral clarity?

Consider: Arjuna doesn't want to lose his loved ones. He doesn't want to bear the psychological burden of having killed his grandfather, his teacher, his cousins. He doesn't want to live with that memory. These are understandable human desires. But they are, in their own way, also forms of attachment—of wanting things to be a certain way, of grasping at a particular outcome.

The Gita will spend the next seventeen chapters addressing exactly this confusion. For now, we simply need to notice it.

There's another layer to explore here. Arjuna says he can "clearly see" the evil of destroying families. But seeing clearly is precisely what he's not doing.

Here's what Arjuna is not seeing: He's not seeing that this war has been coming for decades. He's not seeing that every peaceful option was exhausted. He's not seeing that Duryodhana rejected every compromise, every appeal to justice, every opportunity for reconciliation. He's not seeing that sometimes standing up to adharma requires actions that are painful.

Most importantly, he's not seeing himself clearly. He thinks he's being noble. He thinks refusing to fight is the ethical choice. But mixed into his reasoning are threads of fear, attachment, and confusion that he can't distinguish from his genuine moral concerns.

This is the human condition. We rarely have pure motives. Our noblest intentions are intertwined with our fears and desires. The person who refuses to have a difficult conversation "to keep the peace" may genuinely care about peace—and may also be afraid of conflict. The person who "doesn't want to hurt anyone" may be compassionate—and may also be avoiding the discomfort of standing firm.

Arjuna is not a villain. He's not being dishonest. He is genuinely confused. And that's the point. The Gita takes seriously the fact that confusion can feel like clarity, that attachment can dress itself up as wisdom.

There's a beautiful irony in verse 39 that often goes unnoticed. Arjuna asks: "Why should we not learn to turn away from this sin?"

Learn. He uses the word *jñeya*—that which should be known, that which should be learned.

But learning is exactly what's about to happen. Krishna is going to teach him. The next seventeen chapters are Arjuna's education. And what will he learn? Not that killing is good. Not that compassion doesn't matter. But that his understanding of the situation is incomplete, that his identification of what constitutes sin and virtue is confused, that his notion of who he is and what he's doing needs to be fundamentally revised.

The great teaching is coming. But it can only come because Arjuna asked for it—even though he didn't know he was asking. His anguish, his paralysis, his philosophical objections—all of these created the opening through which wisdom could enter.

In verse 7 of Chapter 2, Arjuna will formally ask Krishna to teach him. But in a sense, the request is already implicit here. A mind that is questioning, struggling, refusing to act from blind obedience—this is a mind that is ready to learn.

Let's also notice how Arjuna addresses Krishna in these verses. In verse 37, he says "Madhava"—emphasizing Krishna's divine descent through the Madhu lineage. In verse 39, he says "Janardana"—a name meaning "one who causes people to tremble" or more positively "one who answers the prayers of people."

These names reveal something about Arjuna's state. He's appealing to Krishna's divinity, his power, his role as the one who responds to devotees' prayers. On some level, Arjuna knows that what he needs right now is not just practical advice but divine guidance. He may think he wants Krishna to validate his choice not to fight. But deeper down, he's calling out to the divine for rescue from his own confusion.

Every sincere prayer is like this. We think we know what we want. We think we're asking for something specific. But underneath the specific request is a more fundamental cry: Help me. Show me. I am lost.

These verses also touch on one of life's most difficult truths: the fact that others' wrongdoing does not excuse us from our own responsibilities.

Arjuna says, in effect: "They are blinded by greed. They don't see clearly. Therefore they can be excused for their actions. But we see clearly—so we should act accordingly."

The logic seems impeccable. But here's the problem: In a world where everyone excused themselves from difficult action by pointing to others' moral failures, nothing would ever get done. Evil would flourish unchecked, protected by the scruples of good people who didn't want to dirty their hands.

This is one of the oldest moral debates in human history. How do we respond to wrongdoing? Is it better to remain pure and let evil triumph? Or to engage with the messy, morally ambiguous work of opposing it?

The Gita's answer will be nuanced. It won't simply say "fight" or "don't fight." It will reframe the entire question by introducing the concept of *nishkama karma*—action without attachment to results. It will distinguish between the action itself and the ego that claims ownership of the action. It will show that the real sin is not in acting but in acting from a place of ego, attachment, and delusion.

But we're not there yet. Right now, we're sitting with Arjuna in his confusion. And perhaps that's where we need to start—acknowledging our own confusion, our own mixed motives, our own sophisticated rationalizations. Before we can receive the teaching, we have to feel the weight of not knowing.

There's something else worth exploring in these verses—the concept of *sukha*, happiness. In verse 37, Arjuna asks: "How can we be happy by killing our own people?"

It's a reasonable question. And it points to something fundamental about how most of us think about ethics and action. We tend to evaluate our choices based on whether they will make us happy or unhappy. Will this bring me peace? Will I be able to live with myself?

But the Gita is going to challenge this entire framework. Krishna will eventually teach that true happiness—*ananda*—doesn't depend on external circumstances at all. It doesn't come from the results of our actions, whether pleasant or painful. It comes from something deeper, something that remains constant regardless of what happens in the world.

Arjuna is worried about his future mental state. He's trying to protect his peace of mind. And from one perspective, this seems wise. But from another perspective, it reveals the problem: he's making his decision based on attachment to a particular inner state rather than based on what the situation actually requires.

This is subtle, and it's worth sitting with. We often pride ourselves on being conscientious people who care about the consequences of our actions. But sometimes that very conscientiousness becomes another form of self-centeredness—we're so focused on how we'll feel afterward that we can't see clearly what needs to be done now.

The word *kula* appears repeatedly in these verses—it means family, lineage, or clan. Arjuna speaks of *kulakshaya*, the destruction of families. This was a profound concern in the ancient world, where family lineage carried tremendous weight, where ancestral traditions were passed down through generations, where the continuity of the clan was seen as sacred.

But here's the thing: the Kauravas had already destroyed the family. Duryodhana's greed, his jealousy, his repeated attempts to murder his cousins, his public humiliation of Draupadi—all of this had already torn the fabric of the family apart. The war wasn't destroying something intact; it was the final consequence of decades of destruction that had already occurred.

Arjuna speaks as if he has a choice between preserving the family and destroying it. But that choice was made long ago, by others. What Arjuna actually faces is a different choice: whether to stand up for dharma in the aftermath of destruction, or to let adharma triumph unchallenged.

This distinction matters in our own lives too. We sometimes imagine that by withdrawing from conflict, we're preserving peace. But often, by the time we face a difficult choice, the damage has already been done by others. Our choice isn't between peace and conflict; it's between facing reality and pretending it doesn't exist.

One final observation about these verses. Notice that Arjuna is still talking. He's been making arguments for verses now—philosophical, emotional, moral arguments. He's been eloquent. He's been passionate. He's made some excellent points.

But he hasn't asked Krishna for guidance yet. Not really. He's presenting his case, building his argument, trying to convince Krishna that he's right. He's still operating from the assumption that he understands the situation and just needs validation.

The real breakthrough will come in Chapter 2, when Arjuna finally admits: "I don't know what's right. I'm confused. Please teach me." Until he reaches that point of genuine not-knowing, no teaching can enter.

This is true for all of us. As long as we're sure we're right, as long as we're building our case and making our arguments, we're not actually open to learning anything new. Wisdom requires a particular kind of humility—the willingness to admit that our current understanding might be incomplete or mistaken.

Arjuna isn't there yet. But he's getting closer. Each verse brings him nearer to the point of surrender. And that's the arc of Chapter 1: the gradual dissolution of certainty, the slow crumbling of confidence, until finally there's enough openness for something new to emerge.
snippets.reflection:
Consider a situation in your life where moral clarity seems to lead toward inaction. Where doing nothing feels like the ethical choice. Where engaging with difficulty feels like it would compromise your principles.

Now ask yourself: Is this really clarity, or might it be attachment wearing the mask of wisdom? Is there something I don't want to lose? Something I don't want to face? Something I'm afraid of?

This isn't to say that every instance of stepping back is wrong. Sometimes restraint is exactly what's called for. But the Gita invites us to examine our motives with rigorous honesty. To notice when our "principles" conveniently align with our fears. To question whether our "seeing clearly" might itself be a kind of not-seeing.

The next time you find yourself saying "I can't do that—it wouldn't be right," pause. Ask yourself: What is the "I" that can't do this? What would it cost me? What am I really protecting?

These are uncomfortable questions. But they're the questions that crack open the door to genuine wisdom. Arjuna's confusion was the beginning of his education. Yours might be too.

snippets.title: Day 14: Destruction of Family
snippets.sanskrit:
कुलक्षये प्रणश्यन्ति कुलधर्माः सनातनाः |

अधर्माभिभवात्कृष्ण प्रदुष्यन्ति कुलस्त्रियः |

सङ्करो नरकायैव कुलघ्नानां कुलस्य च |
snippets.transliteration:
kulakṣaye praṇaśyanti kuladharmāḥ sanātanāḥ .

adharmābhibhavātkṛṣṇa praduṣyanti kulastriyaḥ .

saṅkaro narakāyaiva kulaghnānāṃ kulasya ca .
verseTranslations:
In the destruction of a family, the immemorial religious
rites of that family perish; on the destruction of spirituality, impiety,
indeed, overcomes the whole family.
When irreligion spreads, the women of the house begin to stray; when they lose their purity, adulteration of the stock follows.
Promiscuity ruins both the family and those who defile it; while the souls of our ancestors droop, through lack of the funeral cakes and ablutions.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter one, Arjuna, Vishada Yoga, Yoga of Arjuna's Grief. So far in chapter one we have seen that Arjuna was very confident before declaration of the war and he was anxious to get started. But then when he decided to look at the situation in its entirety, we have seen that he started melting down. So we have seen the Arjuna's meltdown. In this chapter, by the sheer enormity of the task and the consequences of the task, we work all of our life to achieve something. Then comes a defining moment in our life.

That defining moment, how we behave will determine the outcome of what we achieve in life. Gujarat is saying that Gora Dasarana Divasejnadoda, that horse who has been preparing all year for the race which is supposed to be on Dasira day. I think in olden times he was doing very well in practice, but he doesn't run on that race day. So it's a defining moment for Arjuna. They suffered through all the cruelties and injustices and now came the time for him to fight against that. But just looking at the enormity of the task, he realized that he's not prepared for it.

So the first few scene that he breaks down in his mental attitude and then he starts justifying why this task is not for him. So the first his argument was by killing our relatives, we are going to incursion. There is no really good going to come out of this war because we are fighting against our own people. We will be fighting against our own uncles and our own teachers, our own grandparents and our in laws. So what is the point in it for whom we desire this kingdom? We work hard in our life for the people in our family.

But if those people in our family are standing against each other and they are ready to destroy each other, what is the point in gaining anything? So there was the first argument. What is the point of fighting this war to get this kingdom? Because for those for whom we are fighting this are ready here to sacrifice their own lives and everything they have on both Sides so he doesn't see really a good outcome. I see bad omen that nothing good is going to come out of it. And then he said, not only that nothing good is going to come out, but killing your own people is a sin.

Even though they are felons, even though they are criminals. So till the time he was seeing the world black and white, there was not much issue. He saw Kauravas as real people and on his side good people, there was not really much problem. He wanted to go eliminate all the evil in this world. But when he saw that evil is not pure evil and good is not pure good, this is what we face in life. Situations we encounter are not black and white.

They are not cleanly divided between good and bad. Everything in life comes with its own side effects. So any medicine you take is not purely killing the disease, but it will also kill something good in you. So the decision to take is whether the side effects are more important or curing the disease is more important. You take chemotherapy. Obviously there are side effects, but you have to to persevere the side effects to kill the disease.

So Arjuna is missing that point here. So he's trying to make his argument why this war should not be fought and let those criminals continue doing their criminal acts because they are our relatives. That was his first false argument. If there are other people not my relatives, I will have no problem getting rid of them. But because they are my relatives, I think it's a sin. Even that argument did not make much impression on Krishna.

Because he was looking for Krishna's validation that his argument is correct. We shouldn't be fighting this war. But he comes to the point that he had already made up his mind. So in verse 37 we have seen that he said tasmat, therefore we shall not fight this war. He's already made up his mind. Previously he made an argument saying I can't stand, I think I'm seeing bad omens.

But now he said, I have made up my mind, I do not want to fight this war and we should not fight. Not only I should not fight, we should not fight this war because there is nothing good is going to come out of it. Killing our people is sin. That argument did not make any impression on Krishna. So he continued in his argument saying kulakshaye pranashyanti, kuladharmaha sanatanaha. By killing these people we will be killing the family units.

By fighting this war we'll be killing the head of the family and each family. And once that head of the family is destroyed. The family will be destroyed. These people on the other side, they're not realizing this, that this is the greatest sin to destroy families. But at least we are wise enough to realize the value of family unit, and therefore we should not be committing this sin. So what we are seeing here is the social structure at the time.

The family was the unit of the society at the time. And the family was not, as we see family now, always a joint family coming from generation to generation, living together and passing on their values from one generation to another. There's always an older generation available to give guidance to the next generation and to enforce the values and the discipline on the second generation. So he said, with that lineage will be broken. Swamiji then points out here that the family unit changed it from a joint family to a couple, husband and wife. So this was Phyllis, Swamiji wrote in 50s and 60s.

In our time now, that's not a family anymore, or that's not the unit of the society anymore. The unit of the society now is an individual, therefore individual rights. What we are more concerned about in our modern time, previously we have seen a couple's rights were more important. And even today we are fighting about who is considered a couple and who gets the inheritance. But in those days, in Arjuna's time, the family unit was most important, where not one generation, but generations have lived together with each other and passed on their values. You see, when you destroy that lineage of people living together in a family, there will be disaster in the society because you're destroying the unit of the society.

And whoever is the cause for the destruction will be the greatest sinner. We know the other people are doing that, but they are ignorant people. We are not ignorant people. Therefore, we shall not engage in the same sinful act. Kulakshaye, Pranashanti, Kula, Dharma, Sanatanah. This eternal Dharma of a family, eternal means because it came from generations, from generations.

My parents did what they were taught from their parents. Their parents did what they were taught from their parents. That lineage is continuing, and I have a responsibility to pass it on to my next generation. That's called Eternal Kuladharma, that in our family we only do things this way. Dharme, Naste, Kulam, Krishnam, Dharmo, abhi, Bhavyatut. And if Dharma is destroyed, then the entire order in the society will be there, Krishnam.

Entire the whole society. The Dharma of the whole society will be destroyed. As we have seen in our culture, there is Dharma for everything. That which makes you what you are is your Dharma. So I as an individual has a Dharma. I as a member of my family has my own Dharma that I can only act this way.

I as a part of the society has Dharma as a part of the civilized society. How I act and behave, the society has its own Dharma. So all these Dharmas which are dependent on an individual and in this case individual family, Arjuna says they will be all destroyed. The whole society will be in disarray because there is no order. There is no order in the family. Therefore there will not be order in the community.

And there is no order in the community. There is no order in the society. And we will be the guilty parties that we started this war. And all this happened. So Adharma bhi bhavat Krishna Pradishyanti Kulastriyaha. And he's trying to demonstrate how this Dharma will now be destroyed.

Why war will destroy Dharma in the society. Now none of these arguments is invalid. The argument he is making are all valid argument. Because we have seen after wars this does happen. And they may have seen that too. However, at that time, the only remedy was the war.

Sometimes the disease is so acute you have to take the side effects with it. But it is more important to kill the disease. Because by fear of the side effects, you don't take the medication, then the disease will kill you. So here it was very important to cure the disease. But Arjuna is now more focused on the side effects. So he's now explaining to Krishna, saying aaa Dharma bhi bhavat Krishna pradishyanti kulastriya ha.

Because now the society has no order. It will corrupt the women in this society. Now obviously we all get very upset when it comes to this type of statement in our scriptures. But remember one thing. The context of this statement is society at that time, not the society today. Society today has given enough opportunities for women to be independent.

They can function independently. You don't really need a man to support you. Just two generations ago, that was not really possible. You remember at least? I remember because I'm old enough to remember my older generation, which was relatively living a similar life. So when a daughter is given away, they used to give us three dhan eventually became a dowry.

Was not really a dowry in the olden society. It was given as a security wealth to the woman. If something happens to her husband, she will be protected. She will have means to support herself. There was called Tridhan in the marriage. The parents of the bride will give it to the bride as a gift.

And that is Supposed to be very sacred, that you will not touch, that you will not waste, that Sridhan, the husband will have no right to use this Sridhar. There was a security for that woman because there was no other means for her to support herself. Now you can regress it back to 3,500 years ago, when society was completely different, where the division of labor was clearly defined between men and women. Our society had evolved from hunter gatherer society. The hunter gatherer society, there was very clear division of labor. Men will go out and hunt and bring food, women will stay in the caves and take care of children.

Obviously you couldn't reverse that in that society. And that was basically a model continued in our society where men went out and worked in the world outside to generate wealth and women took care of the family. Now, if the man is out, the one part of that unit which was responsible to support the family is gone. And if the woman does not have any means to do that, then obviously there will be corruption. Arjuna is making his argument here, that why it is so important to keep the family unit intact. So in that time society, maybe one person dies in a family, but there was other male in the.

In the family who will be there to take care of the widow and her children.

snippets.title: Day 15: The Grief Deepens
snippets.sanskrit:
दोषैरेतैः कुलघ्नानां वर्णसङ्करकारकैः |

उत्सन्नकुलधर्माणां मनुष्याणां जनार्दन |

अहो बत महत्पापं कर्तुं व्यवसिता वयम् |
snippets.transliteration:
doṣairetaiḥ kulaghnānāṃ varṇasaṅkarakārakaiḥ .

utsannakuladharmāṇāṃ manuṣyāṇāṃ janārdana .

aho bata mahatpāpaṃ kartuṃ vyavasitā vayam .
verseTranslations: By the destruction of our lineage and the pollution of blood, ancient class traditions and family purity alike perish.
The wise say, my Lord, that they are forever lost, whose ancient traditions are lost.
Alas, it is strange that we should be willing to kill our own countrymen and commit a great sin, in order to enjoy the pleasures of a kingdom.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter one, Arjuna Vishada, Yoga, Yoga of Arjuna's Grave. We have come to the final concluding _Verses_ of chapter one. So the chapter one paints a scenario where if not millions, thousands of people gathered in Kurukshetra to do whatever they do best. So they basically to fight the war. So Kurukshetra is also called dharmakshetra by Dhritarashtra in the first words. The first was Dhritarashtra says, I want to know what's happening in the Kurukshetra, which is a dharmakshetra.

So Kurukshetra is analogous to Karmakshetra, field of action. Also it's called dharmakshetra, which is analogous to a field of actions where I can practice my dharma, Dharma that which I'm prepared for. So for an architect like me, Dharma Kshetra is my office and practice art of architecture. Well, that's my dharmakshetra. My dharma as an architect is to design buildings. The field of action which gives me an opportunity to practice that art is my dharmakshetra.

So this scenario which is painted is analogous to the situations which we find ourselves in our lives. So every year the universities have graduation ceremonies where we see the sea of students who are graduating, ready to enter into the workforce. And obviously the question in the parent's mind is whether my son will be successful in wherever he practices his whatever the education and the profession which he has prepared himself for. And obviously the thought comes to our mind is that maybe the one who has the most resources will be successful in his life, person who comes from a good family, who has a family background, has a family business. Well, maybe that person will be successful in his life. Or the other thought is maybe the one who is well equipped, who is a good student, has the highest grade, who is always ahead in this class, that he will be the most successful in his life.

Consider a situation in your own life where you face conflicting duties—where doing right by one person or principle seems to require doing wrong by another. The Gita doesn't offer easy answers to such dilemmas, but it invites us to face them honestly rather than avoiding them.

श्रीभगवानुवाच |

क्लैब्यं मा स्म गमः पार्थ नैतत्त्वय्युपपद्यते |
snippets.transliteration:
sañjaya uvāca .

śrībhagavānuvāca .

klaibyaṃ mā sma gamaḥ pārtha naitattvayyupapadyate .
verseTranslations: Sanjaya then told how the Lord Shri Krishna, seeing Arjuna overwhelmed with compassion, his eyes dimmed with flowing tears and full of despondency, consoled him:

"The Lord said: My beloved friend! Why yield, just on the eve of battle, to this weakness which does no credit to those who call themselves Aryans, and only brings them infamy and bars against them the gates of heaven?
O Arjuna! Why give way to unmanliness? O thou who art the terror of thine enemies! Shake off such shameful effeminacy, make ready to act!
snippets.commentary:
We will be discussing chapter two, Sankhya Yoga. Yoga of Knowledge means uniting with the knowledge. The knowledge can be generally classified into two categories. One is secular knowledge and sacred. Secular is the knowledge about the world of objects. So even to get the secular knowledge, what we generally have to do is to make observations of the objects and then understand them.

So all the objects in the world which we know about today are not dependent on my personal observation, my personal understanding. The generations of scientists and mathematicians and and experimenters have gathered this information and passed them to us. So our knowledge is based on the efforts of generations of great thinkers. Sacred knowledge is something similar. So the knowledge about the self is also. It is not my personal experience right now, but I have to depend on the generations of sages who very carefully contemplated on the nature of the self.

And those declarations are basically recorded in Vedas in our tradition. The knowledge they gained in their contemplation, in their observation, in their meditations are recorded as declarations and Vedas. The Veda means to vid is to know and the book of knowledge is Vedas. So there are four Vedas, Rukh, Sam, Yajur and Atharva. Based on the declarations of Vedas, there are six Darshan Shastras in our traditions. Various masters have taken those declarations and formulated a school of philosophy to explain the truth, the nature of the self.

And that became the six schools of philosophy. In our tradition they can be generally categorized into three main categories. The first is called Tarka Logic. They come to the conclusion about what the truth is by logical conclusions. So that's called Tarka. And there are two great masters, Kannada and Gautam.

They form their Darsana, Sastra, which go Vaisheshika and Nyaya. Out of the six, five of them do not believe that God can be realized by meditation and knowledge. Only the last one, Vedanta, recognized the fact that God can be realized by meditation and knowledge. So as I said, they can be classified into three. The one is Tarka, which is logic. Second is Sankhya or Sankhya that is the logical enumeration of the facts.

Very logical argument about what is the truth and how we come to that conclusion. And Kapil Muni is the author of Sankhya philosophy. But he did not include the Creator Ishvara or the God Principle in his philosophy. So his Darshan Sastra is near Iswara. Sankya Iswara is not included in his thesis. But then Patanjali included Isvara in the same Sankhya philosophy.

So it becomes Sa Iswara. Sankhya in the last one is called Mimasa Deliberations deliberating the fact, deliberating the facts which are available to us and come to the conclusion what is the real truth. So the declarations in Vedas are in basically two general categories. The earlier part of Vedas is called Karmakanda. The later part of the Vedas called Jnanakanda. The deliberations made based on the earlier part of the Vedas is called Purva Mimsa.

Jaimini Rusi made it detise on this Purva Mimsa methodical path of how to achieve the ultimate goal. The ultimate goal in Purva Vimansa is to go to heaven. All the good deeds of or good rituals. When you perform and acquire merits Punya then you are given a place to experience happiness and peace and bliss. And that state is called Swarga. So the goal of life as per Purva Vimansa is to achieve the Swarga based on the Jnanakanda.

The later part of the Vedas, the Darsam Shastra which was developed by Sage Badarayan is called Uttar Mimansa. So the Uttar Mimsa is the one recognized, the one single entity Brahman. So various teachers in Acharyas have taken the basis from one or the other of Darshana Shastra and created the schools of thoughts in our culture. And they are basically three Dvaita, the dualistic school. God and I are two different entities. They will never become one.

God is the Master and I am his servant. Dvaita Radhvacharya founded the school of thought. Rama Rajacharya established Visisht Advaita which says God is the whole and I'm part of F. So most of our Vaishnava Sampradha is based on Vishist Advaita. Then the last one is Adhvaita. Bhagavan Shankaracharya established the school of thought called Advaita based on Vedanta. Vedanta Literally means end of Vedas.

End of Vedas we have Upanishads, the declarations in the Upanishads which says Myself and God is one and the same. Tattvamasi that thou art, that which I am seeking is none other than my own self. That school is called Advaita philosophy, non dualistic school of thought. So Bhagavad Gita the people have seen from all different points of view. In our tradition, Chinmaya, mission tradition or Sankarachira's tradition, we typically look at it from a non dualistic school of thought. So the chapter literally combines all these various schools of thoughts into understandable philosophy which takes the salient points of all three philosophies.

But in nature it is still Advaiti. And therefore we have seen in Gitamatvay Advaita Amru to varshed him which teaches us that myself and God's self is one and the same. So therefore this chapter is titled Sankhya Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge, predominantly based on the Sankhya philosophy of logical conclusions. So it is more scientific and modern in its approach towards the truth. All our Upanishads are in the form of dialogues between student and the teacher. Student ask question.

The teacher answer the question or give him guidance. So it is never to be taken without any understanding. If you don't understand, ask questions. Bhagavad Gita is basically in the same format. Bhagavan gives advice Arjuna, if he does not understand, he stops him and says let me tell you what I don't understand. So that's the tradition where you do not take anything for granted without understanding it.

So the chapter two Sankhya Yoga is now giving us a thumbnail picture of what the core declarations in Vedas in modern day presentation, effective presentation generally in three parts. Tell them what you're going to tell them, then tell them and then tell them what you told them. So you go to any professional meeting, you have an agenda. So you basically tell them. What we're going to discuss today is an agenda to that we hold a discussion on those items on the agenda. At the end of the meeting you say let's conclude what are the X and I, what we agreed on.

Then we'll be discussing Bhagavad Gita and Chapter 18 will tell us what we Discussed all throughout Bhagavad Gita. Conclusion Action items what we have to do now, after that I have learned Bhagavad Gita. So the Sankhya Yoga is yoga of knowledge. Assuming that I don't have the knowledge right now, therefore I'm going to learn.

So chapter one gave us the scenario of our life situations. We typically live our life by complaining about injustices, discriminations, unfairness. And therefore what we do is we try to prepare ourselves for overcoming those obstacles. That's what we call education, training, internships. These are basically our preparations. Now is the preparation good enough to achieve success and happiness in life?

There's something more. All the graduates who come out from the university, they don't achieve exactly the same results. They're all prepared. They don't achieve the same result. Because there is something else that they differ from each other. Their inner strength and inner qualities and inner understandings of how to deal with the situation.

When you encounter a situation, will you be able to take the right decision? What to do and what not to do is basically the training in the spiritual quest. If we have the clear understanding about what my position is in this situation and what my role is in this situation, then I'll be able to take the decision correctly. If I represent a company, when I go to a meeting with my client, if I have clear understanding what my role is as a company employee, then what my goal is here, then I will take the right decision. But if I misunderstand my role and introduce my personal objectives and personality into that discussion, then I as a company representative will fail. I actually never get chances to be on a selection side of an interview.

But then there are some people who say, yeah, but I know that guy and I like him. So I'm now injecting my personal bias into the decision making process. If you take that personal bias out of it, your decision will be relatively correct. But once you start seeing it through your personal bias, your decision will be deluded. May or may not be correct. So what we have seen in chapter one is when your personal attachments and biases are overwhelming you in facing the situation, the chances of your failure is much greater.

snippets.title: Day 19: Arjuna Surrenders as Student
snippets.sanskrit:
कार्पण्यदोषोपहतस्वभावः

न हि प्रपश्यामि ममापनुद्याद्

सञ्जय उवाच |
snippets.transliteration:
kārpaṇyadoṣopahatasvabhāvaḥ pṛcchāmi tvāṃ dharmasammūḍhacetāḥ .

na hi prapaśyāmi mamāpanudyād yacchokamucchoṣaṇamindriyāṇām .

sañjaya uvāca .
verseTranslations: My heart is oppressed with pity; and my mind confused as to what my duty is. Therefore, my Lord, tell me what is best for my spiritual welfare, for I am Thy disciple. Please direct me, I pray.
For should I attain the monarchy of the visible world, or over the invisible world, it would not drive away the anguish which is now paralysing my senses."
Sanjaya continued: "Arjuna, the conqueror of all enemies, then told the Lord of All-Hearts that he would no fight, and became silent, O King!
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter two. We have still seen in the first few _Verses_ continuing to argue about why he feels that he should not be fighting. Obviously, we have spent the whole chapter one listening to his argument. Then Bhagavan told him that why are you behaving this way? Where does this un Aryan like importance come upon you? In other words, this behavior which is not fitting to somebody who is civilized and trained about Dharma.

As we have seen that in our culture everything is defined by Dharma. So whatever the basic qualities of the thing are being that defines who that person is. So we have broadly a Manavadharma, what is the Dharma of a human being? We generally define the Dharma of a human being is to act according to his true self, which is Divinity, the expression of the God. So our Dharma as human being is to align our actions in line with the divinity. So everything we do should be keeping in mind that my true Dharma is divinity and therefore I'm acting in that manner.

Then obviously we come down to now that I have aligned myself to divinity. I'm now just playing a role in this life or in this state, or in this time. Now, whatever the role I'm playing at that time will define what my Dharma is. My Dharma from Monday through Friday is to act as an architect. So that time, what is right for me is defined by the role I have taken. On Sunday it will be different.

If I start talking about architecture here, it will be very inappropriate. So my Dharma changes as per the time and role I am taking. There is no universally I can say that if I behave this way will be appropriate. I have to find what is the time I am in and what the role I have taken and then find what is my appropriate dharma. Arjuna right now is in a battlefield leading an army. Their army is depending on him on his strength and capability to win this war.

And now he wants to go back. Therefore Bhagavan said where the Un Aryan like behavior come upon you because as an Arya he was taught what is Dharma of a Kshatriya Kshatriya Dharma is when he is facing an enemy is to fight. Once he has decided this is the right battle, he has to fight. So Bhagavanti, where does this behavior come from? Is it something that somebody was not clear enough while teaching you what a Dharmapakshatriya is? Or what is your Dharma as a prince?

Or what is your Dharma as one of the Pandavas? Where is this behavior come from? So Arjuna obviously was not expecting that. He was expecting some sympathetic words. So he continues to make his point. But then he realized that there may be something I'm completely missing here, that all my arguments up till now has not made any impression on Krishna.

So there may be something I need to think about what is right. And maybe I'm not capable of thinking what is right. So the next few _Verses_ says, karpanya doso aphatva Bhavaha prachami tv. I made my argument thinking that I'm. What I'm thinking is right, that this is my Dharma. Not to kill my teacher, not to kill my great grandfather, not to kill my cousins.

For a while I thought, that's my Dharma. Now you are telling me that that's not my Dharma, that this is not the Arya like behavior. Therefore Dharma asam mudhe daha. I am completely confused about what is Dharma right now. I do not know what my Dharma is. Pruchamitam, I am asking you, someone who is confused about his Dharma.

What is my Dharma right now? What am I supposed to be doing at this time? Karpanya do so Aphatvah. My own nature is overwhelmed by this pity, pity on me that I am facing the situation. I don't know what I am doing. Normally I'm in my control.

Normally I know what I'm supposed to be doing from my training, from my own intellect. I know in this situation how I should be behaving, which is most appropriate. But looks like my whole subhava. My nature is overwhelmed by this pity about my own situation which I'm facing. Therefore I am Dharma. I am completely deluded about what is my Dharma.

Is it not killing them is my Dharma. Not fighting this war is my Dharma or fighting this war is my Dharma. Yat sreihaat nishitam bruhi tanme. Therefore you tell me with definitive guidance what is right for me. Up till now he was using his own intellect and ego to come up with what is right and wrong. Then he put forward his argument.

This is something, an indication to us that sometimes what we think through our intellect may not be right. We do come up with all this argument about why I'm doing this. You know, why I don't make any donation because they are all corrupt and all these organizations are corrupt. Why should I be supporting them? All this nice argument which I come up with, they may be just my own delusion. As long as I hang on to my ego and my intellect to come up with the right answer.

There may be right answer or there may be wrong answer. So right now, because you are telling me that what I was thinking is not right, I'm assuming that I'm completely deluded. Now you tell me what is right for me. We go to ask advice, but typically we are not really ready to listen to the advice. We go to somebody and say, you know, this is what I'm doing. This is the situation.

What do you think I should be doing? You know, the best thing for you to do is this. And you say, yeah, but I don't think I'll be able to. Because then you can say, well, what does he. I mean, obviously he doesn't know everything. We know what situation we are in.

We are really asking for advice just to get confirmation of what I'm thinking that somebody, yes, yes, you are right. You shouldn't be doing that. I think what you did is very right. That would be looking. We just need little pat on our back saying, I think, Neil, you're so smart. You figured out what to do.

We are not really looking for advice. Sisya Deham, I am your student. In our culture, Guru Sishya, relationship is very unique. It is very different from a father and a son or a mother and a son or a friend. Shishya completely surrenders to the Guru once he finds that the Guru is appropriate. After that, there is no argument about what Guru says.

Once he has surrendered to the Guru, then Guru tells him what to do and he does it. It is not a relationship between a professor and a student. Students can argue here, there. The Guru says, once I have decided that's my Guru, I have completely surrendered to him. And then whatever he says without any argument, I will follow. Because I have done all my homework before.

Whether that should be my Guru or I shouldn't be learning this particular thing from him or not. Once he has done that, I have completely surrendered. So he makes it clear to Krishna that I'm not just simply asking advice from you because I'm confused. I'm surrendering to you. Therefore, now you tell me what is Good for me and I will follow that. Sadhimam Tvam Prapannam I have taken refuge in you.

I have completely given up that I can come up with the right answer in this situation what is right and wrong. But I am now your student. You who will tell me what is right and wrong for me. And whatever you tell me, I will do it now. One thing I learned many, many years ago and not learned from any of the swami, but Dr. Naidu in whose house we used to do the classes. And he actually made me understand what a surrender is.

Surrender is something when you feel completely helpless. We go to temple and say I surrender to you Lord. But we are really not. We really want to make sure that I am in control, who is behind me, who is ahead of me. They would be paying attention that I am putting donation. So we are not really surrendering.

Surrender is when I completely feel helpless. In the example Dr. Naidu gave me, which really stuck with me. Two armies fighting and the one king, when he decides he's going to surrender, when is he going to surrender? When he feels completely helpless that there is no way he's going to win this battle, he surrenders to the other army. That point he's completely helpless. He's completely at the mercy of their other king.

The story of Eporus and Alexander when he surrendered, Alexander asked him, how do you want me to treat you? And Polish said, treat me like a king. Because at that point he has no other choice but to say I surrender. Now you can treat me the way you want. But you asked me, so I'm telling you, treat me like a king. So that's a surrender.

Surrender when you really feel that you don't have any other way out here. And I surrender to you. Arjuna came to that point that my ego, my intellect, my all this training is of no value right now. I can't come up with an answer which is going to be satisfactory to me or to you. Therefore I'm now your student. I'm asking you to teach me what is right and wrong.

Then tell me without any options. If Krishna get two options. One option is do this. And second, I'm again confused. Don't give me that option. You know, when I came to this country, I must have told this story many, many times.

But when I was in Africa to get a new car, you had to get in line, you had to register yourself. And then after two or three years you get notification from the dealership saying now your car has arrived and you can get it. So to get a new car then everybody wants to get a new car. Everybody will come and congratulate you. Oh, that's a new car. Oh, when did you register it?

So my boss told me go and get a new car. So I come and tell everybody and they said, your boss is joking with you because by the time you get your new car you probably will be working someplace else. So I made all my effort to use all my influence to get a new car within six months. And I was very proud. And as people have predicted, after eight months I was in the United States. I told my brother in law that it looks like there is no public transportation in this country.

He said no problem, we'll go over the weekend. Do you want to wait till weekend? He said, don't worry, we'll go over the weekend. Over the weekend he takes me first to a Chrysler's dealership and there are cars till my eyes can see in the parking lot or that lot. And he said, you can select any car, but let me tell you. And I said, you just tell me which car I should be buying.

He said, this is just Chrysler. Then we are going to go to gm, then we'll go to Ford and then if you like we can go to Toyota or other Japanese car. And I say I'm getting dizzy, you just tell me which car I should be buying.
