snippets.title: Day 27: The Warrior's Duty
snippets.sanskrit:
स्वधर्ममपि चावेक्ष्य न विकम्पितुमर्हसि |

यदृच्छया चोपपन्नं स्वर्गद्वारमपावृतम् |

अथ चेत्त्वमिमं धर्म्यं संग्रामं न करिष्यसि |
snippets.transliteration:
svadharmamapi cāvekṣya na vikampitumarhasi .

yadṛcchayā copapannaṃ svargadvāramapāvṛtam .

atha cettvamimaṃ dharmyaṃ saṃgrāmaṃ na kariṣyasi .
verseTranslations: Thou must look at thy duty. Nothing can be more welcome to a soldier than a righteous war. Therefore to waver in this resolve is unworthy, O Arjuna!
Blessed are the soldiers who find their opportunity. This opportunity has opened for thee the gates of heaven.
Refuse to fight in this righteous cause, and thou wilt be a traitor, lost to fame, incurring only sin.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge. So far we have seen in the chapter that Bhagavan explained to Arjuna his situation from various perspectives, not just one perspective, that this is my idea, you should do this. But he gave him various perspectives. The first perspective, spiritual perspective, from the highest perspective, from the spirit's point of view that the self is immutable, imperishable. So that's the highest perspective. Then it came down to the society's perspective.

And see, from a society's perspective, you as a Kshatriya has duty to protect the society from evil. If you see that evil is occurring in the society, we rely on the Kshatriya just like we rely on our armies to protect ourselves. Our army cannot become pacifist at the last minute. From that perspective, this is the best opportunity you have to perform your art and perform your duty. So society's perspective, he gave his opinion that this is still what you should be looking at. Then came down the individual's perspective.

There we have seen Bhagavan said, if you give up, you run away from your duty, then you will incur sin. He has looked at the issue from various perspectives and came to the same conclusion that Arjuna should fight this war. So in the process, Bhagavan also taught us the art of persuasion. If to persuade somebody who is bent upon doing something other than what we think is right for him, just giving me your opinion that look, you are doing something wrong, but it's not going to work. The only way that works is when you give him a three dimensional view of his situation, give him the view from various perspectives, look at it from various points of view and then the person will be able to see it correctly, then you will be able to persuade him. This can be also applicable to looking at any problem, any situation.

You come across a situation where you got a job in another town, that's best for you. From your professional perspective, well that's great. But if you take the decision just based on that, it may or may not be right. So you have to look at it from various perspectives. First you say, well from a professional perspective it seems like that job will give me more opportunity to go further in my career. Then you see it from family's perspective.

Will my family be comfortable relocating from this town to another? Will they be able to adjust as easily as they are adjusted here? Then lastly, you also have to see what the school district is in that new town. Is it as good or better in that town? And if you come to the same conclusion from all three of them, then relocation is the great idea. Take the job and move or you will find that you will end up commuting just like most of our friends do who work outside Richmond in Washington or or other places.

So any problem or situation cannot be viewed from just one perspective. And you can come to right decision or you can convince someone. So this art of persuasion is to give somebody a three dimensional view of a situation and then come to the conclusion. In this case, Bhagavan came to the same conclusion from all perspectives. From a spiritual, from a society's perspective, from individual Arjuna must fight this war. What typically works best is when it comes to me, I can see from my perspective that it is right.

So therefore Bhagavan put more stress on his individual situation. So we have seen that he's saying tathaha swadharma kirtim hitva papa vapsyasi. If you give up your duties, you will incur Papa. And this obviously is very dreaded word in Hindu society that you will incur papa. So that obviously worked probably more effectively. But you had the background of other two perspectives that this is right, this is the right thing to do from all perspectives.

So Bhagavan pursue that point of view a little further and says, bhayat ranat uparatam mansante tvam maharathaha isam chatvam bahumatah bhatva yasyasi lagavam. So all these great warriors who are gathered here on our side and on the other side, they have very high regards for you. Because of your valor and your prowess. They are unwillingly accepting your enemy, unwillingly accepting that you are one of the best warriors. It is not easy to confront you. You are the one who has achieved the pasupatastra from Lord Shiva himself.

Obviously there's a story that Arjunaya goes for tapas to please Lord Shiva. And in the end he ended up fighting with Lord Shiva himself. But Lord Shiva was so pleased that he revealed himself that I am not just the hunter which you are fighting, but I am Lord Shiva. Here is the Pashupadashtra. And as the Purana says, the Pasupatastra is like ultimate weapon. It can destroy the entire universe in no time.

So you are the one who has such a prowess that you can destroy everybody in no time if you really choose to. However, you cannot use any weapon irresponsibly. Just like our nuclear weapons. You may have capability but you may never use it. He said those people, they will then think that you ran away from this war because of fear. Even though that may not be reality but that's how you will be viewed by your peers and your enemies.

They will belittle you, they have high respect for you. And they will say I don't know what we were thinking. This guy turned out to be not really what we thought he is going to be. It's not something very comfortable for you if that happens. So the next verse says. Not only that you will disappoint your friends and relatives and people who are relying on you, the society.

But there are ahitha people who are not your well wishers, you know, enemies who wish that you go away. He said they will be telling stories about your cowardice. All kinds of, you know, Bahun, vadish, shanti or vachevadas. Things which we cannot repeat on national tv. That kind of talk, they will be talking about you. So please think about it.

Ninantaha, tava, samaratyam. They will be cavilling at your prowess. That I think it was all big hype. It was all made up stories that he is such a great warrior. I don't think he had those qualities. And if that's happened, what is more painful than that?

That nobody will ever realize that you ran away because you thought that killing your cousins and your teachers is not a right thing to do. But they will think it's a fear of war, fear of defeat which made you go away. So don't think this is going to be easy. If you go away and then in any deal which we make, you have to come up with a win win situation. The only way the deal gets closed, when a client comes to me, he thinks I can provide most appropriate services and I think this is the right project for me then only we sign a contract. If I don't think it is right or he thinks it is right for him, nothing happens.

So you have to come up with any situation. Win win situation where both parties will have a good outcome. Now in this case, if you are just looking at our own situation. Any decision which I take out of the absence available to me, I should feel comfortable that it will be acceptable situation for me. So Bhagavan now uses that final trump card and says if you die, you will go to the hero's heaven. So there is a special section of heaven which is reserved for these great heroes who die on the battlefield.

It's like the GI Bill, these great privileges in heaven for the heroes who serve their country, serve the society, in the process they die. You can think about the health care workers who lost their lives in this battle against Corona. So here our scripture says they have a special Saxon in heaven to reward them for their valor and their courage. Hatova Prapsesi Swargam Jitwava Bakshishe Mahim. If you die, you go to the heaven for the heroes. If you win, you will lead the kingdom on this earth.

This is a no brainer for you. There is no way that you can lose one way or other. Fight and die or fight and win both ways. So there is nothing to think about it. Here the only good decision is fight the war. Therefore he says, Tasmat Utthishtka Yudhaya Krutan Nishayah.

Therefore O son of Kunti, get up with a resolve to fight this war. So this is like a conclusive statement from Bhagavan. In the beginning Arjuna asked him and said, give me which is shreyas for me. And we have come across the word shreyas and prayers before. That which is always good. It may not feel good, but it is good for me.

Prayer says it feels good but not good for me. And Arjuna, no uncertain terms and ask Bhagavan, tell me what is good for me and I will do it. Now Bhagavan says Utthiste Kamanteya, get up with the resolve to fight this war. So that was the conclusive advice from Bhagavan. And then Bhagavan now introduces the concept of Karma Yoga. You have to act in this world and there will be consequences of your actions.

You are part of this world. This Sansa and this Sansar is not homogeneous experiences. The experiences are varied. Some are conducive, some are not conducive. You will fight the war. Outcome is not guaranteed.

The experience will not be as you predict. It may be something different. But you have to treat whatever you face with an equal state of mind. You have to treat them alike no matter what the outcome is. Because you are enjoying the ride in this world. The next verse now introduces the idea of how to transform Karma into Karma Yoga.

Same action, changing the mental attitude becomes Karma yoga. It says Sukhdu KE samy krutva alabha jaya jayo Tathaya yujaswa na evam papam avapsyasi. We came back to the papa again. So in verse 33 he said that Tathaha swadharma kirtim chahitva papam awapsyasi. You will incur sin if you abandon your duty. Here he says Tatha yudhaya yujyashwa na evam papam avapshasi.

You will not incur any sin. But the condition is sukha dukkha samay krutva sukhyana dukkha. You should treat them alike. It's more like an observer. It does not mean that you react to Sukhanidukha in the same way but you treat them alike as an observer. It's like that to me.

One says I think I should have a cup of coffee. The one who is thinking about me having cup of coffee, that's an observer. See that observer should be neutral. He should be treating anything which comes alike. Sukhar Dukkha at the mental level, my experience. When I experience there will be mental reaction and say this is conducive.

Not conducive, not good. Well, say there is a dukkha at the mental level, profit and loss. Now that obviously at the intellectual level. Am I making profit by doing this or I'm losing something? Here is my intellect. I actually thought I'm gonna get this but I didn't get that.

And therefore this is a loss or this is a profit. So that's at the intellectual level. Finally both Jaya and Ajaya victory or defeat is at the physical level. I tried to gain something, I did not gain it. I competed against several firms to get a project. That's a real reality, the physical reality that I don't have that project anymore.

snippets.title: Day 28: Honor and Dishonor
snippets.sanskrit:
अकीर्तिं चापि भूतानि कथयिष्यन्ति तेऽव्ययाम् |

भयाद्रणादुपरतं मंस्यन्ते त्वां महारथाः |

अवाच्यवादांश्च बहून्वदिष्यन्ति तवाहिताः |
snippets.transliteration:
akīrtiṃ cāpi bhūtāni kathayiṣyanti te.avyayām .

bhayādraṇāduparataṃ maṃsyante tvāṃ mahārathāḥ .

avācyavādāṃśca bahūnvadiṣyanti tavāhitāḥ .
verseTranslations: Men will talk forever of thy disgrace; and to the noble, dishonour is worse than death.
Great generals will think that thou hast fled from the battlefield through cowardice; though once honoured thou wilt seem despicable.
Thine enemies will spread scandal and mock at thy courage. Can anything be more humiliating?
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge. So far we have seen in the chapter that Bhagavan explained to Arjuna his situation from various perspectives, not just one perspective, that this is my idea, you should do this. But he gave him various perspectives. The first perspective, spiritual perspective, from the highest perspective, from the spirit's point of view that the self is immutable, imperishable. So that's the highest perspective. Then it came down to the society's perspective.

And see, from a society's perspective, you as a Kshatriya has duty to protect the society from evil. If you see that evil is occurring in the society, we rely on the Kshatriya just like we rely on our armies to protect ourselves. Our army cannot become pacifist at the last minute. From that perspective, this is the best opportunity you have to perform your art and perform your duty. So society's perspective, he gave his opinion that this is still what you should be looking at. Then came down the individual's perspective.

There we have seen Bhagavan said, if you give up, you run away from your duty, then you will incur sin. He has looked at the issue from various perspectives and came to the same conclusion that Arjuna should fight this war. So in the process, Bhagavan also taught us the art of persuasion. If to persuade somebody who is bent upon doing something other than what we think is right for him, just giving me your opinion that look, you are doing something wrong, but it's not going to work. The only way that works is when you give him a three dimensional view of his situation, give him the view from various perspectives, look at it from various points of view and then the person will be able to see it correctly, then you will be able to persuade him. This can be also applicable to looking at any problem, any situation.

You come across a situation where you got a job in another town, that's best for you. From your professional perspective, well that's great. But if you take the decision just based on that, it may or may not be right. So you have to look at it from various perspectives. First you say, well from a professional perspective it seems like that job will give me more opportunity to go further in my career. Then you see it from family's perspective.

Will my family be comfortable relocating from this town to another? Will they be able to adjust as easily as they are adjusted here? Then lastly, you also have to see what the school district is in that new town. Is it as good or better in that town? And if you come to the same conclusion from all three of them, then relocation is the great idea. Take the job and move or you will find that you will end up commuting just like most of our friends do who work outside Richmond in Washington or or other places.

So any problem or situation cannot be viewed from just one perspective. And you can come to right decision or you can convince someone. So this art of persuasion is to give somebody a three dimensional view of a situation and then come to the conclusion. In this case, Bhagavan came to the same conclusion from all perspectives. From a spiritual, from a society's perspective, from individual Arjuna must fight this war. What typically works best is when it comes to me, I can see from my perspective that it is right.

So therefore Bhagavan put more stress on his individual situation. So we have seen that he's saying tathaha swadharma kirtim hitva papa vapsyasi. If you give up your duties, you will incur Papa. And this obviously is very dreaded word in Hindu society that you will incur papa. So that obviously worked probably more effectively. But you had the background of other two perspectives that this is right, this is the right thing to do from all perspectives.

So Bhagavan pursue that point of view a little further and says, bhayat ranat uparatam mansante tvam maharathaha isam chatvam bahumatah bhatva yasyasi lagavam. So all these great warriors who are gathered here on our side and on the other side, they have very high regards for you. Because of your valor and your prowess. They are unwillingly accepting your enemy, unwillingly accepting that you are one of the best warriors. It is not easy to confront you. You are the one who has achieved the pasupatastra from Lord Shiva himself.

Obviously there's a story that Arjunaya goes for tapas to please Lord Shiva. And in the end he ended up fighting with Lord Shiva himself. But Lord Shiva was so pleased that he revealed himself that I am not just the hunter which you are fighting, but I am Lord Shiva. Here is the Pashupadashtra. And as the Purana says, the Pasupatastra is like ultimate weapon. It can destroy the entire universe in no time.

So you are the one who has such a prowess that you can destroy everybody in no time if you really choose to. However, you cannot use any weapon irresponsibly. Just like our nuclear weapons. You may have capability but you may never use it. He said those people, they will then think that you ran away from this war because of fear. Even though that may not be reality but that's how you will be viewed by your peers and your enemies.

They will belittle you, they have high respect for you. And they will say I don't know what we were thinking. This guy turned out to be not really what we thought he is going to be. It's not something very comfortable for you if that happens. So the next verse says. Not only that you will disappoint your friends and relatives and people who are relying on you, the society.

But there are ahitha people who are not your well wishers, you know, enemies who wish that you go away. He said they will be telling stories about your cowardice. All kinds of, you know, Bahun, vadish, shanti or vachevadas. Things which we cannot repeat on national tv. That kind of talk, they will be talking about you. So please think about it.

Ninantaha, tava, samaratyam. They will be cavilling at your prowess. That I think it was all big hype. It was all made up stories that he is such a great warrior. I don't think he had those qualities. And if that's happened, what is more painful than that?

That nobody will ever realize that you ran away because you thought that killing your cousins and your teachers is not a right thing to do. But they will think it's a fear of war, fear of defeat which made you go away. So don't think this is going to be easy. If you go away and then in any deal which we make, you have to come up with a win win situation. The only way the deal gets closed, when a client comes to me, he thinks I can provide most appropriate services and I think this is the right project for me then only we sign a contract. If I don't think it is right or he thinks it is right for him, nothing happens.

So you have to come up with any situation. Win win situation where both parties will have a good outcome. Now in this case, if you are just looking at our own situation. Any decision which I take out of the absence available to me, I should feel comfortable that it will be acceptable situation for me. So Bhagavan now uses that final trump card and says if you die, you will go to the hero's heaven. So there is a special section of heaven which is reserved for these great heroes who die on the battlefield.

It's like the GI Bill, these great privileges in heaven for the heroes who serve their country, serve the society, in the process they die. You can think about the health care workers who lost their lives in this battle against Corona. So here our scripture says they have a special Saxon in heaven to reward them for their valor and their courage. Hatova Prapsesi Swargam Jitwava Bakshishe Mahim. If you die, you go to the heaven for the heroes. If you win, you will lead the kingdom on this earth.

This is a no brainer for you. There is no way that you can lose one way or other. Fight and die or fight and win both ways. So there is nothing to think about it. Here the only good decision is fight the war. Therefore he says, Tasmat Utthishtka Yudhaya Krutan Nishayah.

Therefore O son of Kunti, get up with a resolve to fight this war. So this is like a conclusive statement from Bhagavan. In the beginning Arjuna asked him and said, give me which is shreyas for me. And we have come across the word shreyas and prayers before. That which is always good. It may not feel good, but it is good for me.

Prayer says it feels good but not good for me. And Arjuna, no uncertain terms and ask Bhagavan, tell me what is good for me and I will do it. Now Bhagavan says Utthiste Kamanteya, get up with the resolve to fight this war. So that was the conclusive advice from Bhagavan. And then Bhagavan now introduces the concept of Karma Yoga. You have to act in this world and there will be consequences of your actions.

You are part of this world. This Sansa and this Sansar is not homogeneous experiences. The experiences are varied. Some are conducive, some are not conducive. You will fight the war. Outcome is not guaranteed.

The experience will not be as you predict. It may be something different. But you have to treat whatever you face with an equal state of mind. You have to treat them alike no matter what the outcome is. Because you are enjoying the ride in this world. The next verse now introduces the idea of how to transform Karma into Karma Yoga.

Same action, changing the mental attitude becomes Karma yoga. It says Sukhdu KE samy krutva alabha jaya jayo Tathaya yujaswa na evam papam avapsyasi. We came back to the papa again. So in verse 33 he said that Tathaha swadharma kirtim chahitva papam awapsyasi. You will incur sin if you abandon your duty. Here he says Tatha yudhaya yujyashwa na evam papam avapshasi.

You will not incur any sin. But the condition is sukha dukkha samay krutva sukhyana dukkha. You should treat them alike. It's more like an observer. It does not mean that you react to Sukhanidukha in the same way but you treat them alike as an observer. It's like that to me.

One says I think I should have a cup of coffee. The one who is thinking about me having cup of coffee, that's an observer. See that observer should be neutral. He should be treating anything which comes alike. Sukhar Dukkha at the mental level, my experience. When I experience there will be mental reaction and say this is conducive.

Not conducive, not good. Well, say there is a dukkha at the mental level, profit and loss. Now that obviously at the intellectual level. Am I making profit by doing this or I'm losing something? Here is my intellect. I actually thought I'm gonna get this but I didn't get that.

And therefore this is a loss or this is a profit. So that's at the intellectual level. Finally both Jaya and Ajaya victory or defeat is at the physical level. I tried to gain something, I did not gain it. I competed against several firms to get a project. That's a real reality, the physical reality that I don't have that project anymore.
snippets.reflection:
Take a few moments today to consider: What would change if you truly believed that your essential Self cannot be harmed? Not as a comforting platitude, but as a lived reality?

When fear arises today, experiment with asking: 'What is it that's aware of this fear?' That awareness itself is untouched by what it witnesses. This is the key insight of these verses.

Notice the experiences of pleasure and pain that come to you today. Can you see them as contacts between your senses and sense objects—temporary, impermanent, coming and going like waves? Bear them with equanimity, knowing they will pass.

सुखदुःखे समे कृत्वा लाभालाभौ जयाजयौ |

एषा तेऽभिहिता साङ्ख्ये बुद्धिर्योगे त्विमां शृणु |

eṣā te.abhihitā sāṅkhye buddhiryoge tvimāṃ śṛṇu .

snippets.title: Day 30: The Yoga of Action
snippets.sanskrit:
नेहाभिक्रमनाशोऽस्ति प्रत्यवायो न विद्यते |

व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिरेकेह कुरुनन्दन |

यामिमां पुष्पितां वाचं प्रवदन्त्यविपश्चितः |
snippets.transliteration:
nehābhikramanāśo.asti pratyavāyo na vidyate .

vyavasāyātmikā buddhirekeha kurunandana .

yāmimāṃ puṣpitāṃ vācaṃ pravadantyavipaścitaḥ .
verseTranslations: On this Path, endeavour is never wasted, nor can it ever be repressed. Even a very little of its practice protects one from great danger.
By its means, the straying intellect becomes steadied in the contemplation of one object only; whereas the minds of the irresolute stray into bypaths innumerable.
Only the ignorant speak in figurative language. It is they who extol the letter of the scriptures, saying, There is nothing deeper than this.'
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge. So far we have discussed up to the verse 30, the knowledge of Sankhya, the knowledge about your own self. What is the nature of the self? And then now I'll teach you the Buddhi Yoga. I'll teach you the Yoga of how to implement this knowledge in your life. Buddhi Yoga, Intelligent way of living.

And then Bhagavan said, the way to work in this world is to have equanimity. Equanimity comes from your understanding of what you are getting into. If you understand the field of actions, the nature of the field of actions, the equanimity comes easily, naturally. If you do not understand the field of action, then obviously you will have difficulties. And we have used the example of roller coaster. That one who is standing in the line with all the enthusiasm, he knows what is the nature of the roller coaster.

He anticipates the ups and downs and twists and turns. That's the thrill of riding a roller coaster. If there was no ups and downs and twists and turns, there is no fun in roller coaster. More twists and turns and more ups and downs, that roller coaster more enjoyable then you go back and stand in line again to join. So if you enter this Sansar with the expectation that there will be ups and downs, twists and turns. Sukhaduka Lava Alabha Jaya Jaya.

Well that's the thrill of living in Sansar. So at the end of this life we'll come to the conclusion that that was pretty thrilling ride. Well, let's do it all over again. That's Kurupunar Janma. We'll stand in line again in that Sansa. While we are on that ride we forget that this is what we signed up for.

That's where problem comes. So Bhagavan said keep that in mind that these are natural and this is what you signed up for. The goal of life is to realize your true self. Which is what Bhagavan said I taught you in the first portion of this discussion. Now I want to tell you how to use that knowledge to realize that ultimate truth, the self, the nature of yourself. Bhagavan Ved Vyas discusses what is the difficulty we have in understanding our Darshan Shastras.

So we have basically discussed in the beginning there are six schools of thought and the school of thought which is based on the previous portion of Veda called Karmakanda. So all Vedas are divided into four parts. There are the mantras, then Brahmanas, then Aranyakas, and then Upanishads. The philosophy which is more centered around Karmakand. The Brahmana portion is called Purva Vimansa. We have discussed before, in Purva Mimsa, the goal of life is to reach heavens.

And in heavens then you will have supra sensuous experiences to make you feel happy. Every good action we perform will create merits. You accumulate enough merits so you can go to Swarga. And in that Swarga, then you will have these enjoyments. When you exhaust your balance of your merits, you will come back again, work again for the more merits and go back to Swarga again. But that's the goal of life in Purva Mimsa.

And therefore the society in general placed more emphasis on collecting merits and various ways to do yajnas and rituals. So the means of rituals was supposed to be to purify your mind and intellect so you can become single pointed. But the means became the goal in the society and they completely missed the boat. So now we see the criticism from Bhagavan Ved Vyas that how we have missed that boat as a society. And we have seen time and again in history of India that these philosophers and the great thinkers have come to realign the religion back to its goal. So this spiritual aspect becomes available to all people.

So it seems that during Mahabharata time the spiritual aspect of the goal was not available to most people. People were stuck into the rituals. So Bhagawan Vedvyas criticizes those people who had been misguiding the generations. So he says in verse 42 yam imam puspitam vacam. Those people using the flowery language are unwise. The unwise people are using flowery language.

The language used in Brahmana portion of Bhagavadas. He said, they make it sound like that is the goal. Those description rituals are for you to purify your mind and intellectual. But here they have made it sound like that is the goal. This is what you should be doing. Then it became so elaborate and society was so indulgent into it, that average person was afraid of the word yoga or Yajna.

Because in each ritual it has been said that if you don't perform it correctly then you will incur sin, it will be adverse effect. So you have to have an expert to tell you how to do it. And each ritual became so elaborate that it is very elaborately describe what type of bricks to be used, how the bricks to be arranged for the yajna. So an average person was afraid of the word yajna in yoga with that fear that if I do something wrong, rather than cumulating merits, aloe demerits. Therefore, Bhagavan in the previous verse has given us this assurance that this yoga, this Buddhi Yoga, when you perform there is no danger of any adverse effect. And even a little practice you don't have to be an expert.

You don't have to perform it to a level that you become a master. Even a starting of a little effort also will not go in vain. So it's complete contradiction to what was prevalent in ritualism. In ritualistic practice you have to do it correctly. If you don't do it correctly, it will adverse effect. Here Bhagavan said, no, no, there is no adverse effect in this Yoga, Buddhi Yoga, there is no adverse effect.

You perform your actions in this manner with equanimity of mind and you will be liberated from all your karma bandana, the bondages of actions. So now Bhagawan is criticizing the people who are using flowery language to make people confused about what is right and what is wrong. And he said Veda Vadharathaha. They take great pleasure and using the words of Vedas Na anyat asti ITI Vadhi Naham. They say there is nothing other than this, other than this, other than this Karma Kanda, other than this rituals, other than to accumulate merits and go to heaven, there is nothing else there. Completely missing the boat.

The goal of life is to achieve that oneness with yourself, understanding the self. Kamatmana Swarga Paraha. Because they're desirous of achieving Swarga. So the Swarga became the ultimate goal. They said that Veda says that Karmakand, you should be doing all these karmas. When you do, you will accumulate merits and you will go to Swarga.

So Swarga became the goal of life. Swarga Paraha Janma, Karma Falla Pradha which promises new birth as the renewal of their actions, you will come back again. verseTranslations: As a man can drink water from any side of a full tank, so the skilled theologian can wrest from any scripture that which will serve his purpose.
But thou hast only the right to work, but none to the fruit thereof. Let not then the fruit of thy action be thy motive; nor yet be thou enamored of inaction.
Perform all thy actions with mind concentrated on the Divine, renouncing attachment and looking upon success and failure with an equal eye. Spirituality implies equanimity.
snippets.commentary:
We are now discussing Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge. So far we have seen that Bhagavan gave the knowledge of Sankhya. The Sankhya Darshan is Gina Darshan. It takes us step by step what the reality is. From verse 11 through 30 he gave us this Tankhya Darshan, the Gnana Darshan. Then he said that now I'll teach you the Buddhi Yoga which is the application in your life, how to overcome the Prakruti.

So Sankhya Darshan says that Purusha and Prakruti are two separate entities. When Purusha get involved with Prakruti then all these problems start. The 5 klesa starts, ragadvesha, etc. So yoga sastra says, how to overcome this entanglement with Prakriti. So that Yoga Sastra Bhagavan says, I will now teach you. But Bhagavan coined a new word, Buddhi Yoga Yoga which is established in wisdom.

So Bhagawan is basically now teaching Arjuna the Yoga Sastra in a very simple format that we all can understand. Arjun, I can understand. We all can understand. We have touched upon a landmark verse in bhagavad git verse 47 last time, which is most quoted verse in Bhagavad Git. Most people quote this verse but only quote the half of it. The first line of it.

You will hardly ever hear anybody quoting the entire verse. So the first line everybody is very familiar which says Karmanye vadhikarathe ma faleshu kadaa. And we quote that as if that's the instruction in reality, that is the statement of fact. The first line in that verse is statement of fact that you have only control over your actions, you do not have control over the fruits of actions. That's a statement of fact. All of us who can think about it will agree with that, that I can act or the results will come.

I'm not the Karma Falada. Somebody else is either the world Bhagavan whoever you consider, but that's not you. But you do have control over actions. The second line is actually the prescription. The second line is the advice which says Maa karma fala hai turbuhu. Never engage in any action with the expectations of the results.

It's an advice for us to be wise about how we act. You will never be able to guess what the results would be. You will never have a control over it. There is no reason for you to invest your energy into it. Most of our energies are wasted in regrets of the past or in the anxieties of the future. And then we have less enthusiasm in the present.

So Bhagavan said, therefore, therefore, never engage in action with a result in your mind. And then the last portion of that verse is mate Sangahatu akarmani. And never get attached to inaction by fear of failure or not having any clear direction. You do not want to get engaged in inaction. Instead it become tamasic. So basically the advice Bhagavan given is very clear.

Engage in action without any expectations. Many commentators said this is where you change from prayers to shrayas. So all Kamya karmas are for prayers. That which is going to be pleasant for me. Those actions which are not driven by the expectation of the fruits will lead you to Shreyas. Because you will be only focusing on the action itself.

So Bhagavan has given a clear direction and clear statement of the reality we live in. And now in the following verse, Bhagavan clearly demonstrate how one can engage in this activity. Yogastha Kuru Karmani. Establish yourself in yoga. How to practice this Gnana Darshan, this knowledge of the true self. As I said, there are two entities for Sankhya.

Purusha who is always pure. Chaitanya but inactive. Prakruti which is inert but active. Prakriti does not have the consciousness but it is very active. And Purusha which is pure consciousness but inactive. When these two get entangled with each other, then the confusion starts.

Maharishi Patanjali Yoga Sutra said that Yoga Chitta _Verses_ Nirodha Yoga is to stop the activities of your Chitta Paryoga Sastra. The Chitt is like a mirror, it reflects the pure consciousness. But there are Chitta _Verses_. There are modifications which creates this confusion. Basically the function of Chitta from in our day to day life is Pramana. To get knowledge we parse the contrary knowledge, the wrong knowledge we culp doubt sleep or Nidra Thomas and then Smruti's memory.

These five modifications of Ch create flickering in our Ch. It does not let the consciousness reflect purely. Once these _Verses_ are negated the Purusha is reflected through the Ch in its pure form that basically Yoga Satra Se. But this is very complicated for an average man to understand. So Bhagavan is now clarifying this in a very simple term which you and I can understand and try to practice Yogastha Kuru Karmani. You have to establish yourself in yoga then act outside.

If you are not established in yoga then actions will be haphazard. They will be driven by the results. Then obviously there will be all the side effects which come along with it. Sangam tyaktva Dhananjaya Swamiji points out this is the most important part of this verse and most people leave that out. Sangam tyaksva act in this world by establishing yourself in yoga and without any attachment. So even attachment to actions themselves in is detrimental.

If I get too attached to I have to do this, I need to do this then it will be problematic. There may not be opportunity of the particular actions for you to perform. In other words, you should perform the actions which are appropriate and necessary and available in that environment and not have to have the particular actions you're attached to. I will only do this but I will not do anything else. In olden society in India a Brahmin can only do this. He cannot do menial work.

And I know in time where there was not enough work the people suffered because they will not go down and say I will do this if this work is not available. The Bhagawan said don't get attached to actions. Whatever actions are available and appropriate, engage yourself into it. No attachment to what type of actions I'm performing also have to establish myself into yoga. Now what that yoga is with an average person gets really frightened. The very word you become a yogi will say oh no, no, I don't want to become a yogi.

I have my own life to live. I want to say no, no that's not Yoga is all about. Yoga is something different. So what Maharishi Patanjali says Ch _Verses_ nirodhaha Bhagavan puts it in a very different way which is very palatable to us. So he said Siddhi asidhi samo Bhatva become even minded to success and failures. Once again going back to the previous verse success and Failures come from the past actions.

The success and failures which I am experiencing now are actually results of my past actions. I have no control whatsoever on them anymore. I should have gone to medical college and I would have been a doctor and made more money and I'd be considered a frontline worker right now. I cannot change that. And therefore, whatever the results I'm facing right now, whether I consider them to be success or kind of failures, I should be even minded, take them as they are without attaching my likings and dislikings. Siddhiya Siddhi Samo Bhutva Samatvam Yoga Uchate the very first definition in Bhagavad Gita about Yoga Samatvam Yoga Uchate we will see more definitions and therefore this chapter is so important.

These next three or four verses starting from 47, they are so loaded with meaning and they compressed all the wisdom of Sankhya and Yoga in these few verses that we have to pay lots of attention to understand them. Bhagavan said Siddhi Asidhi Samo Bhatva In a sense do not pay attention to what you are getting because of your past actions. Treat them equally with Prasada Buddhi Engage in your present actions. Do not let your present actions get affected by Siddhiyanes Siddhi which you are facing right now. Samatam Yoga Uchade the balance of mind is Yoga. So we go back to what Maharasi Patanjali said.

Yoga Chitta Vritti Nirodha When Chitta is agitated by all these _Verses_ Appropriate knowledge or good knowledge contrary knowledge, memories Nidra Tamas all those _Verses_ are creating impurities in Chitta. That Chitta is not now available to reflect the right knowledge or the right reality is who I am. Bhagawan said Samatam Yoga Chitta this balance of mind which does not get affected either by past nor by anxiety of the future, does not lose any enthusiasm in present in your current actions is Yoga. Once you are established in this, your actions will bear right results in the next verse. How to look at the situation? Durenahi Avaram Karma Buddhi Yoga Dhananjaya Actions which are prompted by desires are far lower than Buddhi Yoga Bhagawan is obviously using a very unique term Buddhi Yoga Buddhi Yoga is Yoga wisdom, intelligent way of living, establishing yourself in Buddhi.

So again we have discussed before Chitta is a thinking entity. Thinking entity has several functions. We know the three functions are Mana Buddhi And Ahankaar. The Ahankar is always constant. The I feeling is always constant. When that thinking entity is in doubt, it is mind.

Sankalpa Vikalpatmaka manah But nische atmika Buddhi Buddhi which is decisive. This is right, this is the truth and this is what I should be working on. But once you establish in that Buddhi, that wisdom, what is right and what is wrong and don't be in that doubtful situation that is Buddhi Yoga. When Chitta is in that nischyatmic mode, it's Buddhi. So Bhagavan said, engage yourself in Buddhi Yoga. That Buddhi Yoga is far better than Karma.

And here Karma is only Kamya Karma. Desire prompted actions. Karma Khanda, all the actions all the way up to the desire to get Swarga is all Kamya Karma. Therefore all actions perform for those results. Bhagwan said anytime. Even though they may be the highest form of actions to achieve the best possible state of living or living standard, they are far lower than Buddhi Yoga.

Buddha Sharanam Anmeccha take refuge in Buddhi. This also reminded me of Buddham Sharanam Gachami Dhamma saranam Gachami Sangam saranam gacham. I take refuge in Buddha in the wisdom of Buddha. Here Bhagavan says take refuge in your own wisdom. Buddha Saranam anvicha Krupanaha fala heta vah. Those who are working in this world to get inducive results or get the fruits of their actions all the way up to reaching the heavens.

They are Krupanaha unfortunate misers. The translation is wretched. So Krupana means miser. Miser is always unfortunate because he never gets to enjoy his own wealth. He has all the wealth but can't enjoy it so he's wretched. Unfortunate people say those people that include all of us who are working for the fruits of actions.

They are very unfortunate because they will never be able to enjoy fruits of their actions. They will always be in misery, either regretting the past or anxious about the future. They will never be living in present. They are always living in future or in past. They both are hypothetical situation. There is no past that I have experienced and there is no future that I have seen.

Anytime I experience, it is always present. Bhagavan says those people are really unfortunate misers who waste their energies into past and in future and completely ignores the present. O shantihi shri gurubyonamaha harihio. So we had been discussing Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge. And so far we have seen that Bhagavan gave us the knowledge of the Sankhya which is teaching us that this self is immortal, this body is mortal.

Take a few moments today to consider: What would change if you truly believed that your essential Self cannot be harmed? Not as a comforting platitude, but as a lived reality?

When fear arises today, experiment with asking: 'What is it that's aware of this fear?' That awareness itself is untouched by what it witnesses. This is the key insight of these verses.

Notice the experiences of pleasure and pain that come to you today. Can you see them as contacts between your senses and sense objects—temporary, impermanent, coming and going like waves? Bear them with equanimity, knowing they will pass.

śrībhagavānuvāca .

duḥkheṣvanudvignamanāḥ sukheṣu vigataspṛhaḥ .

verseTranslations: Lord Shri Krishna replied: When a man has given up the desires of his heart and is satisfied with the Self alone, be sure that he has reached the highest state.
The sage, whose mind is unruffled in suffering, whose desire is not roused by enjoyment, who is without attachment, anger or fear - take him to be one who stands at that lofty level.

He who wherever he goes is attached to no person and to no place by ties of flesh; who accepts good and evil alike, neither welcoming the one nor shrinking from the other - take him to be one who is merged in the Infinite.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter two, Sankhya Yoga Yoga of Knowledge. So far we have seen that this chapter is divided in four segments. First few verses Arjuna says, I am Navirsheshya. I don't know what to do. You tell me without any option what is good for me. Second, we have seen what Bhagavan responded in his response and said, you shouldn't be worried about anything that is happening in this world simply because what you see happening is temporary.

There's nothing in this world which is permanent because all your experiences are the senses coming in contact with the sense objects. That one which you are worried about yourself is immortal. There is no death for it, there is no birth for it. So is the case for his self herself, myself. Therefore there is no worry about the self. Everything else is temporary.

So why worry about that? Anyway, that was the knowledge part. And then he said how to practice that now that you know that it does not make your life easier. Just because I went to Gita class does not make my life easier. On Monday through Friday he said on Monday through Friday what you should do is act your must just like you were acting before. But establish yourself in yoga.

Yoga is the equanimity of mind. When you establish yourself, your mind into an equanimity that things will continue to change outside. But I will remain same in dealing with them, whether they are conducive or inconducive. Say Samatvam Yoga Uchiha Daya Equanimity of mind is Yoga. When do I know that my mind is equanimous? When you become skillful in your actions.

When your actions become crystallized and precise and efficient. You should know that you have established yourself in Yoga Samatvam Yoga Uchide and Yoga Karmasu Kaushalam. So one is the definition. There is actually a test. If your accents are hafizar, even though you think you are in yoga, you are not. Because in a yogi's accents will be all precise and dexterous.

Lot of time in My life I have seen. Swami Chinnamanda says something seems absolutely ridiculous, that it's not gonna happen. Somehow it all falls into place. But when I think from my logic should not work at all. But for him, if he says this should happen by this time and this will happen by this time and you should do this, he will have. Because he is a mind of a yogi who can see through how to get things done.

Mine is the mind of a Bhogi who cannot see how this can ever happen. So Bhagavan said, that's your test. Yoga Karmasu Kaushalam. When we practice something over and over and over again, we become so efficient. I used to practice music. My teacher said, keep practicing.

You will get it before you know when you will get it. You will never know when you got it. But then you will know what is the Madhya Sapta kana Mantra Sapta kana taar Sapta. Practice makes you perfect. Once you achieve that art, you don't have to make any efforts driving Karmasukaushalam. I don't have to make any effort.

I don't even think about it while driving. Because it is Karmasur Kaushalam, I am established into the Yoga of driving. Therefore, Bhagavan says, that's equanimity of mind. We come to this conclusion very quickly that this is not possible. This is just for yogis, you know, like Swami Chinmayananda and Buddha and Mahavir and not for us. So the question, okay, if that's the case, how do we know that someone is established in yoga?

So you ask a question. So Arjun asked the question, this pragna is tita whose intellect is steady. We saw the definition Samatvam Yoga Uchate. So one's intellect once becomes steady, he becomes sthita pragna. Because that pragna is not changing no matter what the outside situation is. It may be very dark in this room, but I know it is there.

Because my prajna is titaha in the knowledge that it is daytime right now. Even if you turn off light, even if there is clouds outside and it becomes very dark, I still say it's daytime. Because I know it is daytime. Because my prajna is completely sthida in that knowledge. The knowledge which Bhagavan gave in the first section that you are not the mortal being, you are the immortal being. Your self is immortal.

Everything else is just passing experiences. Once that knowledge takes Place in the intellect. No matter what happens in my life, it does not change my understanding of that fact. If that happens to somebody who establishes himself in their knowledge, what is the description of such a person? How would I know such a person? So arjuna in verse 54 asked that question.

Sthita prajnasya ka bhasha samadhisthasya keshava. We know Samadhistha who is established in samadhi. Sa samadhi buddhi buddhi which is steady. We use this word samadhi in a very metaphysical way. Samadhi is a firm conviction that this is the reality. Parmiti Jamanda and one Upanishad class told us that you are in a complete state of samadhi right now of your body consciousness.

Nobody has to remind me who I am. No matter what situation changes. Outside, it is dark, it is light. If everybody's here, nobody's here. This is me that never changes. You can convince me, if you are persuasive enough that this class does not exist.

I am just hallucinating. Neil, you need some help. You are hallucinating. You're talking to yourself. Possible that I will believe that and will start seeking advice from Prakash Ethagee or somebody like him. But you can't convince me that I don't exist.

No matter how confused I am. But this body is actually immortal. So therefore you shouldn't be worried about it. Your samadhi should be in this immortality. Prajna, as we have seen, is pure. Consciousness is prajna. The higher form of awareness is prajna. This is another way of looking at it. That that person will be always happy in whatever is happening. Neither he is congratulating himself nor is he hating himself.

snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge. And as we have seen, this chapter is in four parts and we are in the last part which describes the characteristics of a man of wisdom, a perfect person who has learned how to live in this life intelligently. So this segment is called Sthita Prajna. Lakshana is basically a virtual role model created for us by Bhagavan Krishna. So that's basically a simple definition of a man of perfect wisdom, that he has no desire, he feels complete, he has no attachment, and therefore he has no fear and no anger. And then Bhagawan also described that what is that steady wisdom? What is that steady Buddhist which can make person achieve this state of having no attachment, fear and anger.

And he said that one who does not get affected by any happening, whether conducive or unconducive, he does not get agitated by unconducive happening. He also does not get carried away by conducive happening. Conducive experience does not create longing in him. An unconducing experience does not create any grief or agitation in his mind. So this is basically a state of constant enthusiasm. He's constantly enthusiastic about living his life in a perfect state of mind.

And somebody's going to file a claim against us for errors and omniscience. Some of the things which we always dread to go to your boss and tell him because he will be disappointed. How can you do this, Neil? On the contrary, Dan will be all enthusiastic. Okay, if that's the case, let's do this. Call such and such person.

Let's make sure we do this enthusiasm in both cases I found very unique. He will not get upset because we have now a potential claim against us. But he will get all excited and say let's make sure that we are prepared to deal with it. I will never forget that. And it's now 20 years since I left the job. He now became the head of the entire organization which has 2100 people.

That shows what a person who can maintain his enthusiasm in all situations can achieve. In my own life, I've seen people achieving that. For one said that such a person, his intellect is steady. A man of perfect wisdom. So we come to the conclusion if we achieve that state, we got it made. We don't have to do anything after that. Bhagavan said, no, you have to be very careful. Therefore, a man of perfect wisdom moves around in this world like a tortoise that whenever it senses danger, it withdraws all its limbs. So man of perfect wisdom does not give up this world of plurality. He has to live in this world where he lives with his senses under control of his mind.

So mind is under the control of the intellect and senses are under the control of the mind. That is basically the state of a Perfect wisdom, Bhagavan Seta. So he moves around in that fashion. That is what we have seen in the last two verses. And it says everything starts from constant contemplation on sense object Visayan pansah. That is the root cause of all my troubles.

When I constantly think about something, it becomes my nature. And once I attach myself to the world of finite objects, then now I'm going to assign my happiness to that object that I have now mortgaged. My happiness to the world of objects. And therefore now I have to acquire them because my happiness mortgage with them. Bhagawan said that is the ladder of fall. He started thinking about something that created attachment.

That attachment creates desires. The desires unfortunately creates anger. Anger created delusion. That delusion created loss of intellect. And loss of intellect gets you destroyed. So this is the fall which we have seen.

So that means I have to work with the root cause of my problem is Bhagavan Buddha in his Arya Satya. He says, the first Sathya is that Dukkha exists. There is Dukkha in this world. The second one is that there is a cause for Dukkha. And what is the cause for Dukkha? Desire is the cause for all Dukkha.

So Bhagavan says the same thing here. Dhyaya TOU visayyanpunsa. He is the cause for all the problems. So how do I live in this world? The next three verses actually describe how to get out of this danger. Falling from this ladder of fall.

It says Ragtayhi to visayan indriyesh charan atma vashehi vide prasadam adhigh. So countering that tendency of thinking about objects and then getting attached to them and then falling into that trap, he said, the man of wisdom who has now realized, as we were discussed last time, that attachment is a mental phenomenon or a mental concept. Because my mind gets impression from the world of objects, it gets attached. Detachment, on the other hand, is very intellectual pursuit. Knowing fully well that this attachment is going to create sorrows for me, I try to detach myself from those attachments. How do I detach myself?

But how we act in this world is up to us. So I said one who is devoid of likes and dislikes. He is moving around with Atma Vashyahi, Vidhey Atma. He is self restrained. He is not getting carried away by one experience or the another. Vidheyatma, his self control.

Prasadam Adhi Gachadhi. He achieves that final result. And as we have discussed Prasad many times before, we are used to word Prasad after every puja we have Prasad. That Prasad is always sweet. That because the fruits of all my good actions sweet results. Here the result is tranquility of Mind the mind because it's not getting any impression which is negative.

No matter what impression comes from outside it sees a divine impression and therefore it is in a state of tranquility that is the prasad that's my final reward. Then nothing can upset my mind. Bhagavan said such a person Prasadam Adhighti achieves that final tranquility of mind that no experience can disturb the tranquility of mind. So Bhagawan says get out of likes and dislikes, see mean everything and then your mind will be constantly focused on me. Prasade Sarva Dukkha nam haani Yashi upa Jayate this is where we started. I want to learn Bhagavad Gita because I need to get rid of all my Dukkhas.

I want to get Bhagavan's Kupa because I want to get rid of all my sorrows and unhappiness. Bhagavan says there is a way to do it and it is not my doing, it is your doing. You have to do it yourself. When you control your mind, when you get out of likes and dislikes then you will get prasad of your own actions which with the tranquility of mind that tranquility of mind actually it removes the cause for all your sorrows. Bhagavan Buddha said there is a Dukkha and there is a cause for Dukkha and all you have to do is remove the cause for your Dukkha and then you achieve that Kaivalyam Prasadu Khanam. By this prasad all Dukkhas get destroyed.

Prasanna Cheta sah asu Buddhi pari avatist and for the one who is of tranquil mind, Chitta here Chitta Ekagra is also Chitta Ekagrita Chitta Ekagrita as we have discussed when Chitta only reflects nothing but definitive only Chitta is a mirror which is reflecting all the impressions from outside. When all these impressions are outside are divinized by my focusing on the divine self who created this cosmos out of his own self. As we have discussed before in this logic of causation that if this world exists there must be a Creator. The Creator needs to have two causes, Efficient cause and material cause. He is the efficient cause because he knew how to create this world but he also needed material and the material nothing but his own self.

snippets.title: Day 38: Peace Through Discipline
snippets.sanskrit:
रागद्वेषविमुक्तैस्तु विषयानिन्द्रियैश्चरन् | (or वियुक्तैस्तु)

प्रसादे सर्वदुःखानां हानिरस्योपजायते |

नास्ति बुद्धिरयुक्तस्य न चायुक्तस्य भावना |
snippets.transliteration:
rāgadveṣavimuktaistu viṣayānindriyaiścaran .

prasāde sarvaduḥkhānāṃ hānirasyopajāyate .

nāsti buddhirayuktasya na cāyuktasya bhāvanā .
verseTranslations: But the self-controlled soul, who moves amongst sense objects, free from either attachment or repulsion, he wins eternal Peace.
Having attained Peace, he becomes free from misery; for when the mind gains peace, right discrimination follows.

Right discrimination is not for him who cannot concentrate. Without concentration, there cannot be meditation; he who cannot meditate must not expect peace; and without peace, how can anyone expect happiness?
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge. And as we have seen, this chapter is in four parts and we are in the last part which describes the characteristics of a man of wisdom, a perfect person who has learned how to live in this life intelligently. So this segment is called Sthita Prajna. Lakshana is basically a virtual role model created for us by Bhagavan Krishna. What a perfect person should be, how he acts in this world, and how he conducts himself. Bhagavan gave a very succinct definition of a Sthita Prajna.

The one who has emptied his mind of all desires, one who feels complete, he does not feel incomplete and therefore he does not have to acquire anything or accomplish anything to feel complete. So the person who has emptied his mind of all desires, he becomes Vita Raga Bhayakroda. He becomes devoid of any attachment, fear or anger. So that's basically a simple definition of a man of perfect wisdom, that he has no desire, he feels complete, he has no attachment, and therefore he has no fear and no anger. And then Bhagawan also described that what is that steady wisdom? What is that steady Buddhist which can make person achieve this state of having no attachment, fear and anger.

And he said that one who does not get affected by any happening, whether conducive or unconducive, he does not get agitated by unconducive happening. He also does not get carried away by conducive happening. Conducive experience does not create longing in him. An unconducing experience does not create any grief or agitation in his mind. So this is basically a state of constant enthusiasm. He's constantly enthusiastic about living his life in a perfect state of mind.

Reminds me of my last boss, basically when I left my last office and started NBG architecture. He was a unique person, full of energy. Anytime I'll go to him and say, dan, we have a new project. He'll get excited, tell me what to do. He'll be always encouraging. But the unique thing was When I go to him and tell him that Dan, you know, we have a problem in this project.

And somebody's going to file a claim against us for errors and omniscience. Some of the things which we always dread to go to your boss and tell him because he will be disappointed. How can you do this, Neil? On the contrary, Dan will be all enthusiastic. Okay, if that's the case, let's do this. Call such and such person.

Let's make sure we do this enthusiasm in both cases I found very unique. He will not get upset because we have now a potential claim against us. But he will get all excited and say let's make sure that we are prepared to deal with it. I will never forget that. And it's now 20 years since I left the job. He now became the head of the entire organization which has 2100 people.

That shows what a person who can maintain his enthusiasm in all situations can achieve. In my own life, I've seen people achieving that. For one said that such a person, his intellect is steady. He does not get affected. His enthusiasm for acting in this world is not affected by the experience he is experiencing. So number one defined a role model.

A man of perfect wisdom. So we come to the conclusion if we achieve that state, we got it made. We don't have to do anything after that. Bhagavan said, no, you have to be very careful. So then Bhagavan gives us a warning that be aware that your senses are very powerful. Indriyani Pramatini, Harati Prasabham Manaha.

It can take away the tranquility of mind. Because the very nature of senses is to go out and get impressions of all the objects. So what we know about objects is not really the actual nature of the object but what we have perceived about that object. That is the nature of senses. Those perceptions created on my mind. If my mind is not careful or it's not under the control of my intellect.

Then it will get carried away again. And then it will lose its tranquility. So Bhagavan said, be careful. Therefore, a man of perfect wisdom moves around in this world like a tortoise that whenever it senses danger, it withdraws all its limbs. So man of perfect wisdom does not give up this world of plurality. He has to live in this world where he lives with his senses under control of his mind.

So mind is under the control of the intellect and senses are under the control of the mind. That is basically the state of a Perfect wisdom, Bhagavan Seta. So he moves around in that fashion. That is what we have seen in the last two verses. And it says everything starts from constant contemplation on sense object Visayan pansah. That is the root cause of all my troubles.

When I constantly think about something, it becomes my nature. And once I attach myself to the world of finite objects, then now I'm going to assign my happiness to that object that I have now mortgaged. My happiness to the world of objects. And therefore now I have to acquire them because my happiness mortgage with them. Bhagawan said that is the ladder of fall. He started thinking about something that created attachment.

That attachment creates desires. The desires unfortunately creates anger. Anger created delusion. That delusion created loss of intellect. And loss of intellect gets you destroyed. So this is the fall which we have seen.

So that means I have to work with the root cause of my problem is Bhagavan Buddha in his Arya Satya. He says, the first Sathya is that Dukkha exists. There is Dukkha in this world. The second one is that there is a cause for Dukkha. And what is the cause for Dukkha? Desire is the cause for all Dukkha.

So Bhagavan says the same thing here. Dhyaya TOU visayyanpunsa. He is the cause for all the problems. So how do I live in this world? The next three verses actually describe how to get out of this danger. Falling from this ladder of fall.

It says Ragtayhi to visayan indriyesh charan atma vashehi vide prasadam adhigh. So countering that tendency of thinking about objects and then getting attached to them and then falling into that trap, he said, the man of wisdom who has now realized, as we were discussed last time, that attachment is a mental phenomenon or a mental concept. Because my mind gets impression from the world of objects, it gets attached. Detachment, on the other hand, is very intellectual pursuit. Knowing fully well that this attachment is going to create sorrows for me, I try to detach myself from those attachments. How do I detach myself?

Bhagawan says raga dwese vyuktaihi to one who is devoid of likes and dislikes, Bhagawan has given us pointer how to become that. He said Tani sarvani samyamya yukta asita matparaha. In verse 61 he said, Here is the key. You will not be able to control your senses unless you have a higher goal. Turn your mind towards the higher goals. If your higher goal is engaging your mind then the impressions coming out of this world is not going to affect it.

It will not disturb it. When we are engrossed in doing something we are not aware of what's happening around us. Yukta, Asita, Matparaha. Have me in your mind all the time. Now that again sounds really ridiculous. Goal to have that my mind is always focused on Bhagavan.

Therefore I cannot think of anything else. No, actually once you realize that then nothing exists other than me. Everything you see, you should see me. Once I see all the objects are nothing but manifestations of the God. The impression of that object on my mind will be more divine than a finite image of that object. If you start seeing me in all things and beings then you will be able to control your mind.

If I see Bhagavan all supreme being, all things and being then question of likes and dislikes really does not come. I cannot have one part of Bhagavan I don't like. Another part of Bhagavan I like. That's truly not possible. We like everything about that person. Even his shortcomings we enjoy his shortcoming.

But person we don't like. Even his good qualities we don't enjoy. So once we identify with that supreme self, all his manifestations we will enjoy them all as they are. Because we will not have any judgment about an individual manifestation. So Bhagavan says Sachapa Raga, Dwese Viuktahi. Person who has become devoid of likes and dislikes.

Visayan Indre Charan. He moves around in this world of objects. Because there is no escape from this world of objects. We are part of this world and we have to live in this world. What do we want to achieve? We have to achieve within this world.

But how we act in this world is up to us. So I said one who is devoid of likes and dislikes. He is moving around with Atma Vashyahi, Vidhey Atma. He is self restrained. He is not getting carried away by one experience or the another. Vidheyatma, his self control.

Prasadam Adhi Gachadhi. He achieves that final result. And as we have discussed Prasad many times before, we are used to word Prasad after every puja we have Prasad. That Prasad is always sweet. That because the fruits of all my good actions sweet results. Here the result is tranquility of Mind the mind because it's not getting any impression which is negative.

No matter what impression comes from outside it sees a divine impression and therefore it is in a state of tranquility that is the prasad that's my final reward. Then nothing can upset my mind. Bhagavan said such a person Prasadam Adhighti achieves that final tranquility of mind that no experience can disturb the tranquility of mind. So Bhagawan says get out of likes and dislikes, see mean everything and then your mind will be constantly focused on me. Prasade Sarva Dukkha nam haani Yashi upa Jayate this is where we started. I want to learn Bhagavad Gita because I need to get rid of all my Dukkhas.

I want to get Bhagavan's Kupa because I want to get rid of all my sorrows and unhappiness. Bhagavan says there is a way to do it and it is not my doing, it is your doing. You have to do it yourself. When you control your mind, when you get out of likes and dislikes then you will get prasad of your own actions which with the tranquility of mind that tranquility of mind actually it removes the cause for all your sorrows. Bhagavan Buddha said there is a Dukkha and there is a cause for Dukkha and all you have to do is remove the cause for your Dukkha and then you achieve that Kaivalyam Prasadu Khanam. By this prasad all Dukkhas get destroyed.

Prasanna Cheta sah asu Buddhi pari avatist and for the one who is of tranquil mind, Chitta here Chitta Ekagra is also Chitta Ekagrita Chitta Ekagrita as we have discussed when Chitta only reflects nothing but definitive only Chitta is a mirror which is reflecting all the impressions from outside. When all these impressions are outside are divinized by my focusing on the divine self who created this cosmos out of his own self. As we have discussed before in this logic of causation that if this world exists there must be a Creator. The Creator needs to have two causes, Efficient cause and material cause. He is the efficient cause because he knew how to create this world but he also needed material and the material nothing but his own self.
