snippets.title: Day 39: The Wandering Mind
snippets.sanskrit:
इन्द्रियाणां हि चरतां यन्मनोऽनुविधीयते |

तस्माद्यस्य महाबाहो निगृहीतानि सर्वशः |

या निशा सर्वभूतानां तस्यां जागर्ति संयमी |
snippets.transliteration:
indriyāṇāṃ hi caratāṃ yanmano.anuvidhīyate .

tasmādyasya mahābāho nigṛhītāni sarvaśaḥ .

yā niśā sarvabhūtānāṃ tasyāṃ jāgarti saṃyamī .
verseTranslations: As a ship at sea is tossed by the tempest, so the reason is carried away by the mind when preyed upon by straying senses.
Therefore, O Might-in-Arms, he who keeps his senses detached from their objects - take it that his reason is purified.
The saint is awake when the world sleeps, and he ignores that for which the world lives.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge. Bhagavan gave us a roadmap for our journey from ignorance about ourselves to the knowledge of the Supreme. So we have seen step by step. How can I come out of this ignorance about myself? I consider this body as me, this mind as me, this intellect as me. The idea such as I think, therefore I am, creates attachment to my mind and my intellect.

And this body serves as my vehicle for all my experience in this world, which creates attachment to it. And therefore I consider death of this body is my death. I have not seen anybody coming back after he dies. Therefore I consider the death of this body is my death. So Bhagavan said, dehino asmin yatha de hay kaumaram yavanamjara tatha dehantra prapti diraha tatra namuhyati. Then you have seen changes in your life.

You have seen in your journey various states of existence. You existed as a child, as a youth, and also as an old man. Now he said, you're not confused by that, that does not delude you. These experiences which are different from each other has never confused you, who you are. You always consider, this is me. When I say I, it remains same no matter what state I was in, whether I was a child, a young man or an old man.

But once that did not confuse you. This also should not confuse you when you leave this body and take up another body. This is a hypothesis for us now because we do not have really any experience. But an idea was introduced to us of a reincarnation that this life is not only life. You lived many lives before where you created all your vasanas and tendencies. I have tendency to be artistic, somebody else's tendency to be athletic, and the other person is more intellectual.

Where all these tendencies are coming from? Bhagwan said these tendencies are because of your experiences in the past, before even you were born. And then he basically said that this journey is the one of inactivity. This journey is of activity. This journey you have to be active all your life. Then the question is how do I act in this world?

Bhagavan said, sukha du KE sami krutva laba la Bhav jaya Jayo Tatha Yudhaya Yudjistra that with a balanced mind you should act in this world. That's basically simple advice Bhagavan gave. Samatvam Yoga Uchate. Create balance in your mind in all the various experiences you're experiencing. And then you will be on your path to your destination. Your destination is to find perfect happiness.

Bhagawan said, you will find that if you act in this world with a balanced mind. Then my question is how do I keep a balanced mind with varied experiences in my life? And Bhagawan said, Yukta Asitha Matparaha. Keep an overarching goal which encompass everything. All your experiences and all your feelings and. And all your thoughts.

Then you will be able to balance your mind. If an overarching goal, then that goal becomes the destination. The goal will be reflected in those experiences. So we have all experienced that when you are in love, when you are fixated with one object, then. Then you see that in everything. When you fall in love, you see that person.

In all other persons you see that must be her, that must be him. Because my mind is so overpowered by that goal that I see everything in that. When I become first time a father or mother in all children, I see my child. Then my first time become grandfather. I see my granddaughter and grandson in all children. Because whatever is taking over your mind, you will reflect that in all your experiences.

If your mind is focused on me, if I am your supreme goal, then I will be reflected in all your experiences. So everything I see, I will see his manifestation. Everything I hear, I will hear his voice, his flute in that sound. So everything will become divine. Experience may be anything, but now my mind will not assign any other value but a divine value to it. Bhagawan said, Yukta Asitha Matparaha but to become Yukta Asitha Bhagavan says Tani Sarvani Samyamya by controlling all your senses.

Vasehi Indriyani One who is controlling the senses. Tasya Prajna Pratishtita his wisdom is steady. What he's seeing is to be seen. When my wisdom is steady, my mind is balanced. What I'm seeing is the reality. If my wisdom is not steady, if I assign different things as different values then my wisdom is not steady.

The result of that would be that I Will not have any sukha. I will not be at peace. So last verse which we discussed says, Na asti Buddhi, a Yuktashya, One who has no overarching goal. Yukta, one who is identified with the supreme goal. My supreme goal is really having Sukha and no Dukkha is my supreme goal. That overarching goal in my life is to avoid Dukkha and have Sukkah only ultimate happiness.

If that's my overarching goal. That happens when you are identified with the supreme self. Bhagavan says, the one who is not identified with the supreme goal is Ayuktaha. He has no goal, so anything will become his goal. Whatever the experience I have, I'll be attached to it. And then I will not know where my happiness lies.

It is something like when I was in India or in Africa. There were only few choices. There were only like two or three choices. Kesar, Pista or Kajoodraks. When I go to Low Garden in Ahmedabad, they were very clear. Not really a big question mark.

I come here and their Baskin Robbins has 31 flavors. Now how do I know which flavor is good? If I taste all 31 of them, then I come to conclusion which one I like. By the time I get to 31st flavor, I forget what the first flavor tastes like. I start all over again. So I really have no clue where my happiness lies.

Because every time I taste something, I think that's it. And then I say, but there are 30 other flavors. I need to try them also. Maybe there is one better than this. So Bhagawan said, one who is Ayuktaha who does not have this fixed goal of what he is trying to achieve. He will not have any Buddhi Na asti buddhi Ayuktasya.

He does not have wisdom what my goal is and where my happiness is. He also does not have any identification. His identification shifts from one goal to another. In one who is not identified with one goal, how can we have any peace? Because he agitated in his mind. Even when I'm achieving something, I think this may not be it.

There may be other things which other people are getting. And I'm not getting it. I should be going after them. I may be missing out something because of this coronavirus. People may be out there doing something. So Bhagawan said, Nacha abhaveda Santihi.

One who does not have the identification with his go. He does not ashanti and asantasya kuta Sukham. The one who is agitated wherever is happiness for him. We all know this that when mind is agitated there is no sukkah. Sukkah I only experience when there is no thought in my mind. Swamiji used to say I minus I want is happiness.

As long as there is I want, there cannot be any happiness. As long as I want there cannot be any peace in mind. Because there's agitation, I don't have it. I must be doing something which is not right. Or I may not be doing something which I should be doing now. Those things create asanti.

Such a person cannot have sukkham. If your goal is to get sukkah you need to quieten your mind. And then Bhagavan gives why it is very important that that you start with controlling your senses which we have seen. Dhyayato Visayan Punsaha. If I let my senses get impression of the sense objects then I keep thinking about them. Then I'll fall from the ladder.

So it says Indriyanam hi charatam yat mano anu vidhiyate. Is if my mind follows the wandering senses. Senses are involuntarily going out and getting impressions of the objects they are contacting. If I keep my eyes open and see outside the window there will be impression of what's outside of the window. But what I will see will depend on the disposition of my mind. I see my friend Omi Narayan every day.

He puts one picture of a bird or a flower or something on his Facebook post. Now when I see outside, I see buildings. I say, well that guy's house looks a little better. I think it could have been designed a little better than this. So this position of my mind is to say built world, not natural world. So the senses are involuntarily going out there and getting impressions of these sense objects outside.

It is the mind which creates impressions. It says Indriyanamhi Charatam. These wandering senses. The mind follows these wandering senses. In other words, getting attached to each object it sees and wants to keep thinking about it. Tadasya Harati Pragnam.

Now obviously he does not have wisdom of what is right and what is wrong for him. What to accept and what to reject. So the picture is worth thousand words. So Bhagavan gives this picture that just as a boat on the waters. If there is no controller, there is no boatman and it just boat by itself. It will be Tossed by the wind.

Wherever wind takes it, it will go. There is no fixed destination. If your mind follows every object which is perceived through the senses, then it will be tossed from one object to another. It does not have a goal and therefore it does not have any destination. My destination was happiness, but I lost my way because I have not fixed my destiny. I do not know where to go.

I am just driving, but do not know where I am going. And then Bhagavan says, tasmad Yasya Mahabha. And therefore, oh Mahabha, oh mighty arm. Bhagawan gives Arjuna a little boost of courage that you are capable of doing so, of controlling your senses. Nigru hitani sarvasah Indriyani indriyarthebhya. Therefore one who has control all his senses from the sense objects, Tasya prajna pratishvita, his wisdom is steady.

This is very difficult verse to understand because we think it is impossible, impossible to not have any perception of this world outside. The very job of senses is to perceive world outside. If my mind is completely inert and is not getting any impression, then I'll be basically a dead person. Swamiji says, if that's the case, if you're not perceiving anything, just let us know and we'll do your last rites. So you're a dead person. If that's the case, it is not possible for us to do that.

The very nature of senses is to get impressions in the very nature of mind is to get attached to those impressions. But what I will see as my mind depends on the disposition of my mind. If I have already fixed a goal that my goal is to have ultimate happiness and therefore I have to fix my mind on the ultimate self, then I will see the manifestation of that self in everything which I hear, I taste, I touch. So the people who are bhakta, when they listen to music, they see Krishna Bhakti in it. To them the music is for achieving God's Bhakti. Otherwise I sing film songs and it has different emotions in it.

आपूर्यमाणमचलप्रतिष्ठं

विहाय कामान्यः सर्वान्पुमांश्चरति निःस्पृहः |

एषा ब्राह्मी स्थितिः पार्थ नैनां प्राप्य विमुह्यति |
snippets.transliteration:
āpūryamāṇamacalapratiṣṭhaṃ samudramāpaḥ praviśanti yadvat .

vihāya kāmānyaḥ sarvānpumāṃścarati niḥspṛhaḥ .

eṣā brāhmī sthitiḥ pārtha naināṃ prāpya vimuhyati .
verseTranslations: He attains Peace, into whom desires flow as rivers into the ocean, which though brimming with water remains ever the same; not he whom desire carries away.
He attains Peace who, giving up desire, moves through the world without aspiration, possessing nothing which he can call his own, and free from pride.

O Arjuna! This is the state of the Self, the Supreme Spirit, to which if a man once attain, it shall never be taken from him. Even at the time of leaving the body, he will remain firmly enthroned there, and will become one with the Eternal."
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 2, Sankhya Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge. And we are coming to the end of chapter two and we will be discussing last three verses today and then we'll move on to Karma Yoga, Yoga of Action. So what we have learned so far in chapter two, which happens to be the whole summary of Bhagavad Gita. So all the ideas and the basic philosophy of Bhagavad Gita is summarized in chapter 2, first section of about 10 verses. The most important verse was verse 7 where Arjuna said, karpanya dosho aphatva Bavah that my nature is tainted, is overwhelmed by the taint of beauty, and I do not know what is right and wrong for me. I don't know what is my Dharma.

Dharma Asammuda Cheta Saha. My Buddhi does not tell me right now what is my right Dharma at this time. This is Shishya te Ahm. So he admits that I need guidance. I need someone to tell me what is right. Therefore tell me so Nishitam.

Without any wavering, tell me what is right for me. So the first section gives us our condition sometimes in life that we are completely overwhelmed by the situation and we cannot see what is right and wrong for us. But where we differ from Arjuna is still our ego doesn't give us that humility to say, I'm completely confused, I am your student. Give me guidance from someone who we think can give us guidance. Even at the point of confusion and delusion, we try to hang on to our ego and try to solve our problems ourselves. And therefore we can't see how to get out of this problem.

Because we are in the problem, we need to surrender to someone who can see it from outside and have complete faith in his advice and guidance and say, I'm going to follow whatever you tell me, just tell me. Because I can figure out right now what we typically do is we still carry our ego to whoever we are seeking advice from. Then say, look, Kodan well, okay. But what does he know? My problem only I know. That's why we fail to get the benefit of an advice.

So Bhagavan did not say anything in chapter one because he didn't see that he's ready yet. Swamiji says, even giving advice to a wrong person, wrong time can give more harm than help. Somebody is not ready to take the advice and you come and say, let me tell you, my son. He has to be ready before I can tell him what is right for him. So the first thing we have seen is at the time when you reach a point of complete confusion in your life you have to surrender. And in this case, if nothing else, surrender to my own conscience which is Bhagavan and say, give me guidance.

You tell me I don't know. My intellect cannot come to the conclusion what is right or wrong. And then obviously we have seen all the guidance Bhagavan gave. So he first changes his paradigm of what he thinks he was. You are not who you think you are. This limited being which you have considered yourself to be you, is not really you.

This is just your equipment. This body, mind and intellect which currently I consider it to be me, is actually nothing but my equipment. So if I can realize that this is something which is mine and cannot be me then I will be able to realize who I am and then able to get the benefit of that wisdom which comes to me. So Bhagavan has changed his paradigm and said, you are that imperishable being. And then we have seen the explanation of just as you change their clothes, you will change the body as well. But you remain the same.

Just as you change from the childhood to the youth to the old age, from this life you'll move on to the next life. The advice given by Bhagavan is how to live life. Sukhadu khe samay kritva laba labava jayajayo yudhaya yujyaswa naivam papam avapsya sri in verse 38. So here is how you should live your life. Not a life of inaction, not a life of complete detachment from your duties but complete detachment from what's happening. What I'm experiencing, completely having that understanding that all things are transitory.

They are finite in nature and time space. So sukha du khasame krutva. You remain same, not that sukha dukha. I'll experience the same way. One will be pleasurable, one will be not pleasurable, will be painful. But I enjoy the pleasurable Experience and where the painful experience both time keeping in mind that this is just a passing phase in a finite experience.

How I keep my balance Victory and defeat in our life, we obviously constantly winning and losing. We're winning an argument, we are winning a negotiation, we are losing a deal. Marketing people teach you that everyone is selling something. You may not consider yourself a salesman, but you are selling something to somebody, selling your idea to your spouse, which vacation to take. You have to sell your idea first. So you're constantly selling and marketing and winning and losing in life, and you keep your balance.

Just as you don't really get upset when you lose your argument, sometimes we do, but you're not supposed to because you understand still we are one family. snippets.reflection:
Take a few moments today to consider: What would change if you truly believed that your essential Self cannot be harmed? Not as a comforting platitude, but as a lived reality?

When fear arises today, experiment with asking: 'What is it that's aware of this fear?' That awareness itself is untouched by what it witnesses. This is the key insight of these verses.

Notice the experiences of pleasure and pain that come to you today. Can you see them as contacts between your senses and sense objects—temporary, impermanent, coming and going like waves? Bear them with equanimity, knowing they will pass.

snippets.title: Day 41: Why Action?
snippets.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच |

व्यामिश्रेणेव वाक्येन बुद्धिं मोहयसीव मे |

श्रीभगवानुवाच |

arjuna uvāca .

vyāmiśreṇeva vākyena buddhiṃ mohayasīva me .

śrībhagavānuvāca .

You become a saxhicaitanya. Basically when you take a role of a Janakbha as an employee you have to work as an employee very effectively. When Janakbhai is in a spirituality Janakbhai has to establish in the spirituality. So the answer is not very clear so that Janakbhai can say Deepak bhai tell me one thing, you are not helping me here.

Janakbhai is one and you are telling me to be two different Janakbai So this is not Janakbhai's newly minted question. This question Arjuna had 5,000 years ago. In last chapter in verse 49, the Durenahiyavaram Karmaha Buddhi Yoga Dhananjaya. So therefore you said engage yourself in a Buddhi Yoga. You clearly told me that Tatkim Karmani Ghore mam. Then why are you asking me to fight this war? This, this is like person interested in physics wants to find out what light is all about. He said it depends on the observer. Observer can decide it's a particle or it's a wave. So Bhagavan said, karma is necessary, but Buddhi Yoga is also necessary. One is superior than other depending on where you are. Vya Mishrena Vakhena Buddhim Moha Yasi Evame. This mixed Mishrena you are going the two mixed messages.

You are speaking from both sides of your mouth. One side saying go fight the war, that's okay, kill those people. Other side says, establish yourself in Buddha knowledge. This is confusing my intellect. This statements have already confused my intellect. Tad Ekam Vadanishchtya.

Therefore obviously I am your Srishya. I already told you I am your Shishya. You tell me what is good for me. So don't go into this great arguments about which one is better. Tell me one thing that will be the best for me which will be Shreyas which is good for me. As you are saying shres and prayers.

Something which is pleasant but may not be good for me but something you tell me. It may not be pleasant but tell me this is good for you. And I already told you, I surrender to you. I will do whatever you tell me. And then comes the whole chapter 3 karma yoga bhagavan said Sri Bhagavanu Vacha Now Bhagavan is elaborating in what Karma is all about. Loke Asmin d Vidha Nistha Pura Prukta Maya Anaga don't get confused.

There is not only one path in this world. Loki Asm in this world. Dvivida Nishta I have established two paths. Because you need to give people alternates. You have to have choice. Pura Prokta Mayan Right from the beginning I established two paths.

This is the first time as lots of commentators say. Bhagavan comes out clearly and said I'm not Vasudeva Krishna. I am the Supreme Lord. That right from the beginning of this world I established two paths. So you always had two options available from the day one. The day I forgot myself as who I am.

From the day I forgot that I am the Supreme Being and taken up this identity as me, this limited being, I had two paths available. Loki Asmin Dyudanista My loka started when the very first thought that I am who I am, this limited being. And Bhagawan says there are always two paths available. It is like I'm going to New York. My goal is to reach New York and just around the Delaware where it has two paths. One goes to New Jersey Turnpike, another 95 going through Philadelphia and all that.

I get confused and say which way I'm going. Well, I have two paths available. I can go through the 95 and I still reach New York. And I can go through New Jersey Turnpike and I'll still reach New York. So Tupa is always available to me. Gnana Yogina Sankhyana for those who are established in contemplation, those who are contemplative type.

For them Gnana Yoga Yoga of Knowledge, Karma Yogi and a yoginand. Those who are action oriented. For them Karma is established. Two paths are available to us. Either you have to work through your way to your goal or realize how to get there quickly. If I realize the New Jersey Turnpike will be quicker and I'll take quicker path.

If not, I'll work through my way through 95, going through the smaller town, all of that and traffic then reaching both will lead me. There is also something similar to. In our Indian system of marriage, okay. In Indian system, I say, well, if you want to get married, you have two parts. I'm not sure what is there now. Either you can have love marriage.

You fall in love, find somebody and then get married. Or arrange marriage, find somebody, get married and then fall in love. Both ultimately culminating into what? One starts out by knowing first who I want to marry. Knowledge occurs to me that one I like and then I get married. But then I work towards how to live together, what marriage is all about.

All that takes place after Meena said, I never knew you're this swaroopa till I got married. Even though we were dating for three years. On the other hand, you get married to somebody, you work through an arranged marriage. Then you have to fall in love with her. Ultimate goal is what is to identify. Right now my identification is with this limited self.

My goal is to identify with the supreme self. So identification has to change. When occurs, it becomes love. When I start identifying, then only I can love somebody. I cannot love someone I never met. So I have to first know someone to fall in love with her.

In Swamiji, always you fall in love, you rise in devotion. So to love someone, you have to know the person. So to love the divine, you have to know the divine, that bhakti. Eventually you're trying to achieve the Bhakti Yoga. That's your goal, to have devotion for the Lord. But I cannot devote to somebody whom I do not know.

I love God, but I don't know who. That is not possible. So I have two paths to achieve that devotion. When I get the knowledge that who I am, that I am not this limited self, contemplating on who I am not, and I get the knowledge who I am, then I'll identify with that self.
snippets.reflection:
Choose one action today—any action—and practice doing it with full attention but without attachment to results. Whether it's sending an email, having a conversation, or completing a task, offer it as best you can and then release your grip on the outcome.

Notice what happens when you work this way. Is there more freedom? More presence? More energy? The Gita's teaching of Karma Yoga isn't about becoming passive or indifferent. It's about working with full engagement while remaining internally free.

Ask yourself: Where in my life am I most attached to results? What would change if I could offer my best effort and then surrender the outcome?

snippets.title: Day 43: The Superior Path
snippets.sanskrit:

yastvindriyāṇi manasā niyamyārabhate.arjuna .

niyataṃ kuru karma tvaṃ karma jyāyo hyakarmaṇaḥ .

yajñārthātkarmaṇo.anyatra loko.ayaṃ karmabandhanaḥ .
verseTranslations: But, O Arjuna! All honour to him whose mind controls his senses, for he is thereby beginning to practise Karma-Yoga, the Path of Right Action, keeping himself always unattached.
Do thy duty as prescribed, for action for duty's sake is superior to inaction. Even the maintenance of the body would be impossible if man remained inactive.
In this world people are fettered by action, unless it is performed as a sacrifice. Therefore, O Arjuna, let thy acts be done without attachment, as sacrifice only.
snippets.commentary:
So far we have seen that in the dilemma of whether to work in this world or renounce actions. We have discussed many times in this discussion that the action which is an interaction between I and this world creates impression. This impressions on my mind creates tendencies, these tendencies create desires, the desires create actions. And then cycle starts all over again. More I act, more I'll interact with this world. That interaction will have this cause and effect relationship.

This cycle seems like never ending cycle that I can never get out of this. And the whole purpose of all this studies is to get out of this cycle. So obviously Arjuna is confused whether he should act by fighting this war or renounce all these actions and go to Himalaya. So that's where we started the chapter and last verse. We have seen Bhagavan Singh Niyatam Kuru Karmatwam Very firm prescription. You must do all your ordained duties.

Niyatam Kuru Karmatvam Karma Jayahi Akarma Naha Because Karma is superior than inaction. Action is superior than inaction. So very simple, very clear that what you should do in life is do your ordained duties. And, and we have seen in last discussion, the ordained duties are. Daily duties which we can't really escape. Brushing your teeth, taking bath, going to work, all these Nitya Karma, there's nothing special about it.

Nobody is going to congratulate you every morning for brushing your teeth unless you are a little three year old child. Then Naymithya Karma which are the special duties, when something required by your family, your community, your society, your nation, then you have to perform those duties. You're not doing those duties every day. On special occasions you're required to participate. Either you have voluntary army or a draft. If you're not volunteering on your own to protect your country, there will be a draft.

You have to draft you because that's required a special duty. So Bhagavan says Niyyatam Kuro Karma tum. Then Niyata Karma includes both the Nitya and Nainitya that means there is no escape from any duty. Swamiji, give example that your friend is sick and he needs your help. That time you can say I am very busy. You can, but that means you are shirking your duty.

You are not doing your part. So Bhagawan very clearly says Nidham Kuru Karma Thomas Karma Jyay or Karmanaha Karma is anytime better than inaction. Action is anytime better than inaction. Sari Yatra Apicha Tena prasiddayat or Karmanah. By inaction you can't even sustain your body. We can understand that even to sustain my body, I have to act.

And therefore action is prescribed here. So now we are still in the conundrum. On one hand we want to liberate ourselves from this bondage and other hand we have to act. So it looks like catch 22. So the next four verses, as Swamiji says, are laid out as the overall scheme of thing as the Creator has created how to act and how to be liberated from your actions, not bound by your actions. Also, when this world is created, there should be a plan for sustaining it.

So the whole plan is laid out in the next few verses. And I obviously had been listening to Swamiji from the Cold War era. And Swamiji used to say, don't blame me or don't put me in jail because it sound like I'm a communist or a socialist. The Krishna who is socialist, not me. Where Krishna now lays out the whole path of socialism in the next four verses, Swamiji says, there is no real social nation on this planet because everybody is. Even though communist countries, there are people who are just for their power.

That's not what the socialism is all about. So the next four verses lay out the whole plan of sustaining this universe and you being a part of that universe. How you can participate but not get bound by your actions. So the next verse says, Yajnar Thaat Karmano anyatra Loko Ayam Karma Bandanaha. Actions other than those performed for the Yajna are binding Loko yam in this loka in this world. This Loka is bound by Kun, cause and effect.

Everything in this world is bound by cause and effect. There is nothing in this world is free from cause and effect. Therefore, we give this standard example. If I see something in this room, it's an effect. If I see a table in this room, it's an effect. And I cannot say that this table has no cause.

Where did this table come? Kneel and say, we are chinma mission, we don't want to do anything. And table appears here. Obviously nobody will believe me because you know I bought it from somewhere. Even if I didn't buy it, I stole it from somebody. So buy, borrow or steal.

Only three ways we can acquire things. Table is in effect, so it must have a cause. This cause has two aspects, efficient cause and a material cause. Someone who knew how to make this table is the efficient cause carpenter and the material cause, the wood which was required. So having this relationship of cause and effect, this table comes into existence. So in this loca everything is bound by cause and effect.

So if you act, there will be an effect. So you will be bound by this cause and effect. If you are acting for your own desires, for your own betterment, for your own good only. But if you are working for the betterment of the whole society, for the cosmic order, then you are bound by one thing. So yajna karmano van Yatra, actions performed for the Yajna. Obviously we know culturally that it's a ritual of offering sacrifices in the fire.

But the original meaning, the significance of Yajna in Vedic period was to propitiate the deities who are in charge of this elemental forces. As a observant person, we realize that there are two aspects of my success. One is my own efforts, but then also the environment in which I'm putting my efforts. I may be very hard working farmer where if there is no rain, obviously I will not have any success. So I know that something other than me is participating in my success. So that's we call it Devam.

That's something destiny we call it. So these phenomenal forces are the ones I don't have control over. One year there is a lot of rain, the other year there is a drought and third year there is just appropriate rain. How do I control that? There must be some controller who decides this. That controller we call deva.

Maybe there is a controller who controls this rain, a deva. So if we appease those devas, it will be good for the whole society and there will be rain for the whole society. This yajnas were the cooperative endeavor to appease the deities of phenomenal forces. So the purpose was to have a common good where everyone can benefit in the community. Therefore you hear the story about in Bhagavad, Krishna lifting the govardhan parvat. You know how it all started.

Krishna was a reformer. Everybody was doing yajna to Indra. Krishna said, why are you Offering this Yajna to Indra. Indra is not doing anything for you. These cows are doing supporting you. This Mother Earth is supporting.

Let's have Yajna for the cows and lay Yajna for the earth. That's from Mother Earth. Mother Cow, they are supporting us, not Indra. So Indra got mad and then the whole story goes he sent all the storms and hurricanes and typhoons or whatever. And then Krishna protects them under the Govardhan Parvat. Even though he was holding it, everyone else was supporting it with their sticks.

And then in the end what do we have? Because of the rain, there's so much food that when all the rains subsided, everybody said let's have a party. Everybody brought their own food. So there was Annakut. There was like the mountain of food. So if you think that Patlak was started in America, Krishna started Patlak from that Govardhan Parvat there.

So the whole idea is that we have a capacity to work together for the common good. When we work together for common good that include my good also. But not just my good, but everyone else's good as well. Those actions are considered Yajna actions. Bhagavan says all the actions performed in that spirit are not binding. You may be acting in your profession but if you're only acting for the salary then that's a self esteem.

But reacting because you are improving the other people's lives. By participating as a doctor, as engineer, you're making the society better and making everyone's life easier. It's a Yajna actions. Actions performed in the spirit of Yajna are non binding. All others are binding. So here is your escape hatch.

You can continue doing whatever you are doing. Just change the attitude that I'm not doing it for myself, I'm doing it for the greater good. Whether I'm an architect, a doctor, a housewife, a mother, everything I'm doing is not just for me but for the overall good of the society, the community, the cosmos, the universe. So Yajna Karmano Anyatna Loko Yam Karma Bandanah Tadartam Karma Kantaya Mukta Sangha Samacharah. Therefore here is the clear advice. Perform actions in the Yajna spirit for Yajna without any attachment.

Perform your actions. Nothing you have to change in your life. Purely your attitude towards your actions. I'm doing these actions because it will help the Entire society. Therefore we have this now new awareness about green buildings, green society, energy savings. Nothing new we had in our culture.

Therefore when I go for my presentations on this green initiative, I say well, I never had to learn because it comes from my culture. We respected the mother earth, we respected nature because we understood those Vedic people understood the value of nature and our participation. Therefore Bhagavan says Tadartam Karma Kaunteya Tadhartam for the Yajna. That Yajna therefore act for Yajna only Mukta Sangha without attachment. Not having the attachment that I am the doer. I am the only one who can do this.

Because you are just a part of the whole society. You are not an island by yourself. By yourself you are worthy of doing nothing. Just simple act of me coming to this class, I cannot do by myself. So many people have to do so many things. Police have to make sure that there are no crimes on the road.

Roads are clear, the traffic is properly regulated. BMW has to make a car so I can drive a car. Gas companies have to put the gas in the gas stations. All that when it all come together, I can make the simple move from my house to within center if I recognize that. Bhagavan said you are Mukta Sangha. You are detached from your actions.

Sahayagnaha Prajaha Srishtva Purow vacha Prajapati. So how all this Bhagavan says started creator when he created this universe, he knew that he has to sustain it. So how are we going to. If we create something and we do not know how to sustain, we start a business. But you know how to sustain the business. If you start any endeavor or create any creation, you have to make sure you maintain it, you sustain it.

So you have to have a plan for that. You have painting artists create. You have to have a plan for how you are going to protect it, where you are going to display it, how to preserve it. So there is always a plan for sustaining something when you create it. Therefore, in Hindu trinity there is a creator, a sustainer and a destroyer.
snippets.reflection:
Choose one action today—any action—and practice doing it with full attention but without attachment to results. Whether it's sending an email, having a conversation, or completing a task, offer it as best you can and then release your grip on the outcome.

Notice what happens when you work this way. Is there more freedom? More presence? More energy? The Gita's teaching of Karma Yoga isn't about becoming passive or indifferent. It's about working with full engagement while remaining internally free.

Ask yourself: Where in my life am I most attached to results? What would change if I could offer my best effort and then surrender the outcome?

snippets.title: Day 44: The Wheel of Creation
snippets.sanskrit:
सहयज्ञाः प्रजाः सृष्ट्वा पुरोवाच प्रजापतिः |

देवान्भावयतानेन ते देवा भावयन्तु वः |

इष्टान्भोगान्हि वो देवा दास्यन्ते यज्ञभाविताः |
snippets.transliteration:
sahayajñāḥ prajāḥ sṛṣṭvā purovāca prajāpatiḥ .

devānbhāvayatānena te devā bhāvayantu vaḥ .

iṣṭānbhogānhi vo devā dāsyante yajñabhāvitāḥ .
verseTranslations: In the beginning, when God created all beings by the sacrifice of Himself, He said unto them: Through sacrifice you can procreate, and it shall satisfy all your desires.
Worship the Powers of Nature thereby, and let them nourish you in return; thus supporting each other, you shall attain your highest welfare.
For, fed, on sacrifice, nature will give you all the enjoyment you can desire. But he who enjoys what she gives without returning is, indeed, a robber.'
snippets.commentary:
So we are now discussing chapter three. Karma Yoga, Yoga of action. We typically evaluate before getting into any sphere of activity. What are my limitations? If I want to take a particular major in the university? Am I good at mathematics or I'm good at science or arts?

Once I decide what my limitations are, then I say how I can develop my capabilities in that field. And then that becomes the field of my choice. So in Bhagavad Gita, Bhagavan in chapter two, give us our limitations. That Karmaniyeva adhikarahte ma faleshukajana. Our limitation is to act in the present only. And we have no control over the fruits.

So that's our limitation Bhagavan has given us. Therefore, Bhagavan said that do not worry about the fruits. They are not in your capabilities. You never get attached to inactivity. You focus on your actions. And then for development of my capabilities, then Bhagavan said, Yogastha Guru Karmani, establish yourself.

Yoga is nothing but the balance of mind, equanimity of mind. So once you know your limitations that I have no control over the fruits, but I do have control over my actions, then I have to now become more efficient in my action. And therefore Bhagavan said that Yoga Isthaha. Establish yourself in Yoga, you guys. Develop balance of your mind while acting. When your mind is imbalanced, there is no way you can act efficiently.

So once you establish the equanimity of your mind, then Yoga, Karma, Sukhaoshalam, that will be the result. You will become very efficient in your actions. You will be very dexterous in your actions if you can balance your mind. So your job is only to balance your mind no matter what the situation is. Because you will be acting in this world in myriads of situations. Situations are not in your control.

They will be controlled by the world of phenomena, the world outside the people of the world. You have no control over that. But you have to continuously act. Because you cannot stay without any activity. You cannot Change the situation. But you can change the way you perceive and work in this activity.

In one of these TV serials I heard a very interesting line. If you cannot change the Paristhidi then change your Manasthiti. And I thought it's very profound statement. If you can change the circumstances outside, you can at least change your mental reaction to it. Manasthiti, the state of your mind you can change because you cannot change the situation outside. The Bhagavan said Samatvam Yoga Ucha de balance of mind in all situations.

Now that I have learned how to work efficiently, I need to know what is the field of my activity and what spirit I should be acting. So the last verse we have discussed is Yajnarthaat Karmano Anyatra Loko Yam Karmabandana Tad Artam Karma Kohantea Yajnaartha Karma Kauntiya. So Bhagawan has now given us the field of activity that Yajna is the field of your activity. And we have defined Yajna as cooperative activity for the greater good. Dedicated action sacrifice. So Yajna is basically people come together in a spirit of sacrifice.

Each one sacrifice something of his own for the betterment of the community. So Bhagavan said, that's the field and the spirit. If you act with all the capabilities you have developed by that samatvam employed in Yajna Yajna Lokoyam Karma Bandanaham Actions performed other than for Yajna are binding. We know that action is bound by its own reaction. By law of physics Newton taught us in high school at least that action and reaction are equal and opposite. Anytime there is an action, there will be reaction.

So the action is bound by the law of Karma. My actions are bound by law of actions. So I'm bound by the result of my action. Once I perform action, I have no control over the result. And as the actor I will be affected by the result. So my action will have a reaction from the world.

That reaction is now the effect of the cause which was my action. Now the reaction from the world when I react to becomes another cause for the reaction by the world. So that chain starts the chain of cause and effect. Once I start the chain, I will be the only one who can break is I who can stop that chain by not reacting to the reaction of my action. So if I do not react to the fruit of my action then I'll be able to break that chain of that action which I started. Therefore, Bhagawan said Yajna onyatra lokuam Karma, bandana, action which I'm performing for gaining something benefiting from my action are all binding.

All actions are binding. But if I am performing action not for me but for the greater good then I'm not really expecting anything particularly for me and therefore there is no reaction from me and I'll stop that chain reaction. That's why Bhagavan said the karmas performed in Yajna are non binding to you as a person. Those karmas will be binding to the community for which you have performed that Yajna. Those karmas will be binding to the group of people benefit from those actions but not you personally. So Bhagawan says therefore Yajnaartaat Karma, Kauntiya, Mukta Sangha, Samacharah without attachment, now you attach yourself into it.

That I'm doing this so that the community will benefit. That will also benefit me. That attachment will again bind you. But if you are not attached to your actions in the first place and then to the results in the second place then you are completely free. So Mukta Sangha sam acharaha perform those actions. And then the next verse now says that this is the universal design.

This is not something Bhagavan said I came up with just to give you this advice. This is the original design, universal design, how this universe should function. The next verse says Saha Yagnaha, Prajaha, Srushtva, Pura uvacha. Prajapati said that I created Yajna and Prajaya at the same time. So Praja here is all beings. It is now narrowed down to human beings.

Because everything in this world other than human beings working in compliance with the laws of nature, everything is cooperating and complementing each other except when it comes to human beings. We have free will and we become the disruptors if we are not working in this spirit of Yajna. So Bhagawan said, when I created Praja, I also create a Yajna with it. There is a creative force in nature. That creative force is evolving things. And when it comes to a level of evolution that you can function on your own, Prajapati says, I have created Praja but I also created the spirit of Yajna with it.

By this you shall prosper. But I'm giving you means to support yourself, means to prosper yourself. This is your milch cow. This is your Kamadenu. And we obviously all know about the mythology of Kamadhenu the sacred cow which is capable of fulfilling all your desires. So in mythology the cow came out of churning of ocean and it is also described as a cow's body with human female head and bird's wings.

So it is basically combination of all beings. The this Kamadenu is all beings. The birds and animals and human beings all working together can fulfill any desire. In this case your Yajna is the Kamadenu. This cooperative spirit and the actions performed in Yajna are capable of giving you whatever you desire. When I created Praja, I created spirit of Yajna.

We know that everything in this world has has to be working together. And every one of us have to contribute our own share for the betterment of the community. So if I am living in Hendrico county and enjoying all the services Hendrico county offers, I have to contribute my part as paying taxes. If every citizen decides that I'm not going to pay my taxes, there won't be any services after a while. So Bhagavan said, you do your part, but if you work in this cooperative manner, you shall prosper. You will get anything you desire by this Yajna.

And the next verse says Devan Bhavayat vanena te Deva Bhavayantu vaha parasparam Bhavayantaha Sreiyah param avapshata Bhagawan explains how it works. Cherish the Devas with this Yajna. You nurture Devas with your cooperative actions. Because your existence in this universe is not that of an island. You as an individual, as you consider is not really an individual. You're just part of the big whole.

And in this universe everything is connected to everything. And therefore if each part is not working in a right manner, which we call it Dharma Chakra, if that's not working, then there cannot be any progress. There cannot be any evolution. Deva Bhavyatan, we have discussed Deva before. Deva etymologically means that which is shining. So you know in a vernacular language you have Dhyan deeper.

So Diva is that which is shining in human beings. Our senses are shining. Our senses illuminate the world outside. So these senses can only work if I nurture those senses. So for me, even the individual to function properly, I have to nurture my senses. Then the same senses will nurture me.

Deva Bhavayantuvah, those Devas will then nurture you. You nurture Devas and Devas will nurture you in an individual level. If I take care of my senses, then my senses will nourish me. At the universal level, the phenomenal forces are considered devas. So in our mythological stories, The Devas are 33 Karod Devas or 33 Koti. The 33 great elements are the devas.

Somewhere in comment Swamiji has listed those Devas, you know, 8 Vasus, 12 Rudras, etc. In other words, everything in this world is important. And unless every element of this universe is taken care of, the universe cannot function as it's supposed to be. Everything in the universe is working as per the laws of nature. The human beings have to be disciplined. And now in today's situation, we all know about the climate change, the green movement.

We know that world would have worked perfectly fine if we have not created the problem with the environment. Anytime I want to get something out of the environment, I have to make sure the environment is not affected. But which is where we are failing. I actually read a very interesting theory on Facebook or WhatsApp where the theory was that this coronavirus has come out because of 5G network. The presenter was so convincing and he relates all the coincidences saying when the electricity was invented, then we had this great flu and all the pandemics were related to the development in electricity and how we use the electricity. And the Latest is this 5G.

And the Wuhan was the main center of that 5G. Now there may not be any basis in this theory, but one thing is entirely possible, that if we do not use the natural resources with understanding, then it can create disasters which we have not anticipated. The global warming, we are all now experiencing the results of them. So here Bhagawan said, you take care of the nature and nature will take care of you. How can I as an individual take care of the nature? Bhagavan said, if you act in the spirit of Yajna, that every action that you perform, if you analyze and see that it is for the greater good and not just for me.

So Ezra Plate says that will produce more than we consume, will give more than we take. If I have that attitude of Yajna, the sacrifice, I'm sacrificing my actions for the greater good. Because you are cherishing Devas and those Devas, those phenomenal forces will then cherish you, will nurture you.

snippets.title: Day 45: Food and Sacrifice
snippets.sanskrit:
यज्ञशिष्टाशिनः सन्तो मुच्यन्ते सर्वकिल्बिषैः |

अन्नाद्भवन्ति भूतानि पर्जन्यादन्नसम्भवः |

कर्म ब्रह्मोद्भवं विद्धि ब्रह्माक्षरसमुद्भवम् |
snippets.transliteration:
yajñaśiṣṭāśinaḥ santo mucyante sarvakilbiṣaiḥ .

annādbhavanti bhūtāni parjanyādannasambhavaḥ .

karma brahmodbhavaṃ viddhi brahmākṣarasamudbhavam .
verseTranslations: The sages who enjoy the food that remains after the sacrifice is made are freed from all sin; but the selfish who spread their feast only for themselves feed on sin only.
All creatures are the product of food, food is the product of rain, rain comes by sacrifice, and sacrifice is the noblest form of action.
All action originates in the Supreme Spirit, which is Imperishable, and in sacrificial action the all-pervading Spirit is consciously present.
snippets.commentary:
So we are now discussing chapter three, Karma Yoga, Yoga of Action. We have seen so far, Raghavan says. Sa yagnaha prajaha srushtva pura uacha Prajapati an inna prasivaschiddam isha bah twastikamadhu. In the beginning, when the Prajapati created beings Praja, he also created Yajna. So we are right now concerned about Praja. Praja means human beings.

So the Lord of Praja is Prajapati. The one who propagates progeny is Prajapati. So from that perspective all parents are Prajapati. So we are Prajapati for our Praja, for our children. So what we do for our children is not that we have given them life or created their existence, but we also have to create sustenance for them. So what we do is we give them education.

Then say this education will be your milch cow. Use this education to get whatever you want. Prajapati is mentioned in Hiranya Gharba Sukta in Dhruva. So the Rig Veda says that previously there was nothing but Hiranyagarbha. So Hiranya Garbha is something like the condition before the Big Bang. All the potentiality but no reality.

So there is a singularity or the potentiality but no reality. So that Hiranya Garbha then out of its own potential, its own creative urgent, creates a mind. This is also mentioned in Brihadaranya Upanishad and Chandogya Upanishad. Brihadaranyak Upanishad describes this Hirinyagarba. Thus he says, first there was nothing but death and hunger. So death means nothingness.

There is nothing, there is nothing to devour, nothing to enjoy by senses, because there are no senses, there is nothing. And then he creates mind out of his creative force. And with that mind he creates water. And then water create a fire, then whatever in the water solidifies and becomes earth. So basically the creation is explained from the beginning, when there was no creation from the no creation to creation and then a being is born in that and that's it. That being said let this body of mine be fit for a sacrifice.

So that's the creation of your prajapati. In our modern day scriptures we say brahma is the prajapati. Brahma is the creator is the prajapati. But here prajapati is very defined as the pati of praja the beings. See in our puranas we also have daksha prajapati. He is lord of all beings.

In daksha his father in law was a prajapati. So there are several versions of this word prajapati but basically here in this case it means the primordial being from which the praja came. And then obviously that being was also concerned how this praja will prosper for any family man his goal is to expand his family. So it actually says anayne prasivishadvam, may you propagate your progeny through this. May you multiply with this. We also can take it as may you grow with this.

And then he said that this yajna which I have created is your milchka the sacrifice. That which I have created is the giver of all that you desire, all that you need. That's what Bhagavan started in saying. Sacrifice was created, Spirit of sacrifice was created at the same time the praja was created. The praja can only sustain itself by sacrifice. That basically was the intention of that verse.

And it almost seems like that the whole idea comes from the Brihadaranya Upanishad. The same idea is also in Kathopani sadh. So basically there is a being who is the first created being. This will be similar to the christian theory of Adam being the first man. It says that ishtakamadhu for you this will be your milchka, the sacrifice. The spirit of sacrifice will be all that you need.

And then from that you can get anything that you want. Uprisa also says prajapati has two types of sons. One are the devas and other asuras. Now even if we don't get into our Puranic and Vedic theories of our devas and asuras at our micro level the devas are our senses. And if I take care of my senses, my senses will take care of me. If I take care of my eyes, I will take care of my world of seeing.

If I take care of my ears, my ears will take care of my world, of my sound my world will be taken care of if I take care of my senses. So he said that you nourish the Devas and Devas will nourish you. At a global level or universal, we can say devas are the phenomenal forces, the nature. If I cherish nature, nature will cherish me. And probably it was difficult to understand this concept 100 years ago. But in today's time, with the global warming and all the concern about climate change, we can understand that if we as human beings don't take care of the climate, the environment, the environment will not be able to support us as a species on this planet.

The Bhagavan said that you nourish Devas and Devas will nourish you. With that cooperative relationship, thou shall prosper. Yagna sista asinah santah muchante sarvakilbishaihi. The good people, the righteous one, they eat the remnants of the Yajna. And by eating the remnants of the yajna they are freed from all sins. So as we have seen that the idea is not to just take whatever is left over from Yajna, but the product, the profit which we make out of our cooperative endeavor, that if I share only portion which comes rightfully to me, then I don't have a guilty feeling.

If I run a company, there's a profit. If I don't become so greedy that nobody else get, everybody suffers. But I get the lion's share but once. As we have seen earlier, if you get the lion's share of what comes out of the collective activity, everybody has put their sacrifice in it. They put their efforts in it. What came out of that activity.

snippets.title: Day 47: Work Without Attachment
snippets.sanskrit:
तस्मादसक्तः सततं कार्यं कर्म समाचर |

कर्मणैव हि संसिद्धिमास्थिता जनकादयः |

यद्यदाचरति श्रेष्ठस्तत्तदेवेतरो जनः |
snippets.transliteration:
tasmādasaktaḥ satataṃ kāryaṃ karma samācara .

karmaṇaiva hi saṃsiddhimāsthitā janakādayaḥ .

yadyadācarati śreṣṭhastattadevetaro janaḥ .
verseTranslations: Therefore do thy duty perfectly, without care for the results, for he who does his duty disinterestedly attains the Supreme.
King Janaka and others attained perfection through action alone. Even for the sake of enlightening the world, it is thy duty to act;
For whatever a great man does, others imitate. People conform to the standard which he has set.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter three, Karma Yoga and so far we have seen that act you must, because that is the nature of the Prakriti and you are part of the Prakriti. And Prakriti is maintained by each other's actions. And since you are part of that, you have a duty to perform your part in the Prakriti. How long do I have to continue performing these actions? Bhagavan said, as long as you are identified with the Prakriti. As long as I consider this body, mind and intellect to be me, I have to continue performing Niyata Karma, the karmas that are ordained by the roles which I take as part of this Prakriti.

So when I say this is me and now I take the role, I have duties to be performed. But when I get out of this identification with this Prakriti which is right now, this body, mind and intellect and identify with the self, then there is no action. Bhagawan says for such a person, one who is reveling in the self is satisfied with the self. For such a person there is no action because he does not have anything to gain which he not have gained already. Once I get out of this identification with the limited self and identify with this supreme self, there is nothing to be gained, nothing to be competing against, and nothing that I have to do to achieve what I'm trying to achieve right now, which is a complete bliss and a complete happiness. Because that the very nature of the self, the very nature of the self is Sat chit and Ananda.

Right now I'm trying to get out of this mortality. I'm 66 and my life in sun goes till 80. It will be better if I die before 80 because all these premiums I have paid all this life will be in vain. If I die one day after 80, so I can see my mortality. People ask me, when are you going to retire? I say I have no plan.

But then I say I am already 66. In next 5 hours I will be 71 will I be able to function? So whether I like it or not, I am bound by mortality. And what I'm trying to do is overcome that mortality. I'm seeing myself as sat. I'm trying to overcome a SAT ever existing.

I always find myself to be not knowledgeable enough. I don't know everything that I need to know. So I'm constantly in the quest for learning more and more and more with that chit. The very nature of the self is all knowing. So there's nothing more to be known. And right now all I'm trying to get out of is the unhappy unconducive situation.

So I will be in Ananda once and that's this nature. As long as you're identified with this Prakriti, you have to be bound by the laws of Prakriti that every constituent part has to function to make the Prakriti function. And therefore as long as you identified with the Prakrutti, you have to do your part. Once you identify with this self, none of the laws of Prakrutti are applicable to you. Prakrutti will sustain by itself. That's not your responsibility.

Because you say okay, I'm satisfied with the self and I don't do who will do? The one question everybody has, everybody can realize this. Who will do all these things which is happening in this world? He said, that's not your problem. Prakriti will take care of itself. You are in trouble right now.

You are in pain right now of this unhappiness. You want to get out of it. Once you get out of this identification, you have nothing else to do. There is no action for such a person. Say, till that time what am I supposed to do? Asaktaha Karya Samacha.

Till that time you continue working performing all your Niyata Karma. Except right now you are performing with attachment. That people will recognize me at least if I do something for my family. My family will say, you're doing good, I'm doing it out of attachment. He said, you just do without attachment, continue doing what you are doing. Except Asaktah Karma Samachara, you do all your action without attachment.

With that minor adjustment in what you are doing, you will achieve that perfection. Many people in the past, Janak Adayah Janak and others Karma Nai vahi samsiddhaha, they have achieved this just by performing their actions diligently without any attachment. And they achieve the perfection. So could you, so should you. And then he said, now that If I have come to the conclusion that I have done everything, I really don't have to achieve anything, then what should I do? Still continued act in this world, at least for the Loka Sangraha, for the welfare of the society.

Once I come to the conclusion that I have achieved everything I have achieved, you continue to contribute your contribution to the society, for the welfare of the society. That's because the same poison which you have right now, of your own ego, once you take that and dilute it, right now this ego is identified with this limited self. I call me this body, mind and intellect. I take this ego and dilute it with a larger arena, it will lose its bite. 1985 Camp at the end of it, there was a question answer session. Somebody asked Swamiji, Swamiji, do you have ego?

What could be the answer? Swamiji, of course I have ego. He said, without ego, how can I control all of you? And now what we think is, if he has ego, I have ego. So what is the difference between you and I? Why am I wasting my one week and all these dollars to come here and spend time here?

Then the second part of his answer is always is what comes out as the real answer. Yes, I have ego, and so should you. Because without ego, you cannot function. Without any identification, no activity can take place. However, when you take that ego and dilute it. So say you take a pinch of salt and put it in a cup of water and you taste the water, it will be salty.

You take the same water and put it in a jar of water. That salt will not be that noticeable. You take that same jar of water and put it into a whole pond of water. That salt is nowhere to be found. It is still there, so diluted in this body of water that that salt is not effective anymore. Same ego which is right now is so bothersome to me.

When I take it and apply it to a larger group of people. When I identify with my family, it is much more manageable. When I identify with my community, it's even more manageable. I identify with my nation, I become a patriot, I become a hero. When I identify with the whole cosmos, Bhagavan said, you become the realized person. So he said, those who are satisfied with the self, by the self, they have no action other than those.

All of your actions, how long? As long as you identify with it. And then he said, even after you realize that you. You have to still continue to work for the Loka Sangha mystery, for the Benefit Society. Now he's giving his own example. So one who has realized what the reality of life is.

Yadi aham na varteyam jatum karmani atandritah Mama vartmanuvartante manusyaha partha sarvasah. We also seen that Yatyat Acharati sreshta tattat eva itarojanah. It is the very nature of our being that we need something to follow. Some role model, some standard to follow. So someone becomes a role model in our life. Our parents, our teacher, our three year old granddaughter.

She comes to me and says dada, let's do numbers. So we'll put numbers on the floor. And I say okay, now I'll ask you. He said no, no, I'll ask you, show me number five. So obviously I'll say but Medha, how about I ask you no, no, no, show me number five. So then I'll purposely show you number six and say that's number five.

That's not number five. See, Mimik's her teacher. See what she sees in her class. She wants to practice on Meena. She doesn't want to be a student here, she wants to be her teacher. She actually does exactly what her teacher.

Because we have a tendency to follow the behavior we find attractive. So Yatyat acharyati sreshta Purusha. So you have to set a standard of your behavior. Because people are going to follow you whether you like it or not. Because you are role model to somebody. And therefore he says, even when you reach the highest state where there is no action left for you, you have to continue working.

Because I as the supreme being, once we realize the self, he becomes the one with him. If I stop working, other people will follow my example. Other beings will follow my example and they will stop working also. Mama vartmanu vartanti manusyaha partha sarvasaram. We said that Rama took Avatara to set standards for us. What is the standard for good son?

What is the standard for a good husband? What is the standard of a good king? What is the standard of a good father? But he came to demonstrate what is a model behavior. We may or may not agree with him on certain things. So Ramayana is Acharyaniya.

Everything Rama did is to be followed. Krishna, he is not Acharyani at all. What he did you cannot do. Because he did the dance on Kali Nag, we cannot do that. And therefore you also cannot have 1008 or whatever the wives he had we can have. So we have to set a role model.

When we become the supreme we still have a role to play. But once it is the Supreme, I have the role to play. If I don't do my role, other people will stop. Utsidehu IME Lo Kaha Nakuriyam Karma Chet Aham If I stop working or acting, this world will perish. So now I think we come to the conclusion that Krishna is not talking about him as the Devaki son. Because the world did not stop working after Krishna gone.

It's still going on him as the first person singular as the self which is all pervading. The Creator and the controller of this universe. If that stops functioning, this world will perish. This world is functioning as a cosmos and not as chaos because it has laws. We all know there are laws of nature. No denying because we can test it right now.

Go on a second floor and jump out of the window. The laws which Newton found out are still very valid after all these years. So there are laws in nature and then laws are enforced. So he remained law giver and law enforcer and he does not take a day off. If he takes a day off and the laws are mixed up that day, world will be in chaos. Law of thermodynamics Work on Monday through Friday but stop working on Saturday.

Sunday takes a weekend. I wouldn't be able to come here because the car won't start. So he said without taking any break, I have to continue working because this world will only function. The Prakriti will only follow the laws if I am there to support these laws. Sankrasi Chakarta Syam Upahanyami Imaha Prajaha we have great difficulty because we have so much of our cultural burden. All these hundreds of years of our caste system and whatever we want to call it that we keep getting into.

Choose one action today—any action—and practice doing it with full attention but without attachment to results. Whether it's sending an email, having a conversation, or completing a task, offer it as best you can and then release your grip on the outcome.

Ask yourself: Where in my life am I most attached to results? What would change if I could offer my best effort and then surrender the outcome?
