snippets.title: Day 50: Understanding the Gunas
snippets.sanskrit:
तत्त्ववित्तु महाबाहो गुणकर्मविभागयोः |

प्रकृतेर्गुणसम्मूढाः सज्जन्ते गुणकर्मसु |

मयि सर्वाणि कर्माणि संन्यस्याध्यात्मचेतसा |
snippets.transliteration:
tattvavittu mahābāho guṇakarmavibhāgayoḥ .

prakṛterguṇasammūḍhāḥ sajjante guṇakarmasu .

mayi sarvāṇi karmāṇi saṃnyasyādhyātmacetasā .
verseTranslations: But he, O Mighty One, who understands correctly the relation of the Qualities to action, is not attached to the act for he perceives that it is merely the action and reaction of the Qualities among themselves.
Those who do not understand the Qualities are interested in the act. Still, the wise man who knows the truth should not disturb the mind of him who does not.
Therefore, surrendering thy actions unto Me, thy thoughts concentrated on the Absolute, free from selfishness and without anticipation of reward, with mind devoid of excitement, begin thou to fight.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter three, Karma Yoga, Yoga of Actions. And so far we have learned that act we must because we are part of this Prakriti. The Prakriti functions because each individual constituent parts work with each other. Just as we have seen in a cycle of rain during the summer, the ocean water becomes clouds and then clouds become rain and the cycle continue. So there is a cycle in this Prakriti which is dependent on its constituent parts, the Prakriti. This manifest world works because each constituent part work with each other.

We being part of this Prakriti, we have our own duties and we need to fulfill their duties. So the advice is perform all your ordained duties, duties which come with the roles which I take in my life. I take a role of a father, role of a husband, role of an employer, an employee, a son. Whatever role I take, I should perform those actions. So once I understood that this is a part of my duty, I have to continue acting. But then I have come to realize that these actions create bondage.

The bondage of actions and reactions, the reward and punishment. So how do I get out of this? Bhagwan said, act without attachment. If you act with the sense of doership, you are responsible for your actions. And therefore either you will get the credit for it or a punishment for it. So act without attachment and you will not be bound by your actions.

And then the next thing we have seen is that even though I consider that I have nothing more to do now I have achieved everything I need to achieve, it will still continue to act because other people are following your example. As human beings, we have tendency to follow others to act in our life. We need some role model, we need some guidance, we need some standards. And those standards are other people whom I consider to be my role models. I follow them and I become role model for others. And therefore, at any given time I should be acting in appropriate manner.

So others who are following me get the right role model standard to act for themselves. Once I considered that I'm not attached And I'm working. I'm working for the Loka Sangram, for the welfare of the society. Bhagawan said, even you can look at my own example. As the Creator, I have nothing to gain in these three worlds. But I continue to work as the law giver and law enforcer in this universe.

This universe is never without laws. There are no weakens in our natural laws. Law of physics doesn't stop functioning because now it's the leap year on 29th of February. I don't know what to do. There is no exception in nature because the Creator remained as the lawgiver and law enforcer in this universe. So we want to look at I as the Creator.

Even though I have nothing to gain, I continue to work. Because if I do not work, this world will cease to exist. The cycle of creation, maintenance and destruction continues because the Creator continues to support it. That substratum which creates the substratum for this universe is always present in the universe to function. I, as the part of the Parakrati, should follow that lead and do the same. Continue to act even when I don't consider that I have anything to gain just for the welfare of the society.

Even when you consider that other people are acting with attachment. Now I have come to the conclusion that the best way to act in this world is one. Do my duties as ordained by my roles I play, but act without attachment. So have no attachment to your actions and perform actions. But I know that the world is not made up of all those detached sannyasis. The people needs motivation for them to act.

Their motivation may be the goals they want to achieve in their life, their attachment to their actions, their passions. I as the one other Gnani, have a responsibility to make sure that they don't get confused by this high philosophy. So the next verse says, Nabuddi Vedam Janayat Agnanam Karma Sangi Naam. It's a great responsibility on a person who has achieved knowledge that with my knowledge I don't confuse others. You know, in our Gita class, the one common thing we hear is, I'm more confused now than I was before I came to this class. More you know, more you will know than more I don't know.

And that's a biggest responsibility in the part of the wise person. To guide the society in a right manner so that people don't take the wrong message from your advice. One person was alcoholic, so his father or a teacher wanted to give an example and say, let me show you what an alcohol does to you. He takes a glass of alcohol, puts a little worm in it and the worm obviously after a while dies. Did you see what happened? Yes, yes, I understood what happened.

If I drink alcohol, all the worms on my stomach will die. One person was trying to find out where is the brain of a cockroach. He was a researcher obviously like Guptaji and all the people. I'm going to find out where is the brain of the cockroach in his body. So he puts a food in front of the cockroach, cockroach runs towards the food. So he figures out cockroach does have brain.

Now let me find out where the brain is. He breaks his one leg, cockroach limps towards the foot. He still has brain was not in that leg. He breaks another leg, he still limps to that. So brain was not in that leg. He breaks the last leg and the cockroach can't move towards the food and say I figured out the brain was in the last leg which I broke.

From your observations and conclusions and the advice that you hear, unless you're prepared for that, you may come to the wrong conclusion. So it's the great responsibility on the teacher and the wise people to guide the society appropriately without confusing them. Nabuddi Vedam Janayat Agnaram Karma Sanghi naam. The ignorant people who are working in this world with attachment it should not create confusion their mind so they stop working. There was a time when some philosophies make people giving up everything and become sannyasi or a monk. Is the real goal of life well, after all figured out, the society just can function like that.

If all the young people become sannyasis, who would support the Social Security for people like me who will be retiring? We need people to work so you should not unsettle them. Josayat Sarvakarmani Vidhvan Yuktaha Samacharan For a Vidhvan person, the one who is knowledgeable and is Yukta who is balanced. He knows how to motivate people. And if they are working with an attachment, encourage them to work. Jose Sarva somehow engage all of them in actions so the action doesn't stop.

Because if they are acting, there is a chance that sometime they will understand what is the right way to act. Swamiji gives an example that if I am driving in a wrong direction, if I stop driving, I will never reach the right destination. But if I continue driving and then ask somebody and find a direction, then continue driving, I will reach my destination all the time. The Operative word is driving. As long as I keep driving and then correct my direction, I'll find destination. So it is up to us not to confuse our children.

People who listen to us and say this is of no value. What are you going to gain in life? And that's not the way to guide the society. So anybody who has the criticism that the Hinduism teaches pessimism, it teaches actions consistently all throughout your life. There is no discussion of retirement here. Sad Bhagawan says, please make sure as a Vidhvaan person that all people are engaged in actions because activity is the signature of nature.

Prakrutehe kriyamanani gunaihi karmani sarvasah. Then where is this confusion coming between the one who is acting with an attachment, one who is acting without an attachment. Why the one acting without an attachment is more efficient. One with acting with an attachment is less efficient. The reason for me to act without attachment is not to detach myself from what's happening but to become more efficient in what I'm doing. More I get attached more.

My mental energy will be dissipated into the worries about what will come out of my actions. That I will be employing one third of my energy into what may come out of my actions. 1/3 of my energy into what happened last time when I did this, only 1/3 energy is available for me. To last proposal I did, I did not win it. Am I going to win this one? That will take away my complete focus on what needs to be done.

Therefore detachment is necessary that I focus on the present only and function in it. But where is this confusion coming for me where I get attached to my actions and it says this ignorance about how the world works. The actions in this world are working by their own nature. Prakrutehi kriyamanani gunehi karmani sarvasah. All actions performed in this universe are performed because of the gunas of the prakriti of the objects. But I on the other hand think I am the doer.

Ahankara removed atma out of my ignorance by my ego. Karta aham ithimanyate I think I am the doer. Even though guna gunesuvarthantaha we are not island by ourselves, but we can function by ourselves. If everybody moves away from this town and I am the only one left for a few days there will be a very fun because I could walk into Starbucks, nobody can stop me. Get a cup of coffee myself, go to the food line and get Whatever grocery I want. After sometime there won't be anything to do for me because there's nobody else doing anything for me.

I am surviving because other people are doing their part. Therefore I'm functioning as I'm functioning. Once I come to that conclusion that things are working because these constituent parts of this Prakriti are working with each other then I will not develop the ego that I am the doer. I go to the lab and take the hydrogen oxygen and put them together and become water. Now I say I created water. I said no, no Neil, Hydrogen oxygen acted on each other and they behaved as per their qualities to create water.

You are just a mere agent to put them together. So you are not the doer. You are just a Nimitta, Matra, Ahanka, ra, Vimu, dhatma, Karta, ahamiti many. He starts thinking that I am the doer. Whereas the actions are performed by the Prakruti by its own nature. Everything in this Prakriti has sattva, rajas and Tamas.

The basic ingredients in each thing. Those ingredients when they come in contact with each other they function according to their own nature. So two atoms come together. No atomic scientist to do engineered to do anything. Those atoms will act with each other according to their own gunas. Prakrutehe guna, Sammudaha, sajante guna, karma.

So one who is ignorant about this nature of Prakriti in the Gunas of Prakriti he gets attached to the actions. When I do something and then I get success. I'm now attached to my actions. Because I think I achieved this success. I forget that what I submitted as my project There are about 18 people in my office has to work on it.
snippets.reflection:
Choose one action today—any action—and practice doing it with full attention but without attachment to results. Whether it's sending an email, having a conversation, or completing a task, offer it as best you can and then release your grip on the outcome.

Notice what happens when you work this way. Is there more freedom? More presence? More energy? The Gita's teaching of Karma Yoga isn't about becoming passive or indifferent. It's about working with full engagement while remaining internally free.

Ask yourself: Where in my life am I most attached to results? What would change if I could offer my best effort and then surrender the outcome?

snippets.title: Day 51: Following This Teaching
snippets.sanskrit:
ये मे मतमिदं नित्यमनुतिष्ठन्ति मानवाः |

ये त्वेतदभ्यसूयन्तो नानुतिष्ठन्ति मे मतम् |

सदृशं चेष्टते स्वस्याः प्रकृतेर्ज्ञानवानपि |
snippets.transliteration:
ye me matamidaṃ nityamanutiṣṭhanti mānavāḥ .

ye tvetadabhyasūyanto nānutiṣṭhanti me matam .

sadṛśaṃ ceṣṭate svasyāḥ prakṛterjñānavānapi .
verseTranslations: Those who always act in accordance with My precepts, firm in faith and without cavilling, they too are freed from the bondage of action.
But they who ridicule My word and do not keep it, are ignorant, devoid of wisdom and blind. They seek but their own destruction.
Even the wise man acts in character with his nature; indeed, all creatures act according to their natures. What is the use of compulsion then?
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter three, Karma Yoga, Yoga of Action. So we have seen in last few verses. Bhagavan says that Prakrute, he, kriyamanani, gunaihi, karmani, sarvasa, all actions are performed by Prakriti. Ahankara, vimu, dhatma, karta, aham ithimanyade. But the one who is deluded by ego, he thinks he is the doer. So this is something Bhagavan is trying to clarify, which we have learnt in chapter two, that Purusha is the enabler.

Prakriti functions when Purusha and Prakriti come together. But all actions belong to Prakriti. There is no activity in I, the Purusha that we consider our own self, the I which last time we talked of will and free will. German philosopher Schopenhauer wrote a book called the World as Will and Representation. So this will is the force which enables the Prakriti to represent itself. So here we are saying the actions are performed in Prakrut.

There is something similar to a situation that in my house there are several gadgets which generates heat, light, sound, picture which makes the house lively and livable. But all this equipment are only functioning when they're electrified. So if a bulb somehow gets this ego that I am the one who gives light, then the electricity as the guru can come and tell that bulb that no, no. All activities are performed by all equipment, but not because of themselves, but because of the electricity functioning through them. But activity does not belong to electricity. Bulb not functioning well or is dim or bright.

It does not belong to the electricity that belongs to the bulb itself. See, the bulb is getting jealousy. That other bulb is brighter and I am dimmer and I have to do something to be brighter. All that belongs to Prakriti. But once it's first of all know that you are not the doer. Your dimness or brightness belongs to the equipment and not to you, the electricity.

Ahanka, rimu, dhatma, karatha, hamiti, mandy, he thinks that he is the doer. But the one who knows Tattvitu Mahabaha Guna Karma Vibhaga. But one who knows the reality, the truth about this is the guna and a Karma. He knows the gunas of the Prakriti. Vijay Sattvaraja Saint Tamas and their functions. Function of Sattva is to be in existence, in knowledge.

Rajas is activity and Tamas is inertia. They have their own gunas, things which are made up of these three gunas in Prakriti. They function according to those gunas and permutation combinations of those gunas. Guna Gunesajjade Knowing that the qualities of my senses and the sense objects outside, when they come together, when the activity takes place, as we have seen last time, that the senses create sensation on the mind, the sensation creates the perception in mind. That perception conception of that object, that conception of that object. If it is in line with my tendencies, then it creates action.

If it is not in line with my tendency, I won't even pay attention. There are so many sensations come to me, but I am only aware of those I am paying attention to. And I am paying attention to those only which are in line with my tendencies. So Bhagavan says, Guna Guneshu Vartan Tah. My guna is this limited being and the guna of the objects outside, they are acting with each other, but I remains uninvolved. So the verse we have seen which is almost a summary of Karma Yoga in two lines.

Bhagavan says how to practice Karma Yoga. Mai sarvani Karmani Sanyasya Adhyatma Cheta Saha Nirasi Nirmamo Bhatva Yidyaswa Vigatha Juraha. Renouncing all actions in me with mind centered on yourself. It's like that electricity guru telling that bulb that you offer all your light to me. It is me who enables you to give light. You just focus on your own self.

What is your reality? Nirasi Nirmamo Bhatva. You do not have any expectation what will come out of me. So don't consider your past achievement is yours. All that was happening for that bulb is because of electricity. As long as electricity is functioning, whether it was giving a good light or a bad light or it was performing according to the expectation of the home owner or not.

All that is because of the electricity. Whatever is coming out of you as actions, devote all of them to me, the enabler. So here the me, as Bhagavan said, is Your own self, your true self which is limitless. You are binding it into your own limitedness. You offer all your actions to me and do not have any expectations. Do not dwell in future.

What will happen in future? Will my actions generate good results or not? Will I achieve something or not? All that is a you live it to the Karma Falada and Nirmamaha. All you exemplished in the past is also past. We have a great tendency, most of the olden cultures to dwell in past and say we used to have great culture.

Look at our culture in Mahabharata. Look at our culture in Rama's time. That doesn't really matter. What are you doing right now matters. Your culture right now. Are we the most cultured people on this planet?

Do we have the right values or are we corrupt people? That matters what we are doing right now, not what we did in the past. Not we may do in the future. So Bhagawan said Nirasi Nirmammu Bhatva Yudhishva Bhikha Jwaraha. You engage in your activity. Inactivity is not an option for you.

You engage in your activity without having these agitations in your mind which is like a fever will rob your energy. This agitations about what will I get in the future and what are my accomplishments in the past. Forget about all of that. Become completely healthy to function in present. That's basically a summary of Karma Yoga. Act in present, do not worry about the future.

Do not regret what you did or did not do or accomplish in the past. And engage yourself in actions. Devote all actions to the enabler, the self in you. You can only act as long as you are living. You will not be able to act when you die. After your death, there is no activity for this limited body.

So therefore offer all your actions to the enabler, the consciousness, your own self. And then Bhagavan says, Yeme Matamin, this is my opinion whether you like it or not. But I'm telling you, this is my Eme Matamidam Nityam Anuthisthanti Manavah. Those people who follow these teachings of mine. This teaching which I have just taught you, the Karma Yoga, how to act in this world, Offer your actions to the Supreme Self, the supreme will. Our desire is to live.

So there is a will to live, a will to act. Free will is something when I have more choices and I can choose one of them, that's a free will. If I have a Desire to play outside as a child. But my mother said that you have to do homework. Well if I can decide it's a free will. But if my mother decides then no, no.

You can go out to play right now but do your homework. That's not a free will. So Bhagavan says that you have free will. A very narrow window. Either you can choose my teachings of how to act in this world outside or other opinions you have how you can get your happiness by your actions. So we do have a concept in the last time we argued about whether we have concept of free.

We do have a concept of free. We call it Purushartha Purushasthana Prarabdha. Prarabdhdha is something I have no control over. There is no free will there in Prarabdha. The situation I'm facing is because of my past actions. Those past actions go as long as I can think about my existence.

This life, previous life, life previous to that, whatever that is. That's Prarabdha situation is presented to me by my Prarabdha. The way I act in this situation is my Purushart. I don't have a complete free will that I can do whatever I want Because I can't change the situation. But I do have free will to act within the circumstances. See, will of an individual is always limited.

A complete free will is the universal will. The will of God as we call it in our religious terminology. Universal will is free. I have a limited free will and I can exercise that free will. So Bhagawan said those who exercise their narrow free will to follow my teachings Eme matamidam nityam Anuthisthati Manava who constantly follow my teachings. Sraddhavantaha Anusuyantaha muchante tiyapi Karmabhi.

Those who follow my teachings with Shraddha without raising trivial doubts it is my opinion that they will also achieve the liberation from Karma Naiskarma Siddhe. They will achieve the final goal. So here couple of things we can look at. What Bhagavan is saying is that you may have your own doubts whether this is really workable. This Karma Yoga we had been talking about. Act without any expectations.

Don't have any regrets about what you achieved all the way. Unless I have a passion to achieve something. If I have a fire in my belly to go and get it how am I going to get it? Unless I have this passion to achieve and I'LL do anything to achieve it based on my tendencies. Bhagawan said, put all this thing aside. Don't raise those trivial doubts in your mind.

If you subside those trivial doubts in your mind and have Sraddha, have faith that this will work and then you follow all the time. Nityam, Anuti, Sthunti, Manava. Those people who practice, practice that narrow free will to take my advice and have faith in it and follow, they will also be released from all karma, all actions, all sorrows, all unhappiness. We may have heard before, before Gita came along, there were so many other maths as we have discussed there Sat Dashara, Samari, Swarvadi, Samarani, Swarvadi. Some say going to heaven is the only goal. And others say the liberation is the goal.

There are so many Mata. But I say Krishna says this is my Mata. You may think this is so simplistic. People say to achieve the Samadhi, Yogi has to practice for a long period of time. And you are saying Samatvam Yoga, Uchathe, just a balanced mind and you're done. So you may have lots of doubts.

But if your faith in my teachings and follow, you shall achieve that nice karma. So we have discussed many times this word Sraddha. Is it the blind faith that Krishna cannot be wrong. I have to follow him whether you like it or not. So we have come across several definitions of Sraddha. One Swamiji gives in Vivekta Dharma.

He says, my belief in what I do not know, something I do not know. I do not know whether Bhagavan exists or not. That's my belief that yes, there is a superior power. Even though I do not know what that power is right now. But I have believed that I may come to know sometime. If I work at it diligently, I will come to know that power, that supreme power.

What I believe in is Sraddha. If I have a belief in something which I do not have a direct knowledge right now, the faith that I will come to know, then my belief is correct. Swamiji says that's Shruddha. That's Swamiji's definition. But one Shankaracharya's definition is Guru Vedant, Vakya, Adishu, Vishwas Israddha. My trust in the words of my teacher and scriptures.

Scriptures in a sense, the books of knowledge which I have trusted. Upanishads, Vedanta, Bible, whatever you consider book of knowledge, if you have trust in that, that's Sraddha.

snippets.title: Day 52: Likes and Dislikes
snippets.sanskrit:
इन्द्रियस्येन्द्रियस्यार्थे रागद्वेषौ व्यवस्थितौ |

श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात् |

अर्जुन उवाच |
snippets.transliteration:
indriyasyendriyasyārthe rāgadveṣau vyavasthitau .

śreyānsvadharmo viguṇaḥ paradharmātsvanuṣṭhitāt .

arjuna uvāca .
verseTranslations: The love and hate which are aroused by the objects of sense arise from Nature; do not yield to them. They only obstruct the path.

It is better to do thine own duty, however lacking in merit, than to do that of another, even though efficiently. It is better to die doing one's own duty, for to do the duty of another is fraught with danger.
Arjuna asked: My Lord! Tell me, what is it that drives a man to sin, even against his will and as if by compulsion?
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter three, Karma Yoga, Yoga of actions. In other words, we are trying to understand how can I transform my actions which are binding me right now into liberating entities right now, every action I do, I am bound by results which are either good or bad. And this cycle continues. How can I transform this cycle of acting and reacting into liberating me? So more I act, more liberated I become right now, more I act, more bound I am, more and more I seek happiness, I collect more unhappiness. As we discussed last time, the Sukha is something which is defined by absence of dukkha.

As long as I have dukkha of any kind, sukha cannot be experienced. 99% of my body is very healthy except my heart. We typically argue when contractors find or clients find mistakes in our drawing. But look at the rest of the project, how well we have done. I said that doesn't count. Error is an error that creates problem for us.

If car you buy is 99% perfect except the engine is not firing properly, is that a good car or a lemon? So when I have some dukkha, I'm dukkhi. So more I try to achieve happiness, I somewhere along the line acquire unhappiness. So if I look at my life, it is basically more unhappiness and have a little happiness somewhere than unhappiness. Little happiness somewhere. The happiness is experienced when I don't have to gain anything.

The day I feel that I have everything I want and I don't have to acquire anything that day, I feel happy. The next moment where I realize oh, but I forgot I have to also achieve this and the unhappiness starts all over again or pursuit of happiness starts all over again. So Bhagavan said that there is a technique how you can get out of this rut of trying to get happiness and get unhappiness in the bargain. First thing he said is do it for the greater good. Don't Think about yourself. Think about whether it's going to help others.

And then act with the first technique. Secondly, he says, all your likes and dislikes are in your senses only. The likes and dislikes of the object resides in your senses only if I close my eyes, whether there is a good side or bad side. That's why when we are afraid, we close our eyes. We don't want to see. We want to shut down that sense.

So say, know that they are at your sense level. You do not let that become yours. So you get detached from these likes and dislikes. Bhagawan also said that what can you do? You will always act according to your Prakriti Nigraha Kim karishadi. Even a wise man, he knows what is right, what is wrong.

But he cannot act accordingly. Most doctors, at least when I was in India and my friends were doctors, medical students and recently graduated doctors. They were all smoking heavily. Even a wise man who knows all that. But because the force of those vasanas will make you only behave in that manner. Till you exhaust those vasanas or till you transcend those vasanas.

When we were children, we were hung up on little things. But as we grow up, those little attachment for the toys drop out. Because you transcended them. So as long as I'm under the sway of Vasanas, I will act according to the Vasanas Prabhupada. Once I don't let that vasana overpower you. You are going to act according to your vasanas.

But you can sublimate those as I gave you examples. Swami Dheerananda said, if you like to sing all those movie songs, convert them into Bhajans and then come and sing at the Chinmay Mission. So you can take your vasanas and give them a direction which is more conducive to your liberation that the technique is. Mai Karmani Sarvani Sanyasya. You offer all your accents to me. So all your vasanas, you offer it to him.

Just like on a Shivratri. Devi said, when you offer a flower with each name, you say one of my vasanas Bhagwan, I give it to you. That's why in our culture, all this art, music, dances, is all Krishna in it. All those bandises which are done in all the different ragas, all about Krishna. Because they realized that two make this art a divine art. If you associate Bhagavan into it.

Same art, same bandits. You are singing now he is a Krishna in it. So all these great Ustads, you know, who are all Muslims, but they all sunk Krishna's glory. All our dances all about Krishna. Because these are our vasana. These are our natural tendency to express ourselves into art, music, dances.

But rather than making them more perverted into some very lusty field, they say, sublimate those same vasanas into higher fields. So Bhagawan said, don't let this Vasana overpower you. You find a way to exhaust your vasanas in a manner that gives you more and more joy towards the higher goal. Offer all your actions to me. If I go to work, I say, well, I'm going it for Krishna. When you have that attitude, then you will overcome all your vasanas.

Then he says, adhatma cheta sa. And you try to find out who you are. You try to figure out who you are and then continue to act in the manner which is according to your vasanas. Because Sreyan Swadharmo we're gonna have Paradharmaat Swanushtita. Sreyan Swadharma Viguna. Whatever we are doing, we always think that had I been a doctor, I would have been making more money.

I didn't realize when I was going to architecture school that architects don't make much money. Actually, our teachers told us in the very first class, very first class. Any architecture school you go. The first thing they said, if you are here to make money, there is a technology engineering college next door and medical school two blocks away. Architecture is not for making money. But we still thought that that may be the only thing I can do.

I want to be an architect. Swadharma, that's what you liked. So Sreyan Swadharmo Vigunaha My dharma, no matter how it seems, devoid of qualities from the society's perspective, I enjoy it. But people says, you'll be a starving artist. Why do you want to be an artist? You'll be starving artist.

I want to be an artist. But society says that's not really worth much. So Sreyan Swadharma Viguna Dharma as we have defined many, many times before in this class. The law of being, what makes me who I am is my dharma. Sugar is sugar because it has its own dharma of being sweet. If it looks like sugar, it feels like sugar.

But it does not taste like sugar. When I was in science college and I studied all my education till inter science in Gujarati. So in chemistry they will say Padarthana guna dharma nu varnankaram. Describe the characteristics of the substance. And that used to be a standard test in a chemistry. They give you a substance.

First you have to do it in an observation, smell and then tell what it is. And then the next level is. Then you prove it by doing some experiment on it. I remember I was in interscience and there was some substance came to me. It has some very peculiar quality and I don't even remember what it was which is very rare. And I kind of latched onto that and I saw that I went to the examiner and said this is what it is.

That's because I latched on to one particular quality which was unique to that substance. Without that, that substance cannot be that. Dharma is that what makes that substance what it is. My swadharma is my own vasana. The texture of my mind, my personality. It is what makes me who I am.

Now that may be viguna ha. It may not be much value to others. Anytime I read all these magazines and say what Bill Gates is doing to help the humanity, what Elon Musk is doing, what the Google guy Larry Page is doing. I'm not doing anything like that. I'm barely making any difference to my own family's life or my staff's life. But that's my swadharma.

This is my swadharma. Many, many years ago when I was still very, very novice in this Bhagavad Gita classes and lectures. One thing I realized, I'm at complete ease when I am in this environment. When I'm talking about Bhagavad Gita or learning Bhagavad Gita in the class everywhere else I'm slightly uncomfortable. So that's my swadharma. So Bhagavan says Sreyan swadharmo Viganaha.

It may not be of much value to others but your good is to act according to your dharma, your swadharma. What is your vasanas? What is your texture of your personality? Paradharmat swanusthitaat. Then others dharma which seems much nobler or well discharged is the translation. Well discharged means he is doing it so easily.

I met few years ago in a convention for this hotel owners association where I go there because I design hotels. Somebody who has when I was growing up in Surat, in the street there Was a Kariwala family who were. They were basically a grocery shop there. Their youngest child was like 4 or 5 years old when I was in college. So he recognized me and said, aren't you such and such? He said, you remember me?

I was such and such from your street. Oh, you were a little kid. I don't remember you. And I said, what do you do? He said, well, I'm a hotel owner. So I said, well, remember I'm an architect.

I said, neil, I don't really develop any hotels. I just buy hotels and sell. And he made millions doing that. He was like multimillionaires. I said, it's very easy, Neel. I just don't do anything.

I just buy and then sell it. For him, it is so easy for me. That's a huge sum insight. You have to have what to buy and where to sell. So Paradharma Svanosthita is so well discharged by him his duties. But for me, that's not as easy.

Swadharme Nidhanam Shreyaha by performing your duty, you may end up dying. In other words, you continue performing your duty duties in a sense what you like. And you die doing that. And may not accomplish anything from others perspective. But because it was your duty, it is better for you. Because that gave you the platform for exhausting your vasanas.

That gave you the platform for performing actions which give you joy. It may be more productive to go and do something else, but that's not your dharma. When I came to this country, I worked for a contractor for a while Because I did not have a job in architecture. And he saw some potential. Minister Neel, this is great. We need to be in a business so we can do this.

And after about three or four months, I left the job. I said, oh, I got a job at architecture office. It was not even a permanent job. And he was paying me literally minimum wages. He said, why are you doing this? You have great opportunity.

But that's what I like. I want to be an architect. I don't want to be a contractor. So that gives me joy even at the minimum wage. But I felt like I'm doing my job. Building Paradharmo Bhayavah, others Dharma, when you try to emulate is dangerous.

We architects, we deal with developers all the time. So after all, we think that I can be Also a developer. All these people come to me to ask advice.

snippets.title: Day 53: The Enemy Called Desire

श्रीभगवानुवाच |

धूमेनाव्रियते वह्निर्यथादर्शो मलेन च |

आवृतं ज्ञानमेतेन ज्ञानिनो नित्यवैरिणा |
snippets.transliteration:
śrībhagavānuvāca .

dhūmenāvriyate vahniryathādarśo malena ca .

āvṛtaṃ jñānametena jñānino nityavairiṇā .
verseTranslations: Lord Shri Krishna: It is desire, it is aversion, born of passion. Desire consumes and corrupts everything. It is man's greatest enemy.
As fire is shrouded in smoke, a mirror by dust and a child by the womb, so is the universe enveloped in desire.
It is the wise man's constant enemy; it tarnishes the face of wisdom. It is as insatiable as a flame of fire.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter three, Karma Yoga, Yoga of actions. In other words, we are trying to understand how can I transform my actions which are binding me right now into liberating entities right now, every action I do, I am bound by results which are either good or bad. And this cycle continues. How can I transform this cycle of acting and reacting into liberating me? So more I act, more liberated I become right now, more I act, more bound I am, more and more I seek happiness, I collect more unhappiness. As we discussed last time, the Sukha is something which is defined by absence of dukkha.

As long as I have dukkha of any kind, sukha cannot be experienced. 99% of my body is very healthy except my heart. We typically argue when contractors find or clients find mistakes in our drawing. But look at the rest of the project, how well we have done. I said that doesn't count. Error is an error that creates problem for us.

If car you buy is 99% perfect except the engine is not firing properly, is that a good car or a lemon? So when I have some dukkha, I'm dukkhi. So more I try to achieve happiness, I somewhere along the line acquire unhappiness. So if I look at my life, it is basically more unhappiness and have a little happiness somewhere than unhappiness. Little happiness somewhere. The happiness is experienced when I don't have to gain anything.

The day I feel that I have everything I want and I don't have to acquire anything that day, I feel happy. The next moment where I realize oh, but I forgot I have to also achieve this and the unhappiness starts all over again or pursuit of happiness starts all over again. So Bhagavan said that there is a technique how you can get out of this rut of trying to get happiness and get unhappiness in the bargain. First thing he said is do it for the greater good. Don't Think about yourself. Think about whether it's going to help others.

And then act with the first technique. Secondly, he says, all your likes and dislikes are in your senses only. The likes and dislikes of the object resides in your senses only if I close my eyes, whether there is a good side or bad side. That's why when we are afraid, we close our eyes. We don't want to see. We want to shut down that sense.

So say, know that they are at your sense level. You do not let that become yours. So you get detached from these likes and dislikes. Bhagawan also said that what can you do? You will always act according to your Prakriti Nigraha Kim karishadi. Even a wise man, he knows what is right, what is wrong.

But he cannot act accordingly. Most doctors, at least when I was in India and my friends were doctors, medical students and recently graduated doctors. They were all smoking heavily. Even a wise man who knows all that. But because the force of those vasanas will make you only behave in that manner. Till you exhaust those vasanas or till you transcend those vasanas.

When we were children, we were hung up on little things. But as we grow up, those little attachment for the toys drop out. Because you transcended them. So as long as I'm under the sway of Vasanas, I will act according to the Vasanas Prabhupada. Once I don't let that vasana overpower you. You are going to act according to your vasanas.

But you can sublimate those as I gave you examples. Swami Dheerananda said, if you like to sing all those movie songs, convert them into Bhajans and then come and sing at the Chinmay Mission. So you can take your vasanas and give them a direction which is more conducive to your liberation that the technique is. Mai Karmani Sarvani Sanyasya. You offer all your accents to me. So all your vasanas, you offer it to him.

Just like on a Shivratri. Devi said, when you offer a flower with each name, you say one of my vasanas Bhagwan, I give it to you. That's why in our culture, all this art, music, dances, is all Krishna in it. All those bandises which are done in all the different ragas, all about Krishna. Because they realized that two make this art a divine art. If you associate Bhagavan into it.

Same art, same bandits. You are singing now he is a Krishna in it. So all these great Ustads, you know, who are all Muslims, but they all sunk Krishna's glory. All our dances all about Krishna. Because these are our vasana. These are our natural tendency to express ourselves into art, music, dances.

But rather than making them more perverted into some very lusty field, they say, sublimate those same vasanas into higher fields. So Bhagawan said, don't let this Vasana overpower you. You find a way to exhaust your vasanas in a manner that gives you more and more joy towards the higher goal. Offer all your actions to me. If I go to work, I say, well, I'm going it for Krishna. When you have that attitude, then you will overcome all your vasanas.

Then he says, adhatma cheta sa. And you try to find out who you are. You try to figure out who you are and then continue to act in the manner which is according to your vasanas. Because Sreyan Swadharmo we're gonna have Paradharmaat Swanushtita. Sreyan Swadharma Viguna. Whatever we are doing, we always think that had I been a doctor, I would have been making more money.

I didn't realize when I was going to architecture school that architects don't make much money. Actually, our teachers told us in the very first class, very first class. Any architecture school you go. The first thing they said, if you are here to make money, there is a technology engineering college next door and medical school two blocks away. Architecture is not for making money. But we still thought that that may be the only thing I can do.

I want to be an architect. Swadharma, that's what you liked. So Sreyan Swadharmo Vigunaha My dharma, no matter how it seems, devoid of qualities from the society's perspective, I enjoy it. But people says, you'll be a starving artist. Why do you want to be an artist? You'll be starving artist.

I want to be an artist. But society says that's not really worth much. So Sreyan Swadharma Viguna Dharma as we have defined many, many times before in this class. The law of being, what makes me who I am is my dharma. Sugar is sugar because it has its own dharma of being sweet. If it looks like sugar, it feels like sugar.

But it does not taste like sugar. When I was in science college and I studied all my education till inter science in Gujarati. So in chemistry they will say Padarthana guna dharma nu varnankaram. Describe the characteristics of the substance. And that used to be a standard test in a chemistry. They give you a substance.

First you have to do it in an observation, smell and then tell what it is. And then the next level is. Then you prove it by doing some experiment on it. I remember I was in interscience and there was some substance came to me. It has some very peculiar quality and I don't even remember what it was which is very rare. And I kind of latched onto that and I saw that I went to the examiner and said this is what it is.

That's because I latched on to one particular quality which was unique to that substance. Without that, that substance cannot be that. Dharma is that what makes that substance what it is. My swadharma is my own vasana. The texture of my mind, my personality. It is what makes me who I am.

Now that may be viguna ha. It may not be much value to others. Anytime I read all these magazines and say what Bill Gates is doing to help the humanity, what Elon Musk is doing, what the Google guy Larry Page is doing. I'm not doing anything like that. I'm barely making any difference to my own family's life or my staff's life. But that's my swadharma.

This is my swadharma. Many, many years ago when I was still very, very novice in this Bhagavad Gita classes and lectures. One thing I realized, I'm at complete ease when I am in this environment. When I'm talking about Bhagavad Gita or learning Bhagavad Gita in the class everywhere else I'm slightly uncomfortable. So that's my swadharma. So Bhagavan says Sreyan swadharmo Viganaha.

It may not be of much value to others but your good is to act according to your dharma, your swadharma. What is your vasanas? What is your texture of your personality? Paradharmat swanusthitaat. Then others dharma which seems much nobler or well discharged is the translation. Well discharged means he is doing it so easily.

I met few years ago in a convention for this hotel owners association where I go there because I design hotels. Somebody who has when I was growing up in Surat, in the street there Was a Kariwala family who were. They were basically a grocery shop there. Their youngest child was like 4 or 5 years old when I was in college. So he recognized me and said, aren't you such and such? He said, you remember me?

I was such and such from your street. Oh, you were a little kid. I don't remember you. And I said, what do you do? He said, well, I'm a hotel owner. So I said, well, remember I'm an architect.

I said, neil, I don't really develop any hotels. I just buy hotels and sell. And he made millions doing that. He was like multimillionaires. I said, it's very easy, Neel. I just don't do anything.

I just buy and then sell it. For him, it is so easy for me. That's a huge sum insight. You have to have what to buy and where to sell. So Paradharma Svanosthita is so well discharged by him his duties. But for me, that's not as easy.

Swadharme Nidhanam Shreyaha by performing your duty, you may end up dying. In other words, you continue performing your duty duties in a sense what you like. And you die doing that. And may not accomplish anything from others perspective. But because it was your duty, it is better for you. Because that gave you the platform for exhausting your vasanas.

That gave you the platform for performing actions which give you joy. It may be more productive to go and do something else, but that's not your dharma. When I came to this country, I worked for a contractor for a while Because I did not have a job in architecture. And he saw some potential. Minister Neel, this is great. We need to be in a business so we can do this.

And after about three or four months, I left the job. I said, oh, I got a job at architecture office. It was not even a permanent job. And he was paying me literally minimum wages. He said, why are you doing this? You have great opportunity.

But that's what I like. I want to be an architect. I don't want to be a contractor. So that gives me joy even at the minimum wage. But I felt like I'm doing my job. Building Paradharmo Bhayavah, others Dharma, when you try to emulate is dangerous.

We architects, we deal with developers all the time. So after all, we think that I can be Also a developer. All these people come to me to ask advice.
snippets.reflection:
Choose one action today—any action—and practice doing it with full attention but without attachment to results. Whether it's sending an email, having a conversation, or completing a task, offer it as best you can and then release your grip on the outcome.

Notice what happens when you work this way. Is there more freedom? More presence? More energy? The Gita's teaching of Karma Yoga isn't about becoming passive or indifferent. It's about working with full engagement while remaining internally free.

Ask yourself: Where in my life am I most attached to results? What would change if I could offer my best effort and then surrender the outcome?

verseTranslations: It works through the senses, the mind and the reason; and with their help destroys wisdom and confounds the soul.

snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter three, Karma Yoga, Yoga of Action. All of us realize that we are defined by our actions. You meet a new person, the first thing you do is obviously judge the person by the way he looks and way he dresses and way he talks and way he acts. But the million dollar question we ask is what do you do? And whatever response comes, you will either enhance your judgment about that person or you will reduce the judgment which you have made by just outward appearance. You know, long time ago, when I first joined Chinmaya Mission in Houston, I met a person in a class called Rambhai.

Rambhai and Gujarat is a pretty simple name. You know, his name is Rambhai. So well, very old fellow, he looks also very, very modest in conversation also. And he actually came to me, he thought that I was asking some smart questions in the class. So I obviously already had a better judgment of me. I'm making the judgment just based on what he looks like.

And then I finally asked Rambha, what do you do? And he said, I'm a structural engineer. And I'm a research engineer, so I don't do normal building structures. I'm basically a researcher. The more I talked to him, I found out the Guy has about three PhDs in structural engineering. He actually was awarded PhD when he was in undergraduate class.

He was doing his last BE because he found the flaw in the way the structural engineer for the high rise building, like 15 or 80 story building, calculate the structural load. He found the flaw in that theory while he was in undergraduate class. As soon as I heard that, for me, Rambhai became a completely different person. I always remember that when I judge somebody, is he not another Rambhai? So actions we know are very important, but not all the time. We can act appropriately.

Even knowing that my actions will describe me, will define me. We don't really do everything right in our life. So we have gone through the whole chapter about what is right, actions, how the actions work, what is the right way to act. But in the end, the question Came back as Arjuna asked. Even though sometimes I know what is right, but I can't do what is right. Paapam Charati Purushah Papam we have a cultural baggage when we say Papa.

We consider something sinful in a sense, something only the sinners do. As we have defined in our discussion in Vedanta, that which creates a negative impression on my mind is a Papa. That which binds me more and more to these limitations is a Papa. That which liberates me is Punya. That which puts a positive impression on my mind, which encourages me, inspires me is Punya. That which dejects me and depresses me is Papa.

When I'm depressed and go through all that, I'm going through hell. So Papa leads me to hell. So what is it that puts me in this misery of life? Even though sometimes I know this isn't the right thing to do. And most of the time, at least in my life, I can tell you most of the time when I took wrong decisions or did wrong things, I already had the inkling in my heart that this may not be a right thing to do. But we did it anyway.

Because everybody says it's okay. My mind says if you don't do it you will be left out, whatever it is. But we did it anyway. So you say Atha kena prayuktam papam chalati purushah anit chada viva. He doesn't want to do it, but baladiyo niyojita as if he is guided by. He is limited by some force which is not allowing him to do what he thinks is right.

Kamayesha krudhe sarajoguna samudd bhavaha not really a big revelation to us, but still we never associated when we did something wrong, we actually transferred the blame to somebody else right away. I shouldn't have done, but what can I do? Circumstances are like that. I wouldn't have any angry had he not pushed my buttons. So we see we right away transfer the blame to the others and we kind of redeem ourselves. I'm actually a nice guy and I normally don't do that.

But because of that, therefore we have no chance to improve. What this basically says is you have a chance to improve. You realize what the source of your mistakes. There is a kama isha krudaya. It is your own desire and anger which led you to do what you thought was not really right. Rajoguna samud Babaha we are born out of Rajoguna activity or actions, going back to actions are very important.

I need to how to act. Same activity, if it is not done properly will lead me to desire and anger. Then that will lead me to commit wrong actions. Therefore it is even more important how to do the right actions. So first thing we have seen is do for the greater good. Do without attachment.

That part is very important. That attachment creates karma and Krodha that attachment created the desire and anger. As you'll learn in the second chapter, the constant thinking of something creates attachment. That attachment then creates desire. Then that desire creates the anger. The same thought is transforming from constant thought to the desire to the anger.

And then buddhi nasha. So Bhagavan said kama erudesa mahasana Mahapatma. Once you are overwhelmed by that flow of thoughts, you can't really get out of it and you continue to commit wrong thing. We have seen all the Hindi movies. When he starts with stealing a loaf of bread and then he becomes a great Amitabh Bachchan who is, you know, angry young man. Once you are in that frame of mind and do not know how to get out of will just take you in that.

So what is it that I knew something is not right and this is right, but I cannot what is it that's clouding my right thinking? So the next verse says dumena abriate vahanihe. Just as the fire is covered by smoke, fire is there, but there is smoke. Where there is a smoke, there is fire. Smoke cannot be there without fire. But I can't see the fire because the smoke smoke is veiling that fire.

Yatha darshao malena cha. Just as mirror is covered by dirt, mirror is there. But I can't see the reflection. Anytime you take a shower, if you are in bathroom doesn't have good exhaust, your mirror will be covered with that water vapor. And you won't be able to see it till you wipe it off. Just as the embryo is covered by whatever you call it.

Placenta, womb, tatha tena idam avrutam. By that this is covered what is that? That wisdom by this what Kamaya krodesa. Three examples are given. As Swamiji says in our scriptures, repetition is not really allowed. Unnecessary repetition not allowed.

Therefore, Bhagavan ved Vyas would give three examples. Just one simple idea. That knowledge is covered veiled by something. It gives that the veiling of various categories. Just as we have seen everything in three categories, veiling is also of three categories. Sattvik, rajastic and tamastic.

The first is Tume na vriya te bhanehe. Fire is covered by smoke, but it's very thin veil. A little breeze will remove that smoke and you will see the fire. It's like a sattvic veiling. My desire to do good for the society, my desire to do good for my family, I may get trouble for that, but there was sattvic desire. And then when I realize that society really doesn't need my help or I'm not capable of doing it, that desire will go away.

That's still availing. Sattva still binds you. By the happiness it gives you. The sattvic desires are still bonded, the golden chain, but still a chain. But it can be removed easily with little knowledge, little brushing up of what is right and wrong, it can go away. The next, just that dust covers the mirror.

This is a rajasic desire. I want to achieve this, I want to acquire this. Those don't go away with little breeze. You literally need some physical actions to remove the dust from the mirror. That wisdom which I have is veiled by this desire.

Itha Ublena, Bruto Gharbaha, we know all the women now at least the man only can infer that how difficult it is for the embryo to mature and come out. It's not something which is done lightly. A child cannot get rid of their desire to play with toys. He has to mature out of that. So those are more stronger desires which you just have to give it time, let the nature take its own course. Just like as we said, how do the animals evolve? And Swami Purushadama told me on the lap of Mother Nature they don't do any karma so they don't have any Papa or Punya. Tena idam Avrutam that Kamayesha Krodhayasa is veiling this knowledge. Next was now defined what this and that is Avrutam Gnanam Etena Gnanino Nitya Vayrina Even a wise person's knowledge and for all practical purpose. Vedanta says we are all wise people.

Actually at the core of our being we know we are sat chit Ananda. But this wailing is stopping me to realize that. So Avrutam Gnanam this knowledge which is instinctively mine that who I am is veiled by Nitya Vereena. These constant enemies which are present in my mind Kamaru pena kaun the analayana cha this constant enemy present in my mind in the form of Kamarupa in the desire no matter how hard I try to get peace of my mind and we constantly sing my gimme vaidauri Santi Apnea Santi is what we are looking for all our life. But Santi we never got. Because this constant enemy is right there.

He's not leaving me alone. Other enemies, you can leave them but this enemy is within you. It's not something which you can fulfill one time and you're done with it. So desire is like that. It's not that the one time you fulfill desire and you're done with it. Duspurena Insatiable.

snippets.title: Day 55: Karma Yoga
snippets.sanskrit: एवं बुद्धेः परं बुद्ध्वा संस्तभ्यात्मानमात्मना |
snippets.transliteration: evaṃ buddheḥ paraṃ buddhvā saṃstabhyātmānamātmanā .
verseTranslations: Thus, O Mighty-in-Arms, knowing Him to be beyond the intellect and, by His help, subduing thy personal egotism, kill thine enemy, Desire, extremely difficult though it be."
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 3, Karma Yoga, Yoga of Action. In Chapter 2, Bhagavan had given us indication about who we are at the core of our being. That the self that I think I am is not the Self, but my self is imperishable, everlasting, all knowing and ever blissful. And it is contrary to my own experience. So it becomes a hypothesis for me. It's not my knowledge right now that the self is all pervading, everlasting, ever blissful.

My life is completely contrary to that. So Bhagawan says, that's because of your ignorance about yourself. So once I remove that ignorance, then I should be able to know the knowledge. That's basically our hypothesis right now. But my effort to know that is not very fruitful so far. So we have to accept that there is a limitation for me to know.

Even all Western scholars and philosophers have come to the conclusion that there is a limit for the rational thinking to get knowledge. Immanuel Kant said, I have to limit my reasoning to make room for faith that there is God or there is a Creator of this universe. And you can postulate a theory, but it does not become my knowledge. You have to rely on faith. Our scriptures say you don't really have to rely on just faith, but you can experience that if you follow certain path, then you will be able to know this. In fact, our scripture says it is your birthright to know this knowledge.

And you will know that when not guaranteed. So you have to make efforts. Efforts means activity, and activity as we know, has its own limitation. So in the beginning of this chapter, having been taught by Bhagavan Karmani, Eva di Karaste Mahphale Shukadachana, your right is only to act, never the fruits of actions. And therefore Yogastha kuru Karmani, establish yourself in yoga and then do your actions and you shall come to know this knowledge. But Arjuna obviously was not convinced that this activity is going to get me anywhere.

So obviously he asked that question. If you think then I have to establish Myself in yoga which is basically sit down, meditate and become a yogi. Then why are you asking me to engage in this war which is a terrible act? Why don't you tell me the act and can lead me to a greater understanding? So Bhagavan basically clarifies that Lokhi Asmin Duvidanishta Pura Praktamayana God in this world, the two paths are created right from the beginning. Gnana Yogina Sankhyana Karma Yogina Yogina for people with Sankhya Buddhi for the contemplative intellect.

For them it is Gnana Yoga to contemplate on this fact that I am not this body, I am not this mind, I am not the intellect. Then who I am is basically Gnan Yoga and Karma Yogini Yoginam. Those who are active in this life. For them, Karma Yoga. So basically, Bhagavan transformed Karma into Karma Yoga. And we have seen that Bhagavan has given five pointers.

Two we get in chapter two. You should not have the fruit in your mind as the goal for your action and establishing Yoga. Perform your all actions. Bhagwan says there are two parts. But for you Karma Yoga is good. Where you are in the station of your life, Karma Yoga will be much better.

There are three paths we typically talk about. Karma Yoga, Gnana Yoga and Bhakti Yoga. Karma and Gnana I have control over. At least I can make my efforts in them. Bhakti I can only get by God's grace. To fall in love is not something in my hand.

When you fall in, there is no choice in love. Bhakti is love for divine and it is choiceless. It only comes by the grace of God. Therefore Bhagawan said, start with Karma Yoga. That Karma Yoga will lead you to knowledge about God. The Bhagavan said, activity is involuntary for all beings.

Nakastyatthyanama PI Jatutisthatiya Karmakrut. But you should act in this world by controlling your senses and without any attachment. So Bhagavan said, when the Prajapati created this Praja, he also created Yajna at the same time. To sustain this Praja, the Yajna was created. So we worry about our children. How would they sustain themselves when we are not there?

So we have to make them independent. How do you make them independent? By this education you shall earn your living. So focus on your education. That's how we do as parents. Prajapati did something Similar, Prajapati created Yajna, cooperative activity where you work with the nature.

This cooperation between the beings in nature will yield results which will sustain this praja. So then we have seen a cycle in this Prakriti Annad Bhavati Bhutani, Prajanyatamna Sambhavah. And in the end says Karma Brahmod Bhav that the unit of this cycle is action. All that is happening in this Prakriti is happening because of activity in the Prakriti. And this activity is only possible at an individual level. At an individual level, if we act, then this activity becomes a communal activity, a national activity, a global activity.

But at an individual level you have to act. Then Bhagavan said, this ability to act comes from that Brahman, the supreme consciousness which is functioning through you. As long as I'm alive, I can act. So Bhagavan said, know that this activity is based in your consciousness and therefore you continue activity without any attachment. Because activity is to acquire something I don't have and preserve what I have. But if I come to a conclusion that I have acquired everything I want, should I continue to act?

For the Loka Sangra, for the preservation of the community, of the society, of this universe, you have to continue working. Look, I have nothing to gain, but I continue to work. If I don't act or work, then there will be a chaos in this cosmos. To avoid this chaos, the Sankarasyacha Kartashyam I will become the cause for this chaos in this world and therefore I continue to work. And then he comes to his final advice in verse 30 where he says, Mai Sarvani Karmani Sanyasya Adhyatma Chet Nirasi Nirmama Bhutva yudhiya, you offer all your actions to me. In this one verse, Bhagavan has given us a complete method of Karma Yoga.

Act you must but act in a manner of Karma Yoga. Now what is Karma Yoga? He said, when you act with that attitude that I'm offering all my actions to the Supreme Lord. Because we have seen in that natural cycle that acts, activity at my level is only possible because I am a conscious being. That life in me, that consciousness in me is not different than the consciousness which is all pervading. Therefore I should offer all my activities to that supreme consciousness.

Nirasi nirmamu vatva without any desire for a particular result from my actions. And Nirma not thinking anything is Mine, even this ability to act is not my own. This ability to act is God's gift to me. I did not do much to prepare that this type of body. I will have this type of mind, I will have this intellect developer. Well, this was given to me as my instrument and I'm now just using them.

If I have a better equipment than some other person, it's not something that I have done something in this life at least. So Bhagavan said, nirasi Nirmammo Bhatva, you become desireless and without any sense of agency that this is mine. Therefore, you should act according to your own dharma. Whatever, wherever you are, whatever the station you are at in your life, you should act according to that. Because you don't really have any choice but to act according to that. I can't suddenly wake up one morning and say, I really don't want to act as an architect anymore.

You know, this business is not doing well for me. I'm going to become something else. Well, I don't really have an ability to change right away. So Bhagavan said, Swadharma Nidhanam, Sreyaha Paradharmo Bhya Vah, you act according to your own dharma, according to your own Prakriti. Because to act like someone else is very dangerous. It may seem easy right now, it may seem glamorous right now, but because it is not your nature, you will fail eventually and you will not make any progress.

So therefore, he said, even a wise person is also bound by his own Prakriti. When a wise person is not free from his own nature, he also acts according to his own nature. Except that he does not consider that as his own nature. He considers this the nature of my body, mind and intellect. I offer all that I do to the Lord who is making me do that. You are bound by the Prakriti because you are part of Prakriti.

Your Prakriti is basically who you are at this point and therefore know your nature and act accordingly. In Arjuna's case, he said, you are a Kshatriya. You are a prince who is responsible to protect others. And now you are in front of this enemy army. Your job is to fight this war. In whatever station of life I am in, I should act accordingly.

Prakriti works by likes and dislikes. I have created the likes and dislikes by my experiences in the world of objects. Some experience say I like, some ideas. These likes and dislikes reside in my senses. In my sense perception. Sense perception was pleasurable.

Perception was painful. They are your obstructions and therefore avoid them. If that is the case, just tell me what is the force which makes people commit sins against their own will? Knowing this is not right, I commit that act and then I come to suffer for it. So Bhagavan said, Kama Esha Crudha esha. In the end it came down to My likes and dislikes are the root cause of how I act.

If I overcome my likes and dislikes then it will be much easier for me to act in a rational manner. Why I have not been able to do that is because of the Kama and Krodha. This likes and dislikes create desire. That desire creates anger. This Kama is the root cause of all my problems. So Bhagavan said, therefore consider them to be your enemies.

This desire and anger are veiling my true nature. We started a journey from I do not know my true self and therefore all my problems in life. If I know my true self, I'll be almighty, all pervading, omniscient, omnipresent. That knowledge has been veiled by this Kama and Krodha. Therefore Bhagavan said Avrutam Gnana Methina. Now this Gnana is the Gnana of myself.

Avruttam Gnanameti na Gnanino Nitya Vairina bhai. This knowledge is veiled from even a wise person. Kama Rupena kaunteya duspuraynanalynacha Kama desire. It is insatiable like a fire. And therefore Bhagavan says Indriyani Manobuddhi adhishthanamuchate. If they enemy have to find his location.

The location of my enemy is Indriyani Manah Buddhi Senses, mind and intellect are this desire's residences. I identified where this desire resides. It deludes the embodied by veiling his wisdom. A simple fact Bhagavan said is this desire is veiling your wisdom about your own self. And therefore this desire is your enemy. The desire is residing in your senses first by the sense perception.

This perception creates the conception of that object and then I have desire to acquire that object. If I can't acquire the object of my desire then I'm angry. This desire and anger is veiling your true self. And therefore Tasmat Indriyani Adav Niyamya Bharata Sabha. Don't let this enemy come into your house. Once it enters your house, you are in trouble.

Therefore you have to lock your doors, have a security system.
snippets.reflection:
Choose one action today—any action—and practice doing it with full attention but without attachment to results. Whether it's sending an email, having a conversation, or completing a task, offer it as best you can and then release your grip on the outcome.

Notice what happens when you work this way. Is there more freedom? More presence? More energy? The Gita's teaching of Karma Yoga isn't about becoming passive or indifferent. It's about working with full engagement while remaining internally free.

Ask yourself: Where in my life am I most attached to results? What would change if I could offer my best effort and then surrender the outcome?
