snippets.title: Day 62: Types of Sacrifice
snippets.sanskrit:
यस्य सर्वे समारम्भाः कामसङ्कल्पवर्जिताः |

त्यक्त्वा कर्मफलासङ्गं नित्यतृप्तो निराश्रयः |

निराशीर्यतचित्तात्मा त्यक्तसर्वपरिग्रहः |
snippets.transliteration:
yasya sarve samārambhāḥ kāmasaṅkalpavarjitāḥ .

tyaktvā karmaphalāsaṅgaṃ nityatṛpto nirāśrayaḥ .

nirāśīryatacittātmā tyaktasarvaparigrahaḥ .
verseTranslations: The wise call him a sage, for whatever he undertakes is free from the motive of desire, and his deeds are purified by the fire of Wisdom.
Having surrendered all claim to the results of his actions, always contented and independent, in reality he does nothing, even though he is apparently acting.
Expecting nothing, his mind and personality controlled, without greed, doing bodily actions only; though he acts, yet he remains untainted.
snippets.commentary:
Bakratam dhammah suryakoti sama. What is my purpose and destiny? So we had been discussing chapter four, Gnana Karma Sannyasa Yoga Yoga of renouncing actions in knowledge. Not renouncing actions, renouncing them in knowledge. How to not identify with their actions. So so far we have seen that Bhagavan said that Ajaha, I am a Jaha, I'm unborn.

Therefore he is also Amara. Therefore he is deathless. One who has no birth cannot have any death. So because he is Ajaha, he is also Amara. And not only that, but he says, I am a Karmaha, I am actionless, I am birthless, I am deathless, also actionless. So at the macro level he says, I'm not participating in anything that you consider is happening.

It is only happening because of my presence. But I am not actively participating in it because I don't have any desire to get anything out of it. There is no desire for Karma Phala of these actions, therefore I am not involved in it. Even the action is taking place because of his presence. But because he is not involved in it, with any desire to gain anything out of it, he is actionless. Same thing applies at a micro level to our self, which we constantly call it I that I am, I am.

But then everything we say after that I am, that I is not involved in it. I am working, I am speaking. So all the words which we attach to I and am that existence, I is not involved in it. So Bhagwan says, who is involved in that action? Then the one who consider that to be the actor is involved in it. That I, when I say I am eating, that's a physical act, so the body is involved.

Then when I say I like what I eat, my mind is involved. And then my intellect says, this is pretty nutritious, so I'm going to get some benefit out of it. My intellect is involved. Whatever gets involved, that's the one which is bound by its results. So once the I is not involved as the actor and therefore remains Actionless. That which gets involved will be bound by the actions and therefore has to receive the results.

So my body is involved in my physical act. So more exercise I do or less exercise I do, more I eat or less I eat will show up in my body. When I go to my doctor, he figures out that you may not have been doing this or you may not be watching your diet. Because my lab results tell him exactly. All that tells him what I had been doing. So the body is bound by its own actions.

Whatever the grudges and complexes I carry, they will show up in my mental attitude. So the mind is bound by what mind does. Then what I learn or not learn will show up at my intellectual level. So this body, mind and intellect are bound by these actions. Till I get attached with that body, mind, intellect, I am not involved and action less. But as soon as I identify with this body, mind and intellect, I become the doer.

And that doer is, aham, the ego. Once the ego is formed, that ego becomes the enjoyer and sufferer of these actions. So now who are we trying to really liberate right now? Not the body, not the mind, not the intellect. Ego is the sufferer and enjoyer. That ego is trying very hard to redeem itself.

Achieving a state where there is no unhappiness, there is no sorrow and there is no death. So that ego is trying very hard to achieve that by actions. Because it can only attach itself to the body, mind and intellect. And therefore it says, let me achieve this. I can achieve security by accomplishing things and acquiring things. Or I can achieve deathlessness by finding all the latest cures about or anti aging drugs, whatever that is.

And it's failing miserably. No matter how hard I try, I think I'm not aging. But other people say, Neil, you look little old now. My nephews and nieces. Kaka, now you look a little tired. And what do you mean?

We are trying very hard to achieve what we are trying to achieve through the means available to us right now. But we are not getting there. So Bhagavan said, the only one way to achieve is you disassociate yourself from actions. But actions cannot stop. So say that you have to achieve that knowledge where you start seeing inaction in actions. Actions are being performed.

The only entity which is inactive in this is myself. My self is not taking any part my consciousness. Just because it is there all These three are functioning the body, mind and intellect. Swamiji uses example that supervisor really doesn't do anything. Let's say in a factory floor, supervisor is not operating machines, but his presence make all the work going on. If he's not there, work will be all over the place.

I give my real life example a lot of times. I used to work in India in architects firm and my boss used to come to United States every two years or so to renew his green card. And those about four or six weeks he's here, we'll have a complete vacation. We all go to work every morning just as when he was there. We try very hard to work for about half an hour. And then somebody will say, you know, Neil, did you know this?

And he will start a topic and then everybody get involved. We have about six, seven people in the same room. That topic will go on till lunchtime. Then we realize, oh God, we haven't done anything. Well, let's have lunch. And then after that we can work something.

And that will go on till about four weeks. And when we realize that one week my boss is going to come back, we start suddenly putting something on a paper which looks like we had done some work. In the end, there was no real work was done when he was not there. And as soon as he comes, everything goes back to normal. We are working just as the supervisor's presence make all the workers work. But the supervisor really doesn't.

He doesn't sit down and start doing what he was supposed to do. His presence make it work. But he is not participating in your activities the same way the self is not participating, but the very presence of the self, the consciousness make people work. But because right now my identification is with the workers, all the drawbacks and the quality of the workers become my qualities. But if I identify with that self who is actionless, then I'll see also myself as action less. Karmani Akarma Yahya Pashet One who sees inaction.

Inaction action only takes place when my ego gets involved. When I was in Zambia, it was so difficult to get a driver's license because the test was about 20 times more difficult than what you go through here. And without driver's license you can't do anything. So you are so keen on getting a driver's license. You work so hard and your mind and intellect both are involved in driving it so hard. Last week I told somebody that, you know, I'm trying very hard to remember everybody's name.

And she said, don't try too hard. That was the problem. So when I'm trying too hard to drive the car, it's so difficult now driving car, I don't consider that as an action because mind and intellect are not involved while I'm driving. So Bhagavan said, when you do that, you reach a level where all your actions you see just as what you see, you're driving, you are literally removed. You have your mind and intellect are free to think about other things. Karmaniya, Karmaiya, Pashet, Karmani, Chakarma Yaha.

Not only that, but even though it seems inaction, but action is taking place. By not acting also you are doing something which is affecting you. Sabuddhiman, Manusheshu. Out of all these people who consider themselves intellectuals, such a person is a wise one. Sabuddhima and Manish Yeshu, he is a Buddhiman. He is a true intelligent person who figured out that actions are taking place at the level of body, mind and intelligence, not at my self level.

Sahayuktaha, Such a person is Yogi. He is connected Yogi, one who is connected with the self. As we have seen at a macro level, the supreme self, the God is everywhere, is omniscient, omnipotent and omnipresent. At micro level, myself is omnipresent, omniscient, omnipotent. In my this body, mind and intellect. When I see that is myself, I'm connected with that self.

So Sai Yuktah, Krishna Karmakrit and such a person knows how to act. In this world we are all acting but at a very lesser capacity. I think they say you are only using the 1/10 of the capacity of your brain. Our brain has so much capacity, but we are only using it at a very micro level. Bhagwan said, if you then think about how capable you are when you connect to your higher self, then when you act, your actions will be perfect. Krishna, Karma, Krita, Such a person know how to perform real actions.

It actually says how to become efficient in life by connecting with your higher self. And then the next few _Verses_ actually give the prescription how to attach to that higher self. So now we have learned one what the issue is. Issue is that I consider myself to be mortal who has birth, who is acting in this world and suffering. He said, no, no, you're birthless, you're deathless and you have all the capacity to work in this world except you have a wrong identification. So yes, We hear this word Samaram in our vernacular language.

When there is some event is taking place. Samaram, event is Event taking place? For whom all events taking place in his life. Kama Sankalpa Varjita There should be Kama Sankalpa Varjita Kama Desire Sankalpa is translated here as planning. I said determination. What are we determining?

I want to do this and I want to get out of this. So first I have a desire. I want to make million dollar, then make a plan. How am I going to make a million dollar? That plan is based on what I'll get a million dollar out of it. So all my actions are first starts with the desire, then I have a plan to achieve that particular results out of that action.

And therefore I'm bound to fail. Because first of all I have not figured out whether what I desire is really appropriate for my capability. And secondly, whether the plan I'm putting together action I'm putting together or capable of achieving it. Because only thing available to me as I said in this world is knowledge of my actions. I do not have knowledge about how the world is going to react to these actions but I'm still determining what the results would be. Therefore there are more unknown than known in my actions.

There are more chances of failure than success in my actions. Do not have any desire and do not have any plan to get something out of it. Kama Sankalpa Varjita Nana Agni Dagda Karmanam I am acting in this world but my all actions are burnt with the fire of knowledge. The knowledge that this body, mind and intellect are limited. They are limited capabilities. But the self which is involved in this actions is only a Saaksi Chaitan is a witness and he is not affected by any of these actions.

snippets.title: Day 63: The Sword of Wisdom
snippets.sanskrit:
यदृच्छालाभसन्तुष्टो द्वन्द्वातीतो विमत्सरः |

गतसङ्गस्य मुक्तस्य ज्ञानावस्थितचेतसः |

ब्रह्मार्पणं ब्रह्म हविर्ब्रह्माग्नौ ब्रह्मणा हुतम् |
snippets.transliteration:
yadṛcchālābhasantuṣṭo dvandvātīto vimatsaraḥ .

gatasaṅgasya muktasya jñānāvasthitacetasaḥ .

brahmārpaṇaṃ brahma havirbrahmāgnau brahmaṇā hutam .
verseTranslations: Content with what comes to him without effort of his own, mounting above the pairs of opposites, free from envy, his mind balanced both in success and failure; though he acts, yet the consequences do not bind him.
He who is without attachment, free, his mind centered in wisdom, his actions, being done as a sacrifice, leave no trace behind.

For him, the sacrifice itself is the Spirit; the Spirit and the oblation are one; it is the Spirit Itself which is sacrificed in Its own fire, and the man even in action is united with God, since while performing his act, his mind never ceases to be fixed on Him.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter four, Gnana Karma Sannyasi Yoga. Yoga of Renouncing actions in Knowledge. So far we have seen that actions are necessary, but actions are also binding. My ultimate goal is to get happiness only way I feel happiness. I'm completely liberated from my limitations and here I am acting in this world and actions are binding. So what is the prescription?

What is that one yoga which will liberate me from these limitations? So in the beginning Bhagavan said, this is the yoga which I taught from time immemorial to people. And people have been benefited by this by practicing this yoga to release themselves from these bondages. So I'm going to teach you again and see, the technique is very, very simple. You have to end all your actions in knowledge that you are not the actor. It is as simple as that.

Right now we are taking burden upon ourselves of something which does not belong to us, a responsibility which does not belong to me. I'm taking upon myself which is to control the Karmaphala. My constant goal in life is to get the desired results. That's why we plan five year plan, three year plan. People ask me all the time, Neil, what's your plan? I say, what do you mean what's my plan?

I'm talking about retirement. What's your plan for retirement? You have to plan out retirement in a particular manner so that then I can enjoy the retirement. So we plan our actions, keeping the final results in mind, which is Karma Phala. Karma Phala by very nature is not in my hand because I'm not the Karma Falada. The rest of the world is the Karma Falada.

I act and the world react and that burden on me is binding me. Bhagawan said, once you realize that you are not the actor, the one who you think you are. This body, mind and intellect is not the one who you try to satisfy. The one which is seeking happiness is someone other than your body, mind and intellect. One who wants to be liberated is someone other than your body, mind and intellect. So he starts out by giving his identity, say Ajaha, a peace on Abhyatma.

I myself is unborn, deathless, immutable, and also do not take part in any actions. And therefore the karmas don't bind me. The actions which I don't take part in, they cannot bind me. Bhagavan said, at the macrocosm I am the all pervading Brahman who is infinite, unborn, deathless. And at the micro level Atman has the exact same quality. So at the macro level he is Brahmandu, all pervading, Almighty, all potent, omniscient God.

At a macro level is Myself which I constantly refer. I is nothing but his own Self. We have logically deducted in our discussion that this world cannot be separate from Him. Because when he created this universe, the cosmos, the Brahman, no other material available to him other than his own Self created out of his own Self. And therefore you and I and this world cannot be any separate from Him. But that understanding when it takes place that this room space is no different than the space outside, then all the limitations of the room space will be gone.

So right now the room space thinks it's limited by its wall, floor and ceiling and it is suffering from its limitation. I want this room to be a higher ceiling. These limitations are also nothing but his own manifestation. If God is omnipresent, where is my body, my intellect, My mind? They are also part of Him. Only there is only one material available to him to create this universe which is his own self.

So he created out of his own self. And now I'm trying to liberate his self from these limitations which are also part of his self. It is like a cup which is made up of ice is immersed into water. So the water outside the cup is also water. Water inside the cup is also water. And the cup itself is nothing but water.

But the crystallization creates identification of name and form and shape. The ego is that crystallization of the shape of a cup. When it melts, it will be all water. So Bhagavan said, once you start realizing that the self you are trying to liberate is already liberated, it is not taking part in any of your actions and therefore it is not bound by it. But you are now identifying this self with this limited body, mind and intellect, with his name, forms and colors. And therefore you are reflecting all its limitations.

So he said, then now you start contemplating on it and then live your life. So we have seen that how to live Life is Vitaraga Bhayakroda. Without any attachment. Without any particular desired fruits of actions. Which I had been trying to achieve. Which is not in my hand.

According to your swadharma. We have learned Swadharma. This body has its own Swadharma. Mind has its own swadharma. Intellect own swadharma. Just go with that flow.

If I try to make this hall into a concert hall, I'll be disappointed. It does not have any of the qualities of a concert hall. I try to have a music party and then I say I don't sound good here. Because the hall does not have the quality to have the acoustics of a concert hall. As long as I live with the limitations of this room, I'll be happy with this room. As soon as I get out of my expectations of what this hall can do.

I'll be disappointed. Bhagavan said, follow your Sudharma and do actions without any attachment. In any particular expectation of the fruits of actions. So the Last verse, the 22nd. This is the state you should be achieving to be happy. To be perfectly happy.

The stage which you have to achieve is Yadruchanthusthaha. Whatever comes to me without effort. That sounds a little tricky to understand. Does not mean that you didn't put your efforts. But without conniving and manipulating the results. So that everything will fall in place as I want.

It's not going to happen. It is not in your hand. No matter how smart you are. Therefore, you act according to your dharma. Then whatever comes without any efforts of manipulating you be santoshta. You put your efforts.

You realize that was according to my efforts. Move on to the next step. Yadruchala va santoshta Dvanda Athitaha. Of course we know that there are times that will be conducive. At time the fruits will be not conducive. I expected something.

I was targeting to achieve this. But I end up getting this. So that's going to happen. That's a given that the law of nature that things will be different every time, same effort. You put two different times, get two different results. Last time I said this and everybody was very excited.

And this time I said let's do this. And nobody is excited. So the world will be like that. Therefore, you will be buffeted between hope and dejection. Vimatsaraha without envy. Now this sounds very difficult.

But it is the only way you can be happy because as you have seen in our analogies, it's always somebody will be little better than me no matter how high I go. So I saw on CNBC someplace, the most difficult group of people to plan for the retirement is the people who are millionaires. It's easier for one who is in a hundred thousand range. They can project what I'm going to rate how many times current income you need for retirement. It's easy for a guy who's making $60,000 a year. Guys making $10 million a year, they're very difficult.

You see, it's very difficult for as you go higher and higher to achieve that perfection. Bill Gates, if you ask him that you need an income seven times your current income to retire. But he will never be able to retire. So Bhagavan said that vimatsarah, do not judge your situation by comparing with the other person. You do not know his situation. Every time I see Facebook, I get very depressed because everybody else in the world seems so happy.

I'm the only one who has all these responsibilities and problems. Do not compare your situation with us. That's where the envy comes. I stopped reading Fortune and Bloomberg, Newsweek, everything because it depresses me. I feel so depressed that I don't have any idea how to improve this world. Vimatsaraha Bhagwan said, only way to be happy is not to compare your situation with others.

Sama Siddhava Siddha, we know success and failure. It's a relative term. But you decided what success is and you did what failure is. You remember that whatever really came is what you really deserved. Swamiji used to say, you don't get what you desire, you get what you deserve. Sama Siddha ashidhav krutvapi nani badhyata.

He never gets bound by any actions he performs, good, bad or ugly. Because once you perform actions you're done with, there's nothing you can do about it. So whatever comes back, you say, okay, next move, let's go to the next one. So you see, that's the state you need to achieve. And it seems very difficult, but it is truly, I'll tell you, it is the only way you will be happy. When you get closer to that state, it may not be exactly as you imagine in your mind what yogi should be.

But at some level, you have to achieve this to be happy. So next verse says, gatha sangasya muktasya gnana avasthi da cha yajnaya acharataha Karma Samagram Praviliyate. Our goal right from the beginning was not to be bound by my actions. My actions should be always pristine and come with the results which are complete. So I will never have to be reacting to it. So I don't want to be bound by my actions.

So the first goal we have said is Gata Sangasya. Attachment to your actions. Whose actions will be as perfect as they need to be to achieve the goal which we established in previous verse. One who is not attached to his actions. Once I'm attached to my actions, I had an interview. I thought I did the best in my interview.

Then this happens all the time. When we go for an interview, we come back and they select us. How can they select him? I think we were the best team. Give us the feedback. All of them are qualified.

But what did we not do? You did everything right. But we thought the other day I was a little better than you are a little more appropriate for this project. But we are so attached to our actions. We think that our actions are the most appropriate. Should get the result I am looking for.

But once I perform action, I should not be attached to Gata Sangasya. We are detached to your actions. Once you perform actions and move on, you are liberated from it. You feel free because you are not thinking about it. Gnana Avasthita Cheta Saha. But this thing only came because I'm established in knowledge.

I have learned over and over and over again. The results are not in my hand. Once that knowledge takes place that no matter how better I do, results will never be in my hand. Same presentation you make one time and you are the best. And next time they will say you are the lowest. Gnana Vastyatchiyata Saha.

His intellect is established in the knowledge that only control I have is on my own actions and not on the results. Yajnaya Acharataha Karma. Therefore he is acting for only one reason.
snippets.reflection:
Today, look for 'action in inaction'—moments when apparent stillness conceals profound inner activity. And look for 'inaction in action'—moments when busy-ness masks inner stagnation.

Where in your life is genuine transformation happening? Where are you just going through the motions? The wise person sees beyond the surface appearance of action and inaction to the truth beneath.

Reflect on the teaching that God Himself works ceaselessly for the welfare of the world, though He has nothing to gain. What would it mean for you to work with that same spirit—fully engaged, yet free from personal agenda?

snippets.commentary:
What is my purpose and destiny? We had been discussing chapter four, Gnana Karma Sannyasa Yoga, Yoga of Enunciation of action in Knowledge. So far we have seen that chapter two defined what Yoga is and then told Arjuna that Yogastha Guru Karmani, you perform actions rooted in Yoga. And then Bhagavan defined what yoga is. Samatam Yoga Uchate, equanimity is Yoga. That was the simple but very powerful definition Bhagavan gives it.

Samatam Yoga Uchate, equanimity of mind is Yoga if your mind is balanced in all situations, whether conducive or unconducive. Bhagwante Dutch Yoga. But then how do I translate that into my daily life? So Bhagavan said Yoga Karmasu Kavushalam, dexterity in your actions is Yoga. If you are performing action without any anxiety, then obviously there will be effective actions. And if this anxiety about the fruits of actions is not there, then your actions will be effective.

Bhagavan says that's the sign of you being establishing Yoga. Bhagawan dedicated chapter three for defining Karma Yoga. So we have seen in chapter three what Karma Yoga is. Karmas are binding because they are bound by the law of causation. It is bound by the law of cause and effect that if I perform an action that will be the cause and there will be effect which is a reaction from the world and I'll be bound by their reaction. How to mitigate that causation is Karma Yoga.

So chapter three Bhagavan dedicated to define what Karma Yoga is. And in a simple term in verse nine, he said Yajnarthaat Karmano Anyatra Loko Ayam Karma Bandanah. Any action which is not performed for Yajna is binding in this world. So the simple definition of Karma Yoga is when I perform action for Yajna, then it is Karma Yoga. And we have then defined Yajna. Yajna is any action which is performed for the greater good is Yajna, any action which is performed for my selfish gain.

Is binding action, Karma. Any action which is performed for the greater good is Yajna. Yajna, Loko, Ayam, Karma, Bandanah. Any action which is performed for the selfish motives, if I am at the center of the result, it is for me that's a selfish motive. And therefore Bhagavan said, you're bound by that action. Whatever the reaction comes from the world of your action, you're bound by that.

You have to enjoy it or suffer it. But if it is performed with a greater good, then you are not bound by it. You perform action and your story ends there. Whatever results come out, the world will suffer or enjoy. So we have defined Karma Yoga in chapter three. Chapter four is now centered on the word Yajna.

So in chapter three, we have learned what Karma Yoga is, is to perform actions in the spirit of Yajna. But what yajna is is now defined in chapter four. And then chapter five will take that a step further. And what sannyasa is, this chapter is labeled Renunciation of Action in Knowledge. So I'm now renouncing my actions and not mine by thorough understanding that I'm not the doer. In other words, I'm not capable of doing anything unless I'm enabled by all others.

All others in this world have to do so many things for me to do even a smallest act of drinking tea. When I come to understand that I am not the sole in charge of my action, then my ego will diminish. And then I come to understand that ego actually have no real part in the consciousness which is enabling the ego to perform action. So Bhagavan said, that will be I am now renouncing my action in knowledge. But when I renounce my actions completely, I become a sannyasa. When I have no sense of agency, I am a sannyasa.

So this concept of Karma Yoga is defined in three chapters. First, define Karma Yoga. And then we will learn what is Sannyasa. So far in chapter four, we have learned what is action, what is inaction. One who sees inaction in action and action in inaction. He's the person who sees things as they are.

There are times when I'm acting, but it's of no consequences. The time I'm not acting with great consequences of me being not acting. And that's a great action. We have seen last time that Mitch McConnell not bringing whatever legislation on the floor is inaction. But it's the greatest action he performs by not doing anything. So similarly, there Are times we don't do anything.

If we don't perform our duty, it's an inaction. But that's a great action performed by us which will have the consequences. So you'll learn what is inaction? The one who sees through inaction and action. He knows what actions are. And then we have seen the characteristics of a sage.

We have seen similar Characteristics in Chapter 2 in Sthita Prajna Lakshana. The last section of Chapter 2 define what a man of perfect wisdom is. So the last verse we have seen. Yadruchalabhasantustaha Dhwandvati Taha Matsyara Sama Siddha asiddhavcha Krustva nani badyate. Who does not get bound by the action? A man of perfect wisdom.

What is perfect wisdom? What is action and what is inaction? One who has learned this art of action. Such a person is from our perspective. He is acting feverishly. Swami Chinmayananda was the most dynamic person I knew.

He was acting all the time. But none of his actions ever bound him. Because Sama Siddhi Asiddhavcha same in success and failure. You take a project and you have great goals. Sometimes you succeed and sometimes you don't. But if you don't take the success and failure to your heart then you are a yogi.

But therefore those actions do not bind you. He is happy with whatever comes naturally. I perform my actions. What comes to me, I accept as Prasad. I do not question why me and why not me. I am not getting result.

Other people are not doing anything but getting all the credits. But once a one who does not think in those terms, he is happy. Yadrucha Lava Santustha. He gets whatever without any anxiety. He is happy with that Dvandvati Tah. He is beyond the pairs of opposites.

In other words, he is not affected by the pairs of opposites. Pairs of opposites are very much in this world. There are days which are cold and there are days which will be very hot. But if I know how to deal with both of them then I am a happy person. How do I compare myself whether I am successful or not? By comparing myself to others.

If I see others are not as successful as I am then I consider myself successful. But I think I am not as successful others. Then I consider myself a failure. That's how we judge ourselves. Our gauge is not inside. Our gauge is outside.

I don't judge by my own height, I judge by other side. Other people are taller than me, therefore I'm short. Other people are shorter than me then I'm tall. When we change who I am Bhagawan said V Matsyara There is no envy. Everybody is who that person is. Such a person Sama Siddha, Siddhav, Krustvapin Nani Badyate he does not get bound.

So we have seen the definition of perfect person in the verse 23 really ties all that together in half a line. What a person of perfect wisdom is Gatha Sanghasya whose attachment is gone devoid of attachment that the first quality of a sage that he has no attachment to anything. He lives in the present environment, in India, in Egypt, in Iran Wherever I find myself, I find myself comfortable. Bhagawan says that's because no attachment. Gatha Sanghas is devoid of attachment in any situation. If I feel comfortable, that means the word of attachment Muktasya this liberation only comes if I have no attachment.

One with no attachment is always free. We are bound by our own attachments. The bondage which I feel in this world is my own creation. I myself decided that I am a tattoo. My family, my children, my profession, my possessions I'm bound by them. I feel myself incomplete without them.

I have bound myself and only I have the capability to liberate myself. When I liberate myself from these attachments, I avoid these attachments. Muktasya he becomes Mukta liberated. But this is only possible if Gnana Avasthita Cheta Saha whose mind, whose Chetana whose Chitta is established in knowledge Knowledge about who I am and who I am not. If I know my true self that I am not this body, mind and intellect, the limited being, this body and intellect are my equipment. But I am something other than this.

All the attachments of the body, all the likes and dislikes of the body, of the mind, of the intellect belong to them only and not to me the self. Such a person will be devoid of attachment. Because he is devoid of attachment he will be liberated. So what is important is the knowledge. Knowledge about your own self. So I may get this glimpse of my true self in meditation.

But it's not going to last forever. I'll come back to my day to day life and have to work in this world. River Bhagawan said Yajna Acharatah Karma Samagram Praviliyate Then I'll still be working in this world. But for Yajna Going back to the verse in chapter three, Yajna tat Karmanu annytra lokoyam Karmabandana. Now that I have no attachment, I will be working, but only for the Yajna for the purpose of helping the community, helping the society, helping everyone around me. All his Karma will be dissolved.

In other words, there is no after effect, there is no rebound effect, there is no cause and effect relationship to his actions. He is not performing for himself. The next verse defines what Yajna is. Brahmarpanam Brahmahavehi Brahmagna Brahmanahutam Brahma Eva Tena Gantavyam Brahma Karma Samadhinaha we have seen that everything in this world, if it is manifestation of the same entity, the Brahman, then obviously you and I cannot be any different from Brahman himself itself, herself. Brahman is the reality. Everything else is just a projection on the Brahman.

I cannot be different from my own Lord. Because if God created this universe out of his own self, there is nothing in the universe which is other than Bhagavan God Ishwara Brahman. Therefore he says any action that liberated sage of perfect wisdom performed, he sees that it's happening in the Brahman by the Brahman, in the self, by the self. Very famous metaphor of Yajna used here to explain Yajna. In the Vedic time the Yajna was very central ritual. So in that central ritual you, you have fire invoked.

A deity is invoked and something is offered to the deity through that fire in the fire by the devotee. So Brahma Arpanam, Brahman is the instrument of offering the ladle which is used in the Yajna to pour the ghee, the ladle itself in nothing but Brahman alone. It is the manifestation of the same reality. So Brahma Arpanam, the means to act is Brahman. In my case, the means to act is my body, my organs of actions. They are nothing but the manifestation or the representation of Brahman only Brahma Havihi.

What I am offering in that fire, what I am offering is my efforts performing actions that's only enabled by Brahman only. So Brahma Havi, the instrument is Brahman. What is offered is also Brahman. Brahma Agna in the fire of Brahman. So in my case the body which enables me to act in this world is expression of Brahman. My efforts to act in this world is also Brahman.

The field of action in which I am putting my efforts is also Brahman.

verseTranslations: And yet others offer as their sacrifice wealth, austerities and meditation. Monks wedded to their vows renounce their scriptural learning and even their spiritual powers.
There are some who practise control of the Vital Energy and govern the subtle forces of Prana and Apana, thereby sacrificing their Prana unto Apana, or their Apana unto Prana.

snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter four, Gnana Karma Sannyasiyog Yoga of Renunciation of Action in Knowledge. So we had been discussing Karma Yoga in last chapter and in chapter two, Bhagavan says the Karmani Eva Adhi ka Rasthi Mafula that your right is only to act, but you have no right for your fruits of actions. So for us to understand that concept, we have to understand what action is. So we have learnt in this chapter what action is, which then relates to what we learned about Karma Yoga. In the last chapter where we have seen that Bhagavan said Yogastha Kuro Karmani Sangam tyaktvadhananjaya. That's the essence of Karma Yoga.

Do not expect any fruits of your action. Establish yourself in yoga and then without any attachment perform actions in this world is Karma Yoga action I must perform, but I must perform in this manner and for what I should perform action. This chapter in verse nine says Yajnar Tat Karmano anyatra Loko Yam Karma Bandanaha. All actions other than those performed for Yajna are binding Tadartam Karma Kanthya. Therefore, perform actions for Yajna alone, Mukta Sangha Samacharaha without any attachment, with equanimity of mind. So the final advice we have seen is perform actions for Yajna.

We learnt in verse 24 then that Yajna is to understand that everything that is involved in my action is nothing but Brahman alone. There is no difference between the hunter and hunted. It's all manifestation of Brahman alone. Say Brahmarpanam Brahma have Brahma Agna Brahma hutam. Using this metaphor of Yajna, we have learned that everything involved in this Yajna, the four things involved the instrument, the offerer, the deity and the offering itself. So these four items Bhagavan said, that is nothing but Brahman alone Brahma Eva Samadhi Nah, it's only going to the Brahman alone.

This is the renunciation of action, in knowledge. Having this knowledge that all actions are performed because in and by Brahman, by the power of Brahman, Bhagawan said that's Yajna. So then next few verses we learn the 12 types of yajnas we have seen so far 10 of them from verse 25 onward. So in verse 25 we say deva Yajna and Brahma Yajna. Deva Yajna is that when I see that all that is happening in my experience all the sense perceptions are only happening. The offerings of the sense object to the senses, the devas.

Therefore I remain detached from those experiences. Every experience I see is only happening between the sense objects and the senses. I am just a witness of what's happening that Deva Yajna. Then we say Brahm Yajna. When I offer my limited self to my higher self. When I realized that my limited self is nothing but the expression of the higher self, it was never separated from its higher self.

As we have seen, the room space and outer space is always one and the same. Remove the room space remains where it is. My conditioned self remained where it is after my death. It was here before my birth. So that's Brahm Yajna. That understanding firm in your mind, constantly keeping at the back of your mind in all your action.

Then sense control, that's another type of Yajna. Either control your senses so that they don't wander around or mind control. Senses may bring any information but mind does not get attached to it. That's the mind control. Self restraint by controlling all the senses it's self restraint. So that's another Yajna we have seen.

And in the last verse which we have discussed there are five Yajnas we have seen. Dravya, Yajna, Tapa Yajna Yoga Yajna, Swadhya Yajna and Jnana Yajna. So the life of charity. Everything that I have is for charity. Dravyajna is not just giving you one check every year during tax time. But it is something which I offer that everything I have is for the greater good.

Nothing belongs to me. What I have acquired from this world, this Prakriti, I have to give it back to the Prakriti. What I have borrowed from this Prakriti, this body, mind and intellect, they also don't belong to me. They are just lended to Me for my experiences, that type of attitude, Dravya Yajna then Tapa Yajna austerities for the self control. When I perform certain disciplines, that's tapa Yajna then yoga Yajna, various upasanas and sadhanas. All these Yajnas are for the purification of my mind and intellect for the Antakarana Shuddhi.

As a seeker of happiness, my job is only to purify my internal instrument. Rest will happen automatically by God's grace. The Bhagavan is partial to his Bhakta. Oh now he's praising me all the time. It is the very nature of yourself. Just like I think that Yogi Berahur said the the more I practice, the luckier I get.

My preparation made me worthy of getting that opportunity. So here yoga is the upasana I prepare myself. Then the next one is swadhyaya. Reflecting on your own self introspection. Who I am is this body me, this mind me, the intellect me, the accomplishments me. That's basically is the swadhya Yajna.

And then we said Gnana Yajna, Yoga of knowledge, offering your ignorance, consciously trying to get out of the veiling of this mind is Gnani Yajna. Our learning Bhagavad Gita falls into the Gnani Yajna. The last two yajnas, the Pranayama and Pratyahara. These come from Patanjali's Yoga sutra, Ashtanga Yoga, eight parts, the Yama Niyama Asana, Pranayama Pratyaha, fourth and fifth steps of Ashtang Yoga, Pranayama Pratyah. So the verse 29 says Apana Jihuati Pranam Pranay apanam Tatha apare prana pan gati ruddhwa Pranayama Pryanaha. Those who are expert, they're engaged in pranayama.

They perform this pranayam in various ways. There is not one method. There are various ways. It says Apana Jhuvati pranam. So apana is outgoing breath. And even this book says outgoing breath.

I read Bhagavan Sankaracharya's Bhashya and it says apana is incoming breath. So there is a little contradiction there. And I checked some other books and some of them kind of agreed with Sankaracharya's Bhasha. Apana is incoming breath, Ap Anaha is incoming and Pra anaha is outgoing. But whichever way you look at it, the meaning does not change. Of the verse, let's say apane jhuvati pranam, some offer outgoing breath into the incoming breath and prana apanam tadapara and some offering the outgoing breath into incoming breath.

In other words, two diametrically opposite practices in pranayama. Pranayama, as we have seen, is the control of all the vital energies. But at the core of it is the control of breath, which is actually the word is svasa. And if you read Patanjan Yoga Sutta, he does not use word prana here. He says svasa, incoming svasana, outgoing use the word swaasa. But the overall technique is also called pranaya.

By controlling your breath, you control your pranas. All the other functions of the pranas which right now I have no control over. So even when I am in a deep sleep, all my organs are functioning properly. My heart, my brain, my liver, my kidneys. Because the conscious mind has no control over this organ. You can imagine if the conscious mind has to control these organs, then we will all be in lots of trouble.

But conscious mind has no control over these organs or they are free of conscious mind. And therefore it functions all three states of my existence. That waking, dream and deep sleep. But the yogis have found ways to control these functions by the conscious mind. This is called pranayama. Their observation was that as the state of my mind change, my breathing changes.

So if I can control my breathing, I may be able to control all my pranas and all my mental thoughts. So the techniques devised was to control breath. Panditji used to say that we have finite number of breaths to take in this life. If you take faster breathing, you have a shorter life. If you have slower breathing, then you have a longer life. So people who are calm, normally quiet and have control over their breathing is normal.

They live longer life. People who are very excitable and constantly get agitated and excited, their breathing goes faster and they live a shorter life. I have no knowledge about that. But this is what the Yoga Sutra basically say, control your breath so that you are regulating your breath. So many, many years ago when we were in Dallas, Texas, we took the course of Raja Yoga in Pranayama and Raj Yoga. One of my friend's father, Mr. Haris Raja, was a disciple of Aswami Muktananda and he gave us a pranayama training.

We used to have that in early morning at 6:00. And that's a part of Raja Yoga. So the yogas which we have seen, the pranayama, are performed in three different types of tradition. One is the Shiva Yoga. Vignana Bhairav is the book from the Kashmir Saivites. And you see on TV this Shiva yogicant and he said that by controlling the breath, you can control all your systems.

There is no need for any medication. We can control everything by controlling breathing. Then popularly, what we know about yoga in this country is Hatha Yoga. Hatha Yoga is basically the first three sections of Ashtang yoga, Yama niyama and asana. We focus more on the third step, which is asana. But then the Yoga Sutra says you should not start pranayama until you have mastered asanas.

So asanas are very important and they're ones who master the asanas. Then you do pranayam. And many, many teachers I have come across say hatha Yoga is very good, but it also can be dangerous if you are not under the guidance of a trained teacher. Be careful, have a good teacher, then you can practice. Raj Yoga, on the other hand, is considered safer and subtler. So what Pandit Ji used to teach is also Raja Yoga.

And what we learned many, many years ago, that's also Raja Yoga where basically the breathing is controlled by nine mudras. They call it remote controls. Now obviously there is no scientific study done on why that works or does it work. But all the yogis have said that they do work. So it's a apana jhuvati panam prana apanam tatha apare prana apana gatirandhwa pranayama prayanaha. Those who are expert, they engage in this pranayama.

And in Bhagavan Sankarachaya's Basya, I learned that the first technique of apane jovati pranam is called purak. We talked about purak, Rechak and Kumbhak. He said these three are described here. The first one is called purak. When you are offering incoming breath into the outgoing, it's called purak. Then another is called rachak because you are offering incoming breath in outgoing breath.

And then pranapati gatim rudwa. This t restricting the flow of air is called kumbhak. This has to be practiced in a serial manner. So Mr. Raja used to write articles in Times of India. Those articles were published into a book. In that he said that the goal of pranayama is our normal breathing is about 16 breaths in a minute.

The goal is to reduce them to four. So in one minute there are only four Breaths and he recommends in his book and what he taught us back in 80s is 5 seconds for inhalation, then 2 seconds of Kumbhak, inner Kumbhak for 2 seconds, then 7 seconds of exhalation. Because he said the air has now expanded because of the body temperature. It takes longer to exhale than inhale. So it is seven seconds. So that makes 14 seconds.

They hold the breath of one second outside before taking the next breath and they start the cycle again. That makes 15 seconds. So there are four breaths in a minute.

snippets.title: Day 66: Types of Sacrifice
snippets.sanskrit:
यज्ञशिष्टामृतभुजो यान्ति ब्रह्म सनातनम् |

एवं बहुविधा यज्ञा वितता ब्रह्मणो मुखे |

श्रेयान्द्रव्यमयाद्यज्ञाज्ज्ञानयज्ञः परन्तप |
snippets.transliteration:
yajñaśiṣṭāmṛtabhujo yānti brahma sanātanam .

evaṃ bahuvidhā yajñā vitatā brahmaṇo mukhe .

śreyāndravyamayādyajñājjñānayajñaḥ parantapa .
verseTranslations: Tasting the nectar of immortality, as the reward of sacrifice, they reach the Eternal. This world is not for those who refuse to sacrifice; much less the other world.
In this way other sacrifices too may be undergone for the Spirit's sake. Know thou that they all depend on action. Knowing this, thou shalt be free.
snippets.commentary:
Shri Purohit Swami did not comment on this sloka

We had been discussing chapter four, Gnana Karma Sanyasi Yuga for renouncing actions in none. So far we have seen that Bhagavan said that I am going to tell you a secret in knowledge, having known that you will not have to know anything else. And this is nothing new. I had been teaching this from the beginning of time how to end your actions. That's the goal, to end my actions. But right now I'm not finding any means to end these actions.

Nurghan said that one who developed the knowledge that the self is not the doer. He can get out of this cycle of actions and reactions and actions. Again, the cycle continues. I act the world react that becomes actions for the world. When I react to that reaction, it become my actions and the action reaction cycle continues. He said, once you get out of this notion that I am the doer, then you will be out of this cycle of doing and reacting, suffering, enjoying.

So in verse 14 he says namaam karmani lin panthi Namay karmafulesh prahaha ithimam yo vijayanathi karma bihin NASA badhyadhya. He is not bound by any actions. One who knows me as Namam Karmani limpanti Karmas do not bind me, they do not attach to me. I don't get attached to the karma in Namay Karmafula. I do not have any desire for the Karma Phala that I is the self in me. I think I have all these desires.

Well, that I does not have any desires. My mind has desires, my intellect has desires, and also my body has desires. It feels a little hot. My body tells me, let's make it comfortable. So all these things which I think I have karma falas pruha or the desire to enjoy is at either the body level, at the mind level or the intellect level. At the self level there is no desire.

The one who knows himself as the one has no attachment to action. Self never gets attached to any action. Neither that self has any karma falas pruha. One who knows this as his own self in this manner he does not get bound by any actions. Another question is how do we get to that point? So in verse 23rd, the technique is Gatha Sangasya.

He has given up all attachments. He works in this world but does not get attached. He said the attachment to the world is like a post it notes. As long as it is there, it is attached, you remove it. It does not leave any mark on their wall. Gatha Sangha says no attachment.

You can take it from here and put it here. And take it from here, put it here. It will get attached to whatever but not leave any mark. Gnana Vasthidha Saha. So he's free, he's not attached. And his intellect is organized by the knowledge that the self is not having desire for any fruits of actions, neither it is taking part in any actions.

Yajnaya Charathaha Karmaha. And therefore he is constantly acting in the spirit of Yajna for the greater good. All the actions which are taking place are only taking place for the greater good, not just for my selfish desires. Karma sama Grim pravely. That's how all the karmas will get destroyed for that person. He's not having any sense of identity with his actions.

Then we have seen that this Yajna can be performed in various ways. But what should be the Yogi, the one who has mastered this art of performing actions in Yajna, his attitude. There are two ways he said. The first one he says is Devam Evapare, Yajnam Yogi, Nahapariupa Sataya. Some yogis will perform all their actions working in this world, experiencing this world as the world is offering its objects for the perception of his senses. World's offering to the senses.

It's not him going to the world, world coming to him. That's how he never gets attached to him. Because he is not really going out to the world. World is coming to him for his perception. So all the perception comes and goes, but he never gets attached to any one of them. That's the one way other.

Brahma Agnavare Yagnam Yagne Eva Upa Jihuvati. Others will sacrifice the self by the self. And the next verse is Brahmarpanam Brahmavi. Everything that is happening is happening by the self alone. So now that when I'm working in this world, I'm offering myself which I consider to be myself right now is my sense of perception. Sense organs of actions in the service of the self, the greater self.

So now everything which I'm doing is offering to the self by myself. The limited self offering its own self for the service of the self. In this attitude, when he works in this world, he's also not getting attached to any actions because he obviously is not really performing any actions for himself. So both are the various ways the Yogi sees this world. Either this way where the world is offering to himself, or he is offering himself to the greater self. Both are the techniques with which he can continue working in this world, but not getting attached to the actions.

And then we have seen that the agnas can be performed in 12 different ways. The fire you have to kindle for this yajna is not the physical fire, but the fire of your self restraint. So Samyama Agni, he's going to start with kindling first his fire of restraint. That restraint first can be at this sense level, sensual perceptions he limits to a point where he does not get attached to them. So restraining the senses is the first method we use it. The second method is the mental restraining the perception.

So whatever the perception comes, he obviously restrain its impression, does not let that perception leave any impression on his mind. So it's a mental level. And the next level of yajnas we have seen is the intellectual level, Swadhyaya Yajna. I constantly reflect on what is the truth about myself. Constantly asking question, who is it that tells me that I am doing this? So that's swadhya yajna at the intellectual level, which is we call gnana yajna.

Then Bhagavan also enumerated that there are other yajnas as well. But all of them we have seen is performing yajnas in the mental level. By kindling the fire of restraint, restraining of the senses, restraining of the mind, or restraining the intellect into the inquiry of what is the self. We have seen there are other methods available. There is not really one method fits all we know because human beings are made in various different permutations and combinations. Sattva, rajas and Tamas, whichever is most conducive for me, I should be practicing.

But the goal is to perform actions in Yajna spirit. That's basically the goal. Evam, Bahvida, Yajna, Vitatha, Brahmana, umukhe. Thus there are many yajnas are lying at the mouth of Brahman. These are not the only yajnas that we have described. But there's a limitation for the poet to tell us how many he cannot Enumerate a list of thousands of Yajnas.

We see many methods that are available to you. Vitatha Brahmanamukha. They are scattered in front of the Brahman's mouth at the gate of Brahman, the gate of perception of the Brahman. There are many paths which are leading towards that that will open the door for you. So any of that, whatever path I take, as long as I have taken the correct path towards my goal, that goal will be available to me. Karma Janaan Vidhi Taan, Sarvaan Evam Gnatva Vimoksha Se.

But know all those paths are born out of actions. In other words you can sit back and relax and say things will be done and then someday I will have a realization. It's your self efforts. No matter which path you take there is no easy shortcut. All of them you have to put your own self efforts to get there. So know that once you know Karma Jan Viddhi there is not a single path which is just stay relax and you will get.

Actions are very much essential in each part. Actions are the binding force right now and I'm trying to get out of it. Actions are the only means available to me to get to Brahman. As long as I put my self efforts on a right path. Bhagavan says Vimoksha Se you will achieve the moksha. As long as I take the right route to go to New York.

Whether I take 95 north through New Jersey Turnpike or go towards Real 95 through Philadelphia and all of that. As long as I know that this path is leading towards my goal and I put my efforts sitting down here thinking about it. I will never go to New York but putting my efforts into it. Tan Sarvan Evam Ganatwa Vimoksha Sey they're all going to take you to the same goal as long as you put your self effort in a diligent manner in a very honest manner. So the next verse says Sreyan Dravyam Yagnath Gnana Yajnaha Parantabah Sarva Karma Ahilam Partha Gnane Parisamarpiate which path I should take. He said the Gnani Yajna is clearly better than the Dravya Yajna.

This is not an indication that this all the various paths which are described as one is better than other. All paths are gonna lead you. As long as you put your self efforts in a clear understanding what my goal is will get you there. However the culture in the environment may mislead Me, me just writing a check to Hindu Center. I think that I have earned some punyas. Bhagavan says that dravya yajna will get you very little because the whole intention behind writing the cheque makes that cheque what is worse to you not to Hindu Center.

Hindu center the same value. I write a check for $101. The $101 they can cash it. But that $01, whether it gives me what value is all about my intentions. What efforts did I put with what intentions, what understanding I did that will give me my reward. Therefore he says Sreyan, Dravyam, Yagnath, Gnana, Yajnah, Paramta.

Whatever your perception of that offering, as long as the knowledge does not take place place, that offering does not get you much. Therefore the knowledge is superior than your physical act of performing Yajna. I may be exercising but not with a clear understanding of what I'm trying to get out of. Then obviously it won't have the same result as with the clear goal of what I'm going to get out of it. With that disciplined actions will get me with a clear plan, clear knowledge what this action should bear. The final results will get you much greater results.

And you go to American Fitness. Do you have a trainer? I don't have a trainer. Why do I need a trainer? That trainer will give you this gnana. Which exercise will be better for you?

I may be putting lot of efforts but in a wrong direction. Yesterday we were at somebody's house and somebody took out of the list of what food does not goes with what. In the end we said if you follow this, we will not be able to eat anything. He said parotta should not be eaten with dahi yogurt. So Punjabis are all gone. See, even that knowledge, if it is put in the right context may have some value.

Obviously whole of our Ayurveda is about parhaj. You have to regulate your diet and that's you don't need other medication. But for hijj which is near the ahar. But just doing upavas without thinking may actually make me sick.

snippets.title: Day 67: The Sword of Wisdom
snippets.sanskrit:
तद्विद्धि प्रणिपातेन परिप्रश्नेन सेवया |

यज्ज्ञात्वा न पुनर्मोहमेवं यास्यसि पाण्डव |

अपि चेदसि पापेभ्यः सर्वेभ्यः पापकृत्तमः |
snippets.transliteration:
tadviddhi praṇipātena paripraśnena sevayā .

yajjñātvā na punarmohamevaṃ yāsyasi pāṇḍava .

api cedasi pāpebhyaḥ sarvebhyaḥ pāpakṛttamaḥ .
verseTranslations: This shalt thou learn by prostrating thyself at the Master's feet, by questioning Him and by serving Him. The wise who have realised the Truth will teach thee wisdom.
Having known That, thou shalt never again be confounded; and, O Arjuna, by the power of that wisdom, thou shalt see all these people as if they were thine own Self, and therefore as Me.
Be thou the greatest of sinners, yet thou shalt cross over all sin by the ferryboat of wisdom.
snippets.commentary:
What is my purpose and destiny? We have been discussing chapter four, Gnana Karma Sannyasa Yoga Yoga of renouncing action in knowledge. So we have seen in the beginning of chapter three, Bhagavan had said that there are two paths always available for a seeker to seek the ultimate knowledge. The Gnana Yogi in a Sankhyana Karma Yoga yogina. For the yogis, the Karma Yoga and for the Gnani, the Gnana Yoga. So chapter three we discussed Karma Yoga.

This is where one needs to start. Bhagavan Saha that if you are engaged in this world of activities, in this rajasic world of activities, then it will start with Karma Yoga. And Karma Yoga simply says act with the balanced mind without expecting any particular fruits of your action and act efficiently. That's basically Karma Yoga. Remain balanced in any situation. Do not react overly in any situation.

Bhagawan said, you start with that. Purpose of that is to purify your mind and intellectual so that you can function very efficiently in this world. But what type of action I should be performing in that manner was described in chapter four. In the beginning, Bhagawan said, you should know what is karma and what is akarma. You should know what is vikarma, what is akarma. So you should have some basic gauge to decide actions are appropriate or not appropriate there.

Bhagavan said that when you reach a point where action seems inaction and inaction seems action, you now come to understand what action is all about. And how do I get to that point? Bhagavan said, Yajnaar Thaat Karmano Anyatra Lokwayam Karma Bandana. You get bondage from your action in this world because you are acting in this world as an individual trying to compete with the rest of the world. It's creating sorrows and unhappiness and fears and greed and jealousy. That's because this concept of duality that I am an island by myself, the world is out there to get me.

Bhagwan said that you overcome by performing your Actions in the field of Yajna. Yajna is something you're not doing for yourself. You're sacrificing something for greater good. So if you go to Hindu temple and Panditji is doing Havana, every mantra start with Idhamna Mama, this is not mine. Up till now I thought this is mine. But right now I'm offering it for the greater good in the holy fire.

Something I always thought is mine. I offer it as does not belong to me anymore, that we call it charity. The money which I thought is mine, I write a check and send it to a non profit organization. I say now it is not mine, it is yours. You do whatever you need to do. So that's the act of Yajna.

Yajna is to sacrifice something which you thought is yours. But you came to the conclusion that really does not belong to me. I heard one of the CNN executive retiring and he said learn, earn and then return. Learn the knowledge, how the business works. Then earn, make money and then return. Return back to the community.

And that's what most of us one way or other do. Because we have seen that when person dies, he cannot take anything with him, acquire things, think that his own and then eventually gives up, leaves everything here and goes away. So Bhagavan said that that concept you have to understand even while acting in this world. And therefore you have to act in the spirit of Yajna, in the sphere of Yajna so that you come to realize the oneness. So Bhagavanjarya, once you perform this, you will get the Brahmagna. So I have this translation of Ganeshwar Maharaj Gnaneshwari.

This chapter is actually titled in Gnaneshwari as Brahma Yajna Prasantsa Brahmajna Prasansa Nama Chaturtha Dhyayah. So here we say Gnana Karma Sanyasi Yogana. There are books I have seen which simply says Gnani Yoga. So chapter four is about knowledge. Knowledge about your own self and how to get it. So the two paths which Bhagavan had initially described that is always available right from the beginning of this universe for a seeker to realize the truth is Karma Yoga.

And then Gnana Yoga, Karma Yoga. When you are not ready yet, very Rajasic, perform Karma Yoga. But then ultimately you have to have Gnana. The knowledge, what it is all about, why my actions are not my actions. And when I come to realize, it becomes inaction. It's no longer any action which is belonging to me.

So in verse 33 we say, Sarvam karma akhilam Partha gnane parisamapyate. Bhagavan came to that final statement saying, O Partha. All the actions, good, bad and ugly that you had been performing or you think you had been performing once you know the knowledge, they get all dissolved once you achieve their knowledge. What is their knowledge? He said we would learn that. Brahma arpanam Brahmahavihi Brahma agno Brahmahutam.

Everything that I perceive in this world that I consider to be something other than me is also not different than me. The same entity which makes me who I am, the very same entity makes the world of plurality what it is. Once I come to that conclusion, Bhagavan said, Sarvam karma akhilam grana parishama pyyade. All actions which I am either very proud of or very afraid of that I may have to pay for them. Those actions all will get resolved. So in last verse 34, Bhagavan said, the only way to get it is to someone who has realized this knowledge.

I can only learn something from someone who has experienced it. If I am dreaming and suffering in my dream, only other waker can see that I may be going through a nightmare and awake me. Are you having a nightmare? Another dreamer cannot do that. Another dreamer who is also dreaming his own dream. He cannot wake me up from my dream.

Only a waker who is not dreaming can see that I am having a nightmare and can wake me up. So Bhagavan said, go to a guru. You may not call him a guru. You may give him another title. But go to someone who has experienced this knowledge, experienced this truth that there is no duality in this world. The world is the manifestation of the same reality.

That duality is created out of my own ignorance about the nature of this universe. In Prakriti there is multiplicity. Prakriti itself is one entity. But in that there is multiplicity. Just as I as one person. But I have multiple limbs which has different parts and different functions.

But I know that all these limbs are nothing but me. And therefore there is no conflict ever. My right hand is not fighting with left hand and left hand is not fighting with my right hand. Because there is a unity of thinking. And that knowledge, you can only get it from a great person who has realized this Tadviddhi Prani pati ne pari prasnayana sevaya. You have to put your own efforts.

You can't really get it just by thinking about it. You have to put your own efforts with that humility that you do not know. Right now what I know is. Is creating more conflict for me, is creating the sorrows, unhappiness, fears, jealousy, greed, all that. Because I think the world is out there to get me and I need to take care of myself. So once you know the Tadviddhi Prani patena pari prashnena by inquiring what is real and what is unreal, what is my true self and what is not my true self.

Sevayah by serving the teacher Upadekshyanti tegnanam Gnani nah Tattvadarshi nah. And if you find that person, if you are sincere you will find a person, if you are sincere to know that that teacher will point you in the right direction, will give you the direction how to find your own self. You have to find yourself. But you will find a guide to get to your destination. Is this something Bhagavan? I'll know one time and then I'll forget it.

There are a lot of things I have learnt before but I now have forgotten is of no great value. Neil, do you know calculus? I've learned in my college days but I know nothing about it anymore. The Bhagawan said no. This knowledge once you know you will never get confused like this. You are right now confused about whether to fight or not to fight this battle.

Knowing that knowledge, you will never get confused again. Bhutani Ashena Drashasi Atmani Athomai. That is because right now my problem is that I see that world is competing with me and therefore I'm getting confused about how to protect myself. And that's what is creating confusion. In Arjuna's case my people are there and I have to kill them. I have no problem killing others, only my people.

I'm worried about killing them. But once in this I and mind, once dissolved, you will not have any problem. Two people facing each other in a dark alley are afraid of each other because one doesn't know who the other one is. So they hide from each other because they think the other person is out there to rob me. But once they realize that other person is my friend then all the fears are gone. So that identification is the unifying factor.

Bhagawan said once that identification takes place, that atmani atomai that you will see that all beings are in your Own self. The self which I consider my own self is not limited to this body, mind and intellect. But it is all pervading and encompassing everything. That teacher will make you realize that yourself is that supreme self where everything is contained in it. And you will see that in me. Me, Bhagavan said, krishna himself.

You will see in the God all the beings. You also said, that's nothing but your own self. When takes place, all the fears will be dissolved, all the negative tendencies of your mind will dissolve and you will be free from all the problems belong to you. So Bhagavan said apiched, So now I come to that point of gauging my own capability. Am I capable of achieving this? And 99 times of 100 we come to the conclusion that's for the sannyasis, that's for somebody, not for me.

It may be, but I don't know whether I'm going to get it in this lifetime or not. Don't worry about the lifetime. Because you do not know what your lifetime is. This life is not the only existence you have. Bahuni, me, Vyatitani, Janmani, Tawachaljani. You and I have spent many, many lives before we never perished and we will be there forever.

So therefore time is not of any consequence here. Neither your own qualification. If you consider yourself to the best among sinners, so even the criminals also have categories. The best and the worst. From a stupid criminal to the most intelligent criminal. All the jewel thief movies I used to love in my younger days.

Because jewel thief is not an ordinary person, he is so intelligent. If you consider that you are the worst of sinners, then also it does not exclude you. Because sin is nothing but the other aspect of karma. If it is utilized in a proper field, it becomes merit. If it is in a wrong field with a wrong attitude, it becomes sin. So all you are doing up till now is what you consider your sins is you're applying your ability to act with a wrong attitude.

Those attitude and the consequences experiences are creating negative impression on your mind. Therefore you consider yourself sinner. You cannot be a sinner because you are part of that pristine reality.
