Bhagavan said that when you reach a point where action seems inaction and inaction seems action, you now come to understand what action is all about. And how do I get to that point? Bhagavan said, Yajnaar Thaat Karmano Anyatra Lokwayam Karma Bandana. You get bondage from your action in this world because you are acting in this world as an individual trying to compete with the rest of the world. It's creating sorrows and unhappiness and fears and greed and jealousy. That's because this concept of duality that I am an island by myself, the world is out there to get me.

Bhagwan said that you overcome by performing your Actions in the field of Yajna. Yajna is something you're not doing for yourself. You're sacrificing something for greater good. So if you go to Hindu temple and Panditji is doing Havana, every mantra start with Idhamna Mama, this is not mine. Up till now I thought this is mine. But right now I'm offering it for the greater good in the holy fire.

Something I always thought is mine. I offer it as does not belong to me anymore, that we call it charity. The money which I thought is mine, I write a check and send it to a non profit organization. I say now it is not mine, it is yours. You do whatever you need to do. So that's the act of Yajna.

Yajna is to sacrifice something which you thought is yours. But you came to the conclusion that really does not belong to me. I heard one of the CNN executive retiring and he said learn, earn and then return. Learn the knowledge, how the business works. Then earn, make money and then return. Return back to the community.

And that's what most of us one way or other do. Because we have seen that when person dies, he cannot take anything with him, acquire things, think that his own and then eventually gives up, leaves everything here and goes away. So Bhagavan said that that concept you have to understand even while acting in this world. And therefore you have to act in the spirit of Yajna, in the sphere of Yajna so that you come to realize the oneness. So Bhagavanjarya, once you perform this, you will get the Brahmagna. So I have this translation of Ganeshwar Maharaj Gnaneshwari.

This chapter is actually titled in Gnaneshwari as Brahma Yajna Prasantsa Brahmajna Prasansa Nama Chaturtha Dhyayah. So here we say Gnana Karma Sanyasi Yogana. There are books I have seen which simply says Gnani Yoga. So chapter four is about knowledge. Knowledge about your own self and how to get it. So the two paths which Bhagavan had initially described that is always available right from the beginning of this universe for a seeker to realize the truth is Karma Yoga.

And then Gnana Yoga, Karma Yoga. When you are not ready yet, very Rajasic, perform Karma Yoga. But then ultimately you have to have Gnana. The knowledge, what it is all about, why my actions are not my actions. And when I come to realize, it becomes inaction. It's no longer any action which is belonging to me.

So in verse 33 we say, Sarvam karma akhilam Partha gnane parisamapyate. Bhagavan came to that final statement saying, O Partha. All the actions, good, bad and ugly that you had been performing or you think you had been performing once you know the knowledge, they get all dissolved once you achieve their knowledge. What is their knowledge? He said we would learn that. Brahma arpanam Brahmahavihi Brahma agno Brahmahutam.

Everything that I perceive in this world that I consider to be something other than me is also not different than me. The same entity which makes me who I am, the very same entity makes the world of plurality what it is. Once I come to that conclusion, Bhagavan said, Sarvam karma akhilam grana parishama pyyade. All actions which I am either very proud of or very afraid of that I may have to pay for them. Those actions all will get resolved. So in last verse 34, Bhagavan said, the only way to get it is to someone who has realized this knowledge.

I can only learn something from someone who has experienced it. If I am dreaming and suffering in my dream, only other waker can see that I may be going through a nightmare and awake me. Are you having a nightmare? Another dreamer cannot do that. Another dreamer who is also dreaming his own dream. He cannot wake me up from my dream.

Only a waker who is not dreaming can see that I am having a nightmare and can wake me up. So Bhagavan said, go to a guru. You may not call him a guru. You may give him another title. But go to someone who has experienced this knowledge, experienced this truth that there is no duality in this world. The world is the manifestation of the same reality.

That duality is created out of my own ignorance about the nature of this universe. In Prakriti there is multiplicity. Prakriti itself is one entity. But in that there is multiplicity. Just as I as one person. But I have multiple limbs which has different parts and different functions.

But I know that all these limbs are nothing but me. And therefore there is no conflict ever. My right hand is not fighting with left hand and left hand is not fighting with my right hand. Because there is a unity of thinking. And that knowledge, you can only get it from a great person who has realized this Tadviddhi Prani pati ne pari prasnayana sevaya. You have to put your own efforts.

You can't really get it just by thinking about it. You have to put your own efforts with that humility that you do not know. Right now what I know is. Is creating more conflict for me, is creating the sorrows, unhappiness, fears, jealousy, greed, all that. Because I think the world is out there to get me and I need to take care of myself. So once you know the Tadviddhi Prani patena pari prashnena by inquiring what is real and what is unreal, what is my true self and what is not my true self.

Sevayah by serving the teacher Upadekshyanti tegnanam Gnani nah Tattvadarshi nah. And if you find that person, if you are sincere you will find a person, if you are sincere to know that that teacher will point you in the right direction, will give you the direction how to find your own self. You have to find yourself. But you will find a guide to get to your destination. Is this something Bhagavan? I'll know one time and then I'll forget it.

There are a lot of things I have learnt before but I now have forgotten is of no great value. Neil, do you know calculus? I've learned in my college days but I know nothing about it anymore. The Bhagawan said no. This knowledge once you know you will never get confused like this. You are right now confused about whether to fight or not to fight this battle.

Knowing that knowledge, you will never get confused again. Bhutani Ashena Drashasi Atmani Athomai. That is because right now my problem is that I see that world is competing with me and therefore I'm getting confused about how to protect myself. And that's what is creating confusion. In Arjuna's case my people are there and I have to kill them. I have no problem killing others, only my people.

I'm worried about killing them. But once in this I and mind, once dissolved, you will not have any problem. Two people facing each other in a dark alley are afraid of each other because one doesn't know who the other one is. So they hide from each other because they think the other person is out there to rob me. But once they realize that other person is my friend then all the fears are gone. So that identification is the unifying factor.

Bhagawan said once that identification takes place, that atmani atomai that you will see that all beings are in your Own self. The self which I consider my own self is not limited to this body, mind and intellect. But it is all pervading and encompassing everything. That teacher will make you realize that yourself is that supreme self where everything is contained in it. And you will see that in me. Me, Bhagavan said, krishna himself.

You will see in the God all the beings. You also said, that's nothing but your own self. When takes place, all the fears will be dissolved, all the negative tendencies of your mind will dissolve and you will be free from all the problems belong to you. So Bhagavan said apiched, So now I come to that point of gauging my own capability. Am I capable of achieving this? And 99 times of 100 we come to the conclusion that's for the sannyasis, that's for somebody, not for me.

It may be, but I don't know whether I'm going to get it in this lifetime or not. Don't worry about the lifetime. Because you do not know what your lifetime is. This life is not the only existence you have. Bahuni, me, Vyatitani, Janmani, Tawachaljani. You and I have spent many, many lives before we never perished and we will be there forever.

So therefore time is not of any consequence here. Neither your own qualification. If you consider yourself to the best among sinners, so even the criminals also have categories. The best and the worst. From a stupid criminal to the most intelligent criminal. All the jewel thief movies I used to love in my younger days.

Because jewel thief is not an ordinary person, he is so intelligent. If you consider that you are the worst of sinners, then also it does not exclude you. Because sin is nothing but the other aspect of karma. If it is utilized in a proper field, it becomes merit. If it is in a wrong field with a wrong attitude, it becomes sin. So all you are doing up till now is what you consider your sins is you're applying your ability to act with a wrong attitude.

Those attitude and the consequences experiences are creating negative impression on your mind. Therefore you consider yourself sinner. You cannot be a sinner because you are part of that pristine reality.
snippets.reflection:
Today, look for 'action in inaction'—moments when apparent stillness conceals profound inner activity. And look for 'inaction in action'—moments when busy-ness masks inner stagnation.

Where in your life is genuine transformation happening? Where are you just going through the motions? The wise person sees beyond the surface appearance of action and inaction to the truth beneath.

Reflect on the teaching that God Himself works ceaselessly for the welfare of the world, though He has nothing to gain. What would it mean for you to work with that same spirit—fully engaged, yet free from personal agenda?

snippets.title: Day 69: Action in Inaction
snippets.sanskrit:
अज्ञश्चाश्रद्दधानश्च संशयात्मा विनश्यति |

योगसंन्यस्तकर्माणं ज्ञानसञ्छिन्नसंशयम् |

तस्मादज्ञानसम्भूतं हृत्स्थं ज्ञानासिनात्मनः |
snippets.transliteration:
ajñaścāśraddadhānaśca saṃśayātmā vinaśyati .

yogasaṃnyastakarmāṇaṃ jñānasañchinnasaṃśayam .

tasmādajñānasambhūtaṃ hṛtsthaṃ jñānāsinātmanaḥ .
verseTranslations: But the ignorant man, and he who has no faith, and the sceptic are lost. Neither in this world nor elsewhere is there any happiness in store for him who always doubts.
But the man who has renounced his action for meditation, who has cleft his doubt in twain by the sword of wisdom, who remains always enthroned in his Self, is not bound by his acts.
Therefore, cleaving asunder with the sword of wisdom the doubts of the heart, which thine own ignorance has engendered, follow the Path of Wisdom and arise!"
snippets.commentary:
So far in Bhagavad Gita and in our discussion about Vedantic philosophy, we have learnt that Brahman is pristine, imperishable, immutable and without any attributes. That Brahman, which is all pervading, nothing exists outside Brahman. So there is no good or evil which is beyond Brahman, outside of Brahman. And if Brahman is all pervading, then obviously the good and evil, as I perceive, must be residing within the realm of Brahman. But these are two contradictory assertions. One, Brahman is all pervading, pristine, and there is no good and evil.

There is no happiness and sorrows in Brahman. At the same token, if the happiness and sorrows do exist in my life, then this happiness and sorrows must be existing outside of Brahman. When I make that assertion, I make Brahman limited. Because now that realm of happiness and sorrow is outside the realm of Brahman, which makes Brahman limited. Either there is happiness and sorrow in Brahman, or there is no happiness and sorrows. And Brahman remains pristine, unborn, imperishable, untainted.

So that is the quest of our life. So then we have looked at how I experience my life and what is my relationship to Brahman. So we have seen that Brahman expresses as Purusha and Prakriti, matter and energy, mind and matter, consciousness and matter. When I think about consciousness, I'm conscious of everything, but not about my own self. So this Purusha remains untainted. The Prakriti, it seems, goes through changes.

This Prakriti, which is the manifest world, has plurality. And that's where we see changes. World, as I knew yesterday, does not exist today. It has already changed. So it seems Prakruti is going through changes. So we have learned that Prakruti has three Gunas, Sattva, Rajas and Tamas.

These three Gunas, when they are in equilibrium, there is no phenomenal world. When my three Gunas in my self at a micro level, are in equilibrium, there is no experience which I call deep Sleep. In deep sleep there is no Sattva, there is no Rajas, pure Tamas and everything is in equilibrium. And therefore I do not experience anything. So there is no phenomenal world when these three gunas are in equilibrium. It is only the touch of consciousness when I wake up from my deep sleep that the world of phenomena comes in place.

So I must make a journey from that world of Brahman which is pristine to the world of phenomena which I experience. So the world of my happiness and sorrows are within the phenomenal world. So Bhagavan in Sankhya Yoga told, you will experience this bliss if you lose your identification with this individual being that you consider yourself to be. And for that he said, you have to purify your internal instrument. The instrument which you have to experience the world outside is mind and intellect. I am experiencing the world outside through my mind and intellect supported by my senses.

River Bhagavan in chapter three gave us a simple method of Karma Yoga to purify your mind and intellect. Right now has come to the conclusion that my happiness outside in this world and I need to acquire it. That notion is creating this conflict with this world. And therefore I'm working hard in this world. Actions are motivated by my desire to achieve that state of perfect happiness. All my actions right now are either to get happiness or avoid unhappiness.

So Bhagawan said, you are motivated by your quest for happiness. All now you have to do is find out where your happiness is. And therefore he said that the happiness lies within yourself and you need to find it. The senses are creating sense experience as we have discussed. And my mind gets deluded by Moha attachment. When I see something which I like, I get attached to it, then I want to acquire it.

And if I can't acquire it then I get angry. So Bhagavan said, you have to purify your mind and intellect and therefore start with Karma Yoga. Perform your actions because you're motivated to act in this world. But just change your attitude towards your actions. Your actions should expand your identity. Your problem on one side is your identity so limited to yourself, to your body, to your mind, to intellect, you to expand it more, you expand more.

Happiness, evil, gain. If you come to the conclusion that everything that is happening in this world is perfect then you have less complaint about this world. If Brahman is perfect, then Purusha has to be perfect and Purusha is perfect. Prakriti has to be perfect because Purusha and Prakruti are nothing but the expression of the same Brahman. One cannot be imperfect, another remains perfect. If Brahman is perfect, his creation also has to be perfect.

So Brahman plus Maya, as we have discussed is Ishvara. If Ishvara is perfect, his creation also has to be perfect. If I take that notion that this world is perfect then the imperfections which I see has to be because of my own ignorance. My complaint about this world is about its imperfection. It is not as perfect as I would like it to be to make me perfectly happy. River Bhagavan said, when you change your vision, your drasthi then you will be able to see that this world is perfect.

Everything is in this world is the necessity. Without that the world will not function. The world will function perfectly for you if you start seeing it as perfect. So that journey was Karma Yoga, Yoga of Action. To expand my identity, more I work for the greater good, more I identify with that greater good. Then achieve that sense of belonging to that greater self.

So Bhagavan said, you perform Karma Yoga. To perform Karma Yoga, Bhagavan has given us Yajna. And Bhagavan says, once you perform this Yajna diligently then you will achieve knowledge. That knowledge is not outside of you but within you. You already know yourself but right now it is veiled by your identification with your limited self and your duality between the world and you. That knowledge will remove that veil.

So what we have seen in last few verses is it says Yatha e Dhansi, Samidha, Agnihi Basma Sat Gurute. Just as blazing fire burns everything to ashes, now there is no duality left in that fuel. If you put fire in different things, the wood and something else and paper, all that has duality before. Once it becomes ashes, they all become one. Gnana Agnihi, Sarvakarmani, Basma Saat Kurute Datta. The knowledge about yourself will burn all your actions which you consider either good or evil.

All of that will merge into one. In this world there is nothing but the same entity. And therefore there cannot be too many different things. Everything has to be the expression of the same entity. I don't identify myself as my mind is separate and I am separate. So at my level I say my mind and body are one and the same.

My present is nothing but an imaginary line between my past and future. Past and future are not two separate entities but continuum of my own self. So Bhagavan said that knowledge will burn all your Actions just as when I wake up from the dream, all the actions in the dream are resolved. No consequences of any bad, good or ugly actions in my dream. So Bhagavan said, in your understanding all accents will burn. Nahi g na ne Sadrusam Pavitram Miha Vidyate There is no greater purifier of your own actions other than that knowledge that you are not the doer.

This world is functioning as Bhagavan has designed. So once you know that everything in this world is perfect, it is as it is necessitated and I am a part of it, then it will purify all the impurities in your mind which is creating this confusion. So therefore he said, there is no greater purifier. I try my best to purify my experience, make it all good, but it is not really working. Prabhupada Gandhi Once you know this knowledge that your self is nothing but expression of the supreme self, all your actions will be dissolved and you will be purified of all your wailing and sins. Tatsvayam Yogasansiddha Kalena Atmani Vindhati that the person who is established in Yoga and we have seen the definition of Yoga before.

One whose mind is completely balanced that he does not get affected by any situation because now he has stopped seeing world as good and evil. He has stopped seeing world as I in the world. So his mind is completely balanced. Yoga Sansidhya Tatsvayam he himself will recognize this in his own self in time to come. It will not happen overnight because as Swamiji says, some guru put his hand on me. But it will happen because I made effort to purify my mind and intellect by gaining the knowledge about who I am.

That journey may take time. Karl, it will happen. Is it a year from now? But once it will happen. Your job is to keep marching on the path of Karma. Use the methods which are available in Sastra.

All these yagnas which we have seen. Bhavan said, at the mouth of Brahman, there are many such yajnas are available. In other words, there are so many paths. Whichever path is the most conducive for your own situation, you should take that. But your responsibility is to walk that path and not just know about it. So Bhagawan said, Saddhavan Lavateghnana now for that to take that path, first of all you have to have faith that there is something which I can achieve.

That destination is available. If I want to go to some fictional place, there is no chance that I will ever reach there no matter how hard I try. A fictional city created in some fictional novel. And if I want to see that. I think people have tried to find Sherlock Holmes home. We all know Sherlock Holmes is a fictional character and therefore everything we describe is somewhat fictional.

But people still go to London to find Sir Cellock Holmes home. That's a fictional destination. If I know Sherlock Holmes did not exist and therefore his home cannot exist and therefore there is no chance for me to find the home where Sherlock Holmes lived. But if I know that destination which I'm looking for exists, there is Hawaii on this planet and I can go to Hawaii if I make efforts and I save enough money and take my journey. If I have that faith that Sraddha Bhagawan Sankaracharya says. Guru Vedanta Vakya Adisu Vishwas If I have trust in what my teachers have told me that H2O makes water then someday I can go into laboratory and make it happen and then experience myself.

But if I think this formula is wrong, what my teacher is teaching me then I will never get there. That Sadhana is trust in what I have learned from others from their experience. I trust that there is a destination where the pure happiness lies. Tatparaha Sanyat indriyaha lapate gnanam1 who is tatparaha who is anxious, he wants to go there. Not only I know about Hawaii but I had intense desire to go there. We heard that in Wimbledon both players are equally prepared and equally capable.

One who wins is one who has the fire in his belly that I need to win this match. That anxiousness, that burning desire to achieve it. Tatparaha Sainyat Indriyaha I may have both have faith there is a destination. I also have this great desire but not disciplined. I want to a great athlete but I have no discipline. So these three if I cultivate, I have faith that there is a state where I can be perfectly happy and I want to get it.

snippets.title: Day 70: True Renunciation
snippets.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच |

श्रीभगवानुवाच |

ज्ञेयः स नित्यसंन्यासी यो न द्वेष्टि न काङ्क्षति |
snippets.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca .

śrībhagavānuvāca .

jñeyaḥ sa nityasaṃnyāsī yo na dveṣṭi na kāṅkṣati .
verseTranslations: "Arjuna said: My Lord! At one moment Thou praisest renunciation of action; at another, right action. Tell me truly, I pray, which of these is the more conducive to my highest welfare?
Lord Shri Krishna replied: Renunciation of action and the path of right action both lead to the highest; of the two, right action is the better.
He is a true ascetic who never desires or dislikes, who is uninfluenced by the opposites and is easily freed from bondage.
snippets.commentary:
We completed chapter four and we started discussing chapter five. Chapter four was Gnana Karma Sannyasa Yoga, Yoga of Liberation of actions in Knowledge. Now chapter five is called Karma Sannyasa Yoga, Yoga of Renunciation of accents. Some of the books only titled it Sannyasa Yoga. So basically Yoga for renunciation or true renunciation. And the word true is very meaningful here because renunciation can be of many types.

And we have been discussing what is true renunciation. Chapter one and two give us the background and gave us the insight into the nature of the self. 3 and 4 talked about karma Yoga, Yoga of action. So our journey is from inertness, which is the true nature of this body. In Prakriti everything is inert and our body is nothing but part of this Prakriti. So the very nature of our self is inert.

Given a choice, what we want to do is nothing. So what are you doing this weekend, Neil? And my answer is nothing. I really don't plan anything. The real joy is not doing anything. So that's our basic nature is inertia, inertness.

So inertia is our nature and therefore the danger is that we may fall into tamas. So first quest is to whip yourself up into rajas to start doing activity. You can't do activity unless there is motivation. What is the motivation? My desires, my goals. To acquire accomplice is the motivation that very very important to have motivation.

So all my activities are driven by my motivation, which is desires. So from inertia I have to go to desire prompted activities. That's where I do things and accomplish and achieve. But then I have to rise above those because I realize that's not the end, that's the means to go to the end. So the next goal is to have desire less activities which is the yoga. So we have seen the yoga is the activity which keeping the greater good in mind so that the Yajnas used in 12 different types of Yajnas described in last chapters, which is to prompt ourselves into level of activity which will purify your mind and intellect.

And why are we purifying our mind and intellect? Get to the next stage where we can realize who we are, the self. So that's meditation, Dhyana, contemplating on your own self what it is. So it's a journey from inertia to realizing yourself. Chapter 3rd and 4th prepared us for desireless activities Yagna. As we said, the definition of yajna is activity, which I do for the greater good.

Keeping the good of the entire society, the community, the cosmos, the universe, the humanity in mind is my Yajna. There are 12 different methods we have learned. Now once I have learned the art of action, then I have to go beyond actions. So the next two chapters, chapter five and six focus on how to transcend actions and transcendence. As we have seen something, when I drop attachment to, I transcend that. In the standard examples we have seen is when I was a child or attached to my toys.

And as I grow, the attachment to those toys drop. You can't give a 12 year old on a birthday in a balloon or something which you gave him at the age of three. Even though a little Maida, I can see a difference between what I could give her six months ago and now constantly changing, say oh no, I don't want that. See, because that's a baby's toys. Just six months ago she was playing with it, now that's a baby's toy. So you transcend as you attach to the higher and higher.

So if you attach to the higher, then the lower drops off. When we attach to the activity, Tamas drops off. When I attach to the desireless activities, the desires drops off. And now I have to go beyond that. So the next two chapters. Chapter five makes a bridge between contemplation, the Dhyana and the yoga which is activity actions.

So therefore it's called a Sanyasa yoga Karma. Sannyasa renouncing actions in the first few verses starts with Arjuna's question. Now this is not really anything unique. Even the ardent students of Bhagavad Gita constantly get confused about what is the goal of life and whether it is sannyasa is good or yoga is good. In the two terms we have defined before, egoless action giving up the sense of doership is sannyasa. If I give up the agency, the I am the doer, it's sannyas.

But if I give up the enjoyership that I am the enjoyer of roots of my actions, then I am a yogi. So yoga requires tyaga, giving up the Fruits of actions. Sannyasa requires complete renunciation of myself as this limited being as the doer but not very clear to most of us. So Bhagavan puts this question in Arjuna's mouth which we have universally asked. Sanyasam Karmanam Krishna punar yogam Chasansashi Yat shreya etayoho ekam tanme bruhi sunis chitam. We go and ask this question all over.

Tell me one thing that I can practice. Don't confuse me with all this elaborate discussion about what is right and what is wrong. Just tell me should I go and do this or not? Sanyasam Karmanam Krishna punar yogam chasansi. You are praising Sannyasa because we have seen several verses in last four chapters which says offer everything to me, just do actions for me. All of that basically means I have to renounce actions.

So it says Sanyasam Karmana sansasi. You are praising renunciation of action, giving up actions at the same time. And also you are praising Yoga. You spent the whole chapter describing what Yoga is. So now you tell me what is good for me. Yat sreya ethayaha ekam tanmi bruhisoneshitam.

Don't give me two absence. As I told you before, probably absence really create confusion. When I was in Nairobi to buy a car I had to register your name just like in India used to be. And I think they changed. But I'm talking about 80s in India also to get a car you have to register yourself and after two, three years your number comes. Nairobi was same way.

My boss told me that Neil go and buy a new car. The company used to give me a car and an old car. I was so excited I went and told my friends. My boss told me buy a new car. They all started laughing. I said why are you guys laughing?

He said new car means next couple of years then you may get it. I said no, no no, I need it now. He said there is no way you're going to get a new car. You register then a number will come. But I was so determined I need a new car. My boss told me you can get a new car, I'm going to get it.

So I used all my influences, told all my friends, all networking, all business people I knew they finally found one car from the remote area agency where there's one car available. Because you know they allocate quotas to different agencies and remote area. There was no one to buy cars so it was available so we bought the car from the remote area and drove it back to Nairobi. And I was so proud that I got a car. There is not even a question which car it is. Whatever it is, it was actually called Ford Laser.

None of you may have ever heard here Ford Laser. It is actually Mazda Trivanti, made in Japan for Ford company. I didn't even ask them what does that mean. They actually told me it's actually Mazda but it's Ford. New car, that's all I need. And I was so proud and happy.

And after about eight months we decided to come to United States. I had to sell the car. So my boss said, you go and sell the car. I said, are you sure? Yeah, you sell it to whoever there. I realized why he wanted me to have a new car.

They're selling a car fetches more money than what I paid for because cars are scarce. So somebody has a new car, people going to pay premium. So I sold that car for probably one and a half times what I bought it for. So the company made a profit on me in eight months. I used the car and give a profit to it. Then I come here very first week I realized I can't survive in this country without a car.

snippets.title: Day 72: The Liberated Soul
snippets.sanskrit:
योगयुक्तो विशुद्धात्मा विजितात्मा जितेन्द्रियः |

नैव किञ्चित्करोमीति युक्तो मन्येत तत्त्ववित् |

verseTranslations: He who is spiritual, who is pure, who has overcome his senses and his personal self, who has realised his highest Self as the Self of all, such a one, even though he acts, is not bound by his acts.
Though the saint sees, hears, touches, smells, eats, moves, sleeps and breathes, yet he knows the Truth, and he knows that it is not he who acts.
Though he talks, though he gives and receives, though he opens his eyes and shuts them, he still knows that his senses are merely disporting themselves among the objects of perception.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter five, Karma Sannyasa Yoga, Yoga of True Renunciation. So the chapter opens with Arjuna's question, which one is better? You had been praising Sannyasa. At the same time you are asking me to engage in action. Both are reaching the same goal. Whether you start with Karma Yoga or a Sannyasa, it will take you to the goal which you are striving all your life, that is finding a permanent bliss.

Right now, it seems my life is filled with agitations and unhappiness. No matter how hard I try, I can't get out of agitations. Even when I think I'm doing something with good intentions, it creates agitations. As the Rolling Stones say, the road to hell is paved with good intentions. We do think we are doing it with good intentions. We end up in a very uneasy situation.

So how do I get out of it? One side, I think if I continue working harder and harder, I'll get to the point where there will be bliss. That's our retirement plan, isn't it? I want to work hard and work hard so I can get to a blissful retirement. Or say, I'm so tired of this agitations and unhappiness, I should give up everything and not get involved in anything. That's typically what we go through in our life at various stages of our life.

And that's basically Arjuna's question is, and Bhagavan said no. Intelligently engaging yourself in both, either in Karma or renouncing karma will get you the same goal. However, for you, Karma Yoga is clearly better. You are not at a state to renounce actions. As Swami says, I can only renounce something which I have. I can renounce and say I have given up Hanover County.

I don't own Hanover County. I can't renounce Hanover county. Or I give Hanover county donation to Chinmaya Mission can't happen. I have to have something to renounce. So if I have worked very hard in the field of my actions, then only I can retire from actions. If I never engage myself into actions, there is nothing to retire from.

The man who never worked in his life, he can retire. If you're not working Monday through Friday, there is no weekend. All seven days are weekend for you. So Bhagavan says first thing is you have to engage yourself in actions. You start with Karma Yoga, apply yourself into actions and you start out your actions in your life with first with desire prompted actions. I want to achieve this, I want to accomplish this, I want to get this and that will get me to happiness.

Then he realized that that's not getting me anywhere. Then started desire less actions. Bill Gates obviously started out with a lot of desires, built the biggest company, want to put PC on every home and build the largest company. And he did whatever is stuck to make the Microsoft the biggest company. Now what he's doing is desireless actions. He's giving up all the money he has earned.

He's engaging himself actively into his foundation to better the people's life. So I start out to get that happiness through my desire prompted actions. Then graduate from desire prompted action, desire less actions. From this desireless action only I can graduate to the agency less selfless action. So the selfish action then selfless action is a journey. And for that a Karma Yoga is a means to achieve that.

So Bhagavan said that only the people who do not understand this journey they will think that Karma Yoga is different than Sannyasa, Sankhya or Gnani Yoga is different than Karma Yoga. But one who establishes one will get the result of both. Once I establish myself in Karma Yoga, my mind and intellect will purify and achieve that bliss. So is when I realize that I'm not this limited being being, I am not the doer, then I'll achieve the same bliss. So Yat Sankhe Praapvyate Sthanam Tad Yogi API gamma te. Whatever is received by the knowledge that I am not this limited being is also be achieved by performing Karma Yuga.

So the one who sees that this is the same path leading to the same goal, Yapasyati Sapashyati. Such a person realizes what the true destination is. What is the true journey is Sanya Sastamaha Baha Dukham Aptama Yogatah. But if I start renouncing things before achieving things, it's very painful. I haven't even gained anything. How can I renounce anything?

So first step to make myself worthy of giving up. If I start giving up without achieving anything, I want to make a Donation of a million dollar. But I have only hundred thousand dollars in my bank. It's going to give me more pain. If I achieve the level well, I can start giving up. Bill Gates could not have given up his money before Microsoft was built, right?

So for one who wants to renounce before achieving anything, it's very painful. Therefore don't start thinking about giving up actions before you accomplish actions. Yoga Yukta, Munihi Brahman Achiranadhi Gacha Diprama. Once you establish yourself in the Yoga, Karma Yoga which is selfless action, Niskama Karma from a desire prompted action. When I establish myself from desireless actions it is very easy to give up after that then Sannyasa comes very naturally to us. See therefore in number four Varanasram, you start with Brahmacharya which is the life of a student.

Then Grhasthasram, you have to engage yourself in the activity, achieve things, produce things, do whatever it is to support the society, your family, community. Then Mana Prastam, gradually retreat from all activity. Not suddenly but gradually start giving up the powers to your juniors, your sons, your underlings, whoever you consider. And then Sannyasa, you already taken yourself out of this action to a point where it's very easy to exit out of these actions. So you see, once you establish yourself in that desireless actions it is very easy to achieve that peace which you are looking for. Yoga Yukto Visuddhatma, Vijitatma Jitendriyaha Sarva Bhuttma Bhutatma Kurvanapi Na Lipyate.

Once I establish myself in desireless action and I want to take Sannyasa. That Sannyasa does not mean that I will not be acting in this world. Outside I'll be working in the world. But now the actions don't bind me. He said Yoga Yukta once was established himself in the Karma Yoga and the art of action. When I was learning music, obviously it's so painful to do this Saragamma Sargam.

Once you establish in that, it's very easy. So once you master anything, it's very easy to perform that action. So to perform these actions in a right way, Bhagavan said is without desire. You perform the same action without desires. Right now it is very difficult for me. Because everything is prompted by my desire.

I want to achieve this. So all this is creating agitations. Once I'm out of agitations then it is very easy for me to give up. So these are the qualifications Yoga Yuktah Once we established in how to perform actions. Visuddhaatma Vasudhatma. Your internal instrument is purified.

Mind and intellect is now purified. So it sees things as they are. And we are not polluted by my desires. Right now the reality is colored by my desire. If the market is going up, we are all very happy. And the interest rates are at zero level.

Great for a businessman. But as the guy who is retired and he is relying on that investment income, he is suffering with a 0% interest rate for so long. So person who is surviving on the investment income for him 0% interest is a disaster. For a person who is borrowing money to leverage his business, that's great. There's never a better time in this country than last few years. So it's all colored by my desire.

But the one who is not involved in both, he sees that as a normal occurring. This is how the world works and there's nothing to rejoice or regret about it. Vijay Tatma who has a control over his self in this case is ego. Who has a control over his ego. He knows that these things are happening. I'm just doing my part.

Jit Indriyaha One who has control over the senses. Indriyas are there for purpose and they have their own reasons to be there. And I have control over what I see, what I hear, what I touch, what I taste. I have control over it, not my senses. Sarva Bhuttma Bhuttatma now this is the real test of a Sannyasi. Once he starts seeing that the self in me is the self in all beings.

Myself and yourself and his self or herself are not various selves. One self manifesting as me, you, he, she, it. When that reason comes, Bhagavan says Kurvan API na lipya dhai. He can do whatever he wants in this world but not affected by it. We are affected by our actions because we think I've done good, that means I'm going to get something out of it. I've done bad, I'm going to get punished by it.

All these things because my desires. But once I have transcended the desires. See, when two children are playing and both are your children, who wins and who loses is not a problem. Serena Williams and Venus Williams. At one time they were both in a final Wimbledon or one of them to their father. What does it matter which one will his daughter is going to win.

Guaranteed he is that as otherwise he is jumping up and down in his chair. Whether his daughter is going to win or not, if I start seeing the myself in everything, then whoever is winning or losing is all me winning and me losing. Therefore, Bhagawan always says, you are not suffering, I'm suffering with you. When I suffer, he suffers at the same time. You know, different Puranas, they say that somebody did this or Bhagwan had the pain. It's kind of symbolic.

But if I pervade everywhere in my dream, even the one who is suffering and one who is enjoying, both are me. So Bhagavan said, when I start seeing that Kurvanna pina Lipyade, then whatever I do is not affecting me. So the following three verses say the attitude of a person who has achieved that level of accomplishment and seeing things as one. How that Sanyasi so is now a realized person. He has seen that the one self pervades everywhere and I am no different than it. His attitude will be Naiva kinship, Karomi Ithi, Yuktah, manyya tattvavit.

Here is the qualification or the description of a self realized master Tattavit who knows in essence what the reality is all about. There is no plurality as we see. The perception of plurality is because I have confined myself to this limited identification. I am a one person when it comes to when I identify this as me. But I am just when representing a family, a company. When I say I'm from Google, so I represent Google.

The entire Google pervades in me. The whole power of that company I exude when I say I am from Google. I remember I used to work for large companies. So when I go to Austria or someplace, I'm not Neil Bart. I'm representing wzmh, one of the largest companies. When I take out my card and say I'm Neil Bart, wzmh.

I'm not presenting my qualifications. I'm presenting qualifications of my company. Then I left company, started NBJ architecture with four people. Now I have to say I am who I am. It changes your perception when you expand your identification. So one who has expanded his identification to the entire universe, for him Naiva kinship.

snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter five, Karma Sannyasa Yoga, Yoga of Renunciation of Actions. So far we have learnt in Bhagavad Gita that the self which I consider myself is not the real self. We learnt in chapter two, Sankhya Yoga. So the entire quest in our life is to reconcile this paradox we have. We consider ourselves to be a limited being. But Bhagavad Gita says, you are not the limited being.

So how do I remove this paradox? How do I change this paradigm with which I'm functioning right now as an individual limited being and identify with that unlimited supreme being? That's basically the goal of rest of the teachings of Bhagavad Gita. So in chapter three, Bhagavan said, you can start with Karma Yoga, Yoga of Action. Act you must but act in a way that it does not bind you so that you can free yourself from this conditioning that you have considered to be. You act in this world without an expectation for the fruits because you are not in control of the fruits.

Right now I consider myself to be completely separate from this world and I'm competing with this world. Bhagavan said, unless you give up this identity of your own, you will not be able to realize your true identity. So Upanishads tell us that the world which I see is finite, that supreme is unlimited, infinite, Almighty, all knowing. But for me to perceive that is very, very difficult. So therefore we stand this Om Purnamadhah Purnamidam Purnath Purnamuddhachate Purnasya Purnamadaya Purnamavashate. It says that from that infinite came this infinite which I see as infinite.

Jagat, this Prakriti which I say is also complete and infinite, that from which it came, this supreme Brahman is also infinite, that is infinite. This is also infinite. The world I'm identifying with is also infinite. Even though it seems finite. Even though I see myself as a finite being in the world of the being which I see is finite, it's not Finite, it's infinite. And if you take this infinite out of that infinite, what remains is still infinite.

In other words, there is no separation between the world which I perceive and the real self. There is no separation between my limited self and that supreme self. But the ignorance is creating this dual vision and I need to remove that. So the first step is when you act in this world, see this unity and don't expect any results from your actions which will relieve you from anxiety of the fruits of actions. And then chapter four said, there is not really two separate entities. Both came from the same singular entity and therefore act for the betterment of the entire Jagat.

The Jagat that you consider your own world, your own world, maybe your own family, maybe your own community, maybe your own nation. Work for that without expectations that your actions will bear particular results that will free you from this anxiety. And now in this chapter we are learning how to renounce this sense of agency that I am the doer. So Bhagavan started this chapter saying, you can reach that same goal by renouncing actions and also by performing actions. By renouncing actions in the knowledge that I am not the doer will take you to that place where you can identify with your supreme self. But performing actions in this world without any expectations will also lead you to that state by purifying your internal instrument which is right now is conditioned by this limitedness that you have taken upon yourself as your own.

Bhagavan said, both are one and the same. Yatsangkhi prapyate sthanam tadyogi apigema. That place which is reached by contemplation on that very fact that we learnt in chapter two that I am not this mortal being, I am that immortal being. If I contemplate on that statement and come to the conclusion that that's the truth where I change my identification from this limited self to the higher self. See, that's the path of Sankhya contemplating on that great statement that Tattvamasi, you are that. But if that's not in my capability right now, Bhagavan said, tat yoge API gammade.

By performing this Karma Yoga, you can also achieve that same state, the same result. And therefore you should start with Karma Yoga. Because contemplation without preparing your mind for the contemplation is pretty painful. In other words, it will not bear any good result. And then you will be frustrated. And then you will say, I don't think this has any value.

So rather than engaging yourself in Something you're not capable of, engage yourself in purifying your mind and intellect. The yogi who has achieved the state of purification, he knows that naiva kinchit karomi ITI yuktaham manyate tattvavit. One who knows the essence of the self, that that which feels like my limited self is nothing but the supreme self. It is my own ignorance that I'm identifying with the limitations and therefore I feel limited. One who has recognized that truth by establishing himself in yoga or by contemplation, he knows that naivakinchitkarami I am not doing anything. Everything is performed by indriyani indriyarthesu vartanta ITI dharayan.

He clearly sees that activity which I perceive sometimes it is performed by me is nothing. But senses are reacting or associating with sense objects. And we can clearly see through our normal observations that my sense of taste will indulge me into eating more sweets that will show up on my body. So this sense object and senses reacting with each other. Or I may consider myself to be a very wise person and have control over my intellect and control over my mind, but just the substance from this world called alcohol. If I indulge in it, all my wisdom and my sanity will go away and I will act like an average idiot.

So we know that these sense objects have clear effect on my behavior, a clear effect on how I think. And therefore I have to come to the conclusion that indriyaani indriya teshu vartnantah, the senses are indulging in activity with the sense objects. So all the activities, all that which is good and how that is bad is nothing but purely the interaction between the senses and sense objects. And we have seen sabdas parsa rupa rasa gandha, the five sense objects, and kshutra thvaka chakshuhu rasana grana, the five senses we have, you remove one, then the world of that sense will go away. If you remove all five, the world of objects which I perceive will go away. So therefore Bhagavan says, brahmani adhaya karmani sangam tukta karauthiyah.

So now that I am not at that level of that yogi who clearly sees the naiva kinsit karomi, I am not doing anything. He does not have this confusion that I have. That means I think I am doing this. I have done this and not done this yet he does not have that confusion. He is like that ocean which sees its own waves and sees I as the ocean is not involved in all the activities of the waves. Waves are the water reacting with the wind is creating these waves on my surface.

But at the bottom of the ocean I am standstill. They say Brahmani Adhaya Karmani Sangam Tyaktva Karutiyah. The Sangam tiktva comes as Sid pointed out last time, in next this verse in next and then Karma Falam tektvakaramde third verse. This tactva word is constantly coming in our discussion. So anytime we see the word tyaktva it clearly means we are already attached. It's a give up, abandon.

I can only do that if I have something which I have to give up. So this clearly says that Sangam Tyaktva I am already attached. It's given that I'm attached to this world. I'm attached to this body, I'm attached to this mind, I'm attached to my intellect. No matter how hard I try, I keep identifying with who I am. As this limited being.

The idea that I am the doer does not go away very easily. Therefore, Bhagavan said, there is a method to get rid of that. Your mind has a tendency to attach and if you don't give it an alternate, you will never be able to give up your attachment. So the alternate Brahmani Yadhaya Karmani, you offer all your action to that supreme. That supreme which is complete. There is no place for you to be there as an individual.

If that supreme is all pervading, all complete. If I'm all pervading in my chair, there's no place for somebody else to be here. If that supreme is all pervading, there is no place for me as a little ego to be there. And therefore offer all your action to that supreme. Brahmani Yadhaya Karmani Sangam Tyaktva first you have to detach yourself from this attachment. I'm now in that party.

So by attaching yourself to Brahman, you offer all actions to him. Right now I'm bound by all my actions. I get success and I get elated. I get failure and I get dejected. When I get dejected and disappointed, it creates negative impression in my mind that the sin I'm incurring. So now the exercise for you, Bhagavan said, is because you are not at that level of a yogi, you offer all your action, continue working, but think that you are not working for yourself, you are working for him.

Whatever the results come, that will be his loss or profit, not yours. This analogy comes in our scriptures all the time. Just as lotus leaf is in the water, but does not get moistened by the water, it comes out of water, goes back into the water, decays in water, but during its lifetime it never gets moistened by the water. The same way you came in this world, you live in this world. You will die in this world. But while living, you don't get attached to the world by attaching yourself to Brahman.

So here is the technique Bhagavan has given for giving up the sense of agency for those of us who are still at a level of where we think that we are the doers. Kayana, Manasa, Buddhaya, Kaivalay, Indriyahiyapi, Yogi nahakarma, Karvanti, Sangam tyaktva atma sudaye. Again the word sangam tyaktva by giving up attachment, because right now I am attached. That fact has to be acknowledged first. And then we can say what is my next step. It is like that Alcohol Anonymous.

First step is to admit that I'm an alcoholic. See, the first step is to admit that I am attached to this world and to my body, my mind and my intellect and my senses. Therefore, now I should say that I am not the one who is instigating all these activities. The activities are done by my body because the very nature of the body to function Manasa by my mind, because the very nature of mind to go out and get attached Buddha, my intellect, the very nature of my intellect to think what is right, what is wrong, what I have experienced, what I have not experienced, and my senses. The very nature of the senses is to go out and get impressions from the world outside. Those impressions now reported to mind creates impressions on mind.

That impressions on mind creates perceptions in my intellect. And then I become the doer of the activity. But once I detach myself from all of this, Kaya, Mana, Buddhi and Indriya, they are independent of me. They are acting according to their own own nature. But I, the consciousness, the self is not involved in it. Yogi Naha, Karma, Kurvanti, Sangam tyaktwa atma sudaye.

So here clearly Bhagavan gives us the goal. The goal is the purification of the internal instrument Atma.
snippets.reflection:
Practice what the Gita calls 'renunciation in action.' Choose one activity today and do it without any sense of 'I am doing this' or 'this will benefit me.' Just let the action happen through you.

Notice the quality of mind that emerges when personal stake is released. This is true sannyasa—not running away from the world, but engaging fully while remaining free.

The person established in this wisdom sees the same Self in all beings. Today, practice looking at others—friends, strangers, even those who irritate you—and remembering that the same consciousness that looks out through your eyes looks out through theirs.

snippets.title: Day 74: True Renunciation
snippets.sanskrit:
सर्वकर्माणि मनसा संन्यस्यास्ते सुखं वशी |

न कर्तृत्वं न कर्माणि लोकस्य सृजति प्रभुः |

नादत्ते कस्यचित्पापं न चैव सुकृतं विभुः |
snippets.transliteration:
sarvakarmāṇi manasā saṃnyasyāste sukhaṃ vaśī .

na kartṛtvaṃ na karmāṇi lokasya sṛjati prabhuḥ .

nādatte kasyacitpāpaṃ na caiva sukṛtaṃ vibhuḥ .
verseTranslations: Mentally renouncing all actions, the self-controlled soul enjoys bliss in this body, the city of the nine gates, neither doing anything himself nor causing anything to be done.
The Lord of this universe has not ordained activity, or any incentive thereto, or any relation between an act and its consequences. All this is the work of Nature.
The Lord does not accept responsibility for any man's sin or merit. Men are deluded because in them wisdom is submerged in ignorance.
snippets.commentary:
So now we know that in my life accents are necessary, but they're also my assets. My accents are my assets. Well, Neil, how did you accomplish what you accomplished? All that I have done went to architecture school, then worked for all these years for very little pay. My actions are my assets, but my actions are also liability. So my actions are both the assets and liabilities.

And what we try to do is leverage the assets and renounce the liabilities. When you file bankruptcy, what are you trying to do? You're renouncing your liabilities, but at the same token, you have to renounce your assets as well. You know, very good recent example, hdl, very well respected, fastest growing company, thousands of employees and millions of dollars of investment. They filed for bankruptcy. Not only their bad deeds they have renounced and their debt, but the assets also they have to renounce just got sold for like 32 million or $37 million.

There are probably hundreds of million dollars worth of investment. Bhagawan said that when you file a bankruptcy on your liabilities, you have to also renounce your assets. So if I give up this sense of agency for both my good actions and bad actions, then I'm free. You have no assets, no liability. So Bhagawan said that one who takes the doership has to suffer through merits or the sins of his actions. So the yogi, while working, he realized that he can't give up the agency, but he gives up the fruits of actions.

Whatever will come out, I'll accept. Because I'm not the Ch faladatta, I'm the actor. I have the capacity to act empowered by the Lord as my consciousness. But I have no control over what comes out from the world. The world is the Ch falada. When I practice architecture, all the efforts I put, I can give myself a project.

Somebody else have to give me a project. So Ch Faladatta is somebody other than myself. Now in our Puranic sense, we think that Ch faladatta is Bhagavan Bhagavan is keeping score of what good deeds you have done. What bad deeds you have done. Therefore when we go to the temple, what do we ask for? Bhagavan Maf karna Bhagavan Bhagavan hoge.

We don't say that you remember what good deeds I have done that I'm in control. Don't Worry about you Mr. Bhagavan. Just Bhagavan maf karna Bhagavan Bhagavan hoge ham saa. So whenever we are in trouble we ask Bhagavan to forgive us for all of our bad actions. When it comes to I'm a self made man. Came to this country with $8 in my pocket.

When I left India, the only thing I can take with me was $8. That was the total foreign exchange India government allowed for the people who leave India. So most of us came with $8 in our pocket. Your problems Bhagavan, you take care of it. Bhagavan said, look, neither I can take care of your problem nor can I give you credit for what you have done. Because all these actions which you are performing is in the realm of Prakriti.

Not in the realm of the self. Bhagavan is functioning in the realm of self. So the worst which we will be seeing today says Nakartrutvam nakarmani lo kassya srajati prabhuhu. This is completely in contrast to what we have believed all along. The Bhagavan is the controller of all that I do. See, every time I make mistake, I just tell you what can I do?

Bhagavan has made me like that. Bhagavan put me in this situation. And that's a good comforting thought. That look, I'm not doing anything wrong. Bhagawan is putting me in this situation. And also we have this Puranic idea that Chitragupta is writing this book.

When you die he will just open up your account and say look, what good deeds you did. What bad deeds you did. Well, looks like your balance is pretty good. Well, it looks like your account on the negative side so it will go to hell. So we thought that somebody is taking care of all these things. So we always have this comfort zone that Bhagavan is actively participating in my life and he is guiding me or he is maneuvering me to what I am doing.

But now this Verse says Bhagavan says, I'm not doing anything. Nakartrutvam Nakarmani not the doership or the actions are created in this world by Prabhu. One who is a Prabha is a Prabhu. The Lord, one on which my life depends, is my Lord. The Lord is the one who sustains my livelihood. So my Lord is the one on whom my life depends.

So he's the Lord of my being, my consciousness. As long as I'm alive, I am who I am. As soon as the consciousness leaves me, I'm no longer who I am. That dead body you won't call Neelbhat. You will get rid of him as quickly as you can. Because I am who I am because of the consciousness in me.

So here Bhagavan says Nakaratrutvam Nakarmani in this world is created by the Lord of your being, my consciousness. The self which I call myself, you call yourself, he call himself, she call herself is not forcing you to do anything. It's not creating any actions for you. It's also not creating any sense of agency for you. It's not taking any part in anything which you're doing. Then where does this idea of me doing things come from?

It comes from your identification with the conditioning of yourself. Navadvare puree dehi naiva kinship Karomiyeti. It is the embodied one in this nine gated city. He says, I am not doing anything. But the one who identifies with this nine gated city is the doer. And that identifier is my ego that says this is me.

The ego is the doer because he is the identifier with the conditioning. So Bhagavan said, the self, I, the Lord of your being is not forcing you to do anything nor am I creating any actions for you. He's also not the one who is actively sitting down with his supercomputer and saying Neil did this. He's completely out of this business. He simply says, let the nature takes care of it. Everything that is happening to me is happening because the way I acted according to my nature, nature of my body, nature of my mind, nature of my intellect and then nature of the world on what object I have acted at my level of physical abilities.

If I punch a guy who is 6ft 5 inches tall and about 300 pound, what do you think the reaction would be according to his Prakriti According to my Prakriti Swabha was too pravarted. So Bhagavan said, in this world actions are also performed by the very nature of the beings. Very nature of my body, mind and intellect. And the Karma Phala coming to me is also dependent on the nature of the world. I always say I may be the best architect on this planet. But if there is no work outside no matter how much efforts I put, will there be any resource?

Because the world is completely devoid of that need. But if I practice my effort into the field where there is a need which is compatible with my ability then I will get the results out of it. So what is happening? The Karma and Karma Phala are not dependent on. Bhagavan thought I'm a good guy or a bad guy. Well, give Neel some projects.

He takes Gita class on Sundays. My clients don't care whether I take Gita class or Bible class. They only care whether I can design their buildings effectively. So Kvabhavastha Parvata. Everything in this world is guided by the laws of nature. Bhagwan says I as the Prabhu is not involved at all.

So please don't count on me. He is a big shocker for all of us. We always thought that no matter what bad I did as long as I go to the temple the coconuts I can offer take care of it. So Bhagwan said, now I do not take part in any of that. Na Adity Kasya Chit Papam. I do not take sins from anybody.

No matter what bad I do. Bhagavan says it does not affect me at all. Nachayeva Sukritam Vibhuhu. And also I don't accept any good deeds. AAP Khilee Karaha Bhagwansha, you don't do anything for me. I don't accept anything.

I don't accept any of your good deeds or bad deeds. That self which is all pervading is not affected by any good deeds or bad deeds in this universe. Myself, my consciousness which I considered my Prabhu. Because I cannot sustain myself without him. The same self is also Vibhu. So right now I'm burdened by my sins.

In a sense I'm burdened by what things I have done wrong in my life. I wish I had done this. I wish I had done this. I wish I had not put money in the market before it crashed. I wish I had bought Apple stock when it came out 25 years ago or whatever. But one said, but it's not affecting me.

The self in me is not tainted by my. My sins, my bad deeds or my good merits. So all the good deeds and bad deeds happening in this world, we constantly ask this question. Why Bhagavan Ko ki Pathani Chaltahe? What is this ISIS doing? And Tsunami and all these terrorists and all the things happening.

Is he sleeping at the wheel? He said, no, I really have nothing to do with it. Everything is happening as per the nature of the Prakriti. Once I have created the Prakriti. Prakriti is governed by its own laws. We know the laws Sattva Rajasantamas.

These laws and a permutation of combinations create this world of plurality. The world of plurality interact with itself according to their own gunas and creates their own results. But I stay out of it. Once you created laws of the game, referee only judges the player based on the rules of the games. Not what he thinks is a nice guy or a bad person. You have to play by the rules of the games.

Once I sit in my car and turn my ignition, the car does not know whether a nice person has turned the ignition or bad person. It will go by as the laws of thermodynamics works in the engine. So Bhagawan says, I do not really accept any good deeds or bad deeds. Then why we are not seeing this thing? Why we are not seeing that all these things happening is very natural and it is exactly happening as it should happen. The world is perfect as Dan used to say all the time.

The world as is is the way it should be. But I constantly think this world is not appropriate. I don't know why everything is so messed up. You know, it's a chaos. But once I know it's not a chaos, it's the cosmos, it's not a chaos. Things are exactly happening in your life as it should happen.

Because what you did so far, things will exactly happen in your future as you build your future. But then I am completely confused about these laws of the game. I'm actually participating in a game without knowing the rules of the game. Basically that's the problem. If I start playing football without knowing what the rules are, well, I'm going to be crushed. That's exactly what is happening with me right now.

So Bhagawan says, why that is happening? Agnane Abrutam Gnanam this knowledge about the self is covered by the ignorance.

snippets.title: Day 75: Action and Knowledge
snippets.sanskrit:
ज्ञानेन तु तदज्ञानं येषां नाशितमात्मनः |

तद्बुद्धयस्तदात्मानस्तन्निष्ठास्तत्परायणाः |

विद्याविनयसम्पन्ने ब्राह्मणे गवि हस्तिनि |
snippets.transliteration:
jñānena tu tadajñānaṃ yeṣāṃ nāśitamātmanaḥ .

tadbuddhayastadātmānastanniṣṭhāstatparāyaṇāḥ .

vidyāvinayasampanne brāhmaṇe gavi hastini .
verseTranslations: Surely wisdom is like the sun, revealing the supreme truth to those whose ignorance is dispelled by the wisdom of the Self.
Meditating on the Divine, having faith in the Divine, concentrating on the Divine and losing themselves in the Divine, their sins dissolved in wisdom, they go whence there is no return.
Sages look equally upon all, whether he be a minister of learning and humility, or an infidel, or whether it be a cow, an elephant or a dog.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter five, Karma Sannyas Yoga and so far we have seen that Bhagawan said that Karma Yoga is clearly better for you because sannyasa may be more difficult to pursue for one who has not developed a quality that Northwest Tina Kanksha, who does not hate or does not even desire such a person. Sannyasa is not really easy to practice. Therefore, Karma Yoga, the Yoga Yogi Yukta Bhava become Yoga Yukta. Yoga Yukta Bhava is to develop art of performing actions which is for the greater good, not for myself and the technique given to us in this chapter he says while you are performing all your actions, constantly think that you are not doing anything. Pralapan vishrujan, srunan svashan. Even when you are breathing, seeing, hearing, touching, thinks you are not doing that someone other than what you think you are is doing it.

So that's a technique given to us that constantly while I'm acting in this world, I should see that something else is what is that something else which is doing it? Well, we can clearly identify everything we do is either my body is doing it, my mind is doing it, or my intellect is doing it. The observer who is observing this activity is someone other than body, mind and intellect. So constantly see you as the witness of your own activity. Just as when we witness other people doing and saying I know he's doing well, he's not doing well, I think he's wrong or he's right, but we are not involved in it. So we are constantly judging other people from our vantage point, our perspective.

If we start developing a practice where we can do the same thing for us, we will clearly be seeing what is right and wrong for us. When we do something wrong. If we step also out of that activity and see it, we'll see whether that was right or wrong and the next time we can correct it. So the technique is given to us. Constantly watch yourself as a third party observer in all the activities you do and then the last few verses which he had been discussing where Bhagavan come out and says that Nakkar truth lokas Prabhu, Prabhu. The Lord is not creating any sense of doership.

The ego which I have right now saying this is me and I am the doer. I am the enjoyer and I am the sufferer. Bhagawan said, I really have nothing to do with it. So please don't blame me. I did not create this ego for you. It is the very part of the Prakriti that these activities are going on.

Your body, mind and intellect are nothing but part of the Prakriti. You identifying it created this ego. But I am not the creator of your ego. You now have the responsibility to get rid of the ego yourself. Nakartruttam na karmanis Lokas. The Lord who is the Lord of my being is not responsible or not the creator of this ego.

That which I have, that this is me, that's not me. Nobody else could have done it without me. This cannot function. Bhagawan said, I'm not putting in your head. I'm not creating this sense of agency nor I am creating any actions. In other words, the Lord of my being is beyond the world of activity.

And we know this world of activity. At the Prakriti level. Activity is taking place at the level of Prakriti. This world of plurality. The world where I exist and you exist and the world exists. For any activity to take place, you need two things.

When I act an object of activity, then only activity takes place. If there is no duality, no activity takes place. That's why when you are alone, you are getting bored. By myself, what can I do? I need somebody to play with. That's why solitude is so difficult for us to practice.

We want life where everything is going on. The so Bhagawan said, but in reality there is no duality when it comes down to the core of your being. Yourself and myself and his self and herself. So at his level, no activity is ever taking place in his self. Therefore he says that I am beyond this activity. So he said, I am not creating and also I am not creating.

We constantly blame Bhagavan for the thing which is not going right for us. I know I put all the efforts and got it. When things go right, I don't know. Bhagwan is not looking after me these days. He said I am completely away from your activity. I am not in a business of marrying your actions with the fruits of actions.

I'm not taking stock about what Papa I had done or Punya I had done. It's entirely up to you and the world you're working in to figure out the transactions and what is the results of the transactions. Because I created this Prakriti out of my own self by my Maya. In the chapter before we have seen clearly says that I am working in this world out of my own Maya. Ajahapisan Avya Yatma Bhutana Iswaropisan Prakrutim Swam Adhishthaya Sambhavami Atma Mayaya by my own Maya. By presiding over this Prakriti, I work in this world.

So once I created the Prakriti out of my own Maya from the Bhagavan's perspective, my work is done. I created the field of activity, the rules of the activity, the laws of nature. And we had been saying many, many times in this discussion that the laws of nature are without any exception. They apply to all of us in the Prakriti equally. It does not see that because I have done this many punyas that my papa gets wiped out. It's not a canceling each other type of activity.

You do one good, you're forgiven one bad. You pay for your bad and you get reward for your good. That's the rules of the game. So one, I am a part of the Prakriti. I'm going through my life within the laws of the Prakriti. Now as long as I am abiding by the rules of the Prakriti then I'll be evolving in the Prakriti.

The whole game is the Bhagavant Leela, Krishna Leela as we call it is that it starts out as being the ignorant self of who I am. That's the original sin. When I forgot who I am is the original sin. Avidy from that Avidy through my own efforts, evolutionary effort. So when I was just in one cell amoeba, I evolved at the lap of Mother Nature. Then I became human being.

And now I have to evolve with my own efforts. With this evolution, I have to get out of this identification with this body, mind and intellect to identify with the self where the game started when the Avidya started. And I have to get out of the Avidya and become Vidya again. While I'm at the Prakriti level, I still have a responsibility and activity to Perform. So in chapter three, we are given the rules of the game. If you really want to evolve in this Prakriti act for the greater good.

All your activities must be for the greater good. For the Yajna spirit, not for you as this self, as you consider self, which is this body, mind and intellect, but for the greater good. By acting in this greater good, I will rise above this selfish ego and will purify my mind and intellect. Now we are giving self will. And therefore at times we will be acting part of Dharma. And the part against Dharma in this chapter says, I am not taking any part into your activity.

It's done as per the rules of the games. When I put the key in the ignition of my car, there is no discrimination for BMW to decide whether I'm a nice guy or a bad guy, whether I'm the owner of the car or the thief who is stealing this BMW. It would work exactly as the laws of thermodynamics and electricity are in this nature. It will start the car as long as I have the right key. So you see, if he's not taking part, then who is maintaining the laws in this nature? If there are laws in this nature, there got to be law giver and law enforcer.

Without law enforcer, no law is of any value. Because the law enforcing there is a law enforcement, the laws are abided. In this country or anywhere else in this world, we see the laws are very precisely followed in nature. So there got to be law enforcer. And if he says I'm not taking part, who is law enforcing? Bhagawan says, that's also me.

As part of my lower nature as a Prakriti, I control the laws of Prakriti. And therefore anytime in a society when majority of the people are not following these laws, I have to take charge again and set those rules visible again for everybody, clarify the situation and make those laws again visible to people to follow. snippets.commentary:
