Then chapter one we have encountered the situation which we encounter in our daily life.

A common man facing day to day situation which never comes clean cut as black and white, good or bad, happy or unhappy. It always have complexity which makes me confused about what is right and wrong, which action to be taken. So we have seen Arjuna's situation. He cannot see whether there is good in fighting the battle or running away from the battle. Fighting the battle is going to create some collateral damage as we have seen recently in Afghanistan. Some people who I really respect and revere may also get hurt or killed.

And that happens in our life all the time. So first chapter describe our situation as we face in life today. The second chapter told us that what we think who we are is not who we are. So there is a paradigm shift for us. We consider this self to be this limited me, this body, mind and intellect. And at the end of my journey in this life, this self will be destroyed.

The self that I consider myself will never be destroyed. The death will be only for the body. So that's a paradigm shift for us. So now understanding that it still does not give me what to do next. So the third chapter gave us the instruction about how to work in this world in an efficient manner. The two things it told us.

One thing it says Swadharma Nidhanam, Shreya, Paradharma Vayabah. Act according to your own nature, your own Prakrisi, because that's where your welfare is. Your good is in acting according to your nature, Paradharma, Bhayavah, others Dharma may seem very noble, very excellent, but you can follow that because that's not your Dharma. Act according to your Dharma and act for the greater good. Not just in a selfish manner, just for your own good, but act that can help the greater community in that. We called it Karma Yoga.

The art of acting in this world which will help me purify my mind and intellect, is called Karma Yoga. Then chapter four says, once you learned how to act outside in this world, now you have to renounce these actions which you considered yours. Even while I'm acting in a Karma Yoga, I still think I'm practicing Karma Yoga. So there is still agency involved and say, I am doing it. So the fourth chapter says, you have to now renounce these actions in knowledge. Knowledge which you already learned in chapter two.

That is self, which I consider self is not the self. That which I consider self is actually the equipment belong to the self, body, mind and intellect. So now in the chapter four it says, learn that this knowledge about the self and renounce these actions, that these actions belong to the Prakriti, this body, mind and intellect, they do not belong to me, the self. That's chapter four, Chapter five. We started seeing Karma Sannyasa. Now how to really gain this sannyas which we talked about in chapter four.

So we have this detailed instruction about how to think, how to adjust our attitude towards actions. And the first thing it said is, think that you are not doing anything. And then it says, Brahmani Yadhaya, Karmani, Sangam, Tyaktva Karutiyah. The person who devote all his actions to the Brahman, that universal self, not just myself as the limited self, but I am doing it for that greater self. Then he does not incur any sin. He does not incur any negative impression on his mind.

Our problem is we take our actions so personally that somebody says, neel, you are not doing well. We get hurt right away. Right away it tells me that this person is not respecting me and it starts putting the negative impression. So the next time when I have to do that, I'll be thinking twice, should I be doing it? Will people appreciate it or will it not be appreciated? So that negative impression will not be on the mind of a person who is not doing it with this limited ego.

Because to him, action is an action, the result is a result. So he has no impression on his mind. So such a person will act in this world like a Padmapatra, the lotus leaf which remaining in the water coming out of the mud does not ever get tainted by any of that. Water falls on it, it rolls off. So that's the technique given to us in this chapter. In such a person who is constantly thinking about his self as the greater self will be liberated from these limitations.

And then we have seen that is such a yogi. Once he get to that level then how will he be behaving in this world? Bahiasparcesu Asaktatma he is unattached to the context outside. Sabhrahma Yoga Yoga Yuktamatma Sukham Akshayam Asnute we are constantly seeking this happiness which is unlimited. We are not seeking happiness which is limited. We think we are happy if we get some limited happiness.

Green card, Green card, Green card. Once I have it I won't ask for anything more. But I know the next thing I'll ask is now I got the green card. Maybe I need to find the right person to get married. So take a vacation for three weeks from your job maximum go to India. And I said, Neel, I can't do it in three weeks because my parents aligned up all the girls.

But I think I still need some more time. Can I get two more weeks of vacation? And then it continues. We are seeking unlimited happiness. And Bhagavan said there's only one formula that works. Sua Saktatma is unattached to the context outside in this world.

Sabhrama Yogi Yuktarna Such a person is Yogi. He is one with the Brahman, one who is connected with the Brahman. And all of this seems very difficult to practice. So next verse says, but remember that it may give you happiness. What is there if I am going to avoid all these pleasures in my life? What is the fun of living life?

When I was teenager we used to have this joke. He said when you go up to the Chitragupta he will ask Bdpaka PI because we are smoking. So we have to justify if you didn't do that, what did you do? Go back, experience all that and then come back. So we think if I don't experience any pleasure in this world, what is there to to live this life for? They say, well you can experience all these pleasures.

Remember Yehi sans Parsija Bhoga Dukha Yoane this pleasures coming out of context with the objects in the world outside has limited capacity to give you pain. There is a womb of unhappiness. So unless you are careful, you will know that these pleasures are Adi and Antavanta. It starts at one point of time and will end. So you don't get Ramatha Inasa, don't get engaged into it. You experience the pleasure and move on.

It's not that it's a nice day, I'm saying no, I mean this is not good. I mean how can you have a nice day? How can I enjoy nice day? Gita tells me it's all Adiyanta Vanta. But when there's a nice day, enjoy it. But next day when there's not nice, don't complain.

That's all it says not Ramadan that you are not going to have riots in the city of Richmond. Because why we don't have nice days. Why is he not controlling their climate? We know this is the reality of life. The next three verses tells us why one should be detached from this context outside and how. Saknutihi yeva yaha sodham prak sareeda vimokshanaat Kama krod udbhavam vegam sa yuktaha sa sukhi nara.

The happy person definition is here. We are very happy, elated. I read on Facebook somewhere that may your life be as happy as it seems on Facebook. Because we know that that's not the reality, right? We are not putting all the garbage from our life on the Facebook. So Sukhi who is truly sukhi, not who appears to be happy.

We all appear to be happy. From other point of view. Neel, you're doing very well. Only Neel knows how he is doing, right? Bhagavan said Saknoti, hi Evaha yaha sodum praksharevamuksanath. Before this body disintegrates, who can withhold the vega the power of Tamakru, the udbhavam that force which is generated in in my mind by Kama the desire and Krodha the anger.

It did not say you will not have Kama or Krodha. Vega is the operative word here. When it is flowing peacefully in a serene manner, it is the most enjoyable thing, right? People enjoy the river. Some of our friends have houses right on the river. And we all go in envy and say James river.

When Wakin was predicted, he was preparing for so James river, when it is flowing peacefully there is no problem. It gives peace and happiness to anybody. Our mind is like the river. When it is flowing in a peace and a serene manner, it takes you towards your happiness. When do we think about some inspired projects or inspired actions? When we feel happy, when we are calm and happy then we say let's do this.

When I am upset, no matter how good an idea put in front of me, forget about it. So the mind has to be serene and flowing in a in an appropriate manner towards its goal. Then only the peace and happiness can come. But this uninvited guest Vakin comes. The wake will be manifold uncontrollable and then anything comes in its way it will destroy. Bhagwan said that Kama and a Krodha when that desire is so powerful that you are rushing towards that objects of desire and whatever comes in your way you want to destroy.

That's anger that Vega should be withheld. A person who can withhold the force of Kamayana Krodha in his mind Yukta. He is the one who is connected with his own self. Because he will be then happy in all situation. Because he has control over the flow of his thoughts. Mind as we have learned in Tattva Bodhi is nothing but the flow of thoughts.

One thought does not make a mind. Second thought creates the genesis of mind. Then more and more thoughts, second thought give rise to the third thought and the fourth thought and fifth thought in the same direction. Now thoughts flowing in one direction create in my mind. As long as the mind is flowing toward the right destination in a disciplined manner, it creates happiness. When my desires are all over the place I want to be a billionaire and then I also want to become a wise person.

And then I also want to be a sports personality. And then I'm torn all over and then I'm creating disaster. A person who creates before this capacity, before this body disintegrates. Because after that you don't really have any chance. This is your chance to create discipline in your mind. Such a person is Sukhi Naraha Yo Antaha yo.

You know all this expression in the slang language Yo yo yo yo.

Then chapter four says, once you learned how to act outside in this world, now you have to renounce these actions which you considered yours. Even while I'm acting in a Karma Yoga, I still think I'm practicing Karma Yoga. So there is still agency involved and say, I am doing it. So the fourth chapter says, you have to now renounce these actions in knowledge. Knowledge which you already learned in chapter two.

That is self, which I consider self is not the self. That which I consider self is actually the equipment belong to the self, body, mind and intellect. So now in the chapter four it says, learn that this knowledge about the self and renounce these actions, that these actions belong to the Prakriti, this body, mind and intellect, they do not belong to me, the self. That's chapter four, Chapter five. We started seeing Karma Sannyasa. Now how to really gain this sannyas which we talked about in chapter four.

So we have this detailed instruction about how to think, how to adjust our attitude towards actions. And the first thing it said is, think that you are not doing anything. And then it says, Brahmani Yadhaya, Karmani, Sangam, Tyaktva Karutiyah. The person who devote all his actions to the Brahman, that universal self, not just myself as the limited self, but I am doing it for that greater self. Then he does not incur any sin. He does not incur any negative impression on his mind.

Our problem is we take our actions so personally that somebody says, neel, you are not doing well. We get hurt right away. Right away it tells me that this person is not respecting me and it starts putting the negative impression. So the next time when I have to do that, I'll be thinking twice, should I be doing it? Will people appreciate it or will it not be appreciated? So that negative impression will not be on the mind of a person who is not doing it with this limited ego.

Because to him, action is an action, the result is a result. So he has no impression on his mind. So such a person will act in this world like a Padmapatra, the lotus leaf which remaining in the water coming out of the mud does not ever get tainted by any of that. Water falls on it, it rolls off. So that's the technique given to us in this chapter. In such a person who is constantly thinking about his self as the greater self will be liberated from these limitations.

And then we have seen that is such a yogi. Once he get to that level then how will he be behaving in this world? Bahiasparcesu Asaktatma he is unattached to the context outside. Sabhrahma Yoga Yoga Yuktamatma Sukham Akshayam Asnute we are constantly seeking this happiness which is unlimited. We are not seeking happiness which is limited. We think we are happy if we get some limited happiness.

Green card, Green card, Green card. Once I have it I won't ask for anything more. But I know the next thing I'll ask is now I got the green card. Maybe I need to find the right person to get married. So take a vacation for three weeks from your job maximum go to India. And I said, Neel, I can't do it in three weeks because my parents aligned up all the girls.

But I think I still need some more time. Can I get two more weeks of vacation? And then it continues. We are seeking unlimited happiness. And Bhagavan said there's only one formula that works. Sua Saktatma is unattached to the context outside in this world.

Sabhrama Yogi Yuktarna Such a person is Yogi. He is one with the Brahman, one who is connected with the Brahman. And all of this seems very difficult to practice. So next verse says, but remember that it may give you happiness. What is there if I am going to avoid all these pleasures in my life? What is the fun of living life?

When I was teenager we used to have this joke. He said when you go up to the Chitragupta he will ask Bdpaka PI because we are smoking. So we have to justify if you didn't do that, what did you do? Go back, experience all that and then come back. So we think if I don't experience any pleasure in this world, what is there to to live this life for? They say, well you can experience all these pleasures.

Remember Yehi sans Parsija Bhoga Dukha Yoane this pleasures coming out of context with the objects in the world outside has limited capacity to give you pain. There is a womb of unhappiness. So unless you are careful, you will know that these pleasures are Adi and Antavanta. It starts at one point of time and will end. So you don't get Ramatha Inasa, don't get engaged into it. You experience the pleasure and move on.

It's not that it's a nice day, I'm saying no, I mean this is not good. I mean how can you have a nice day? How can I enjoy nice day? Gita tells me it's all Adiyanta Vanta. But when there's a nice day, enjoy it. But next day when there's not nice, don't complain.

That's all it says not Ramadan that you are not going to have riots in the city of Richmond. Because why we don't have nice days. Why is he not controlling their climate? We know this is the reality of life. The next three verses tells us why one should be detached from this context outside and how. Saknutihi yeva yaha sodham prak sareeda vimokshanaat Kama krod udbhavam vegam sa yuktaha sa sukhi nara.

The happy person definition is here. We are very happy, elated. I read on Facebook somewhere that may your life be as happy as it seems on Facebook. Because we know that that's not the reality, right? We are not putting all the garbage from our life on the Facebook. So Sukhi who is truly sukhi, not who appears to be happy.

We all appear to be happy. From other point of view. Neel, you're doing very well. Only Neel knows how he is doing, right? Bhagavan said Saknoti, hi Evaha yaha sodum praksharevamuksanath. Before this body disintegrates, who can withhold the vega the power of Tamakru, the udbhavam that force which is generated in in my mind by Kama the desire and Krodha the anger.

It did not say you will not have Kama or Krodha. Vega is the operative word here. When it is flowing peacefully in a serene manner, it is the most enjoyable thing, right? People enjoy the river. Some of our friends have houses right on the river. And we all go in envy and say James river.

When Wakin was predicted, he was preparing for so James river, when it is flowing peacefully there is no problem. It gives peace and happiness to anybody. Our mind is like the river. When it is flowing in a peace and a serene manner, it takes you towards your happiness. When do we think about some inspired projects or inspired actions? When we feel happy, when we are calm and happy then we say let's do this.

When I am upset, no matter how good an idea put in front of me, forget about it. So the mind has to be serene and flowing in a in an appropriate manner towards its goal. Then only the peace and happiness can come. But this uninvited guest Vakin comes. The wake will be manifold uncontrollable and then anything comes in its way it will destroy. Bhagwan said that Kama and a Krodha when that desire is so powerful that you are rushing towards that objects of desire and whatever comes in your way you want to destroy.

That's anger that Vega should be withheld. A person who can withhold the force of Kamayana Krodha in his mind Yukta. He is the one who is connected with his own self. Because he will be then happy in all situation. Because he has control over the flow of his thoughts. Mind as we have learned in Tattva Bodhi is nothing but the flow of thoughts.

One thought does not make a mind. Second thought creates the genesis of mind. Then more and more thoughts, second thought give rise to the third thought and the fourth thought and fifth thought in the same direction. Now thoughts flowing in one direction create in my mind. As long as the mind is flowing toward the right destination in a disciplined manner, it creates happiness. When my desires are all over the place I want to be a billionaire and then I also want to become a wise person.

And then I also want to be a sports personality. And then I'm torn all over and then I'm creating disaster. A person who creates before this capacity, before this body disintegrates. Because after that you don't really have any chance. This is your chance to create discipline in your mind. Such a person is Sukhi Naraha Yo Antaha yo.

You know all this expression in the slang language Yo yo yo yo.
snippets.reflection:
Practice what the Gita calls 'renunciation in action.' Choose one activity today and do it without any sense of 'I am doing this' or 'this will benefit me.' Just let the action happen through you.

Notice the quality of mind that emerges when personal stake is released. This is true sannyasa—not running away from the world, but engaging fully while remaining free.

The person established in this wisdom sees the same Self in all beings. Today, practice looking at others—friends, strangers, even those who irritate you—and remembering that the same consciousness that looks out through your eyes looks out through theirs.

snippets.title: Day 79: Action and Knowledge
snippets.sanskrit:
यतेन्द्रियमनोबुद्धिर्मुनिर्मोक्षपरायणः |

भोक्तारं यज्ञतपसां सर्वलोकमहेश्वरम् |
snippets.transliteration:
yatendriyamanobuddhirmunirmokṣaparāyaṇaḥ .

bhoktāraṃ yajñatapasāṃ sarvalokamaheśvaram .
verseTranslations: Governing sense, mind and intellect, intent on liberation, free from desire, fear and anger, the sage is forever free.
Knowing me as Him who gladly receives all offerings of austerity and sacrifice, as the Might Ruler of all the Worlds and the Friend of all beings, he passes to Eternal Peace."
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 5, Gnana Karma Sannyasa Yoga Yoga of True Renunciation of Actions. We are coming to the concluding part of chapter five, the last three verses. And we have seen previously that Bhagawan said that the one who develops qualities which are appropriate to merge with Brahman, he merges with Brahman. Yah Anta Sukhaha Antahramah Tatha Antah Jyotihi Evayaha, Sahayogi Brahmanirvanam, Brahma Bhutodi Gachade. These are the qualifications one must develop. If he wants to attain that eternal liberation, wants to merge with the supreme Self.

If he wants to achieve the final goal of attaining complete liberation, then he needs to understand this finite being is not capable of attaining that. He has to leave attachment to this finite being, this body, mind and intellect which is running outside and seeking happiness outside. That idea has to be renounced, that happiness lies outside in the world. And he has to develop qualities where he becomes satisfied within his own selves. Yha Antaha Sukhaha who finds his happiness within himself. Ya Antahramaha who revels in his own self, Antha Jyoti.

He reveals his own existence. I do not need anyone to convince me that I exist. Other verification is required for everything else. I need verification whether I'm smart, whether I'm powerful, whether I achieved anything, am I an architect or not? I need a verification. But whether I exist, I need no verification.

I know that the self emerging knowledge by oneself, one who is relying on that, one who identifies with that Sahayogi Brahmanirvanam, he loses his self. He loses his identity in that greater identity. As we have seen in our analogy, when a small company merges a big company, the small company's name goes away and it becomes one with the larger company. Lavante Brahman Nirvanam, Rusayakshina Kalmashaha. But to achieve that, you have to become Kshina Kalma without any impurities of mind. Bhagwan those disease who have purified themselves of all sins, they achieve this Brahmanirvanam.

They dissolve themselves into this Brahmana. And we have seen this sin is nothing but the agitations in my mind. As long as I want something out of this world, it's a desire. And as long as I don't have it, I'm incomplete. That creates agitation. If I acquire it, I want to preserve it.

That creates another agitation. I accomplished all that. I have this bank balance in my 401k. It seems I'm set for my retirement of what happens if the market collapses and I lose everything. So there's always fear of preserving what I have and also an anxiety about what I have not accomplished. One who is without this agitation in his mind, whose mind is purified, he attains that ultimate truth.

He becomes one with that supreme self. Chinna Dwai dah He does not see the duality. Up till now I have lived my life as an island. The world is outside which is competing with me and I have to get my happiness out of it. So I'm constantly in battle with this world outside as an individual. If that individuality is dissolved and if I expand my identification as we have seen before, right now my ego is concentrated in my limited self which I call myself.

If I can expand my ego to include others, my identification. So at a small level we all do that. We identify with our family, we identify with our friends. We identify with our community, our nation. Therefore, when Brazil was not doing well in coronavirus, we were not that upset. But now India is not doing well.

We are all very disturbed. Because identification. I have expanded my identification from not just me but the country where I was born and raised and also the country which I live in, Chennadvaidah. They have expanded their identification to include everything. Yat Atmanah has a control over this limited self. Once I identify with the world, then my recreation becomes to seek the welfare of all beings.

So these are the qualifications we have seen of the person who wants to achieve the liberation. Mumukshu who is desirous of moksha, the liberation. One who is happy the way he is, he does not need anything to do with this. But one who is not happy with the condition he is in and he wants that liberation for him. These are the qualifications he has to achieve. He has to strive for.

And then the next three verses, the last three verses, they're actually introductory verses for the next chapter. Swamiji explains that in Sanskrit Literature it is very common that the author will introduce a subject at the end of a chapter so that you are ready for the next chapter. It's like in Gujarati magazines. The story gets very interesting and then it ends and says more interesting part will be in the next edition. So Bhagawani is also using the similar technique. He's introducing meditation in these last three verses.

And these verses are more like sutras in very succinct way. The entire process of meditation and the goal is described. It says Sparsan krutva bahihi bahiyar chakshuhucha evantare bruvoho prana panav samukrutva nasya bhyantara charino. Here is the entire technique of meditation is given. The first is Sparsan krutva bahi bahyan. Keep all the sense objects outside, outside of your perception.

So don't let the senses bring the information from outside of the sense objects which then creates these impressions on your mind. You shut off that mechanism of bringing all those impressions from the outside. This is something like if you have an old style camera which has a Kodak film in it. If you open the shutter, whatever is inside the image will come inside to the lens. And then the film is like your mind. So the film will capture the impression on it.

So there are two ways you can avoid taking any picture. One is you don't open the lens at all. I have done it before. Forgot to remove the cap. I kept clicking but nothing on the film because the lens was covered. Kathopani said you should fold your senses into the mind.

The senses are not turned inward, they are not looking outwards. Then there is no experience from outside. Or keep the experience outside, outside only. Not let it influence your mind. And focus your gaze at the juncture of your eyebrows. It says that now that you have turned your gaze inside, you have to focus on your mind.

So now mind is focused laserized. We have good explanation about the scientific or medical implication of focusing between the eyes. But from a yogic perspective we are focused on Agna chakra. In our bodies we have six chakras. In some tradition there's seventh chakra which is the Sahasrara chakra which is also called Brahmarandra. That's your exit point when you die if you are a yogi.

Bhagavan says here that focus on your Ajna chakra. The Agna chakra is also called third eye. In our literature we have Shiva had third eye, the eye of wisdom. So this third eye or Ajna chakra is supposed to be associated with the subtle body, the mind and intellect. So rather than focusing on the world outside, now you focus on the world inside, on your mind and intellect and turn them towards this chakra which is a connection between you and the supreme. So Bhagawan said, Chakshucha Eva Antare bruvaha.

Focus your attention between the two eyebrows with Agna chakra. It's also corresponding to the pineal gland in your physiology. And therefore we also have a bindi in our culture at that point. And also the yogis, they put Chandan tika to keep that Agna chakra protected Prana Panav Samokrutva. We also Learnt in chapter three, I think it was verse 29 which says they offer the prana into Apana or Apana into Prana. One of the Yajnas is this prana upon Yajna which is basically Purak or Kumbak Pranayam.

There was a great technique developed by all over Rishis. They noticed that my mind affects my breathing. And so if I use that knowledge of my observation that there is a connection between my mind and my breathing, I can control breathing to control my mind, so I can regulate breathing to control my mind. And this whole elaborate science of pranayama was developed. So here it says prana and apana making them equal. There is no imbalance between the two which in turn will control my mind, will make my mind balance Prana Pana Samokratva.

I have read Ganeshwar Maharaj Ganeshwari and it says, combine the power of Prana and apana together and direct it towards your spirit Sahasrara Chakra. So this energy which is right now used for maintaining this body, equalize it. So the body is maintained with a very minimal energy. The rest of the energy is focused towards your Sahastrara chakra where you have a connection with your great self. The energy which we receive from that great self is through that chakra according to the yogic tradition. So Bhagawan says, balance your Prana and Apana NASA Bhyantara Charina which are happening in your nostrils.

Yat Indriyaha Manaha Buddhi Munihi Moksha Parayanaha. If you are desirous of liberation, if a goal is to achieve liberation, then you have to make this preparation throughout your life. It is not something that you get up one morning and start meditating. Bhagawan Buddha did not get up early that morning under a Bodhi tree and said, I need to Meditate and achieve enlightenment. He had to work all his life to achieve that enlightenment. This is the practice that has controlled my organs, my senses, my mana, my mind and my buddhis.

This cannot happen as we know overnight. It also is not going to happen just because you decided to do so. It's a constant practice without any gap in it. Eknathi Swaran used to say that if you miss a day in meditation, it takes a week to make up. And if you miss a week of meditation, it takes a month to make it up. If you miss a month, it takes a year to make it up.

So it's a constant practice to control your organs, control your mind, control intellect. Now we are all doing it. So it's not something which is not in our control. We control over organs in a sense. We don't behave in an inappropriate manner in the public. We also control our mind.

Sometimes we feel like doing something, but we realize it's not the right thing to do. So we control our mind. We control intellect too. Sometimes we get fancy ideas, but then we think, no, that's not the right thing. We do have capabilities. Except our goal is different in using that capability.

We're trying to achieve something from this world. Here it says Moksha parayanaha. Those who are mumukshu, those who are desirous of liberation, they use this capability to control mind, intellect and body in achieving that liberation. Vigatha Ichabaya krodaha this is only possible if you're without any desire, fear and anger. We know that our life is basically nothing but a permutation combination of these three. Either we are desirous of getting something we are fearful of of something may not get it, or I'm angry.

That's because my mind is right now turned outside seeking happiness. If I realize that the happiness does not lie outside the world of objects has no capability to give me happiness. As we have seen, every object which gives me happiness has equal capability to give me unhappiness. If that's true, they actually cancels each other out. It is like the particles which have a negative and positive charge. They cancel each other out and they disappear.

These objects are illusory. They do not have the essential thing which I am seeking happinessah.

snippets.title: Day 80: The Practice of Yoga
snippets.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |

यं संन्यासमिति प्राहुर्योगं तं विद्धि पाण्डव |

आरुरुक्षोर्मुनेर्योगं कर्म कारणमुच्यते |
snippets.transliteration:
śrībhagavānuvāca .

yaṃ saṃnyāsamiti prāhuryogaṃ taṃ viddhi pāṇḍava .

ārurukṣormuneryogaṃ karma kāraṇamucyate .
verseTranslations: "Lord Shri Krishna said: He who acts because it is his duty, not thinking of the consequences, is really spiritual and a true ascetic; and not he who merely observes rituals or who shuns all action.
O Arjuna! Renunciation is in fact what is called Right Action. No one can become spiritual who has not renounced all desire.
For the sage who seeks the heights of spiritual meditation, practice is the only method, and when he has attained them, he must maintain himself there by continual self-control.
snippets.commentary:
We have completed chapter five. Now we'll be discussing chapter six. Swami Chinmayanda says meditation is not a verb, it's a noun. It is a state to be achieved and not something you do. Something you do is actually called contemplation. So what we have seen in Bhagavad Gita so far is the conclusion of the first set of chapters and we are coming to this culminating chapter, Dhyana Yoga, which will indicate the state which we have to achieve.

So we have discussed many times that Bhagavad Gita is divided into three distinct sections of each having six chapters. According to Anandagiri, who was a 13th century head of Dwarka Mutt, he said Bhagavad Gita is exposition on the Mahavakya Tattvamasi. The Mahavakya is a statement which connects the lower to the higher, the river to the Paramatma. Tattvamasi is a Mahavakyan Chandogya Upanishad. And according to Anandagiri who wrote Tikas on Bhagavan Sankara's Arya's Bhasyas. So Bhagavan Ved Vyas wrote Bhagavad Gita.

Then Bhagavan Sankaracharya wrote Bhasya on Bhagavad Gita and then Anandagiri wrote Tika on Bhagavan Sankracher as Bhashya. There he says this Bhagavad Gita is exposition on Tattvamasi that thou art. There are other opinions about what Bhagavad Gita is and how it is divided. Madhusuddhan Saraswati, he was 16th, late 16th, early 17th century Advaitic scholar. He said that Bhagavad Gita is divided into three parts, starting with Karma Yoga in the first six chapters, Bhakti Yoga in seven through 12 chapters, and Gnana Yoga in 13th to 18th chapter. Swamiji also points out here that there are others who believe that first six chapters relates to the Karmakanda in Vedas.

Next set of six chapters relates to Upasanakanda in Vedas. In last six chapters relates to Gnanakanda in Vedas. However, Bhagawan Sankaracharya does not make any distinction in his Basya. He simply says the spiritual evolution described in Bhagavad Gita follows. First you act in this world with hankering for the fruits. So you are working in the world with with expectations.

So in the first Saxon Bhagavan Hatova prapsisi swargam ji tova Bhaksi sevahim. What do you have to lose in performing any action? You shall achieve either the heaven for the heroes if you die, and if you don't die, you will achieve the kingdom on this earth. When you're expecting a result, that's your motivation. The second stage will be to act without any hankering for the fruits of action which we have seen as Karma Yoga. And then the third stage in the spiritual evolution is the integration of the mind with Upasana.

In the last state, he says, is the realization acquiring the knowledge. So so far what we have seen is in chapter one we have seen the confusion of an ordinary man of this world which we are all. We want to act in this world and get the right results. But we do not know what accents are right. So that's our confusion. Arjun Visa Yuga explained that through the Arjuna's condition, Chapter two give us the philosophical perfection of Upanishads.

The highest knowledge in Upanishads was given out right away as the goal. Not that Bhagavan Krishna expected Arjuna to understand, but he gave out that knowledge of perfection, that this self is immutable, imperishable. And at the end of the chapter we also saw the characteristics of a man of perfection, a wise person. How would he act in this world? If you achieve the state of perfect wisdom, then you will have a balanced mind to achieve that. Then chapter three gave us the path of Karma Yoga, the method of self integration of our mind and intellect.

That's the second stage. First you act with the desire for the fruits. Then you act without desire or expectation for the fruit. So that's chapter three. And chapter four actually gives the various means, Bahiranga, Sadhana, the external aids, how to perform Karma Yoga. So we have seen many Yajnas in chapter four.

Then chapter five gave us a technique. Even while working in this world without any expectations, there will be some impact on your mind to avoid that. Chapter five gives you the path of Renunciation that you give up the sense of agency for your actions while performing actions selflessly. Also you must renounce your sense of doership. So that's what we saw in chapter five. Renouncing the sense of agency is the Sannyasa Yoga, Yoga of renunciation.

And now all that knowledge, if you have been practicing diligently, then Bhagavan said, you are ready for Dhyana Yoga, Yoga of Meditation. Swamiji says it's a yoga of contemplation. Meditation is a state to reach. Contemplation is way to achieve that. So that is Dhyana Yoga. So you have to prepare yourself with Karma Yoga to get to Dhyana Yoga.

So chapter literally opens with that statement. Anasritah Karma Falam karyam Karma Karotiyah. One who is performing actions without depending on the fruits of actions, Sahasanyasi cha Yogi, Cha na nir agnihi nacha Akriaha. One who is performing actions without any dependence on the fruits of actions. Such a person is a sannyasi and a yogi. So Bhagawan is now basically relating both the yoga which can be viewed as a Karma Yoga, and sannyas as one and the same.

The ultimate result is one and the same as long as you perform Karma Yoga without any expectation for the fruits. This is basically clarification. Because we carry baggage of our culture. We see sannyasi as somebody who has given up all activities, one who is completely inactive from a society's perspective. He does not have a job, he does not have a family, he has no relationship, he has given up everything. Sannyasi is the one who renounced everything.

All means of making living, all possessions, all relationships, including possession of his body. When somebody takes sannyas, he actually performs the last rites. So the one who has decided to take sannyas, he then wears, you know, saffron robe. He's not doing anything. And Bhagavan said, outwardly that person may have taken sannyas, but if he has not given up these fruits of actions, then he's not a Sannyasi Akriaha. He seems inactive, but that does not mean he is a sannyasi Niragniha, one who does not have fire.

So this fire comes from our Vedic culture where every householder will have a fire in his house. Because fire is necessary for your day to day cooking, but also for the religious rites. All the religious practices or upasanas were done through fire, yagnas, homas. So they used to continually keep fire in the house because they didn't have this instant matches or lighters. So they'll keep a fire burning in the house so that when they need fire, they can use that to light bigger fire. So person who is a householder will always have fire in his house.

And sannyasi gives up that responsibility of carrying fire. He doesn't need to cook anymore. Or he also is not performing any religious rites. He's not performing any kind of traditional pujas. Bhagavan clarifies this. A person has given up the grvastha shram.

But if he is not at a mental level, then he is not a sannyasi. If he has not renounced his sense of agency and fruits of actions, then he is not a sannyasi. It's a clarification that the sannyasa is a state of mind, is a state of renouncing sense of agency. The one who is a yogi is also sannyasi, Sanyasi also yogi. In the next verse, Bhagawan says, yam Sanyasam ITI prahuhu yogam tam vidhi pandava O Pandav. That which is said to be sannyasa.

Sannyasa is renouncing the sense of agency. Prahu yogam tam vidyapandava. So that is Dhyana yoga. That with the sannyasa is also yoga. Because without becoming Yogi, one cannot become sanyasi nahi sanyasta, Sankalpah Yogi, Bhavati kastanah. Because without renouncing Sankalpa, Sankalpa, Swamiji says, is difficult word to translate in English.

But expectations, nahisa nyasta Sankalpaha. One who has not given up expectations, Yogi Bhavati kastanaha, he cannot become yogi. So one who has not given up a fancy of one's mind. That Swamiji elaborates what Sankalpa is. It is confusing for us because in our culture, in our vernacular languages, in our religious practices, you always do Sankalpa before you start any puja. Panditji will say, do Sankalpa.

So Sankalpa also means termination, taking a vow. When I decide that this action, I'm doing it for this reason, that's a sankalpa. I'm going to be regular in my exercise every day. I'll go for a walk every day as we do on a. I guess a New Year's Eve, a resolution. Because you have a goal in mind, you have a result in mind. But Bhagavan says that this Sankalpa should be given up if you want to become a yogi.

Because Sankalpa result in future which is exactly contrary to Karma Yoga. Karma Yoga is not to expect any results. Sankalpa is to expect a result in future and then work towards it that there is nothing wrong in it. But human mind is such that Sankalpa does not remain constant. And we all know that every resolution we make on New Year's Eve by the time that month is over, we have forgotten about it and we have some other Sankalpa. So the nature of our mind is to make a Sankalpa for the future.

But the action can always be performed in present. And before we start that action in present, we move on to the next Sankalpa. We want to do something else. So we never reach a goal. Because the goal is constantly a moving target that the fancy of our mind. So to stop that one has to give up Sankalpa.

One has to learn how to give up this fancy of a mind. And I heard that you have to learn how to give up Sankalpa to get Sankalpa Siddhi. In a sense you're determined to get something. You work towards it and get it. So you make a Sankalpa. Something which is unattainable.

I want to achieve liberation Moksha unattainable right now. But if you make that Sankalpa then first you have to learn how to give up the other fancy of your mind to give up other Sankalpa and then just work toward the one Sankalpa. Then you can reach that. So learn how to give up Sankalpa so you can achieve Sankalpa Siddhi. So Bhagavan here says is that no one can become Yogi who has not given up Sankalpa. So he is already a renouncer.

He has given up Sankalpa. He is a Sanyasi and therefore he is Yogi. So Yogi and Sanyasi are one and the same. Then it gives us who should practice what, who is capable of inactivity and who should perform actions. We have already seen that inactivity is not an option for Usta. It's not possible for any living being to be inactive.

But inactivity is the goal. Then we want Niskarma Siddhi. We want to retire from our day to day life is the goal. So he says Aru Ruksoho munehe Yogam Karma Karanam Uchate Karma is the means for a seeker, A Muni who wants to ascend to yoga, who wants to become yogi. But he is not a yogi yet. For such a person, such a seeker who is not yogi means the one who has the control over his mind is a yogi.

One who wants to control his mind. But mind is not in control yet. For Karma is prescribed. Remember we have started chapter called Dhyana Yoga. So we expected that Bhagawan just talking about Dhyana, how to meditate, what to do. We are done with Karma Yoga.

Now let's focus on Dhyana Yoga. But Bhagavan really puts Karma Yoga at the highest level here and say unless you have practiced Karma Yoga and achieved the results of the Karma Yoga which is the control of the mind, purification of the mind, the next step is not really for you.

Try even five minutes of stillness today. Don't worry about doing it correctly. Simply sit, close your eyes, and notice what's happening in your field of awareness.

verseTranslations: When a man renounces even the thought of initiating action, when he is not interested in sense objects or any results which may flow from his acts, then in truth he understands spirituality.
Let him seek liberation by the help of his Highest Self, and let him never disgrace his own Self. For that Self is his only friend; yet it may also be his enemy.
To him who has conquered his lower nature by Its help, the Self is a friend, but to him who has not done so, It is an enemy.
snippets.commentary:
What is my purpose and destiny? We have been discussing Chapter 6, Dhyana Yoga, Yoga of Contemplation and Meditation. In the first five chapters, we have seen that Bhagavan defined the word Yoga. In chapter two, Bhagavan defined the word Yoga, Samatvam Yoga, Uchade Yoga is the balance of mind. And then he said, yoga ha Karma Sukha Vishalam Yoga is dexterity in action. So that basically was given as a goal.

That yoga is to balance your mind. Your mind should be balanced in all situation and that's your goal. Then the next three chapters, 3, 4 and 5 basically gives two techniques to achieve that yoga of balancing the mind. The one he said Karma Yoga do not depend on the Karma Phala. By giving up the expectations for the results is one technique which we call Karma Yoga. The other technique given was they're giving up the sense of agency which was called sannyasa.

So in these two techniques we have seen that they have two different modes. One is promoting actions, but without any expectation of the fruits. Other one is promoting inaction. Giving up the sense of agency is giving up actions. I am not doing anything. So for an average person it may seem contradictory.

The one is promoting actions, other is promoting inaction. Also culturally we have seen that Karma Yogi is engaged in actions where sannyasi has given up all actions. He gives up his job, he gives up his family. So even in olden days, a grahasti was required to perform certain rituals daily that he has to perform at the grahasti. Therefore, as we have seen, he keeps fire in his house, burning all the time because he needs the fire for performing the rituals. But once he becomes a sanyasi, if he takes sanyasi, he is not required to do any of the actions.

So in the narrow sense, the Karma Kanda says that grahastha is required to perform actions which are ritualistic actions and sannyasi is not required to perform those actions. We have seen these two opposite sides of the same coin, but very contrary to each other. So that can Create confusion in in our mind that tyagi or yogi is better or the sannyasi is better. And therefore the chapter opened with a clear declaration from Bhagavan. Anastirithah Karma, Falam Karyam, Karma, Karotiyah Samyasi Sacha Yogi. So Bhagavan once again extols Karma Yoga as the very means of achieving this balance of mind.

That one who performs actions without depending on the fruits of action is Yogi and a sannyasi, both because a sannyasa cannot be achieved or yoga cannot be achieved by renouncing actions. And therefore both achieve the same goal of samatwam, the balance of mind which we are looking for. Therefore, Ibwansidha sannyasam, idhi prahuhu Yogamtam, vidhi pandavah. Know that sannyasa is the same thing, what they call Yoga. One who has not given up the Sankalpa, he cannot become Yogi. But depending on progress in your evolutionary process of reaching lower to the higher, you can choose one or the other.

So in the third verse we have seen Aru ruksho mune Yogam Karma karanamuchate. If you're still not there, you're not establish yourself in Yoga. Then Karma is the means. If I can't balance my mind, I know that I can lose the balance of my mind. When the situation occurs which is not conducive, I think I keep my mind balanced. When things are going well, I act very rationally.

It's only when things are not going right that I become irrational. The irrationality, Bhagavan says, should shows that you have no control over your mind. Situation affecting you and you blaming the situation. But the root cause is that you have no control over your mind. So the mind is taking away the peace in your inner self. And therefore Bhagawan says, then keep doing actions without expectations.

That's your exercise. Continue working on that Yoga Rudrasya dasheva samahakaranamuchade. But one who has balanced his mind, one who has achieved a state of yoga for him, Shamah, inactivity, quiescence of mind. The mind has no desire, no thoughts of achieving something. He doesn't become thoughtless. But he does not have really any goal of achieving something which he does not have because it feels complete.

All our plans for achieving things are because we feel incomplete. Without my car, I'm incomplete. So things which makes me incomplete, I try to achieve from outside the world. When you Feel incomplete and you have to get something out of this world. That's a power of Sankalpa. In your mind you create a situation.

You really create a scenario that if I have this then I will feel complete. If I come here on any kind of student visa or H1 visa only if I can get green card then everything will be solved. Once I get green card, things will be perfectly fine. That becomes a Sankalpa overarching desire who is considered to be Yogaruda. One who has balanced his mind that he has now control over his mind. Here is the litmus test that if I do not get attached to sense objects, that does not mean that I do not use sense objects.

But I use them for utility. I feel thirsty and I drink water. I feel hungry and I eat food. But I don't get attached to them. And I have to have this amras every day. That's an attachment.

Enjoying mango juice is not a problem. Getting attached to the taste is a problem. So Bhagawan said one day doesn't attach to the sense objects. He use these sense objects for whatever the utility they provide for maintaining my life but not getting attached to them. If they are not there tomorrow, I will still be the same person. This part is even more difficult.

We can probably get detached from sense objects, but my own actions. Therefore we have discussed many, many times before. Retiring is not that easy. Something which I get used to doing all my life. I know it very well because I'm not retired yet. It's very difficult to give up actions which you are performing and getting used to them.

Those actions define myself. The first thing comes out of your mouth, I'm an architect because that defines who you are. That's your profession. Oh, I'm a son of such and such. Well, that's your relationship. We continue this inquiry of defining ourselves and we miserably fail in the end.

Because everything we define ourselves is some kind of a relationship, some kind of a acquisition, some kind of position, but not really who you are. That Bhagavan says is attachment to your actions. You call yourself an architect because you're attached to your profession. You call yourself a father because you're attached to your relationship with your. Those attachments are to my actions, not to the sense objects. I'm not attached to my son.

I'm not attached to my actions, my profession. That's attachment action. See both Somebody has given up. That does not mean he does not have a relationship or he doesn't work. But he considered that as part of this world where I have to function. Sarvasankalpa Sanyasi.

So these words come time and again. And therefore we obviously have to understand them as thoroughly as we can. So Sankalpa, the word comes in our culture all the time. As we discussed last time. When you go to do puja, Panditji will ask you to make Sankalpa that this puja, I'm doing it for such and such. The Sankalpa is Samyak Kalpana.

And the word samyak literally means overarching, which encompass everything. That is Samyak kalpana. When there is an overarching desire in my mind that I want to get this, that's Sankalpa. Firm determination that my happiness lies there and I must get it. So therefore Panditji says, when you are doing a puja, you have to Sankalpa Samyak Kalpana that by doing this puja I shall get this. Our mind does that Sankalpa all the time.

The only problem is it continues to change. Sankalpa Bhagawan said, this mind has this capacity to jump from one Sankalpa to another Sankalpa. And that creates variety of desire. In Mahabharata there's a statement which says, kamaha janame te mulam. I know your roots, that your roots are Sankalpa. I know that you are born out of Sankalpa, the desire which is defining me.

So Upanishad also says, the self is nothing but the identification with desire which I consider to be me. In Mahabharata it says, O desire. You are born after Sankalpa. And therefore I will never think about it. So you will be destroyed with your own roots. If I don't have Sankalpa, I don't think I am a Sankalpa.

Then there won't be any desire. And I can kill the desire. Sarva Sankalpa sanyasi. Therefore, the word Sarva Sankalpa is constantly changing. We constantly change our overarching desire. Today this is what I want to achieve, and then tomorrow it changes.

Unless we curb that urge to create new Sankalpa, I cannot become a Sanyasi. So he said, serve a Sankalpa Sannyasi, one who has given up all Sankalpas. Yoga Rudhata Duchate. That person is considered established in Yoga. If I feel complete, I will not Have a desire to achieve anything overarchingly. I will have needs and I'll fulfill my needs.

I need water because I'm thirsty. I need food because I'm hungry. I need job because I need to make a living. Those are normal things we do. But when there is Sankalpa is this is what I need to get so that I feel happy. Bhagwan says that Sankalpa and one who gives up that sense of Sankalpa he becomes Yogarudhata Duche.

If you find yourself in that situation that now you have no desire to achieve anything. Bhagawan said you are Yoga Ruda at that point. Samahakarana Uchati for such a person, inactivity. And in fact from the scriptural point of view the time comes when you have to stop your activity. So Swamiji says here it is a sin not to act when you are required to act. But it is also equally dangerous if you continue acting when you're not required to act.

And therefore we used to have those ashrams, Brahmacharyashram, Grahasthashram, Vanapastha, Asram Sanyata Ashram. You have to reach a point in your life where inactivity is your goal. And then start working not for the self but on the self. So start working on your own self. Udharat Atmana Tmanam Na tmanam avasadayat. It seems like there are two me.

One is watching me and one is working me. That watching me is constantly deciding what needs to be done. So what we call our own conscience that we feel this is right. But then my my pragmatic thought says no, that may not be very useful. So let's go and do that. This watching me is the my higher self.

Or consider that which has a clear vision of what is right and what is wrong that is constantly watching me. Therefore I think I should have a cup of tea. There are two I one who thinks, one who wants cup of tea. So this watching me is the one who can guide you. And Bhagavan said Udharit Atmana tmanam. Let your lower self, lower self.

The working me to be raised out of this Sansar, this Jagat which is constantly changing. Raise that lower set working me by the help of their watching me. Then my own conscience can help me get out of the sorrows of day to day life. If I become friend with that, if I listen to that voice. Na tmanam avasadayat. Don't let this working me drown in this World of sorrows and day to day rut atmevahi atmano banduhu that watching me can be my friend if I allow him to be my friend.

jñānavijñānatṛptātmā kūṭastho vijitendriyaḥ .

suhṛnmitrāryudāsīnamadhyasthadveṣyabandhuṣu .
verseTranslations: The Self of him who is self-controlled, and has attained peace is equally unmoved by heat or cold, pleasure or pain, honour or dishonour.
He who desires nothing but wisdom and spiritual insight, who has conquered his senses and who looks with the same eye upon a lump of earth, a stone or fine gold, is a real saint.
He looks impartially on all - lover, friend or foe; indifferent or hostile; alien or relative; virtuous or sinful.
snippets.commentary:
Unlike a car with its user's manual, we are born without instructions how to live. We experience life vicissitudes without a so called user's manual. The Gita has been described as such a guide. Okay, so last time we have seen that the advice from Bhagavad Gita is Raise yourself by the self, Don't let the self fall. Raise yourself by the self. We all really know in life that the only one who can really help oneself is one's own self.

Only my own efforts will raise me out of the situation I'm in. But the connotation here is that raise your lower self by the higher self, the self in me, which remains constant all throughout all these changes of birth and death, as we have seen in last chapter two, that is imperishable, immutable, untaintable. Let that self raise your lower self which is suffering right now by its own limitations. I can't stand limitations because my true nature is limitless, limitless. So now the only thing I can do is let my higher self raise my lower self to the same level the higher self is. So say, raise yourself by yourself.

Don't let yourself fall. Don't let your lower self go even further down. And that's because it says the higher self is a friend of the lower self. When this lower self is conquered by the higher self, when the lower self starts identifying with the higher self, recognizing its existence, there is something beyond my this day to day life which I live. There is something beyond the life which I consider started at my birth and will end at my death. When I start recognizing this and make that higher self a friend of this lower self, I'll be able to pull the lower self out of its present state of misery.

But it said the same self, higher self, can be the enemy of the lower self. If my ego fails to recognize that there is something beyond my this limited self, then the same higher self will act as if it's enemy because it will let you go down further and further into this misery. By empowering you to do the wrong thing. Higher self will empower you to do whatever you wish you to do. If the ego goes down into the lower and lower plane of existence, it will be empowered by the same higher self. Just as a car out of control is empowered by the same gas which is in the tank which was making it go straight on the road in a controlled fashion.

Same gas will be the power which will create a disastrous wreck. So the advice was clearly, raise yourself by the self. But he said, to do that you have to have certain qualifications. You have to make your efforts to raise your lower self to a worthiness that it can start working with the higher self. It can start identifying with the higher self. So the verses which we discussed 7, 8 and 9 describes the state of Yoga Rudha.

One who has become one master of his self. You know, master of his lower self, Yoga Rudha. We have seen two Arurukshaha and Yoga Rudha. Someone who is desirous to gain that control over his mind, body and intellect. For them the advice was karma karanamuchade. Keep working in this world with selfless motivation and you will achieve that.

But once you reach that state where you have that control over that, then they shamaha karana mucha there at that point, the contemplation and meditation to now get to the higher level. To achieve the goal of that eternal happiness. We want to get out of the limitations. I want to be happy all the time. Bhagawan said, it is absolutely possible only when you identify with the higher, not the lower. You are the manifestation of the higher.

But my identification right now is with the lower. As long as I don't identify with the lower, its limitations cannot affect me. It is like when you go to the science museum or some place where there is funny mirror are there. I stand in front of it and I look like I have bloated 10 times than what I am today. Well, as long as I don't identify that image in the mirror, I am fine. Everybody goes in a funny mirror and laugh at it.

Because they are not identifying with the image they see in the mirror. They clearly identify with the self which is standing in front of the mirror. That's why they can laugh at it. But once one who identifies with that, he cannot laugh. Our situation, Bhagavan says, like we are looking at ourselves in this funny mirror and looking at this miserable self. And now we are in misery.

But one who identifies with the real self which is standing in front of the mirror, the higher self which makes this lower self possible is without any miseries. So the one who has achieved that sense of balance over himself has now become the Yoga Rudha. What will he gain is what we learned. In last three verses it says jitath manah prasantashya paramatma Samahitaha Sita ushna sukha dukeshu tathamana apamana Yoho. Where do our problems lie? In all the trees which we have seen here.

Physical condition is not comfortable. Room is too hot or too cold, you know. So at the body level I can be be uncomfortable displeasure. At a mental level, I feel this is good time going on or I don't have a good time these days things are not working out for me. At a mental level, the Mana apamana Yoho honor and dishonor. Intellectually, I feel that people are now respecting me.

I have achieved something or dishonor, they're not respecting. All these are cause for pleasure and pain in life. But one who has achieved that Yoga Rudha state, in other words, one who has become one with his higher self, has recognized the existence of the higher self in him and start aligning himself with the higher self for him. Prasantasya Paramatma. His self is remains equanimous in all this situation because I am not identifying with it. We wrongly understand that the one who has become this evil, he will not turn on the temporary thermo thermostat adjusted because so what it is uncomfortable.

Well, that's a sheer foolishness. It if I have the facility here to adjust the temperature to my level of comfort, then I should do it. Swami Chinmaynda, people used to ask him all the time, swami, you talk about all this detachment and all that, but when you come, people come and pick you up in Lexus and BMWs and Jaguars. And why don't you go with somebody who has a broken car? Swamiji says, my friend, I'm a swami. That doesn't mean I'm completely stupid.

As long as there is a more reliable and comfortable vehicle available, why should I choose one which is completely unreliable and uncomfortable? That's a common sense. It has nothing to do with attachment or detachment. So we wrongly perceive that the person who has achieved has to suffer. Then only he is considered. It simply says the self in him, the higher self in him is prasantasya is always at equanimity.

It not disturbed by the outside happening. Whatever is happening in the body level, I see that is happening clearly at the body level and let the body deal with it at its own capacity. Whatever is happening at the mental level, I see clearly that's happening at the mental level. Let the mind deal with it at its own capacity and what will happen in the intellectual level, Let it happen at intellectual. Let my intellect deal with it its own capacity. But I, the self, the balance of my core never gets shaken by this happening in this world.

That's why I always say there are no riots when there's 102° outside in Richmond. We didn't have any people throwing stones at Richmond City hall. What's happening here 102° we didn't anticipate, we expected that, we accepted that, that that can happen. Deal with it with the best situation we can create. So we all turned down our thermostat and let the air condition run as best as it can. But we didn't get upset, we didn't have anything to complain to because we knew that it is something beyond my control.

When a yogi becomes one with his higher self he sees all the occurring at the mental level, the physical level and the intellectual level occurring at the lower level of existence. But higher self is not involved and does not get attached to it. It's not affected by any of this thing. So that's his fulfillment. Because of becoming Yogarudha is not now disturbed by this small thing which used to disturb me before. Before it is hot, we are complaining all over the place.

When it is not conducive complain. Now I can take it as is and look at it as a transitory phase of happening in my life, in my existence and don't get disturbed by it. The next was you say gnana vignana triptatma kutasthah vijatendriyaha yukta itiuchate Yogi sama losta ashma kanchanaha. This is the verse I never understood ever when I was growing up and have started learning Bhagavad Gitas since I was about 18 years old. And I say wow, what is my attitude in life if that's the case that I am become sama losta asma kanchanaha. The lump of clay, the iron and the gold, I become equanimous to it.

Well that means I have lost all kind of judgment in life. You know, I don't know what truly want well, it really doesn't say that in your day to day transactions in this world that you do not make any differentiation between the usefulness or a value of one thing or the other. But it does tell me that one who has achieved the sense of understanding, one who has the knowledge, Gnana. Gnana is something which I learn from others, from the books, from the teachers, from my listening, I receive the knowledge. But that knowledge remains at a bookish knowledge till I apply it and make it my own. That becomes vignana.

That was science saved laboratories. You know, you go into the. You learn in the classroom and say H2O is water. Then you go to the lab and make it on your own with two molecules of hydrogen and one oxygen and say the water. Now I'm absolutely convinced. That's now my wisdom.

Vignana visishtagnana. That only comes with self experience. Experimenting what I have learned in my own life, I get wisdom. That's why I didn't understand when I was 18. Now at 62, it is very clear, okay? Because I have gone through the experimentation of it in life.

So it says Gnana Vignana, Truptatma Kutastha. And kutastha whatever. I think it comes from that anvil in the smithy shop. That blacksmith is hammering something on that anvil that both are made up of iron. But the one changes its shape and will remain the same. So Kutastha, he remains unshaken by whatever is happening on that.

Who has the control over his senses. You know, Yuktaiti Uchathe. Such a person is called fulfilled yukta or harmonized or one who has achieved the sense of his self. Satchin Yogi sama losta Ashma Kanchanaha. He sees the lump of clay, the iron and the gold is same. He sees the same as its original value.

What is the value of gold? What is the value of my house? Well, we put this place for lease or sell or whatever. So what is the value? Well, I may want anything I want.

शुचौ देशे प्रतिष्ठाप्य स्थिरमासनमात्मनः |

snippets.transliteration:
