verseTranslations: Let the student of spirituality try unceasingly to concentrate his mind; Let him live in seclusion, absolutely alone, with mind and personality controlled, free from desire and without possessions.
Having chosen a holy place, let him sit in a firm posture on a seat, neither too high nor too low, and covered with a grass mat, a deer skin and a cloth.
Seated thus, his mind concentrated, its functions controlled and his senses governed, let him practise meditation for the purification of his lower nature.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter six, Dhyana Yoga Yoga of Meditation. In first five chapters we learned about ourselves. We learned the terms Yogi and sannyasi. So in this chapter we've learned so far that the one who is acting in this world without depending on the fruits of actions is a yogi and also a sannyasi. Because a sannyasi cannot be a sannyasi unless he has given up all the sense of agency. A Yogi cannot be a yogi until he gives up all the Sankalpas Sarva Sankalpa Sanyasi.

So both reach the same state of becoming equanimous to all the happenings around them. And Bhagavan said, the one who has not yet achieved the state of Yoga, Arudha. So we are seekers, the seeker. The prescription is to selfless actions. Karma Karanam Uchathe. But one, you are established in Yoga then Shamah Karanamuchate then controlling your mind is your pursuit to achieve the higher level.

How do I know that I have become established in yoga? You see, once you get detached from your actions and also the sense objects, when you are completely detached from the world of objects and also world of your activities, in other words, you are functioning but not having that attachment to it. When you achieve that state Sarva Sankalpa Sanyasi there are no aspirations to achieve anything or to accomplish anything. Seems like a pretty dangerous state of mind. But in other words, you know what needs to be done and you will be doing it, but without any anxiety about what will come out of it. So when you teach that state, then your Yoga Rudha.

But how do I get to that point where Bhagavan said, let yourself lift yourself. Let your higher self lift this lower self to that level that they both become aligned with each other. Right now my identification is the lower self, which is we have defined as my body, mind and intellect. This limited being I consider to be me in all my pursuits. To achieve happiness is through this limited being. Limited being limited.

It cannot achieve infinite happiness. But I miss that equation that Something that finite cannot achieve anything that is infinite. I am constantly pursuing infinite happiness, infinite bliss, infinite state where there is no sorrow, using the equipment which are finite. So once you align yourself with that higher self which is infinite, you will be achieve your goal. So let your higher self lift your lower self to a level that is aligned with it. And then the caution was that that higher self can be your enemy or a friend.

Depending on whether I have control over my self, my senses, my mind. If I have no control over mind and senses, higher self enable me to do whatever my lower self wants to do and then it will be a disaster. So now the higher self is acting as an enemy because it's allowing me to do things which are not good for me. So once I have understood that the higher self is there to enable me to achieve higher goals and align with it, it will become my friend. Once I have achieved that state, what will happen? We have learned that then one becomes in a state of equanimity.

His self remains same in a Sita, Ushna, Sukhada, Kamana or Pramana. At the level of physical being, at the level of mental being or intellectual being. My connection with the higher remains the same. In other words, that I do not identify with what's happening with my body, mind and intellect. I continue to identify with my higher self which remains as a witness to what's happening. Therefore it is not getting affected.

When I see that things are happening to the people around me but I am not affected, then I am a witness. I had heard long time ago a definition of a recession and depression. It's when your neighbour gets laid off, it's a recession. So when is it depression? When you get laid off, it's a depression. As long as I'm not affected.

It's a good topic to talk about. So as long as I don't identify with what's happening, it does not affect me. So as long as my self is constantly identifying with the higher self, whatever happening at the physical level, mental level, intellectual level, it does not get affected. Then he will also become one with all the beings in their relationship. Gnana, Vignana, Trupta, Tatna, Kutastha, Vijayat Tendriaha, Yuktai, Dvuchate, Yogi, Samalosta, Asma Kanchanaha. He sees everything in the physical world as the objects are the same.

He knows that there is no inherent value in anything. Value is what I assign the value to. As long as I know this is a million dollar Diamond. There is a value because I can sell it. But if I do not know what their value is, it is no different than a costume jewelry. So values are what I assign to it, the world assigned to it.

But there is no inherent value in anything or being. That's the person with the alignment of the higher self. Then we are saying that even in his relationship, Suhan, mitra, Hari, udasin, madhyas, all different types of people we deal with in our life. Some are friends, some are foes, some are indifferent, some are relatives. But we see them all equally. In other words, they are all manifestation of the same self.

So this is the state described of a yogi. But we are not at this stage. So prescription is, continue doing selfless actions for the purification of your mind and intellect. When the internal instrument becomes pure, you start seeing your connection with the higher, that inner voice which is so feeble right now, you'll hear it loud and clear. How to get there is what the next few _Verses_ tells us, a detailed description of the practices one can practice. Now, last time we had this description about whether this meditation is for the yogis or for anybody.

And I guess there is a question about whether we understand what meditation is. So the meditation is the final state. So if you take Patanjali's Yoga Sutra, there are eight different states before you get to the state of meditation. Start with Yama, Niyama, asana, pranayama, Pratyahar, dharana, and then come. So we have to go through all these different steps to get to a level where we are ready for meditation. But that does not mean that you don't have to start anywhere.

So you have to start at some place, wherever you are in your journey, one step at a time. And then you have to discipline yourself, which is where the yama, which is restrained. Niyama is the practice in anything. What really matters is a constant practice. When I used to work for large companies, these marketing people, before you go for an interview, they say, well, let's have a rehearsal. And some of us will feel, I've been doing it for years, why do I have to practice?

They say, no, no, Neel, do the rehearsal one time and we are done. Practice, practice and practice some more. Then only you will be able to present it flawlessly when you go there. So in anything, practice, practice and practice some more is the key. Most of us will say, I tried that. And when obviously it's not working for me.

But how long have you tried? It's a couple of days. Well, obviously there is no way to judge what you can achieve if you continue to practice. But practicing how is as important. We sometimes say that somebody has 10 years of experience, but it may be a one year experience. He never progressed to the next level very first year.

Whatever he learned, he keeps doing it next 10 years and say, I have 10 years of experience. So you have to learn how to start in the right manner and then make progress. To start from the right manner, we need to learn how to do it. So the next three _Verses_ teach us how to start that journey. Yogi Yunjita, satatatam, atmanam, rahasisthitah, ekaki yata, chittatma, nirasihi parigraha. This is the description about how the yogi should live in one verse.

Now, the yogi who has established himself is yogarudha. He has already gone through the other things we have talked about. He is not attached to the world of objects. He is not attached to his activities. He reached that state. Now he wants to attain that final connection with the self.

So he said, let the yogi try constantly to keep the mind steady. Probably half an hour a day. So what about the next 23 and a half hours is I let my mind go wherever it wants to go. So what would be more prominent on your mind? The one which you've done in 23 and a half hours or the one you did for half an hour? Of course, the 23 and a half hours will be predominant on your mind.

What will be the nature of your mind, what you do for next 23 and a half hours? So the goal here is to open all 24 hours should be the same. Let the yogi try constantly. Keep the mind steady. Remaining in solitude. Remaining in solitude.

Mentally in solitude. You may be in a marketplace, but your goal always remains. How my mind is connected, myself is connected. Swamiji gives a standard example of mother in a child. A mother with an infant child. Child may be in the next room and she is in a kitchen and she is doing whatever she is doing.

But her mind is completely attuned to the child. Even the slightest noise she will recognize. In those days they didn't have those monitors we have here so that you can put a monitor all over the house. But her mind is so tuned to that baby that other people can't hear. Because mind is constantly focused on where the baby is and what it is doing. A yogi becomes like that he may be doing whatever but his mind is constantly aligned towards his self and the conditions given which will allow him to do this.

He never consider himself to be attached to all these people around him. Yata Chitta TMA he is balanced in his Chitta in atma, the self and the thinking entity. Nirashihi without any asa this is where we get lost here and maybe not for us. I have too many things to accomplish. Nirashihi he does not have anything to accomplish outside in the world. He may be accomplishing a lot, but that accomplishment is not going to give him anything more for his connection to his higher self.

So he's constantly focused on his connection. So therefore he has no other desire that getting this out of this world will make me more appropriate to achieve my supreme happiness. Parik Graha Having anything to possess. All my possessions are of no value when it really comes to my understanding of myself. I may be a billionaire, but happiness cannot be bought by billion dollars. What I'm seeking for is infinite happiness.

I have come to the conclusion anything which is finite is not going to give me happiness. Therefore, acquiring things to get happiness. I have come to the conclusion is not a good idea. I may acquire things for other reason. To support my body, my mind, my intellect, my relatives, my friends. For them I'm doing this.

But not for me to get happiness. I'm not buying happiness by acquiring things. That clear idea is in my mind. My possessing thing is not going to give me happiness. I have come to the conclusion that I have tried this before.
snippets.reflection:
Try even five minutes of stillness today. Don't worry about doing it correctly. Simply sit, close your eyes, and notice what's happening in your field of awareness.

When the mind wanders—and it will—gently bring it back. This gentle returning is the practice. Each time you notice wandering and return, you're strengthening the muscle of awareness. The Gita is clear: the mind is restless and difficult to control, but through practice and dispassion, it can be mastered.

Consider: What is your relationship with your own mind? Are you its master, or does it control you? The practice of meditation is the practice of reclaiming sovereignty over your own inner world.

snippets.title: Day 84: The Practice of Yoga
snippets.sanskrit:
समं कायशिरोग्रीवं धारयन्नचलं स्थिरः |

प्रशान्तात्मा विगतभीर्ब्रह्मचारिव्रते स्थितः |

युञ्जन्नेवं सदात्मानं योगी नियतमानसः |
snippets.transliteration:
samaṃ kāyaśirogrīvaṃ dhārayannacalaṃ sthiraḥ .

praśāntātmā vigatabhīrbrahmacārivrate sthitaḥ .

yuñjannevaṃ sadātmānaṃ yogī niyatamānasaḥ .
verseTranslations: Let him hold body, head and neck erect, motionless and steady; let him look fixedly at the tip of his nose, turning neither to the right nor to the left.
With peace in his heart and nor fear, observing the vow of celibacy, with mind controlled and fixed on Me, let the student lose himself in contemplation of Me.
Thus keeping his mind always in communion with Me, and with his thoughts subdued, he shall attain that Peace which is mine and which will lead him to liberation at last.
snippets.commentary:
Unlike a car with its user's manual, we are born without instructions how to live. We experience life vicissitudes without a so called user's manual. The Gita has been described as such a guide. We had been discussing chapter six, Dhyana Yoga Yoga of Meditation. We have so far understood that the Yogi is trying to achieve the state of mind where he is not attached to either the sense objects or his actions, or he does not have any grand plans for the future. To achieve this state of mind, one obviously have to turn one's gaze to the inner self and stop let the mind running out to the outer world.

The nature of the mind is obviously to go after the sense objects because it is receiving the information from the senses, senses, reports to the mind. And mind wants to go out and analyze those experiences in the world of sense objects. For this mind to train to turn inward is the training of meditation. And we have seen that Bhagavan has given a clear instruction of how to start this practice. Obviously anything which we are doing and we want to change it, you have to make it a practice, a habit. I heard somewhere that if you do something seven times, it becomes a habit.

And I have personally experienced that if I get up one day at 6:30 and it seems too early the next day, I try a little harder and still get up at 6:30. And then after a while that becomes my normal routine that I'll get up at 6:30. So the mind gradually gets used to what we do in a routine manner, or we do it repeatedly. My mind is a flow of thoughts. In whatever direction we turn it, that's the direction the mind will start flowing into. Right now the mind has been trained since my birth to go out to the outside world and gather information whether that experience is conducive or not conducive, whether it is a pleasant or unpleasant experience.

And my happiness or unhappiness right now is defined by my experiences which are either conducive or unconducive, pleasant or unpleasant. Dhyana Yoga is the practice to turn this mind away from this outer experiences and experience the inner self. So so far we have seen that the instruction is given that having lived the life of a selfless activity. In other words, I have now changed my priorities in my life. Where whatever I'm doing, I will be thinking about the greater good. Then I will think about not only practicing this art for making money or making my living, but also how good I can make the others lives.

My clients will be using these buildings. Whether have I improved their lives. And that will be my motivation in practicing my art. If I train my mind to think that way for everything I do, my activities start becoming more selfless than selfish. More and more I practice my selfless activities. My mind becomes purer and purer and seeing the world outside.

But I have yet not trained itself to turn inward to see what is the experience of myself. And that's where the meditation come in place. So the instruction we have seen in last few _Verses_ it says such. Establish a place of your own meditation which is steady and firm. Naati uchritam naati nicham that it is not too tall, not too low. And once I've established my place of meditation, I've become comfortable on that asana.

And I sit down with my folded legs or any other position which is most comfortable. The whole goal is to make my body so comfortable that my mind does not run towards discomfort of my body. My mind gets used to sitting at that place and realizing that now is the time to contemplate and meditate. I'm training my mind. I'm programming my mind that once I sit down at this place, it is time to meditate. So the next instruction was, what do I do once I sit down?

I sit down, I close my eyes lightly. And then the instructions say tatra ekagramana kutva. Then focusing the mind at a single point, Yatachatta indriya kriyah. That controlling the senses. I'm not letting my eyes to see, my ears to hear, or my skin to feel any touch. And I will be practicing this for the purpose of atma vishuddaye, for purifying my internal instrument.

I keep this goal in mind at the seat of meditation. That I am doing this for my internal the purification of my internal instrument. Antakarana, my mind and intellect, the operating system of myself, which is my mind and intellect. So the next three _Verses_ gives us further instructions into what would be the most appropriate posture to achieve that. So the verse 13 says, Samam kaya shirogrivam dharayan achalam sthiraha. I sat down, I closed my eyes, but I'm trying to focus my mind and I feel the weight of my body.

It's slouching me down and slumping me down and that distracts me. I have never understood this before. I joined Chinmaya Mission and started hearing and learning about meditation. But I heard Swamiji saying that the most comfortable position will be to sit erect. If you want to sit at the seat of meditation, not only that you have to have a right, right seat, but you have to right posture so that you can sit without any stress and strain or having any discomfort in your body in the posture which is most natural, most natural posture. And I now understand more as an architectural statement that if I have the column straight, it will have less stress because I'm transferring all the load on that column straight to mother Earth.

But if I have a bent column and I'm putting a load on the second floor at the top of that column, that column actually will have more stresses and strain. And I have to design it in a way that it has more reinforcement and all different type of calculations to make sure that the column remains in place. So simple fact in our normal structural knowledge that if I have a straight column, it requires less strength and because it will, less strain of the load coming on top of it or load imposed on it. Now this actually applies to our body too, because our body is nothing but a structure, just like any building structure. So when we are sitting down, our backbone, if it is bent, it will put more stress on it to keep itself in place. The stress and strain will then eventually transfer to my mind and to start thinking about how do I become comfortable under this stress and strain.

So I need to create a posture which is the most natural in nature is to have a straight column. My backbone should be completely straight. So therefore it says Samam kaya shira grivam. Keep the head, neck and the body in a straight line. It's an observation by our rishis that this is the most comfortable position for our self, our body. It will less strain if you work on your posture and all the time make sure that you are sitting straight.

You will realize that the most comfortable position and you can sit in that position for a longer period of time without feeling any stress on your body. And this comes straight from Bhagavad Gita Samam Kaya Shirogrivam Having your body, neck and head in this straight line. Dharayan hold it Achalam. Dharayan, hold it Achalam without moving. Once again, let's go back to my own architectural training. If I have a column which had the wind load applied on it and it is moving in the wind now, I learned that to my surprise when I started working on high rise buildings, that all high rise buildings actually kind of sway in the wind just like a tree moves in the wind.

We typically think the buildings are stable and they don't move. But all buildings move just like a tree would move in a wind. So in a high rise building which are about 50, 60, 70 stories tall or more, they literally move in a wind just like a tree would move. And I even have heard that people get seasickness on the, on the top floors of high rise, those who are very, very sensitive to movement. Because at the top floor, if you are in a hundred story building or 110 story building and you are on a 110th floor, the movement may be in feet. You know, the building moves several feet from one side to another.

And people who are sensitive, most people don't, may not feel it. But some people who are very sensitive start feeling their movement, they develop something similar to seasickness. So in other words, if the column was straight, no other force is applied on it and not moving, it is the, it has the least stresses. But now the building I am anticipating is going to move in the wind on a high rise building. The engineer has to calculate that movement and apply those forces on it so that it's going to remain steady at the wind load applied on it. And he has to add more, reinforcing more strength to this column to remain intact in that condition.

So one more time, our backbone in our body, when it is moving, it requires more stress and strain or experiences more stress and strain and eventually that transfers to our mind. If I want to have my mind completely relieved of any kind of a thinking, I need to relieve it from any stress or strain coming from my body. So Bhagavan says Dharayan Achalam, without moving firmly, hold this posture of having the head, neck and the body in this straight line without moving firmly. That does not mean I will have a stiff posture that I'm trying not to move, but naturally achieve that firmness, but in a most relaxed manner. Now I have the seat sat down on it, I held my body in a firm position, I have a posture corrected, I'm in a straight line My backbone is completely straight. How do I control my mind?

At one point I'll have to give my mind something to think about, something to focus on. The next line says some preksha nasika agram swam gaze at your own nose tip. Somebody will say, but Neil, my eyes are closed, how am I going to gaze at my nose tip? Well, you're not really seeing, you are trying to focusing on it. So with your eyes closed, focus your mind at the tip of your nose. You are not seeing it, you are imagining it.

Focusing your mind at the tip of your nose. Some prakshinasika agram swam di sahacha an Avalokayan without seeing in the other directions. Our mind has a very imaginative nature. So when you close your eyes, the first thing mind does is well, I can't see now but let me imagine what's around me. What if I look on right? What must be happening?

Would I look on the left? What must be happening? What could be behind me and what could be ahead of me? This nature of imagining things, we need to stop my mind to do. Therefore I'm trying to focus my mind at the tip of my nose and not letting it go in all other direction. So the verse 13 has told us how to sit erect, hold the body firm then gaze at the tip of your nose with your eyes lightly closed and not let the mind try to imagine what's on the other side.

In the next verse say this.

snippets.title: Day 85: Meditation
snippets.sanskrit:
नात्यश्नतस्तु योगोऽस्ति न चैकान्तमनश्नतः |

युक्ताहारविहारस्य युक्तचेष्टस्य कर्मसु |

यदा विनियतं चित्तमात्मन्येवावतिष्ठते |
snippets.transliteration:
nātyaśnatastu yogo.asti na caikāntamanaśnataḥ .

yuktāhāravihārasya yuktaceṣṭasya karmasu .

yadā viniyataṃ cittamātmanyevāvatiṣṭhate .
verseTranslations: Meditation is not for him who eats too much, not for him who eats not at all; not for him who is overmuch addicted to sleep, not for him who is always awake.
But for him who regulates his food and recreation, who is balanced in action, in sleep and in waking, it shall dispel all unhappiness.
When the mind, completely controlled, is centered in the Self, and free from all earthly desires, then is the man truly spiritual.
snippets.commentary:
Unlike a car with its user's manual, we are born without instructions how to live. We experience life vicissitudes without a so called user's manual. The Gita has been described as such a guide. We obviously have been discussing the Yoga of Meditation. We went through several chapters with the Karma Yoga, then culminating the Karma into Wisdom and then Sannyasa Yoga. And now we are saying Dhyana Yoga, the Yoga of Meditation.

And we have so far seen that all that we are doing this is for the Atma Sudhaye, for the purification of my internal instrument, that my mind and intellect, which is the internal instrument, that's the only task I have as a seeker, is to purify my mind and intellect and then my real self will shine through. Then I will realize who I am, the peace which I had been seeking all my life. Bhagavan said in the last verse we have discussed that you will then achieve that Santim Nirvana Paramam Matsanstam Adhiyachadi. In the verse 15 which we discussed, as I discussed last time, it said, having gone through this and you have done this, this Yoga of meditation, which is to how to control your mind, how to sit still, control your body, control your senses, control your mind and then focus on yourself, then focus on me as your supreme goal. Then you will find that peace which you had been looking all your life. That's because that peace resides in me, the supreme self.

The peace I'm seeking in this world does not exist in this world. And therefore me seeking the peace in this world is something like if, let's say for there is a one weekend at King's Dominion, there is a free ride that you can take as many rides as many times, no tickets needed or no attendants are going to stop you from taking that ride over and over again. We go on that roller coaster ride because this is a great chance. I know it's a lot of fun and here it is that there is no restriction. How many times I can take it. So I go on the roller coaster and while I'm going through the roller coaster, I'm constantly thinking, well, if this thing can stabilize, I'll really feel good about it.

Boy, it is going up and down. I can't even predict when it's going to go up and when it's going to come down. If it just stabilizes, I'll feel good about it. But because of my desire to have this fun, I'm not getting off the roller coaster. And after all, I get so engrossed into this, I don't even realize when it stops and starts again. And I'm constantly thinking, if this stabilizes, I may feel a little better about it.

At that point, some roller coaster guru can come and say, if you really want it stabilized, why don't you get off the roller coaster when it stops next time? So I said, what do I need to do? I said, well, just focus on when it stops. When it stops, you get out and then you'll be in a stable ground, which is what your real place is on a stable ground. That's where you were before. Before you decided you want to have this unlimited fun on this roller coaster.

Because there is no fee today. There is no restriction how many times you can take it. You say, well, I'll basically take it as long as I can stay there. But in that goal, I forgot that what I'm seeking is stability. That's my true nature. That's what I'm daily living.

But in that quest for getting this unlimited fun in what I always thought is a great fun, but I did not go there because it cost so much. Now that my chance to do it free, I'm on a roller coaster constantly seeking for the stability which does not exist in roller coaster. Very nature of roller coaster is to go up and down. So some guru comes and said, just focus on yourself. When you see a little stability, that's where the roller coaster stops. And then you will find that stability which you had been seeking all throughout this roller coaster will be yours because it resides outside this roller coaster.

Bhagavan says the Santi Nirvana Paramam, that santhi which only gets when you are liberated from this rat of this limited being, trying to seek happiness and peace in this world outside. You will achieve that because your mind and intellect is now pure to experience the joy which resides in the self. And once you unite with that self, Matsangstham Adigacchati, you will achieve that state of mind. And then the last three verses which you've seen, which is 16, 17 and 18. And it said, what we tend to think is, well, I need to live my life as I'm living. But then I need to have like 15 minutes in the morning.

I'm going to meditate, you know, and then I've achieved this state of paramshanti. Well that absolutely is a false notion. To do a meditation, you have to prepare for doing meditation. So how do we prepare for it? The Bhagavan says that the yoga is not possible for people who leave life without any control. I live undisciplined life.

And then I say, then I sit down and do yoga. A lot of people have this strong notion that I am living this dynamic life of working for 18 hours a day. But because I have 15 minutes of meditation then I can go on for another 18 hours. Bhagavan clearly says that that's not the reality. You live a life which is hectic and uncontrolled. You will not be able to meditate at all.

And therefore it says Na nati athi Asna tastu Yoga aste. One who eats too much for him. In other words, if I'm indulging in the sense gratifications, Yoga is not possible. Also not possible for one who doesn't eat at all. One who is completely avoiding any of this fulfillment for this body. So one is not eating at all.

One is eating too much is also not possible for him. One is not eating at all. It is not possible for him. It clearly says that torturing my body and senses unnecessarily will not make me any more worthy of meditation than a person who is moderately living life and leave a disciplined life. You know, Nacha ATI Swapna Shila shya Swapna shil Swapna. One who is engaged in swapna.

Dreaming is only possible when you're sleeping. So you see, one who is Swapna silhou now Swapna silhu. I can be Swapna seal while I'm waking in this world also. Because from the point of Vedanta, the Swapna extends from my dream world into the waking world. Waking world is nothing but another glorified dream. From the Vedanta's perspective then Najas Swapna Shila Siya who is sleeping too much in this or not sleeping at all.

Jagrato Nayva Charjana or constantly awake in this world More engaged in this world, not taking enough sleep or not eating at all. Anything which is extreme is to be avoided by oneself because it will not give you the purity of yourself, the control over yourself to focus your mind. And it's very enlightening that this is not something which is a sacred knowledge which only learn from Bhagavad Gita. People learn on their own when they want to achieve something. You know, we definitely will say, well tomorrow I cannot do this because I have to wake up early and do this. I'm not coming to that party or I'm not going to late night movie if I'm serious about what I'm going to do next day.

I saw two interviews on TV by two Bollywood stars which I probably wouldn't think that has ever gone to any of the schools of philosophy. Both of them are basically known for their good looks like Akshay Kumar and John Abraham. I heard them on short interviews and the first thing they said is that how do you do that? I live a very disciplined life. Now you won't think that you will hear from a Bollywood star, but both of them said that the only way we can achieve this stardom which and maintain it by living a very disciplined life. I don't stay awake after 9 o' clock or whatever.

I go to sleep by that time. This I wake up early. Akshay Kumar had some so and said this has to only be, what do we call it, recorded at six o' clock in the morning. But that's the only time he will be available. He won't be staying late or doing this. And he said, I'm very disciplined.

I do this exercise daily. And I heard exact same thing from John Abraham's interview on somewhere. Now I wouldn't really think that they have a great knowledge of Bhagavad Gita or somebody told them. They themselves figured out that if I want to maintain my success, the only way I can maintain it is by living a disciplined life. So anyone who is is serious about success eventually finds out that success is only possible by living a moderate life of moderation. So Bhagavad Gita says if I'm not clear about that and think that meditation will be panasha, that it will solve all the problems, then I can live as Mina said, I take Lipitor and after that I can eat anything I want because I'm on Lipitor.

That's not a smart idea, right? Because anytime a doctor gives me medication, I say, Neil, you have A cholesterol problem. Here's the medication. But medication only will work well if you control your diet and do the following things. So anything which I want to achieve, the moderation is the key. Bhagavan says, first of all, it says, yoga is not for the people who live an extreme life, you know?

Then the positive message is Yukta Ahara Vihaarasya, Yukta Chestasya Karmasu, Yukta Sapnava Vodashya Yogo Bhavati Dukhaha. So now it says, well, did I really forget why I'm doing this yoga? Why did I start all this thing in the first place? If I have to do this moderate life and all this fun I used to have at the party at night, I have to give up on all that. Why do I even start getting into something like that? You are doing it, my friend, to get rid of your dukkha.

All the sorrows which you have, you want to get rid of it. When every moment of your life, there's not a single moment where I can say, this pain is great. Bola really feels good, you know, Unless you heard this. Somebody was banging his head. And I don't know who said it, it's pretty famous. He said someone was banging his head.

Why are you banging your head against the wall? He said, because it feels good when I stop. Just to get that feeling of good. When you stop, you don't bang your head against the wall. snippets.title: Day 86: The Restless Mind
snippets.sanskrit:
यथा दीपो निवातस्थो नेङ्गते सोपमा स्मृता |

यत्रोपरमते चित्तं निरुद्धं योगसेवया |

सुखमात्यन्तिकं यत्तद् बुद्धिग्राह्यमतीन्द्रियम् |
snippets.transliteration:
yathā dīpo nivātastho neṅgate sopamā smṛtā .

yatroparamate cittaṃ niruddhaṃ yogasevayā .

sukhamātyantikaṃ yattad buddhigrāhyamatīndriyam .
verseTranslations: The wise man who has conquered his mind and is absorbed in the Self is as a lamp which does not flicker, since it stands sheltered from every wind.

There, where the whole nature is seen in the light of the Self, where the man abides within his Self and is satisfied there, its functions restrained by its union with the Divine, the mind finds rest.
When he enjoys the Bliss which passes sense, and which only the Pure Intellect can grasp, when he comes to rest within his own highest Self, never again will he stray from reality.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 6, Dhyana Yoga, Yoga of Meditation. And that happiness can only come if we become detached from our attachment to this world of objects and beings. But we still have to work in this world. And therefore the simple definition given of a person who has achieved that detachment, whether you call him a yogi or a sannyasis, Anasritaha Karma, Falam Karyam Karautiya. One who acts in this world without depending on the fruits of actions, he is acting, but he is not dependent on what will come out of my actions. That anxiety is not there.

One who has achieved that state of mind control. He is a yogi or he is a sannyasi. That's as simple a definition. Then he says to achieve that state, obviously you have to go through several disciplines and practices. And all this is all about controlling your mind. Because all that we consider a happiness or unhappiness, sorrow or pleasure is all a mental state.

That mental state is controlled. Then we can control whether we are in a happiness or unhappiness state. So the practice given is called meditation. This meditation is not just a physical act of sitting down cross legged and focusing on some idea, but regulating the entire life. So we have seen the prerequisites of what needs to be done. It's a one who is regulating his life in all aspects.

He does not eat too much, he does not eat too little, he does not sleep too much, he does not sleep too little. And even in the activities that he does not exert himself too much. In other words, everything in moderation. All that really means is you only apply the appropriate amount of efforts and not too much, not too little, you are tightening a bolt. If you tighten too much, it's a problem. If you don't tighten enough, it's too much.

Only time it works perfectly is when it is appropriately tightened. So every activity of our life should be regulated to a point. But then your mind has to be focused or controlled and how do we control mind? And we have learned that the very nature of the mind, very definition of mind is mind is nothing but a flow of thoughts. Mind is like a river. Water does not make a river, but a flowing water in one direction makes a river.

So mind is nothing but the flow of thoughts, in our case, many directions. So these thoughts which are right now are channelized into many channels. Those each channel thinks that there is, at the end of the channel, there is happiness. That this channel, if we channelize to one particular point where we think the happiness really lies, Scripture says, lies within yourself. So that exercise of reverting your mind's flow of thoughts from outward to inward is called meditation. To practice that, we have been given a prescription and detailed instruction.

Sit down erect so there is no discomfort in your body. There is no discomfort in the environment around you. And then focus your mind onto yourself. That peace which you experience during that inward journey is yourself. And as the meditators of all ages have said, once you experience that peace, you will like to experience that over and over again. And then with that constant practice, you reach a point where that peace become permanent.

So the last thing we have seen is that. YADAV VINIYATAM CHITTAM TMANIYEVA TISHTATHE when the mind rests in the self, only once the mind found its final destination, where the peace lies, it does not want to go anywhere. If somebody says, where do you want to buy a house in Richmond? And everybody says, where? Once I've decided the West End is the right place to buy a house, I'm not going to look around in Mechanicsville or in a Chesterfield, because I have already decided that right place to find house is in West End. So once the mind decides that the real resting place where the peace is is in myself, it will not go anywhere else.

It's just the very nature of the mind. So it says, once that mind is rest in self, free from longing. NISPROHA SARVA KAMA E BIHA all the kamas were up till now, were for what? Everything I have done since I understood who I am till last night or this morning is to get happiness, to feel happy, to get peace in life. And this peace is so elusive. More you go after it like a mirage.

More you go after it, more it runs away from you. And that once you find a place where it is not a mirage, then you will establish in that. So he says, once you establish in that there is no longing of all objects and desire, then it is Said he is united that Yuktah. We are like the lost children. We are lost in this sansar, this mela and we are seeking our own place where our family or where we came from. So that place when we get united we find peace.

A child will be lost in India festival and is crying profusely. No matter what you tell him, give me chocolate. Nothing works till find my parent. And as soon as he finds his parents nothing can attract him but that peace. When you find after that there is nothing else you will look for. So our nature is peace and therefore we are seeking peace.

If our nature is not peace, we wouldn't be seeking peace. My nature is health, therefore I am seeking health. So anything happens, I run to the doctor, run to whatever, fix me quickly, as quickly as you can. Everybody says antibiotics, read about antibiotics and all the perils of taking antibiotics. The first thing I go and ask my doctor is give me the antibiotics as quickly and as powerful as possible. I want to get rid of whatever that is not health as quickly as possible.

Because my real nature is health. My real nature is not unhealthy. So I am always seeking what my true nature is. My true nature is peace. And everything else in this world is giving me un peace. Once I unite with that peace, I am considered Yuktaha.

This simile used is just as in a windless room the flame of a lamp does not flicker, it remains steady. Yatra uparamate chittam nirdam yoga sevaya yatracha eva atmana tmanam pasyan atmani tushyade. So when the mind restrained by the practice of yoga attains quietude by when seeing the self by the self he satisfied by the self always seeking all our life is some satisfaction, some peace. We tried everywhere else but it was never complete. It may come for a for a while as I said. As soon as I get that, the key of my first BMW in my hand, a complete peace in my mind.

All that I want to achieve. And the next moment the agitation starts again. As soon as he tells me what the insurance would be for this guy. But once I found that piece where? By the self satisfied by the self. So yogi, once he practices this yoga to find his peace and he found it, he is now satisfied that the final state.

So this four verses which we are looking at basically describe yoga, what yoga is all about. Because we have this whole notion about yoga sitting down in a lotus position. Those are all the practices to control your body, mind and intellect. All agitations are coming to me in my life is through my body, mind and intellect. Either my body is not healthy, my body is very healthy. My mind is not healthy.

Mind is okay, but ideas are not coming the intellect. Once those are controlled and the peace comes, then I am a yogi. Sukhum atyantikam Yattat Buddhi Grahiyam Atindriyam Vetti Yatra nachayevayam Titaha chalati tatvatah. This is like somebody who has gone to Hawaii and is explaining the joy of being in Hawaii. He said I had been to all these different destination for vacation. He said, no, no, Neil, forget about all of that.

You just go to Hawaii one time and that's the end of the story. You wouldn't like to go anywhere else. So he explained and see, when you go there, they have all these things. After that you never have to take a vacation anywhere else. Sukam Atyantikam Yattad When a yogi feels this infinite bliss, one who has experienced this bliss in his meditation, he said that's infinite bliss. That bliss is not something which comes and goes.

So what we worry about is this too much trouble in the first place. First place I can't wake up early in the morning as everybody says that you should do. Then I have to sit down in a particular place. Then I have to control my mind which is not controllable in the first place. And then I will, someday I will find little peace and then it will go away and then start all over again. Swami used to say in our business there is no danger because we can bluff our way out and nobody can catch us. But no, Bhagavan said that's not true. What my Buddhist says, this is good for you or what Is not good for you is all colored by my experiences and my desires and my Vasanas. Once Buddhi grasps that infinite peace he will never be shaken from that ultimate reality. Tattvataha he will never be able to think other way around. He will never be able to think happiness lies outside.

Because his Buddhi has grasped that the reality where the bliss is so that's a state which only you have to achieve one time. Once you achieve that, nobody will be able to shake you off that realization. Once you realize what is reality. Once you wake up from your dream and you realize what the reality is. No matter how much you convince yourself that no, no, no. The reality was the one which was experiencing the dream.

In my dream I was Bill Gates boss. No matter how much I convinced myself that no, no, I am actually Bill Gates boss. That's not going to work. Because once my Buddhis grasped that what I was experiencing was nothing but a dream, as a waker I will not be able to go back to that. In the same way the Upanishad says that the waking world is a dream. We have assigned values to all these objects in our waking world which is happiness.

Once you wake up from this, do you realize that there is no value outside for my own bliss or happiness? In that you cannot be shaken off. Yamlab dvaach aparam labam manyate na adhikam tathaha. Having experienced that, you will realize there is nothing else greater to be achieved. All my life, everything I have done is to find some peace. Some peace, some happiness.

Well, here is ultimate happiness and ultimate bliss. So there is nothing to be gained if I suddenly wake up and realize that my forefathers used to own the entire real estate in Richmond.

snippets.title: Day 87: The Supreme Yogi
snippets.sanskrit:
यं लब्ध्वा चापरं लाभं मन्यते नाधिकं ततः |

तं विद्याद् दुःखसंयोगवियोगं योगसंज्ञितम् |

सङ्कल्पप्रभवान्कामांस्त्यक्त्वा सर्वानशेषतः |
snippets.transliteration:
yaṃ labdhvā cāparaṃ lābhaṃ manyate nādhikaṃ tataḥ .

taṃ vidyād duḥkhasaṃyogaviyogaṃ yogasaṃjñitam .

saṅkalpaprabhavānkāmāṃstyaktvā sarvānaśeṣataḥ .
verseTranslations: Finding That, he will realise that there is no possession so precious. And when once established here, no calamity can disturb him.
This inner severance from the affliction of misery is spirituality. It should be practised with determination and with a heart which refuses to be depressed.
Renouncing every desire which imagination can conceive, controlling the senses at every point by the power of mind;
snippets.commentary:
Unlike a car with its user's manual, we are born without instructions how to live. We experience life vicissitudes without a so called user's manual. The Gita has been described as such a guide. So those of you who remember we were on chapter six two weeks ago and we discuss _Verses_ 25, 26 and 27. Chapter six is a dhyana yoga. The first six chapters, as we have discussed many, many times, describe the you part of that.

You are that thou art Tattvamasi in the Upanishads. So the you part is you and I, who we are. Today we discussed in first six chapter and it culminates into Dhyana Yoga that who I am, which I can't understand right now, I can reflect on myself and find that self. This false notion is this is me, this body, mind and intellect. To undo this, I have to contemplate on that self. And once I find myself by myself, becomes content in myself, then my yoga is complete.

That's what we have seen. The verse we have seen which says. Atmanam Pashyam atmani Tushadi. Seeing the self by the Atmana. Atmanam Pashyan Atmani Tushadhi. Seeing the self by the self.

I'm satisfied in myself. That's the goal of life. I want contentment, I want happiness which is everlasting. I looked at, I sought that outside. I finally find in myself. And once I find that in myself, I'm satisfied, content.

So the first six chapters told us who we are, what are our shortcomings and how to overcome that, culminating into meditation. And we came across a new definition of yoga in last few _Verses_ which says Dukkha sahyoga vayoga is yoga. Disassociation with the association with sorrows is yoga. You've seen that right now we actually associate with our sorrows, therefore we are sorrowful. I have ache and pain in my leg and I think I have pain. So I start associating with this pain, somebody pricks me and that's my pain.

But when doctor or a nurse is ready to give me an injection, I'm already prepared for that. I disassociate myself from that pain so I can tolerate it without any problem. Because I have already disengaged and said that's not really a pain, not something unnatural happening to me. That attitude of disassociating yourself with the association with pain. Pain exists, sorrows exist and my association with that ends. Bhagavan says that's Yoga Dukkha sah Yoga.

Yoga is Yoga and therefore say Dukena Guruna API na Vichalyate then the greatest sorrows come from the outside world. It seems like greatest sorrows are coming to me. From my perspective those sorrows are just the natural occurring of this world. It happens just as the laws of nature predicted will happen. So therefore in Yogi who has disassociated himself from the sorrows, he is without any. He has found himself by himself and he finds this infinite joy and happiness in that.

So the next three _Verses_ which he had seen says they go along with 24 which is Sankalpa Prabhavan Kaman Tak Manasa Indriyagram Vinam Vinayamya. Samantha, you have traveled that journey from ignorance about yourself to understanding what's not right in my internal instrument, the mind and intellect, purifying it through the Karma Yoga, contemplating on that self, I have come to this point that now I have given up all the desire prompted actions, all the desires which are prompted by Sankalpa Shakti of my mind. In other words, I may have normal desire like I'm thirsty and I want water. That's not Sankalpa Prabhavan Kama. They are not born out of my fanciful imagination. I'm thirsty when I need water.

But the Sankalpa Shakti in my mind is my mind projects a future, imaginary future and say if I do this then I can do this and then I will have this and then I'll gain this and then I'll be a millionaire. Well that's my Sankalpa Shakti. And what I do is before I start a plan to achieve that goal, my mind has already moved on to another goal. But I can also do this and then do this and then do this and then I can be a billionaire. So before even I start any concrete actions to achieve my goal my mind has erased that goal and gave me another goal. So I'm constantly chasing the goal which is not there.

By that time I start working on my goal. My goal has moved away. So I'm aimlessly moving. And you see that Sankalpa Shakti. All the desires prompted by this fanciful nature of my mind. When I give up asesata without leaving anything behind.

In other words, I will leave in the presence of work, in the presence and all my goals which are grounded in my life and I'll work towards that. That's not Gita says you should give up. But it says Sankalpa Prabhuan. All the desires prompted by this fanciful nature of a mind. You give up Manasa Indriyagram Vinayamya and then controlling all these senses. The senses which are my instrument to transact with this world outside.

My sense of sight, sense of sound, touch, smell, taste that I control by my mind. Because the senses really do not have any power. Till the mind creates tricks, plays tricks with it. So if I control my mind, my mind is now steady because it is inwardly focused on myself. I control all the senses through my mind. So Sanahi then the verse we have seen is Sanahi Sanahi Uparam Buddhaya Dhruti Gruhitaya Atma Sanstam Manaha Krutva Nakinchi da Vicentayat.

He says this is not going to come overnight. You have to constantly practice that. Then gradually Sanai, gradually you will have a control over this by the firm intellectual intellect which is now purified by all the things which we talked about in the first six chapters. Selfless actions, you know, and all these things. And now purified my intellect which is a pure intellect is seeing the reality. What is right and what is wrong.

What is really good for me and what is not good for me. With that intellect I. I gradually get the control and get this peace and say Atma Sanstam Manaha Kratva. Mind is established in the self. It's not running outside to fulfilling these fanciful desires. It established in the self. Kincit Apinachintayat Yogi.

Such a seeker will not be thinking about anything but the self. In other words, now I clearly see the difference between I and the instruments of my transaction with the world. This body, mind and intellect are just instruments which I use to transact with this world. That duality only exists in my mind. Myself and your self and his self is one and the same self. This duality has created these sorrows for me.

This Establishment in the self gives me the contentment which I had been seeking for. And now comes the prescription. Because we think that once I have figured out and I'm established in meditation, that everything is over. I have now achieved what I'm going to achieve. And after that there's not really much efforts left for me. So the next verse, Bhagavan reminds us that this is a constant effort to control your mind.

If you think the mind is going to turn towards yourself and that is the end of the story that is going to remain there, you are mistaken. The very nature of mind is restless. The mind is called mind because it is the flow of thoughts. And a flow of thoughts. Keeping in one direction is going to be difficult. So therefore you need to be vigilant in your intellect and seeing what the mind is doing.

And controlam ashiram very nature of the mind is. It is restless, unsteady. You can't think of the one thing for a long period of time. I'm thinking about something and suddenly I hear something and my mind just runs away. I'm thinking about doing something and my mind sees something and it runs away from that. It is the very nature of the mind to use the senses as its gateways and runs away.

And I say, don't try to punish yourself for that. But remember that your job is to bring that mind back to where it needs to be. So you have to train this mind and tell this mind this is not right. You're trying to meditate, you're trying to study. You're trying to do something which you decided is good for you. This is what you want to do.

But hearing something, listening something, seeing something, mind runs away. Don't get discouraged. But bring the mind back and say, you should be doing this right now. So Bhagawan says, yatha yattaha nisharati manaha chanchalam astiram tathaha tathaha niyamya etad atmani evam vasam nayat. Whenever, whenever mind does that. That time you bring the mind and establish back into yourself by yourself.

Bring your mind, turn it towards yourself and then say prasantamanasamhinam yoginam sukhamuttamam. Why are we doing all of that? Why do you want to control the mind? Just because I want to punish my mind, say no, no. What you're looking for was happiness, Sukham. You are looking for a happiness which is everlasting.

Therefore it's uttamam, not the regular ones which we get for a While and then it goes away. Well, we had been good. We had been going through this all our life and we are not very happy about it. We want something everlasting. Give me something which I never have to return back to the. I want something permanent happiness.

Bhagawan said the only permanent happiness comes from Prasantamanah. By a quiet mind is the only source of joy and happiness. Agitated mind cannot give you any happiness. I may be telling you the greatest news of your life. But if your mind is agitated, you won't listen to me. I may be giving you the greatest gift you can receive.

But if your mind is agitated, you won't even see it. So it is the mind which decides whether I am happy or not. So what is the quality of the mind which is in happiness? The mind which is quiet gives me happiness. And there is a Prasantamanasam Hienam Yoginam Sukha Muttamam. The yogi who has been striving and seeking the self.

Once he finds his self established the mind in it, his mind now becomes quiet. This quietness in the mind gives the Sukham Uttamam the greatest happiness. Sensing Upeti Santa Rajasam. You know why he gets the happiness? Shanta Rajasam Rajasa activity. You know this Sattva Rajasantamas the very nature of the mind is to be Rajasa want to run away.

When you make this mind quiet out of his habit of running away into say stay quiet. You know it gives the happiness. Brahma Bhutam Akalpasham with this practice of meditation when I purified my mind and intellect. Now I have trained my mind to be steady which is contrary to its own nature of running away. This quiet mind removes all my sin or kalmasam and the Yogi becomes without any sin. And the sin is nothing but the impurities in my internal instruments mind and intellect.

I'm purified by those impurities. I now realize that myself and the supreme self is one and the same self. So I become Brahma Bhutam. I've now identified myself with the eternal self which is all pervading, an almighty and omniscient and omnipotent. Then in my previous case I identified myself with this limited self which is limit in my body. A limit of my mental capacity and my intellectual capacity.

All my problems are because my identification with this limitedness. Now because I have now identified myself with the supreme. All my problems have dissolved into a permanent peace.

Samantha, you have traveled that journey from ignorance about yourself to understanding what's not right in my internal instrument, the mind and intellect, purifying it through the Karma Yoga, contemplating on that self, I have come to this point that now I have given up all the desire prompted actions, all the desires which are prompted by Sankalpa Shakti of my mind. In other words, I may have normal desire like I'm thirsty and I want water. That's not Sankalpa Prabhavan Kama. They are not born out of my fanciful imagination. I'm thirsty when I need water.

But the Sankalpa Shakti in my mind is my mind projects a future, imaginary future and say if I do this then I can do this and then I will have this and then I'll gain this and then I'll be a millionaire. Well that's my Sankalpa Shakti. And what I do is before I start a plan to achieve that goal, my mind has already moved on to another goal. But I can also do this and then do this and then do this and then I can be a billionaire. So before even I start any concrete actions to achieve my goal my mind has erased that goal and gave me another goal. So I'm constantly chasing the goal which is not there.

By that time I start working on my goal. My goal has moved away. So I'm aimlessly moving. And you see that Sankalpa Shakti. All the desires prompted by this fanciful nature of my mind. When I give up asesata without leaving anything behind.

In other words, I will leave in the presence of work, in the presence and all my goals which are grounded in my life and I'll work towards that. That's not Gita says you should give up. But it says Sankalpa Prabhuan. All the desires prompted by this fanciful nature of a mind. You give up Manasa Indriyagram Vinayamya and then controlling all these senses. The senses which are my instrument to transact with this world outside.

My sense of sight, sense of sound, touch, smell, taste that I control by my mind. Because the senses really do not have any power. Till the mind creates tricks, plays tricks with it. So if I control my mind, my mind is now steady because it is inwardly focused on myself. I control all the senses through my mind. So Sanahi then the verse we have seen is Sanahi Sanahi Uparam Buddhaya Dhruti Gruhitaya Atma Sanstam Manaha Krutva Nakinchi da Vicentayat.

He says this is not going to come overnight. You have to constantly practice that. Then gradually Sanai, gradually you will have a control over this by the firm intellectual intellect which is now purified by all the things which we talked about in the first six chapters. Selfless actions, you know, and all these things. And now purified my intellect which is a pure intellect is seeing the reality. What is right and what is wrong.

What is really good for me and what is not good for me. With that intellect I. I gradually get the control and get this peace and say Atma Sanstam Manaha Kratva. Mind is established in the self. It's not running outside to fulfilling these fanciful desires. It established in the self. Kincit Apinachintayat Yogi.

Such a seeker will not be thinking about anything but the self. In other words, now I clearly see the difference between I and the instruments of my transaction with the world. This body, mind and intellect are just instruments which I use to transact with this world. That duality only exists in my mind. Myself and your self and his self is one and the same self. This duality has created these sorrows for me.

This Establishment in the self gives me the contentment which I had been seeking for. And now comes the prescription. Because we think that once I have figured out and I'm established in meditation, that everything is over. I have now achieved what I'm going to achieve. And after that there's not really much efforts left for me. So the next verse, Bhagavan reminds us that this is a constant effort to control your mind.

If you think the mind is going to turn towards yourself and that is the end of the story that is going to remain there, you are mistaken. The very nature of mind is restless. The mind is called mind because it is the flow of thoughts. And a flow of thoughts. Keeping in one direction is going to be difficult. So therefore you need to be vigilant in your intellect and seeing what the mind is doing.

And controlam ashiram very nature of the mind is. It is restless, unsteady. You can't think of the one thing for a long period of time. I'm thinking about something and suddenly I hear something and my mind just runs away. I'm thinking about doing something and my mind sees something and it runs away from that. It is the very nature of the mind to use the senses as its gateways and runs away.

And I say, don't try to punish yourself for that. But remember that your job is to bring that mind back to where it needs to be. So you have to train this mind and tell this mind this is not right. You're trying to meditate, you're trying to study. You're trying to do something which you decided is good for you. This is what you want to do.

But hearing something, listening something, seeing something, mind runs away. Don't get discouraged. But bring the mind back and say, you should be doing this right now. So Bhagawan says, yatha yattaha nisharati manaha chanchalam astiram tathaha tathaha niyamya etad atmani evam vasam nayat. Whenever, whenever mind does that. That time you bring the mind and establish back into yourself by yourself.

Bring your mind, turn it towards yourself and then say prasantamanasamhinam yoginam sukhamuttamam. Why are we doing all of that? Why do you want to control the mind? Just because I want to punish my mind, say no, no. What you're looking for was happiness, Sukham. You are looking for a happiness which is everlasting.

Therefore it's uttamam, not the regular ones which we get for a While and then it goes away. Well, we had been good. We had been going through this all our life and we are not very happy about it. We want something everlasting. Give me something which I never have to return back to the. I want something permanent happiness.

Bhagawan said the only permanent happiness comes from Prasantamanah. By a quiet mind is the only source of joy and happiness. Agitated mind cannot give you any happiness. I may be telling you the greatest news of your life. But if your mind is agitated, you won't listen to me. I may be giving you the greatest gift you can receive.

But if your mind is agitated, you won't even see it. So it is the mind which decides whether I am happy or not. So what is the quality of the mind which is in happiness? The mind which is quiet gives me happiness. And there is a Prasantamanasam Hienam Yoginam Sukha Muttamam. The yogi who has been striving and seeking the self.

Once he finds his self established the mind in it, his mind now becomes quiet. This quietness in the mind gives the Sukham Uttamam the greatest happiness. Sensing Upeti Santa Rajasam. You know why he gets the happiness? Shanta Rajasam Rajasa activity. You know this Sattva Rajasantamas the very nature of the mind is to be Rajasa want to run away.

When you make this mind quiet out of his habit of running away into say stay quiet. You know it gives the happiness. Brahma Bhutam Akalpasham with this practice of meditation when I purified my mind and intellect. Now I have trained my mind to be steady which is contrary to its own nature of running away. This quiet mind removes all my sin or kalmasam and the Yogi becomes without any sin. And the sin is nothing but the impurities in my internal instruments mind and intellect.

I'm purified by those impurities. I now realize that myself and the supreme self is one and the same self. So I become Brahma Bhutam. I've now identified myself with the eternal self which is all pervading, an almighty and omniscient and omnipotent. Then in my previous case I identified myself with this limited self which is limit in my body. A limit of my mental capacity and my intellectual capacity.

All my problems are because my identification with this limitedness. Now because I have now identified myself with the supreme. All my problems have dissolved into a permanent peace.
snippets.reflection:
Try even five minutes of stillness today. Don't worry about doing it correctly. Simply sit, close your eyes, and notice what's happening in your field of awareness.

When the mind wanders—and it will—gently bring it back. This gentle returning is the practice. Each time you notice wandering and return, you're strengthening the muscle of awareness. The Gita is clear: the mind is restless and difficult to control, but through practice and dispassion, it can be mastered.

Consider: What is your relationship with your own mind? Are you its master, or does it control you? The practice of meditation is the practice of reclaiming sovereignty over your own inner world.

snippets.title: Day 89: Meditation
snippets.sanskrit:
युञ्जन्नेवं सदात्मानं योगी विगतकल्मषः |

सर्वभूतस्थमात्मानं सर्वभूतानि चात्मनि |

यो मां पश्यति सर्वत्र सर्वं च मयि पश्यति |
snippets.transliteration:
yuñjannevaṃ sadātmānaṃ yogī vigatakalmaṣaḥ .

sarvabhūtasthamātmānaṃ sarvabhūtāni cātmani .

yo māṃ paśyati sarvatra sarvaṃ ca mayi paśyati .
verseTranslations: Thus, free from sin, abiding always in the Eternal, the saint enjoys without effort the Bliss which flows from realisation of the Infinite.
He who experiences the unity of life sees his own Self in all beings, and all beings in his own Self, and looks on everything with an impartial eye;
He who sees Me in everything and everything in Me, him shall I never forsake, nor shall he lose Me.
snippets.commentary:
Unlike a car with its user's manual, we are born without instructions how to live. We experience life vicissitudes without a so called user's manual. The Gita has been described as such a guide. We had been discussing chapter six, Yoga of Meditation. So far we have seen up to verse 27 that the goal of meditation is to make the mind steady. The mind currently in my present situation is flickering and running away in many, many directions.

And therefore the whole idea of making the mind steady seems very, very difficult for me. So we have seen the practice how to meditate, how to make this mind steady, Choose a place which is conducive, make it a practice every day, make this as a habit, same place, same position, controlling your body from not disturbing you, make it most comfortable, sit down and focus your mind. Now this is where we find ourselves in difficulty focusing the mind on one goal and one target. We have heard this simile that the mind, when it is like a mind, like a lamp, when there is a wind in the room or in the place where the lamp is placed, the flame flickers. And depending on the nature of the wind, flame may flicker very heavily or may flicker just a little, depending on how much wind there is. The mind works in a similar way.

Depending on my vasanas, depending on the desires in my mind, this mind will be running after many, many thoughts and one thought will lead to the another. Swamiji used to say, I'm trying to chant Rama and the Rama. The word Rama reminds me of Ramlal who has borrowed money from me. And then we go on and on and on. But this obviously can be controlled, as we have seen that if you calm down this wind of desires, at least at the time of sitting in the meditation, that you have trained your mind not to think about other things and you focus on that one thought, then mind will be steady. And as we have seen that by a constant practice, the yogi can make his mind steady.

And once that mind becomes steady, he will Recognize the peace within himself from whatever the cause. The restless and the unsteady mind wanders away from that. Let him restrain it and bring it back under the control of the self alone by practice now it is becoming easier for me. I guess I am speaking for every seeker who is practicing that practice makes man perfect. We have heard this before. We have learned in our life that anything I continue to practice, it becomes easier.

Something which I practice over and over and over again. It reaches a point that there is no effort required. Something like driving a car. When I was first learning how to drive a car, obviously I had all kinds of problems. And I may have said this before that I used to complain to my cousins who were trying to teach me how to drive a car in Africa. I had gone from India.

I had never driven a car in India. I probably took some lessons in India before I was living for Zambia. And in India it was very easy to get a license. Nobody even bothered with it. I really knew how to drive, but I got a license now I went to Zambia. And then I really had to drive.

So learning from my cousins how to drive, and they will tell me, well, keep your car steady, keep your car steady. And I said, how can I keep it steady when I'm sitting on one side of the car? If the steering wheel was in the center of the car, it would have been much easier for me. But that was an excuse because I did not know how to control the car. And then more and more I practice driving the car. It started becoming easier and easier.

And then I reached a point where driving a car requires no efforts. I sit down in the car, put the key in the ignition, can be thinking about every other thing except driving the car. But I will be driving properly in a right lane. And whatever the appropriate thing I have to do for driving the car. But I do not have to put any more efforts in. Comes automatically and naturally.

As soon as I sit down in the driver's seat, my mind takes over. My subconscious mind takes over how to drive this car. Meditation is like that. If I practice over and over and over again to steady my mind under one thought and one thought alone. As soon as I sit at the seat of meditation, my mind will know what to do and it will control itself automatically. And Bhagavan says that such a yogi experiences the supreme bliss, that peace which I had been seeking all my life.

And I had been trying to achieve that in many different ways. To acquire things, to make sure everything is secured, my future is secured, my Family's future is secured. However, I never experience that peace in my mind. Now at the seat of meditation, I can experience the supreme bliss. Bhagavan said, the supreme bliss verily comes to this yogi whose mind is quiet and peaceful. His passions are quietened.

Now he is free from sin. And we have seen the sin is nothing but impurities on my mind. Impurities are the impressions on my mind which makes me think that this I will do and that will make me happy. Once my mind is steady and is focused on one thought, who I am, what is myself, all these impurities are purified and I achieve that bliss. And the term used is Brahma Bhutam akalmasham. He becomes one with the Brahman all pervading self and he becomes free of all sins.

Continuing in this thought, the next three verses talks about the yogi who has with continued practice has made this as his own nature that the Yunjan Evam Sada Atmanam Yogi Vigada kalmashah. Again we are talking about in Yogi who has become freed from all his sins. Now we sometimes makes an argument that on one hand, the law of karma says that if I have done something, I have to pay for it. Or if I pay for it, in a sense, if it was a negative act, if it is a positive act, I will get the reward. And then here it says that by meditation I will become free of all sins. How do we reconcile the idea of the law of karma which says you cannot escape from your actions?

Here it says just by plain meditation I can become free from all my sins. Well, the law of karma simply says that my actions will have equal and appropriate reactions. If I've done something inappropriate, I will have to pay the consequences. However, the sins are not the consequences of the actions. Sins are the impressions on my mind. A negative impression on my mind of any event or an experience is a sin.

These negative impressions are the ones which are causing me to do more wrong things. I have seen somebody making money by illegal means. That impressions, that thought or the observation leaves a wrong impression that if I have to make money, it seemed like this is the only way to do it. That negative impression is a sin. Now that sin will make me act in an inappropriate manner. Then I will also try to achieve the wealth by what I thought was the only way you can achieve wealth by inappropriate means.

The wrong impression on the mind made me do the wrong things. Now I have to face the consequences of the wrong things I'm doing. However, if I have cleaned up my mind from all these impressions then I'm free of sins. I may have to face the consequences of my actions. There are no more wrong actions will be generated from the impressions on my mind. A Yogi constantly controlling his mind reaches the level of purification that there are no negative impressions.

And therefore there is no question for him to react inappropriately. So Yunjan Evam Sada Atmanam Yogi Vikatha Kalma Sahar. The Yogi always engaging the mind. Thus in the practice of yoga, freed from sins, he now Sukena Brahmasp Samsparsam Atyantam Sukham Ashnate. He now easily enjoy that infinite bliss. Because his mind, no matter whatever is happening in his life, in his situations, he is constantly in the thought of that supreme Brahman that he is enjoying that bliss at every moment.

So he has become Brahma sans person. He is in touch with Brahman in all situation and therefore he is experiencing that bliss in all situation. Sukham Atyantam Ashnute and he enjoys this Sukham, this happiness which is infinite. I have tried in my life all other things, but I never got it. Scripture says that Yogi who meditates and makes his mind steady. Just by that simple act of making the mind steady, he will be in touch with the Brahman.

The supreme reality will be freed from all his limitations. So the Yogi has now experienced the supreme bliss. So what would be his vision? His vision is Sarva Bhutastam Atmanam, Sarva Bhutani Cha Atmani Ikshate Yoga Yuktatma Sarvatra Samadarshanah. When now his mind harmonized and becoming in touch with the supreme reality, he starts seeing that same reality residing in all beings and also seeing all being, deciding in that supreme reality. We had seen this paradox before in Bhagavad Gita is the Bhagavan is within me or I am in the Bhagavan Is the God is within me the limited being or I the limited being in the God self which is unlimited?

The both are correct. It depends on your viewpoint. Is the room space in the universal space or is this universal space is in the room? Depending on your perspective, when you see the room space as an individual space, it is nothing but the part of the universal space. But when you see that space in the room as part of the universal space, that universal space is in the room I the limited being in the self of the Bhagavan who is manifesting everywhere and pervading everywhere. But when I look at it from my limited perspective that I see, I the limited being, have the presence of Bhagavan in me.

So I start seeing that he is in all the beings. I also see that all the beings are in that supreme self. Icsate Yoga Yukta Tatma. Thus the Yogi who is one with the yoga, one, the Yogi who has become one with his Self, he sees this Sarvatra Samadarshanaha everywhere He sees that unity. He sees this presence of the Lord equally in all beings and things. Same Lord which resides in Me is also residing in everything else that manifests in this world.

Such a vision makes this Yogi becoming one with this world and act as if this world is nothing but its own extension. Yomam pashyati Sarvatra Sarvam chamay Pashyati Tasya aham Napranashyami Sachamena Pranashyati Bhagavan now says Yomam pascati sarvatra. When Lord Krishna in Bhagavad Gita refers to himself as the first person singular, Swamiji points out every time that he is not speaking as Devaki's son or Yasuda's son, but he is referring to himself as the supreme being pervading everyone. That thus the Yogi who sees me everywhere, Yomaam Pashati Sarvatra Anything I see right away, I recognize that is nothing but the Bhagavan's manifestation. Sarvamchamay Pashati I I also see the God's presence in everything. Nothing could have been possible without his presence.
