Try even five minutes of stillness today. Don't worry about doing it correctly. Simply sit, close your eyes, and notice what's happening in your field of awareness.

When the mind wanders—and it will—gently bring it back. This gentle returning is the practice. Each time you notice wandering and return, you're strengthening the muscle of awareness. The Gita is clear: the mind is restless and difficult to control, but through practice and dispassion, it can be mastered.

Consider: What is your relationship with your own mind? Are you its master, or does it control you? The practice of meditation is the practice of reclaiming sovereignty over your own inner world.

snippets.title: Day 90: The Restless Mind
snippets.sanskrit:
सर्वभूतस्थितं यो मां भजत्येकत्वमास्थितः |

आत्मौपम्येन सर्वत्र समं पश्यति योऽर्जुन |

अर्जुन उवाच |
snippets.transliteration:
sarvabhūtasthitaṃ yo māṃ bhajatyekatvamāsthitaḥ .

ātmaupamyena sarvatra samaṃ paśyati yo.arjuna .

arjuna uvāca .
verseTranslations: The sage who realises the unity of life and who worships Me in all beings, lives in Me, whatever may be his lot.
O Arjuna! He is the perfect saint who, taught by the likeness within himself, sees the same Self everywhere, whether the outer form be pleasurable or painful.
Arjuna said: I do not see how I can attain this state of equanimity which Thou has revealed, owing to the restlessness of my mind.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter six, Dhyana Yoga, Yoga of Meditation. In chapter two, Sankhya Yoga, we learned how to differentiate between the self and non self. Self is that which is Ajaha, which is unborn and imperishable. Nayanam Chindanti Sastrani Nayanam Dhati Pavaka. That which cannot be destroyed by anything, by weapons or fire or water or air. That's the definition of the self.

Anything which does not fit into the definition is non self. So everything which I consider myself today does not fit into that definition. I was born, I have a birth date and I may have a death date. And everything which I know about me and my possessions fall into the same category. So it all falls into non self. So my world is populated by non self only.

All that I consider myself so far as me is also non self. My body has a birth and death. My mind has beginning and end. My intellect has beginning and end. So everything that I associate myself and considered to be me is non self. So now the search for the self.

How do I find myself? So we have learned up to chapter five how to purify the mind and intellect. In other words, how to prepare yourself for this search for running a marathon. You first have to prepare for it the whole period of training. So the second chapter onward we had this clear instruction how to prepare your mind. So once that mind is prepared, which we call Yoga Rudha, one who is now prepared to take on this journey for the search of the self.

So chapter six we started that journey. How to find the journey once the mind is prepared. When it becomes sinless, that the word we constantly keep using in every language that you wash your sins. In other words, the mind is cleared of all the impurities. We learn the mind is nothing but the thought channels. A thought occurs, second thought follows that same thought.

Third thought now follows the second thought. It is now creating a channel. Those channels are created which has become my mind and it is all going outwards. I'm thinking about something other than me now the same Mind I have to turn towards me the self. So everything I have learned so far is about non self. All my education, all my contemplation on what is good and what is bad, all that is about non self.

So now I have to turn towards myself the self. That's chapter six Dhyana Yoga Yoga of Meditation. So the how to prepare yourself and position yourself so that you can start that inward journey. So we have seen the clear instruction that once you have prepared your mind and purified your mind of all the scenes, then you start this journey of Dhyana Yoga and constantly doing that search you will come to a point where you will find that bliss. So verse 28 onward we are saying it says the Yogi always engaging in the mind. Thus Yunjan evam sada atmanam Yogi vigatha Kalmasah One who is freed of all sins.

In other words all the impurities of the mind. Mind which has tendency to see wrong things or going in a wrong direction that I have now adjusted the mind focuses on the right thing, clearly sees this is non self and searching for the Self that Sukena Brahma sans Parsam. Very easily it enjoys the contact with the Brahman. He easily can understand what the Self is. So clear goal here is to do inward search about what is the self is all about. When do I consider that my search has yield some results?

The next one is Sarva Bhuta Stamatmanam Sarva Bhutani Chaatmani. When I start seeing that self which I'm searching as the real self, not the non self is not only residing in me, but residing in all beings searching for myself. In tone I found the eternal self which is residing all beings and Sarva Bhutani Ch' Aatmani and I see the all beings are in the Self. My standard example, all the houses, all the buildings, I see the space. But then I also see that all the buildings are in the space because the space is all pervading. I was searching for the space for my own room once I realized the nature of the self.

I realized that space is the same in all the buildings in the world. And all the buildings are nothing but in that all pervading self. Once that awareness takes place, then I realize I am now truly understand what the nature of the space is. Space is not something which I create as an architect, not something I can buy from Lowe's or Home Depot. I can only buy material to condition my space. Space is universal and all pervading.

Once that understanding takes place about the self Bhagavan said he will say sarvatra samadharsanaha. Now he can see the equality everywhere. Now he sees the connectivity everywhere. Yomam pashyati sarvatra sarvam chamay pashati tasya ahamna pranasyami sachamena pranashati. So here comes basically an assurance. Is it something that one time I understand in meditation that I have suddenly and then next day I go to work and I forget all about it?

Once you have that understanding of all pervading self, that connection with yourself will never get broken, will never be separated. Once I understood the nature of the space, the space is all pervading. These are all conditioning. The buildings we create, the things which are in the space, then my understanding of the space will never go away, no matter what I'm doing. Yomam pashyati sarvatya. The one who sees me everywhere, Sarvamchyamay pashyati.

All the being, all the things, he sees me in it. Now, as Swamiji says, every time Krishna uses the word me, it's referring to this supreme self. Then my big I is what I'm referring to. The conditioned I is the small I, as we call it. And the big I is the unconditioned I. So when Krishna says me, he's referring to the unconditioned I, which is all perverting.

Yoma M. Pasade sir, one who sees me in all things and all things in me. Because now there is no differentiation between the self and the non self. Even the non self was nothing but the part of this. If something is all pervading, there is no space left for anything else to exist. It's only I'm limited. There is a space for other people.

If I buy all the real estate in Richmond, can you buy anything else? No, there's no nothing left for you to buy. It's only when I leave out a parcel and say I don't want that, then you can come and buy. That when I have recognized myself is all pervading, there is nothing left for anything else to exist. But now I have a vision now of the equality in this plurality. So yomam pasyati sarvatra sarvam chamayi pasyati tasya ahamna pranayami.

For him I never get separated. Once that vision takes place, you are never separated from it. Once I wake up from my dream, I never get separated from the waker. Both dreamer and waker are now connected to the waker. Dreamer also remembers that I am the waker I was dreamer, now I am a waker. Same dreamer is now waker.

The waker knows I am the waker who is dreaming. Now waking up, I never go back to the dreaming state. So once I established in my waking state, I never get separated from that till I go to sleep again. So basically once that understanding takes place, then myself is nothing but all pervading self. I never get separated from myself. There is such a Meena Pranashati and now the assurance from the all pervading Lord and I will never get separated from him.

That relationship is dual relationship. I have relationship with him and he has relationship with me. It is not a one sided love. I liked her, but she never know that I exist. Then I say, well I will never leave you. But she said, I don't even know that you exist.

I, the conditioned self has now recognized that I'm nothing but the manifestation of the me of the supreme self. The supreme self knows that I am not conditioned in this body mind. So this relationship is mutual relationship. Both exist in their own perspective. The supreme self exists from a perspective of the macrocosm. And my conditioned self exists in a perspective of the microcosm.

The room space exists as a. We can be meeting here on Sunday morning. If I say room space does not exist, only universal space exists. Go and meet in a Louis Ginter garden same as meeting here. No, we have to come here. This is where we meet.

It does exist, but nothing but the manifestation of this supreme space. So same way my conditioned self exists as an ego which is identifying with this conditioning. But it clearly knows that this is purely an identification with this conditioning for the convenience as an equipment of transaction with other conditioning selves. So the next verse says Sarva Bhuta sthitam yomam bhajati e kattum asthitah. Once we've established in this unity, now that I have seen what is myself, my search was for if this is my non self, this body is my non self. Mind is my non self, intellect is my non self.

I found myself that that consciousness which is not conditioned by this body, mind and intellect is myself. That's why in meditation the whole goal is to not to be aware about your body, not to be aware about your thoughts, about everything else, not to be aware about your intellect. Because intellect can become a hindrance in understanding. More I consider that I'm pretty smart. More I do dumb things. More I give up my idea about My intellectual.

I learn more and more about myself. So Bhagavan said, the one Ekatvamasti, the one who is now established in the unity of all things. I have realized that my conditioning, your conditioning is very different. You are not me and I am not you. You have your own limitations, I have mine. But the essence which makes me who I am, in essence between who you are is the one and the same.

The self in you and self in I is one and the same. That unity I have found. We constantly search commonness. We come across a new person. We don't try to find how different we are from each other. First thing we try to find what is common among us.

I say, I am from Richmond. Oh, I am also from Richmond. Okay, we have one commonness we found. Then we gradually say, okay. Where do you come from? Well, I come from Surat.

Oh, I'm also from Surat. More we find commonness, more we feel comfort. Then we are not worried as much about the differences which we have. The differences drop more common things. We find the people whom we love, all the negative things about them. We don't pay attention to our children, our grandchildren.

Try even five minutes of stillness today. Don't worry about doing it correctly. Simply sit, close your eyes, and notice what's happening in your field of awareness.

When the mind wanders—and it will—gently bring it back. This gentle returning is the practice. Each time you notice wandering and return, you're strengthening the muscle of awareness. snippets.reflection:
Today, practice seeing the sacred in the ordinary. That person who annoyed you? A form of the divine. That sunset that took your breath away? The same. Can you hold both truths simultaneously?

What would change if you moved through your day knowing that everything you encounter is, in its essence, a manifestation of the one divine reality? The Gita teaches that the Lord pervades all things—not as a poetic metaphor, but as literal truth.

Notice where you draw lines between sacred and secular in your life. What would happen if those lines dissolved?

verseTranslations: The inhabitants of the world, misled by those natures which the Qualities have engendered, know not that I am higher than them all, and that I do not change.

I have never seen God before.

But I pervade in this universe with my Astha DHA Prakriti. In my Eightfold nature, I manifest in this world. And you see me every day. And I say that Bhumiyapo anala kam vayuhu Manabuddhi Ahankar. That's my Eightfold Prakriti. And you see me every day.

This is my lower Prakriti. Lower means more grosser manifestation which you and I can perceive through our senses. Everything comes out of me and everything goes back into me. These three absolutely require for anything to exist. You know, the awareness that it exists, the activity, dynamism and then inertia, all three in a different proportions, in different permutation combination creates this world of plurality. What would change if you moved through your day knowing that everything you encounter is, in its essence, a manifestation of the one divine reality? The Gita teaches that the Lord pervades all things—not as a poetic metaphor, but as literal truth.

Notice where you draw lines between sacred and secular in your life. What would happen if those lines dissolved?

snippets.title: Day 101: The Material World
snippets.sanskrit:
चतुर्विधा भजन्ते मां जनाः सुकृतिनोऽर्जुन |

तेषां ज्ञानी नित्ययुक्त एकभक्तिर्विशिष्यते |

उदाराः सर्व एवैते ज्ञानी त्वात्मैव मे मतम् |
snippets.transliteration:
caturvidhā bhajante māṃ janāḥ sukṛtino.arjuna .

teṣāṃ jñānī nityayukta ekabhaktirviśiṣyate .

udārāḥ sarva evaite jñānī tvātmaiva me matam .
verseTranslations: O Arjuna! The righteous who worship Me are grouped by stages: first, they who suffer, next they who desire knowledge, then they who thirst after truth, and lastly they who attain wisdom.

Of all of these, he who has gained wisdom, who meditates on Me without ceasing, devoting himself only to Me, he is the best; for by the wise man I am exceedingly beloved and the wise man, too, is beloved by Me.
Noble-minded are they all, but the wise man I hold as my own Self; for he, remaining always at peace with Me, makes me his final goal.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing chapter seven, Inan Vignan Yoga Yoga of Knowledge and Wisdom. So, as we have discussed in chapter six, we have learned how to meditate. In chapter seven, he is teaching us what to meditate upon. In chapter six, we have learned how to identify with the Supreme Self and detach yourself from the limited self that I consider myself. In chapter seven, Bhagavan is giving us the indications of how to think about the Supreme Being. We have seen his lower and higher nature.

The lower nature is what I can see, perceive, think. In this world is the lower Prakriti. So Bhagavan said, he is all pervading and anything which I see, I should see his presence in it. Anything which I consider not conducive or conducive is still manifestation of the same underlying reality that this Prakriti has three Gunas, Sattva, Rajasant, Tamas. See, whatever, whichever it is, whatever there is which is Sattvik, Rajasik or Tamasik. Consider that all come from me, the supreme reality.

It is actually my mind which divide this world into three different categories. The world which I see as Sattvik, world which I see as Rajasic, world which I see as Tamasic. That makes me think about positive emotions where I feel happy, I feel that's a Sattvic world. The world which makes me agitated, I consider that world is Rajasik. The world which confuses me is the world is tamasic for me. But once in no matter what world you are identifying with, that is your world and you are in the center of it.

But consider that comes from me. All sense objects in this world, whether they give you Sattvic experience, rajasic experience or Tamasic experience, they all come from me. But I am not in them, they are in me. In other words, there is no indication of supreme reality in them. I cannot find its presence in them in those sense objects. But note that all sense objects are in me.

In other words, without that supreme reality, without my consciousness, I will not be able to detect any of those sense objects. Therefore, all the sense objects in this world are actually in my consciousness. Consider that they are all present because of my presence as your own consciousness. Then Bhagawan explains why we cannot say that. Because all people, all beings in this world are confused by this Maya. As we have discussed, Maya is that which is not, but appears to be.

That the world of sense objects are actually created by my own mind. The impression I have of the world of sense objects is actually my impression only. I will never know what the reality is. When I look up into the sky, I see stars and moon and sun. What I see is my world. What I see, the impression that I see is the representation of this world in my mind.

I will never know what the reality is. So Bhagawan said, consider all that to be me. But you will never be able to cross this illusion that you have created about your world. This knowledge about this underlying reality is lost to me because I'm under the spell of this Maya. I do not see this unity in diversity of the sense objects around me. Because I consider myself to the island by myself.

I am so unique that I'm different than this world. This notion about my uniqueness creates this duality about I and the world. Because that's the my illusion that the Maya's illusion. Knowing fully well through my intellectual appreciation. Then my body, my mind, my intellect are part of this Prakriti. This body is nothing but the food modified.

But I never see my body as food modified. I always see my body as something very unique. Bhagwan said, that's the confusion created by Maya. Tribhi, Gunamaya, Bhavai, Bhi Sarvam, Idam, Jagat Mohitam, the entire Jagat. All, all beings are confused by the three Gunas. But those who have some inkling about this underlying reality, they will pursue that reality.

That's basically I'm worshipping. I'm trying to find out and identify with the supreme self. I have inkling that there is something higher than me and that I am pursuing. So Bhagavan now tells us which type of a person will try to identify with their supreme self. In last verse, which we discussed, he said, who will not be aware of the existence of something greater than his own self? He said, Namam Duskruti, Noamudaha Prapadyanti Naradamaha, Maya Aprudgana, Asuram Bhava Masritaha Those who are under the complete spell of Maya, they will only identify with this ignorance that they have.

This ignorance that I am by myself and the world is a complete different entity. Duskrutina Mudha the people who are not yet evolved to a point to identify themselves with something higher than their limited self. He said they will not be able to understand this and therefore they will take refuge in their own ignorance. In their own ignorance that I am who I am, the world is out there to get me. In contrast to that, Bhagavan said there are people who have evolved from the stage of identifying with their limited self and have recognized that there is an underlying unity in all sense. Objects which I see, they are strung into the same reality.

Obviously, physics tell us the same thing, that in this world there is one underlying energy. And in this world nothing is lost. No matter what incident or which phenomenon is happening, we know that energy in this world remains constant. If you take a gallon of water and boil it to a point which all evaporates, that does not mean that the water is lost. The same amount of energy which was in the water, the mass is now converted into something else. When you add all that up, it will come exactly the same amount.

That's what we learned in high school physics. The Bhagawan said that you in this world there is nothing is really lost or gained. It just changes appearances. And those who have come to the realization that there is an underlying reality, they will pursue identification with that reality. And those people who go on and say that Chatur Vida Bhajante maam janaha sukrutino Arjunah. Contrast with the last verse.

People who are wrong doers, wrongdoers, in essence they are acting in this world with the wrong notion that their own self is the only reality. Charvak darshan, basmi Bhutasha punara gaman kutaha. When this body is burnt, there is no coming back. So this life is the only life. And enjoy as best as you can, no matter what you have to do. Runam kutva ghrutum pibet.

Those are duskritina because they have a very narrow view about who they are. And therefore their actions are also driven by that paradigm. That paradigm that I am by myself and have to make the most out of this life. Bhagavan calls them Maya Prudgana. Their knowledge about their self and their connection with the higher self is lost because of confusion created by Maya. Chatur Vidha Bhajanti Maam Janaha Sukratina Arjunaha Contrast to the people who are good doers, the people who are of good deeds, they pursue me.

They try to identify with me in four different ways. Or you can say the four different types of people who identify with me. Now this can be one person in a four different states of pursuing the supreme reality. Arthaha, Jignasuhu, Artharthi, Gnani, Chabharatarshapa, Osayno, Bharat clan. There are of four types. One is Arthah with the one who is in distress and looking for help.

But there is a slight distinction people have made in understanding this verse. Bhagavan has called them Sukrutina. Also in the next two verses he will attach the word udara to them. The noble people who who are trying to understand why things are the way they are in this world. So we have seen that people who are working for themselves, all actions are binding to them. Any action which is binding to me is dusk.

Any action which is liberating me is sukruta. So in last words, people were wrongdoers. All their actions were binding. They get more and more deeper into this bondage of their egos. In contrast, these people are so krutina. All their actions are towards liberation from their identification.

So this Aaatha may not be an average person who is in distress is and seeking Bhagavan's help. I'm in trouble and help me. I have back pain, please help me. He's trying to why there is distress in this world, why people are suffering in this world. And he's seeking Lord's help, guidance how to alleviate people from their suffering. So during pandemic time, a person may be very safe in his house and he's in a location where he's not going to get infected.

But just watching people suffering in the world, you may think, oh Lord, why are you not removing all this suffering from this world and help people who are suffering from this pandemic? Bhagavan said, that's the Artha. There is one Bhakta who is pursuing me, is disturbed by the distress, seeking understanding. The next was Jignaso, the Jignasu. He wants to know how this world works, why there is suffering in this world. It may be at my own personal level that when I'm in distress, I'm trying to find out why there is sorrow in my life.

What is it that I'm not doing right, which makes me sorrowful. But at a greater level, the Bhakta is trying to understand why there is sorrow, why people are suffering in this world is trying to find the answer. Bhagavan Buddha he was not upset about his own situation. He was well protected in the palace, but he saw the suffering outside. He said, I need to find the cause for this suffering. Bhagawan said, that's a jignasu.

Then third one Bhagawan said, Artharti, one who is seeking wealth. So we all fall into that category. We do Lakshmi Puja on Diwali Day because I want to make sure the next year will be as good or better than the last year. But this Arthur, is not just for me. But these people are seeking wealth so that they can help others. So these are Arthartic.

They want to create wealth for the betterment of the society so that the sorrows can be eliminated from the society. And the last one is the Gnani who has truly understood the relationship between his limited self and the greater self. Because he understand the relationship between his limited self and the Supreme Self. Bhagavan in the next verse says that he is better. Sachamama Priya out of these four devotees, they are selfless workers. They have gone through first six chapters of Bhagavad Gita, have learned the art of Karma Yoga.

They're working in this world outside for greater good. But still they have questions about why there is suffering, where the suffering is coming from. What can I do to alleviate the suffering? Oh Lord, give enough so everyone can eat and nobody goes hungry. But the Gnani understands that his own limited self is none other than the Supreme Self. The Supreme Self and his own Self are one and the same.

They're connected with each other. And they're only separated by the conditioning Nitya Yukta constantly establishing their knowledge. Then no matter what I see outside, the Self is pervading all throughout this world. Whether people are suffering or people are enjoying, but it is the same reality which is expressing itself. Ek Bhakta Viseshyade is single, pointedly identified with that because there is nothing else that he can identify with. Once he has realized that myself is not different than the Supreme Self.

snippets.title: Day 102: Four Types of Seekers
snippets.sanskrit:
बहूनां जन्मनामन्ते ज्ञानवान्मां प्रपद्यते |

कामैस्तैस्तैर्हृतज्ञानाः प्रपद्यन्तेऽन्यदेवताः |

यो यो यां यां तनुं भक्तः श्रद्धयार्चितुमिच्छति |
snippets.transliteration:
bahūnāṃ janmanāmante jñānavānmāṃ prapadyate .

kāmaistaistairhṛtajñānāḥ prapadyante.anyadevatāḥ .

yo yo yāṃ yāṃ tanuṃ bhaktaḥ śraddhayārcitumicchati .
verseTranslations: After many lives, at last the wise man realises Me as I am. A man so enlightened that he sees God everywhere is very difficult to find.
They in whom wisdom is obscured by one desire or the other, worship the lesser Powers, practising many rites which vary according to their temperaments.
But whatever the form of worship, if the devotee have faith, then upon his faith in that worship do I set My own seal.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing chapter seven, Gnana Vignan Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge and Wisdom. We have seen in Bhagavad Gita so far that Bhagavan taught us Gnana Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge or Path of Knowledge. In chapter two, Sankhya Yoga, we learned that our self is is immortal, imperishable or we consider ourselves to be mortal. So that was the path of Knowledge revealing the nature of the self. Then from chapter three to five we learned Karma Yoga, Path of Action, how we can transform our day to day action into selfless activities and purify our mind and intellect. So the Karma Yoga is to develop equanimity and purification of the mind.

That's Path of Action. And in chapter six, Bhagavan taught us Dhyana Yoga, Yoga of Meditation, how we can shift our mind from identifying with this limited self that I consider myself, this body, this mind, this intellect that I consider to be my own self. In chapter two we learned that the all pervading Self, Almighty, all pervading, omniscient, ever existing Self which is of the nature of Satchit and Ananda, is nothing but my own self as the universal Self. What I consider myself right now is the conditioned consciousness. That same consciousness were conditioned by this conditionings I call body, mind and intellect. So we learned how to shift this identification from this limited self to the Higher self through Dhyana Yuga Yoga of Meditation, focusing my mind on that supreme Self.

At the end of chapter six, Bhagavan made a declaration that Yogi, one who has tuned his mind to the Supreme Self, in other words, one who has shifted his identification from this limited self to the Higher Self, is greater than Tapasvi, one who is practicing austerities. He is also greater than jñānī, one who has acquired knowledge about the supreme through the study of Scriptures, Vedas and Upanishads and all other scriptures. And finally, Bhagavan says he is greater than Karmi, the one who is acting in this world. And he only thinks that doing good is good enough. The Bhagavan clarified that doing good is not good enough. You have to have this clear understanding that myself is not this limited self.

But the limited self is nothing but the expression of the Supreme Self. The three paths which are described in our system, those of Karma Yoga, Gnana Yoga and Bhakti Yoga, they need to be practiced serially. Therefore, the Gita starts with Karma Yoga. Now in chapter seven, Bhagavan is instructing us how to practice Path of Bhakti, the path of devotion. But before I can start practicing Bhakti Yoga, I have to develop that identification with that supreme Self. Without knowing that supreme Self, I will not be able to focus my limited mind, which is right now fully identified with this limited self, onto that supreme self which is limitless.

So Bhagavan in the opening of this chapter gives Arjuna assurance that I will teach you. I will tell you how to do that. Bhagavan opens the chapter by saying Yogam Injan Mat Asraya, tune your mind to me. My mind right now is fully tuned with this body. Identify the limited self. That mind has to now identify with the Supreme Self.

He said, once you do that, you will come to know me. And then he also assured us that he will teach us both the knowledge and its application. I will tell you the Gnanam, the Knowledge and Vignana Visishta Gnanam, its application in your life without leaving anything behind. Having known that, you will not have to know anything else. In other words, having known myself in its true nature, there will not be any need for me to achieve, accomplish or acquire to find that ultimate happiness, that happiness which I'm seeking, which has no limitation. I do not want to be unhappy at any given time.

If you ask me when do you want to be happy? It is not okay for me to be happy during the weekdays, but unhappy during weekends. I want to be happy all seven days of the week and 365 days of the year. Bhagwan says, having known that knowledge that yourself is not the limited self, you shall achieve that ultimate happiness. Why people are not achieving this knowledge? He said, manushyanam, out of three thousands of human beings on this planet, someone will try to achieve this perfection.

We can now say billions of people out of billions of people. Very few will try this method of achieving perfect happiness by identifying with that Supreme. And he says, those who are striving, there are very few are striving. Out of billions of people, maybe few hundred or few dozens are Trying this. And he says out of them, yata, tamashcha, Siddhanam, kaschimat, Mam, viddhi, tattvatah and even those who are striving sincerely. Only very few will achieve this perfection.

So this almost looks like Bhagavan is discouraging us. But Bhagavan is not discouraging us. Bhagavan is saying that it is an equal opportunity goal. Anyone can achieve this goal if they try in an appropriate manner. So Bhagavan then describes the people who are striving to achieve identification with the Supreme Self. He calls them my devotees, my Bhakti.

And he classifies those devotees into four categories. In general, he divided the entire human race into two categories. One, those who are striving for perfection. Those who are not striving for perfection. Those who are striving for perfection are trying to develop some kind of relationship with the Supreme. Others are simply considering that this world is where I can find my happiness.

I work outside, I go and acquire things, I go and accomplish things and that will give me happiness. A group of people who are not even trying to develop any relationship with the Supreme. He called them Duskritina does not mean they are evildoers. But they are working towards their happiness in a wrong way which will guarantee their failure. He defines the other group as Sukrutina, those people of good deeds. He says they are my devotees.

But they fall into four different categories. Therefore not all of them are going to achieve perfection. The first one is artharthi. One who is identifying or reaching out to the Supreme. Developing some relationship with him due to distress that there is sorrow in his life or her life or there is sorrow just all around Him. And therefore he wants to know how invoking the God's grace will alleviate that sorrow.

We'll only invoke his grace when we feel helpless. I know I can solve my problem. It's only when we feel helpless. Then we'll seek help from the Higher self. They are my devotees, but they have limited relationship. They only seek my help when they feel helpless.

It's like my son when he was in college. He will only call me when he really needs something. Otherwise he is happy doing whatever he was doing. Then we have to call him and say Bhai, you didn't call us all throughout the month. But when he needs something he will suddenly remember that my parents are there to take care of me. Let me call my dad and the dad send me some more money.

So that relationship is still of a Son and a father. My Father in heaven will take care of me when I really need him. The other one is jignasu. One who is curious about the nature of the Supreme. All the scientists actually fall in that category. Because they're trying to find that God equation.

That equation which will reveal what is the nature of the Creator who created this universe. So that's out of the curiosity to know the nature of the self, nature of the supreme, nature of the ultimate reality. They are developing relationship with him. Then the third Bhagavan says, artharthi, the entire wealth on this planet or in this universe is created by the Supreme Being. And therefore he is the owner. So when I need wealth to support myself, to support my family, to support my community, support my nation, I seek his health.

On our dollar bill it says, in God we trust. And I'm seeking this wealth. So that Bhakta is an Artharti. And the last one, he said, is jñānī. One who has developed this relationship with the supreme by understanding the real nature of the Supreme. Shifting his identification from the limited self to the higher self.

That the higher self is my true self. This limited self is just the reflection of that self. So Bhagavan said that jñānī is the one who is closest to me. So Bhagavan said, Udaraha Sarvaeve tatra Gnanitvam Eva Mehmatam. All my devotees are noble people. They're people who are doing good deeds.

They are on a right path. I may start developing relationship with Bhagavan because I feel distressed. But eventually I will progress in the path where I'll understand his true nature. It's like we know somebody. Just by knowing a little bit about that person, we start liking him more. Closer we come to that person, we will know that person more in detail.

Then ultimately we'll know that person almost in totality. So Bhagawan said, all these devotees of mine are noble people. However, jñānī I consider to be my own self. He is no different than me. Asthita Sahiyuktaatma Mama Eva Anuttamam Gatim. By establishing steadfastly his mind in me, he comes to me.

But then he says something which discourages many of us. bahūnām janmanām ante jñānavān māmprapadyate Vasudevah sarvam iti samātmā sudurlabhā. But this jñānī has not become jñānī overnight. After going through this journey of knowing the Supreme Self for many, many, many lives. He comes to understand the nature of the Supreme. And he realizes that there is nothing in this universe.

There is nothing in this prakṛiti which is other than Vasudeva. Vasudeva, the supreme, all pervading Self. So Bhagavan said, I told you in the beginning that the prakṛiti is my lower nature. The prakṛiti is my manifest nature which one can experience through senses. I can see, I can touch, I can feel. But other than this manifest nature of mind, there is higher nature which is unmanifest which you to experience.

And then only you will come to know. So after many, many births of trying to seek unity in this diversity. Such a jñānī, such a person achieves that understanding that there is nothing but that supreme self is everywhere. Sab Mahatma sudurlabhā. Such a great soul is very rare to find. So we come to the conclusion that this is not something which I can achieve.

But come to think of it, there's nothing in this life we achieve in any other way. We have to start somewhere and then gradually make progress one step at a time. We have learned that in elementary school somebody asked me, what do you want to become? I want to become a doctor. It does not make you become doctor the next day. It took you a long time.

From elementary school to secondary school to high school to college, then medical school, then internship. All that effort you put for many, many, many years. And then you achieved this status as doctor. Such and such people recognize you as doctor. You practice your art of medicine. All that is only possible because of the journey you started from your kindergarten which ended into your internship in some hospital.

Bhagavan says bahūnām janmanāmante, the jñānī which you see today. As a knowledgeable person. He did not achieve the knowledge overnight. He put his efforts into it. So Bhagawan is encouraging us. No matter where we are in our journey, we keep making progress one step at a time.

But then the caution here is we may get distracted.

snippets.title: Day 103: The Deluded
snippets.sanskrit:
स तया श्रद्धया युक्तस्तस्याराधनमीहते |

अन्तवत्तु फलं तेषां तद्भवत्यल्पमेधसाम् |

अव्यक्तं व्यक्तिमापन्नं मन्यन्ते मामबुद्धयः |
snippets.transliteration:
sa tayā śraddhayā yuktastasyārādhanamīhate .

antavattu phalaṃ teṣāṃ tadbhavatyalpamedhasām .

avyaktaṃ vyaktimāpannaṃ manyante māmabuddhayaḥ .
verseTranslations: If he worships one form alone with real faith, then shall his desires be fulfilled through that only; for thus have I ordained.
The fruit that comes to men of limited insight is, after all, finite. They who worship the Lower Powers attain them; but those who worship Me come unto Me alone.
The ignorant think of Me, who am the Unmanifested Spirit, as if I were really in human form. They do not understand that My Superior Nature is changeless and most excellent.
snippets.commentary:
Unlike a car with its user's manual, we are born without instructions how to live. We experience life vicissitudes without a so called user's manual. The Gita has been described as such a guide. We have been discussing chapter seven, the Knowledge and Wisdom. And we have seen that Bhagavan said that consciously or unconsciously, we are all seeking the Lord. We are all seeking who we are, where we came from.

But some of us seek unconsciously and some of us seek consciously. Those who feel unconsciously, obviously they do not know where the answer is. Those who say consciously, they are worshipping the Lord, that which makes the source of my being. And we have seen they can be classified in four out of this four. The Gnani is so firm in his conviction that his self is something other than this limited self. We need to find out what that is.

But the journey from the ignorance about the self to the self takes its own efforts. Bahunam Janmanam ante Gnanavaan Maamrapadhyate. After many years of sincere seeking the Gnani who is sincerely seeking his own self, he finds the truth. And then he comes to the conclusion that Vasudha Deva Sarvamiti there is nothing other than the reality. Supreme reality exists. There is no world and there is no I.

All that exists is Vasudevas. Anything that I see, touch, feel, perceive is nothing but that one supreme reality alone. But he said, why we don't all fail? Because Kamehi taihi taihi rhtagna. Because of this desire and that desire, that knowledge which is inherently ours, we feel who we are, but that is taken away from us by this desire or that desire. And therefore now we seek the fulfiller of that desire.

Who do I go and meet and say hello to him in a party? One who I think is going to be the most beneficial to me. Networking parties, I'm talking about, that's where we go. Somebody may be coming very Lovingly and say Neil, I said no, no, no, not right now. I need to go and talk to that guy because that's what I think my benefits are. I need to talk to them.

Even in a social party, somebody whom we think is most important, we go and say hello to him first. See, with that desire and this desire our sense of who we are is looted away. And then we seek that fulfiller of that desire. That's the Devata who we consider the fulfill. Our divine desire is the Devata. We worship those Devata.

And Bhagavan says whatever your desire and whoever your Devata eventually comes from me alone. So Bhagavan said that whatever you have faith in that, that entity, that source will fulfill my desire. I make your faith even firmer. Because where does the faith come? Faith come from my own attachment and understanding, my own consciousness, my own thinking is only possible because this supreme functions through me as consciousness. Same consciousness which allows me to think makes me think over and over again in the same line of thinking.

And it makes my faith firmer and firmer. More I think in that line. So I say only science can give me the answer. More I indulge into that thought. More my faith become firmer. All these people are nonsense.

All these sadhus and Swamis. Swamiji himself said that's how he started. These guys are just bluffing away their way. So more and more we think in the same line. The same faith becomes firmer by our own consciousness. Bhagawan says, I make their fame firm.

And then I said more. They, you know, worship that Devta. They fulfill that desire sincerely. Whenever I apply myself in whatever field, the success comes from that field. Sister Bhagavan said, wherever you with your faith apply yourself. Your desires will be fulfilled.

However, he said all that comes from me alone. Sataya Srdhaya, Yuktah Tasya Aradhanam Ihate Lavatecha Tathah Kaman Maya Eva Vithaan Hitan. No matter where you think this prophet came to you, where you think this success came to you. No matter who you think helped you, Bhagavan said that was your faith that would make you think that it came from this. However, because I am the all pervading Lord. Everything that is coming to you from these different Devatas are coming from me alone.

I am the only source. Those who are in business, you have several different accounts and LLCs. And then you transfer this money from that and that money from that. Eventually whose money that is your. Anytime we go out and do something. And Mina said, so how are you going to pay for this thing?

I said, oh, that's for nbjs. She thinks the money coming from nbj who is paying the rent here. Then I don't have to worry about it. As long as you don't think this is coming from me. But eventually it all comes from me, right? But I feel at the time that it didn't come from the Lord.

It came from this Devta, this source. Bhagavan says all the sources eventually merges into me. verseTranslations: I am not visible to all, for I am enveloped by the illusion of Phenomenon. This deluded world does not know Me as the Unborn and the Imperishable.

snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter seven, Gnana Vignana Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge and Wisdom. Knowledge about the Supreme Self, contemplating on which we can get the wisdom. So in this chapter we have seen from verses 4 through 7, Bhagavan gave a thumbnail sketch of who the Lord is, what to meditate upon. So first thing he said is, my manifest Prakriti is Eightfold, which is available to you for perception through your senses, which includes everything that we can think of, everything we can see, everything we can touch, everything we can feel, and everything we can think. So all body, mind and intellect experiences the all three worlds of our body, mind and intellect are part of his manifested Prakriti. But then he said that other than this is my Higher Prakriti.

In other words, that which is not available to you for cognition through your senses. Therefore it's called unmanifest because not available to us. Thinking through my mind, thinking through my intellect, or perceiving through my senses, it's not available. And therefore I say that's a higher Prakriti. Lower is which I can interact with. Higher I cannot perceive.

But that higher is the basis of all the manifest manifestation, without which the world which you and I know will not exist. If I'm not conscious about my world, does the world exist? It only exists because I'm aware of it. The known only exists when the Knower is there. So because the Knower is there, the world of known things and beings exist. So therefore Bhagavan said, my Higher Prakriti is the one which is stringing all these manifestations together.

What you perceive, what I perceive, what he perceives, what she perceives. When you put all perception together, it is a world of our beings. That's my real nature. So we have seen from verse 4 through 7 the identity of the Lord, the Supreme, the our Self and how to contemplate on it. And then we have seen. Bhagavan said that you can perceive that through anything, which is the essence of anything.

Brilliance in brilliant Swamiji used to say I am kick in whiskey. What is whiskey if there is no kick in it? It may look like whiskey, it may taste like whiskey. But if there is no cake in it, it's not a whiskey. That which makes thing and beings what it is, is who I am for one. Then he said that the people who have no discriminating intellect to pursue this will never pursue this, never would like to think about it.

But there are people who who are pursuing to understand the very nature of the self and to get over their limitations. We have seen there are four types of devotees. Arthaha, Jyugnasu, Vartarthi and Gnani. The Gnani is very close to me. He has come close to understanding, realizing what the self is all about. To Arjuna, therefore become a Gnani.

Therefore pursue the path of knowledge which makes you realize who you are. And then he also said that in our delusion we sometimes think that the unmanifested come to manifest. See, Unmanifest never manifest. But we feel it has manifested. Bhagavan Vedvyas make this point very clear here. Because we have all this fighting about different religions.

Because we say that our Bhagavan has manifested as Krishna. Yours manifested is Christ, but mine is greater than yours. Because the very first ignorance about unmanifest comes into manifest. Unmanifest will never come into manifestation who has not used his intellect. Every religion says God is omnipresent. God is omniscient, God is omnipotent.

Then how can your God be different than mine? If my God is omnipresent, there is no room for other God in me. Knowing which we will be fighting about. My God is greater than yours. Because Buddh Dayaha without using my intellect, I think that the God which is unmanifest come into manifestation as incarnation, as a prophet, as a sage. Param Bhavam Ajanantah.

They are not aware of my real nature. My real nature is Avyayayam immutable. That Bhagavan who created this world out of his own self because he has no other material available to him. Did he ever mutated into this world? He never mutated into this world. Therefore he said, one who does not know by nature is immutable.

He is the only one who is fighting about it. There is nothing higher than that. There is nothing beyond his existence. If you Take him out, nothing remains. If you put everything together, then nothing but him alone. But see, that's not available to all of us.

To perceive my own self is what I'm trying to understand. How can it be that difficult? It is difficult because Na aham Prakasaha Sarvasya Yogamaya samabrtaha. I am not available to awe because my real nature is veiled by the Yoga Maya. This Yoga Maya which creates this world of plurality out of these three gunas confuses so we can't see his real nature. Muda ayam na abhijanati Loko Maam Ajam avyam.

Deluded by that Yoga Maya, I do not recognize its very nature which is unborn and immutable. That for our whole problem starts with our sorrows and limitations. So this Yoga Maya is the power with which he created this universe. This perception of plurality is because of this Yoga Maya. It is something like when I'm dreaming out of my own mental power, I create my own world and delude myself. I create my own world, but I remain I the waker remains immutable in that dream I remain unchanged.

I remain ajaha in my dream. I never take birth as Bill Gates, but I feel like in my dream that I'm Bill Gates. So he said that is not available to all. Nobody will ever know it. It's not a statement which is to discourage us. It is a statement for us to contemplate on it.

So he said it is available to those who contemplate in my real nature and cross over. This Maya sees beyond this, therefore the word divyadraste. I have one perspective about this world right now. And then I can change my perspective when I get a greater knowledge. Before I came to Richmond, I had one perspective. I thought, oh, Richmond is a very conservative southern town.

So it's an old boy network type of a town. It almost seemed like so far away in south from Washington D.C. where I used to live, it's only 100 miles. It becomes more encompassing. So Bhagavan said that one who does not have this perspective, he will not know my nature. Therefore, we will need a Divya Drasthi to see his real nature. His nature in totality so he said muda. Mudha means the one who has not yet developed that perspective. How to see the totality of the Lord's nature.

Therefore we have Learned from verse 4 through 7 How to see him in his totality. That there is nothing which is separate from each other. We are not islands by ourselves. We are connected to each other in a way that we will never be able to separate ourselves from each other. You can't have this class without any one of you. We will need all of you, including myself, to have this class.

But if I miss that perspective, I am a mudhaha. I think a father cannot be father without a son or a daughter. A daughter cannot be daughter without father and mother. This interdependence we have right from our birth in this world is what we miss is our ego. Then we become I am a self made man. You couldn't even breathe on your own.

So Bhagavan said, Veda aham. Atitani vartamanani cha Arjuna Bhavishyani chabhutani. I know all the beings of past, present and future. But Mam tu vedana kastyana but no one knows me. It's a real hide and seek game. One who is at the top, but with a greater perspective.

He sees everything, but we can see him. So Swamiji elaborates on it that why he knows everyone. From a building's perspective, I only know the conditioned space. Therefore I think I'm limited. I have birth, I have death. I don't know what is the real nature of the space. I think the nature of the space is the room. So all of us, as soon as we take this identification, we forget the real nature of ourselves and take the identification of the conditioning.

But from the consciousness perspective. Consciousness is the same consciousness in me as in you, as in him as was in my father, my grandfather, my ancestors, probably 5,000 years ago, same consciousness. Therefore, from a consciousness perspective, the consciousness knew all the beings in the past, all the beings in present and all the beings in future. Because it never changed it remained what it is, the being, the conditioning came and went and will come and go. But the inherent ingredient, the entity which makes it possible remains same. So we know God is omnipresent.

We none of us somehow not do doubt it. Thing that is omnipresent is by very nature becomes omniscient. If I am all pervading in this chair, I know everything about this space. So Bhagavan is omnipresent and therefore he is omniscient. But from a narrow perspective, if I try to understand Bhagavan, it will never be possible. Therefore he says, Mam tu vedana kastana.

Because we try to personify him in a limited entity. Therefore North Indian Rama looks like a North Indian and South Indian Rama looks like South Indian. We personify him, the artist from North. When he paints it, he paints it in his imagination. We see Bhagavan in our imagination. So we put all our conditioning on him.

Therefore Bhagavan says, no one knows me. We have to cross over these limitations of our mind and intellect. Therefore it's called transcendental meditation. Icha Dwesa, Samuthena, Dvandwa, Mohena, Bharada. What is it that creating this confusion? Iccha and Dwesha, the likes and dislikes.

Sarvabhutani, Sammoham, Sargay, Yanti, Parantabha. All the beings are deluded from very birth what that being likes or dislikes. Right from the birth, the little baby knows what is comfortable and what is not comfortable. As soon as there is something not comfortable, diaper is wet, it starts crying. Because it has taken that conditioning. And per our scriptures, that baby has taken conditioning.

Because of past vasanas, that body is taken. I take this particular state of existence. That's what I wanted to achieve. That's what I want to experience. He said, why do I go to concert and not go to the boxing wrestling matches? That's what I want to experience, you know.

That's why I go to the concerts, not to wrestling matches. One who goes to wrestling matches, you tell him to go to opera, no? So he said, you have taken upon your conditioning which you like. Now you are going to divide your world into the world which I like, the world which I don't like. World of my physical existence. World of my emotions involved with my thinking.

snippets.commentary:
Unlike a car with its user's manual, we are born without instructions how to live. We experience life vicissitudes without a so called user's manual. The Gita has been described as such a guide. Just to remind us that the Bhagavad Gita divided in three segments six chapters. The first segment we learned all about ourselves. Second chapter did tell us about the summary of who we are.

What we remember from second chapter is the self is immutable, imperishable. The myself, which I considered me, is immutable, imperishable. But we never made a connection of what that really means. So we saw the characteristics of a Gnani, but that didn't give us any different than what we do. So the next few chapters gave us how to analyze our actions and our self and then recalibrates our actions become more productive and more effective. And that segment ended with the last chapter, meditation. Meditation is the means given to us to recalibrate this instrument called mind, body and intellect. Then this next segment of this six chapters from 7 to 12 you learned is all about what is that imperishable shelf which we talked about in chapter two. So that's where the way the first chapter of this segment, chapter seven, which is Gnana Vignana Yoga, that we want to have this knowledge about the Lord or that immutable self we Learned in chapter 2.

But how can we make it a Visishtagnana that we can apply it? And Therefore the Chapter 7 in detail describe the Lord's nature and why we can't realize that in our day to day life. So we saw in the first Bhagavan said that I manifest in this world as the Eightfold Prakriti. That's something which you and I can see where one says, that's Nothing but my own manifestation. Then he says, there is nothing in this world which does not come out of me. Anything that you can see, feel, touch and perceive has came out of me and will dissolve in me.

And all this world of plurality as we see, is strung to each other. Nothing is independent, like an island in this universe which is hinting at us that we think we are the island of the universe as me and everything else is revolving around me. He said, no, Everything is strung in a necklace. Pearls are strung into a necklace. And I am that common thread. I pervade through this universe as the Eightfold Prakriti.

And you are part of that Prakriti, and I am this. The unmanifest is the common thread among all the manifestations which apparently looks different from each other. They say, why then we are not seeing that? They say, because you are under the spell of my divine Maya, my Maya, which creates this plurality out of singularity. As long as you are under the spell of that, you see yourself different than this world. So we defined that this Maya has these three gunas, or how the Maya create this plurality of infinite varieties of things and beings is because there's three basic gunas, the qualities of Maya, sattvarajas and tamas.

The permutation combination of these three gunas create myriads of forms and myriads of colors, myriads of shapes, sounds. But as long as I can't overcome that Maya, you can't see it in the last we have seen that. Iccha dwesha, samutena, dhvandvamohena bharat. Because of this desire, or that desire because of, I have divided this world into two. The world I like and the world I don't like. Right from the birth, I'm deluded about myself.

That immutable, imperishable self talked about in chapter two. I'm not recognizing yet because of only my duality, my concept of duality created by my mind. My mind says, this is me and everything else is the world. As long as I can get out of that concept, out of my mind, Bhagavan said, you won't be able to realize this thing. However, he says in the last three verses, said that those Gnanis who have erased this wrong notion of who I am and their papas are all erased by this new line of thinking. I said, esham tu antagatam papam jananam punya karmana.

So there is a hope, you know, the Bhagavan said that this is not just a. A philosophical discussion. Then Look, I'M telling you, you will never realize it. Let's figure out what was the problem in the beginning. The problem was my wrong line of thinking that I am different than this world created. This notion that I am this limited being and therefore I have all these problems or whatever.

The limitation I consider as prabhupada. Once I undo that thinking that I am this limited being that will be gone. So he said, esham tu antagatam papam. Those whose papas have come to an end. And now the classic definition of papa is that sin is a thought or an impression which takes me away from myself, takes me away from my understanding of that I am that immutable, imperishable self and creates this division between I and the world through the papa. As long as I am driven by the desires of the flesh, then my thinking would be to how to fulfill that desire.

When I start thinking and if I continue thinking in the same line of thinking, it creates the deep channels in my mind which now guide this second thought into the same channel. This habit of following the same line of thinking to fulfill the desires creates papa. Because I just can get out of that line of thinking that this will make me happy. Last time I had a cup of coffee and made me happy. This time it should do the same thing and I continue to do that. Bhagavan said that creates his own notion of who you are.

How do I come out of it? He said more and more I become the introvert by the technique given to me in the previous chapter. The meditation that no, this is not me. The one who is getting happy with the Starbucks coffee is not me, is someone other than myself. He said that line of thinking erases those channels which were created by my attempt to satisfy all the desires that my body and mind and intellect has created. More I fulfill my desire, new experiences I get that creates new channels of thinking and that creates new vasanas.

This vasana, the tendencies creates more the same line of thinking and create the same line of actions. I need to get out of doing actions in the same line of thinking which is not giving me happiness. Even though I figured out the last time I invested money in stock market was not good. But because everybody says, don't miss this cycle, I'm back again. You need to get out of that line of thinking by one side. Once you start meditating on what really makes me happy, if I analyze my experience, is that the experience which made me happy or something else made me happy, you come to the conclusion it is that no desire makes me happy when I'm completely at ease.

That I don't want anything, I've already eaten my lunch and I don't have anywhere to go and I can just sit down in front of TV or that at least I still have just a desire to watch TV but even if I drop that I probably will be completely happy. Once in the line of thinking creates undoing of all these wrong channels created in my mind. So now I have removed all the papas. Papas are just the wrong line of thinking. Wrong line of vasanas sid eam tu amtagatam papam jananam Punya karmanam Method obviously we have learned in the first six chapter is Karma Yoga selfless actions. I also realize actually the real happiness I got when I did something for others that the true happiness we get when you do something for our children, something for our parents, something for our relatives, something our friends that really gives you happiness. Janana and Punya Karmana they have changed their line of actions therefore they change the line of their thinking therefore they change the line of their tendencies. And now they are in a completely different realm of actions, completely different realm of thinking that their papas are all erased and said te dwanva mohanermukta so now they are out of this duality that I'm not just working for me, I'm working for the whole humanity, the whole my town, whole my family. I keep expanding my identity. So there is one point, there is no duality between I and the world. Te dvandvam mohanir mukta this dwandva is nothing but a delusion that you and I are different from each other.

That this world and I are two different entities is nothing but a delusion. He said those who by acting in a right manner erase those line of thinking which creates delusion. And now bhajante maam drabhrataha worshiping, worshipping we have seen is an act of love that the love for the divine becomes so firm that I am firmly established in the thought that I and the world are nothing but part of the same all pervading entity. The next verse says Jara marana mokshaya and why I am doing all of this? Because the two things I'm afraid of in life are jara old age and mara. We had a party yesterday, somebody had Valentine day party and you know what was the topic because we are all probably above 50 there.

How do we get out of this problem of when you are dying? You know, the 10 tubes going through you because we are afraid of Jarrah old age. I will not be in my control. You know, I was reading time about Ronald Reagan when he was taking a walk and people say good morning Mr. President. He wouldn't recognize why people are calling me president or he didn't know that he was a president. He said this guy is nice that he's greeting me.

That's all he can think now. The thought that if a person reaches that level and then reaches to a point where he can even recognize who he is is pretty scary for all of us. Because all of our life we took pride in what I'm in control. I take care of myself. I take care of my family. I take care of my business.

I take care of my that I take care. I am in charge makes me who I am. Very thought that I will not be in control is very, very disturbing to us. We want to get out of that. I want to exist and the death wipes me out. It just doesn't seem right.

Jara Marana Mokshaya for the liberation from this thought of old age and death. Maam Asritya Taking complete refuge in me means not Lord Krishna or Rama or Jesus in that immutable self. Taking complete refuge in identification with my immutable self. Just as I'm in a complete control in a barber's chair I'm sitting in a barber's chair. The hair which I let go and the hair which I keep, I'm in complete control. The hair which I let go I don't get attached and swelled.

Please, please pack it up for me. I say wipe it out clean as quickly as possible.
