verseTranslations: The worlds, with the whole realm of creation, come and go; but, O Arjuna, whoso comes to Me, for him there is nor rebirth.
Those who understand the cosmic day and cosmic night know that one day of creation is a thousand cycles, and that the night is of equal length.
At the dawning of that day all objects in manifestation stream forth from the Unmanifest, and when evening falls they are dissolved into It again.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 8, Akshara Brahma Yoga Yoga of Imperishable Brahman this world which I live in has things and beings. Things have their production date or a date of creation and will also have a date of destruction. And the beings have their birth dates and also they will have their death dates. Then nothing in this world remains permanently. Everything is perishable, exists for a limited period in both time and space. But this ever changing reality which I experience as the world cannot exist unless there is an imperishable substratum.

And Bhagavan said in this chapter that Brahman is that imperishable reality. Brahman is the truth which makes all other relative truths possible. For example, I can say this room exists. That's a statement of truth. But it only exists because the another universal truth exists. That is the room space existed before this room was built.

It is right now here as room space and will remain space when this room will be destroyed. So based on that universal reality which I call space, the relative reality, what I call room space can exist. Bhagavan says the Brahman in a similar way exists. As Bhagawan Shankaracharya says, the principle that graces all bodies is their essential self. Any being will not be aware of his own self unless that principle, imperishable immortal principle is residing in that body. With that consciousness I become aware of my conditioning which I call my body, mind and intellect.

And then I'm aware of myself. So it is the self knowing reality which is the very nature of Brahman which makes me aware of myself as that conditioned self. Right now I'm not aware of my supreme self that is imperishable, deathless and birthless. But I'm aware of myself as this limited body, limited mind, limited intellect, as Nil Bhatt because of that consciousness which is functioning through me. So the Bhagavan says that that consciousness which is now making you aware of your own limitations and also making you aware of the existence of this world of Perishable nature. And as long as I am conditioned and identified by this body, mind and intellect, I will have all the limitations of this body, mind and intellect.

And therefore the sorrows, therefore unhappiness. And therefore I feel bound by these limitations. My goal is to liberate myself from my limitations, my unhappiness, my sorrows and attain a state of bliss where there never will be any sorrow, never will be any limitations and never will be any unhappiness. Bhagavan said, that can only happen when you identify with me, the imperishable and not the one who is conditioned by your body, mind and intellect. As long as I remain aware of the limitations of the room, I will be only seeing the space as the room space. If I want to see this space as immortal.

If I never want to get this space destroyed, I'll be always afraid of what happens if someone destroys this building. If earthquake happens or a meteor falls on my property, well, it will be destroyed. Is the room space getting destroyed? But right now I'm more identified with the conditioning than the space itself. And therefore that fear of destruction. If my identification was not with the conditioning, just the space.

This is my land and this is my space. And I want to own this thing forever. But once it's possible, nothing can destroy the space which you're owning. Only thing that can destroy whatever you have built on that land, on that space, the space will never be destroyed. But as long as my identification with that building, on that land, I'll be afraid. When my identification is beyond that, then I will not be afraid of the destruction of the building.

So Bhagavan said, one who identifies with me, he will come to attain me. Antakale chamameva kalevaram ya prayasi prayati sasad madh bhavam yati na asti tatra sansayah. There is no doubt that one who gives up this identification with this body, mind and intellect while leaving this identification as the death and thinking about me alone will come to me. There is no doubt about that. So the advice we have seen so far, it says, therefore, tasmat sarveshu kale sumamanusmaryudyyacha. Therefore engage in this battle of life constantly remembering me as your true self.

Not this conditioned self as your true self, but me, the imperishable, who is making it possible for you to function. Fight this battle of life with that in mind. And thou shall be liberated from these limitations. And you will come to be one with me once you become one with me. After that there is no coming and going again. Maam upetya punar janma du kalayam asasvatam na apnuvanti.

Having attained me, there is no coming and going back to this house of pain we call this world. But now Bhagavan says, in a stark contrast to the ones who have identified with me and one who has become one with me. If you're striving to achieve that liberation but haven't reached that prerequisite qualification, then you will constantly come back and forth. So the next verse 16 says, Abhram ponat lokah punara vartinau Arjuna Mam upetyatu kamteya punarjan manna vidya the world up to the world of Brahmaji, Brahmaloga aa Brahma Bhuvan lokad up to the world of Brahmaji. They are subject to birth and rebirth. Punara vartina Constantly coming again and again, coming back to the same thing.

One who reaches me, there is no rebirth for him. So what does that mean, reaching up to the world of Brahmaji? Brahmaji is the creator. As we know in our Hindu Trinity, Brahma is the creator, Vishnu is the sustainer and Shiva is the destroyer. This creative destruction is constantly going on in this world. Brahma is the ultimate creator of this entire universe.

So in our concept of Hiranyagarbha in Vedanta, it is the ultimate creator. It is the total mind and total intellectual. I am a creator of my own world. You are a creator of your world and she is the creator of her world. We create our world through our mind and intellect depending on our desires and vasanas. Now if I take this group and say one, we individually we have our vasanas and desire, but we also have a group vasanas and desires.

So we'll say, well, when are we going to have the Janmastami next? So everybody will say, well, I would like to have it on such and such and let's do this and let's do that. These common thoughts put together what we call it a planning, a group planning will have group activity. So that's a mind which is expanded from my mind to a group's mind. You can continue to expand this mind and intellect, including more and more people and beings into it. When you reach the ultimate limit of all the beings and and things, all the minds and intellects put together is Brahmaji Brahma the creator.

When my identification rises from me to My family, to my neighborhood, to my community. I'm expanding my identity and including them as my own self. So I may be making progress in my spiritual evolution in expanding my identity, but until I reach that pre qualifying limit, I still have to come back over and over again. Well, it is something like this. If you are taking any licensing examination, for those of you who are professionals who have to take the licensing exam, you probably know all about it. But I took mine in this country when I came here in 84, and I knew that it was going to be difficult because I have barely come here, no experience in this country, and people have already warned me, going to take you a long time to get this license in this country simply because there were nine parts of exam and you have to clear all nine parts, then you get a license.

So the firm I had joined initially a large firm, and there were at least about a couple of hundred people, at least at any given year, there are about 60 to 80 people taking exams. So they told me that, you take it easy, Neil. You just came to this country, it's going to take you eight to 10 years before you can pass this exam. And I say, what do you mean by that? I don't understand what you're saying. Why should it take so long and say, well, here is how it works.

You'll take the exams and you probably will pass out of nine, maybe two parts, and then you will come back again next year and may pass another couple of parts, then you will come back after next year and may pass one or two. And people who experience this, so they have formulated an average time it takes for somebody to get the license as an architect in this country after graduating from architecture school, it takes about six to eight or eight to 10 years to do that, because till you pass all nine parts, and then if any one subject, if you fail more than three times, you take all nine parts all over again. There are some people I knew who have already given up taking tests for these licensing exams. And I said, well, all you have to do is pass all nine parts and it will be fine. They say, yeah, that sounds easy, but it is not. And that was obviously their perception of this.

So they go, take exam, come back, take exam and come back till you reach a point when 9th part is cleared, then you get a license. And one who reaches the ninth part, he also have to maintain that vigilance that after even passing the nine parts and getting a license, he still have to maintain his continuing education to remain effective as an architect. Well, this is something like this. Bhagavan said that we are all trying our spiritual evolution as seekers. And we reach from the level we are right now to the next level as we make more progress. But at the time of death, if my evolution has not gone up to the level where I can be liberated, well, I'll have to come back, just as I said, with the time of my taking the exams.

If I'm not cleared all nine parts, then I have to come back next year to clear whatever parts are left. Same way, in our spiritual journey, things we have learned and things which are yet to be learned will decide how many times I have to come back. And this is driven by my desires and vasanas. My desire will make me come back to that state, that stage which makes me feel comfortable that I can make progress from here. After I pass my high school graduation, I go to the undergraduate school. I cannot just say that after my high school graduation, just leave me alone now my education is finished.

To get to a doctorate level, I have to make my own efforts. So up to the world of Brahmaji. In the world of Brahmaji, you have the identification with this entire creation. And as Swamiji explains here that in the concept of gradual liberation, Karma Mukti, which is accepted in Vedanta, it basically says that karma with Upasana can lead you to the realm of Brahmaji. If you do your karma diligently with devotion to the Lord, you will reach a state of identification where you will feel the whole world is your own being and you reach the world of Brahmaji. Once reaching that, there is no coming back.

From that, you will just merge into the supreme Brahman.
snippets.reflection:
Consider: If you were to die tonight, what would your final thoughts be? Not to create anxiety, but to clarify priorities. What matters most to you? Are you giving it the attention it deserves?

Practice falling asleep tonight with awareness—watching the transition from waking to sleep as a small rehearsal for the larger letting go. The Gita teaches that our state of consciousness at death is shaped by our entire life. What are you cultivating?

Think about where your mind goes in unguarded moments. This reveals what you truly value, and according to these teachings, points toward your future trajectory.

snippets.title: Day 112: The Two Paths
snippets.sanskrit:
भूतग्रामः स एवायं भूत्वा भूत्वा प्रलीयते |

परस्तस्मात्तु भावोऽन्योऽव्यक्तोऽव्यक्तात्सनातनः |

अव्यक्तोऽक्षर इत्युक्तस्तमाहुः परमां गतिम् |
snippets.transliteration:
bhūtagrāmaḥ sa evāyaṃ bhūtvā bhūtvā pralīyate .

parastasmāttu bhāvo.anyo.avyakto.avyaktātsanātanaḥ .

avyakto.akṣara ityuktastamāhuḥ paramāṃ gatim .
verseTranslations: The same multitude of beings, which have lived on earth so often, all are dissolved as the night of the universe approaches, to issue forth anew when morning breaks. Thus is it ordained.
In truth, therefore, there is the Eternal Unmanifest, which is beyond and above the Unmanifest Spirit of Creation, which is never destroyed when all these being perish.
The wise say that the Unmanifest and Indestructible is the highest goal of all; when once That is reached, there is no return. That is My Blessed Home.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 8, Akshara Brahma Yoga Yoga of Imperishable Brahman as we have seen that we are trying to understand the nature of the supreme reality, so we have to do some heavy lifting here to understand the underlying concepts in this chapter. So in the beginning we have heard from Bhagavan that Brahman is imperishable, immutable, Self knowledge is its nature. So what is the nature of Brahman? It is self knowledge. It does not require any other aid to understand it. So it's self effulgent.

It's very nature is self knowledge. With its creative force, it works to create things and beings. What his work is that which creates these things and beings. That Brahman which is imperishable, its nature is self knowledge. With its own creative force, it works to create things and beings. Then what is nature of the things and beings that Brahman has created?

Brahman is imperishable, but anything that is created by its creative force is perishable. That because the very act of creation gives it a birth date, it's now created. Something is created, therefore it will have its own life. Then it will get destroyed. It will have a limited shelf life as we call it, no matter how long. That is what makes those things and beings function as they are.

Is a Daivam inherently that same Brahman remaining within each created entity? That Daivam makes the thing or being possible as a creation. But out of all this activity, when these things and beings are reacting with each other, it's only possible because Brahman remains present as the Yajnam in all the activities, that Supreme Being is present. Therefore all activities are possible in this world of these created beings. Analogy we have heard before is more like my dream. I as the conscious being have experiences in my waking world.

The same experiences at night gets all jumbled up. My mind creates its own world. Out of my own mind, I create my own world. That mind by itself creates various entities, things and beings in My dream. Those entities are acting in the dream because I am in and through available to project the dream. But when I wake up, all those entities, things and beings are now unmanifest.

Till next time I go to sleep again and dream again. So this is what we have seen is how the overall cosmos is functioning at the level of Brahman. Him remaining supreme, unchangeable with his self knowledge, with his own creative force, he works to create these things and beings. These things and beings, their Gunana Dharma. I studied chemistry in Gujarati because I studied all throughout my school days, in college days in Gujarati medium in chemistry they used to ask us Padarthana Gunadharmanu Varnankara describes the characteristics and nature of this substance. So there are two things every substance has Guna and Dharma.

Guna is the basic characteristics of that substance or a thing or a being. And Dharma is the nature of that substance depending on guna. So what is my Dharma is depending on my gunas. The gunas which I have as an entity creates my Dharma. So Guna and Dharma are related to each other. So Brahman creating things and beings.

Each thing and being has its own Dharma, Guna and Dharma. This Guna and Dharma continues to change as we acquire more impressions. So my guna before I went to architecture school has nothing to do with architecture. In fact, I was not even aware of what architecture is all about. So at that point my Dharma had nothing to do with architectural knowledge or practice. More I acquired the architectural knowledge.

My gunas changed, so my Dharma changed. So now I practice architecture. So Guna Dharma is constantly changing this evolutionary path a thing or being takes in the creation itself. So Bhagavan said that this creation is now guided by its own laws, where each thing and being is driven by their own guna and Dharma. So what will be my next state of existence? The gunas which I am creating through my experiences as practicing architect or the Bhagavad Gita student.

So my next state of existence can only be evolution from a present state. It cannot completely change overnight from where I am today. So that's the evolutionary path each thing and being in the creation takes. So from some stardust, my original evolution started and then that keeps changing. Gunanayana Dharma came to this level where I am today. I read in some one of these popular science books that our atoms in the body continues to change.

They are not the same atoms because our body, the cells change every few years. And they said that it is possible that the atoms which exist in Shakespeare's body or Rama's body or Krishna's body has passed through my body at one point of because there are finite amount of energy, finite amount of matter, all things and beings are created out of that. In the nature of this cosmos is one thing changes into the shape and form of other and continues. So where I am today is the product of my past. From that stardust to who I am today, my future would be the product of my present, present plus my past. So the advice then given to us is that if you want to accelerate this evolution, not go through this gradual path of changing Guna and Dharma, that you can directly relate to the Source which is we have seen the Brahman who is imperishable, immutable, created this universe out of his own creative force that the efficient cause, he's created for the efficient cause to create this own universe.

Material cause was the only thing available to Brahman, which is his own self. He created this universe out of his own self. And each creation has limited life. Creation remains perishable, but the underlying material which creates this universe remains imperishable. So either I can identify with my Guna and a Dharma today and then take a step next forward in the same path of my evolution, or I can short circuit this whole cycle and go straight to my source where I started. So that's the advice in this chapter.

At the time of death, death is the end of this state of existence Is death. Created today, death of today will create tomorrow. At the time of this transition, whatever I think would be my next state of existence, that's what I will become. Bhagawan said, you can focus directly onto the Source and become source up to the Brahma Loka, the world of Brahma, everything has coming and going. Till we are within the realm of this Prakriti which is made up of nothing but the total things and beings in this world. I will be keep recycling from one state of existence to another.

And that we have said how long it will continue. Then we have said is as long as the Brahma is creating and dissolving. So we see our day and night from our day to day activities. Day is the active _part of my life. Night is the inactive _part of my life. Superimposing the same concept on Brahmaji is the total creator.

I am the creator of my world. You are the creator of your world. She is the creator of her world. When you put all things and beings together, all the ideas and vasanas and thoughts together create cosmic mind. The cosmic mind has the latency to create this cosmos. And that's called Hiranyagarpa, the golden embryo, which is all the possibilities of creating everything that is in this cosmos that continues to be go in the cycles of activity and inactivity.

When Brahma is actively creating, it's his day. When he takes rest and is inactive, it's night for him. Because we superimpose our day and night on my day is activity, my night is inactivity. It's not different now with nightlife. But in 5,000 years ago they probably didn't have night life. What is Brahma's day?

Brahma's day is thousand eons. So for thousand eons this activity of creation continues. Things changing from one thing to another to another. And then Brahmaji takes rest. All the things which he has created now goes into dormant state. Not get destroyed, gets into dormant state.

Just as I, the architect, goes into dormant state from Friday to Sunday. But that doesn't mean the architect in me has died. Architect in me will wake up on Monday morning and start all over again. So all the ideas and thoughts and vasanas in this total mind goes into hibernation in dormant state. He said, how long that lasts? Another thousand year.

So we did some calculation the other day and said it's 4.316 million years is one year. So thousand of these 4.31 billion years and you take two of them day and night. That 8.6 something billion years is a one complete cycle. So when you think about your journey, this is, this is what is continue from day to night, day and night. It will continue from one state of existence to another, one state of existence to another. And if you think that you as the entity is not really happy about it, then there is escape hatch that is take refuge in me, refuge in me, identify with the source.

Till we reach the state of that Brahmaj's loka, his world, the Creator's world. As long as I'm watching David Copperfield performing magic, it's wonderful to watch and get enchanted by it and then keep thinking, how does he do it? Till one day I show up when he is preparing for his show and say, I want to be your apprentice, sir. And he takes me and then he shows me and then I see how all these magics are done and then all magic is gone. Now I'm not confused. Now he's cutting the lady into half.

I know exactly what he's doing. Till that time, I have to keep coming back. Till I eat the Brahma's Loka, the Creator's own world, I will be coming back into the same cycle. But then when I reach there and then identify with the source, then I will become one with that. So it gives us a scale. My quest in life to achieve happiness is not a short term, even though I put it in a short term goal and long term goals.

But in the end I want happiness. If you just extend that to Brahma, just day and night and now work towards your goal, that's the only way to achieve that is to identify with the source. Avyakta d vyaktayaha Sarvaha prabhavanti aha Agame. So all those things in beings with all their guna and Dharma are in dormant state. When Brahmaj is inactive, which we consider as a dissolution. Pralaya, Vishnu, lying in a Kshira, Shira, Samudra, milky ocean.

There are no vasanas, pure Sattva, then there is no activity. If it is pure Sattva, there is no activity. Rajas and Tamas has to be there. So when you are in a pure state of Sattva, there is no activity. But all other things in being there in dormant state. All the other thoughts are in dormant state.

Just as when I go to sleep, all my thoughts about what I'm going to be doing next week are in dormant state. Not that I've forgotten anything about it. I'm just in dormant state. As soon as I wake up on Monday morning, we all come into being and becomes my work and my activity and my creation. Avyakta, vyaktaha, sarvaha prabhavanti ahaha made the arrival of the day. All those who were unmanifest now becomes manifest in all those who are manifest during the day.

snippets.title: Day 113: Reaching the Supreme
snippets.sanskrit:
पुरुषः स परः पार्थ भक्त्या लभ्यस्त्वनन्यया |

यत्र काले त्वनावृत्तिमावृत्तिं चैव योगिनः |

अग्निर्जोतिरहः शुक्लः षण्मासा उत्तरायणम् |
snippets.transliteration:
puruṣaḥ sa paraḥ pārtha bhaktyā labhyastvananyayā .

yatra kāle tvanāvṛttimāvṛttiṃ caiva yoginaḥ .

agnirjotirahaḥ śuklaḥ ṣaṇmāsā uttarāyaṇam .
verseTranslations: *Now I will tell thee, O Arjuna, of the times at which, if the mystics go forth, they do not return, and at which they go forth only to return.

If knowing the Supreme Spirit the sage goes forth with fire and light, in the daytime, in the fortnight of the waxing moon and in the six months before the Northern summer solstice, he will attain the Supreme.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter eight, Imperishable Brahman. We are coming to the last concluding verses of this chapter. In chapter seven, we learned about the nature of the supreme as the Higher Prakriti and the Lower Prakriti. He said, my Lower Prakriti is Eightfold Prakriti which is manifest. My Higher Prakriti which supports this lower Prakriti. So that higher Prakriti is the imperishable Brahman, which is the substratum for this Lower Prakriti.

That which is manifest is supported by that which is Unmanifest. That Unmanifest is the Supreme Brahman, the Imperishable. So chapter eight is our quest to understand the imperishable Brahman. We've been discussing the nature of the Imperishable Brahman. In the beginning we have learned that the nature of that supreme reality is imperishable. He is self knowing and in his work is to create these things and beings.

Same supreme reality creates these things and beings is Prakriti. As the Lower Prakriti out of his own self, so the world which we see is the manifest world, but it is supported by the Unmanifest. Unmanifest is imperishable, but the world which it creates is perishable. Prakriti is infinite, just as Brahman is infinite. Prakriti is ever existing, just as Brahman is ever existing. But the creations within Prakriti are perishable because the same entity which creates these things and beings will keep creating and destroying the Brahma, the Creator, while he is working, that's his day.

When he's not working, that's his night. And we have seen that how long the Brahma's day is compared to hours. Then in the end we have talked about how can the individual ego, the individual entity which finds itself to be limited by these limitations of mind and intellectual, can rise above this limitations and reach the Supreme. Why I'm suffering through my limitations. And therefore there are Sorrows. If I was having no limitation, there will not be any sorrow.

So my quest in life is to get over all my limitations. So when I transit from one existence to another, my goal is always to get to a stage which has less limitations or no limitations. So we talked about the one who dies with that thought of imperishable in mind will lead the imperishable. One who dies with the goal of achieving something will get to that state of achievement. Those who worship Devas will go to Devas. Those who worship Brahman will go to Brahman.

Then we elaborately discussed how to get to that point where we can think about that goal. So the verse 21, which was the last one we had discussed, it says, vyakta aksara ITI ukta tam ahuhu paramahamgapti. That which is considered the unmanifest, Imperishable is your highest goal. And they who reach it never again return. Yam prapyanna neverthanti. Everyone else has to come back because of some goal or other.

Some desire or other which is unfulfilled. And I want to fulfill it. I want to achieve their capabilities and then achieve that goal. So to achieve that, now I'm in a pursuit of happiness. Because my happiness is somewhere else. I have to come back to pursue my happiness.

But one who wants to achieve that happiness which is supreme, then he doesn't have to come back. And therefore it says that your goal is to achieve that unmanifest and imperishable that is considered the highest goal. They who reach it never again return. Bhagwan says, that is my highest abode. That's what my my abode is. All this time we had been discussing and thinking about what is the nature of the Lord and where does he reside.

Number one says, that is my abode and that's my nature. My nature is supreme, imperishable, unmanifest. My abode is that state of awareness. That's where you will find me. So the next seven verses, which are the concluding verses, say, Purushasa partha bhaktiya labhyatu Ananya. Is it ever possible to achieve that state of achieving oneness with the imperishable Brahman?

Right now I can achieve oneness with my own limitations that this is me. I can also relate to the other things in the world and achieve oneness. But it is unthinkable right now to achieve that oneness with the supreme imperishable brahman. The Bhagavan gives guarantee here that it is achievable by Bhaktiya labyadu Ananya by single pointed devotion. The single pointed devotion. The single pointed identification with that imperishable Brahman.

As long as I'm identified with something else, I cannot be identifying with that. As long as I'm identified with my body, my intellect there is no way that I can identify with him. So Bhagavan said, it is possible for Purusha, any person to achieve that by single pointed devotion. That's the only path.

Yasyantahasthani Bhutani. That single pointed devotion for what? That which is the indwelling for all beings. I am trying to achieve understanding about myself. But in that inward journey I have to realize that myself is not just limited to my limited self but it is the self of all the beings. Yesyanta sthani Bhutani.

That's the dwelling place for all the beings. Enam sarvam vidam tatam and everything is pervaded by it. That entity with which I want to identify which is the dwelling place for all the beings and things. With that single pointed devotion, I'm identifying with that. We can very easily identify with the people and things which are similar to me. We have difficulty identifying with people who are a little different than us.

They speak different language, they look different. It's a way I can overcome that. But then I have to identify with entire Jagat and it goes even beyond that and says there is nothing in this universe cosmos where the self is not pervaded. In my inward journey of meditation I have to understand and identify with that entity which does not leave anything out. If I say I love this, but I hate this, well, I have limited him. I created limitation for him and therefore my journey is incomplete.

So now Bhagavan said that I will explain to you how to reach there. And he said there are two paths. Yatra kale to anavrutyam avruttim chevayogina. Well, first qualification. You should be a Yogi.

You are the one who is striving to achieve this liberation that's given. But the striving alone will not guarantee that you will achieve liberation. Because the path you may take. They said that I will explain the time and path while parting from this state of existence. One which is the path of return and one path of no return. We had been trying, people had Been trying, but we continue to come back to the same world of sorrow.

Prayatha Yanti Tamkalam Vakyami Bharata Sabah. So I will let you know what path will lead you to no return. I also let you know what the path of return. So that's basically just an introduction to the next two verses. Next is Agnihi Jyotihi Ahaha, Shuklaha Shanmasa, Uttarayanam Tatra, Prayahata, Gachanti, Brahma, Brahma Vidojanaha. These two mantas are very, very difficult to understand because from a superficial translation it makes no sense whatsoever.

snippets.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |

राजविद्या राजगुह्यं पवित्रमिदमुत्तमम् |

अश्रद्दधानाः पुरुषा धर्मस्यास्य परन्तप |
snippets.transliteration:
śrībhagavānuvāca .

rājavidyā rājaguhyaṃ pavitramidamuttamam .

aśraddadhānāḥ puruṣā dharmasyāsya parantapa .
verseTranslations: "Lord Shri Krishna said: I will now reveal to thee, since thou doubtest not, that profound mysticism, which when followed by experience, shall liberate thee from sin.
This is the Premier Science, the Sovereign Secret, the Purest and Best; intuitional, righteous; and to him who practiseth it pleasant beyond measure.
They who have no faith in this teaching cannot find Me, but remain lost in the purlieus of this perishable world.
snippets.commentary:
We have started discussing chapter nine, which is the Raja Vidya Rajaguhiya Yoga, the Yoga of the Royal Knowledge and Royal Secret. Obviously this is in continuation of what we have so far discussed in last two chapters of 7 and 8. In chapter 7 we have seen Gnana Vignana Yoga, Yoga of Knowledge, in Visishtha Gnana, which is applied knowledge or what we call wisdom. A typical call wisdom is something which we have gained a knowledge through our own experience that says, well, look at my gray hair. I didn't have this gray hair standing in the sun outside all this experience. In other words, what I have learned through my experience became my own knowledge.

Somebody told me something that remained at the information level, then I applied it and it became my own knowledge. That's why in the science college you have theoretical classes and then you go to lab same thing which you Learned there, that H2O makes water. You go and experiment it out and yourself realize that's what happens. So the first thing we did after finishing the first six chapters, talking about who we are and how do we purify our internal instrument by meditation, by all these sadhanas, selfless actions. See now what are we meditating upon is what we need to know. So from chapter seven onward, we started talking about the self knowledge, knowledge about my own self, removing this paradox where I think this is me and still worrying about what happens to me after my death and what happened before my birth.

snippets.reflection:
The Gita promises that sincere, heartfelt offering is always received. Today, offer something simple—a leaf, a flower, a thought, a moment of gratitude—with your whole heart.

snippets.sanskrit:

verseTranslations: The whole world is pervaded by Me, yet My form is not seen. All living things have their being in Me, yet I am not limited by them.

snippets.title: Day 118: Worship and Devotion
snippets.sanskrit:

verseTranslations: All beings, O Arjuna, return at the close of every cosmic cycle into the realm of Nature, which is a part of Me, and at the beginning of the next I send them forth again.

snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing chapter nine, Rajavidya Raja Guya Yogunan. So far we have seen that Bhagavan has indicated the relationless relationship of Jiva, Jagat and Paramatma. That's basically what the topic of this discussion Bhagawan started. So we are aware of our relationship with the Jiva to the Jagat, that I consider myself to be independent of the Jagat, the world. So the world I consider is an object, something other than me. But we still do not have any inkling about what our relationship with the Paramatma is.

The all pervading being. So Bhagawan clarified in the first six verses which we have seen that his relationship to the Jagat is relationless relationship. So first he said, I am not in them, they are in me. So the first conception we have from our childhood, learning from other teachers, religions that Bhagavan is within me, but I do not know who that Bhagavan is. Bhagavan clarified that I am not in them, I am not in the beings. So the first paradigm shift here is Bhagawan is saying I am not in them.

The next thing he says is that they are in me. I pervade this entire Jagat Jagat which I can imagine and perceive in its infinity. Bhagawan said I am that infinite Jagat and all beings are in the Jagat. I am not in it, but it is in me. So Brahman Paramatma is the fundamental. Everything is an emergent reality.

The Jagat is emerging out of Paramatma, Jiva is emerging out of Jagat. So he clarified this relationship that I am fundamental, Jagat and Jivas are within me. But then he clarifies further saying but in reality, even they are not in me. So first we are conceived as the wind in the space, that the space is all pervading and infinite. From our perspective, the wind is finite and moving around within the space. In the same way all other elements which we see below, space, air, fire, water, earth, they're within space.

So space Is substratum for all things and beings to be in. That's our normal perception. The space is all pervading. Everything is within the space. Now Bhagavan is saying that he is beyond space and time. The Jagat is bound by space and time.

Bhagavan says, I am beyond space and time. So the Bhagavan is fundamental, infinite, all pervading, unchanging. Jagat is bound by space and time. And therefore it is changing, but is constantly changing with time. So the conundrum is, if the Jagat and Jiva came out of Brahman, the supreme reality, how did Brahman change? Where I see the manifest Jagat, which is the manifest Prakriti, which came out of Brahman, which is unmanifest.

How did the unmanifest became manifest is the riddle we have to solve. So Bhagavan said, even they are not in me. It makes it clear that the Jiva and Jagat are apparent reality are not the fundamental reality. Because they appear to be in me. But you see, they are also actually not in me. In other words, they appear to be in me.

And therefore we use this analogy of snake and rope. So that's the only way the two things can exist in the same state of manifest and unmanifest at the same time. Rope is unmanifest to the one who is afraid of snake. But someone who is aware of the rope, for him, the snake is not there. So these two are related, but have no real relationship. Snake and rope are related because without rope, the snake cannot exist.

But snake has no real reality other than the observer is creating this reality. You remove the observer, the snake and rope dichotomy goes away. So this Jagat and Jiva, which I see as two realities, the Bhagavan said that they do not really exist. Are created by my observations. It's my mind which projects the space and time. Space and time are concepts of my mind.

When I am not aware of myself. In deep sleep, neither space nor time exists. So when you wake up, only then you can say, nice sleep. But how long did I sleep? I will have no idea unless I look at the watch or clock. And so I went to sleep at such and such time, woke up at such and such time.

So I infer that I slept for as many hours. But a deep sleeper has no sense of time or space. So the Bhagavan said, jiva and Jagat are the conceptions of mind. But I, in reality is pristine without any change. But then Jeevan Jagat are very real for us. How do they come into existence?

Bhagawan now explains in the following verses. Sarvabhutani, Kaunteya, Prakrutim, Yanti, Mami kam, Kalpakshaye, Punastha, Kalpadav, Vishrajami aham. At the end of the Kalpa all beings Sarva Bhutani. We see in the Prakriti they come back to my original nature. Prakriti we discussed last time is the fundamental manifest reality also called Hiranyagarbha. We also called Ishvara.

So Brahman with Maya is Ishvara. Brahman is the efficient cause. Maya is the material cause. Maya provides this material to create this Jagat. So this Maya is the fundamental Prakriti. From that fundamental Prakriti, the Prakriti which I see as pluralistic manifestation comes into existence.

This plurality goes back into that singular Prakriti at the end of Kalpa. We learned in last chapter that Brahmaji is one day is one Kalpa. Brahmaji is one day is 1000 Maha Yugas. One Mahayuga has four Yugas, Sathya, Treta, Dwapur and Kali. And we have calculated the one Kalpa is 4.3 billion years. So here Bhagavan says there is one cycle of creation.

The another cycle of dissolution is Brahmaj's night, which is equally as long as 4.3 billion years. The Bhagawan said, I create this Jagat at the beginning of my day and all that comes back to its original state at the end of the Kalpa. So the creation goes to the evolution as we perceive in our scientific observations. In our modern day, the universe came into existence, the Big Bang. It continues to expand, it continues to evolve, and at some point of time it will go back to its original state. Bhagavad said Sarvabhutani, all beings in this Jagat, Prakrutim, Yanthi, Mamikam, Kalpakshaya.

At the end of Kalpa they all come back to me in my Prakriti. Punahatani, Kalpada, visra jami aham. I recreate them at the beginning of the next Kalpa, which is very similar to when I go to sleep every night I have all these ideas during the day I have all the goals during my days I have to do list. All during my day I go to sleep. All those ideas are folded back into my consciousness When I go to sleep when I'm in deep sleep. I don't really feel anything.

I have no to do list, no idea what I need to become, what I need to acquire what I already accomplished. All those ideas in dormant state when I'm sleeping the next morning when I wake up, exactly those same ideas will create my new day. So I went to sleep as an architect. I wake up as an architect. A doctor who went to sleep as a doctor wakes up the doctor. My problems yesterday unresolved.

They're still unresolved today. So we start from where we left off last night. Bhagavan said here in the case of the Srishti, at the individual level, my world starts at the beginning of the day or ends when I go to sleep at night. At the Samasthi level. At the end of Kalpa, the whole world goes to sleep. But all those Vasanas tendencies of all the beings are in a dormant state.

The new Kalpa will start with the old Kalpa. So nothing really changes. When the new Kalpa starts, the same cycle will start all over again. And so Bhagavan said, Prakrutim swam Avastabhya Vishrujami Puna Puna. This is unending cycle. The Brahmaji wakes up one day and then goes to sleep.

And then we are done with it. Brahmaji's life is considered hundred years. One day and one night we see his two Kalpas. Now you have to put his hundred years. That Brahma then gets liberation Moksha. The new Brahma takes over.

The new cycle starts all over again. So this is unending creation. My world comes out of my ideas and it dissolves into my nothingness. When I go to deep sleep, when I wake up, it starts all over again. This happens all throughout my life. When I die, everything gets merged into tendencies.

I will have no memory of my experiences. But I'll carry that fragrance with me of what I have experienced in this life which will be the beginning of my next life. At an individual level, Brahma's level, the entire Srushti is in that state. Bhagavan said, you can visualize this entire Jagat as your own self. Just as you're visualizing yourself right now is a limited being. Otherwise Bhuta Gramma Inam Krishnam Avasam Prakrutehe Avashat.

This cycle continues perpetually. Because Brahman is beyond time. The time does not exist for us. Time exists because we are perceiving events in space. The time is an interval between two events. If you remove all events, there is no time.

If I don't experience anything, there is no time. But I experience one event, then a second event. This interval becomes time. This Bhuta, grammam, Krishnam, this entire group of beings, Avasham, without any choice, as long as I have a tendency, I'm going to manifest that tendency. If I have desire, I'll act according to that desire. Vishrujami pristam, Avasam Prakrute, Avashat.

Because they are under the spell of Prakriti, the Maya. Therefore they do not have any choice but to act according to their own tendencies and vasanas. All beings are propelled to act according to their swadharma, according to their makeup of their own vasanas and desires. Even when they go into dormant state, those vasanas and desires remain in dormant state. When you wake up, those vasanas and desires come back again. And this cycle continues perpetually unless you get out of this cycle of becoming and doing.

Now the question Bhagavan answers here is whether that affects Brahman. Because he is the propeller, he is the prompter. He is the supporter of all this activity which is happening perpetually. Creation dissolution is continuing. Creation dissolution cannot happen without the presence of Brahman. My day and my night and my activity cannot happen unless I'm conscious of it.

As long as my consciousness is there, there will be day for me. There is a waking state for me. The dream state for me, deeply state for me. Question is, is my consciousness getting affected by my experiences at an individual level? At this Samasthi level, does Brahman get affected by these happenings? So Bhagavan clarifies in this verse Nachyamam Tani Karmani, Nibadnandi.

These actions of creation and dissolution which is only possible because I, the Supreme Consciousness is supporting it by using Maya. But the Maya is Brahma Shraya. It is supported by Brahman. There is no magician. You have to have magician to create magic. So that magic is supported by magician.

This Maya is supported by Brahman. But Brahman uses that Maya as the material to create this Jagat. Just as in my dream state, I create the experiences of my waking state as the material to create my dreams. No matter how weird a dream is, it is never based on something which you have not experienced before. It may be jumbled up of all the experiences. But all my dreams are based on my experiences, not on anybody else's experiences.

So Brahman creating this Maya as the material, creating this Jagat and then dissolving this Jagat into Prakriti again remain in its pristine state, unaffected by individual actions.

verseTranslations: Under my guidance, Nature produces all things movable and immovable. Thus it is, O Arjuna, that this universe revolves.
Fools disregard Me, seeing Me clad in human form. They know not that in My higher nature I am the Lord-God of all.

snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing chapter nine and what we have learned is that Bhagavan said, I am the source of all the things, all the beings, everything that you see, I am the source and I am also the final resting place for all things. Things come out of me and they will rush back into me. There is nothing really that can exist without me. As we said in that classical example that a ghost cannot exist without the post. So from the post point of view, post can say the ghost came out of me. And once you realize there is no ghost, is also goes back into me.

At any given time the ghost has no modifications or it never changed into ghost. But my ignorance and my perception has created this perception of a ghost. In a similar way, Bhagavan says from me the whole Prakriti comes into existence. This world of plurality as you see, is because of my existence. If I'm not there, there is no world of plurality. This world as we know is I.

And the world only exists because the fundamental basic reality is the self. I know I exist because of myself. You know you exist because of yourself. She knows she exists because of herself. But we think these are different selves. Bhagavan says it's just me, myself reflecting through all of them.

But we don't recognize it because of Moga Asha, but of vain desires that I am the center of my universe. The world needs to revolve around my desires. I want things to be like this. I want the world to be like this. I want market to do this. When I invest, therefore we do the wrong actions.

Because I have now considered this limited being as me. Now I have my false desires. We know we have very little power how things work in this world. But when we act, we forget that we know that even I can buy a gallon of milk. If so many people do so many things to bring that gallon of milk into your nearest martins or food line, then only you can go and buy. But I think that If I have $4 in my pocket, I'm the king and can buy that Milk that Moga Asana create this false notion that I am in control.

And Bhagavan says Moga gnana viche dashaha because of this false knowledge that this is me and I can change this world as I want creates this false notion of my control. Rakshasim Asuram Shaiva. These people are of the nature of Rakshasa and Asura. Rakshasa is one who is predominated by that Rajasic nature. We have seen in Vedanta that there is nothing can exist in this world of time and space if it does not have these three qualities of Sattva, Rajas and Tamas. Fundamental classifications of what are the basic qualities.

For any effect to exist in time and space, you need to have the Sattva, which is that awareness that this exists. The activity, the intense activity we see at the atomic level, subatomic level, or even at the level of our that it exists. And then Tamasa, the inertia for the thing to remain in its state as long as it can till the other force changes it to a different. He said that one with the most Rajasic predominance are the Rakshasas because they consider that this activity of theirs will give them the control over their world. And the Asuras are the Tamasic, the one with the predominant quality, which is Tamas. They rely on the inertia.

If I don't do anything, things won't change. Let's keep things as is, don't change it. Not realizing the nature of this world is Samsara. Constantly changing is Samsar. In that Samsara I try to keep things inert as is say the nature of Asura. These two qualities makes us forget the real nature of the self.

In contrast to that Mahatman, Asthmampartha, Devim, Prakruti, Mahasritaha. But the other group of people who do not fall into these two group of people who are Rajasic and Tamasic. And they are constantly interested only this existence. As I see the material existence, my physical existence and say my goal of life is to maintain this existence and have as much pleasure for this world as possible. Not realizing that this is a temporary existence in time and space. But my real existence is infinite, permanent, immutable or in the nature of the self.

The other group of people who are Mahatma, they are great souls simply because they will realize the nature of the self. So say Mahatma, Nastama, Partha, Divim, Prakriti, Mahasridah. Because they are taken Refuge into the divine nature of the self, which is to recognize the Sattva, the truth, that eternal truth which does not change with time. Everything in this world is relative truth. Somebody says, what is it? I say, it's a day outside.

Well, that's a relative truth. It was not true at 4 o' clock in the morning. It will not be true at 8 o' clock at night. It is true only now in this time. So it's called a relative truth. But the truth which remains constant in any period of time is called Sattva, which I can say it was this 150 years ago.

It is now and it will be for eternity. That's the universal truth, the Sattva. Those who take taken refuge into this awareness of that immutable truth which is the nature of the self. My self is not this limited being which has started its life on day one time. When I was born and I'll die is time T2. And I want to make the most out of this life.

Between this span of T1 and T2 are those Asuras and Rakshasana. One who says, well, this is just a flicker in my existence. My existence is infinite before, will be infinite after. I want to achieve that sense back, not get bogged down with this limited being. The great souls, they identified not with the limited self, but with the higher self. Is the example I have used many times because I'm an architect.

The space in this room is a conditioned space. Right now my association with this space is room space conditioned by these walls and floor and ceiling. But I also recognize that this space is universal space. It is here and it will be here. Whether this building will be there or not. The one who recognizes the myself will always be here with his body is there, mind is there or intellect is there or not.

They are the great soul. Therefore they have taken refuge in the Devimprakrati. This Sattva, predominantly Sattvic in nature. They recognize the ultimate truth about their own self. Bajanti, Ananya, Manasaha. Therefore they devote themselves to me with a single pointed mind.

Now obviously there are word connotations come from our own experience in life. Bhajanti, with that kirtan, kirtal and all that you know, Bhajanti, Ananya, Manasaha, Satatam. So constantly they are. But that's not possible. But we know that the vedantic connotation word Bhajanti means love. For divine is devotion Love is nothing but identification.

More I identify with someone, My love increases. More I identify with the divine. So Ananya Manasaha without any other thought. Without any other thought that this is me. I'm not an architect, I'm not a father, I'm not a son. All these are superimposition on me.

Amitabh Bachchan never forgets when he does the coolie. He knows he is Amitabh Bachchan. Never ever he forgets while doing all these roles he plays. I do play all these roles. But I forget and I get identified with it. And I get carried away with it.

At the immutable, imperishable self. They drop the identification with the limited. Playing this part very efficiently in this world.

But always the identification is with the higher self. Just as Amitabh Bachchan never forgets in Amitabh Bachchan. But he is a coolie at the time. You know, say, Satatam Kirtayantah maam Yatan taschadiravratah. So now what will be my attitude once I have recognized that this limited being is not me. This life is just a part I am playing for the time being.

Before I was born, I existed as the universal being. After that all existed as a universal being. Before this building was built, this space was here. And I can vouch for it because I live here long enough. Long before this building was here, this space was here. After the building is built, there's room spaces here.

And someday somebody will decide we can do better use of this land. And the building will be gone, but the space will be here. I am here, I was here and I will be here. That's the eternal truth. Bhagavan says Satatam Kirtayantah. Having known this, so what will be my actions?

Satatam constantly Kirtayantaha. I am singing the glory of that eternal self that I am my Lord, who functions through me as this limited being. Swamiji obviously said kirtan du Visival. We have a bhajan, you know, next week. So that's the kirtan. That's the only time we do kirtan Bhajan and kirtan Swamiji.

This song with equally crude and noisy instrument. Only for that time, for your mind to occupy that has its own place. Because at least that time my mind is focused into those songs and the verses and what it means at that time. It is I'm not thinking. And those who do any kind of art or they. That mind has to occupy with something.

And if it doesn't occupy, then it wanders away. One whose mind is constantly attached to that understanding that I am not this limited self, this universal self is manifesting in this world. There is nothing that can exist in this world without Him. And therefore there is no existence for anything else other than that. If God is all pervading, where are we? If we are here, then he is limited.

He cannot be all pervading. So if he is all pervading, there is no place for anyone else. All that I see is nothing but his manifestations. So now that constantly when I see anything in this world, the thought at the back of my mind says, that is nothing but the Lord's manifestation. Whether that is good, bad or ugly. See, we have no problem.

We see something very beautiful, nice and divine. That's God's manifestation. Early morning sun rises and we see O God. When the dark and evil we see and still see his presence in Him. That's where I'll be. Then my Kirtan Bhagavan says it's complete no matter what it is.

I know he pervades the entire universe and all the happenings. There is nothing other than him can exist and therefore there cannot be anything if there is anything other than Him.

snippets.sanskrit:
महात्मानस्तु मां पार्थ दैवीं प्रकृतिमाश्रिताः |

सततं कीर्तयन्तो मां यतन्तश्च दृढव्रताः |

ज्ञानयज्ञेन चाप्यन्ये यजन्तो मामुपासते |
snippets.transliteration:
mahātmānastu māṃ pārtha daivīṃ prakṛtimāśritāḥ .

satataṃ kīrtayanto māṃ yatantaśca dṛḍhavratāḥ .

jñānayajñena cāpyanye yajanto māmupāsate .
verseTranslations: But the Great Souls, O Arjuna! Filled with My Divine Spirit, they worship Me, they fix their minds on Me and on Me alone, for they know that I am the imperishable Source of being.
Always extolling Me, strenuous, firm in their vows, prostrating themselves before Me, they worship Me continually with concentrated devotion.
Others worship Me with full consciousness as the One, the Manifold, the Omnipresent, the Universal.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing chapter nine, Rajavidy Rajagohya Yoga. Yoga of Supreme Knowledge and Supreme Secret. So far we have seen the Bhagavan has revealed the supreme secret that I pervade everything in this Jagat. And this Jagat is supported by my Maya, my association with Prakruti. Prakruti produces all that is moving and unmoving. But I am not in the Prakriti.

I am not in the beings in the Prakriti. Those beings are in me. I am not in the Jagat, but Jagat is in me. In other words, my self supports the perception of the Jagat. So the Jagat exists as long as I perceive it. This world exists for me as long as I am conscious of it.

When I'm not conscious of this Jagat, then this Jagat does not exist for me. The same way from the Supreme Consciousness. As long as that Supreme Consciousness is aware of the Jagat, that Jagat exists. And therefore Bhagavan says that I am not in the Jagat, Jagat is in me. But then he also said that they are also not in me. The beings and things in this Jagat are also not in me.

In other words, the Jagat and the things and beings which I see in the Prakriti, they are not in the consciousness. The consciousness is not affected by this perceptions of the world outside. So Bhagawan created contradictory statements for us to understand. Relationless relationship with Bhagavan. We are related to Bhagavan, as close to him as we are to our own selves. Because this world is created out of Bhagavan's own self.

Therefore I cannot be further away from him than I am from my own self. And that's the secret which is the Supreme Secret. Even though I am as close to him as I am to my own self. But I never feel his presence. So Bhagawan said, to feel my presence you have to identify with me. People who do not identify with me.

Bhagawan is explaining in last verse, 12 he says Moga Asa, Mogha Karmanaha, Moga Gnana Vicheta sah. This is the reason why we are not experiencing his presence. Because we are distracted by our vain desires. Those desires prompt us to do vain actions. Because of our vain knowledge who we are, we consider this body, this mind, this intellect is to be me, this limited being to be me. I'm driven by my Rajasic and Tamasic tendencies.

As we have seen, this Maya is the root cause of the production of this Jagat. Jagat comes into existence out of Maya. Maya has three qualities. Sattva, Rajas and Tamas. Therefore everything in this Prakriti. Prakriti is nothing but the representation of Maya to us.

So everything in this Prakriti has those three qualities, Satvarajas and Dhammas. Awareness, activity and inertia. To exist in space and time, it has to have activity and inertia. And Sattva is the awareness part of it. So everything in this Jagat has these three qualities. The permutation combination of these three qualities makes this plurality that we see like in a three color printing.

There are only three colors, but it creates myriads of shades of color. So we can create all kinds of pictures from the combination of those three colors. The same way this Prakriti produces variety of things and beings by permutation combination of these three. Gunas Bhagavan said those people up to the level of human beings. People are just living by their instincts. All animals and plants and all aquatic life, they survive in the lap of Mother Nature.

They are aware of their own existence. But they are not aware of any other higher entity. Human beings are the only ones who have intellect. To realize that there got to be somebody higher than me, somebody greater than me to have the control over this world. Having that understanding, I still don't identify with him. Because this Rajas and Tamas dominated.

So Tattva is subdued by Rajas and Tamas. Then all my actions will be driven by those Rajasic and Asuric tendencies. The Rajasic and Asuric tendencies tell me that my happiness lies in this world out there. Therefore all my efforts to achieve that happiness which is my true nature. Just like water seeks its own nature, happiness is our true nature. So we constantly seek bliss and happiness.

And therefore we work in the world outside. We never complain about why I'm feeling good today. We always complain I'm not feeling good. Today because being good is my nature, being not feeling good is not my nature. Bhavagan said, you are not recognizing your nature because of your wrong knowledge about yourself. Mogagnana because of the wrong knowledge, we cheta s my thinking is wrong of where my happiness lies.

I'm working outside in a Rajasic manner to acquire things, to achieve things, to get happiness. And then I say, if I don't do anything, then I'll be happy. That asuric tendency, because of these two aspects of my nature, which is predominantly Rajasingh and Asuric, I'm not identifying with him. Bhagavan said that when I take the human form, people do not recognize me and they avoid me, ignore me. So we know everything about our own self, other beings, but we don't know about the divinity which is common in all of us. The consciousness which is the common factor, which is the one thread which ties everything together in this universe.

So therefore Bhagawan says Rakshasim, Asuram, Cheva, Prakrutim, Mohinim, Sritaha. By the nature of this Rajasic and Asharik Prakruti, they are confused about their own self. They're confused about the divinity in all human beings. Contrast to them Mahatmanastmampartha, Devim, Parkuti, mastritah. But in this path of evolution, everything evolves from Tamas to Sattva. So even in our evolution of our planet we obviously can think about first there was nothing but just inert matter.

Then came the organic life. Then gradually it evolved into more complex life, more intelligent life. So everything evolves from inertia to knowledge, from Tamas to Sattva. Some are in the path of evolution at Tamasic level, but they are on the path of their own evolution. So next step is Rajas to be Rajasic. So in our self unfoldment, Swamiji says that when you introspect and see what you find, if you find Tamasic quality, then replace it by Rajasic quality.

If you find Rajasic tendencies, replace them by Sattvic tendencies. So this is a conscious effort. As a human being, we have our freedom to choose how to behave. So Bhagavan said, those Mahatmas who have evolved to Sattva, even Mahatma has Rajasic and Tamasic tendencies. But they're subdued by Sattvic tendencies. In other cases, the Rajasic tendencies are subduing the Sattvic tendency.

Here the Sattvic tendencies are subduing the Rajasic tendencies and Tamasic tendencies. The devim Prakriti Mastritah so the Sattvik is considered the Devi divine quality. Closer to the reality. Devima Mastritaha Bhajantim Ananya Manasaha Knowing fully well that I am not this bundle of matter. I'm not this mind, this intellect. Even though I'm pulled by the tendencies of body, tendencies of mind, tendencies of intellect.

I'm constantly reminding myself I'm part of this all pervading consciousness. My consciousness is same as consciousness in all other being. Bhajanti Ananya Manasa not having any other thought. Even though I'm functioning in the world like everybody else. But that thought is constant in my mind that I am the divine being at the core of my being. I am that supreme self, the all pervading consciousness.

Knowing that Gnatva Bhuta dim avyam I am part of that immutable self which is all pervading. So we have discussed this example before. The space in my car or my car is in this space. The car is in the space. Space is not in the car. The space seems divided in different cars in different rooms.

But it is not really divided. Otherwise the car cannot move in the space and have Hendricko space. When it is in Hendricko Hanover space when it's in Hanover County. Bhuta Dim Gnatva Bhuta Dim avyam the self in me and self in you. They are not two divided selves. The self in all the being.

The consciousness which makes the entire Jagat possible is undivided. It's not that my consciousness is different than your consciousness. Your equipment, my equipment are different. And therefore our manifest representations are different. So Bhagavan says Mahatma. One who has evolved to that level of understanding that the self is undivided and all beings are existing in that consciousness.

Bhajanti Ananyamanah he devotes himself to me without any other thought, constantly with a single pointed devotion. There is no other doubt. There is no other identification. Even though he realizes that he is an individual functioning as this body, mind, intellect. But that is only possible because the consciousness functioning. We know this body is inert because we have seen dead bodies.

Dead body cannot function when the consciousness is not there. Therefore we come to the conclusion that the body is inert. Body is nothing but made up of food which I have eaten all my life. But I am a conscious being. Therefore my real identity is the consciousness and not this body. This Mahatma has come to this level of understanding.

Therefore he is constantly devoting himself to that true self which is the consciousness. Satatam, Kirta, Yanthamam, Yatantaschadravrataha. He is constantly doing kirtan to me. He is constantly praising me. So we obviously kirtan, bhajan, kirtan. We hear these words in our day to day conversation.

In our culture, though the Bhajan is something we are thinking about the Lord. Kirtan is obviously we are praising the Lord. But here the praise and thinking about the Lord is in a very different connotation. So when I am praising the Lord, I am devoted to the Lord. Devotion is love for the Divine that we have considered divine. Our love for the Divine that becomes devotion.

And love is nothing but identification. When I identify with something or someone, I love that thing or love that person. I love my BMW because I identify with my BMW. When I identify with the Lord as my Lord, then I devote myself to Him. This devotion is nothing but my identification with the Lord. And therefore that kirtan, kirtan is not that one Sunday afternoon or Saturday evening we get together and Swamiji says the noisy kirtan we do with equally noisy equipment.

Kirtan is a constant thought in my mind that I am not this limited being and my Lord is not divided in this being. But we all exist in his own being. We are only existing because he exists. I am only alive because the consciousness is functioning through me. When the consciousness will not be there, I will be purely as just a bundle of matter. They will call it dead body and get rid of it as quickly as possible.

Satantiyamta, Yatantascha, Dhruvrataha. They are constantly striving because they will be pulled from this prakriti to identify with it. To identify with my body. Then go out and get things and go out and identify with things outside. I'll fall in love with things and beings outside. I have to constantly remind myself that therefore it's yatantaha.

So once you get this knowledge from the books or from a guru, you're not done with it. That's just the beginning of it. Now you have to constantly remember with everything you do. The constant efforts are required for even Mahatmas, Dhruda, vrataha. And they are steadfastly established in this knowledge. There is never a doubt that this is not true.

Some of us, we read this and then we read other book and they start doubting whether this is right or that is right. The other one says there is Ishvara, the Other one says there is no Ishvara One path said there is no life after death.

verseTranslations: I am the Oblation, the Sacrifice and the Worship; I am the Fuel and the Chant, I am the Butter offered to the fire, I am the Fire itself, and I am the Act of offering.
I am the Father of the universe and its Mother; I am its Nourisher and its Grandfather; I am the Knowable and the Pure; I am Om; and I am the Sacred Scriptures.
I am the Goal, the Sustainer, the Lord, the Witness, the Home, the Shelter, the Lover and the Origin; I am Life and Death; I am the Fountain and the Seed Imperishable.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter nine, Raja Vidya, Raja Guhya, Yoga, Yoga of King of Secrets and King of Knowledge. So from one through six chapters we have seen who I am and how I should work in this world, work in this world with the Spirit of Yajna. Because those accents are not binding. All others are binding. Then we have looked in chapter seven, the lower nature of the supreme, that which is manifest all around me. And then in chapter eight we have seen his higher nature which is unmanifest, supporting all the beings.

The secret still is what is my relationship with him is the secret. Having known all that, I still cannot find how I can relate to Him. So now chapter nine gives us the indication of what is your relationship with the Supreme? The Bhagavan, the Almighty, my Creator. So in the beginning he said that my relationship to this Prakriti which you are part of it. I'm trying to find out my relationship with Him.

I already Learned in chapter 8 that I'm nothing but a part of this manifest world. Therefore I'm nothing but a Prakriti. The Gita promises that sincere, heartfelt offering is always received. Today, offer something simple—a leaf, a flower, a thought, a moment of gratitude—with your whole heart.

They have followed the letter of the scriptures, yet because they have sought but to fulfill their own desires, they must depart and return again and again.

snippets.sanskrit:

पत्रं पुष्पं फलं तोयं यो मे भक्त्या प्रयच्छति |

यत्करोषि यदश्नासि यज्जुहोषि ददासि यत् |

yānti devavratā devānpitṝnyānti pitṛvratāḥ .

patraṃ puṣpaṃ phalaṃ toyaṃ yo me bhaktyā prayacchati .

yatkaroṣi yadaśnāsi yajjuhoṣi dadāsi yat .

All the imperfections we see in this world, which we constantly wonder why Lord created this world like that.

Do not change anything that you are doing except change your attitude that you're not doing it for yourself, you're doing it for him.

Therefore he when you enjoy something, he's the enjoyer. When you suffer, he's the sufferer. You achieve something, he's the achiever. When you fail somewhere, he is the failure. So Subha, Subha fala evam moks Thus you shall be freed from this bondage of Stuba and Ashuba. This is not good for me.

So you can imagine if you have a cataract in a vision in both your eyes, the world will be very fuzzy. And Bhagavan said, that's where we are Right now. Whatever the results come from my actions, I'll say, lord, you gave me this Buddhi to do this and I did that.

The yogi is the one who has given up the desire for the results of the actions. One who is given the Karma Phala is the yogi. You are established in Yoga if you have no particular desire for particular results. I will do my actions because I am not the Karma Faladatta. I am never the actor is never in control of its results. It's always somebody else.

snippets.title: Day 126: Worship and Devotion
snippets.sanskrit:
क्षिप्रं भवति धर्मात्मा शश्वच्छान्तिं निगच्छति |

मां हि पार्थ व्यपाश्रित्य येऽपि स्युः पापयोनयः |

किं पुनर्ब्राह्मणाः पुण्या भक्ता राजर्षयस्तथा |
snippets.transliteration:
kṣipraṃ bhavati dharmātmā śaśvacchāntiṃ nigacchati .

māṃ hi pārtha vyapāśritya ye.api syuḥ pāpayonayaḥ .

kiṃ punarbrāhmaṇāḥ puṇyā bhaktā rājarṣayastathā .
verseTranslations: He shall attain spirituality ere long, and Eternal Peace shall be his. O Arjuna! Believe me, My devotee is never lost.
For even the children of sinful parents, and those miscalled the weaker sex, and merchants, and labourers, if only they will make Me their refuge, they shall attain the Highest.
What need then to mention the holy Ministers of God, the devotees and the saintly rulers? Do thou, therefore, born in this changing and miserable world, do thou too worship Me.
snippets.commentary:
So we are concluding chapter nine today. Chapter nine, Raja Vidya, Raja Guja Yoga. Yoga of Royal Knowledge and Royal Secret. And obviously the question last time, what is this secret? Well, we have discussed many times, the secret is, where does my happiness lie? All my life I was seeking one thing and one thing alone.

That is permanent happiness and permanent peace. I have tried everywhere, I have tried in getting knowledge, learning things in this world. I have tried in accomplishing things, achieving things, acquiring things in my relationships. But in the end, if every happiness came with associated unhappiness, as we have learned through our life that anything which has a capacity to give me happiness has equal amount of capacity to give me unhappiness. In our relationships we know exactly closer you are, more chances of getting hurt. Even though we know what we are looking for and looking everywhere in our life, we can't find our happiness.

snippets.reflection:
The Gita promises that sincere, heartfelt offering is always received. Today, offer something simple—a leaf, a flower, a thought, a moment of gratitude—with your whole heart.

Don't worry about getting it right. What matters is the quality of love behind the gesture, however imperfect. The Lord sees the heart, not the outer form.

Consider: What would change if you truly believed that the supreme Reality is equally available to all, regardless of background, education, or social status? The Gita democratizes spirituality in a radical way.
