snippets.title: Day 128: Divine Glories
snippets.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |

न मे विदुः सुरगणाः प्रभवं न महर्षयः |

यो मामजमनादिं च वेत्ति लोकमहेश्वरम् |
snippets.transliteration:
śrībhagavānuvāca .

na me viduḥ suragaṇāḥ prabhavaṃ na maharṣayaḥ .

yo māmajamanādiṃ ca vetti lokamaheśvaram .
verseTranslations: "Lord Shri Krishna said: Now, O Prince! Listen to My supreme advice, which I give thee for the sake of thy welfare, for thou art My beloved.
Neither the professors of divinity nor the great ascetics know My origin, for I am the source of them all.
He who knows Me as the unborn, without beginning, the Lord of the universe, he, stripped of his delusion, becomes free from all conceivable sin.
snippets.commentary:
So we completed chapter nine and we'll now be discussing chapter 10, Vibhuti Yoga. So in the first six chapters we learned about I, the limited being which is part of this Prakriti. Prakriti has three constituent parts. Sattva, Rajasantamas. Everything in this Prakriti is made up of these three Gunas, whichever has the predominance that becomes my nature. So this Sattva is the purity, Rajas is activity and Tamas is inertia.

Everything in this Prakriti is made up of these three gunas. And we have learned the nature of Prakriti in chapter seven. So from up to chapter six we have learnt about us as the limited beings and what is the makeup of our beings. Chapter 7 Onward, we are learning about the nature of the supreme, the Lord. So in the chapter seven we learnt about his lower natures. Bhagavan said this Asthatha, Prakriti, Bhumi, Apah, Anlaha, Kham, Vayu, Mana, Buddhi, Ahanka.

The eight five great elements, Mind, intellect and Ahanka are the nature of the Prakriti, my lower nature. These are not different from me, but these are my lower nature in a sense, the grosser manifestation which you and I can perceive through our senses. We have discussed that in chapter seven. We discussed Prakriti in chapter seven. Chapter eight said that in Prakriti things are unmanifest in the beginning, then manifest in the middle, then unmanifest again. So Prakriti itself has two aspects.

One is manifest, one is unmanifest. There is unmanifest, Prakriti. There is manifest Prakriti. Bhagawan said, other than this unmanifest, there is another unmanifest which is my higher. Prakriti, which always remains unmanifest, is the support of all things and beings. So in chapter 8, Akshara Brahma Yoga, we learnt about this unmanifest nature of Purusha remaining unmanifest, it supports everything.

Bhagawan said that I'm the origin of all things and beings and I'm also the dissolution of all things and beings. I get confused about my being and therefore I'm not experiencing the very nature of the supreme. The very nature of supreme is Sat chit In Ananda very nature of the self is Sat existence, chit knowledge and Ananda happiness bliss. So right now neither I'm experiencing Sat. I know I exist but I'm afraid I'll be non existent. I'm not experiencing Satan cheat.

I'm not experiencing. I know something but I don't know everything. So I'm not experiencing cheat either. In Ananda is my biggest problem. Happiness comes and goes. For a while I'm happy and most of the time I'm just pursuing happiness.

So I'm trying to get out of the impermanence nature of Ananda into the permanent nature of Ananda. In trying to find out where is that permanent Ananda. The happiness Bhagavan in ninth chapter says that's the roll secret. That the greatest secret. It is your very nature to be Sat chit in Ananda but you are not experiencing it. That knowledge which connects me back to my real nature is the royal knowledge.

So that was chapter nine. At the end of chapter nine, Bhagavan said the only way one can experience this is Manmana Bhava. Make your mind focused on me. Offer yourself to me. Make me as your goal Yuktva Mat Parayanaha. In other words, completely identify with me and you will experience that Ananda which you are seeking.

Now how do I get to that level where I can completely identify with him is the subject of chapter 10. So it's called Vibhuti Yoga. Yoga of divine glories. I see, perceive, touch and feel this world of my experiences. But I break them all down into perishable things and beings. Anything which I see, I can say I understand this.

This is just a table. All this, I understand this. Well, I understand this is plant kingdom. So I break this down into the impermanent, perishable conglomeration of things and beings which by very nature they are impermanent and not divine. I don't consider them as divine. I don't say this table is divine.

I don't consider my colleagues as divine. Even when some wise person comes. But he is not Bhagavan. We have difficulty if somebody calls himself Bhagawan because we cannot associate the divinity with the objects of my perception. So how to change that and start seeing Divinity in everything I see and touch and feel is the subject of chapter 10. Therefore it is called Yoga of Divine Glory.

How to see this divinity, this divine glories in everything and being that I come across in the world of my experiences, my world of my perception. So Bhagavan starts this chapter without waiting for Arjuna to ask questions because he saw that he is enjoying it and he wanted to continue the theme which he started in chapter seven about the Prakriti. When he says, this Prakriti is nothing but my lower nature. Everything in this Prakriti Aa Sesah. There is nothing left in this Prakriti which is not divine. But we don't really see that way.

In fact, we divide this world into good and evil. We have some level of acceptance that good is divine. But we are difficult when it comes to bad and ugly. I can't associate divinity with it. This chapter will say that even that is only possible. Bad is only possible because of my presence and evil is only possible because of my presence.

There is nothing that can happen or exist in this world without me. So chapter opens with Bhagavan's statement says Bhuya Eva Mahabaho srunume paramam vacha yatta te aham Priyamanaya vakshyami Hita Kamya. I wish your welfare Hita Kamiya. Therefore I'm going to continue. And in last chapter I told you that this knowledge is available to all. And we discussed that verse which is very troublesome to discuss and say.

Those who are born in Papayonayaha Triya vaishya tathakshadraha. Even they have equal right when they come to me. If they focus their mind onto me. We discuss why Papayoni. Anything which takes me away from my identification with the supreme is sin. That which does not recognize my true potential which is Sat chit in Ananda is Papa.

It the impurity on my mind which is right now not letting me see who I am. An environment which is more likely to create wrong impressions on my mind is Papa Yoni. Yoni is a collection of people which creates an environment which is similar for each other. So it will be symbiotic relationship. It's like a satsang in a reverse bad company. If I'm put up in that environment that I get more sinful impression on my Mind I have less chance of rising out of it once I.

Even those people, those who are disadvantaged by their environment, by the society they are put in an environment which does not give them the equal right to achieve what they try to achieve. Even they can rise above that. Triya Vaishya Tatakshudra. These people Vaishya says never complained about this verse. Only two people complain. Vaishya didn't say why we are included in it as well.

We are higher than you now. All business people are worshipped now. Not Dikshatriyas and Brahmanas. So Bhagawan says that at the time of Mahabharata you can say Vaishas were not considered as high as the Brahmins and Kshatriya. I heard when I was growing up. Which profession you are supposed to take?

Uttam Kheti Keti Farming. Madhyam Vyapa and Kanishta Nokri. The worst is you want to work for somebody is Kanishta. We all work for corporate and feel great about it. If you can't do farming then only you do Vaipa. So they were considered lower.

Now today you go and tell India you become a farmer. How many farmers are committing suicide? Why do you want me to do farming? But in that society Kshatriyas were farmers. Janakaraj, when he was stealing his land, he found Sidha. Kshatriyas, the kings were themselves were landlords and farmers.

So those people in that environment they had a great chance to uplift themselves by getting this knowledge. But others did not have that equal rights. Women, Vaishya, Kshudra. But even they can get this knowledge and come to me. But you are a Mahabaho. You are the mighty armed person who has all the opportunities and all the prerequisites to know this.

So Bhuya Eva Mahabaho again. Listen to my very important words. I think you have come to a level that you are understanding what I'm saying. Manmana Bhava Madh Bhakta Madhya ji Mam namaskaru. I heard Obama saying the other day, stay focused. Don't get distracted by the protesters.

Don't get distracted by your doubts in your mind. Bhagavan says Paramam vacha yate aham Priyamanaya. And I'm only telling those people who likes to listen to this type of knowledge. Vakshyami Hitakami Ayyaa. Because I wish welfare for you all. And therefore I'm telling you.

So what I'm telling you is what we had started in the last chapter saying. What is the royal secret? Aham Adhi Devanam Maharshinam Chasarva Sah. Neither the Devas in the heavens nor the great Rishis know my origin. What is the source of my being? Not on the great Rishis, not the Devas.

Because even in Puranas, Devas have their own limitations. Devas are considered pretty greedy. They want to have everything. Devas, they don't know. And Rishis, they are distracted by their own intellect. See, when we learn something, we get to a level where our intellect will become an obstacle.

We can't experience it because we keep doubting ourselves. So Bhagavan says, even they don't know. Because the source of the Deva and Rishis is me. Swami Dheerananda's very famous example. Batteries in the flashlight. If you're in a dark room and I have flashlight, I can see everything in the room.

But somebody says, what type of batteries are you using, Neil? I say, well, let me take it out. I take out the batteries. I put the batteries back. Light is back, but I can't see the batteries. I said, I don't know till tomorrow morning.

So the source of the light in the flashlight is the batteries. And therefore I cannot know through the light of the flashlight the type of batteries I'm using. Through my intellect, which is the Rishi, I cannot know the source of my being. I constantly try to contemplate through my intellect by deduction and inferences who I am. Bhagavan said, you will not know that the Rishis, our intellect, the knower, the seer in us is the Rishi. In the Devas are our sense perceptions.

To illumine something which is illuminated by my senses. So my senses are the Devas. Without them, the world is not existent for me. You remove the one sense of seeing. The world of sight is gone. You remove the hearing.

The world of sound is gone. You remove all five senses. The world is illuminated by my senses. So they are Devas through my senses. I am trying to find Bhagavan. I want to see Bhagavan.

I want to see the presence of Bhagavan. In the laboratory, when somebody dies, what happens? Where is that atma is going? The people have done experiments of people dying. And what is it that leaving they cannot find it simply because Bhagavan said, because I am the source of this Deva Dhanda, I am the source of your senses and your intellect. You will never be able to find me through this.

Because the instrument cannot find its own source. Bhagwan says, aham, Adhi Diwanam, Maharishi Nam Cha Sarvasa. I'm not available to any of those, to the sense perceptions or by intellectual inquiry. I'm only available by contemplation and identification. By identification that I will be able to find myself. Yom Ajam Anadim Chavaiyati.

One who knows that I am that I. Whichever way you apply it, when applied to the supreme, he is the God1 Bhagawan says I that includes everything.

snippets.title: Day 129: The Source of All
snippets.sanskrit:
बुद्धिर्ज्ञानमसम्मोहः क्षमा सत्यं दमः शमः |

अहिंसा समता तुष्टिस्तपो दानं यशोऽयशः |

महर्षयः सप्त पूर्वे चत्वारो मनवस्तथा |
snippets.transliteration:
buddhirjñānamasammohaḥ kṣamā satyaṃ damaḥ śamaḥ .

ahiṃsā samatā tuṣṭistapo dānaṃ yaśo.ayaśaḥ .

maharṣayaḥ sapta pūrve catvāro manavastathā .
verseTranslations: Intelligence, wisdom, non-illusion, forgiveness, truth, self-control, calmness, pleasure, pain, birth, death, fear and fearlessness;
Harmlessness, equanimity, contentment, austerity, beneficence, fame and failure, all these, the characteristics of beings, spring from Me only.

The seven Great Seers,* the Progenitors of mankind, the Ancient Four,** and the Lawgivers were born of My Will and come forth direct from Me. The race of mankind has sprung from them. [* Mareechi, Atri, Angira, Pulah, Kratu, Pulastya, Vahishta. ** The Masters: Sanak, Sanandan, Sanatan, Sanatkumar.]
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing Chapter 10, Vibhuti Yoga, Yoga of Divine Glories. We have seen so far that Bhagavan is immanent as well as transcendental. Bhagavan is immanent because he resides in the hearts of all beings. Ishvara Sarva, Bhutanam Rudeserjuna Tishtadhi. Ishvara is residing in the hearts of all beings, therefore immanent. But he's also transcendental because we do not recognize him.

This chapter started out by Bhagavan saying in the second verse, I am not known to anyone. Neither the Devas, the divine beings or or the divine senses know me, nor the Great Rishis know me. He is not known by the mind or the intellect. By applying the normal tools of my cognition, I cannot know Ishwaran. Therefore he is transcendental. So these two aspects of the Bhagavan we have to overcome in a sense, to know Him.

We have to find altar of meditation. We have completed the first segment of Karma Yoga, culminated in a Dhyana Yoga to meditate upon that supreme Self, my true Self. But what to meditate upon is what we have been discussing since last three chapters 7, 8 and 9. And Bhagawan in various ways told us what his real nature is that I am all pervading. Everything is strung into me. There is no reality other than me.

But it's still difficult for us to meditate on those aspects of Bhagavan. So the Vibhuti Yoga, the glories of the Lord, are required to meditate upon, to focus on. Something which I can identify through the limited means that I have, is my mind and intellect. So in this chapter, the Bhagavan is giving us the Vibhuti, that which I can identify and vouch for his presence. It is something like when I am in a deep sleep at night and wake up suddenly if I really want to know whether the sun is outside or not. That means, is it a day or not?

When I open my windows and I see sunlight, I do not see the sun, but I see sunlight. The presence of sunlight tells me that sun has risen. The sun is there outside. I may not be able to see sun for various reasons. Maybe a building is blocking my view, maybe so bright that I cannot see it. But the very fact that I can experience the sunlight, it tells me that sun has risen.

In the same way, if I know the Vibhutis Sri Bhagawan says, if you can identify the qualities which emanate from me, which are my real qualities, then you should be able to vouch for my presence. The Lord resides in all hearts, in all beings, in all things. But I cannot vouch for it right now. So Bhagawan is giving us the tools to realize his presence. So in verse 3, Bhagavan concluded Yomam Ajam Anadim, Chaviti, Loka Maheshwaram. I am not known to the Devas.

I am also not known to the Rishis, the great sages. I am not known through intellect nor I am known through mind. However, if one knows that I am Ajam Anadim, I am the source of all being. I am birthless and beginningless. It is uncaused, caused, then it is birthless. There is nothing before me.

Therefore there is nothing is causing my existence. And also I'm beginningless because there's nothing before me. Loka Maheshwaram, the Lord of all the entire creation is there because of me. Because of the entity which is beginningless and birthless, the entire Jagat exists, the Bhagavan, the Lord Ishvara is the material cause and efficient cause for this Jagat. When he created this universe out of his own Maya, there was no other material available to him. From his own self, from his own qualities.

He provided the material as well as the knowledge, the efficient cause to create this Jagat. So the creation, if it all comes out of he is the Loka Maheshram. He is the Lord of all the beings. Lord is the one on whom my existence depends. So my Lord is my own consciousness. Without that, my existence as this limited being does not exist.

The day consciousness is not there, I will not be nil Bhatt. I'll be just a dead body. So Bhagavan said Asammudasam, the one who is not deluded by these appearances, he will be relieved of all the sins. In other words, all the ignorances, all the ignorant ideas that I have about myself as a limited being, I'll be liberated from. And then he enumerate those 20 qualities of that supreme Being, the divinity. That these qualities in people, in things and being exists because of my presence, those qualities are somewhat easy to understand.

Buddhi, Gnanam, Asamoha, Shamah, Satyam, Damaha, Shamaha, Buddhi, intellect, Nischayatmika, Buddhi. That which decides what is right and wrong is Buddhi. So when I feel that I'm exhibiting my Buddha because I can decide it is day and not night, that's my Buddhi. Bhagavan says that because of my presence in you, this Buddhi exists in you at the microcosm. This Buddhi I use for deciding what's outside in this world. Gnanam this Buddhi now gives me knowledge what is real and what is unreal.

Asammoha and non illusion. When I have Buddhi and I apply it to find out whether it is day outside or night, when I wake up, it gives me non illusion. Even though it was dark in my room, there is no difference between day and night in my room. But as soon as I open the window, I knew it's a day outside. That is because of my Buddhi that if there is sunlight outside, the sun has risen and therefore it is a day. So that created a Samohaha.

Non illusion, no delusion, no confusion. Out of these three, I developed other qualities such as Satyam, Dhamah, Shama Shama, forgiveness, Satyam, truth, Dhammaha, control of Indriya and Shamaha is control of mind. We've seen in Tatva, Bodh, Shamah, Mano, Vigraha, the Addict, Samah and then Dhammaha is control of the senses such as eyes, ears, control of those Shama and Satyam Shama is forgiveness. If I see that somebody is not yet convinced that it's a day outside. Even though I have concluded that it is day outside. But if my wife doesn't agree with me, then I forgive her.

I think she has not seen outside yet. Because of my knowledge, my Buddhi is in my non delusion. I can forgive other people who are still not at that level. She has not woken up completely. She cannot see the light outside, see things, it's still night. I can forgive her because of my knowledge.

If I have no knowledge, there will be confused. They will be fighting about it. But because I have knowledge about it, I can have the Kshama and I can vouch for the truth that it is day outside. I can control my actions and also my mind. All this emanating from the same source, my own Consciousness at the vyasti, at the microcosm. I have all these exhibiting through me.

Because of that divinity, the consciousness functioning through me, I'm identifying with it. Sukham du kam babah abhavah, Bhayamcha, Abhayam evacha. These are the pairs of opposites I have to deal with in this world. This world which I have created out of my own consciousness. In the deep sleep, there was no world outside to deal with. There were no pairs of opposites.

There was no confusion about day or night. But as soon as I woke up and I have this Buddhi and Gnana exhibiting through me. Now I have to deal with this world outside which has pairs of opposites. So Kannadukha Bhava and Abhava. Existence and non existence, birth and death. Bhayam cha Bhayam Bhaya is a positive emotion which protects me from getting myself hurt.

If I have no Bhaya of jumping from a third floor window, then I'm going to hurt myself. So this fear of getting hurt is actually protecting me. So therefore it's a positive emotion. And Abhaya and fearlessness. Things which I am very sure about. I'll be fearless no matter what.

Somebody tells me that I do not exist. So things which I so sure about my existence, I'm fearless. Things which I'm not sure about my existence. After my death, I'm fearful. I have fear of death because I have no idea what will happen after my death. I'm fearless about my existence right now.

Because I know who I am and how I exist exist. So there's both fear and fearlessness emanating from my identification with my consciousness. Ahimsa, non injury, Samatha, equanimity, Tusthi, contentment, Tapaha, disciplines, austerity, Dhanam, charity, Yashaha, Fame and also Ayyashaha ill fame. All these I experience because of my identification with myself as my conscious conscious being. These 20 qualities are given as the glories of that supreme Lord. These are the basic qualities through which he manifests in this world through beings.

He resides in the hearts of all the beings. And when those beings identify with him, these positive qualities are exhibited through them. Then what about the opposites of this? Like Hinsa, Abudhi, Agnana, Samoha. It is nothing but non identification with the self. When I identify with the Divinity within me, all these positive qualities of the divinity will be manifesting through me.

When I'm not identifying with that divinity, then the lack of those qualities will be exhibiting. So the lack of qualities are not really any qualities. They are just lack of good qualities. Something similar to There is nothing called cold but just a lack of heat. Heat I can identify as the form of energy. But cold there is no form of any energy.

It just lack of heat creates sensation of cold. Lack of Ahimsa creates Hinsa. Lack of Buddha creates a Abuddi Abu, one who doesn't know anything. Lack of knowledge creates ignorance. So the negatives which we see in this world is because of non identification with the true self. Bhagavan said this entire Jagat is created by my own mind using my own self as the material.

My Maya is the material, therefore he is the Loka Maheshwaram. Without him no world is possible. Without you being conscious of your world, your world cannot exist. Without me being conscious of my world, my world does not exist. And therefore he, the Supreme Lord who is functioning through all beings as their consciousness. He is the Lord of all all the beings.

So he is justifying why he is Loka, Maheshwaram, Bhavanti, Bhava, Bhutana, Mata Eva, Pruthakvida. These varieties of expressions you see in this world through various beings with all these qualities in the various levels, this permutation combinations, all these 20 qualities creates this multitude of personalities in this world. Somebody has more Buddhi, somebody has more Kshama, somebody has more Ahimsa. All these manifestations in this world through beings. But anytime I see the expression of any of these qualities I must know that divinity is present in that being. Said Bhavanti, Bhava, Bhutana, Mata, Evapratak, Vidaha.

All these different kinds of qualities of being arise from me alone. Without that one common thread which we call it consciousness, life, none of these are possible. And therefore we should know when we see these qualities that the Lord is present. And therefore when we meet each other, when we see the exhibition of any of these qualities, we have to do Namaste that I see the divinity in you is emanating through you as kindness. All these qualities are nothing but the glories of the Lord and Bhagawan. Meditate on those glories.

These are your means, the tools for you to meditate on the divine self that you are. Then Bhagavan concludes by giving a complete picture of the creation. Maharsayah, Saptapurve, Chatvarohu, Manamahata, Madbhava Manasa Jata, Esam, Loka, Imah, Prajaha.

एतां विभूतिं योगं च मम यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः |

अहं सर्वस्य प्रभवो मत्तः सर्वं प्रवर्तते |

मच्चित्ता मद्गतप्राणा बोधयन्तः परस्परम् |
snippets.transliteration:
etāṃ vibhūtiṃ yogaṃ ca mama yo vetti tattvataḥ .

ahaṃ sarvasya prabhavo mattaḥ sarvaṃ pravartate .

maccittā madgataprāṇā bodhayantaḥ parasparam .
verseTranslations: He who rightly understands My manifested glory and My Creative Power, beyond doubt attains perfect peace.
I am the source of all; from Me everything flows. Therefore the wise worship Me with unchanging devotion.
With minds concentrated on Me, with lives absorbed in Me, and enlightening each other, they ever feel content and happy.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 10, Vibhuti Yoga, the Lord's Vibhuti, that one which appears to be many is His Vibhuti. By his power of Yoga he appears to us as many. So you go to the jewelry shop, the gold is gold, but the Vibhuti of gold with all the jewelries you see, that's the glory of the gold you see in the jewelry shop. And the yogic power is the jeweler who is the yogic power, that efficient cause with which he creates many out of this one gold. So Bhagavan said that I am the source of all the beings in this chapter, but says not many people can realize that. Even the Rishis, Maharisis and the Devas Sura Ganaha, even they cannot recognize that.

The reason being that I am the source of even those who we consider to be the higher beings, such as Sura Ganaha and Mahari says, and therefore the effect cannot find its own source. All this Saptarisis, sanat, Kumaras and 14 Manus, they're all born out of my mind. In other words, anything which you consider is the source of your being, source of your human race or your existence, all came out of me, born out of my mind. And after that, all the progeny of those are also me. However, it appears to us as many because of our own ignorance about our own self. Now the goal is to unwind that clock from where we started and reached to this point of ignorance and remove that ignorance.

So, Aham, Sarvasya prabhavah, Matta Sarva pravartate Itimatva Bhajant Buddha, Bhavan Samanvitaha, but one whose intellect is steady, Bhava Samanvitaha, they will see me as I am the source of all the beings and everything is pervaded by me with such understanding and such devotion. One who worship me, they obviously will get me and say Machitta Maggat Pranah Bodhayantah Parasparam Kathayantas Chamam nityam to Sinticha Ramanti Cha what we don't have in our life is contentment and delight. Our life is full of discontent and dejection. One of the Swamijis used to say, our life is like the cardiogram. Unhappiness, Unhappiness, little happiness. Unhappiness, little happiness.

That's the story of our life. What we're seeking is exactly the contentment. I want to be satisfied, I want to be content. I want to have bliss. Then I want to enjoy my life. That's what we are looking for.

And everything we have tried so far in our life has its own limitation. So that what we are lacking. The Bhagavan says, the only people who achieves this is Macchitaha, whose mind is absorbed in me. In other words, I have come to the conclusion the Lord is the source of all the being. And we have seen from the logic of spirituality. That is, this world was created by God, by the only material available to him which is own self.

You and I cannot be anything different than his own self. With that, if my mind is resting in him always, anything I see, anything I feel, anything I touch is nothing but his self. Machittaha Madgat Pranaha. Everything that is happening with my life, Prana has. Swamiji takes a much wider view of Prana. Any experience which I have through my sense organs is nothing but his experience alone.

Because I have come to the firm conclusion that this world could not have been created out of anything but the God's own self. There is no other material available to him to create this world but his own self. We constantly remind each other that you and I are nothing but the Lord's only self. It reminds me kind of practical joke. When I was in Dallas group and a lot of Americans who were involved in what I do, they said, neel, I noticed something. You guys always say, hurry home.

Chinmay Mission we meet each other and say, hurry home. Jaishu Krishna, hurry home. He said, I know now why you guys have a better family life. You remind each other. You constantly remind each other. Your wife must be waiting.

Neil, go home, otherwise you'll be in trouble. We remind each other, hurry home. Then we won't have any trouble. He said, Bodhiantha Parasparam we constantly remind each other and enlighten others that there is no other self in you, in I, but the same self. That's why Namaste is I bow down to you. The same self which is in me is in you.

Bodhiantaha parasparam kathayantas chamam nityam. Constantly speaking about me, constantly reminding ourselves in all our actions that everything that is happening in my life, every experience that I'm experiencing is nothing but the Lord's glory alone to Shinti ramanticha. They're content and they're reveling in their own self. Ramanti in Swamiji weeks and elaborate a distinction between Kridanti and Ramanti. Krida requires an outside object to interact with, to play a ball or whatever. That krida ramanti is reveling in yourself, by yourself you're enjoying is Ramanti jahana.

So the two things we always are lacking is this contentment and the joy. Bhagavan said, you can only get by your mind constantly focused on the self. All your activities are devoted to the self. Reminding, enlightening each other that we are the manifestation of the same Lord. And then kathayanti cha and speaking about that will lead you to contentment and enjoyment. Dadami buddhi yogam Chenamam payanthite.

Those who do what we have discussed in the previous verse, Bhagawan says, now what my job is. Te sam satati yuktanam Bhajatam priti purvakam Dadami buddhi yogam Tam yena mama upayanti te. I give them the Buddhi Yoga. Those who are doing what we just discussed, constantly focusing their mind into the self. All their activities are dedicated to the self. Enlightening each other and speaking about that they're content.

Because Bhagavan said, I give them Buddhi yoga. Buddhi Yoga is not this Buddhi that we know as the Mana Buddhi Chitta nahankara. This Buddhi is to decipher the world of objects. With this intellect I try to decide my experiences. Whether this is right or that is right. And I come to that conclusion.

This is right in this experience. So that is the Buddhi. But this is Yogic Buddha. Buddhi we associate with knowing something. Becoming firmly convicted about something is a Buddhi. Waffling is a mind I like, I dislike.

I know I don't know this or that. One I decisively know that's Buddhi. In this case I now decisively know what my self is. There is no doubt left in my mind anymore. Up till now I had a doubt. What is my relationship with the Lord?

Is he really looking after me or not? Well, I'm doing the does he know that I'M doing his puja. Therefore make sure that we publish it in Bharadwani that I did Lakshmi Puja. Lord, you know that it was published in bharadwani. Now it's your responsibility. Bhagavan said, I give them that Buddhi gives you that contentment and joy.

Te yena mam upayanti te. With that Buddhi yoga they come to me. Our journey started from we separated from ourselves by the ignorance started thinking about this is me, this body is me, this mind is me, this intellect is me. And now at my age, I realize that not this body which I was born with and then grew out of the food, but the steel plate in my leg and the acrylic lens in my eye is also me. No difference between the lens I was born with. I actually asked my Abdulman.

I said, doesn't it come with a lifetime warranty? He said, no, it doesn't. I said, how about this one? He said, this has a limited warranty too. All that I consider me turns out to be something I have borrowed from this world. Bhagavan said, once that awareness takes place that there is nothing but the self exists.

You know, there is nothing but I exist. That parallax is now removed between my lower self and the higher self. Desaam eb anu kam parthum aham Agnana jam tamah nasayami atma bhavastah gnana deepena bhasvada. So now it seems like that Bhagavan is doing all that very partially to those who put all this effort. And he really doesn't care about people like us who are constantly busy with our business and our studies and our professions and all that. Bhagavan is ever compassionate and all religion says that, including Christianity.

Bhagawan is never considered as something who is harshly judging people. He's ever compassionate, but he has his own limitations. Unless I seek his compassion, he does not have any power to give and shower his compassion on you. Let's say I have five children and four of them are never talking to me and only one talks to me. My compassion is only revealed to the one who constantly with me. Other four has never ever experienced my compassions because they never allowed me to show my compassion to them.

Swamiji gives another example. That sun is always compassionate to give you sunlight. But as long as I keep the windows closed, he doesn't have any power to give you compassion. He has to patiently wait outside your window till you allow him to come inside your room by opening the windows. Then he can shower his compassion by giving you the light. It is us where we have to become worthy of his compassion.

So Bhagawan said, tesham those we just talked about all the qualities they have achieved. Te sam eva anu kam partam aham agnanajam tamah. What has made me feel different from my own self, the God, my own ignorance. The self is self effulgent. It has its own revelation. It becomes revealed to you by its own glory.

Myself, I'm always aware. I'm under whatever condition I know I exist. That requires no intellectual conviction or no intellectual argument about what I exist or not. Everything else require my intellectual conclusion. Am I an architect or a doctor? I come to the conclusion I cannot be anything but an architect.

I never went to medical school. So all these things which my upadi requires my intellectual conclusion that this is who I am, but I exist requires no intellectual argument. It reveals to me that I exist in my awareness. So Bhagavan says, what has removed you from that revelation? That yourself and the God self is one. Your ignorance created by identification with the non self which is my body, my mind, my intellect that created a avarana availing over my understanding that I, I exist.

And that veiling once removed, no other efforts are required. Swamiji uses a very good example. I'm looking for my key in the room and the key is lying on the table. But the room is pitch dark. Obviously I can't find my key. But somebody with his compassion turned the lights on.

With that compassion of turning the light on. And now the light shines on my key and I see my key. The person didn't have to produce a key. But just out of the compassion he removes the darkness in the room and I find my key. It's in the same way Bhagawan said. The self was always dwelling in my own heart.

It always revealing that I exist. But I consider that I to be this I their existence which I feel all the time. I now take it for granted. It is talking about my body, my mind, my intellect, my achievement, my position, my relationship. That's I. Bhagawan said, with destruction of this ignorance by all the things which you have talked about. I remove that darkness by lighting up Gnanadip in the light of knowledge in your heart.

And you come to this revelation that my existence is of that supreme self.

snippets.reflection:
Today, practice 'Vibhuti vision'—looking for manifestations of the divine wherever you are. Excellence in any field, beauty in any form, moments of genuine wisdom or love—all these are rays of the infinite.

Keep a mental (or written) list of divine glories you encounter. At day's end, reflect on how this practice affected your experience. Did the world seem more alive, more meaningful?

The Gita teaches that a single fraction of God's splendor supports the entire universe. What does it mean to live in constant awareness of that splendor?

My senses are not capable. So Bhagavan Sapita, I will tell you how you should contemplate on me. So he said, Aham Sarvast prabhava matthaha Sarva pravartate. Start thinking first that I pervade everywhere. I am the source of all the being. And Matthaha sarva pravartade ITI mattwa Bhajante Maam Buddhaha Bhava saman vitaha.

Today, practice 'Vibhuti vision'—looking for manifestations of the divine wherever you are. Excellence in any field, beauty in any form, moments of genuine wisdom or love—all these are rays of the infinite.

Keep a mental (or written) list of divine glories you encounter. At day's end, reflect on how this practice affected your experience. Did the world seem more alive, more meaningful?

The Gita teaches that a single fraction of God's splendor supports the entire universe. What does it mean to live in constant awareness of that splendor?

snippets.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |

अहमात्मा गुडाकेश सर्वभूताशयस्थितः |

आदित्यानामहं विष्णुर्ज्योतिषां रविरंशुमान् |
snippets.transliteration:
śrībhagavānuvāca .

ahamātmā guḍākeśa sarvabhūtāśayasthitaḥ .

ādityānāmahaṃ viṣṇurjyotiṣāṃ raviraṃśumān .
verseTranslations: Lord Shri Krishna replied: So be it, My beloved fried! I will unfold to thee some of the chief aspects of My glory. Of its full extent there is no end.
O Arjuna! I am the Self, seated in the hearts of all beings; I am the beginning and the life, and I am the end of them all.

And that's why Arjuna said I am having difficulty.

I cannot conceptualize in my mind what is that all pervading entity is all about. You need to give me some pointers. Something which I can tangibly can relate to, which I can conceptualize in my mind, in my meditation, in my contemplation, where I can hang on to that entity as the divine entity, as the one all pervading entity. And then I may make some progress. So tell me all your glories without leaving anything behind, because I never get tired of listening to it. You tell me all these times.

So tell me what is it that I should be looking for in this universe which I can identify as your manifestation? Everything I see right now, even though I have understood, come very short of being divine. So what should I focus on? So in response to that, we have this next 22 verses which Bhagavan gives Various pointers to meditate upon. It is not very clear to us how to identify divinity. So Bhagavan said, you find divinity in everything that is best among their own spheres.

So Bhagavan starts his response by clarifying that we are not coming to any new conclusion now, that only the best is where I am, but not the rest. So verse 20, it clearly makes a summary statement that let's not get deviated from what we already talked about, that I am the source of all the beings or seychina without living anything about. But it may be more prominent in some this divinity to identify. So you say aham, atma gudakesha sarva bhuta asayasthitah. So let's make it clear that I reside as the core of all the beings. There is no exception.

Just because we say the one is more manifesting divinity and other is not, that does not mean the other is devoid of my presence. So very first clarification is I reside in all the beings as the core of their beings. Aham adhisha madhyacha bhutanam anta evacha. I am the origin, Adi middle and the end of all the beings. All the beings are part of the Prakriti. They have beginning and end.

They come from somewhere. They exist in time and space for a while and then they end. But all the time the source of that being is me. I am the one who sustained them during their existence. And I am the one they dissolve into. That you should never forget, Bhagavanji, even in your contemplation, that there is no exception.

There is nothing which can exist without my presence. But for your question was what to contemplate upon. How can I conceptualize the divinity, the self, which is all pervading, immortal? So I'll give you the pointers as Swamiji says in next 21 verses. Bhagawan gave 75 pointers. It is like something which is obvious we can identify with.

When the lights are on in this room, we know the electricity is there. When lights were off, electricity was still here. It just was not available for my perception. The electricity always pervades in this room in all this electrical wiring. I can only prove when I show you the presence of it in some manifest form. So the manifest forms rest of the chapter talks about.

And because it is given to Arjuna in his time, we obviously walk through several of these Vedic references and Puranic references. Krishna was talking today. He will say, I am the iPhone 7among all smartphones. I'M Google among all technology companies. So we relate to things which are familiar to us. And therefore the analogies given are more in line with the culture at the time.

And what Arjuna can identify with, he starts out from the higher, then come down to the level which in a day to day life Arjuna can identify. Adityanam Aham Vishnaho among the Aditya, I am Vishnu. Aditi's sons are Aditya. As Swamiji points out here that Aditi is mentioned in a big Veda. Aditi means limitless. Aditi is mother of all celestial beings.

And then in Puranic time, Aditi was also shown as wife of Kashyap Rushi. But from the Vedic point of view, Aditi was the perennial mother, the primordial mother which gives birth to this universe. Celestial beings According to our scriptures and puranas, somewhere the four aditya are mentioned. Somewhere six adityas mentioned. But eventually they settled on 12 adityas. If the word is used singularly, it means Sun.

When it mentioned in plurality, it means 12. Aditya somewhat identifies with the 12 months of the year. Each one is in charge of one segment of the. So among the Aditya, Bhagavan says I am a Vishnu. Vishnu is all pervading. Vishnu means who has long reach.

You can probably say that the one is the longest day in a year. The son which is in charge of that day is Vishnu. But basically saying among all the celestial that becomes very apparent to me is Vishnu because he is all pervading. Consider me as I am Vishnu among all Adityas. Jyoti, Sam Ravihi Anshuman among the luminaries in the sky, those objects or entities were self effulgent. I am the radiant Sun.

Sun is something obvious to us. But we can only relate to Sun. Among the luminaries in the sky, I am Sun. Marichihi Marutam Asmi among the winds, wind is air in different forms. It can be hurricane, it can be tornado, it can be storm or it can be a pleasant breeze. Marutas in plurality are in charge of all these different types of winds.

Now obviously in Vedic time, we were reliant on the natural forces. Natural forces are something we are trying to understand. So each natural force is a deity. We came to one conclusion that if there is an activity, there is somebody in charge of the activity. Activity cannot take place unless there is somebody guiding it. If I see an effect, there has to be a cause.

If I see a wind moving, there is A cause somebody is in charge. Somebody making sure that in this condition only this thing can occur. So marutas were in charge of winds. And each type of wind has a different maruta. The Marichi is among the best because it is the in charge of the pleasant breeze which we can enjoy. We are afraid of tornado, we are afraid of hurricane.

But we are very happy when this pleasant breeze is flowing. Among all the Marutas, Nakshatranam, Ahamshashi, Nakshatrana, the asterisms or constellations among them all the arrangement of stars in the sky. In Nakshatra, moon appears to be travelling through this star clusters. So when I see at night the sky, the asterisms are dimly lit, but the moon is brightly lit. He seems like the king of all these asterisms. He is traveling through all these Nakshatras, you know, as if the king of all the Nakshatras.

So therefore he says, among the Nakshatras, I am Shashi. He say, consider me as the sun. Night time I see moon. He says, consider me as moon. If it is windy, consider that my Maruta are working. But when you feel at ease, most at comfort, I am Marichi.

And among all the celestial beings, I am Vishnu. Without Vishnu, nothing can exist. So therefore, when you see anything, something which catches your imagination, something that can invoke these divine feelings in you, consider that my presence you are experiencing. The next verse says Vedanam Sama Vedo Asmi. Obviously, Arjuna was a product of a Vedic culture. We consider Vedas the basis of our culture.

If things cannot have a proof in Vedas, it is not true. Truth has to have basis in Vedas. And obviously we know there are four Vedas. Rug Veda, Sam Veda, Yajurveda and Tharva Veda. Sam Veda is most pleasant. Saam Veda is basically as we have heard all in poetry.

Rug Veda is in prose, Sama Veda in poetry. So listening to Sama Veda is most pleasant. Even today if you listen to our Panditji, he is Samavedi. When he chant, it really catches your attention. Chanting normally going on in temple, everybody is talking. You know, when he starts in a Sam Vedi chanting, everybody is quiet.

Something really unique, something which catches your attention, something which catches your mind is Sama Veda. Among all the Vedas, I am Sama Veda. Knowledge is in all Vedas. But something that can invoke the sense of divinity in your heart is when you have this beautiful Poetry sung in a proper raga. So if the Vedas discussion is going on, if it is not interesting to me, Swami says the Ghata pata Gadabada. You know there's two pandas talking about this Vedic discussion.

They give example a Ghata and a pata, Ghata and a pata. One who cannot get anything out of it say all this. They spell Gaddapada garbhat. They are doing garbat. That's where the garbhat words come from. Because we can understand what they are talking about.

So it's a garbhat to us. Even though they may be talking at the highest level. But even the one who has no knowledge of Veda, he listens to the Sama Veda. He will have that divinity experience in his heart. Bharu Bhagavan said, among Vedas, I am Sama Veda Devanam Asmi, Vasavah, Vasava Indra. Among the Devas, I am Indra.

We know Indra is the king of all the Devas. He is the mightiest, he is the wealthiest. He is the greatest kingdom Splendor. Deva Loka is supposed to be a place for enjoyment. Even the Devas have all these politics among themselves. Who is higher, who is lower.

They have as much jealousy as us. This is serial Kantosima. Indra's wife Paulami is the bad one and Santosima is the good one. One harasses people and one tries to save people. So among Devas, in other words, even if you reach to a level of goodness, your shortcomings will still be there. If I want to be happy and say, if I become a millionaire or a billionaire, I'll be happy.

All your shortcomings will be with you when you become billionaire. What is making me unhappy will make me unhappy. Then also just having wealth, just having accomplishment is not a remedy for any happiness or experiencing any divinity. But even when you consider that as the basis of divinity, I am among all Devasam Indra, most accomplished, the king of all. From a material wealth perspective, Indriyana Manasthyasmi. Even in the previous line, he also said among the Devasam Indra Deva means to Dev is to illuminate.

That which illuminates is the Deva.

snippets.sanskrit:
महर्षीणां भृगुरहं गिरामस्म्येकमक्षरम् |

अश्वत्थः सर्ववृक्षाणां देवर्षीणां च नारदः |

उच्चैःश्रवसमश्वानां विद्धि माममृतोद्भवम् |
snippets.transliteration:
maharṣīṇāṃ bhṛgurahaṃ girāmasmyekamakṣaram .

aśvatthaḥ sarvavṛkṣāṇāṃ devarṣīṇāṃ ca nāradaḥ .

uccaiḥśravasamaśvānāṃ viddhi māmamṛtodbhavam .
verseTranslations: Of the great seers I am Bhrigu, of words I am Om, of offerings I am the silent prayer, among things immovable I am the Himalayas.
Of trees I am the sacred Fig-tree, of the Divine Seers Narada, of the heavenly singers I am Chitraratha, their Leader, and of sages I am Kapila.
Know that among horses I am Pegasus, the heaven-born; among the lordly elephants I am the White one, and I am the Ruler among men.

So whenever you see these qualities, know that I am present in that being. So that is one point. And then he said that aham, Sarvasya prabhavah, Mattha sarvapravartha.

There, there is nothing that is not based in me. I am the source of all things and being, and everything proceeds from me. So Bhagawan has made it very clear that there is nothing which is devoid of him. But Arjun obviously wanted to get examples in his world which he can relate to. So that's what he said. Keshu, Keshu, Bhaveshu, Chintyo, Asi, Bhagavanmaya.

In what different forms that I see in this world which I can worship as your presence. If I have to find examples of divinity which are worthy of worship, tell me, how do I find them, how do I recognize them and how do I approach them? Therefore, Bhagavan said that when you see anything which is best among that category, consider that's worthy of worshipping. Excellence is worthy of worshipping. Yoga, Karmasu, Kaushalam, Kaushalam, the proficiency is worshipable. Anything which is efficient and proficient.

Bhagawan said, consider that is my manifestation. It is worthy of worship. So therefore, Bhagavan has been giving various examples of best among those categories. And we have seen so far as Swamiji explains that Bhagawan started with Vedic examples based rooted in the culture of Vedic period. And then he has given some examples which are common between Vedic and Puranic period. And then he has been giving examples from Puranic period.

In other words, he's covering all that Arjuna has experienced, ancestral, past, folklore. And then Also the day to day world where I'm trying to find divinity. I try to find divinity in my great culture. Also try to find divinity in the folklore which I've heard from people. And I also try to find divinity in my world. Verses 27, 28, 29 continues in that tradition.

We are seeing more Quranic examples. The Uchehi Sava sama aswanam, Vidhimam, Amrutod bhavam among the horses Uchesrava which came out of this endeavor of finding nectar. It is the story of churning of the milky ocean to find nectar immortality. But by product of that effort we can call Riddhi and Siddhi. Swamiji explains here. This churning of ocean is nothing but churning your own mind.

One side is bad and other side is good thoughts. Bad thoughts and good thoughts are churning your mind. What comes out of it are the byproducts I call Riddhi and Siddhi. When we try to achieve the final goal of liberation or immortality or ultimate happiness, whichever you want to call it, we are constantly churning our mind to find that ultimate happiness. In that process we achieve some accomplishments. Those are Siddhi and Riddhi.

We get along our pursuit of happiness. We have not got the happiness yet but we get some things which are by product of a pursuit of happiness. So me buying a BMW or Albany and Maulik going to Hawaii. You people went to Hawaii and I bought a BMW X5 Hybrid over the weekend. So we covered two bases of my vedantic journey. Now you have to go to Starbucks to complete the third leg of it all that is in pursuit of happiness.

That's why I want to go to Hawaii. That's why I want to buy BMW. But that is not the end goal. Bhagavan says the end goal is to find the nectar. The nectar is endless happiness without any break in it. That is what we call immortality.

That is also we call liberation. So this churning of ocean Vidhi maam amrutod bhavam. This flying horse came out of this pursuit of happiness as an excellent achievement from the pursuit of finding something else. They were not looking for flying horse, they were looking for nectar. But what came out flying horse. The best among the horses.

We become excellent in our profession. That actually was the goal. I want to make more money. Then I became very proficient in my profession. We consider unfortunately that is the goal. That never was my goal.

My goal was to be happy. But I sometimes become so Enamored by my own achievement that I just stop right there, that I'm the best. So Bhagavan said, among horses, Uche Shravaha, the flying horse which came out of the journey of ocean, Airavatam, Gajendrana both came out of the same pursuit. The white elephant with many tusks came out. Airavat and Cheshrava, the flying horse came. They both came in same pursuit of finding nectar.

The airavat was given to Indra, but horse was given to Daitya. But both came out as excellent examples of something you can accomplish by your pursuit of finding nectar. Bliss Naranamcha, Naradhipah among men. I am the king among man. When somebody becomes as powerful as one can be, he is called king. Airavat is an example among elephants, Uchesa among horses.

So in all living beings you find example of excellence. In our culture the king is considered divine representation. Not only in our culture, but all Western cultures also King was considered divine. He is the one who is supporting the whole kingdom by his own action. Therefore he is considered divine. Anything that is excellent among man, among animals, among beings of any kind considered to be my manifestation is worthy of worshipping.

Because the original question was Keshu, Keshu, Chabhesu. So Bhagavan is giving him various examples. Ayudhanam Aham Vajraha. Not only beings but things. Among the weapons and Vajra. Vajra was conceived by Indra as the weapon which can kill the demon Vritrasur.

He was the snake in a human form. The snake is generally considered poisonous. So something which is poisonous and in stopping my progress bad thoughts in my mind. So Vhtrasu is my negative tendencies. And to kill that I need a weapon which is powerful and effective. So here Indra to kill Vritrasur wanted Vajra, the ultimate weapon to kill this demon who was stopping the course of rivers.

So he was someone who was stopping the progress. So Vritrasur can be only be killed by something which is very pious and self sacrificing. So Indra found the Dhiji is the right candidate. He has all the positive qualities selfless in his endeavors. And when the Dichi approached, he agreed to give up his body. And then his bones were used to make this Vajra.

The meaning of this metaphor is if you have to kill the negative tendencies of your mind, you have to sacrifice. Selfless sacrifice is the only sure weapon to kill the negativity in your mind. Of all the weapons to kill your negativity Bhagwan said, I am Vajra Denunam Asmi Kamaduk among cows. The milch cow was also described in chapter three in verse 10 where Bhagavan said Sahayagna prajasrustva Purvacha Prajapati Anena Prasi vistadvam ishacha asthu isht Kama dhak. In the beginning Prajapati said, I have created Praja in the same time Yajna. This Yajna will be your Kamadhenu.

This Yajna will be your cow which fulfills all your desires. So the Kamadenu is something which has capacity to fulfill all your desires. And as for Purana, Vasisthta had this Kamadhina. Vasistha had this cow. This cow which can give whatever you desire like a genie in other Arabic tale. Whatever you desire, genie can present.

Bhagavan said, kamadhanu is your cooperative endeavors Yajna spirit. When you work together, when you combine your resources of your community, of your family, of your country then you can get whatever you want. Dhienuna masmikamadu. In our culture cow is sacred because cow supports life. In olden days cow provided everything. Cow provided milk for sustaining bodies.

Cow also provided bullocks to till the land. Cow also provided cow dung for source of fuel. That cow dung was also his building material to plaster the floors. The cow has ultimate giving capacity that it can sustain life. And and therefore cow is considered sacred. But among all cows Bhagavan said, I am Kama Dhuk.

I am Kama Dhenu which has capacity to fulfill all desires. And as Bhagawana said in chapter three, Kama Denu is your Yajna spirit. When you work selflessly and work together you can fulfill all your desires. Prajanastya Asmi Kandarpah among the progenitor. I am that instinct to create progeny. This instinct, Bhagavan said, is divine.

Normally any sexual instinct we consider it to be negative, not good. Our culture clearly says that's divine. Anything which is natural has to be divine. So this instinct to further your progeny is a divine instinct. Attraction for the opposite sex is put in beings by Bhagavan for a reason and therefore it is divine. Swamiji used to say that if you don't get attracted by opposite sex, go and see a doctor.

There's something wrong with you. That is something natural and divine. It is how you use it, how you Manage it makes it either divine or devilish. Prajanas chasmi Kandarpaha. Kandarpah is that innate attraction for the opposite sex in you. I am that Sarpanam Asmi Vasukihi.

We have discussed two types of snakes, Sarpa and naga. Sarpa is the unhooded snake. Hooded snake is Naga. Snakes like pythons and other garden snakes. And they are not many times poisonous. Python can kill you, but it's not poisonous.

There's a Naga Panchami day at least in Surat where I grew up. All these guys will bring cobra in in their little basket. And my mother will offer milk and give some donation. Naga cobra is poisonous. But Bhagavan said even that poisonous instinct in beings is also divine. Because there is no other source for this poisonous instinct than God alone.

Everything in this world, even though it seems negative from our perspective. When you change the perspective it becomes natural and necessary. I very recently read an article I think in New York Times. Forest fires are necessary for the survival of the forest. Now that was complete revelation to me. Because every time I see forest fire in California on the TV I say why can't they do something?

Can they not figure out how to stop this thing? Or what is the purpose of this? And it really opened my eyes. That article said without forest fire, forest cannot survive because the undergrowth will be so dense the trees won't survive. The forest fires clean up the forest every year now, obviously out of control. Anything creates disasters.

And most of the forest fires are man made or man created. They are not naturally created. So anything which I see negative may have been over manipulated by someone. But the actual phenomenon, whether it seems negative or positive, my perspective is natural and divine. So therefore you say Sarpanam Asmi Vasukihi. Among serpents and Vasuki Vasukhi is the smallest snake on Shiva's finger.

Also used as the rope in churning the ocean. And Vasuki also selflessly volunteered to become that rope which are on the ocean among snakes. And Vasuki who gives his services selflessly for the common good. Anantahacha Asminagana. And among Nagam Ananta Ananta endless. Another name of Ananta Nageshanahaya.

We have seen Vishnu lying on the sheshanag in a slumber. Lakshmi Ji massaging his feet and Lotus coming out of his navel and Brahmaji sitting on it. So this thousand hooded snake is nothing but my mind. It is thousand different desires in thousand different directions. With that capacity when it is associated with Tamas and Rajas, it has creative urge.
snippets.reflection:
Today, practice 'Vibhuti vision'—looking for manifestations of the divine wherever you are. Excellence in any field, beauty in any form, moments of genuine wisdom or love—all these are rays of the infinite.

Keep a mental (or written) list of divine glories you encounter. At day's end, reflect on how this practice affected your experience. Did the world seem more alive, more meaningful?

The Gita teaches that a single fraction of God's splendor supports the entire universe. What does it mean to live in constant awareness of that splendor?

snippets.title: Day 138: Divine Manifestations
snippets.sanskrit:
पवनः पवतामस्मि रामः शस्त्रभृतामहम् |

सर्गाणामादिरन्तश्च मध्यं चैवाहमर्जुन |

अक्षराणामकारोऽस्मि द्वन्द्वः सामासिकस्य च |
snippets.transliteration:
pavanaḥ pavatāmasmi rāmaḥ śastrabhṛtāmaham .

sargāṇāmādirantaśca madhyaṃ caivāhamarjuna .

akṣarāṇāmakāro.asmi dvandvaḥ sāmāsikasya ca .
verseTranslations: I am the Wind among purifiers, the King Rama among warriors; I am the Crocodile among the fishes, and I am the Ganges among rivers.
I am the Beginning, the Middle and the End in creation; among sciences, I am the science of Spirituality; I am the Discussion among disputants.
Of letters I am A; I am the copulative in compound words; I am Time inexhaustible; and I am the all-pervading Preserver.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing Chapter 10 Vibhuti Yoga Yoga of Divine Glories. As we have seen Arjuna after listening to the whole discourse from Bhagavan, Nature of the Supreme Self, he said, but I need to know. So in verse 18 he says, Vittarena atmano yogam Vibhutim cha janardhana puyaha kathaya truptihi snowto nastyami amrutam. Tell me again in detail, va janadini, your yoga power and your imminent glory, because I do not feel satisfied hearing your life giving nectar like speech. In other words, he said, give me some examples. So Bhagavan said, divyahi atma vibhuta yah, my glories are divine.

Pradhanyadha kuru sreshta na ashya anta vistarashyami. There is no end to this glory, but I can give you some prominent examples. So Bhavan clearly clarified to Arjuna then I'm going to give you some prominent examples. They do not constitute my entire glory, but they will give you some idea of where to see my presence. So we have been seeing many, many examples right from the Vedic period to Puranic period. And Bhagavan is now even coming down to our day to day experiences.

Pavanaha Pavatamasmi. Something which we experience in phenomenal nature. Everything and every being is nothing but my own self. Because he said everything proceeds from me and I am the source of all things and beings. There is no other thing which has created this universe. When we see an effect there has to be two causes.

One is the efficient cause, somebody to know how to make that thing to come into existence. And one is the material to create that thing is that pizza. We need a pizza maker and pizza ingredients. So if you see pizza here, you can't simply say well the pizza just appeared here. We are Chinma mission, we are divine people. We don't need to order pizza.

Pizza just appears here. We know that an intelligent person will not believe that. He knows that if there is pizza there, there is a pizza maker and he had the ingredients for the pizza. So the same way, if this world exists, there is the material cause and efficient cause. Material cause is something which we have difficulty understanding. We think if Bhagavan knows everything, obviously he knows how to create this world.

The problem is where did he find the material? How do we create something? I'm an architect, so I can create buildings. Because I know how to design building. Just knowing how to create building doesn't create building. I need to have materials.

Go to Home Depot or Lowe's to buy that material. Home Depot and say, where do you get materials? We get from our suppliers. So you can go up to the source of the material, where it came from. So in this case, if we find the source of the material which Bhagavan used to create this Jagat you can always say that Bhagavan found the material from X. Then X becomes greater Bhagavan than the Bhagawan who created it.

Go to X and say, where did you get the material From Y. Then the Y becomes greater than X because he had the original material. You know, Y and say, where did you get the material? Z had the material when the Z becomes greater God than Y. So this exercise is futile because we cannot get to the source of the material. You have to come to the conclusion that Bhagavan was the source of the material.

In Bhagawan, there's only one thing which he did not have to buy, borrow or steal. That is his own self. Everything we acquire in this world, we bought from somebody. We borrowed from somebody. We were stolen from somebody. But one thing I never had to acquire that is my own self.

That which I call I. I did not acquire it from anywhere. I didn't buy from anywhere. So that's the only material available to Bhagavan. So he created this Jagat using his knowledge of creating this universe as an efficient cause. And he also used the material available to him with his own self. So he became the material cause and the efficient cause for this universe.

Therefore he said, everything proceeds from me and I am the source of all things. However, that is not something for us to easily understand. So give me some examples of glories. It may be difficult to find glory in something which is average. But we can find in something which is really excellent. If you have a water jug and if you just a little salt in it and you taste it you won't know that there is salt in it.

But there's a lot of salt in it. And you taste it, you know there's salt in it. The Bhagawan has been giving several prominent examples. Sarjanam, Adihicha, Antacha, Madhyamcha Evam, Aham, Arjunah. In the creation for anything which is created and the beginning, the middle and the end, there is no other material to create anything, to sustain anything or destroy anything. The same material which was used to create this Jagat, everything in Jagat in this universe is also created by the same original material.

So Bhagawan said, any creation you see in this world, I am the beginning, the middle and the end. In verse 33 he says, Aksaranam Akaro Asmi. snippets.sanskrit:
वृष्णीनां वासुदेवोऽस्मि पाण्डवानां धनञ्जयः |

दण्डो दमयतामस्मि नीतिरस्मि जिगीषताम् |

यच्चापि सर्वभूतानां बीजं तदहमर्जुन |
snippets.transliteration:
vṛṣṇīnāṃ vāsudevo.asmi pāṇḍavānāṃ dhanañjayaḥ .

daṇḍo damayatāmasmi nītirasmi jigīṣatām .

yaccāpi sarvabhūtānāṃ bījaṃ tadahamarjuna .
verseTranslations: I am Shri Krishna among the Vishnu-clan and Arjuna among the Pandavas; of the saints I am Vyasa, and I am Shukracharya among the sages.
I am the Sceptre of rulers, the Strategy of the conquerors, the Silence of mystery, the Wisdom of the wise.
I am the Seed of all being, O Arjuna! No creature moving or unmoving can live without Me.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing chapter 10. We are coming to the conclusion, chapter 10. So far we have seen that Bhagavan has been hammering on the same idea which had been discussed many times before in Bhagavad Gita, that I am the source of all things and beings. The central theme of Bhagavad Gita is there is unity in diversity. Even though we see things in this world as world of plurality, that each individual is different from each other, each thing is different from each other. But there is a unseen thread running through all the things and beings which are so different from each other because they all come from the same source.

So there is similarity, there is something which is common to all. That's Bhagavan's basically theme. All throughout the Bhagavad Gita, he had been explaining that in various ways. And we have seen in the beginning of this chapter, Bhagawan has reiterated that Aham, sarvasya prabhavah matta sarvapravartade. I am the source of all beings and everything proceeds from me. It is something like a scientist would say that everything started from Big Bang in our universe, and everything which we see in this universe is nothing but came from the Big Bang.

So when you and I are nothing but the product of the Big Bang, when there is nothing but hydrogen and helium, now we have all this complex mechanism, complex universe that we are trying to understand. So if somebody comes out and says, that's all good, but explain to me how can I see that evidence of the Big Bang or the source of that Big Bang in the universe, then people can start explaining that what you see in the galaxies, you see the hydrogen in the galaxy, the microwave radiation, it all comes from that original sense. But you still have to go and give some examples. So here Arjuna says the same thing. I understood that everything comes from that supreme reality. You, the supreme reality.

Many sages in the past have said the same thing, and you are also now saying the same thing. I'm not doubting those sages nor I have any doubt in you. But can you give me some examples in my life where I can feel your presence in the world of objects and beings? That's what Bhagawan has given 54 examples, very reluctantly. Okay, alas, I explained all of this, but you still want to know. It's like we all can learn Bhagavad Gita and say that God is everywhere.

God has no form, God is not a man, he's not a woman. But then the ends it. But I want to Bhagavan's Darshan because we are stuck with our perception of the reality. Our perception is limited by our mind and intellect and our senses. We also want to see Bhagavan in our image which we have created in our mind. Arjuna says the same thing.

Show me evidence of your presence in my world. The Bhagavan has given these 54 examples, starting from all the Vedic entities to Pavranik, and then in the natural phenomena and everything else which you can think about, including some negative ones. Dandaha, damaya, damasmi, and among all the cheating and gambling. So he wanted to convey to Arjuna that I am not just in good, but everything that's seemingly evil to you in your world, that also exists only because I exist. And then the last four _Verses_ are somewhat conclusion of this chapter where Bhagawan says, okay, I have exhausted all examples which I can give you, but there is not really any end to this discussion. You can't continue to say, just give me one more example, just give me one more example.

So you say, yacha API sarva bhutanam bijam tat am Arjuna. Whatever is the source of anything. Because anything as we have described in this world is an effect. When I see something which I can perceive through my senses, it's an effect. There has to be a cause, there has to be a source. So you see a child, you know there are parents for that child.

A child cannot exist without parents. So the parents are the source of the child. We see pizza, we know there is a pizza maker somewhere. So everything we know has a source. And right now our conclusion is everything has different sources. Wood comes from somewhere, steel comes from somewhere else.

Then all this comes together and we build buildings. Bhagawan here says that whatever you see in this thing, in this world is a being. Being means that which has existence in the being, that which comes into being, which comes into existence in this space and time. I am the source, no matter what you see. Ya PI sarvabhutanam Bijam, Tad Aham Arjun. I am the primordial cause for all things and beings.

We understand this analogy of a seed and anything which comes out of it. A tree, an animal, a human being from the seed. But in that case, the seed is destroyed. After that manifestation is completed, when tree comes into existence, that seed is gone. But in this case, that seed is immutable. It remains as the support for that manifestation.

So that cause remains support for the effect. There are three laws of causation, Swamiji teaches. One of them is said, if you remove the cause from the effect, the effect does not remain. You remove the cause from this universe which is the Supreme Being. The universe does not remain. The gold is the cause for gold ornament.

You remove the gold from gold ornament. Gold ornament does not remain. Naatad Asthi, Vina Yat Shyam, Atmaya, Bhutam, Characharam. Without me, the moving or unmoving cannot exist in this world. Just as if we remove the gold, the gold ornament cannot exist. So Bhagawan has basically concluded that all these examples are given for you to understand and try to train your mind to start seeing things as they are.

They're all made up of the same material. This universe has one source. Eventually you can trace down the source to that one entity which remains immutable. That the uncaused cause, there is no source for that cause. If you find a source for that cause, therefore can go further and find that source. So it's one point of time there will be a cause which is no cause.

So therefore Bhagavan said, I am that cause. And without that nothing can exist. You remove that from this universe. It's like in my dream. My own thoughts are the source of my dream. But when I go into the deep sleep, that dream cannot exist.

Because without my mind, the source there is the dream cannot exist. Bhagawan here says, conclusion of all my examples is I am the ultimate cause. I am the ultimate source of all things. And being no thing moving or unmoving. This is the very efficient way in Vedanta to explain that includes everything when it's the moving and unmoving. So all sentient beings and all inert things, all included in it, thing cannot exist without my presence.

There is no end to my Vibhuti. You cannot count all the manifestations. If you want to catalog all the manifestations of physical world, in this physical world, even that's not possible. So now we have in our science all this Webb telescope so we can see as far as possible. But let's say you want to catalog all the galaxies and all the stars in this universe. No matter what kind of a telescope you will have.

There are billions and billions of stars and millions and millions of galaxies. It's almost impossible. And by the time you catalog all of them, the new galaxies are formed and new stars are born, new old stars. It's a continuous change. Therefore, in Sanskrit it's called Jagat universe. But Jagat is that which is constantly changing.

Something which is constantly changing, there is no end to its manifestation. If it's constantly changing, you cannot count it. But by the time you catalog what you have known, new things come into existence. We were in high school, we thought, if I learn this physics and chemistry, then I'll be good at it. Well, physics and chemistry keeps changing in my own lifetime, so even that is not possible. Na antah asti mama divyanaam vibhuti nam paranti.

But there is no end to the divine glories, the physical manifestation of myself. But I told you some in detail just because you asked for it. Now you can figure out rest by yourself. Basically you teach somebody how to think, then the person can think himself rather than spoon feeding him. Give them example and then a person can learn on his own how to detect that. If you figure out if you are working in a jewelry shop and you figure out how to test a gold ornament, whether it is gold or not, once you have one example, you can then apply that on any other example.

So taking all these 54 examples, you have seen the method that anything which you see which has some excellence, that's because of the presence of that Lord. Now I told you all that you should be able to detect this. But in conclusion I can tell you. Yat Vibhuti mat satvam Srimat urjitam eva va tattat eva avagatschatvam mama tej ansa sambhavah. Whatever you see in this world, the world of your experiences, as Swamiji says that Jagat is not just the physical world which is changing outside the world of my experiences, world of my perception that is changing constantly, whatever in your perception, in your experience, you see as Vibhuti mat which has glory or its own excellence, Sattvam existence Sat is which is real, asat which is unreal. So Sattvam one context purity also that which has existence Srimat prosperous And Urjitam energetic.

So anything which you see in this world, in nature, in society, in your community, in your family, where you see these qualities, you should know that they are all coming from me alone. Tatta Eva Avagacvam Mama Teja Ansa Sambhavam. It's coming into existence because iota of my being. So don't consider that if I add up all this manifestation someday with some supercomputer and add it up, that will be Bhagavan. He said no, no, that will be just an iota of my being. Swamiji gives a very good example that my mind has all the capabilities.

But once in a while it gets confused or deluded by some random thought. And then it goes into a wrong direction. It creates this scenario which is unrealistic. That doesn't mean I completely have lost all my ability to think. My 99% of my ability is still valid. But right now it's dormant.

It's covered by the one delusion. But when that one delusion is removed, 100% of my ability will be back. So Bhagavan is Satchitananda is ever pure. But this manifestation, the Prakriti, the world of plurality comes into existence by just one part which creates this disturbance which they call the Hiranyagarva cumulative Vasanas. Of all the beings and things which are in this universe, that one portion is now creating a new world. So when I go to sleep, my world comes to an end.

In a deep sleep there is no world. I don't exist, world does not exist. But my Vasras are there in dormant form. That dormant vasanas will find the appropriate condition. My body has rested fully. I will wake up and they will all come back and manifest and create my own world.

In case of Ishvara also, Ishwara remains as pure as Brahman. But all the cumulative asanas of of the Jagat are still in a dormant form.
