snippets.title: Day 141: The Source of All
snippets.sanskrit:
नान्तोऽस्ति मम दिव्यानां विभूतीनां परन्तप |

यद्यद्विभूतिमत्सत्त्वं श्रीमदूर्जितमेव वा |

अथवा बहुनैतेन किं ज्ञातेन तवार्जुन |
snippets.transliteration:
nānto.asti mama divyānāṃ vibhūtīnāṃ parantapa .

yadyadvibhūtimatsattvaṃ śrīmadūrjitameva vā .

athavā bahunaitena kiṃ jñātena tavārjuna .
verseTranslations: O Arjuna! The aspects of My divine life are endless. I have mentioned but a few by way of illustration.
Whatever is glorious, excellent, beautiful and mighty, be assured that it comes from a fragment of My splendour.
But what is the use of all these details to thee? O Arjuna! I sustain this universe with only small part of Myself."
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing chapter 10. We are coming to the conclusion, chapter 10. So far we have seen that Bhagavan has been hammering on the same idea which had been discussed many times before in Bhagavad Gita, that I am the source of all things and beings. The central theme of Bhagavad Gita is there is unity in diversity. Even though we see things in this world as world of plurality, that each individual is different from each other, each thing is different from each other. But there is a unseen thread running through all the things and beings which are so different from each other because they all come from the same source.

So there is similarity, there is something which is common to all. That's Bhagavan's basically theme. All throughout the Bhagavad Gita, he had been explaining that in various ways. And we have seen in the beginning of this chapter, Bhagawan has reiterated that Aham, sarvasya prabhavah matta sarvapravartade. I am the source of all beings and everything proceeds from me. It is something like a scientist would say that everything started from Big Bang in our universe, and everything which we see in this universe is nothing but came from the Big Bang.

So when you and I are nothing but the product of the Big Bang, when there is nothing but hydrogen and helium, now we have all this complex mechanism, complex universe that we are trying to understand. So if somebody comes out and says, that's all good, but explain to me how can I see that evidence of the Big Bang or the source of that Big Bang in the universe, then people can start explaining that what you see in the galaxies, you see the hydrogen in the galaxy, the microwave radiation, it all comes from that original sense. But you still have to go and give some examples. So here Arjuna says the same thing. I understood that everything comes from that supreme reality. You, the supreme reality.

Many sages in the past have said the same thing, and you are also now saying the same thing. I'm not doubting those sages nor I have any doubt in you. But can you give me some examples in my life where I can feel your presence in the world of objects and beings? That's what Bhagawan has given 54 examples, very reluctantly. Okay, alas, I explained all of this, but you still want to know. It's like we all can learn Bhagavad Gita and say that God is everywhere.

God has no form, God is not a man, he's not a woman. But then the ends it. But I want to Bhagavan's Darshan because we are stuck with our perception of the reality. Our perception is limited by our mind and intellect and our senses. We also want to see Bhagavan in our image which we have created in our mind. Arjuna says the same thing.

Show me evidence of your presence in my world. The Bhagavan has given these 54 examples, starting from all the Vedic entities to Pavranik, and then in the natural phenomena and everything else which you can think about, including some negative ones. Dandaha, damaya, damasmi, and among all the cheating and gambling. So he wanted to convey to Arjuna that I am not just in good, but everything that's seemingly evil to you in your world, that also exists only because I exist. And then the last four _Verses_ are somewhat conclusion of this chapter where Bhagawan says, okay, I have exhausted all examples which I can give you, but there is not really any end to this discussion. You can't continue to say, just give me one more example, just give me one more example.

So you say, yacha API sarva bhutanam bijam tat am Arjuna. Whatever is the source of anything. Because anything as we have described in this world is an effect. When I see something which I can perceive through my senses, it's an effect. There has to be a cause, there has to be a source. So you see a child, you know there are parents for that child.

A child cannot exist without parents. So the parents are the source of the child. We see pizza, we know there is a pizza maker somewhere. So everything we know has a source. And right now our conclusion is everything has different sources. Wood comes from somewhere, steel comes from somewhere else.

Then all this comes together and we build buildings. Bhagawan here says that whatever you see in this thing, in this world is a being. Being means that which has existence in the being, that which comes into being, which comes into existence in this space and time. I am the source, no matter what you see. Ya PI sarvabhutanam Bijam, Tad Aham Arjun. I am the primordial cause for all things and beings.

We understand this analogy of a seed and anything which comes out of it. A tree, an animal, a human being from the seed. But in that case, the seed is destroyed. After that manifestation is completed, when tree comes into existence, that seed is gone. But in this case, that seed is immutable. It remains as the support for that manifestation.

So that cause remains support for the effect. There are three laws of causation, Swamiji teaches. One of them is said, if you remove the cause from the effect, the effect does not remain. You remove the cause from this universe which is the Supreme Being. The universe does not remain. The gold is the cause for gold ornament.

You remove the gold from gold ornament. Gold ornament does not remain. Naatad Asthi, Vina Yat Shyam, Atmaya, Bhutam, Characharam. Without me, the moving or unmoving cannot exist in this world. Just as if we remove the gold, the gold ornament cannot exist. So Bhagawan has basically concluded that all these examples are given for you to understand and try to train your mind to start seeing things as they are.

They're all made up of the same material. This universe has one source. Eventually you can trace down the source to that one entity which remains immutable. That the uncaused cause, there is no source for that cause. If you find a source for that cause, therefore can go further and find that source. So it's one point of time there will be a cause which is no cause.

So therefore Bhagavan said, I am that cause. And without that nothing can exist. You remove that from this universe. It's like in my dream. My own thoughts are the source of my dream. But when I go into the deep sleep, that dream cannot exist.

Because without my mind, the source there is the dream cannot exist. Bhagawan here says, conclusion of all my examples is I am the ultimate cause. I am the ultimate source of all things. And being no thing moving or unmoving. This is the very efficient way in Vedanta to explain that includes everything when it's the moving and unmoving. So all sentient beings and all inert things, all included in it, thing cannot exist without my presence.

There is no end to my Vibhuti. You cannot count all the manifestations. If you want to catalog all the manifestations of physical world, in this physical world, even that's not possible. So now we have in our science all this Webb telescope so we can see as far as possible. But let's say you want to catalog all the galaxies and all the stars in this universe. No matter what kind of a telescope you will have.

There are billions and billions of stars and millions and millions of galaxies. It's almost impossible. And by the time you catalog all of them, the new galaxies are formed and new stars are born, new old stars. It's a continuous change. Therefore, in Sanskrit it's called Jagat universe. But Jagat is that which is constantly changing.

Something which is constantly changing, there is no end to its manifestation. If it's constantly changing, you cannot count it. But by the time you catalog what you have known, new things come into existence. We were in high school, we thought, if I learn this physics and chemistry, then I'll be good at it. Well, physics and chemistry keeps changing in my own lifetime, so even that is not possible. Na antah asti mama divyanaam vibhuti nam paranti.

But there is no end to the divine glories, the physical manifestation of myself. But I told you some in detail just because you asked for it. Now you can figure out rest by yourself. Basically you teach somebody how to think, then the person can think himself rather than spoon feeding him. Give them example and then a person can learn on his own how to detect that. If you figure out if you are working in a jewelry shop and you figure out how to test a gold ornament, whether it is gold or not, once you have one example, you can then apply that on any other example.

So taking all these 54 examples, you have seen the method that anything which you see which has some excellence, that's because of the presence of that Lord. Now I told you all that you should be able to detect this. But in conclusion I can tell you. Yat Vibhuti mat satvam Srimat urjitam eva va tattat eva avagatschatvam mama tej ansa sambhavah. Whatever you see in this world, the world of your experiences, as Swamiji says that Jagat is not just the physical world which is changing outside the world of my experiences, world of my perception that is changing constantly, whatever in your perception, in your experience, you see as Vibhuti mat which has glory or its own excellence, Sattvam existence Sat is which is real, asat which is unreal. So Sattvam one context purity also that which has existence Srimat prosperous And Urjitam energetic.

So anything which you see in this world, in nature, in society, in your community, in your family, where you see these qualities, you should know that they are all coming from me alone. Tatta Eva Avagacvam Mama Teja Ansa Sambhavam. It's coming into existence because iota of my being. So don't consider that if I add up all this manifestation someday with some supercomputer and add it up, that will be Bhagavan. He said no, no, that will be just an iota of my being. Swamiji gives a very good example that my mind has all the capabilities.

But once in a while it gets confused or deluded by some random thought. And then it goes into a wrong direction. It creates this scenario which is unrealistic. That doesn't mean I completely have lost all my ability to think. My 99% of my ability is still valid. But right now it's dormant.

It's covered by the one delusion. But when that one delusion is removed, 100% of my ability will be back. So Bhagavan is Satchitananda is ever pure. But this manifestation, the Prakriti, the world of plurality comes into existence by just one part which creates this disturbance which they call the Hiranyagarva cumulative Vasanas. Of all the beings and things which are in this universe, that one portion is now creating a new world. So when I go to sleep, my world comes to an end.

In a deep sleep there is no world. I don't exist, world does not exist. But my Vasras are there in dormant form. That dormant vasanas will find the appropriate condition. My body has rested fully. I will wake up and they will all come back and manifest and create my own world.

In case of Ishvara also, Ishwara remains as pure as Brahman. But all the cumulative asanas of of the Jagat are still in a dormant form.
snippets.reflection:

Keep a mental (or written) list of divine glories you encounter. At day's end, reflect on how this practice affected your experience. Did the world seem more alive, more meaningful?

The Gita teaches that a single fraction of God's splendor supports the entire universe. What does it mean to live in constant awareness of that splendor?

snippets.title: Day 142: The Cosmic Form
snippets.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच |

भवाप्ययौ हि भूतानां श्रुतौ विस्तरशो मया |

एवमेतद्यथात्थ त्वमात्मानं परमेश्वर |
snippets.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca .

bhavāpyayau hi bhūtānāṃ śrutau vistaraśo mayā .

evametadyathāttha tvamātmānaṃ parameśvara .
verseTranslations: "Arjuna said: My Lord! Thy words concerning the Supreme Secret of Self, given for my blessing, have dispelled the illusions which surrounded me.
O Lord, whose eyes are like the lotus petal! Thou hast described in detail the origin and the dissolution of being, and Thine own Eternal Majesty.
I believe all as Thou hast declared it. I long now to have a vision of thy Divine Form, O Thou Most High!
snippets.commentary:
We have started discussing Chapter 11, Vishwarupadarshan Reason of the Cosmic Form. So up till now in Bhagavad Gita we have learned that all of us are trying to liberate ourselves from our sorrows. So in very first chapter we have defined our condition. From my perspective, the life is full of sorrows and joys. But they don't come as cleanly defined as we would like them to be. Sorrows come with little joy and joys come with little sorrows.

Everything that is positive come with little negative and everything negative has some positive in it. The very first chapter defined our condition. To get out of this, we are trying all our means to overcome these limitations. So the first five chapters we define who we are, in what perspective we are seeing our life. Therefore we have this limitation. So we have seen that we are defining ourselves by our accomplishments, our relationships, our ability, and also our limitations.

From that perspective, when I see the world, I'm a minuscule being and the world is out there to get me. The world is a vast world out there as the Karma Falada. My actions in this field, of my activity in this world, and I have very limited control over what comes out of my actions. The vast world out there is staked against me as the Karma Falada. And in that situation I constantly try to find what is right and what is wrong, what is appropriate, what is inappropriate, and I can't find a clear definition of what is right and what is wrong. So chapter two onwards, we have seen that why that perspective is not correct.

That perspective me looking at from a very narrow perspective about myself is creating all this confusion. If I change the perspective from who I am, which Bhagavan clarifies in chapter two that you are not who you think you are. This mortal self is not you, but your equipment, my body, my mind, my intellect and my equipment, but not me. I consider that to be me and associate all its limitations and my limitations. So up to chapter five we have learned what that equipment is all about and how using it in this world effectively will get me to where I want to be, with which is a state of complete bliss. So we learned the art of meditation in chapter six, how to meditate upon that other self which I have not experienced yet, but that's my real self.

So the quest in the following chapter 7 onward is to define that Self, that self which I have not yet identified with. But identification with that self will end all my sorrows and limitations. So we have learned that that self is the Almighty, all pervading self. That self is none other than the self which I consider to be myself, the one self which constantly reminds me that I exist. That self is the same self as the self outside. But the change of perspective I need.

So how do I get to that was the topic of chapter 10. How do I now start identifying with that higher self? By seeing that self in everything and every being. In chapter 10, the Vibhuti Yoga, Yoga of Divine Glories, we have learned that Bhagavan says there anything glorious, splendid, powerful, wonderful, you see in this world. Consider that is that because of me, the self in it. So the theme of chapter 10 was that I am the origin and dissolution of all the being.

Aham Sarvasya prabhavaha matthaha Sarva Prabhartate. When you take that statement that everything is pervaded by me, it basically tells me that everything is one and the same. Nothing is different than I because the I pervades everywhere. There is no space left. If you say I pervades only in the sentient being, then it is a different story. This I pervade everywhere.

Aham Atma guda kesa sarva asyas thetah. I'm seated in the hearts of all being. I'm the core of all, all the beings and things. So we have learnt and have intellectual appreciation. So the knowledge in our life comes from three different sources. One is Pratyaksa Pramana.

You can keep telling me that it is night outside. You are hallucinating where I personally can see. That's the Pratyaksha Parama. I infer where there is smoke, there is fire. So chapter 10 gave me all the inferences. How can I claim that there is electricity in this room?

I said, don't you see the lights are on. That means electricity is on. It's an inference that does not say that I can see electricity. All my knowledge about electricity comes from inferences. Only heater is on, lights are on, air conditioning working. But my pratyaksa Praman will be.

I put finger in that outlet. No words are necessary. No description is necessary. That's a Pratyaksha Brahman seeing is this is the closest I can come. So over Sastra Sankhya philosophy. Accept three sources of knowledge.

Perception, Pratyaksha Prama, my perception through my senses. I infer from my observation this must be the truth. And third is testimony. Somebody comes and tells me what it is. So most of our knowledge about Bhagavan comes from testimony only so far. My parents told me Bhagavan is like that.

All religions tell me Bhagavan is all for reading. Swamiji even said Bhagavan is all pervading. Who am I to doubt him? So I'm relying totally on testimony right now about Bhagavan. From a lineage of all the gurus. They are telling about that the Atma is the Paramatma.

Who am I to question them? I have complete faith in them, in the testimony. How does a judge ever decide what is right and what is wrong? Who is guilty, not guilty. He relies strictly on testimony. Because he is hardly ever there at the scene of crime.

Maybe some some very unique case that he happens to be there. Otherwise he is never have any other means of knowledge other than testimony. So that's why taken oath that truth and nothing but the truth. So I can rely on testimony if I trust the testimony. So far we have trusted the testimony of Bhagavan. Aham Atma Guda Kesas Sarva says Chitta his testimony.

He says so unless we doubt him, we don't have any reason to doubt him. So we say okay, that's fine. Then he said okay, if you don't believe me. Everywhere you see all this power and glory. Because power and glory will not be there if I am not there. So anytime I see something splendid.

Anytime you go to nature, something awesome. Right away you have that sense of awe about the definitive, the nature. How wonderful this nature. Because this exists, there must be God. Because the nature has laws, there must be a lawgiver. And because the laws are implicitly followed, there must be a law enforcer.

We have never met him. But we know if I jump from the 14th floor window, Mother Earth will receive me. As Newton figured out. But that's still not good enough for me to vouch for his presence. What I want is seeing is believing. So Vishwarupadarshan is the final experience all of us are seeking.

In spite of my complete faith in Bhagavad Gita and Swami Chinma, only time I can come and tell you Bhagawan exists is if I experience him so. Therefore now Arjuna says Mat Anugrahaa Paramam Guhiyam Adhyatma Sangin Matanughaya Paramam. Out of this great compassion for me, not that I was deserving, not that I did something special, Mother does something for a child, not because child is deserving. Out of complete compassion for the child Yat Paya Uktam out of great compassion for me, you have given me. You told me this secret knowledge about the self. You told me about what the Self is all about.

In chapter two you told me that you are not that mortal being. You are the immortal being. All beings are immortal. The self in them is immortal. All bodies are destroyable, perishable. But the self in those bodies is immortal.

You told me this great secret which is only possible if there is a great teacher and a very eligible student is available. Otherwise secret remains secret. Teachers may come and tell you. You will never learn. My delusion is gone by this discourse. This knowledge that you have given me out of your great compassion for me.

So that confusion about who I am and what my duty. Am I a soldier, a general? Or am I a brother and a grandson and a student? What is more important, my duty as a general or duty as a family man? That delusion is gone. The field of actions changes, but I, the actor remains the same.

So depending on the field of action, I should be working. I can think about architecture. I can start giving them discourse about Bhagavad Gita. Clients will go away. Their delusion is gone. I now know what is right, what is wrong.

However, Bhava Apyayo hi Bhutanam Srutao Vistara Shomaya. Let me also tell you what I understood so far. That Bhava Apya origin and dissolution of beings in Bhutanam Sruta Vistara Somaya. I heard in detail which you told me Kamala Patraaksa Mahatmyam Apicha Avyam that it is the eternal self which is the origin and dissolution. Ishvara the Lord is the resting place and the source of all the beings. Also Mahatmyam Apicha Abhyam.

Then also your great glories. Then I heard you the Isvara. I heard Your glories. He addresses Krishna Kamalapatra as one who is lotus eyed. Now obviously in our culture lotus eyed is considered beautiful. But there is another implication here.

That you are seeing this world as a lotus eyed. In other words, the lotus remains pure no matter what the condition of its being. You the self remain unattached to all this prakriti that you have in detail described to me how this world functions. But you remain completely detached of that. I understood that part also. I understood who I am, what my duty is.

Now I also understood your nature as the Ishwara and how you remain detached from all the workings of this Prakriti. Evam etad yatha ATH tvam atmanam parameshwara. Thus you have described Eva metat. So be it or so it is. Evam eta yatha atma as you said what we just discussed that you are the source of all the beings and you are the dissolution of all the beings. That includes myself as well.

You describe to me that you are the source of all the beings. You are the dissolution of all the beings. However, Drastu mitchami I want to say I understood. There is no question anymore. However, I want to say it. The sense of sight is the most dear to us.

Because seeing is believing. I may close my eyes and I may hear my granddaughter. But that doesn't mean that she is here. Somebody put recording. I want to see what I'm hearing is correct or something else I'm hearing. That's why I want to have the direct experience.

Where then I can vouch for it that your nature is such. I'm understanding, accepting no doubt from the testimony you have given. And all of this including Narad Muni and Kavi Ushna and all the people we have talked about testimony taken granted inference you told me to see in this world, everywhere you see is me. I also understood that. But I still need my direct experience. Pratyaksha Pramana Drastumi Chami Terupam Ayeshwaram.

That splendid form of yours where everything is included in it. But just a very narrow perspective. When we look at the photographs of any building, we are only seeing a part of it.
snippets.reflection:
Sit for a moment with the vastness of existence—billions of stars, billions of years, billions of beings. Let yourself feel small in the face of it all.

Then remember: you are not separate from this vastness. You are the universe looking at itself. Both the terror and the wonder are appropriate responses to ultimate reality.

The cosmic vision shows that time devours all things. What would change if you held this truth constantly in awareness? Would petty concerns still trouble you? Would you use your time differently?

snippets.title: Day 143: Universal Vision
snippets.sanskrit:
मन्यसे यदि तच्छक्यं मया द्रष्टुमिति प्रभो |

श्रीभगवानुवाच |

पश्यादित्यान्वसून्रुद्रानश्विनौ मरुतस्तथा |
snippets.transliteration:
manyase yadi tacchakyaṃ mayā draṣṭumiti prabho .

śrībhagavānuvāca .

paśyādityānvasūnrudrānaśvinau marutastathā .
verseTranslations: If Thou thinkest that it can be made possible for me to see it, show me, O Lord of Lords, Thine own Eternal Self.
Lord Shri Krishna replied: Behold, O Arjuna! My celestial forms, by hundred and thousands, various in kind, in colour and in shape.

Behold thou the Powers of Nature: fire, earth, wind and sky; the sun, the heavens, the moon, the stars; all forces of vitality and of healing; and the roving winds. See the myriad wonders revealed to none but thee.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 11, the Vishwarupadarshan, the cosmic form of the Lord. In the Beginning of chapter 11, he said, Anugrahaya, out of your compassion for me, you give me this deepest secret about the Self and showed me how to experience that and meditate on it. However, that's not sufficient for me to understand the nature of the self which you have described. They said, my delusion is dispelled. Delusion about myself. When he started in the first chapter saying, I cannot kill these people even if I get killed, Bhagawan said in the second chapter, that self cannot be killed.

Self in you is imperishable, immutable. The self in you is the same self in everyone else. So that can one who thinks he is a slayer, one who thinks he is slain, both are wrong because it is like within myself, I cannot be slayer and slain of my own self. Arjuna said, now I'm very clear. My confusion about who what my self is, that is gone. However, I'm still at a level where I can comprehend the unity of all beings myself.

I understand, I also can experience yourself. I'm very aware about yourself, I'm very aware of myself. I can now theoretically have understood that as my self is imperishable, yourself is also imperishable. However, that oneness of the self is beyond my understanding. If you really see at this point of the Bhagavad Gita, we are exactly at the same level. All of us who have been sincerely seeking to understand the nature of the self.

All this is intellectually understood. But when it comes to realizing, myself and yourself is one and the same understanding falls apart from experience. My experience is very different in day to day life. I know everything about myself and how I feel, but I cannot relate to yourself and how you feel. Therefore, Arjuna said, I am very clear. You have also explained to me how the things come into being and how they perishes all comes out of the same self and perishes back into the same self.

It is very clear to me that however, this oneness of the Lord, the glory of the supreme Self, to be perceived as one and not as many, is beyond my control right now. And that's the hurdle in the path of my realization. Right now I'm in a constant samadhi about myself. This conditioned self which I think is me, no effort requires for me to realize this is me. It's an automatic knowledge. As soon as the baby is born, he or she knows this is her or him and everyone else is someone.

So that's an automatic knowledge. We're conditioned by that. The conditioned self has conditioned us to think who we are. The knowledge given to us by the sages telling us that no, this conditioned self is not the only nature of yourself. Yourself is omnipresent, omnipotent and omniscient. You're just conditioning it and making it limited yourself.

Once you get those limitations go, you will identify with the Supreme Self. And that's where Arjuna says, I have a difficulty. I can't experience that. I want to experience that form of the self of you. That's because you claim to know that form of the self. I know this form, the self, you know, the supreme form of the self.

I need to see that to get over the hurdle. So he said, drastumi chami te rupam aishwaram purushottamam. O Lord of all the beings. Purushottam, I want to say that form of yours where everything is included in one. I see myself as separate. The world is separate.

The world of plurality is very easy for me to comprehend. But I want to see all in its totality. That if you think that it is possible for me to see. So Bhagavan said, okay, I think you are ready for it. You come to that level of understanding that the only barrier left is your own intellect. The only barrier left is your own conditioning.

You accepted fully that myself and the selves of the others is one and the same. By inference, we have come to the conclusion that we cannot be but the part of the same self. If the Lord created this universe out of his Self, no other material he had to create this universe and universe and Lord both exist. What is the material for this universe is the Lord Self. If this Myself is created out of Lord Self, then my self and his self cannot be different. So is the case for everything else which I see.

However, that oneness which I should feel, which I am feeling in my own body, in my own limited self, I have complete oneness and never argument about the left hand versus the right hand. No argument on right eye versus left eye. If one is weak, other one takes over. You don't even realize when that happens because there's a complete oneness in it. But that's not happening with my family members or my community members or my one is suffering. To some extent I will do that, but not to the extent where I'll do it for myself.

Arjuna said, let me see that oneness. Verse 5 Sri Bhagavan Vacha Pashame Partharu Pani Satasa Athah Sahastra Saha Nana Vidhani Divyani Nana Varana Krutinicha. I will let you see this my form which has hundreds and thousands of forms in it, various types of divine shapes and color. Once you see that, you will see in my own being you will see this hundreds and thousands of forms, the forms which you have seen till now and forms which are not seen in a flash you will see all of that all in one. So you will see hundreds and thousands of form, various colors of various types and various forms. And next one he says Pashya, Aditya, Rudra, Asvinau, Marutahata, Bahuni, Adristha, Purvani, Pasha, Acharyani, Bharada.

He said, not only that you will see the forms which you are familiar with, you will see the forms which you are not familiar with. Not only the forms and beings which you want to see it in one, but the divine beings which you have been worshipping as someone other than this world. verseTranslations: In that vision Arjuna saw the universe, with its manifold shapes, all embraced in One, its Supreme Lord.
Thereupon Arjuna, dumb with awe, his hair on end, his head bowed, his hands clasped in salutation, addressed the Lord thus:
Arjuna said: O almighty God! I see in Thee the powers of Nature, the various creatures of the world, the Progenitor on his lotus throne, the Sages and the shining angels.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 11, Vishwarupadarsha Yoga of Cosmic Form. So far we have seen in Bhagavad Gita that the quest for each individual is to understand who Bhagavan is. So we try in a different way to conceptualize Bhagavan. And we typically would hear that people want to see Bhagawan as a person. And all philosophers basically tell Bhagavan is not a person, he's not a man, he's not a woman, he's not it, he's not he, he's not she. So how one can conceptualize Bhagavan is a riddle.

If you see the Abrahamic religions, they forbid any picture of God. What God looks like is not possible. Therefore they say, do not draw. Do not create an image which can falsify the image of God in your mind. Our religion, on the other hand, is a very daring feat to describe bhagawan. So chapter 11, Bhagavan Ved Vyas is a great attempt to describe what Bhagavan would look like if you ever have his darshan.

So so far we have seen that Arjuna said, I have understood everything you have said that hum Aksaram Brahma Paramam, I am that imperishable being. I am the source of things and beings. I have no doubt he said etat Atha, that means so be it. I understood, no question about it. I'm convinced that this is what your nature is, that you are the source of all beings. But how do I contemplate upon you?

How do I meditate upon you? Because you told me that meditate on myself, then you will become myself. So Bhagavan Ved Vyas takes us to Arjuna's journey and say, how does he see it? So Arjuna makes a request and Bhagavan grants his request and says, okay, I will show you my total form that nobody has seen before. But you won't be able to see it with your natural vision. So I have to give You a divine vision.

I'll give you a divine perspective. With your perspective today you will not be able to understand this. So I'll give you a divine perspective. Things not changing what it is. When we change our perspective, we see things in a very different light. Things we have only seen from one narrow perspective.

So right now we are seeing the world from our narrow perspective of I, the limited being. Then conceptualize what would be that greater self. We are part of the plurality. We want to experience singularity. Bhagavan Krishna told Arjuna, I will change your vision. And Bhagavan Bedya has already given that divine vision to Sanjaya.

That Sanjaya can see everything that is happening on the Kurukshatra. And also everything what Krishna Arjuna sees, he sees. So Sanjaya saw the form and described Dhritarashtra that we have seen in last few verses that he said. Then yes, he granted this vision to Arjuna. He said that Anek vaktra Nayanam, Anek ad Buddha, Darshanam, Aneka Dibya Paranam. Everything I see in my world is included in it.

I see various types of dresses, various types of ornaments, various types of fragrances. All that he is saying is Anek vaktra Nayanam. As we have discussed last time, if I take the concept of space out of my mind by some magic, then everything will lump into one. All hands will be of that one big body of a person. And all hands are his, all mouths are his, all eyes are his. Because now I'm seeing it from my world's perspective.

We see things always from our own perspective. We see things based on what we already know. So if we have to describe something which you have not seen before, I can only describe to you from the perspective what you already know. Do you know where short pump is? I don't know where short pump is. Do you know where that Walmart is?

Okay, well that's the short pump. You need a short pump to give you a reasonable short pump where to get you to Walmart. And then you can put together in your mind what that short pump should look like. So Bhagavan, now giving Arjuna a reason, Sanjay is putting together in his mind what he has seen in his world. Many mouths and many hands and many different type of dresses and many different type of fragrances. Aneka, Divya, Bharanam.

Then he says, Divya, Mallya, Ambar, Dharam, same thing. Whatever I have seen in my world, I Now see in that form and Sarva ascharimayam Devammanantam everything is very wonderful and infinite. I cannot describe what it is from our perspective. When we try to put together things in one vision, it looks really infinite. We try to find out how wide this universe is. We have to simply say it's infinite.

Because we can't really imagine. We see the stars, we see the moonkanish. But what is the nature of cosmic infinite Anant? Now if I really take my gaze from my world to the outer world, then he said, what you see is Yadibaha Divi Surya sahasrasya Bhavet Yukpat Uthita. In my world I see one sun rising every morning. And I know the splendor of that sun.

That splendor is incomparable. In my world, there's nothing I can compare to the sun's splendor. When we design light, designing a surgery room, we have to mimic the sunlight. So you have to come close to the sunlight from your artificial light. You are still only talking about the sunlight. As we experience this far away from sun.

But to experience the sun where he is and to look at him, it's splendid. We can hardly look at it. See, now you imagine that all the space between all the stars are removed. And all the stars, all the suns in this cosmos, they all come together. The splendor of that entity which is all the thousands of stars together we can look at the sky and look at the stars because they're so far away. By the time the light come to us, it's so feeble, it looks like twinkling stars.

But if they all come together because you have removed space and time from your mind, they all come together at the same time. Therefore Divi Surya sahasrasya Yadi Bhaha. If the thousands of sun rising in the sky, if you can imagine Sadrusi Sat Basahat Manaha the splendor of that great person Mahatmana, that great soul, great being cannot describe his splendor as like thousand suns are rising in the sky. Because he is stars and he is moonkanish. He is everything that we can think of. Therefore we cannot draw his picture.

Because everything that I can imagine as part of this cosmos, Bhagavan said, it is me. Then this is my Eightfold prakriti that includes everything they can think of. Bhoomi apah analaha kam vayuhu mana buddhi ahanka. So space is part of that manifestation, everything else I can imagine. Now, if I say that I have Bhagavan's darshan, all that darshan has to come together in one. Therefore it is not possible.

But what we try to do as human beings, we personify that reason in one person. So therefore he said, bhagavan, I'm seeing this vision in your body. Even in our life, what we do is all the divinity that we can think of or we have imagined of. We assign that to one person. We want to see that in one person. So therefore we say, bhagavan, I see all that in Swami Chinbananda somebody says, I saw all that in Bhagavan Rajneesh, somebody says, because we gather all that conceptualization of divinity into one person, we want to see that in one person.

And then we get disappointed because a person by very nature cannot have all the attributes of that entire divinity. But if we change our perspective, then we will be able to see that. So Bhagavan said, yadibaha divi Surya Sahastrasya Bhavet yukpat Uthita Sadrushi saa saad Bhasah Tasya mahat manah. Splendor of that being which represents totality, heirs of thousands of sons. You cannot describe it. Tatra Ekastam, Jagat Krishnam, Pravibhaktam, Anekata, it's all centered into one.

Because that's what Arjuna asked for. I want to see all that centered into you, all in one. Right now I see them as Pravibhakta, different parts. I know this cosmos exist as nature, as Lord's manifestation, but in different parts I can manage. I can manage to understand. It is your world, his world, her world, my planet, different planets.

There are different parts of his manifestation. From my narrow perspective, I can understand it. But now he says, Tatra Ekastam is centered into one Jagat Krushnam. The entire Jagat Jagat includes everything. Jagat includes your physical cosmos as well as your emotional cosmos and your intellectual cosmos. Everything that you can think of that the greatness of our Hinduism, it has included in Astra, Prakriti, mind, intellect and ego.

Without that, your world is not complete. If I can put all this together, one person and what that vision would be, that's what Arjuna is seeing right now. In that Mahatma Deva Devashya Sari re. Arjuna saw in the body of the God of Gods. Krishna is no longer a person. Dhritarashtra can relate to who he knew as the king of Yadavas or Pandava's ally.

But now he says he's a Deva Devasya, the God of all the gods. So he said, I see the Maruta and I see Rudras, all these Devas, all the deities which he is the God of all those deities. Everything that we have imagined, who has the control over this world, he has control over all of them. Deva Deveshary, Pandavahatada, Pandava Arjuna. Arjuna saw in the body of that God of gods this splendor of thousands of suns blazing at the same time. So what could be the reaction of Arjuna Vishma Yavista overcame by the wonderment?

He's completely dumbfounded. Rustiroma is here standing on hands. I don't know if the English translation of in our language it's very well used. Goosebumps is the only thing come to my mind in English. He's having goosebumps. He's completely dumbfounded looking at this.

He asked for it, but did not know what to expect. Now he's seeing in the body of the God of God because he's all that vision is personified in one person. Ristiroma Dhananjaya Dhananjaya again Arjuna Pranasya Silasadvam. Once you have that experience, as soon as you see him, Chamatkar I may not believe anything about when he does Chamatkar, he takes out a Rolex watch and gives you namaskar right there. So Pranamya Sirasadevam, as soon as he realized the nature of this total being is surrendered. We don't surrender right now because we don't think this is all true, even though we kind of learn and all that.

But when it comes to our life, we say, no, no, I have better control. I have people come to me and say, stop coming to class. I think it was actually giving him less motivation to do things. So right now our motivation in working in a world is we don't have much trust in him. We don't think he can take care of it. I really need to look out for myself, look out for number one.

That used to be a mantra when I came to this country. Somebody has started and said, think about number one. Number one is you start from thinking about you first, then comes everybody else. Your family, your children, your. Start from you take care of yourself first and then go to. But here he said he realized that he is nobody with whom he is relating to what he is seeing Nobody.

So Pranaam is Sirasa Devam Dandavat Pranam Only the South Indians do that Dandavat Pranayama Punjabi is doing Mathotic they just put the head on and Gujaratvi yeah Pranamya Sirasadevam, Once you have understood the greatness of who you are relating to, you are completely surrendered to him.
snippets.reflection:
Sit for a moment with the vastness of existence—billions of stars, billions of years, billions of beings. Let yourself feel small in the face of it all.

Then remember: you are not separate from this vastness. You are the universe looking at itself. Both the terror and the wonder are appropriate responses to ultimate reality.

The cosmic vision shows that time devours all things. What would change if you held this truth constantly in awareness? Would petty concerns still trouble you? Would you use your time differently?

verseTranslations: I see Thee, infinite in form, with, as it were, faces, eyes and limbs everywhere; no beginning, no middle, no end; O Thou Lord of the Universe, Whose Form is universal!
I see thee with the crown, the sceptre and the discus; a blaze of splendour. Scarce can I gaze on thee, so radiant thou art, glowing like the blazing fire, brilliant as the sun, immeasurable.
Imperishable art Thou, the Sole One worthy to be known, the priceless Treasure-house of the universe, the immortal Guardian of the Life Eternal, the Spirit Everlasting.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 11, Vishwarupadasha Yoga of Cosmic Form. As we have seen so far, in the beginning, Arjuna made the request saying that my delusion is gone now. Out of compassion, you explained to me that you are the source of all the beings. You are the resting place of all the beings. Nothing existing which is away from you. Everything I see is the manifestation of you alone.

So now my delusion is gone about what is right and what is wrong. However, I would like to see that form of yours in its totality in one place. In the previous chapters we have seen his Prakriti Astada Prakruti. So you can say you can experience, you are seeing it every day. His Eightfold Prakriti, you are experiencing and seeing every day. But I still can't see it in one place.

I basically see as the plurality what I want to see as one entity. Arjuna Singh that's basically what we are all struggling to understand intellectually. We understand what Bhagavad Gita says. When it comes to a day to day life, it is very difficult to comprehend. So Arjuna said, my delusion is gone. I understand Nag, but I want to see it, I want to experience it.

And in response Bhagavan said that if you wish to, I will show you, but you will not be able to see it from your present way of looking at the world, the present perspective from your present eyes. You will not be able to see it the way you see the world right now. It will remain divided. Because I see my world right now as I as an individual and everything else individual entities. If I see it that way, I will never be able to see the unity in them. If I change my perspective and see it from the singularity's point of view and include myself into it, then I'll be able to see it.

That's you have to change your perspective. So I'll give you that perspective. Divyam Dadami te Chakshuhu. I'll give you that vision and then you will be able to see. Having said that, he showed the Swaroopa and Sanjaya was the witness. He confirmed that, yes.

Having said that, Yogeshwarakrishna showed him his Virata Swarup. And he described on his own what Arjuna Swan said. Aneka Vaktra Bahu, many mouths and many hands, as if there are thousands of suns blazing in the sky at the same time, it's so resplendent and difficult to see. And he also showed us the Arjuna's reaction. And having seen that Arjuna, Pranamya, Sira, Sahadevam, Chamatka Namaskar, as soon as he saw who the Krishna in his real form is, he basically completely surrendered to him. And then what he said is.

Now we are discussing from verse 15 onward, as we have discussed before, the Bhagavad Gita is generally all verses are in Anushtupchanda. Now these verses are in Tristupchanda because they are more to describe. So this is a much longer verses, more words packed into each verse. And this is beautiful poetry or a prayer and describing what is the nature of the Supreme Being. So from Arjuna's perspective, now when he sees that Swarupa, he sees things which are common to his experiences. When we go to any other town, like we went to New York and I say I'll go to Manhattan, what am I going to say?

I'm going to see the buildings, 911 memorial, One World Tower, because that's the world I see is what Manhattan is all about. So now what Arjuna sees in that Swarupa is what he is familiar with. He says, pasyami Devan Tava Deva, Deva Sarvantatham Bhuta Visesanga O Deva. He doesn't say Krishna for Sid, O resplendent Being. I see in your body all the other Devas. In this Puranic culture, we have assigned deities of each sense and those resplendent beings, the Devas, he said, I see in your body all of them.

Pasyami Devan, Tava Deva Dehe. In your body I see them all. Tatha Bhuta, we say the Sangana, various groups of other beings, Brahmanam Isam, Kamala, Sanastha, and I see the Lord Brahma. Swamiji looks at it both ways. He said, lord Brahma or say Brahma and Isha Brahma and Shiva, Kamala Sanastha sitting on the lotus. I see the whole creation in you, and I see the Creator himself.

You are the Creation and you are the creator. I see everything all in one. You Tatahu seems Cha Sarva and all that he sees. So it's like flashing through his eyes. Everything he has learned about divinity in this world, it's flashing at the same time. And also Uragan Cha Divyan and I'll see also the divine serpents.

The Swami points out here that this is one of the technique the poets use to take you to the most sublime level and then bring you down, all the way down to the lowest of the low. So I see all the divine beings, including the Lord Creator himself, but also all the serpents. So the entire universe, starting from the lowest of the low to the highest of the high. I see in your body at one time. And then he says Aneka Bahu Udar Bhaktanektra. Sanjaya has already described that before to Dhritarashtra.

Now Arjuna himself says that I see infinite hands. Bahu udara, stomachs, Vaktra mouth, Netra eyes, Pasyamitvam Sarvato Anantarupam. I see you facing everywhere. Infinite is now realizing that this is not something I will be able to describe. Infinite mouth, infinite hands, infinite eyes. As we have discussed earlier, once you take the space out of our world and keep all the beings lumped as one.

Right now I have two hands and you have two hands. But when you are together there are many hands. All the hands in this world are his hands. All the legs in this world are his legs. All the mouths in this world are his mouths. He is experiencing that.

But then he says, anywhere I see, you know, this 360 degree movie, it's projected all over. Oh, you are focused one side and so what happened to the other side? Still the same movie and different parts. But we can't describe where that movie starts and where that picture ends. We actually went to the 911 memorial. They have presentation three sided.

So people when they enter, they start putting the strollers on those sides as if they're keeping. Then the guy comes and move all those because the movie is going to be in all three sides. Then we are focusing on one wall and then realize, oh, there is some other details I'm missing out on this side. And then okay, what about this side? So then we realized we will never be able to capture all three sides at the same time. It's beyond my capacity to see all three sides at the same time.

So Arjuna experiencing something even at the much grander scale and say, I will not be able to describe everything that I can see. Pasyami tvam Sarvato Anantarva. I see you everywhere with infinite forms. There is no end to what I see in you. Naantam namadhyam napunah Ta Adim we have learned this before. In previous chapters.

Bhagavan himself said that I don't have any beginning, I don't have any end. I am the resting place, everything. Now Arjuna tells him, Bhagavan, that I see you as you are no end, no beginning, no origin. Pasyami Vishweshvara. Vishwaroopa is accepting the fact that you are the Lord of all the universe. And this is your Vishwaroopa.

This is your infinite form. That which I'm experiencing now is your real nature that you are beginningless. You have no middle and no end. Wherever we stand is ever present. Whatever we left behind is our past. What we have not yet experienced in our future.

But if we experience all of it at the same time, there is no beginning, there is no end, there is no past, there is no future. So he's seeing this everything in his present. You are the Lord of the whole universe and I am seeing your Viswaroopa Kiritinam Gadhinam Chakrinamcha. And as Swamiji explains here that Arjuna is now recognizing that what he's seeing is not a being outside, but what he always perceived as the Lord is. So Kiritinam Gadhinam Chakri nam Cha Tejo rasim Sarvato Diptim Manantam. I see you with the crown, the club and the discus which is the universal form of Vishnu in his four hands a lotus club, then discus, and then Shankar.

And then he is wearing the crown. So one who has the complete control of his self can only wear the crown. Vishnu is the only one who has the complete control of the self. Therefore he wears the crown. That means he has the authority. We wear the crown temporarily.

Whenever I feel I am in authority, I wear my crown. But that only lasts for a limited period of time. My authority slips away before even I realize. Like the cardboard crown in a drama. My authority is like that. Well, I'm on this drama stage.

I have that cardboard crown. As soon as of this stage the crown is gone. Vishnu carries that authority all the time. That's why he is the crown. So he's the lotus which signifies the purity and knowledge. And then he has a conch to wake you up from your ignorance.

And if you don't listen to the call for waking up, then he uses his club gada to shape you up. And if you shape up, it well and good. If not, chakra annihilate you, just destroy you. So that's how the creation and maintenance continue. Bhagavan gives you all the chances to shape up. You don't shape up, time will take care of you.

So Bhagwan said, Arjuna sees that form as the totality, as the kiritinam Gadhinam Chakrinam Cha Tejo rasim Sarvato Diptim Anantam is the mass of radiance. Sarvato Diptim blazing everywhere. The previous verses Sanjaya says, like the thousand suns are blazing in the sky. Here he says the Tejo rasim Sarvato Diptim Manantam Everywhere it's blazing. And Swamiji explains here that what he's seeing is not the light of any sun, but he sees the light of the self, the consciousness, that which illumines everything. Anant Diptim infinite teja.

So he is experiencing resplendence of the self. Pasyami tvam Durniriksham Samantha. But it is difficult to see. It is difficult to understand the light of consciousness. For me, in light of my consciousness, I understand everything. I see all this thing.

Kiritanam Gadhinam Chakri nam Cha through the light of consciousness. But seeing yourself, your splendid being, is difficult to see. From light of my consciousness I can describe everything. But describing my consciousness is not possible. So Dura Niriksham I cannot say it. Duru Niriksham Dipta analar Ka Dtim Aprameyam.

That light is blazing all around like fire and sun. And it's incomprehensible. He come to the conclusion that what I'm seeing is undefinable. At the same time, whatever I want to see, I'll see in it. Any museum or gallery. We go and see, look at the pictures.

Every visitor will see something different. In that even in our world, we see what we want to see. We'll never see the things we do not want to see. As soon as we see something which is not conducive, we will run away from that. Many years ago, when I first started working on this forensic lab and medical examiner's office in the first time I met with them and they have statistics about how many people go through the autopsy, how many people who die. And they statistics like one in four persons goes through the autopsy.

verseTranslations: Without beginning, without middle and without end, infinite in power, Thine arms all-embracing, the sun and moon Thine eyes, Thy face beaming with the fire of sacrifice, flooding the whole universe with light.
Alone thou fillest all the quarters of the sky, earth and heaven, and the regions between. O Almighty Lord! Seeing Thy marvellous and awe-inspiring Form, the spheres tremble with fear.

snippets.commentary:
We have completed chapter 10, _Verses_ Yoga, and we'll be now discussing chapter 11, Vishwarupadarshan, the cosmic form of the Divine. So in last chapter, Arjuna had asked Krishna that tell me how I should feel your presence, the presence of the divine, presence of that all pervading self, then how I can meditate upon that. And in response to that, Bhagavan has given him the various examples of excellence in this world from various walks of life for Arjuna, which is also applicable to us, that from our day to day life, from our cultural backgrounds, from our spiritual quest, that we find examples all around us of excellence and feel Lord's presence. As we have discussed in chapter 10, that anytime I see excellence, my mind thinks it is the God's blessings, the grace of God, in other words, the divinity is evident in excellence. So Bhagavan has given various examples for Arjuna and say, when you see this, it will remind you of my presence in all things and beings. I'm not limited to those excellent manifestations, but that's where you will find it easier to experience my presence.

And now that Arjuna has heard that, he says that I'm not still experiencing that oneness, that oneness which you talk about all throughout this discourse. I have intellectually appreciated and I've come to the conclusion that that's what it is, that there is a one singular entity pervading this entire universe, which is you, the Supreme Self. But I need to have that experience. I would like to experience that oneness. This is something, as Swamiji explains, is similar to how we scientifically make any concept or a theory knowledge of our own. First I need to gather all the evidences and data.

And then once I have gathered all the data, all the evidences, that now I have to demonstrate that that phenomenon exists. I gather all information about how the water is formed. In chemistry classes, two molecules of hydrogen, one molecule of oxygen can create water. But at some point I want to see the demonstration so that in the lab I create that situation and Then see the demonstration how the hydrogen oxygen can create water in a similar fashion. Arjuna has now understood, but he wants to see a demonstration. So the chapter starts with Arjuna Vacha.

Arjuna said mat anugraha yaparamam guhyam adhyatma Sangnitam yat tvaya uktam vachasthena Moho ayam vigatomama. With your compassion for me, you have given me this secret knowledge. And as you have said, the that the self is indestructible, imperishable, one who consider himself to be the slayer or the slain in both cases is wrong. There is nothing to grieve over the changes which takes place in this world, including death. Because death is not the end of existence. It is only the existence in the form of this body.

So moho yam vigato Mama. By this discourse of yours. You have given me the secret knowledge. Bhavapyayohibhutanam srutao vistarsomaya totta Kamal patraksa mahatmya API cha vyayam. And I have also heard the origin and destruction of beings, O lotusaid Krishna from you and also your inexhaustible greatness. I heard the greatness of the self, the supreme Brahman, that which is not limited by anything.

And therefore my delusion is gone. I understand it clearly now. Evam etat yatha attha tvam atmanam parameshwara jastumi chami the rupam aishwaram purushottamam. However, I would like to see. Form as you described yourself of that oneness in this world of plurality. I have understood that you pervade the entire universe and therefore there is no existence separate from you.

However, at this time I cannot see that. And I would like to see that. I would like to experience that oneness of yours. Manyase yaditatsakyam maya drastum ITI prabhav. If you think it is possible for me to see that divine form, then, O Lord of Yogas, show me you are that imperishable form which includes everything in this world. I would like to see that complete form of yours where everything is in yourself.

It is easier for me to see your presence in this world of plurality. As Swamiji explains that it is easier for me to see gold in gold jewelry. I can take one look at it, experience it, the gold in it, I can pick up the another one as long as it is the excellence. In other words, the gold is apparent. It's not covered by something. The gold is manifested in the jewelry.

I can see the gold in it. So it is easier to see the divinity in the world of plurality for us. What is not possible for us generally is seeing all the plurality in that one single entity. Those who are wise enough to not get perturbed by whatever the outcome is, they are blissful and praising the Lord because they have accepted everything. So you see those wise people are praising you, but others are entering into you. They are afraid of you. And then he says, I also see you as Vishnu. I see you as that Almighty Vishnu.

I am good, I am doing puja, I am doing meditation. I am that I is so solid there that the surrender is of not much value.
