snippets.sanskrit:
तेषामहं समुद्धर्ता मृत्युसंसारसागरात् |

मय्येव मन आधत्स्व मयि बुद्धिं निवेशय |

अथ चित्तं समाधातुं न शक्नोषि मयि स्थिरम् |
snippets.transliteration:
teṣāmahaṃ samuddhartā mṛtyusaṃsārasāgarāt .

mayyeva mana ādhatsva mayi buddhiṃ niveśaya .

atha cittaṃ samādhātuṃ na śaknoṣi mayi sthiram .
verseTranslations: O Arjuna! I rescue them from the ocean of life and death, for their minds are fixed on Me.
Then let thy mind cling only to Me, let thy intellect abide in Me; and without doubt thou shalt live hereafter in Me alone.
But if thou canst not fix thy mind firmly on Me, then, My beloved friend, try to do so by constant practice.
snippets.commentary:

Everything that has to be told is already told in the chapters before. So as we have discussed from chapter six to ten we saw the Bhagavan Sri Bhuti, his glory, his identification, how to find him in this manifest world. We saw on 6 to 10 where he said, I am in the fragrance of flower, I am the sweetness of honey, I am even in the cheating power of the cheats.

Whatever you can think of is the essence of a thing or a being. The Dharma of that being or a thing is me. Thing only exists because its inherent quality to be its own Dharma. We are human beings because we have this basic qualities necessary for a human being. You take that away, you are no more human being. If a person looks like Michael Jackson, you go near, but he doesn't move.

We know you are a Madam Two Sides Museum. That's not Michael Jackson. Because that statue does not have inherent qualities required to be Michael Jackson. So that which makes you, you an I, I and it it is, Bhagavan said, is me. We have seen that from chapter six to ten, and from that we should have developed a reason to say it. But obviously that's not that simple.

So Arjuna asked bhagavan in chapter 11 that I understood all of it, but I want to experience it, I can't experience it. So with Lord's grace, he gets a divine reason to comprehend this oneness in this manifest world, which is what we had been talking about. We just can't connect it with that. And Arjuna gets connected to that where he sees this manifest world as nothing but a one being with many mouths and many hands and many legs and many things happening. With that understanding, one should develop the devotion to that being, that one supreme Being who is nothing but my own self. So the chapter 12 is the yoga of devotion.

Once you contemplated who I am, realize the nature of the supreme and realize that myself and the supreme selves are not two different selves. I must instantaneously develop identification with that supreme self, which we call it a love for the Divine devotion. So this chapter is about all the Bhakti Yoga, how to unite with yourself by devotion. And we had been talking about various paths to attain that oneness with the Supreme. And we have talked about three different three distinct paths. Karma Yoga, Bhakti Yoga, Gnana Yoga.

And we always get because our cultural baggage. We have understood bhakti as something which happens in a temple or during bhajan time that we can associate. I'm not that kind of bhakta. Well, I don't really wear a mala and then keep kirtan and do all the kirta. I'm not a bhakta like that. So here is our chance to understand what bhakti is.

So the chapter opened with Arjuna's two obvious question. Should I be devoted to you in the form which I have seen you as Krishna or Rama or Shiva, Jesus, whatever, whom I have now developed a sense of divinity, that you are divine, I'm a mortal, that I can put my faith into that one manifestation and achieve that oneness. Or like others discussed in Vedas and Upanishads, as that being which has nirguna Niraka has no qualities, no shape and form, and that all pervading being in its unmanifest form that I should be worshipping or devoted to. And obviously Bhagavan's answer was one who gives his mind to me and then do have me as the supreme goal and do it with faith, he comes to me quicker. But the others who want to devote to the unmanifest, and if they can do the following Sam nyam indriyagram, all this sense is under control, equanimous to all. Where he can see the equanimity in this entire manifest world, he can see that there is the underlying thread in this world of plurality and this diversity which binds this entire universe into that thread which we already discussed in previous verses.

Sutre Eva, Maniganaha Eva, just as a thread in the necklace of the beads, we can see that. And then I, sarvabhutahi tera taha, I'm constantly engaging myself into the welfare of all the beings. Not my group of people, my family, my people, other people can go to wherever Sarvabhuta hitherta. Then he also comes to me, Bhagavan said, and then obviously the question is, then which one is better? I devote to a Particular deity being whom I feel most closer and inspired. And Bhagawan said, both are fine.

But kleso adiktarahatesham, those who devote to the unmanifest, it's a harder path. There are more obstacles on your way to achieve that. For dehavadbhee, those who are attached to the body, first qualification required for that is to have samnyam, indriya grammam, all. The senses to be under control. But if I'm not in that and have attachment to these senses in the body no matter how intellectually I consider myself non dualistic that duality will bring you down. And therefore Bhagavan says for them it is more difficulty if you are deha vadvi.

Not just the indwell of the body but one who is attached to this body. I never understood the meaning of samadhi. They talk about in meditation in this. But one time Swami Tejamanda explained to. Me in one simple term. He was not addressing just to me, but an audience.

But I got it, you know, he said, you are in this state of samadhi all the time. A reference to your body. There is never a time where I am not identified with my body. Nobody has to wake me up and say, Neil, that's not you, that's you. I'm always in a state of samadhi, a reference to my body. That's actually dehavad beh.

I'm attached to this body. For me, attaching to this body as an ego I and then trying to establish myself into the supreme unmanifest. Bhagavan says kleso adhiktarhatesha for them there. Are lots of difficulties. Therefore he said, easy path is maiyeva mana adasva. Give your mind to me and then do everything for me.

And I will become the savior of you. To save you from this ocean of samsara. This ocean of experiences we have which seems infinite. I don't see the end of it. So many times I thought I got it that we told Bhagavan that oh Lord, just give me this, just give me green card and I'll be fine. When you didn't have green card, I don't know.

You know, Bhagavan says, for those who have given their mind to me. Have supreme faith in me, I become their savior. They are not capable by themselves to cross this ocean of infinite experiences. Infinite experience of finite world. I will make this savior for them. To save them and take them to the other side.

Where there is no sorrow. Where there is pure happiness. What you are looking for. There is no ignorance about who I am. And there is no death. There is no end of me.

There is no ignorance and there is no sorrow. So it's all about mind that we figured out. Bhagavan never said give me your intellect and body. Intellect is nothing but a memory bank of my experiences. I think I know based on only my experiences. My mind takes the flight into unknown and then keeps on going.

There is a story about a sexchalli. One who can't control his imagination. I'd heard a story in my childhood that a Brahmin's son who obviously makes his living by getting bhiksha One day he got more vixa than he can consume. He got this flower more than he said. Well, today was a good day and I got a lot of this vixa. I cannot consume all of it.

So what I'm going to do is take the part which is left and. I'm going to sell it and make some money. Then what I'm going to do with that money? Well then I'll buy this and then I'll do this little business. Then I'll make more money and then I will have a worthy partner. Then I'll get married.

And then I will have children. And then children will come to me. And he Kicked and he kicked that pot which has the flower in it and broke it and it all gone. So his flight of imagination of his mind took him away with it and. He lost everything which he was thinking about. So he said, that quality of the mind which we have seen is Sankalpa Shakte.

You need to curb that and put it in me. Saya nivasashi Maya Ayva ata Urdhumna Sansaya. Fix thy mind in me, place thy intellect in me too. See right now we are so much dependent on our own intellect. Doubt came to my mind. Almost everybody who learned Bhagavad Git and said all this is great but I don't think you can succeed if you just continue.

You have to have passion and thus to do this then only you can succeed in life. So if you don't succeed in life, learn this but don't get hung up on it. Because you know why I'm relying on my own intellect which is nothing but a finite experiences which says what succeeds, what doesn't. We have seen the people like Steve Jobs and they did and that's why they are succeeding. Well, I should be like that. Bhagwan said, no, don't rely on your intellect.

It will misguide you. Because it has not a capacity to go beyond the realm of your experiences. What you are trying to cross is the realm of your experiences. How can you rely on your intellect? You need to plug into the global database, Cosmic database. If I don't know anything, what do I do?

I go on Google and see if I can find it. If I find it on Google, I'm fine. That entire database of the supreme intellect, that cosmic intelligence, I need to rest in that. I have to rest my intellect into that. Plug into not only my hard drive which is my intellect to the cloud computing connected to that Bhagavan. Not only give your mind to me but rest your intellect into me.

Realize that there is a guide who will guide me once I put faith in him.

snippets.title: Day 164: Dear to the Lord
snippets.sanskrit:
अभ्यासेऽप्यसमर्थोऽसि मत्कर्मपरमो भव |

अथैतदप्यशक्तोऽसि कर्तुं मद्योगमाश्रितः |

श्रेयो हि ज्ञानमभ्यासाज्ज्ञानाद्ध्यानं विशिष्यते |
snippets.transliteration:
abhyāse.apyasamartho.asi matkarmaparamo bhava .

athaitadapyaśakto.asi kartuṃ madyogamāśritaḥ .

śreyo hi jñānamabhyāsājjñānāddhyānaṃ viśiṣyate .
verseTranslations: And if thou are not strong enough to practise concentration, then devote thyself to My service, do all thine acts for My sake, and thou shalt still attain the goal.
And if thou art too weak even for this, then seek refuge in union with Me, and with perfect self-control renounce the fruit of thy action.
Knowledge is superior to blind action, meditation to mere knowledge, renunciation of the fruit of action to meditation, and where there is renunciation peace will follow.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing Chapter 12, Bhakti Yoga Yoga of Devotion. So in our scriptures, generally there are three paths prescribed. Karma Yoga, Gnani Yoga and Bhakti Yoga. Most people consider Bhakti Yoga to be the easiest path because it requires no special training. It does not require any special arrangement. You can just go and worship the Lord.

You go to the temple, you sing Bhajans. So we find that most people feel it is more comfortable and much easier to practice Bhakti Yoga than Karma Yoga or Gnan Yoga. That's our general understanding. But it turns out Bhakti Yoga is the most difficult path to follow because Bhakti is the emotional response to something we adore or something we worship. Devotion, as we have discussed before, is nothing but love for the divine. Narad Ji defines Bhakti in his Narad Bhakti Sutra is Satasmin Premarupa.

It is of the nature of love. It is the nature of immortality. Yatlab DVA Puma, Siddho Bhavati. Once a person achieves that Bhakti established in Bhakti Yoga, Pumane person becomes Siddha. He becomes accomplished. Amrutva Bhavti, he becomes immortal and Tripto Bhavati, he becomes completely satisfied.

So to achieve that state is not very simple. So what we find actually is it is easier for me to practice Karma Yoga. Karma Yoga is something related to my actions. I consider it is in my control. How I act in this world is something I can control. So Karma Yoga is related to my organs of actions and how I perform my actions in this world which I consider I have some control over it.

At least I can attempt to practice Karma Yoga. And then Gnana Yoga is related to intellect, acquire knowledge. So that again I find is something in my control. I can make a choice that I want to now learn this or that. If I want to learn about physics, I can make a resolve. I can go to the physics department, learn physics.

So the knowledge is something I find it within my choice. To pursue actions I find within my choice to pursue. Bhakti is related to mind. It's an emotional response. Nobody can say that I'll fall in love in 2025. You cannot plan falling in love.

It really does not go by your planning or your calendar. The love will only come if I know the divine. And therefore, we have gone through five chapters in this segment, from 7th through 11 to know the Supreme Lord. In chapter 10 and 11, Bhagawan has given Arjuna all required information, and 10 has given all the Vibhutis in the manifest world, then he gave him the total representation of his nature. If you have been equipped with that level of knowledge, then Bhakti actually becomes an automatic response. However, it is still related to the mind.

And therefore Bhagavan starts this chapter by saying, fix your mind onto me. No matter what amount of knowledge I may have intellectually or how much activity I have performed, but it is the mind which decides what will be my next destination. It is the mind which will have desire to explore new things. So Bhagavan said, attach your mind to me. So we have seen in last few verses, Bhagavan has clarified that focusing your mind into one particular form is the easiest way to do it. That does not mean that Bhagavan is simply saying, idol worship is all that you have to do.

So we have discussed last time that idol worship is acceptable or not acceptable. It is one form or one means to achieve bhakti. So most of the time when we consider Bhakti simply, he is going to the temple and he sings bhajan. So that's the sum total of bhakti. And Bhagavan said, that's not true. It is your mind, not your activity, going to the temple, it is not singing.

Swamiji used to say bhajans with noisy instruments. He said, that's not Bhakti. Bhakti is where mind penetrates the nature of the Lord and fixes itself to that form. Bhagwan said, first requirement, fix your mind onto me. So your mind and intellect should be firmly established in that supreme knowledge. So we've been learning all throughout this last five chapters.

Nothing exists other than his self. What I see through my senses is his lower nature. What I do not see but feel as my own existence, my own consciousness is his higher nature. I cannot vouch for any other person's consciousness, but I can vouch for my own because I Feel I exist, that nobody can take away from me. This consciousness cannot be displayed in any other way other than when I act outside. Then you can say, he's speaking, he's talking, he's alive.

So that is higher nature. Consciousness which is making this equipment which is inert to function in this world is the higher nature. If you understood these two, then first for focus your mind onto me, constantly think about me does not mean that you have to drop everything and start thinking about him. But whatever you think in the back of your mind, you should think that he is the enabler of this thought. Without his presence, without this consciousness, this mind just cannot even run away in different directions. At least you should have that as a background thought.

Just as in music you have the Shruti playing in the background. Nobody pays attention to the Shruti. But you miss Shruti, then you are done with your Bhajan. So if you attention to the shruti, then the entire music falls in place. Once you miss Shruti, everything is haywire. Our Shruti should be that I am that Satchitananda, this consciousness is me.

But when we miss that and ignore that, then the music of our life falls apart. Bhagavan said, therefore my Aveshimana and then my intellect Buddhi Nivesha have placed your intellect into me. So now that intellectually we appreciate it, the Bhagavan is everywhere. There is nothing that exists without Bhagavan. Everything I see is Bhagavan alone. Now my intellectual reminds me every time I transact in this world.

Then no matter what I think about, the opposite party which I'm dealing with is nothing but his own representation. And Bhagawan said, if you keep that in mind, you will never be able to do anything wrong. You will not be able to perform any crime. And therefore he says, Nivasyasi Maiyeva Ata Urdham na Sansaya. If you constantly keep this thought in your mind and have your intellect constantly remind you that whatever you are dealing with in this world is nothing but his Prakriti, then you will come to me. You will reside in me.

There is no doubt about it. So Bhagavan had clearly clarified. The Bhakti is all about mental control. Having their mind focused onto the supreme reality. We find that actually very difficult. Because we all have admitted that controlling mind is not that easy.

So Bhakti is actually a destination. You start your journey from Karma Yoga. If have no other training in spirituality and somebody says this is the path, then easiest path is Karma Yoga. Because you can control your action with that. When you purify mind and intellect, your intellect becomes ready for knowledge. Then once you get knowledge, you really have to do nothing.

You don't have to do anything. Bhakti will reveal itself automatically in your mind. It's like when you fell in love. You didn't even realize when you fell in love. You started knowing about her at some point. You didn't realize when you fell in love.

There is no timeframe you can say on such and such date, I fell in love. I went to a music teacher when I was in my late 40s. And I kept saying Subhashi, I really have trouble understanding what you are saying. I understand it, but I don't feel it. You're telling me you're out of rhythm. But I don't know when I'm out of rhythm.

When I stopped going to the class at some point I started understanding it that I'm out of scale, I'm out of rhythm. And when that happened, I cannot pinpoint when the knowledge of scale and rhythm came. There is no timeline for it. But it is because of the music classes I took. This is what is called skill. So Bhagavan said, all you have to do is purify your mind and intellect.

Put your mind and intellect in me and this will happen automatically. Once you achieve Bhakti, as Narad Muni said, it is amruta Swarupa. You will have no fear of death. You will feel Trupta. You will have nothing to achieve anymore in this world. Bhagavan is very kind and said there are alternates.

If you don't think that is possible for you even after going through last five chapters, then he said, if you are not capable of controlling your mind then just perform Abhyasa Yoga. Abhyasa Yoga is simply to keep reminding yourself that I am deviating from what I have learned and try to bring it back to to. Your goal is Abhyasa Yoga. It's constant practice. But practice makes you perfect. By practice, you can train the wild animals in circus.

So obviously you can train your mind. If wild animals can be trained, your mind can be trained. That's given it is how much practice you perform. Bhagavan says, just keep practicing. But somebody like me says, Bhagavan, even that's really difficult. Because I get so distracted by my thought that I even forget to remember that I have to bring my mind back where it should be.

And Bhagawan has already said in chapter seven that all my duos at Udaraha, they are noble people. No matter what level they are. Udara, Sarvaevethi, they are all good people. They are performing good actions. No matter how incomplete they are. No matter how incapable they are to realizing their own self.

But they're good people. At whatever level you are, you are at a KG level or at a high school level. But you can start your journey towards your goal. Abhya sahibi sambar tha piya matkarma paramao bhava. Then perform actions for me. But keep in mind that I am doing it for the Lord.

In a sense that if I have come to realize that there is nothing but the Lord alone. Whoever I serve, I'm serving him. In your profession, when you serve your clients, you keep in mind that the client is nothing but his own representation. You serving him, he's serving the Lord. You serve other people. They are also formed the same Lord.

And therefore I'm serving Him. So keep that thought in mind that I am performing all actions for him only. Mother sama, bhi karmani kurvan siddhi mabashe. Even just by performing actions for me, you also can achieve that perfection. So you don't have to meditate. You don't have to do any kind of tapas.

But if keep performing your actions for me alone. But keep in mind that you're not doing it for yourself. This limited self has to be removed from this equation. Now I want welfare of all beings. But even that is not possible. You are so selfish that you can think about anybody but yourself.

What I'm doing is for myself or I am the doer. The ego is so strong. Bhagawan says atha etad API asaktavasi. If you are even incapable of doing so, then kartum udayoga masritah sarvak karma falatyaga. If you cannot perform all actions for me, perform actions for whatever purpose you are performing before. For accomplishing things, achieving things.

Get respect in the society. Your big bank balances, all that is good. Continue doing the same thing you are doing. But give up the anxiety for the fruits.

snippets.sanskrit:
अद्वेष्टा सर्वभूतानां मैत्रः करुण एव च |

सन्तुष्टः सततं योगी यतात्मा दृढनिश्चयः |

यस्मान्नोद्विजते लोको लोकान्नोद्विजते च यः |
snippets.transliteration:
adveṣṭā sarvabhūtānāṃ maitraḥ karuṇa eva ca .

santuṣṭaḥ satataṃ yogī yatātmā dṛḍhaniścayaḥ .

yasmānnodvijate loko lokānnodvijate ca yaḥ .
verseTranslations: He who is incapable of hatred towards any being, who is kind and compassionate, free from selfishness, without pride, equable in pleasure and in pain, and forgiving,
Always contented, self-centred, self-controlled, resolute, with mind and reason dedicated to Me, such a devotee of Mine is My beloved.
He who does not harm the world, and whom the world cannot harm, who is not carried away by any impulse of joy, anger or fear, such a one is My beloved.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 12. This is Bhakti Yoga, the Yoga of devotion. And as we had been discussing that Bhagavad Gita is the science of self improvements. So we started out with the first. Section of the Bhagavad Gita to understand who we are and how our body, mind and intellect functions, and how you can get the most effective actions. So that segment ended with meditation.

Once you understood what is myself and what is not myself, you have to contemplate on it, meditate on it. To move this identification from this limited self which is very natural to us. You consider this is me to that supreme Me, the self which is all pervading. And then we have seen the Lord's nature. Once you identify with the self, what is the nature of that self? What I need to meditate on.

So the chapter seven through 11, we have seen the nature of that self, that all pervading self and that segment ended in Bhakti Yoga, the Yoga of devotion. The identification with that supreme self is devotion to that supreme self. We have many, many times discussed devotion is love. For divine love is nothing but identification. Identification only comes by finding our common traits, common ground. Our common ground with the supreme self is I want happiness, unlimited happiness, unlimited existence and unlimited bliss.

This is where I'm looking in my life. Scripture says, the only way you can do it once you identify with that self. So the Bhakti Yoga is the yoga of devotion. How to achieve that identification? We have seen there are two types of way of meditating upon the supreme, either with the form or without the form. And the Bhagavan said, with form is easier for the one who is associated with the body, one who is more attached to this body, this limited ego.

It's easier to identify with the Lord with the form, whatever form that you and I can assign for our own personal God. And then he says, what is devotion? He said, devotion is the complete surrender of my mind to Him. Right now, my mind is surrendered completely to my ego. My mind and intellect have identified completely with my ego. And therefore I am one with my ego.

My identity is my ego. And therefore all the limitations of my mind and intellect are now the limitations of myself as identified with the ego. The sorrows which I'm experiencing in life, the unhappiness which I'm experiencing in my life are because of these limitations. My inner self is seeking complete happiness, unending happiness, unbound happiness. But I am identified with my ego. And therefore the limitations of my mind and intellect are creating the unpleasant situations.

So to get out of this situation, the only way I can achieve that perfect happiness is by identifying with that supreme self, the self which is residing in me, residing in you, residing in him, residing in her. And everything that we perceive, think. Consider as our world and Bhagavan. Therefore, in the last seven verses of this chapter, starting from verse 13 enumerates the qualities of a true devotee. A true Bhakta who has surrendered his or her mind and intellect to the supreme self. So now the mind and intellect have become the instrument of the supreme Self, the Lord we have seen.

In last two verses we discussed verse 13 and 14 where Bhagavan has enumerated 11 qualities of a true devotee. Where we are saying Advaishta, Sarvabhutana, Maitra, Karuna Yevacha, Nirmama, Nirahankarah, samadu kaksha kakshami. He hates no creature, he is friendly to all beings, he's compassionate, he has no ego, he has no sense of attachment. He is balanced in pleasure and pain. Santustha Satatatam, Yogi, Yatatma, Dhrinisthayaha. He is ever content, steady in meditation about who he is.

He is self controlled and he possessed firm conviction with mind and intellectual, dedicated to the supreme self. Bhagavan says, such a person is my Bhakta and he is dear to me. Continuing the same description of true devotee Bhagavan Describes in verse 15. Yasmaat na udvijate Lokaha. He by whom the world is not agitated. If my presence makes the world around me agitated, then obviously there is something I need to correct.

We have experienced this all the time. Some people can just enter the room and suddenly the room will be in a very positive mood, in a very joyful mood. That he will bring that joy, that enthusiasm, that excitement in the room. And some people come in the room and there is a gloom and doom is what we experience. Now we have experienced this or we can feel about this about our day to day acquaintances and friends. But truly we have experienced this in presence of a Mahatma.

I obviously have experienced in presence of Swami Chinmayananda where people used to sit for hours, including myself, without doing anything. Just sitting in front of him and just watching him. And it gives you such a peace in your mind that you just don't want to leave. I tell people that for long time when Swamiji comes, all the devotees will get together. Those who are close to him, who gets a chance to be with him and just be in his room. And Swamiji is doing whatever he's doing.

He's watching tennis. Because Swamiji used to love watching tennis after lectures. Somebody has taped his Wimbledon or whatever the tournament, and he will be watching that. And other people are just watching Swamiji but feel peace. In a very early days of this exposure to spirituality. My mentor at the time was a chief architect where I used to work as an intern architect.

After the first year of architecture school and a vacation, he took me to St. Morta in Surat. And at the time I didn't understand much. But because my chief architect was telling me that you should come with me, I went along with him. And somebody asked Santamurta a question and said, murta, how do we know that a person we are meeting is a sadhu, is a saint, is a true saint or a true sadhu? Because he could be a cheat. He could be just putting up a show and cheating people.

And Samatamhurta said, there is only one test for it. If in his presence you feel peace, he is the true sadhu or a sanyasi. If in his presence your mind gets agitated, consider that that person is not a saint or a sadhu at that age. I was only about 17 at the time and I couldn't understand how that can be. But over the years I've experienced that in presence of a Mahatma, a peace prevails in your mind. Automatically he projects his peace into your mind and everyone around him.

So Bhagavan said, yasmatna udvijate lokaha. He by whom the world is not agitated, his presence bring peace and joy to the people around him and the world around him. We obviously have heard that in presence of Lord Buddha and Sach Mahatma, even the animals will just sit down in front of him and feel peace. Lions and tigers have been calmed by Lord Buddha. So Lokat na udvijate chayaha, neither he agitates the world nor the world can agitate him. As we had seen that in presence of great Mahatmas like Lord Buddha, even the Animals feel peace and they will come down in front of him.

So this is a test or these are the qualities you find in a true devotee of the Lord. That in his presence you will experience joy. And your agitation in your mind will not affect him. Sometimes everything is going good. But as soon as I come from my office, I create the agitation in the house. Because I bring my agitation from the office to the house.

And now my household which was peaceful without me is now agitated because of my presence. Therefore we typically have the threat to our children. Well, you just wait, dad is coming. That means there will be now a turmoil and agitation in the house. So you behave and not add any more agitation to his agitation. So we put a lot of burden on our children to calm down their parents.

Obviously I'm joking. So Bhagavan said that my devotee is such a person who brings peace to this world and does not get agitated by this world. Harsh Amarsh, Bhaya, Udvega, Muktaha is free from joy. Harsh Amarsh, envy, Bhaya fear and udvega anxiety. Such a person, Bhagavan says Yah Sacha me priyah. His closer to me does not mean that now Bhagavan is partial to him.

But he feels the peace prevailing in the supreme self as his peace. And therefore he is closer to him. Continuing in the same vein, the next two verses form the third segment of the qualities of a true devotee. And it says Anapekshaha, Shuchi, dakshaha, Udasinaha, gata, vyatah. So so far in the previous stanza we have seen about 14 characteristics of a true devotee. In this stanza we see six more.

They say Anapekshaha, he is free from all wants. He has no expectation from this world. Now these are very difficult concepts for you and I to understand. Because we live in a world where expectation and anticipation and performing to the one's expectation. And all these things are a normal part of our vocabulary in the business world, in our regular world we live in. But what we are talking about is my internal world.

We are not talking about the world outside. And I dealing with the world of my peers and my superiors and my enemies and my competitors. That's the world my ego has created. Now the world we are concerned about is the world for myself, my inner self. For that inner self there is no real enemy or there is no real competitor. Because the same self which is pervading the entire Jagat is also residing in me.

And I'm trying to get in contact with that. Once I am in touch with that Bhagavan said, you will have no apeksha. I am satisfied by my own self. And therefore I have no other expectation from the world. Up till now my expectation world will make me happy. My children will grow up and then will do this and they will make me happy.

My wife will do this and that will make me happy. My friends will do this and that will make me happy. I have mortgaged my happiness with all the people which I know but have not left anything for me to do. So now I have no control over my happiness. I have to rely on the people who mortgage my happiness. So they have to do something to make me happy.

My children have to perform well in their studies or in their sports or whatever I expect them to do. My wife have to perform according to my desires. My friends have to behave the way I want. When they do that, I'll be happy. So I mortgage my happiness. And therefore I apeksha expectations from the world to make me happy.

Bhagavan says my devotee is Anapekshaha. There is no expectation because he is the reservoir of his happiness. Someone who is devoted to the Lord. He cannot be filthy and dirty. Both in his own mind, intellect and also in his surroundings. He will live a clean life both inside and out.

When your mind is clean you automatically will make your environment around you clean. It has a reverse effect also. When my environment around me is clean it will calm my mind down and my mind will be clean too. There is no laziness in him.

snippets.title: Day 166: The Ideal Devotee
snippets.sanskrit:
अनपेक्षः शुचिर्दक्ष उदासीनो गतव्यथः |

यो न हृष्यति न द्वेष्टि न शोचति न काङ्क्षति |

समः शत्रौ च मित्रे च तथा मानापमानयोः |
snippets.transliteration:
anapekṣaḥ śucirdakṣa udāsīno gatavyathaḥ .

yo na hṛṣyati na dveṣṭi na śocati na kāṅkṣati .

samaḥ śatrau ca mitre ca tathā mānāpamānayoḥ .
verseTranslations: He who expects nothing, who is pure, watchful, indifferent, unruffled, and who renounces all initiative, such a one is My beloved.
He who is beyond joy and hate, who neither laments nor desires, to whom good and evil fortunes are the same, such a one is My beloved.
snippets.commentary:
Shri Purohit Swami did not comment on this sloka

What is my purpose and destiny? We have been discussing chapter 12, Bhakti Yoga, Yoga of Devotion. The first six chapters described Karma Yoga or taught us Karma Yoga, the Yoga of action, who we are as individuals and how our actions function and how we can make our actions more efficient. We have seen two definitions of Yoga, Samatvam Yoga Ucha there, then we also send Yoga Karma Sukhav Salam. The equanimity of mind is Yoga. And also the dexterity in action is Yoga.

You can only be dexterous in your actions if your mind is quiet. So that was the technique we learned in first six chapters. And then in the end of those chapters we had Dhyana Yoga, Yoga of Meditation. Bhagawan said, I consider Yogi to be higher than even a Gnani, even Tapasvi. So therefore he said, you become Yogi Arjuna. He said, how do I become Yogi?

He said, you offer your mind and intellect to me, focus your mind and intellect to me, synchronize your mind and intellect to me, and you become a Yogi. Bhagavan has defined a perfect Bhakta. Bhagavan defined his devotee as the one who offers his mind and intellect and considers him to be the supreme goal. Now here we discussed that Bhagavan, the supreme self which is pervading everywhere, is the same self as you consider yourself. Right now I consider myself to be identified with this body, mind and intellectual. Bhagawan said, when you tune your mind and intellect to me and align with me and identify with me, you become my Bhakta.

So that's the definition of bhakta we learn up front in this chapter. Mai Arpit Manobuddhe, one who has offered his mind and intellect to me. Swamiji used to joke about it that in all our temples, the Bhagavans are standing there with the hand extended, hoping that some Bhakta will come someday and offer his mind and intellect to me. I'll fix it and give it back to him. But he says they're all unemployed. When no Bhakta ever goes to offer his mind and intellect.

They go and offer them coconuts and flowers and prasads, but nobody interested in giving their mind or intellect to Bhagavan. So Bhagavan has defined in this chapter, the devotee is the one whose mind is fixed on him and his intellect is aligned with him. We started this chapter with Arjuna's question the two types of Bhaktas. One who consider God to be manifested in a particular form and worshipping him as his goal, and one who considers God to be Nirakar without any attributes, only all pervading. Which one is better, which one is closer to him? And Bhagawan said, both are closer to me.

But for somebody who considers himself to be embodied, who identifies with his body as him, for him, it is very difficult to focus on God without any attributes. Therefore, it is much easier for you, Arjuna, to focus on someone or something you consider as the representation of the supreme reality. In this case, Bhagavan said, krishna as me, if you focus on me as the representation of the supreme reality. So you basically say the entire divinity in that person. Swamiji explains, just as we see my entire patriotic feelings are assigned to the flag of my country. When that flag is raised in that stadium in the time of Olympics medal giving, all the citizens of that country feel elated because that flag represents their identification with their country.

Bhagwan said, in the same way, when you can identify in one person, in one thing, the entire supreme reality, then it is easier for you to worship that one. Then Bhagawan has given us choices that if you cannot offer your mind and intellect to me, at least do Abhyasa. There are two ways to interpret. One is to constantly trying to offer your mind an intellect to Bhagawan or other is to learn about the nature of God through the Scripturesan. Then that you come to realize what is the supreme reality is and then offer yourself to it. You see, if that is not possible, offer all your actions to me that you are working for me.

Surrender to me, and then I'll take care of everything. It's like when you work for a large company. Whatever you do in your position, you're actually doing it for the company. When you go for a meeting with your client, you don't say I am such and such. You say I represent such and such company. The whole entire power of that company is behind you.

Nobody knows better than me because I used to work for large companies. The last firm I used to work had 2100 people. So when I represent myself and Sam from Dubai and Davis, they obviously know that I represent 2100 people firm. When I left that firm and started my own firm, I had five people. When I go and say I'm NBG Architecture, first I have to explain what NBG Architecture is, who owns it and how it came into existence. Then I say I'm the same person used to meet.

Because the power of that company is what you're representing. Larger the company, the larger power you have. So if you identify with this limited mind and intellect, you're projecting the limited power of this mind and intellect. But if you identify with that universal mind and intellect, then when you work in this world outside, you're projecting the power of the supreme in this world. The Bhagavan said, do all your actions for me, consider me as your employer and then work in this world. And you will have the supreme power behind you to be successful in everything you do.

There's even that is not possible. Then give up the anxiety for the fruits of your actions. The Karma Falada, the Prakriti that will give you peace instantaneously. All those things may not give you peace instantaneously. But this one thing, if you give up the anxiety for the fruits of actions will give you peace instantaneously. No Achiraat right away you will get this peace.

So therefore Bhagavan in the end said Karma filth Yaga is the greatest devotion to me. In other words, you have given up the sense of ownership that I am the doer and I control my destiny. Once you have given up that all your anxiety will be gone and then you will be aligned with me. So but once he is my greatest devotee who gives up the anxiety for the fruits of actions. In the last few verses, Bhagavan has been defining perfect devotee perfect bhakta. From verses 13 onwards till verse 19, Bhagavan is defining a perfect devotee.

These qualities described for a perfect devotee are no different than the Muni we have seen in chapter two. The qualities are exactly same. They are presented in a different way. But they are exactly the same qualities which we are learning when Bhagavan consider such a person as his Bhakta. And Swamiji categorized these qualities into six categories. So after every other, every verse, Bhagavan said Samay Priyaha, such a devotee is closer to me, is dear to me.

When you say dear to me, Bhagavan is not partial that if you have this quality. And if you don't have this quality, I don't like you. But that person is identifying much closer the qualities which we have been seeing from verse 13 onward. It says that Adhvista Sarvabhutanam Maitra Karunayevacha, he does not hate anyone in this world. Now that is something we find it very difficult for us to do because we hate many things and many beings in this world. I hate cockroaches and I hate snakes.

Bhagawan said, you may not want to associate with them, you may want to stay away from them, but you do not hate them. It's not like Parasuram is, I'm going to go and make this earth. Nakshatri means no Kshatriyas on this planet. I'm not going to go and say I'll make this earth without any cockroaches because they have survived the longest. As we know, we will be gone, but they will be there. The Bhagawan said, one who is not hating anyone, then we have seen several qualities.

And then we are coming to the verse. Yasmatna dwijate Lokaha. This is a very important verse, Lokatna Dvijatechayaha. One who is not disturbed by others, he is not disturbing the world outside. My behavior, my presence should not agitate others and nor should I be agitated by others. I used to work for the company.

I had moved from Dallas from another company, wzmh. They gave me a project and said there was already a project manager. But they said they were looking for replacement. So they gave me that project. I went to the first meeting and the contractor said, neil, I'm glad that now you are going to be the project manager. The last project manager we have a guy named Howard Johnson.

He said he may not say anything, he may not do anything, but as he walks into the room, everybody will be tense and agitated. It's somehow the way he handled people, it just didn't make people comfortable. They say, you shouldn't be that type of a person. People should calm and comfortable in your presence. I remember one incident. My chief architect where I was interning in first years, architecture student who introduced me to Swami Chinmayanda.

He took me to another Sant Mota. He somehow was on a mission to introduce me to all great sages. And I kept telling him, padna, I have no interest in spirituality. But anyway, he introduced me to Sant Mota. He Founded this Moun Mandira. His concept was that you stay alone in a room as long as you can.

So people sign up for one day, two days, one week, one month. And the condition was that you just go there, do whatever you want to do. You chant, you read Bhagavad Gita, read even novel if you want to. But you are not connected with the world outside. No phones, no newspapers. Take what are the books you want to take.

But other than that you stay there. People used to come from all over the world to sign up for that Mount Mandir. I'm not sure whether it's still there or not. But he was called Sant Mota when Padya took me to him. Somebody asked Muta a question and I was only 17 years old. I hear all about some are fake sadhus who are genuine teachers.

How do we differentiate? Because we don't know how to differentiate between a fake guru and a real guru. What I say is very simple. If you come to that person and if you feel peace in your mind, he is the right Sadhu. In his presence you get agitated. Consider him to be not good for you.

I still remember that answer after all these years. And it is such a profound statement. Because I'll tell you what we have experienced ourselves in presence of Gurudev. No matter as many questions and as you went then I'm going to talk to Swamiji and tell him that these people are doing this to me and all that. You go there, you forget everything. You forgot what you were going to go and complain or even your own.

People used to just sit in front of Swamiji for hours. Swamiji keeps doing whatever he was doing. He was actually in those days watching. Swamiji always liked to watch tennis because he was a tennis player. So people will record all those Wimbledon matches and all that. And when Swamiji is relaxing, he will watch tennis.

We will have like 15, 20 people just sitting there for hours without any words exchanged.
snippets.reflection:
Consider the qualities of the ideal devotee described in this chapter: free from ego, equal toward friend and foe, steady in all circumstances. Don't judge yourself against this standard—just let it serve as a direction.

Which quality feels most needed in your life right now? How might you nurture it? The path of devotion isn't about achieving perfection but about orienting the heart toward what is highest.

Notice the moments today when you feel most connected to something greater than yourself. What conditions support that connection? How might you cultivate them?

snippets.title: Day 167: Steps to Devotion
snippets.sanskrit:
तुल्यनिन्दास्तुतिर्मौनी सन्तुष्टो येन केनचित् |

ये तु धर्म्यामृतमिदं यथोक्तं पर्युपासते |
snippets.transliteration:
tulyanindāstutirmaunī santuṣṭo yena kenacit .

ye tu dharmyāmṛtamidaṃ yathoktaṃ paryupāsate .
verseTranslations: Who is indifferent to praise and censure, who enjoys silence, who is contented with every fate, who has no fixed abode, who is steadfast in mind, and filled with devotion, such a one is My beloved.
Verily those who love the spiritual wisdom as I have taught, whose faith never fails, and who concentrate their whole nature on Me, they indeed are My most beloved."
snippets.commentary:
What is my purpose and destiny? We've been discussing chapter 12, Bhakti Yoga. Devotion is love for the Divine. Love is nothing but identification. When we identify with someone more, we identify more. We like that person more.

When identification becomes complete, we say we fell in love with that person. So Bhakti is nothing but the love for the Divine. The love cannot occur without knowledge of that person or knowledge of that thing. So in this case, loving God is not possible without knowing God. So knowledge is as important as my desire to love God. So the knowledge about God or knowledge about the Supreme Being is what we had been learning from Bhagavan.

In last five chapters. From chapter 7 through 11, Bhagavan elaborated what is the nature of the Supreme. In chapter seven he says, there is nothing greater than Me. And then he has explained that everything that you see is nothing but me. That the Prakriti you see is nothing but my lower Prakriti, my lower nature which is manifest Prakriti. So he has described his lower Prakriti as the manifest world which we see.

We complain that we have not seen Bhagavan. But Bhagavan said, you see me every day. You deal with me every day. You just do not know that you are dealing with Bhagavan because there is nothing other than me in this world. Then he had described many aspects of this Prakriti. How we can identify his presence in Prakriti which we have seen in chapter 10 in Vibhuti Yoga that anything which you see which is excellent in this world, consider that to be my presence.

I am the strength in strong and the intelligence in intellect. I am the fragrance in flower. Everything that right now I consider is something other than me. Bhagavan said, it is me, the supreme alone. So right now my identification is so complete with this limited self that I am. I consider this body, mind and intellect is me.

So this identity is so complete they allow myself. Loving myself is very easy. In spite of all my shortcoming that I am aware of, I Never hate myself, because the identification is so complete that I'm in love with myself. But once again, the quest in life is to change this identification from this limited self to the supreme self. For that to happen, I obviously didn't know Bhagavan. As we have seen in last five chapters, Bhagavan has been telling us what is the nature of the supreme.

In chapter 11, before this chapter, we have seen that Bhagavan has demonstrated that everything comes out of me and everything is merging into me, whether you consider good, bad or ugly. Because it's very easy for us to associate divinity with something which is very pristine and sattvic. But it's very difficult for our mind to associate divinity with something which does not work with me, which is not conducive to me. Therefore, in this chapter, when Bhagavan explaining Bhakti describes the nature of the perfect devotee. From the beginning of this chapter we have seen Arjuna's question, which is better? One who worships this manifest Prakriti, the manifest nature of the God, those who worship supreme without any attributes.

Because in the end we have learned that he does not have any form. He is not a man, he is not a woman, he is not it, he is not she, he is not he, he's everything. So without any form, it is very difficult for us to grasp his nature. That higher Prakriti of mind, Bhagawan said, is very different than the manifest Prakriti which you see. But to focus on that higher Prakriti, my mind may not be capable of. The Bhagavan said, for those who consider them to be identified with this body, the embodied ones who consider this is me.

As we said we, our identity is so complete with this body, mind, intellect. Nobody is to tell me that this is me or that's me and this is not me. Rest is the world outside. It's a one who considers that for him to focus his mind on unmanifest is very difficult. Klesa, Adhiktara, Tesha. For them the difficulty is much greater.

So for them it is easier to focus on one form which you find Divine Ramakrishna or Gurudeh Swami Chinmayanda in his presence, you don't have to figure out what the God looks like. Many children in our neighborhood, when Sadhguru Deva came to our house, the God came to Bhatt's house. Because we associate the divinity with God, Bhagawan said, this may be easier for you, Arjuna, at your level the easiest way for you to worship me is give your mind and intellect to me. In other words, synchronize your mind and intellect with me. As we have discussed last time, wwkd, what would Krishna do in this situation? The Christian bracelets called wwjd.

It's for teenagers who are facing this peer pressure and see should I smoke or not smoke? You say, Think about it. Look at the breast lights in wwjd. What would Jesus do in this case? Synchronize your mind and intellect with me. Give your mind and intellect to me and make me supreme goal.

I'll take care of myself. If that is not possible, Bhagawan gives another option. Constant practice or constant learning of the nature of Lord from the scriptures. If that is not possible, give me all your actions, work for me and do all your actions for me. My employer is Lord Krishna. Everything I do is for him.

Because even that is not possible. Then just do Karma Falath Yaga. Don't expect anything from what you do. In the end he said, Karma Falath Yaga is the greatest of all because it gives you peace instantaneously. As soon as you give up the anxiety for the fruits of actions, your mind will stop agitating about it. Most of my agitations about the fruits fear of what will happen in future.

Bhagawan said, once you give up, that peace will come automatically. Therefore it is greater than anything. So Bhakti is like a hov lane on highway. It takes you to your destination much quicker than other paths. Karma yoga, Nana yoga, Dhyana yoga. Those are slower paths.

Margaret, there are several entry points you can have. Either you are ready and give your mind to me. If you're not ready, keep practicing. If not, keep working for me. If not, just give up fruits of actions and you will be my Bhakta. And then in last few _Verses_ Starting from verse 13, we've seen the nature or the characteristics or qualities of a perfect devotee.

All our preconceived notion about a bhakta, that he has given up everything and he is just doing nothing but bhajans all day long. And as Swamiji used to say, with those noisy accompaniment, he said, no, that's not bhakti. Bhakta is the one who has these qualities. So Bhagawan has given the litmus test of who is a perfect devotee. And Swamiji enumerates 36 qualities of a perfect devotee starting From Adwaishtaha Sarvabhuta Ram Maitra Karunayevacha. One who does not hate anyone.

As I said, it is so difficult for us to even have that concept. Because so many things we don't like in this world we have seen. As long as you have the identification with this bodyman, intellect within the realm of this body, realm of this mind, realm of this intellect. And therefore anything which is not conducive to the body, I'll hate. It's too hot, it's too cold, you know, because it's not conducive to my body. When I used to live in Nairobi, you don't need air conditioning, you don't need heating.

Because city by nature is perfectly air conditioned. The temperature remains between 65 and 75 all throughout the year. So I find that very conducive. Good city to live in. Till we found out that Meena and my son Neeraj both had asthma because of the high altitude. So now for me it is very conducive.

For them it is completely not conducive. So Bhagawan says, as long as you identify this body, mind and intellect. There is something which is mentally conducive. Sometimes mentally not conducive, intellectually conducive, intellectually not conducive. But one who is not identified with this, for him it is okay to worship the God without any form. But in true Bhakta reaches that point.

So we have been seeing these qualities from last few _Verses_. Sama satra uchamitrecha tatham mana apamana yoho sita ushna sukha dukeshu sama sanga vivarjitah. One who is not now considering this body, my intellect to be me, but my equipment. For him, his relationships are very neutral in all aspects. Nobody is my friend and nobody is my foe. But there is a Vyavaharik relationship I will have.

The people who help me are my friends. The people who hinder me are my enemies, not my. But that's a Vyavaharik relationship. But the core of my being. I remain equanimous to them. As long as I identify with my mind, there will be honor and dishonor.

Obviously we architects put out our buildings for all to see. They saying that doctors bury their mistakes. We put out for the world to see. And I avoid passing by those buildings, the ones which I like. I make sure that I pass by that building because that's intellectual level. Honor and dishonor is what I perceive.

But you see the True bhakta. For him, both are equal. Sita, ushna, Sukha, Dukhyadeshu and the body level, hot and cold. That does not mean that I don't feel hot. Somebody asked Swamiji Gurudev, why do I always say that you go in the best car? Because people go to pick up Swamiji at the airport.

Somebody's a Mercedes or BMW or Lexus. There are people who have Toyotas. You don't go in those cars. Swamiji said, I'm not stupid. If there is best car available, which is more reliable, it is not going to break down on the way. Why should I take a chance and go in an old Subaru with my breakdown highway?

So when it is available to me to mitigate the discomfort I have at the bottom, I will do it. But if it is not available, I persevere and continue. Sita ushna, sukhaduka, agama apa. You know, Anityaha, they come and go. I remain constantly at peace because Samaha, sangha, vivarjitah. I remain constant, constantly in the state of bliss or equanimity because I'm not attached to any of these worlds of mine.

Physical, mental, intellectual. Tulya nindah tuthi mauni tulya Nindahast is equanimous to criticism and praise. Because no matter what you do, somebody will praise the same act and somebody will hate that act. Supreme Court took a decision on those abortion pills. Democrats are rejoicing. They did the right thing.

Republicans are saying, what is this court doing? So Ninda and Stuti both I consider to be not my doing, but their mental environment. Somebody will like what I say because it is conducive to him or her. Somebody will criticize what I say because it is not conducive to them. So therefore, a true devotee of the Lord, in other words, one who has identified himself with the supreme, he remains okay in all situations, Mauni. He becomes silent, not just physically or at the speech level.

At the mind level, I may be silent, but fuming inside. And that's very dangerous. You can end up in mental asylum if you don't vocalize your anger. You don't vocalize your ideas. You don't vocalize what's going on in your mind. But this silence at the mind level.

When Mouni, the true devotee, becomes silent. Santusta eena kena chit is content with this or that.

snippets.title: Day 168: The Field
snippets.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच |

श्रीभगवानुवाच |

क्षेत्रज्ञं चापि मां विद्धि सर्वक्षेत्रेषु भारत |
snippets.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca .

śrībhagavānuvāca .

kṣetrajñaṃ cāpi māṃ viddhi sarvakṣetreṣu bhārata .
verseTranslations: "Arjuna asked: My Lord! Who is God and what is Nature; what is Matter and what is the Self; what is that they call Wisdom, and what is it that is worth knowing? I wish to have this explained.
Lord Shri Krishna replied: O Arjuna! The body of man is the playground of the Self; and That which knows the activities of Matter, sages call the Self.
I am the Omniscient self that abides in the playground of Matter; knowledge of Matter and of the all-knowing Self is wisdom.
snippets.commentary:
We concluded chapter 12, Bhakti Yoga Yoga of Devotion. Now we'll be starting Discussion on Chapter 13, the Kshatrakshatragna Vibhaga Yoga Yoga of differentiation between the field and its knower. So far we have seen the two segments of the Bhagavad Gita which discussed DHA and that from the Mahavakya Tattvamasi. First six chapters we learned about Dao, Next six chapters we learned about that. Now we will be discussing about the correlative verb asi, the connections between the two and how to differentiate between the two. Therefore it's called Kshetra Kshatragna Vibhaga Yoga Yoga of the field and its knower.

In other words, how to differentiate between what I am not and what I am. There is a granth written by Bhagavan Shankaracharya or at least attributed to him called Drishya Viveka, which is similar in nature but more logically explained. Drek Drasya Viveka, discrimination between the seer and the seeing. Who is the seer and what is seen? If we can differentiate then we know the both. So the same way here it says Kshatrakshatragna Vibhaga how to differentiate the fuel from its knower.

So that's the theme of this chapter. In other words, we will be learning how to navigate through Maya. Maya is the entity which creates this confusion for me, who I am and what is my real nature. Maya creates this illusion of plurality where the only singularity exists. One exists, but it appears to be many. So the chapter now discusses this aspect of Maya in detail.

Swamiji explains here that this chapter suddenly after devotion, Krishna took up a theme which is completely different and therefore some interpolar has added this one verse. The very first verse, Arjuna Vacha, which seemed to be not there in previous commentators commentary such as Bhagavan Sankaracharya, he did not comment on the first verse Arjuna Vacha. He starts from the second verse, same as Naneswari starts also from the second verse. Not the first Sri Bhagavan, not from Arjunaja but because it is a subject which seemed like suddenly Bhagavan has taken up a different topic. Somebody thought it is appropriate to add a connector between what we have discussed so far and what we'll be discussing. So what we will be discussing is actually the continuation of the theme.

Bhagavan started in chapter seven and chapter eight. In chapter seven he talked about the Eightfold Lower Prakriti and the Manifest Prakriti. And then in chapter eight he talked imperishable Brahman. And then chapter nine, 10, 11 was somewhat of a distraction from the theme because Arjuna kept asking question. He wanted to know in what different forms to be thought about Bhagavan. So he gave the Vibhuti Yoga.

Then he wanted to know the Bhagavan in its totality to give him the Vishwarupadarshan. And then obviously it culminated in Bhakti Yoga. So Bhagavan picked up that theme again from chapter 7 8. In chapter 13 we want to continue the theme of how to differentiate between the Jiva and Paramatma and what is their connection. So as we have learnt in that great statement that thou art that which you are seeking and you who consider who you are are one and the same. But right now I don't see the connection.

Once I know the nature of both then I will be able to connect them both. So that's basically the theme of the chapter 13, Kshitrakshatragna Vig Yoga. The very first verse Arjuna Vacha basically gives you what we're going to discuss in this chapter. So as we've discussed many times, best presentation is when you go and tell them what we're going to talk about. You know, tell them what we are talking about and then tell them what you told them. This is what we discussed.

Summarize it, put an agenda up front, make the presentation and then summarize. So here the first verse which was attributed to Arjuna, it says Prakrutim Purusamcha Eva Kshetra Kshatragnam Eva Cha etat veditum ichami Gnanam Gnayam Chakishava. These are the things I want to understand clearly. So we pick up the themes from 7 and 8 chapter Prakrutin Purusha I want to know Prakrutin Purusham. We have discussed before, we need to brush up our knowledge what is Prakriti and Purusha and also Kshatra Nakshatra Gna, the field and its Knower, you talked about the field of my actions. This world currently is clear to me that this is the field of my actions.

For me it is very simple. I am the actor and this world is the field of my actions. So I am the knower of the field of my actions. But when it comes to knowing who I am, I have to go further down there. So we will talk about that. Kshatrakshatragnam evacha e titit vedutu mi cham I gnanam gneam cha KE So I also want to know what is knowledge and what is to be known.

So we clarified by this first verse what we'll be discussing. To know myself, I have to be very clear about what is Prakriti and what is Purusha, what is manifested, what is unmanifest. I also need to know what is the field of my activity, who is the actor. Also I want to know what is knowledge and what is to be known. Just simple curiosity. I want to know doesn't mean anything.

I need to know what is there to be known. So Arjuna asked this question to put the agenda forward for this chapter saying we want to know about these things. So the next verse where it changes the paradigm for us. Idam sariram konteya Kshatram ITI abhidhiyate. This body or kantea is called the field. Completely different than what I thought all along.

We thought that this world is the field. And I as this limited being is the knower of this world. I, I know my world, I know my field, my field of my profession, field of my activity. So right now I have considered this body to be the knower, this me, this limited being to be me. The knower Bhagwan said, no, this body itself is the field. This field which I consider to be the world and this body, mind, intellect to be me.

He said, no, this body belongs to the field, the Prakriti. You then knower is somebody different than that. This body is called the field. He who knows is called the Kshatragna. One who knows this body is the Kshatragna. Once I have established what the field is, who knows the field is the knower.

So from the perspective of the world, the I is the one which is the seer of this world. When I see the colors and forms, my eye is the seer, the world is the seer. When it comes to my eye, the mind is the seer and I is the seeing. When I see and say what is happening to my eye, who is seeing my mind is seeing my eye. So I took a step backward and put the seer in the field of the sea. And if I keep receding, then everything that I consider today to be me will belong to the field of Prakriti.

That which I consider to be me so far is my mind, my body, my intellect. That's what I define myself to be. But when seen from the perspective of what do I know, I know about my body. If I know my body, then I am the the knower. Somebody other than my body. Same goes for my mind.

I'm very aware that my mind is upset. So I am the knower of my mind. My mind is not, you know, calm today. Somebody who sees the mind to be not calm or calm. There is some other entity which is seeing the mind. That some other entities also can judge whether my intellect is sharp or dull.

I don't know about it. So there is somebody other than this body, mind and intellect who is the knower. One who knows all these three. So in short, Ibhagavan says the body is the field. The one who knows that is considered to be the knower. That's basically simple.

But because of my identification, I always considered this to be the seer. As I give the example that my eye can see but only with the aid of my glasses. So I consider the glasses to be as important as my eye. If I want to read without glasses, I cannot read. So glasses are as important for me to read as my eye is. But I don't consider my eye and glasses in the same category.

Because I know I can go to Lens Crafter and get replacement glass in one hour. I least today, is not that easy to replace. Someday it will be probably as simple. Till that time, I consider eye to be something very special. I consider _part of me without which I cannot see. But glasses I can replace.

But if I can now learn that even I can be replaced anytime, then I will also put the eye in the same category as my glasses are. So sometimes through which we see, we identify so closely that we forget the differentiation between the seer and seen. So Bhagawan changes this paradigm and says this body is the field through which the seer is functioning to manifest. Electricity needs all these lamps and gadgets. Electricity is present in this room when we can vouch for it. Because the lights are on, the air conditioning is on.

But you remove both air conditioning and the light. We will not know whether the electricity is in the room or not until you put finger in that outlet.
