snippets.title: Day 175: Prakriti and Purusha
snippets.sanskrit:
पुरुषः प्रकृतिस्थो हि भुङ्क्ते प्रकृतिजान्गुणान् |

उपद्रष्टानुमन्ता च भर्ता भोक्ता महेश्वरः |

य एवं वेत्ति पुरुषं प्रकृतिं च गुणैः सह |
snippets.transliteration:
puruṣaḥ prakṛtistho hi bhuṅkte prakṛtijānguṇān .

upadraṣṭānumantā ca bhartā bhoktā maheśvaraḥ .

ya evaṃ vetti puruṣaṃ prakṛtiṃ ca guṇaiḥ saha .
verseTranslations: God dwelling in the heart of Nature experiences the Qualities which nature brings forth; and His affinity towards the Qualities is the reason for His living in a good or evil body.
Thus in the body of man dwells the Supreme God; He who sees and permits, upholds and enjoys, the Highest God and the Highest Self.
He who understands God and Nature along with her qualities, whatever be his condition in life, he comes not again to earth.
snippets.commentary:
We have been discussing Chapter 13, Kshatrakshatragna Vibhaga Yoga, Yoga of Discrimination between the Field and its Knower. So far we have seen in this chapter the Bhagawan has described the Kshetra that this body is the Kshatra that includes not only the external instrument, also the internal instrument which mind Buddhi, Chittanahanka and all its modifications. Kshatragna is Paramatma alone. The Supreme Lord, the God, the Almighty, all pervading consciousness is the Kshatragni in all the fields. Then he said, I'm going to tell you what is Gnanam, Gnayam, Gnanagamyam. What is knowledge, what is to be known and how.

Then he explained how this Purusha and Prakriti are related to each other. The Purusha and Prakriti intertwine themselves and create this world which we experience. Purusha and Prakriti both are beginningless, both are the aspects of Ishwara. So in our cosmology we have Purusha and Prakriti. Both are beginningless, but they are controlled by Ishwara. Ishwara is the Mayapathy.

Ishvara is in charge of Maya. So Brahman with Maya becomes Ishwara and Ishwara is the Mayapati with his Maya he controls both the Prakriti and Purusha. Purusha is the knower. The attributes of Purusha we have seen Sat, Chit and Ananda. So Purusha is Sat, existence, Chit, Knowledge and Ananda the Bliss. These are the attributes of Purusha, the knower.

Then Prakriti has three Gunas, Sattva, Rajas and Tamas. Purusha has no Gunas, Prakruti has three Gunas. Purusha is sentient conscious. But interaction with the two create this world that we experience. So that's basically what we have so far learnt in this discussion. The last verse which we have seen which says Purushaha, Prakriti Staha Bhumte Prakriti Janguna.

When seated in Prakriti, when intertwined with the Prakriti, it experiences all the gunas of the Prakriti. Karanam Guna, Sangasya Sad Asat, Yoni Janmasu. And attachment to the Gunas is the cause for the birth in good or not so good wombs. In other words, the existence which I experience right now in this life is because of my attachment and avidya to the Gunas in my past life. Maybe two years before or before my birth. What I'm experiencing today is because of my attachment to the gunas of the Prakriti.

Because as the Purusha adopted all the Gunas so Purusha coming in contact with the Prakriti. All the gunas of the Prakriti are superimposed on the Purusha Purushas. All the attributes get superimposed in the Prakriti. So Prakriti experience the Satchit and Ananda. That's why we experience the sense of existence. And also we experience Sukha and Dukha as we have seen in this everywhere.

Prakriti on the other hand becomes sentient. Therefore my body becomes sentient, inert body becomes sentient. My mind knows and I also feel that Ananda or Sukharga. So he said Purusha Prante, Prakti. That's the reason we come into being. So we have like three bodies.

The gross body which everybody can see. The subtle body which is the internal instrument, the mind Buddhi Chitta Nahanka and the causal body which is the cause for both these bodies to come into existence. Which is my left Tor Vasanas, leftover desires which is what we learned in this previous chapter. The leftover impressions and desires prompt me to take birth in this particular situation. So these two bodies come into existence because of the past Karma Bhagavan Sangha is Sat Karma Janyam. Because of your good actions you achieve this gross and subtle body in this life.

And then he said, how this Pratibimba I think Jina, your question was is there anything reflecting? And Bhagavan Sankaraja Satupa directly answered that question saying Sthula Sarira Abhimani Jiva Namakam Brahmaprati Bambam Bhavati Sa Eva Jivaha Prakritya Swasmat Iswaram Binnat Vena Janati. So it says that the reflection of Brahman, the all pervading Almighty consciousness which is immutable undividable. Its reflection occurs in the internal instrument of that being. That being now receives the impressions reflection of the Brahman. And that is called Jiva.

Now this Brahman as the Purusha reflecting in the internal instrument of individual ego is called Jiva. So it's called Jivaatma atma. The self or the soul, it's called Jiva atma. This Jiva by nature of ignorance consider itself to be different from the Ishvara. This is where we not experience the almightiness of Ishvara. The consciousness which we have is nothing but the Buddhist all pervading Purusha's consciousness.

The Purusa as my soul has the same nature as the Brahman which is of Sat, Chit and Ananda. So this Sat aspect gives me the sense of existence. The Cheetah aspect gives me the sense of knowing. That's why I know myself, I know the world around me. I know my relationships that comes from that. And Ananda that I experience Sukhendukha in my life.

So this reflection is in my internal instrument. This internal instrument is right now not clean enough. It is also reflecting all other things of Prakriti. So this is more like if I am sitting in a dark room and suddenly light comes on and I see there are mirrors all around me. In that mirror not only I see myself but I also see everything in the room. Now not only I recognize myself in in the mirror but I also recognize everything in the room and I start identifying with them.

So the internal instrument not only reflects the Purusha, it also reflecting the world of objects. All the sensory perceptions we get, we get the sensation through our senses on the internal instrument. The internal instrument is like a mirror or like a film in a camera. It captures everything which comes to it whether it's a Purusha or the world of objects. It captures all the images. That sensation creates perception in the mind.

Then the mind asks the intellect to interpret and it creates conception. That's how we conceive thoughts, we conceive ideas, we conceive things outside. So Bhagawan Shankaracharya says it is the Brahman reflecting in your internal instruments become your individual ego. But I don't recognize it the same as Ishvara. Purusha with the Upadi of Maya becomes Ishwara Purusha with the Upadi of ignorance. In my case same Purusha superimposed by the ignorance, he becomes Jiva, the individual soul conditioned consciousness in case of Lord, unconditioned consciousness superimposed by Maya, by creativity.

Why Bhagavan creates the world? Because it is the very nature of that Purusha. So with that we'll go to the next verse. So next verse says, even though I see that as the cause for my birth in this Sansar, but this supreme Purusa in me, the reflection of the Brahman which I consider to be my limited self, also can be seen as Upadrista, Anumanta, Chabharta, Loka, Maheshwaraha, Paramatma, Iticha, opi Uktaha, dehe Ashmin, Purushah, Paraha, that Purushahaparaha, the supreme Purusha. In this body, the same supreme being which is everywhere, also in the same body. I call myself a Jiva.

An individual ego also is called Upadrasta, the onlooker. Because it is not really taking any part in the activities of my body, mind and intellect. This gross body, this subtle mind and intellect, they're functioning all the time. They are empowered by consciousness, consciousness not taking part in it. Therefore it is also called Upadrasta, onlooker, anumantacha. So that onlooker does not really discriminate between the good activity or bad activities.

But when my mind is thinking something higher, something nobler, something greater, he also becomes permitter. He allows me to act in that particular manner which will help me in my evolution. When I act in that manner, he becomes Bharata, the supporter of my activities and my evolution. He also becomes Bhokta. He also become the enjoyer of those actions. So this Purusha in me is a witness.

He also permits all the things which I do, good or evil. But when it is good, it allows me to grow, then also makes me enjoy those fruits of actions. He is also called Maheshwarah because he is no different than the Great Lord himself. Therefore he is also called Maheshwara. Maheshwara the Great Lord himself and Paramatma in the supreme soul. But looking from the different perspective, when I grow out of my ignorance that I am this body, I am this mind intellect, then I see him as the same Lord Paramatma.

I see him as Maheshwara, the Great Ishwara. So there is no difference between the Lord outside and Lord within me. Therefore, Bhagawan Shankaracharya says this should not be accepted. That Jiva and Paramatma are two different entities. It is one and the same, seen from two different perspectives, one through the lens of ignorance and Other through the lens of knowledge. Sa evam vitti purusam prakritim cha gunaihi saha sarvatha vartamano PI nasabuyo abhijayate.

Such a person who knows Purusha and Prakruti in their real nature, he knows that nature Purusha is satchit and Ananda. It never gets tainted by Prakruti's gunas. But Prakruti's gunas are superimposed on the Purusha when it comes in contact with it. We have heard example in Brahma sutras that if you take a iron ball and put it in fire, each will give its own gunas to the other. So the fire which is red hot, now the ball looks red hot. So the fire attributes are now on the iron ball.

And the fire which was formless, now you can see the round shape. Because that ball was round, you see the red hot ball of iron. So each gives its own attributes to the other when they come in contact with each other. So in this case also that we have seen that the Prakrudin Purusa gives each other their own attributes. One who knows that that they remain separate. They seem to be associated with each other.

They seem to be taking each other's gunas, but they remain separate Gunehi Saha including the gunas, Sarvatha, Varsamanoapi. No matter what situation or condition that person is, he doesn't take the next board. And this is somewhat of a difficult concept because it basically says all my actions in the past and present and future get nullified when I get this knowledge. So there are some technical arguments made here that what happens to the actions which I have performed in the past which are Sanchita Karma? So the actions are three types. Sanchida Karma, Agami Karma and Prarabdha Karma.

Prarabdha Karmas are which I am experiencing right now. The past actions mature today as my circumstances. I went to architecture school. I'm an architect now. That's a Prarabdhyakarna. So if a Gnani becomes knowledgeable about this, do all his karmas get nullified?

And the answer is no. He will continue to experience the Prarabdha Karma which I have matured now in this life. So you will still live this life. But then this Sanchita Karma which accumulated actions which are not yet matured, they get roasted so they never will fructify. And Agame Karma, which I will perform now onward, will have no Meaning because it does not create any more vasanas in me. We have realized that I am not this limited being.

And therefore I don't associate any of the gunas of the body, mind and intellect, even though body, mind and intellect continue to function as they were before. Therefore, these verses say, such a person, at the end of the exhaustion of this life, he will not take the birth again. So I'll leave it to you how you take it. But that's exactly what this verse says. The next verse says how people achieve the state of knowledge, that all the accumulated actions get burned. Prarabdha Karma means nothing because I don't really see myself as the enjoyer, sufferer, as a limited being.

And no actions in the future will make and any difference. Some highly qualified seekers, seekers of liberation, seekers of ultimate happiness, those who are highly qualified, they will achieve this by contemplation.

All the attributes get superimposed in the Prakriti. So Prakriti experience the Satchit and Ananda. That's why we experience the sense of existence. And also we experience Sukha and Dukha as we have seen in this everywhere.

The gross body which everybody can see. The subtle body which is the internal instrument, the mind Buddhi Chitta Nahanka and the causal body which is the cause for both these bodies to come into existence. Which is my left Tor Vasanas, leftover desires which is what we learned in this previous chapter. The leftover impressions and desires prompt me to take birth in this particular situation. So these two bodies come into existence because of the past Karma Bhagavan Sangha is Sat Karma Janyam. Because of your good actions you achieve this gross and subtle body in this life.

So it says that the reflection of Brahman, the all pervading Almighty consciousness which is immutable undividable. Its reflection occurs in the internal instrument of that being. That being now receives the impressions reflection of the Brahman. And that is called Jiva.

Now this Brahman as the Purusha reflecting in the internal instrument of individual ego is called Jiva. So it's called Jivaatma atma. The self or the soul, it's called Jiva atma. This Jiva by nature of ignorance consider itself to be different from the Ishvara. This is where we not experience the almightiness of Ishvara. The consciousness which we have is nothing but the Buddhist all pervading Purusha's consciousness.

The Purusa as my soul has the same nature as the Brahman which is of Sat, Chit and Ananda. So this Sat aspect gives me the sense of existence. The Cheetah aspect gives me the sense of knowing. That's why I know myself, I know the world around me. I know my relationships that comes from that. And Ananda that I experience Sukhendukha in my life.

So this reflection is in my internal instrument. This internal instrument is right now not clean enough. It is also reflecting all other things of Prakriti. snippets.reflection:
Today, practice distinguishing the field from the knower of the field. When emotions arise, notice: 'This is happening in the field, and I am aware of it.' When thoughts arise, the same.

You are not your thoughts, not your emotions, not your body. You are that which is aware of all these. This simple shift in identification—from the observed to the observer—is the beginning of liberation.

Pay attention to the moments when you forget this distinction and get lost in experience. Can you notice the moment of forgetting? The moment of remembering?

snippets.title: Day 177: The Knower
snippets.sanskrit:
समं सर्वेषु भूतेषु तिष्ठन्तं परमेश्वरम् |

समं पश्यन्हि सर्वत्र समवस्थितमीश्वरम् |

प्रकृत्यैव च कर्माणि क्रियमाणानि सर्वशः |
snippets.transliteration:
samaṃ sarveṣu bhūteṣu tiṣṭhantaṃ parameśvaram .

samaṃ paśyanhi sarvatra samavasthitamīśvaram .

prakṛtyaiva ca karmāṇi kriyamāṇāni sarvaśaḥ .
verseTranslations: He who can see the Supreme Lord in all beings, the Imperishable amidst the perishable, he it is who really sees.
Beholding the Lord in all things equally, his actions do not mar his spiritual life but lead him to the height of Bliss.
He who understands that it is only the Law of Nature that brings action to fruition, and that the Self never acts, alone knows the Truth.

By completely identifying with the lower self, I'm literally disassociating myself from the higher self. If I completely identify myself as the body, mind, intellect and say this is it. Runam krutva gurutumbibet yavad jeevet Sukam jeevet.

Even if you incur death, drink ghee, live happily. After this body is burnt, there is no coming back. So leave as comfortably as you can by whatever means. There is one type of philosophy which is Charvak Darshan, one of the schools of thought in our Indian philosophy. But once again if you are abiding to that thought then you have completely negated the existence of the higher self. You disassociated yourself with Sahara self.

You are not recognizing the existence of the higher self. That is killing your higher self by yourself identifying with the non self. This ego is not the self. This thinking entity. This thinking entity is inert and cannot think unless it is energized by the Purusha's presence, the sentience in me. But the ego starts thinking.

These are the qualities of mind. And therefore I am the Almighty for my world and I do not need any higher guidance. He says such a person kills the higher self by the lower self and he does not see the real truth. One who does not do that, he achieves the higher state of existence. Prakruti evacha Karmani Kriyamanani Sarvasah. One who sees that all actions are being performed within the Prakriti by the Prakriti and Atma.

One which is identified with this limited being, the limited self which is conditioned consciousness. That limited self is constantly getting the guidance from the higher self which is the paramatma. My own conscience, my own antaratma which guides me all the time. I know before I do anything whether it is right or wrong. My antaratna will tell me. The Bhagawan saying that you have let yourself down by your own self, not listening to the higher self. Because I'm always connected even though I am not aware of it. Just the conditioned space in the room is always connected with the universal space outside. There was never a division between the room space and the space outside. It is only in my mind that I see that as limited space.

Therefore I call this room space. All the things which I consider the attributes of the room space are actually those attributes are of the conditioning of the room, the walls, the length, width, height, the contamination or the room is clean or dirty. I call it A room space. But what I'm describing is the conditioning of that room. The same way Bhagavan said. When I identify with this conditioning, the node of the field becomes limited.

That is the ahamkartru, the ahankar. When it reflects the consciousness, it itself think it is consciousness. That consciousness is now reflecting the limitations of the condition in the body, mind and intellect. Just as the room space is now reflecting the limitations of the room. How wide it is, how long it is, how tall it is. All those are attributes of the conditioning, not of the space.

So Bhagwante samam pashanhi sarvatra sam avasthitam Ishwaram. One who sees this Ishwara pervading all knowers of these fields. He does not destroy the higher self by the lower self. By completely identifying with the lower self, I'm literally disassociating myself from the higher self. If I completely identify myself as the body, mind, intellect and say this is it. Runam krutva gurutumbibet yavad jeevet Sukam jeevet.

This thinking entity is inert and cannot think unless it is energized by the Purusha's presence, the sentience in me. But the ego starts thinking.

These are the qualities of mind. And therefore I am the Almighty for my world and I do not need any higher guidance. He says such a person kills the higher self by the lower self and he does not see the real truth. One who does not do that, he achieves the higher state of existence. Prakruti evacha Karmani Kriyamanani Sarvasah. One who sees that all actions are being performed within the Prakriti by the Prakriti and Atma.

In studying Bhagavad Gita, we have seen that the Bhagavad Gita divided into three parts describing Tattvamasi, that thou art thou, that is you, as you are that which is the Lord which you are seeking in the one. They both are one and the same. So in the first six chapters we have talked about you as we are today. Next six chapter we talked about the identity of the Lord. Myself and this supreme self are not two different cells, but just one and the same. So the chapter 13 started with saying how this differentiation come in our perception, in our understanding of I and the world, the duality created between myself in everything other than that which I consider myself. So the chapter 13 we have seen Kshetra, Kshetragna, Vibhaga Yoga. The differentiation that is created in my understanding between the field and its knower and the differentiation right now is very clear. I am the knower of the world that I know and world is my field of actions. This chapter takes it a one notch higher and said Idham Shariram Kaunteya Itikshetram.

This which I consider as a knower right now is actually part of the field. This body is the field and one who knows the body is the knower. So we took it to one more subtler level. The definition which I know intuitively that I am the knower and the world is my field. So now I have included my body as part of the world and I the knower, remains somewhat other than this body. Then we also include the mind and intellect and all my emotions into it.

You know, all the vikaras, the modifications of this field, all my emotions into it, my experiences into it. Then what is left who is aware of everything is the knower. The field is where all the activity is taking place. We have also defined it in a different way Prakriti and Purusha. So now we know there are two entities which constitute my world. My world is the world of the matter, the field in which all the activity is taking place.

And if there is no cause, it is beginningless. If this Prakriti and Purusha are the two aspect of the supreme, they both are beginningless. So we started with this basic understanding. Then he said, if that's the case, then obviously all hands are his, all mouths are his so anywhere or any place where a thing or a being is coming into existence that because of of the union between these two, the Prakriti and Purusha, the creation only takes place of anything or a being. When this to the Prakruti and Purusha, the field and its knower come together. If there is no knower, there is no field.

And if there is no field, there is no knower. As long as I consider myself a being, a living being, as long as one, I have this body, mind and intellect. And secondly, I'm aware of it. Therefore I wake up and say I had a good sleep. If I'm not aware of myself, I wouldn't be able to say that.

Therefore I say I exist even in my deep sleep. I exist as a waker, I exist as dreamer. I also exist as a deep sleeper. As this limited ego, I considered myself. And then Bhagavan takes us to the path where he says, what is knowledge and what is to be known? He said, what is to be known is seated in hearts of all the beings and all the things.

The core of our being is our awareness about our self that is to be known. Who is that that is aware of my being and that leads me to the knowledge is the knowledge. So I say those qualities will take me to knowing the self. Which then will make me aware that my self is no distinct than yourself and herself and himself, but is the one self. Tamam Pasyanhi Sarvatra sama Avesthitam Ishwaram. One who starts seeing that the Ishvara my Lord is sitting equally in all hearts is present everywhere equally. And therefore I'm not negating the supreme self by my small self Right now I've already negated.

I only consider this is me. Nothing other than this I consider me that's not me, that's not me, that's not me, that's not me. In Bhagavanje once I say this is all me, I'm not negated even though I'm aware of this limited self. But I'm also aware that this extension of this world is nothing but me alone. But the same time aware of my existence as the supreme self. So the last few verses we have seen last time say Anaditvat nirgunat tvat paramatma Ayam avyaha sarirasthobi karnataya nakarotti na lipyate. But my real self which is knowing this Prakriti has no qualities. Because as I said the Bhagavan, the self has no cause and therefore it is beginningless. And because it is beginningless and no cause, it cannot have any qualities which makes it limited. Therefore, knowing that the Paramatma which is immutable, imperishable is beginningless and qualityless. And so is the nature of myself. And therefore, though it is seated in my heart, in this body, as the propeller for this body to perform actions, it is not doing anything.

No actions are being performed by myself. All actions are performed by the qualities of the Prakriti. Therefore, in Gujarati there is a this saying Prana, Prakriti sate jai. The Prana, Prana and the Prakriti both goes together. Nothing goes first or nothing goes later. In other words, my inherent nature will not change no matter what happens.

Even though it seems he is seated in this heart and propelling this body, mind and intellect to act. The acts are only performed by this body, mind and intellect and belong to them alone. As long as this conditioned self is identifying with, suffers and it enjoys when that identification is removed there is no suffering or enjoyment because of the actions of this body. So therefore he says Nakaroti, he is not doing anything na lipyade he is not affected by it.

The next verse says, Yathas sarvagatam sukshmit akasham na upalipyade sarvatra avasthito dehe tata atman. The just as and I use very conveniently as an architect the space. But even they use the same justice because of its subtle nature. The space is not it says Akasha.

snippets.sanskrit:

verseTranslations: "Lord Shri Krishna continued: Now I will reveal unto the Wisdom which is beyond knowledge, by attaining which the sages have reached Perfection.
Dwelling in Wisdom and realising My Divinity, they are not born again when the universe is re-created at the beginning of every cycle, nor are they affected when it is dissolved.

snippets.commentary:
We have completed chapter 13 and started discussing chapter 14. So in the last chapter we have very exhaustively discussed the relationship of the nature and the knower of the Nature, the Prakriti and Purusha, the field and its knower, that we have seen that both are Anadi, both are beginningless. But all these activities take place in Prakriti. The self remains inactive, it becomes a witness, but its very presence makes it possible. All the activities, this field and its Knower, when come together, then only a creation comes into place. If there is a field but there is no knower, or the knower but there is no field, both cannot exist because field of the Knower only exists because there is a field and the field only exists because the Knower is there.

So this superimposition filled in its knower creates this world of plurality as we know. But it never really explained to us why this plurality, in other words, why this variety. We know that the Prakriti is beginningless. We know the Purusha is beginningless. Both are, even in terms of there is no difference in Prakriti here or Prakriti there. There is no difference between an over here and over there.

Then what is that causes all this world of plurality and the variations and modifications that we see that I am different than you are, you are different than you is. This chapter deals with that aspect of it, knowing that Prakriti is all pervading and even everywhere, so is the Knower. But the qualities of this Prakriti which creates this variety, as we know. So this chapter, Yoga of Gunas now talks about the nature of the Prakritis. Because we have seen that there is no activity taking place in the Knower, the self, but all the activities, all the Karmas are the cause and the cause of the Prakriti. The very nature of things and beings creates this activity and this variety.

So that will be discussed in this chapter. The chapter opens with Lord Krishna's declaration one more time, as he has done many different time before he says parambhuyaha pravakshami Gnananam Gnanamuttamam, I'm going to tell you, I shall again declare to you the supreme knowledge Gnananam Gnanamuttam, the best among all knowledge. What it really means is that we need to constantly keep repeating what is important, what is real and what is unreal. In the last chapter, in a very broad brush, we have seen that how we can disassociate ourselves as the knower from the field that included my body, mind and intellect. That was the paradigm shift for us, that this body, mind and intellect is part of the field. One who knows this body, mind and intellect is the knower of this field.

That knower is the self. That self is pervading equally among all the beings. However, it never explained then if that's the case, if the knower is the same, he's pervading everywhere. Why there is a variety why I am who I am and you are who you are. So this chapter says, if I know why I am who I am right now, if I have a guide to analyze my own self, I. I can introspect and say what makes me who I am. At times I'm a nice person, at times I'm a very angry man.

And at times I'm not so nice. What makes me that not so nice and nice? At various times, if I can have a guide where I can use that as the path to introspect myself, maybe I will have a better chance to understand myself as I exist as the jiva, as the individual ego and then can transcend that individual ego to identify with the self which is all pervading in all of us. Therefore, this knowledge is the most important knowledge among all the knowledges because it allows you to introspect your own self. Yat gnatva munayha sarve param siddham ita gataha. Anytime you have to sell something to somebody, you have to make sure that there is a proof.

You can't say that nobody has ever heard this before. You are the first guinea pig I'm going to try out on you. And let's see it works. This knowledge was used by many munis Yat gnatma. Knowing this knowledge, they attain the param siddhim, the highest supreme achievement. After going from here, it's pretty complex sometimes and sometimes can be misleading.

If you don't read between the line, the first one is say ita gathaha. After going from here. So we come to the conclusion that this knowledge will be only beneficial after I die, having been here, may not be possible for me to gain that knowledge. Then yad ginatva munay ha. All the Munis who knowing this, has achieved the supreme state. And we all know that we started out by saying what is the supreme state?

We are looking for the supreme state where there is no limitation. For me, I am right now suffering from my limitations. I want to get out of these limitations so that I can have eternal bliss. So am I qualified for this? And this thing can misguided and say munihi survey. So we think that all the Muni it is for the Munis.

Our picture of a Muni is as Swamiji says, guy who is in his 70s and 80s, somewhere in Himalayas with white beard and is surviving on just whatever he can gather around in Himalayas. Nothing to do with the Sansar. Swamiji tried to explain to us that Muni is one who is contemplating about his mind. In his mind he's contemplating about his self is a Muni. One who is a seeker of this knowledge is a Muni. As this knowledge becomes more and more clearer to him, Yad gatva this knowledge becomes clearer to him, get closer and closer to his goal.

Once this knowledge becomes his own, he achieves that final state where there is no limitations. Itaha kathaha after having gone from here, gone from here, from this state of my understanding that this is me, this body, mind and intellect is me. And the workings of my body mind are my doings. And I am the enjoy and suffer. Once that understanding has changed from body, mind and intellect are part of the field. And I am just the observer who makes this body, mind, intellect function.

So Itah kath going from this stage of identifying with the condition individualized ego which we have seen in the field and it's knower. The knower which identifies with the field becomes the individualized ego knower which identifies with my body, my mind, my intellect, becomes me, the jiva. Once that identification is detached and I see myself as every other self, I become free from that. Itha gath Munihi have come to understand this. The next would say Idam gnanam upashitya mama sa Dharmyam Agathah. So we have two entities right now in our understanding.

One is me who is eternally suffering. Because anytime I think I have achieved what I want, something else is higher than that which creates. So something gets out of My control. I think I have control all the situations. Then suddenly something gets out of control. We figured out everything is going right.

And suddenly we hear that oh my son is not doing son. Somehow I make sure that that side becomes. Then we figure out oh economy has. We try to manage things within our control. But then constantly something is getting out of our control. Then we know that oh, there is someone who has a control over everything that one never have to worry about.

He doesn't have to compete for jobs with anybody. He is the Lord of all these beings. This too has a complete division. I and him are separate. But my goal is constantly become him. Because my goal is to become without any limitations, without any sorrows.

So I'm constantly trying to become what I am from what he is. And Bhagavan says, Idam Gnanam Upashatya. One who has taken refuge in this knowledge. The knowledge which he has not given us yet, but he's going to give it to us. He has given us the kind of broad brush understanding of how things work in this. But how to get from here to there, we don't know yet.

But he says, idam Gnanam Upasatya mama sa Dharma Agathah. One who has taken refuge in the knowledge, they become one with me. Their dharmas have become what my dharmas are. My dharmas are limited. Right now his dharmas are unlimited. From this limitedness to unlimitedness, Bhagavan said, those munis who have understood this knowledge and became one with that knowledge have become one with me.

Sadharamyam Agatha API na upa jayante Pralayena Vihanticha. Broad statement for somebody like us who are worried about next paycheck and says that. They do not take birth even at the time of creation. We are saying, look, forget about the creation and Pralaya. I am worried about what's happening tomorrow. But he says, there's such a person Sargiya Pina upa Jayante Pralay na Vyatanti character.

And he doesn't get destroyed at the time of Pralaya. Because we are also pretty long term planners. So we say, okay, I mean I do all of that. But then again I'll take a birth and I'll go back to the same thing all over again. I'll realize that I'm that unlimited being. But then I'll take a birth again and then I'll start from scratch all over again.

Bhagavad said, no, once you have realized who you are, there Is no birth or death for you. He says, why if that happens, if everybody realizes this, well, obviously there is no creation and there is no Pralaya. So why are we going through all of this again? He says, this is self knowledge. This is for you to get out of the misery which you are going through. You are not worried about what the others are doing.

We are not taking over his job of creating and destroying. I am only concerned about me. If job market is bad and we have 10 of our friends who are out of job, including yourself, who are you most worried about to get a job? Good luck to all of you. Once I get a job, I get right Others may be what whatever they are doing. Bhagavan may be whatever his goal is in this Pralayas and creation.

I need to get out of this misery. He's the one who has understood this. He will never have to take birth again or die again. Swamiji explains in a logical, philosophical manner. He said, the world keeps on going the way it is. But I understand that this Prakriti is an illusion.

The creation is a trick of my mind. If there is a lump of clay or a play doh, I make the shape myself and assign value to it, that is to it all. Or it's an elephant or it's whatever it is. Nothing has changed in the plate or the clay itself. But my mind has now assigned a value that it's a creation created by me and I have given a name and form to it. Now if I don't assign the name and form to it and keep seeing the clay as it is, there is no creation taking place.

Now when I take that clay and that elephant would have made and destroy it into lump of clay again, that elephant is destroyed. If I have taken credit for that creation, assigned a name and form to it, but I never assigned a name and form to has remained what it was before. Lump of clay, Prakriti remaining Prakriti and Purusha remaining Purusha.
snippets.reflection:
Notice the play of the three gunas in yourself today. When do you feel clear and light (sattva)? When restless and driven (rajas)? When heavy and stuck (tamas)?

Don't judge—just observe. This observation itself is the beginning of freedom from the gunas' grip. The one who watches the gunas is not bound by them.

Consider what activities, foods, relationships, and environments increase sattva in your life. What increases rajas? Tamas? With this awareness, you can make wiser choices.

But all these activities take place in Prakriti. The self remains inactive, it becomes a witness, but its very presence makes it possible. All the activities, this field and its Knower, when come together, then only a creation comes into place. If there is a field but there is no knower, or the knower but there is no field, both cannot exist because field of the Knower only exists because there is a field and the field only exists because the Knower is there.

So this superimposition filled in its knower creates this world of plurality as we know. But it never really explained to us why this plurality, in other words, why this variety. We know that the Prakriti is beginningless. We know the Purusha is beginningless. Both are, even in terms of there is no difference in Prakriti here or Prakriti there. There is no difference between an over here and over there.

Then what is that causes all this world of plurality and the variations and modifications that we see that I am different than you are, you are different than you is. This chapter deals with that aspect of it, knowing that Prakriti is all pervading and even everywhere, so is the Knower. But the qualities of this Prakriti which creates this variety, as we know. So this chapter, Yoga of Gunas now talks about the nature of the Prakritis. Because we have seen that there is no activity taking place in the Knower, the self, but all the activities, all the Karmas are the cause and the cause of the Prakriti. The very nature of things and beings creates this activity and this variety.

So that will be discussed in this chapter. The chapter opens with Lord Krishna's declaration one more time, as he has done many different time before he says parambhuyaha pravakshami Gnananam Gnanamuttamam, I'm going to tell you, I shall again declare to you the supreme knowledge Gnananam Gnanamuttam, the best among all knowledge. What it really means is that we need to constantly keep repeating what is important, what is real and what is unreal. In the last chapter, in a very broad brush, we have seen that how we can disassociate ourselves as the knower from the field that included my body, mind and intellect. That was the paradigm shift for us, that this body, mind and intellect is part of the field. One who knows this body, mind and intellect is the knower of this field.

That knower is the self. That self is pervading equally among all the beings. However, it never explained then if that's the case, if the knower is the same, he's pervading everywhere. Why there is a variety why I am who I am and you are who you are. So this chapter says, if I know why I am who I am right now, if I have a guide to analyze my own self, I. I can introspect and say what makes me who I am. At times I'm a nice person, at times I'm a very angry man.

And at times I'm not so nice. What makes me that not so nice and nice? At various times, if I can have a guide where I can use that as the path to introspect myself, maybe I will have a better chance to understand myself as I exist as the jiva, as the individual ego and then can transcend that individual ego to identify with the self which is all pervading in all of us. Therefore, this knowledge is the most important knowledge among all the knowledges because it allows you to introspect your own self. Yat gnatva munayha sarve param siddham ita gataha. Anytime you have to sell something to somebody, you have to make sure that there is a proof.

You can't say that nobody has ever heard this before. You are the first guinea pig I'm going to try out on you. And let's see it works. This knowledge was used by many munis Yat gnatma. Knowing this knowledge, they attain the param siddhim, the highest supreme achievement. After going from here, it's pretty complex sometimes and sometimes can be misleading.

If you don't read between the line, the first one is say ita gathaha. After going from here. So we come to the conclusion that this knowledge will be only beneficial after I die, having been here, may not be possible for me to gain that knowledge. Then yad ginatva munay ha. All the Munis who knowing this, has achieved the supreme state. And we all know that we started out by saying what is the supreme state?

We are looking for the supreme state where there is no limitation. For me, I am right now suffering from my limitations. I want to get out of these limitations so that I can have eternal bliss. So am I qualified for this? And this thing can misguided and say munihi survey. So we think that all the Muni it is for the Munis.

Our picture of a Muni is as Swamiji says, guy who is in his 70s and 80s, somewhere in Himalayas with white beard and is surviving on just whatever he can gather around in Himalayas. Nothing to do with the Sansar. Swamiji tried to explain to us that Muni is one who is contemplating about his mind. In his mind he's contemplating about his self is a Muni. One who is a seeker of this knowledge is a Muni. As this knowledge becomes more and more clearer to him, Yad gatva this knowledge becomes clearer to him, get closer and closer to his goal.

Once this knowledge becomes his own, he achieves that final state where there is no limitations. Itaha kathaha after having gone from here, gone from here, from this state of my understanding that this is me, this body, mind and intellect is me. And the workings of my body mind are my doings. And I am the enjoy and suffer. Once that understanding has changed from body, mind and intellect are part of the field. And I am just the observer who makes this body, mind, intellect function.

So Itah kath going from this stage of identifying with the condition individualized ego which we have seen in the field and it's knower. The knower which identifies with the field becomes the individualized ego knower which identifies with my body, my mind, my intellect, becomes me, the jiva. Once that identification is detached and I see myself as every other self, I become free from that. Itha gath Munihi have come to understand this. The next would say Idam gnanam upashitya mama sa Dharmyam Agathah. So we have two entities right now in our understanding.

One is me who is eternally suffering. Because anytime I think I have achieved what I want, something else is higher than that which creates. So something gets out of My control. I think I have control all the situations. Then suddenly something gets out of control. We figured out everything is going right.

And suddenly we hear that oh my son is not doing son. Somehow I make sure that that side becomes. Then we figure out oh economy has. We try to manage things within our control. But then constantly something is getting out of our control. Then we know that oh, there is someone who has a control over everything that one never have to worry about.

He doesn't have to compete for jobs with anybody. He is the Lord of all these beings. This too has a complete division. I and him are separate. But my goal is constantly become him. Because my goal is to become without any limitations, without any sorrows.

So I'm constantly trying to become what I am from what he is. And Bhagavan says, Idam Gnanam Upashatya. One who has taken refuge in this knowledge. The knowledge which he has not given us yet, but he's going to give it to us. He has given us the kind of broad brush understanding of how things work in this. But how to get from here to there, we don't know yet.

But he says, idam Gnanam Upasatya mama sa Dharma Agathah. One who has taken refuge in the knowledge, they become one with me. Their dharmas have become what my dharmas are. My dharmas are limited. Right now his dharmas are unlimited. From this limitedness to unlimitedness, Bhagavan said, those munis who have understood this knowledge and became one with that knowledge have become one with me.

Sadharamyam Agatha API na upa jayante Pralayena Vihanticha. Broad statement for somebody like us who are worried about next paycheck and says that. They do not take birth even at the time of creation. We are saying, look, forget about the creation and Pralaya. I am worried about what's happening tomorrow. But he says, there's such a person Sargiya Pina upa Jayante Pralay na Vyatanti character.

And he doesn't get destroyed at the time of Pralaya. Because we are also pretty long term planners. So we say, okay, I mean I do all of that. But then again I'll take a birth and I'll go back to the same thing all over again. I'll realize that I'm that unlimited being. But then I'll take a birth again and then I'll start from scratch all over again.

Bhagavad said, no, once you have realized who you are, there Is no birth or death for you. He says, why if that happens, if everybody realizes this, well, obviously there is no creation and there is no Pralaya. So why are we going through all of this again? He says, this is self knowledge. This is for you to get out of the misery which you are going through. You are not worried about what the others are doing.

We are not taking over his job of creating and destroying. I am only concerned about me. If job market is bad and we have 10 of our friends who are out of job, including yourself, who are you most worried about to get a job? Good luck to all of you. Once I get a job, I get right Others may be what whatever they are doing. Bhagavan may be whatever his goal is in this Pralayas and creation.

I need to get out of this misery. He's the one who has understood this. He will never have to take birth again or die again. Swamiji explains in a logical, philosophical manner. He said, the world keeps on going the way it is. But I understand that this Prakriti is an illusion.

The creation is a trick of my mind. If there is a lump of clay or a play doh, I make the shape myself and assign value to it, that is to it all. Or it's an elephant or it's whatever it is. Nothing has changed in the plate or the clay itself. But my mind has now assigned a value that it's a creation created by me and I have given a name and form to it. Now if I don't assign the name and form to it and keep seeing the clay as it is, there is no creation taking place.

Now when I take that clay and that elephant would have made and destroy it into lump of clay again, that elephant is destroyed. If I have taken credit for that creation, assigned a name and form to it, but I never assigned a name and form to has remained what it was before. Lump of clay, Prakriti remaining Prakriti and Purusha remaining Purusha.
snippets.reflection:
Notice the play of the three gunas in yourself today. When do you feel clear and light (sattva)? When restless and driven (rajas)? When heavy and stuck (tamas)?

Don't judge—just observe. This observation itself is the beginning of freedom from the gunas' grip. The one who watches the gunas is not bound by them.

Consider what activities, foods, relationships, and environments increase sattva in your life. What increases rajas? Tamas? With this awareness, you can make wiser choices.

snippets.title: Day 182: Rising Above

तमस्त्वज्ञानजं विद्धि मोहनं सर्वदेहिनाम् |

snippets.transliteration:
rajo rāgātmakaṃ viddhi tṛṣṇāsaṅgasamudbhavam .

tamastvajñānajaṃ viddhi mohanaṃ sarvadehinām .

verseTranslations: Passion, engendered by thirst for pleasure and attachment, binds the soul through its fondness for activity.
But Ignorance, the product of darkness, stupefies the senses in all embodied beings, binding them by chains of folly, indolence and lethargy.
Purity brings happiness, Passion commotion, and Ignorance, which obscures wisdom, leads to a life of failure.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 14, Gunatraya Vibhaga Yoga, the Yoga of Trigunas. We had just completed the Kshetrakshatragna Vibhaga, the differentiation between the field and its knower. We have seen that this world of ours is made up of two things. One is the field and its knower. In my case, I the knower of my world. And then we have also seen at the macro level, it's a Purusha and Prakriti, two entities which makes this manifest world apparent to me.

Prakriti is the nature, the manifest world, and Purusha, the unmanifestation which is making this Prakriti animated. So this understanding of Purushana Prakriti is. Now we can use it to our understanding. As Bhagawan says, we can only understand it if we know the nature of this Prakriti. Prakriti, even in our vernacular language, for anybody's inherent qualities in nature, that's his Prakriti. Also in Gujarati they are saying, I'm sure it's another language though.

Pranayani, Prakruti, Sathya Jay, that this breath and my quality, they go together, they remain embedded in me. So knowing this Prakriti can certainly be a big help in my spiritual quest of knowing myself. So this chapter talks about Gunatraya, the three Gunas of the Prakriti. Prakriti, that is me as this body, mind and intellect. This world as I see and it's all pervading, just as the nature of the Brahman is. And as we have said, both the Purusha and Prakriti are beginningless because both are the nature of Brahman, which is beginningless.

Something which is beginningless in whatever format it is presented remains beginningless. Therefore, Prakriti is beginningless. Purusha is beginningless. In my quest of understanding myself, myself is beginningless. Where did I create this misunderstanding that I'm limited and I'm going through these ups and downs in my life? I'm Going through these sorrows and happiness, the spurts of little happiness and then long period of pursuit of happiness.

Bhagavan said that understanding this nature of this Prakriti will be helpful. Bhagawan said, I am the Mahat Yoni Brahman. I, the Brahman in the form of a Prakriti is the womb of all the beings. No being or thing can come into existence unless the Purusha and Prakriti come together. So see, anywhere you see a thing or being coming into existence, consider that as the union of the Purusha and Prakarati, that unmanifest and manifest coming together creates a new creation. Wherever there is a birth taking place, consider that it is coming from my womb, the universal womb.

And then you say, I am the Sid giver, Father. Prakriti is the womb and Purusha is the father. Therefore, in our all vernacular language is Mother Nature, Mother Earth. And Bhagavan is Pita. Bhagavan is my father. Prakriti is my mother, comes directly from this verse from Bhagavad Gita.

So this nature, the mother nature, when it comes to me, creates this body, mind and intellect. When I was born, what I was born with is this body which continues to grow and decay. Born with this mind and intellect, which obviously at the rudimentary level when I was born with the intellect and grew into who I think I am today. What is the nature of this Prakriti, if I know, will help me to understand who I am. So the next three verses tells us the nature of the Prakritiensi. Swattam Rajah, Tama, iti, Gunaha, Prakriti, Sambhavah.

The three Gunas which we see in this world, in almost everything that we can observe, are Sattva, rajas and Tamas. They are born out of Prakriti. This manifest world becomes manifest because of these Gunas. You take these three gunas away and there is no world. Manifest world remains. So what is the first Sattvam of a purity, Awareness, knowledge, luminosity.

A thing comes into existence when for me, when I become aware of it. We went to a cruise about two years ago and we realized at the last minute that we need some cash on the cruise. So I went to the ATM because it was Sunday. Well, my car just won't work. So I finally called my client in Baltimore. Mike, can you have $300 in cash for me?

I'll give you a check when I come there. So anyway, he has crisp $100, three notes ready for me, envelopes and Neel Butt. I went there, I collected it, gave check to him and went to a cruise. We never used that money. It was sealed in that envelope since we came and we forgot all about it. Those $300 never existed for us for all this time.

Because we all forgot about it. Opened it with $300 in it. We are suddenly $300 richer. They did not exist for us. So now Mina said, I gave you that $200. What did you do with it?

Well I said I have it. I'll give it back to you if you want. That money came into existence when I became aware of it. Mina became aware of it. Till that time it did not exist. Sattvam, unless you are aware of this world, world does not come into existence for you.

So is for her, for him and everybody else. We all become unaware of this world. So Satvam is the first quality of Prakriti. In this nature we are aware of each other and therefore we exist for each other. Next is Rajas and third is Thomas. We heard it many, many many times before.

But he said they are Prakriti Sambhavah. These Kunas are born out of Prakriti. My Prakriti is I become aware of my world. This experience of this world create passion and desires in me. Passion creates desire, desire creates actions, actions create reactions. And my world continues with cause and effect.

Somebody comes and says you should be investing money right now because market is down. Then suddenly my desire to make money also. Neel, you need to do something And I start doing things. That creates another chain reaction when market drops. So Rajas is the activity which is the nature of cause and effect. My interaction in this Prakriti because of my passion creates activity.

This activity creates the experience of joys and sorrows. I pat my back and say I'm so smart. When everybody's thinking this, I was doing this. Then when things go bad I said well people really cheated me. They should have told me and tamaha inertia. If we don't have inertia we don't even exist.

To exist something in time and space it has to have inner share. It has to remain in that condition in time and space for other to experience it. I am real because I have inertia. I remain in that state in time and space for others to experience it. So the inertia is the essential part of Prakriti. Tamas is the very essential quality of Prakriti.

Just as Sattva and rajas. If you take one of the three out, Prakriti does not exist. Sattva cannot exist if there is no rajas and Tamas. There is nothing to be aware of. Rajas cannot exist if there is no inertia. But because there is inertia, Tamas, all three continue to work with each other.

So this Tamas is the nature of inertia, which at my level I relate to, is my sleep, deep sleep. When I really don't want to do anything, somebody says, oh, let's go and have a party. Forget about it, I'm not in a mood today. I'm overwhelmed by the Tamas. If I'm very sleepy and you tell me I don't want to do that, well, forget about it. Right now all I want to do is sleep.

That means I am overwhelmed by Tamas. And all I want to do is go back to my basic nature with iti, Gunaha, Prakruti, Sambhavaha, they are part of the Prakruti. They are nature of the Prakruti. They are embedded into the Prakruti. Swamiji says, but they are not like qualities of a material where you can say if I test in the lab, I will find this Sattvaraja Santama. They're actually the moods of my mind when I interact with this Prakriti.

So sometimes my mind is overwhelmed by Sattva. Things starts getting clearer to me. I tried very hard yesterday, couldn't figure out. This morning it suddenly came to me, aha, moment, Eureka moment. Because the predominant Sattva, Rajas, now I figured out I need to do something. And Tamas, this is enough.

I need to go to sleep. There is always a time, no matter how a dynamic person is, he has to take rest. Ithiguna, Prakritisam, Nibadnanti Mahabhaho, Dehe Dehi, nam Avyayaam, this imperishable self, the Purusha Brahman which is imperishable, is now bound by this perishable body, by these three gunas, the Purusha coming in contact with the Prakriti and get attached to this Prakriti. Gunas get bound by this Prakriti. So this dehi in me, my consciousness which is the nature of all pervading, imperishable nature. Once it attaches to this body, mind and intellect and enjoys the gunas, it gets bound.

So now I consider this is me, the body. This is me the intellect. Only possible because the consciousness tells me that's who I am. This imperishable one is now bound in this body by these three gunas. Tatra, satvam, nirmalatva, Prakasakam, anamayam, Sukha, sangena, badnati, gnar, sange. My mind under the influence of these three gunas binds me to this body, this mind and this intellect.

So what is the nature of it? Now I want to unbound myself so that I can realize my imperishable self. That's the quest we have. So that I will have infinite happiness, unlimited happiness which I'm seeking. So I have to unbound myself. So I have to see what is binding me and how.

So the first is Sattva Tatra Sattvm nirmalatva, Prakashakam annamayam. So nature of this atva is prakashakam. Suddenly becomes things clearer to me. Before I walk into this room at night, it's dark. Nothing is clear what's in the room. Suddenly I switch the light on.

Everything becomes completely clear because it is luminous. That's the nature of sattva in my chitta, in my mind. When once Sattva prevails, things start getting clearer to me. So it's the nature of luminosity and annamayam. Eat some sattvic food. You tell Panditji this.

You know cholesterol and all the pure ghee. That's good for you, Sattva. So purity is of nature, of health. When I am completely in tune with myself, I feel healthy and I feel aware. Everything seems nice which is the experience of happiness and joy. That's what binds me to this prakriti.

When I feel I am in command, I understand things. I am enjoying this knowledge. When I learn something, it binds me to knowledge and the happiness of getting knowledge. Sukha sangena badnadi. So it binds me to happiness. Gnana sangena cha anagaha.

Sattva binds me to the knowledge and happiness. It's still a bondage. No matter how golden the chain is, it's still a bondage. Therefore, lot of other saints have argued about this. Vedanti says this and we say harina janato Muktina magya. Whoever the Gujarati fellows can understand he says the God's people they do not want this liberation.

They want birth after birth. So that I enjoy your bhakti. Because if I'm not there, how can I enjoy your bhakti? Therefore Harina Jina Muktina Mangi Mangi Jana Vi Janavata. I want birth after birth so that I can devote myself to you. Bondage to this Sattva?

This experience of my devotion to my Lord is giving me happiness and ecstasy. I don't want to give it up. Just keep me in this state. Don't take me to the next one. Otherwise I will lose this ecstasy. He is a man of dynamic personality.

He worked 18 hours a day.

verseTranslations: O Prince! Purity prevails when Passion and Ignorance are overcome; Passion, when Purity and Ignorance are overcome; and Ignorance when it overcomes Purity and Passion.
When the light of knowledge gleams forth from all the gates of the body, then be sure that Purity prevails.

snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 14, Gunatraya Vibhaga Yoga. So we have seen so far that these three gunas are born out of Prakriti. They are actually the nature of Prakriti. The nature gets it from Maya, as Vedanta says. Then Bhagavan Sankaratabodha says three Gunatmika Maya. This Maya has three gunas.

That which is not but appears to be, that is Maya. So this Maya which creates this illusion that this world is real creates by these three qualities which bind our mind. How do we see hologram? The question is the hologram real? Hologram has its own reality. However, it is not what appears to be.

If I see a hologram of a woman, hologram is real, but the woman is not. So from that perspective, is this Prakriti real? Prakriti is very real, but it is not what it appears to be. We have all learnt in physics by this time that the atom which appears to be solid and no real solid matter in it whatsoever, but it is very real from my perspective because it is a relative reality. So Bhagavan says in this chapter that all the beings which are born in this world are basically are born from the womb of Mother Nature, Prakriti. And I, this consciousness, I, the self, supreme self, Purusha is, is the seed giving father.

The entire Prakriti and entire creation that we know is born of the same entity, the self. The Purusha is the father and the Prakriti. The nature as we know is the mother. This Prakriti has three gunas which bind the Purusa into the Prakriti. This union between the Prakruti and Purusha happens because three gunas in the Prakriti. And when that occurs, a being is born.

An ego is conditioned. Consciousness is conditioned, as we have seen in this analogy, a room space. When a building is built, it binds this space into it and the association creates a room Space. The same way Bhagavan said Purusha came in contact with Prakriti, a conditioned ego is born. Three gunas we have seen is Sattva, Rajas and Tamas. Classic classification we heard over and over again.

Sattva is the nature of purity, light, knowledge, illumination, Rajas activity, passion, attachment and Tamas, ignorance, inertia. And then we have seen each one how it binds this consciousness which is pure and pristine in its nature. Once comes in association with the Prakriti, it binds itself to the Prakriti and creates a new conditioned being. So the verse 9, 10 and 11 gives us this relationship. Sattva binds you to happiness, this embodied one, this consciousness which it feels like embodied in myself is bound by the nature of this field. We have seen this field Idam sariram Kshetram ITI abhidhya.

This body is the field. This field with having its three qualities bind the consciousness in me. But quality of Sattva to happiness. Something happens, I figure it out, I come to know, I enjoy that experience binds Rajastha. The activity, the passion, attachment creates desires, creates activity. And more I do it, more I achieve it, more I get bound, more and more I do stuff I think As I give an example.

When I left India I had one very clear goal. If I make hundred thousand rupees, I'll be back to India and start practicing architecture there. In Ahmedabad I made hundred thousand rupees long, long, long long time ago. I'm still outside India. Rajas binds you to activity, more we do more I want to do it so. And then Tamas ignorance, inertia, all three are absolutely necessary for this Prakriti to exist.

Just as whatever the ingredients of the hologram which binds hologram into a form which I perceive has to have it so the next three _Verses_ say Satvam sukhe Sanjayati Rajah Karmani Bharata Gnanam avrutyatu tamah pramade sanjayatu dah summary of what we already seen. Satum sukeshanjayati to the happiness and the pleasure Rajah to karmani Rajastu actions and this knowledge about the self, the very fact I call myself, but I'm not aware of it, I can't define it. As you have seen this example. Everything I use to define myself turns out to something which is related to myself, but not me. My name, my relationship, my profession, my achievements, my losses, whatever that is, but it's not me. What is it that does not let me figure out who I am?

Tamas Vinanam Avritya to Tamah Pramadi Sanjay by pramad heedlessness myself tells me who I am. But this Prama, the heedlessness, no, it cannot be. Swamiji used to say, I come here every year. Because when Swamiji was alive, I used to come every year to United States and to Yagna. Some of us were standard devotees. We were always there.

He said, I'm glad that you guys are not listening to me. I come here, give you my knowledge and in the last day gather it and go back, you know? So that way you keep me in business. Because otherwise, once you understood, you have no need for me. This Tamas, even though we hear, even though we understand, even though conscience tells us this should be right. But I don't think so, because not everybody else is doing it.

So we get deluded by that Thomas Pramade Sanjay. So here is how he says that pure consciousness is bound into the Prakriti. So now further analysis of how these three gunas work. These three gunas are inherent in all the Prakriti. Tamas is not a negative quality of Prakriti. It is the very essential nature of Prakriti.

For an atom to remain in solid state, for me to recognize the atom, atom has to have certain inertia in it for me to see it as an atom. If I can start seeing it as electron and proton and neutron, the world will disappear because there is no solid matter around. So the inertia, the Tamas is the essential quality of Prakriti. So is the rajas and so is the Sattva. Because we have tendency to classify with the higher, lower and middle. So we say, well, this is higher, this is lower.

snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Ganatra Vibhag Yoga, Yoga of Trigunas. We have concluded that these are the qualities of Prakriti. These Trigunas make the Prakriti what it is. These three gurus come from Maya. Ishwara, in control of Maya, creates Prakrita Maya. That which is not then appears to be there.

This world of plurality appears to be there. In reality, there is only singularity exist. This Maya creates this Prakriti by three gunas, the Sattva, Rajas and Tamas. So everything in this Prakriti has these three gunas. If you take basic building block of our universe as atom, atom obviously has inertia. It has activity and it has some awareness.

From my perspective, atom remains in its space and time because of inertia. If atom doesn't remain in space and time, there's nothing you can do about it. We also know even though it looks inactive, it has extreme activity inside the electron swirling around the neutron or proton within nucleus. So there is rajas, there is Tamas, which is inertia. It keeps it and its shape and its existence in the space and time. It also knows what to do when another atom comes in contact with it, which creates this Prakriti.

So right from the basic building block to ourselves, these three gunas are existent. We obviously are not really concerned about the Prakruti as the universe right now. We are concerned about the Gunas which are manifesting in my internal instrument. Because the goal of my spiritual quest, as we all learned over and over and over again, is cleansing my internal instrument, which is the mind and intellect. This mind and intellect, when is in action, obviously will manifest. One guna or other is more predominant.

My mind and intellect is nothing but the impressions of my experiences and the transactions in this world. This experience, living its impression, will either make my thoughts more Satwik, more Rajasic, or more Tamasic. Under this sway of these experiences with the world outside, my internal instruments constantly is transforming from one predominance to another. And that's where we have seen why we should be aware of these gunas. Once I understand how my mind comes under the sway of these gunas I may be able to train my mind in a manner that which will be more beneficial in my spiritual evolution, in my journey from this limited being to the unlimited being. And therefore we are also concerned that this life is not long enough.

I'm trying to attain something but my body doesn't give cooperation and it falls apart prematurely when I have not achieved my goal. The verses which you had been seeing said this is a continuity. This life is nothing but a one chain and the continuity of chains which is your existence. And as this limited being, my existence is more at the subtle instrument level than at this external instrument level. This external instrument will die and perish when it has run its course. Internal instrument will continue.

It has gathered experience from the past lives, gathering experience in this life and will continue into the next. So the question is what happens when I leave this body? So last three verses deal with that. And as Swamiji says, Hinduism is the only faith where they very systematically deals with afterlife. Whereas most other faiths and most other thoughts in this world do accept that there is a life after this life. So the verses which you have seen so what happens?

What will be my destination when I leave this station of life? The first story says if what happens if my mind is in a sattvic mood? Yadas sache pravruddh detu pralayam yati deha brittama vidam lokan amalan pratipadya de if my mind is in a sattvic mood of predominance at the time of my living I will reach the world of the norths of the highest. So we'll go in the environment which will aid into my journey from this limited being as the Jiva to their higher being. So what happens at the time of my death? I may be comatose, I may be in pain, so my mind cannot think about anything.

But remember what happens when you go to deep sleep. Last night when you went to sleep? Not necessarily every night you go to sleep you are in the same type of a mood or maybe aware of when you went to sleep. But the next morning when you wake up, you're basically the same person who went to sleep a night before. And my mind is predominantly has become an architectural mind.

So when I wake up next morning, no matter what show I saw on the TV that last night, my mind must be completely thinking something else. I'll start with where I left off. That Gita class led me to Gita class today. So the tendencies which we gather we may not remember anything about. The experience of the tendencies we gather creates the sattvic mood or rajasik mood or tamasic mode and we carry on. So it says one who dies with a sattvic predominance of mind will go to the world of highers. Purana says the Brahmaloka where abundance of happiness, very little sorrow or no sorrow and abundance of creativity. The world of creativity.

Somebody who revels in creativity and get the joy out of that creativity. The next verse said Rajasi satvam gatva Karma sangi sujayate. If all my life experience was rajasik in business and whatever that is, obviously when I die my mind is still in that mode. I'm not carrying any experiences. I'm not carrying any memory of the experiences but carrying the tendency of that experiences with me. Maybe the last 15 days of my life I'm completely comatose.

So what I'm going to do, I'm going to look for an environment where I can exhaust my vasanas tendencies for being active. So I may be born in a businessman's house. Karma sanghi su Jayate.

What is the right thing to do? Change that environment. Go back to where I feel comfortable so I can start my progress appropriately. For my mind to remain in equanimity. If I attach myself to this world then nothing but pain. If I attach to good actions, selfless actions, Karma Yoga the results are sattvic and pure.
