When the soul transcends the Qualities, which are the real cause of physical existence, then, freed from birth and death, from old age and misery, he quaffs the nectar of immortality.
Arjuna asked: My Lord! By what signs can he who has transcended the Qualities be recognized? How does he act? How does he live beyond them?
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 14, Gunatreya Vibhag Yoga, Yoga of Trigunas. So so far, first we learned about I, the conditioned consciousness in the first six chapters. Next six chapters we learned about the Supreme Consciousness. From conditioned consciousness to the supreme Consciousness is the journey which we all are taking. So to help that journey, in the last chapter we have defined what is the field and who is the knower and what is the differentiation between the two. So we have said that the I, the knower, know the field which is this body, mind and intellect.

I know my body, I know my mind, I know my intellect, therefore they are my field. And I, the knower is the knower of the field. And the field cannot be knower and knower cannot be filled. Now, in this chapter we are learning about the qualities of the field. So we are taking it a step at a time to understand how can I take this journey from this conditioned consciousness which I consider I, or in Vedanta called Jiva, the limited self, which I consider myself to be the ego from the supreme self which is my true nature. And therefore the quest in life is always to achieve that balance where there is no sorrows, no limitations, nothing that will create unhappiness, a perfect happiness.

And because there is no unhappiness, it cannot be called happiness, but just a bliss. So we have seen this and then we say these gunas. The Prakriti has three gunas. The field which is part of the Prakriti has three gunas. These gunas bind the knower to the field. Those are the attractions which creates bondage between the Purusha and Prakriti, the knower in the field and create identification.

This identification is because of these gunas. And those three gunas we have seen as Sattva rajas and Tamas. My awareness about this field, Sattva rajas, the activity, the passion for something I like and then ignorance. These three binds me. So how do I get out of these three? Or is one helping Me to get out of this conditioned consciousness to supreme consciousness.

So we have seen that quality the Sattva gives knowledge, Rajas gives activity. In the byproduct would be greed. One activity leads to another and to another and another and there's no end to it. So that creates greed and Tamas creates inertia. So now we have to transcend from one to another. So one, the lowest we can see is inertia from our perspective.

These are the qualities of my mind right now. These are the qualities of the field. In this field the body is obviously completely inert. By its very nature it just cannot do anything but to exist. Just like we have seen, the atom has inertia and therefore it exists. As long as the inertia is there, atom exists as an atom.

Once you disturb the inertia, the Rajas will explode into atomic energy. Body is nothing but inertia. But the mind and intellect have all three. The Rajas, Tamas and Sattva. So these are the qualities of my mind which I'm most interested in. And that depending on the quality of my mind, if it is Sattva, it has a knowledge.

Prakash Gnaan if it is Rajas, I'm active new project, new activity and inertia. Don't want to know anything, don't want to do anything. So the verses which you have seen last time now tells me that what happens if one is predominant or other in my mental zone? Urdhvam Gachandi Sattvasthaha. Those who are established in Sattva. If my mental quality is predominantly Sattva, Urdhum Gachandi I go higher, higher and lower is obviously concept of my mind.

I'm going towards my goal. Going from the conditioned consciousness to supreme consciousness, unconditioned consciousness. This conditioning which is binding me, my goal is to get rid of it and become one with the unconditioned supreme consciousness. That which leads me to my goal I consider higher. So Urdham Gachandi, Satvastaha, Sattvik, mode of my mind will lead me towards my goal of unconditioning this conditioning. There is Urdham Gacchanti, Satvasthaha, Madhe, Tishthanti, Rajasaha whose mental zone is predominantly Raju Sikh.

They remained in the middle. Neither they are going up nor they are going down. They remain in a status quo. Just like our election. We were where we started. Rajasik do a lot of activities.

But in the end if you see the sum total of the result is the same. If you can look at all the activities we have done in life. All we have done is to create security for ourselves, stability for ourselves, some kind of a protection that we remain in a good condition. And in the end it all comes down to the same thing. Every few years we have to go through the same thing over and over and over again. So they basically remain in the same state they are in.

Neither they are making progress upward nor they are going downwards. Neither they are going towards unbundening themselves from their bondages nor they are creating more bondage they are in the same state. Jagannya gunavuthistaha adoga chanti tamasaha. But those who are abiding into the lower qualities of tamas, they go down. Obviously we are talking about human beings. Obviously we are talking about the human mind.

Human mind which is evolved into this for the activity, the knowledge to understand the world around it. More it understands, goes higher, more it gets entangled into this world. It remains where it is. More it doesn't want to know. It goes down, down in a sense, in a situation where there is no more knowledge necessary to survive, just basic knowledge of I exist and I survive is good enough. They go down in that state of existence.

In the next verse we have seen said na anyam gune bhyakarata raha yada drasthano nupashadi. Why did we look at that last verse? To introspect in spiritual quest. Introspection is the most important aspect of our pragma. You have to constantly introspect and see what is there in my mental zone. And if I find any impurities I need to remove it that they go antahakarana shuddhe.

And then once I remove the impurity, the purity itself will reveal what is right and wrong. If I introspect and find myself to be in the tamasic zone, my next goal is to become Rajasic Tamasic to Satwik is not a a easy journey. So you have to go through Rajasek. So if you completely. That's why Bhagavad Gita says the people who are doing good for the wrong reason, let them do it, do not stop them. If I'm giving donation to make my name, I'm at least better than the one who is not giving at all.

That's why Bhagavad Gita let them do for whatever the motivation. But you need to make progress into your. So he said, if I am in a tamasic zone, well, let me make sure that at least I'm active. If I'm an active zone, I said Samila, I need to slow down and understand why I'm doing it. That introspection lead me to what will be the remedy. It would be my next efforts.

And therefore the next verse says but this is not enough. So generally we understand well if I'm tamasik or rajasik, once I'm a rajasik to Sattvik, I'm done. Because now I'm remaining in the Sattvik guna. But we have also seen that even this Sattvik guna is also a bondage. We get also get used to of doing good because people praise me well you are really doing very well. So I want to keep getting that praise over and over and over again.

In other words, you get attached to happiness. The joy which comes out of knowledge, the joy which comes out of doing good binds me to this. It does not let me leave. I like we have a saying in our architecture that what happens to the old architects? They don't die, they just wither away. They continue working till they drop dead in the studio.

Because that attachment to creativity, that something I'm doing it, I'm creating that attachment doesn't let you retire. So the bondage to Sattva is still a bondage. So what is the real goal for that conditioned self is to go beyond gunas. And how do you go beyond gunas? Na anyam gunai bhya kartaram There is no other doer in my life other than my own gunas. Only gunas are the doers for everything which I am doing and accomplishing and losing.

Yada drastan unupashadi one who starts seeing it then. All my actions are driven by the modes of my mind. Only when my mind wants to see sky fall at that time. Meena read this chapter is so nice in my I'm going to see Bond movie. Right now you can do whatever you want. I'm not in a mood right now.

So who drives me to Bond movement? Who brings me to here to Gita class? So if I can make my mind the doer and say all that is I do is driven by the quality of my mind as the thought. So the action, whatever my thought, my action will be driven by that. So all my actions I should assign them clearly to my mind. All the gunas are doing what I have all done now Anyam there is no other you can say well I was forced by the society.

Well I really didn't want to go to see a movie. But really they insisted. We used to do that when I was in college. Well, I really didn't want to go there just before the exam. But all my room partners they said Neil, I blame on my room partners why I went to see a movie just before the day of the examination. But if I had no tendencies I wouldn't go.

So Bhagavan says Na anyam guna Bhyakaratam There is none other than my Gunas are the doers for all my actions. One who sees that Yada drastha Anupashyati One who starts seeing it. All my actions are driven by my mind and the qualities of my mind. Gune Bihacha Param vette and he says there is someone higher than these gunas. There is someone who is much higher than my mind who also sees the limitations of my mind. Well, I shouldn't have gone to see a movie just before the exam.

The one who says I shouldn't have that I is different than the I who went to see a movie. Gune Bhyah param veti One who knows that there is one who is above these gunas Mad Bhavam sa adigachadi and identify with that. I really don't need to take any credit or blame for my actions. My mind was in that mood and I did that. However, I am not my mind. My mind is just a field in which my consciousness functions.

That consciousness never took part in any of the action. If my identification takes place that way. Bhagavan says Mad Bhavam sa adhi gachadi he attains my being. We have seen the supreme consciousness. Unconditioned by the limitations of body, mind and intellectual he becomes one with me. As Swamiji says, he doesn't become Krishna with flute and peacock feather.

He becomes one with that unconditioned consciousness. He now starts identifying this room space. Once leaves the identification with the walls, floor and ceiling remaining within the room it identifies now with the space outside. I'm none other than this universal space. Gunaan Etan Atityaha Trindehi Deha Samud Bhavan this dehi One who considers this is me. This body, this mind is me is created by this guna.

This guna bound me to this body and said this is me.
snippets.reflection:
Notice the play of the three gunas in yourself today. When do you feel clear and light (sattva)? When restless and driven (rajas)? When heavy and stuck (tamas)?

Don't judge—just observe. This observation itself is the beginning of freedom from the gunas' grip. The one who watches the gunas is not bound by them.

Consider what activities, foods, relationships, and environments increase sattva in your life. What increases rajas? Tamas? With this awareness, you can make wiser choices.

snippets.title: Day 187: Beyond the Gunas
snippets.sanskrit:

snippets.transliteration:
śrībhagavānuvāca .

udāsīnavadāsīno guṇairyo na vicālyate .

samaduḥkhasukhaḥ svasthaḥ samaloṣṭāśmakāñcanaḥ .
verseTranslations: Lord Shri Krishna replied: O Prince! He who shuns not the Quality which is present, and longs not for that which is absent;
He who maintains an attitude of indifference, who is not disturbed by the Qualities, who realises that it is only they who act, and remains calm;

Who accepts pain and pleasure as it comes, is centred in his Self, to whom a piece of clay or stone or gold are the same, who neither likes nor dislikes, who is steadfast, indifferent alike to praise or censure;
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 14, Gunatreya Vibagi yoga, yoga of three gunas. So so far in Bhagavad Gita you learnt about ourselves, who we are as the limited beings, how we function, how can we make the most out of our actions? How can we Most efficient In the first six chapters. And we learned that working without any attachment or expectation is actually the best method to gain the most out of your life and most out of your actions. To become the most proficient and efficient, the basic requirement is not to get too attached to whatever you are doing. This is contrary completely to what we think.

We think the more passionate I am, the better I will be. Bhagavad Gita says it's other way around. Less you are attached to what you are doing, more efficient you would be, the more successful you would be. So this is what we learned in the first six chapters. That's called a Karma Yoga. How to act in this world as a limited being and to get the most out of your life is Karma Yoga.

Then focus on who you are in reality. That you are not this body, you are not this mind, you are not this intellect. So Yudyana Yoga, what we are contemplating upon that supreme self, the self that I am other than this limited self we have learnt in the next sets of chapters culminated into Bhakti Yoga, the devotion to that self. Unless I identify with something higher, I cannot detach from the lower. To resign from my job, I have to find another job before I resign. If I'm a smart person, don't resign before you get a next job.

You have to find a better job before you can resign from your current job, which you either hate or at least not love as much right now. This limited self, even though I'm comfortable, it's not the best situation I'm in. I'm not always happy, I'm not always achieving what I'm trying to achieve. So I'm trying to see something better than what I have today, something which can Give me permanent happiness. Bhagawan said, you identify with that self which is capable of giving you the permanent happiness. So that's Bhakti Yoga.

Bhakti Yoga is truly to identify with one which has no limitations. As long as I'm identified with this limited being, there is no chance ever in eons to come that I'll achieve my goal of being perfectly happy. But once you identify with that supreme self. So then we are trying to discuss in the last set of these chapters, what is the difference between the limited self and the higher self? And how to go beyond those limitations. So the last chapter we talked about the Kshatrakshatragna Vibhaga Yoga.

What is the field and who is the knower? The knower is always someone other than the field. If I know something, that means that's an object. See, if I know my limited self, the limited self is an object. And I, the knower, is knowing the limited self. So there we identified that this body, this Idam, Sareeram, Kaunteya, Eddhikshatra, Mabhidiyya, this body is the field.

This body includes all my experiences, my mind, my thoughts, modifications of my moods, all that is filled. But one who is witnessing it is the witness. So now how do I go beyond this? We have been learning in this chapter what is binding this unlimited self to their limited self. And we came to the conclusion that the three gunas of the Prakriti. This Prakriti, the manifest world, has three basic qualities.

The three ingredients which makes it pluralistic world. Now projecting as a plural world. We know from science there is nothing but singularity before the Big Bang. And then this world of cosmos came into existence. I was just reading Stephen Hawking, some dialogue with somebody. And somebody asked him, so what was before Big Bang?

And he said, nothing. Nothing before Big Bang. So there was something which obviously we say nothing can. Something cannot come out of nothing. So there was something, but something was not as divided as we perceive it right now. We also learned in cause and effect.

That effect can be nothing but the cause modified. This cosmos cannot be anything but the singularity modified. So Bhagavan said that you have to understand what is binding you to this worldview of pluralistic world. And you are at the center of your own world. I'm in the center of my world. Everything relates to me.

If I remove myself from this world, the world disappears. When I'm not there, that world does not exist. What's Happening in Syria right now does not exist for me because I'm not there. But what's happening here, I'm very much involved. It all relates to me. Once I remove this limited self out of this equation, the pluralistic world does not exist.

These three gunas are binding this infinite to this limited self. Gunas as we have learned, also means ropes. These three ropes are binding you to this limitedness. We are not giving up our limitedness, but expecting infinite happiness, unlimited existence. We all think that we are going to exist forever. We have learned in Mahabharata that Yaksha asked you this direct question.

What is the most wonderful you find about human beings? The most wonderful, most amazing thing is that everyone knows he's going to die. But they all live like they're never going to die. We cannot think about ourselves as non existing. Existence is my real nature. But I also know that this life as I know will end sooner or later.

How can I get out of this fear of mortality, this fear of unhappiness? Bhagawan said you need to get rid of these three binding ropes. You have this great wealth of Satchit and Ananda, but you just don't have the password to that account. Somebody says, Neel, your great grandfather left great wealth in Swiss account. The only problem is we don't have the account number. So we know that we are Satchitananda.

We just don't know the key to it. So Bhagawan said that know that these three are binding you. Once you get out of this three, you will achieve that state where you are immortal, always blissful in and all knowing. So we have learned that these three gunas are binding. They are Sattva, rajas and Tamas. Sattva binds you with happiness, Rajas by activity and Thomas by laziness or inactivity.

So the ultimate prescription was Guna tita Bhava go beyond these three gunas. So Arjuna obviously says, okay, all this well and good, but how can one get to that point? Last verse we have seen says Kailinge hi Trigunan etan atito Bhavati prabhu. How can anyone can go beyond these three gunas? Once he achieves that, what will be his behavior? Katram chetam tri guna nivartate.

How can I understand that this is possible? Give me some indications of what will be like a litmus test, that if I see this that means that person has gone beyond trigona. And also if that is possible, that somebody has Already done that. Then tell me the recipe how to get there. Now we know that Bhagavan has been talking about it all throughout in Bhagavad Gita how to become that. But Arjuna one more time asked this question to make it very clear that this is what the goal of life is.

So Bhagavan answer in the following _Verses_ and it's really very unique. Verse verse 22 and this is something we really want to contemplate. What is his answer to it? Prakashamcha Pravritimcha Mohammad Pandava Nadvasti Sampravruttani he did not say that these gunas will disappear once you become Nirguna Gunatita. He does not hate when these three gunas are present. Prakasham Cha Pravritimcha Moham these are the effects of these three gunas.

Prakash Light knowledge, clear headedness. We clearly understand what's going on. Things are very clear, no confusion. That's the effect of Sattva. When my mind and intellect are in Sattva Guna, everything is crystal clear. I don't need somebody's advice.

I know what is right and what is wrong. Pravrutyam activity I'm busy. That's the effect of Rajas and Moham Delusion. I don't understand what's going on. I don't know whether they're right or wrong. Is Moham is the effect of Tamas.

When these are present in my personality, in my mind, I don't hate them. So up till now we were thinking that when somebody says Guna Titaha Bhava means I will not have those gunas at all. Bhagavad makes it very clear these gunas will remain as they are. Just because you became Sthita Prajna, the world is not going to change. Neither the quality and the nature of your body, mind and intellect are going to change. As we are talking about.

If I am a weakling, it's not overnight going to change because I have become a Gnani that I will be the most powerful person. Body will have his own Dharma. It will be exactly what it is before realization and after realization. Mind will have its own Dharma. It has been with you for eons. It has own personality.

It's not going to change. Neither intellect overnight is going to become Einstein. We know these are my equipment and I have to live with their limitations. But I, at the core of my being, seeing that happening in my mind and intellect remain a witness And I don't hate that. Why I am in this mood is not a question. This is how I react when things happen this way.

This is my nature, not Nivratani Kankshati he also does not desire when they are not present. So when I am in a sattvic mood I believe things are very clear. I'm very very happy about my own clarity. Then when I lose that sattvic mood and get into Rajasigant Tama Singh I hate that I want to be back to my serene, clean, clear state of mind. Bhagavan said that's not possible and therefore you shouldn't be desirous of that. See, many people say I was meditating the very first day it was very good but second day onward nothing really happened.

More you desire more it will stay away from you. In Gujarat there is a saying which says. One who is asking for it, the things go away from them and one who is saying I don't need it people will come to you more you say I don't need it, people will offer you more you say I want it people to take away from you. So Bhagavan said that do not have any of this when they present the effects of these three gunas don't hate them. Understand that these are the common experiences for everyone. Na Nivruttaani when you are not something I was enjoying my activity, I was very busy and now I'm not accepted as is.

So the acceptance is the mark of a true Gnani One who accepts his reality as is he says such a person is Bhagawan Arjuna's question what are his qualities? His qualities are he accepts things as they are. He does not hate them if they are happening he does not desire if they are not happening. Now this is something for us is very difficult to accept because as soon as we talk about somebody and say I don't know he has been talking about all this. But then the other day this thing happened and then he reacted this way. He reacted this way because this is how he was made up of all his life.

But you do not know how that incident affected him so but once at the core of your being you become a witness.

verseTranslations: Who looks equally upon honour and dishonour, loves friends and foes alike, abandons all initiative, such is he who transcends the Qualities.
And he who serves Me and only Me, with unfaltering devotion, shall overcome the Qualities, and become One with the Eternal.
For I am the Home of the Spirit, the continual Source of immortality, of eternal Righteousness and of infinite Joy."
snippets.commentary:
Okay, so I will be discussing the last four _Verses_ of chapter 14. The chapter 14, which is the Gunatraya Vibhaga Yoga, which we have discussed and basically we have found so far that in this Prakriti, this manifest world, everything has these three gunas, which is the signature of Prakriti, that everything has sattva, rajas and tamas. That is Sattva, the light, the knowledge, the awareness, the rajas, the activity and tamas, inertia. These three gunas that are binding this supreme self which has no limitations to this limited being. These qualities belong to my body, mind and intellect. Once the consciousness attaches to this, it takes upon itself all the limitations of Prakriti.

So I, the ego is right now conditioned by this body, mind and intellectual. Therefore it has all the limitations of body, mind and intellect. Therefore it goes through the sorrows and happiness, pleasant experience and unpleasant experiences, conducive situation and unconducive situation. Because each entity by itself is its own priorities and its own situations. World remaining the world. One person sees it as very positive, the other sees it very negative.

Depending on their own conditioning, one who goes beyond these three gunas will be beyond all these conflicts and sorrows. So what we have seen in this is that these three gunas also belongs to my mind. It is my mind which is sometimes in a sattvic, rajasik or tamashik. Depending on the qualities of my mind, I'll see this world. Whether it is Sattvik, rajasik or tamas. My experiences will be driven by the moods of my mind.

So if I can get over this, if I can introspect and can vigilantly monitor the moods of my mind, I will be able to go above the situations which I am facing. Situation remaining the same, I can change the mood of my mind and that will change my reaction to the situation. But you see, the ultimate goal is the one who goes beyond three gunas all the time. So the verse we have seen last Sunday, udasina, avadasina, gunehi, yona vichalyate. One who is indifferent to these gunas and does not gets swallowed by this guna. Guna vartanta ITHI eva avatastati na ingate.

What is happening in this world is nothing but play of the gunas. So gunas are the one which are acting in this world. Guna guneshu vartan taha ITI mattwa NASA jate. Knowing that what that is happening is the gunas of my senses and the guna of this world of objects are reacting with each other. When I have an experience, there are experiences between the gunas of my senses and my body and my mind and interact with the gunas of that. So when I come across this conducive situation, I feel happy.

Unconditional situation. I'm not happy knowing that the self that I am do not get disturbed by it. This verse 23 Guna vartanta itiyeva avati sthati na ingate. Knowing that these are all the play of the gunas only and nothing to do with I the self, he does not move from his state of bliss. He's always in the state of bliss as the self. When we, as we listen to example, when we hear what's happening in Tahrir Square in Egypt, does it really make me so upset that I couldn't sleep at night?

I may have my opinion whether they're good or bad for the world or whatever it is, but that's all it is. I'm a third party observer. If I can do the same thing for everything happening to me in this Tahrir Square, then I will be the same way. That's all it's saying. So now Arjuna had asked three questions. One is what are the marks of a person who has gone beyond the gunas?

This is exactly similar to chapter two where he says, what are the qualities of a person who is Buddhist established into the wisdom? Same thing he says, how do I know that person has gone beyond gunas? Then he says, how does he moves around? He talks in this world. And lastly, how did he do it? The one who is beyond gunas, knowing thus that this is the play of gunas only, he does not get disturbed.

That's the mark of him. What will be his behavior? We have seen in the following _Verses_, Samadukha swasthaha samalosta nah tulya priya apriya dhiraha tulya nindya atmast sans tuthi. We have seen this in Bhagavad Gita before the quality of a person whose Buddhi is established in the supreme self and not in this limited self. When things occur in this life, I see that it's occurring with this ego reacting with the world outside and therefore Samadhu Khashuka. Therefore whether condition is conducive or non conducive, he remains the same.

He sees that we don't have a big riots. As I said, when winter comes from spring we move to fall and then winter. We don't have riots in the streets outside. Why do we have this conditioning now? That's how the nature is. After the spring fall has to come and after the fall the winter has to come.

We adjust to it in our life we are not accepting that we always want hundred percent happiness all the time. Therefore we get all disturbed. But person who knows this, just like I know that the fall will come after spring and winter will come after fall. He knows that after every happy occasion there is something which is unhappy, non conducive. Those of you educated by the Indian TV knows this all the time, right? So Samadhukha Sukha has Svasthaha.

He remains Svasthaha balanced with that affected by the Sukha or Dukkha. Knowing this is a temporary occurring between the gunas of myself as the body, mind, intellect and the world economy is doing well. We were all very happy. Everybody talks about the party. Nothing but how much money they made in the stock market. Now we all talk about I don't know what Obama is doing.

Why doesn't he think about me? That's how the nature of this world is Samalosta ashma kanchanaha. He also sees no greater value in one thing of this world than the other. Now does that mean that somebody asks for you know, one rupee, he gives away thousand dollar note. No transaction in this world is a transaction between I the limited being and there. That is where there is called Vyavahara.

Then Vyavahara should be appropriate to that. However, I don't see that as the one Vyavahara is more important than the other. Swamiji gives example that when you were a little kid, something a card from whatever, you know the game card one was very valuable than the other. I grew up in India so we used to have parlays bottle top. So there was a value parlayed. One has a greater value than if you were socio or something else, right?

Anybody remember that? Now in those days can you imagine your wealth about those parlor bottle taps or this socio and this thing somebody takes away from you. But when you grow out of it, all those bottle tops are bottle taps and they worth nothing for me, you see one who sees the world that way. It has its own value in that particular transaction at a particular time. Therefore, we say, well, you may have styrofoam cup and somebody has a gold cup. Both are thirsty and going to a lake, which one is more valuable than the other?

As long as there is an emptiness which can fetch water. For me, that's all it counts for. At that moment, the value of gold and value of styrofoam is exactly same depending on which can fetch more water. So sama losta asma kanchanaha. He does not give greater value to one or the other, knowing that the value only belongs to the exchange or the utility in that particular transaction. Tulya priya a priya there obviously we all can use.

He remains same when something comes which is dear to me or not dear to me because it is not in my hand. We struggle through in this economy, go through these interviews and proposals and we come out and everybody says, Neel, you really did a fantastic presentation. I feel so good till I hear that my competition got the project. Things will come to you by its own nature. They are not depending on my situation. They're coming to me by its own nature.

And I consider that is my right or my misfortune that is coming to me. You can really use it. I said, boy, Neel, you did so good when you don't. I think you should have prepared a little better. Neel, I think this time you were not really. You should have prepared for the head interview or bad.

What happened suddenly, because my success now defines whether I was good or not. We were reading about Steve Jobs. He said he threw away all the rules of business. No focus groups, no surveys, everything. What do people know what they want, I will tell them what they want. So he worked completely contrary to other people's business model, taught in Harvard and everywhere else.

And he's the most successful company. So now we are saying, well, let's look at the Steve Jobs model, how he made the company. You have to remain same whether people are praising you or not. Praising you simply because it is the nature of the world, not yours. And then the next verse we have seen says, Mana apamana yoho tulyaha atulyo mitraha aripaksha yoho. Continuing the Same argument.

Bhagavan says such a person who has gone beyond guna is acting in this manner. He is working in this world as a normal person. But in his mind, he sees all this is a temporary occurring nothing that he controls. All his duty is to act according to dharma in each situation. Mana apaman yoho this is obviously very, very important to us because we get hurt very easily. Mana and apmana is at our mental level.

This is truly at our mind's level. Sometimes the person who is telling you had no intention of insulting you or hurting you. But you take it that way because your mental climate was such that you receive it. If I'm supremely confident, people say, this is not doing, don't worry about it. But I'm already shaky in sense. Then somebody says, neil, you're not.

Then I collapse right there. So it is not the world, but my mind decide whether this mana or of mana. He is so established in himself that what comes from the world, he just takes that for its face value and moves on. Mitraha aripakshayo ho. This is another thing. These are my friends and these are my enemies.

My relationship may be different with each other, but my reaction to them should remain the same. That does not mean that our enemies are attacking your country. And you say, well, same way, we'll receive you as we receive our allies that time your vivahar is to protect your country. But just as Gandhi said, I hate the British government but not the British people or something like that. It's not the person you are hating or person you are reacting to, but the action you are reacting to. Therefore, you have tulya mitra aripaksha.

Aripaksha in the foes, the enemies. Mitra friend, we all know Sarva Aramba parityagi. We have seen it before. And this is the most difficult one. He gives up all endeavors, all efforts. Sarva Aramba parityagi A small this is complete death.

If I stop doing everything, it's a complete death. I will stop all my endeavors and efforts when I die. Swamiji explained that's exactly what they're asking you to do.
snippets.reflection:
Notice the play of the three gunas in yourself today. When do you feel clear and light (sattva)? When restless and driven (rajas)? When heavy and stuck (tamas)?

Don't judge—just observe. This observation itself is the beginning of freedom from the gunas' grip. The one who watches the gunas is not bound by them.

Consider what activities, foods, relationships, and environments increase sattva in your life. What increases rajas? Tamas? With this awareness, you can make wiser choices.

snippets.title: Day 189: The Cosmic Tree
snippets.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |

अधश्चोर्ध्वं प्रसृतास्तस्य शाखा

न रूपमस्येह तथोपलभ्यते
snippets.transliteration:
śrībhagavānuvāca .

adhaścordhvaṃ prasṛtāstasya śākhā guṇapravṛddhā viṣayapravālāḥ .

na rūpamasyeha tathopalabhyate nānto na cādirna ca sampratiṣṭhā .
verseTranslations: "Lord Shri Krishna continued: This phenomenal creation, which is both ephemeral and eternal, is like a tree, but having its seed above in the Highest and its ramifications on this earth below. The scriptures are its leaves, and he who understands this, knows.

Its branches shoot upwards and downwards, deriving their nourishment from the Qualities; its buds are the objects of sense; and its roots, which follow the Law causing man's regeneration and degeneration, pierce downwards into the soil.

In this world its true form is not known, neither its origin nor its end, and its strength is not understood., until the tree with its roots striking deep into the earth is hewn down by the sharp axe of non-attachment.
snippets.commentary:
We have completed chapter 14, Gunatrevi Bhag Yoga. And now we will be starting discussion of Chapter 15, Purushottam Yoga. Yoga of the Supreme Purusha. In Chapter 13 we have seen the difference between the filled and and its knower. The Prakriti is the field and the one which is aware of the field is the knower of the field. So at my individual level we have learned that this body is the field.

The one who is aware of the body is the knower of the field. So the body is part of the Prakriti. But I, the knower is part of the Purusha, the manifestation of Purusha in me. This Purusha which is imperishable, right now I consider it to be perishable because it is identified with this perishable body. So to make this connection with the Purusha and Prakriti at my individual level and at the universal level, we Learned in chapter 14 that the Purusha is the father of all the beings and Prakriti is the womb of all the beings in this world. So Prakriti is the mother and Purusha is the father.

Any being which is born at any place to any womb. Bhagavan said, consider this great Prakriti is the womb and I am the Sid Giver Father. We see the variety of beings and things in this world that is explained by these three Gunas, the three binding ropes which bind this imperishable Purusha to this perishable manifestation. This variety of things and beings are created by the permutation combination of these Gunas, the three modes of material nature. This variety of things and beings around me create my Sansaar. My relationship with these things and beings is my Sansaar.

This Sansaar is ever changing Samsaratiyeti Sansaar. That which is constantly changing is Sansaar. Sansaar does not remain same. That which was there a minute ago has already changed. It has already passed. So we constantly are struggling with this ever changing Sansaar.

This Sansaar continues to grow. When I was just a single person and a student, my Sansaar were limited to me and my parents they get married. So now you have become two. Listen Salad, your problem plus her problem and then we have children. So not only my problem, her problem but also his problem. Few years ago when I used to go to India I used to have only three houses to visit my three brothers.

Now when I go there, not only my brother's houses but their children they are married their in laws. So by the time I'm done with the 15 days are just gone to just meet with all their relatives. Because my Sansaar has grown. Bajagovindam says Bala hat Kira sakthah taruna tha tah vrudha tavat Chinta saktha When I was a child I was engaged in plays and toys. When I was a young man I was engaged in chasing girls. When I became old man, I'm just overwhelmed by worries.

I said well why would that be? You should be relieved. So I was actually looking forward to an old age. Because I thought the old age means my children will be married. I will have no worries then I will be completely free. Now that I have become an old man, I realize how true that verse was.

Not only I had to worry about myself, my family, my children, their children. So my Sansaar has grown so large. To detach from the Sansaar is increasingly becoming more and more difficult as the Sansaar grows. So this chapter opens up with the allegory of this Sansaar. So it says Urdhamoolah adha shakham asvattam prahuhu avyayam Chandansi Yasya Paranani Yastam Vedasa veda vith describing this Sansaar by using this allegory where it is like an upside tree. Now this allegory has been used in Upanishads in Katha Upanishads in the sixth portion of the Katha Upanishad the Lord of death Yama indicates to Nachiketa that this Sansaar is like the upside down tree.

The roots are in heaven and it is spreading in this world below. So my Sansaar right now is like that Urdhvamuna. Its source is up above. We always say anything which is higher say up Bhagavan kaha Upar. So this world as we see Bhagavad Gita and the Upanishad say the source is Apa. Source is somewhere beyond my perception.

Urdhvamuna adas Sakaha all the branches are below. That which I see growing is here in my world. I see its effect, I don't see the cause. So in our normal tree, roots are not perceivable. They are not perceived. They are below under the ground.

But we see the trunk and we see the branches. And these branches continue to grow. And this Sansaar is like that. As we have learned a few lectures ago that the return in farming is thousand fold. So traditionally the farmers were the richest people. Even the kings were farmers.

Janakaraja, while tilling the land, he found Sita because it was the most profitable business, most rewarding business. You sow one seed and thousand comes out. So the growth is exponential in anything in nature. So the tree grows exponentially. So my Sansaar is like that. It grows exponentially beyond my control.

I do one action and it permeates thousand reactions. So the allegory used Yoga tree is something like that. That one action generates thousand connections in my Sansaar. And its source is Apaba Urdhvamulaha Adasakaha. I see the branches of my Sansaar here below. Prahuhu Abyam the wise people talk about this tree of Sansaar is something which has the roots above the branches below Chandansi, Yasya, Panani.

The Vedas are its leaves. Now this is something slightly off tune here because it becomes very difficult to connect. We have seen the commentaries by various scholars. Swamiji explains here. The Bhagavan Sankaracharya says that Asvathaha, the tree is explained as Asvathaha. Because Asvatha, that which does not remain same tomorrow you broke down Aswatha it becomes that which does not remain same tomorrow.

Therefore this tree of Sansaar is explained as Asvathaha. And therefore that which promotes growth to this tree is the Vedas. The knowledge of Vedas, the instructions in Vedas, when followed by a person, his Sansaar grows healthily. By knowing this Sansaar and Prakriti, I more and more grow my Sansaar here. So these Vedas, the knowledge grows this tree of Sansaar in my life, in yours, in his Chandansi, Yasya, Pranani, Yastam, Vedasa, Veda Vid. And he who knows, he is a Veda knower.

One who knows both the roots and the branches of this tree, he knows the entire tree. So when I look at the tree I already know because I am a Veda knower of the trees that the roots are below in the ground. So There is a knowledge about where the roots are for the tree that makes my knowledge of the tree complete. So right now my knowledge of my Sansaar is incomplete. Because I only know what I see. So I only believe that what I see is the reality beyond my perception.

I don't see there is reality. The other day we are explaining myth to Meda and say myth is something, a made up story to explain something. And she said okay then my English homework is a myth because it's made of stories in it. So we consider that seeing is believing. Everything I see as real is real. Everything else is myth.

And therefore our knowledge is incomplete about this tree of Sansaar. I will know this tree of Sansaar completely when I know the roots, what the source of this tree of Sansaar is. That's why we are lacking for one side. So therefore I say one who knows this, he knows the Vedas. Vedas explain both the cause and effect. The roots and its tree.

So one who knows both is the Veda knower. Not the one who is only rooted in the Prakriti or this world. Only Yastam Vedasa Vedavid. Such a person knows the Vedas. Adhacha Urdhvam Prasuta Tashishaka, Guna Pravruddha, Vishe Pravalaha. So our Sansaar is now described using this allegory of a tree.

So that we understand how my world works. We talked about Prakriti in detail in last chapter but we have still stopped at. But these are the Gunas which are binding me and I need to go beyond these Gunas. Now we are learning about this Sansaar which is constantly changing. And how can I liberate myself from this Sansaar root? The cause for this is the Purusha.

Unless there is consciousness, there is no Sansaar. How this Sansaar is rooted in this consciousness is what I'm trying to understand. That this tree grows in my world. Adha Cha Urdham, Prasuta Tashya Shah. Its branches are up and also below my world of ideas. Prakriti in the lower world where I live in.

But I also have ideas about the higher nature. So my ideas go both ways. They go up and they go down. I think about mundane thing but I also think about the sacred things. So my branches of my Sansaar is spreading in both directions in my Prakriti in my day to day life. But also what is beyond my day to day life.

Guna Pravrudha, Vishaya pravalaha. These branches are nourished by the Gunas. They get more and more entangled into this prakruti. Bound by these Gunas I get more and more entangled in my world here because of the Gunas, my vasanas, my tendencies bind me to this world. My tendency is the music. So I somehow will always have to have some kind of a musical event because my Gunas is binding me.

So these Gunas are binding me into this world below. Guna pravruddha, vishaya pravalaha and the sense objects are the buds. So the sense objects have the potential to grow my Sansaar. If I see something which is of my liking then my Sansaar will grow in that direction. As we have seen that given opportunity I have this latent tendencies. And when a right environment is given to me, those tendencies will play out as first desires and then actions.

So if I don't have a chance, if there is no field then those tendencies will remain dormant. So I may be a nicest person if there is no opportunity given to me to get bribed. I have never taken bribe in my life but I may have tendency to take bribe which was never given an opportunity. The sense objects are bird. This opportunity presenting itself will then grow that tendency in me as desire and in actions. So the sense objects are the birds which has capabilities to grow my sansar in the directions of my tendencies depending on whether I'm a sattvic hemrajas, you go tamasic.

The sense objects will grow my Sansaar in that direction. Adaachar mulani anusanthatani and while I am functioning in this world bound by these Gunas, I am also developing my roots in this prakrit in this world. When we first moved to Richmond, because we moved from Northern Virginia, we were pretty active there. You know, we were running all these classes and all my friends, they say, Neil, it's not too far, only two hours. So anytime we have an event, you come down to Northern Virginia. So first about few months we did that, you know, they will have a music party and they will call me and we go down there, we will have music party, we call them and they come down here.

Gradually we started having roots here in Richmond. You know, we have friends here, our own group and we have classes. So now that we have grown our roots here in Richmond, we gradually get detached from this northern Virginia friends. Now they call me and say yeah, but I don't have time, I have activities here, I have classes here so I can Come.
snippets.reflection:
Reflect on the image of the cosmic tree: roots in the infinite, branches in the finite world. You participate in both realms—anchored in something unchanging while engaging in the play of change.

Where in your life do you need to strengthen your connection to the roots? Where have you become too entangled in the branches?

The Gita teaches that wisdom is the axe that cuts attachment to this tree. What attachments are you ready to release?

snippets.title: Day 190: The Supreme Self
snippets.sanskrit:
ततः पदं तत्परिमार्गितव्यं

निर्मानमोहा जितसङ्गदोषा

न तद्भासयते सूर्यो न शशाङ्को न पावकः |
snippets.transliteration:
tataḥ padaṃ tatparimārgitavyaṃ yasmingatā na nivartanti bhūyaḥ .

nirmānamohā jitasaṅgadoṣā adhyātmanityā vinivṛttakāmāḥ .

na tadbhāsayate sūryo na śaśāṅko na pāvakaḥ .
verseTranslations: Beyond lies the Path, from which, when found, there is no return. This is the Primal God from whence this ancient creation has sprung.

The wise attain Eternity when, freed from pride and delusion, they have conquered their love for the things of sense; when, renouncing desire and fixing their gaze on the Self, they have ceased to be tossed to and fro by the opposing sensations, like pleasure and pain.
Neither sun, moon, nor fire shines there. Those who go thither never come back. For, O Arjuna, that is my Celestial Home!
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 15. We have seen in last two chapters the nature of Prakriti. Chapter 15 is Purushottami Yoga, Yoga of the Supreme Purusha. So now we are learning about the nature of Purusha. So the chapter begins with explaining the tree of Sansar. That Sansar which I find it very real and that which I consider is the real reality is explained in the first three verses.

So it's a Urdhvamoolaha Adashakaha. The allegory used is of a tree because it exponentially growing. Just like a tree grows over a period of time. So this tree of my Sansar is growing exponentially. But its real picture given here is Urdhvamoolaha. The source of this tree is up above and the branches are below and the leaves are below.

This tree of Sansar is is growing in this world with the branches spreading all over. More I know about this Sansar, more this tree grows. More I know about things and beings. More my Sansar mind networking more people. I know my network grows. More people have relationship.

My network grows in this world, this Veda. The knowledge increases my Sansare and as my Sansar increase I start developing roots not knowing what my real source is because because the source is unavailable for me to see. So I develop roots here. More actions and more experiences that I have. It grows the roots here. So the actions are creating new channels in this world and then establishing me in this Sansar.

I start thinking this is where I come from. I cannot find my real source. So I consider this Sansar as my source. So my roots are now growing in this world. And Bhagavan said that Naarupam Ashya iha Tatha Upalambita. Its overall form is not available to me.

I cannot figure out how this Sansa started and how I got entangled into it. Naantah Nachadhi Nacha Samprateshta. I can figure out where it started, where it's going to end and how it is rooted in this world. Asvattam Enam Suvirudamulam if you want to know the overall picture. So we have learned before and said one who knows both he is the Veda Vida. One who knows the source and the Sansa.

One knows the Purusha and Parakriti together is the Veda with he is the knower of the Vedas. We know only _part of it. Like a Karmakanda actions. What we do in this world, we are aware of it but consider ourselves to be Gnani. But one says that's only partial knowledge. That's what actually binding me to this world.

Because I don't have complete knowledge. Veda describes both the Purusha and Prakriti. Therefore one who knows both is the Veda Vida. So to become Veda with you have to go beyond this perception of this Prakriti. Only with that acts of non attachment. What is binding in this world.

What will release me from this world and give me overall picture is detachment. Therefore with that weapon of detachment firmly cut this tree. Tathaha Padam Tat Parim ar Gita Vyam Yasmin Gadhana Nivardanti Bhuyah. This statement comes over and over again in our scriptures. Tasmin Gada na Navaratanti Bhuyaha. One who goes there, he never comes back.

Because this life is just a one small _part of our existence. Our existence is infinite. It started from the way the world started. Now continue till the world ends. This life is just a small sliver of my existence. So I'm trying to resolve all my issues during this lifetime.

But you say it will be nothing but a continuation. End of this life will not be the end of anything. End of the life will be just a milestone. Move on to the next mile. But if I really want to resolve all that I want to resolve in this life, I need to go to a place where I don't have to come back again and again to resolve my issues. My issues are I'm trying to avoid unhappiness.

I'm trying to go beyond sorrows. He said that can only happen if you go to a place where there are no sorrows or where there is no mortality. That place, that goal should be sought. Right now I'm seeking goals which are temporarily giving me happiness. My accomplishments, my acquirements, all these things are giving me happiness, but temporarily. So he said, if you want to go there, then you have to seek that goal.

Now what is that goal? Tamevacha Adhyam Purusam Prapadyam Yat Pravrutvicha, Prasuta Purani. Then now I seek refuge in that primeval Purusha, that original source from which stream forth all the ancient activity. The real source of this activity, the Sansar, is the Purusha. Unless I'm conscious about my Jagat, my Jagat does not exist. Unless you are conscious, your Jagat, your Jagat does not exist.

This world exists as it is because we are aware of it. Bhagavan said from that source, the consciousness is the source from which all the activity started. My Jagat comes into being as soon as I become aware of it. If I'm not aware of it, it does not exist for me. So Bhagavan said that seek that place from which all the activities started, that consciousness. So he said, now my goal is that I seek refuge in that primeval Purusha from which all the activities have started.

So we have defined the goal. We have defined the Sansar. The Sansar seem like roots are here. As we say, wherever we settle down, we form our roots. So now that I'm in Richmond, my roots are in Richmond. I have forgotten all about my previous roots.

People come from Northern Virginia. I don't have time for them. I come from India, but I go back and I feel uncomfortable there. All your formative years in your life were here. And suddenly you feel uncomfortable because you are detached from those roots. The things which we used to find so common, we can find anymore because we keep changing where we establish ourselves.

But once you establish yourself into your original source source, then you will not have to move around. We establish the goal that I need to take refuge in that primeval Purusha, the original source. And my original source, as I know is, everything that I know is because I'm aware of it. My consciousness is the source of all my experiences. My entire Jagat exists because I'm conscious. So I want to take refuge in that.

So then the next verse gives us the qualifications to be achieved or when will I be able to achieve that state? So it says, nirmana moha jita, sangha dosha, adhyatmanitya vinivratta kamah dwandwaihi vimuktaha sukhodukha sangehi gachanti amudaha padam aveyam tat. The six qualifications given here, they are something similar to we have learned before all throughout the Bhagavad Gita. And we have concluded already not possible. We Right away said this is not possible for us. So we move on to the next chapter.

So first was the Nirma na Moha. The one who is free from pride and delusion. Then Mana and Moha both my assessment of my situation and typically my assessment is overly liberal about myself. So Bhagwan said, Moha that over assessment of myself creates the delusion about my importance. Once I have correct assessment of myself then I will not have the delusion. So Mana my importance which I say can say without me the world cannot my company.

I don't know what will happen if I'm not there tomorrow. This society cannot function unless I do this. That wrong perception that I am so important creates the situation which makes me unhappy. In the end all this impurities because of the attachment. My attachment creates the false perception. As we said, the people we like, no matter what they do, it's okay.

So the same event if you watch on Fox News will be completely different than you watch on msnbc. So you have the country is divided into two. One who watches Fox News and one msnbc. Because Sangha attachment. That attachment creates doshaha false perception of the reality. So you have to watch cnn.

So it is my attachment which is creating false perception which is creating dosha in my perception. Therefore Jita Sanga Dosha 1 is victorious over attachment and the stain which comes with it. Adhatma nityaha established in the self. Our mind obviously have to have something to attach to. Our mind cannot stay without any object to think about. Mind does not exist if you don't think about anything.

Therefore in deep sleep there is no mind because there are no objects. In my deep sleep, I don't exist. In deep sleep, not the world exists. The mind does not exist in the deep sleep. As soon as I wake up, the mind rises because all the things which I associate with come into its perception. My house, my car, my family, my work, my job.

Very first moment in the mind is active. So all this talk about jita sangha do saha I say not going to happen. Because more I try to avoid attachment, I get attached more. So Bhagavan said then you have to create an attachment which is so powerful that no other attachment can touch you. That attachment with your own self Adhyatmanity. Constantly remembering that I'm not this body, not this mind, not this intellect.

These are my equipment. This world is temporary but myself is permanent. That constant churning in your mind will give you the ability to detach from Other things. So adhyatmanity you are free from desires. My memory bank is the root cause of all the problems. That's why when we see somebody, we don't see him or her the way.

Right now we remember everything. Our encounter with that person in the past. If the memory bank said the encounter was good, the person is good. The memory encounter wasn't that pleasant. The person is not good. So this memory bank creates ideas and then it creates a desire and the mind starts longing for it.

If we stop power of this memory bank to guide our perceptions, Bhagwanji will see things as they are. If I can judge a person from the day I'm looking at him it will be very different than all the baggage of all my experiences with him before. If you judge him from what he does today then it will be a very different perception. Even the person who is a big criminal. But once he resolved to be good, he should be considered good. Because he should be judged on what he's doing today not what he has done in the past.

But we obviously cannot function that way. We have to find all his resume what he did in the past and then only we can judge people. Bhagawan said vinavrutta kamaha if you don't do that, there won't be any desire to do anything which is not appropriate. Dvandvai vimuktaha we have learned this over and over again. It is the most difficult concept to understand. This is beyond pairs of opposites.

That does not mean the pairs of opposites go away. Pairs of opposites remain as they are. Sukha du kha mana apman they all remain exactly where they are. Winter and summer all those things remain. But I become indifferent to them. That's a dvandvai hi vimuktaha.

Just like in the last chapter we have learned what is the first quality of a guna titaha. He's a Gunatidha one he does not despise when the gunas are present. Also he does not long for them and they are not present when Tamas is there and despise and seek sattva. But I take them as they are and not get attached to them. So therefore he said dhvandvayihi vimukta he is not affected by one or the other.
snippets.reflection:
Reflect on the image of the cosmic tree: roots in the infinite, branches in the finite world. You participate in both realms—anchored in something unchanging while engaging in the play of change.

Where in your life do you need to strengthen your connection to the roots? Where have you become too entangled in the branches?

The Gita teaches that wisdom is the axe that cuts attachment to this tree. What attachments are you ready to release?

snippets.title: Day 191: Two Purushas
snippets.sanskrit:
ममैवांशो जीवलोके जीवभूतः सनातनः |

शरीरं यदवाप्नोति यच्चाप्युत्क्रामतीश्वरः |

श्रोत्रं चक्षुः स्पर्शनं च रसनं घ्राणमेव च |
snippets.transliteration:
mamaivāṃśo jīvaloke jīvabhūtaḥ sanātanaḥ .

śarīraṃ yadavāpnoti yaccāpyutkrāmatīśvaraḥ .

śrotraṃ cakṣuḥ sparśanaṃ ca rasanaṃ ghrāṇameva ca .

snippets.reflection:
Reflect on the image of the cosmic tree: roots in the infinite, branches in the finite world. You participate in both realms—anchored in something unchanging while engaging in the play of change.

Where in your life do you need to strengthen your connection to the roots? Where have you become too entangled in the branches?

snippets.title: Day 195: Two Purushas
snippets.sanskrit:
यो मामेवमसम्मूढो जानाति पुरुषोत्तमम् |

इति गुह्यतमं शास्त्रमिदमुक्तं मयानघ |
snippets.transliteration:
yo māmevamasammūḍho jānāti puruṣottamam .

iti guhyatamaṃ śāstramidamuktaṃ mayānagha .
verseTranslations: He who with unclouded vision sees Me as the Lord-God, knows all there is to be known, and always shall worship Me with his whole heart.
Thus, O Sinless One, I have revealed to thee this most mystic knowledge. He who understands gains wisdom and attains the consummation of life."
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 15, Purushottama yoga, yoga of the Supreme Purusha. We have heard these terms before in Bhagavad Gita and Vedanta, Purusha and Prakriti. We understood from this discussion that the Prakriti is the manifest. Anything that which I can see, touch, feel and vouch for its existence is Prakriti, including my thoughts, my ideas. Because other people may not be able to vouch for, I can vouch for it that they exist. Anything that exists in the realm of my perception, feeling in thoughts is a Prakriti.

But that which supports this Prakriti or awareness is the Purusha. I am aware of this Prakriti because I am alive. If I am not alive, this body cannot perceive whether it is day or night. So that conscious principle in me is a Purusha. That's what we understood. The Prakriti is changing every minute, every second.

At a micro level, my body. My body has been changing every minute. I may not realize it till I see my pictures from five years ago. One good thing about these pictures on a website, we never change it. So I have a picture which was taken in 2003 on my website and anywhere else. So when the people come in contact with you in person, they get shocked.

Neil, you know, look a little different. Well, I never realized it. But other people who say it or when we see our picture, we realize this is constantly changing. What it was yesterday is not today. So that falls into the category of a perishable things and beings. This body is perishable.

But this body is supported by something which remains constant. This change I'm noticing in my body because something remains constant. That constant factor is gauging the change. I used to look like this. I used to have all dark hair, all my beard was dark. That one who notices the change remains constant.

That the support for this change. Change can only takes place if there is something constant. So in my life, I, the consciousness, I, the awareness is constant. So when we remember Our childhood memories we don't think that that was something a different person. I remember this happened to me I remember that I remain constant. Everything else about me keeps changing.

So at my micro level there are two purusas two me One is perishable which is the body, mind and intellect One is imperishable which is the one who is aware of these changes One who is afraid of death Otherwise why would I be afraid if there is not someone watching it and say looks like this body is going to go out. People ask me all the time now Neil, what's your plan? I said what do you mean what's my plan? He said we're talking about retirement. I said I have no plan because I feel the way I felt when I started NBG architecture the very first day I'm the same person you're going to be qualified for Medicare in a couple of months so I'm sure you have some plan. And at that time I started thinking oh is that so?

Statistically Indians don't really last longer than somewhere about early 70s that's 65. I probably have less than 10 years if I have less than 10 years I haven't even planned what I'm going to do because I as I never feel old that I at my level is always be imperishable. We started out this chapter by saying that I when I think about myself it seems like my source is somewhere unknown up above but my life is all here spread all around it the same I now I look at it that when Bhagavan talked about the nature of the Supreme Being is that everything that you see, perceive and feel is nothing but my expression Right now I'm only worried about me. I'm not worried about whether you're going to retire or she is going to retire or he's going to retire what am I going to do? I'm also not worried about whether you people will be around when I die and after I die I'm only worried about what will happen to me. So at my level Bhagavan said in this Loka DHV Purushav There are two Purushas in this world.

In my world there are two Purushas One which is perishable that I see Bhagavan said nothing that you see is other than me. I only exist and pervade everywhere. Everything you see, touch, feel and perceive is nothing but my expression including perception of my own body, mind and intellect which is deteriorating. I can't remember even My employee who has just left me three days ago. And so you know, she used to work here. Because the memory is not now as good as it used to be.

So I see this perishable me which is also the Purusha. And I also see the imperishable one who doesn't think about the retirement even now. Dhwa Imam Purusha, in this loka of mine, in this world of mine, there are two Purushas. One is perishable, one is imperishable. Is the world ends here for me? Beyond these two, there is a supreme Purusha.

Right now that supreme Purusha I really have no connection with. So therefore I'm only worried about this Purusha. The one I feel is imperishable. Whatever I feel is still as young as when I used to be a little child. Bhagawan said that beyond these two there is a Purusha which transcends both the imperishable and perishable. And the example which we have seen is this room space is imperishable.

Room, walls, floor and ceiling is perishable. We are doing some renovation next door. So we say I'll move this wall here and do this because that's perishable. But we know that the space itself is imperishable. In relationship to the wall, floor and ceiling, this space is imperishable. But if we remove this walls, floor and ceiling out of the equation, what happens to this imperishable space?

It's not even imperishable anymore. If there is no perishable things in this world, the word imperishable means nothing, right? Because it is imperishable compared to perishable thing. Long lasting battery. Short lasting battery, Lifetime warranty. Battery's life or the manufacturer's life?

Or that company's life? All of our contractors, we ask them we need 10 year warranty or 15 year warranty. 20 years warranty guy gladly give. 5 years from now you'll try to call him and say we have problem, we need you to. The phone number is out of service. So the lifetime warranty we get is not your lifetime, it's the lifetime of the company.

As long as companies, the warranty is good. But all these things are relative. But if you take the relationship out, what remains is absolute which you cannot really compare in this world. So this Purusha, one is perishable, this body one is imperishable. Which is conditioned by this body, mind and intellectual. But if you remove the conditioning, what remains is absolute Purusha which is neither perishable nor imperishable but ever existing.

And that Bhagavan said is by nature. So he said Uttamahapuru Sahatu Annyaha Paramatma ITI Udahrutah. We heard the word Paramatma. What does paramatma means? My atma is imperishable compared to my self. The body, mind, intellect.

But if I don't have this body, mind, intellect, that atma is absolute. Therefore it is param Atma. Not in reference to this. Our idea is that imperishable. Bhagavad Gita said that I'm imperishable. Even if I die, I'll be nil bhatt somewhere.

Bhagavan said Paramatma, it will be part of the infinite. Therefore that supreme being which forms this being as me is a paramatma. Swamiji gives a very nice example. Even within a room space there is a pot space. The space in the coffee cup is room space. The space remains in the room.

But when I even remove the room, the whole room space becomes so. When we take these layers out of identification, this is my mind, this is my body, this is my intellectual. They have their own identity and then I have my identity. The I which is my mind, my body, my intellect. When you remove in this I, what remains is just an absolute self. My atma, not conditioned by my limitations is Paramatma.

Your lokatriyam Avishya Bibhartya via Ishvaraha. That Paramatma is supporting the three worlds I live in my three worlds. Waking dream and deep sleep. My waking world is different. My dream world is different and my deep sleep world is different. I, the conditioned self is going through all these three experiences in my life.

But the condition self is supported by whom? This room space is bigger, smaller, depending on where I put the walls here. But supported by what? By the universal space. This is a part of that universal space. Yasmaat Aksharam Atito Aham Aksarat Apicho Uttamah.

Therefore Bhagavan's Yasmat Aksharam Adith. This self is even beyond imperishable. This self in me is much greater than this perishable Me. That's what we take some solace in learning Bhagavad Gita that even if I die, I will not die. Bhagavan said, but that self is even beyond Aksharaha. Beyond this imperishableness.

Imperishable as we have seen is only reference to the perishable. So let's say my life is hundred years. But there are things here which are 5000 years old. Compared to me, that thing has existing forever. But this time frame, when we completely remove the scale from our mind, what remains is absolute existence. No past, no present, no future.

So Bhagavan said Yashmat Aksharaati Tahm beyond imperishable and perishable. I am even supreme than this perishable and imperishable. Ataha Asmi Lokethah Purushottamaha. We had been hearing this word Purushottama. What is that Purushottama? He said, because my real nature I the Lord the Ishvara and I say Lordship is that which supports my existence is my Lord.

That's when we call King a Lord. Because my existence as the commoner is because of his grace. He allows me to do that. That's why he's the Lord. In this case my Lord is him. Because my existence is because of him.

Therefore in this world I am called Purushottama in the Vedas. Purushottama is described in Vedas as the one which is beyond perishable and imperishable. And also the scholars and poets in this world has sung its glory as something beyond perishable and imperishable. And therefore Bhagavan said, I am called Purushottama. Therefore this chapter was called Purushottama Yoga. Yoga of Purushottama.

Right now I am completely yoked with this perishable and imperishable Purusha. I am very aware this is perishable me. I also know this body is going to die. But I have complete identification with it. I also have some solace because I had been learning Bhagavad Gita for many, many, many years. That something within me is imperishable.

Bhagavan said, but I am Purushottama. I am beyond this perishable imperishable. Therefore I am called Purushottama, my own self. When drops relationship with this body, mind and intellectual, this world, this perception, this feeling, these thoughts becomes Purushottama. Yo Mam Eva Samudaha Janati Purushottamam who knows his self as Purushottama One who Asamuda, one who is undeluded. We are, whether we like it or not, are deluded, fooled by the illusions that you are different than I am and she is different than he is.

No matter how hard we try, this conditioning is so complete that we will not be able to get out of it. R. Bhagavan said there is a state for a Gyani to go beyond this illusion or delusion that he sees all the time that his relationship is with the Purushottama and not with this Purusha. Sarva Vid Bhajati Maam Sarva Bhavena Bharata.

snippets.reflection:
Review the list of divine qualities in this chapter. Without judgment, ask: Which are strong in me? Which need development?

Choose one quality to consciously cultivate today—perhaps kindness, or truthfulness, or patience. Watch for opportunities to exercise it. Growth happens through practice, not through wishing.

Also notice which demonic qualities—arrogance, anger, cruelty—sometimes arise in you. Acknowledge them without shame. Awareness is the first step to transformation.

Abhimanaha Krodha anger then Parushyam harshness, Physical harshness or mental harshness or Parasham harshness. Agnanam so ignorance Bhagavan says mourn out of your devilish qualities. Nibandhaya Asuri Mata Asuri is considered to be binding you to this limitedness. Masuchaha Sampadam daibim Abhijato Asi Bandava. But O Pandav, you don't worry, O Arjuna, don't worry. You are born with divine qualities. And last time we had discussion about whether Bhagavan said that because you are a royal prince. It does not say anything about royal prince here.

It simply says you are born with divine qualities. Bhagavan just assured him that just the behavior you have exhibited in your life. I assure you that you are born in divine qualities. As Swamiji says that we all can be assured that we have divine qualities. The very fact that on a Sunday morning you are learning Bhagavad Gita because of the divine quality. Giving assurance to seekers that if you are sincere about Liberating yourself, you need to have some courage.

As I said, we have easy detection of a divine quality. But when it comes to our judgment, we are not sure whether we are divine or not. So here is an assurance that because you are exhibiting divine qualities that you are divine. So the Master Chaha, do not worry. I look back on my life and I see a lot of mistakes I made and now I am worried about whether this is my exhibition of my devilish qualities. The very fact that you're interested in liberating yourself tells you that you are exhibiting the divine quality.

Continue in a path of your journey for seeking your liberation. Now start making statements. Dvav Bhuta Sargo Loki Asmin Deva Asura Evacha Devo Vistarasahaprakhtaha Asuram Partha Meshrunaho. There are two types of beings in this world, Divine and demonic. Divine we have talked about at length in the previous chapters in Bhagavad Gita we have been talking about these divine qualities of the Supreme Being manifesting through all beings. We have been describing in detail.

Bhagawan said, so now I'll just focus on Asuri. I'm going to tell you Asuri in detail now. So rest of the chapter now focus on the behavior of Asuri. Prakriti Pravritimcha Nivruttimcha Janana Vidhu Asuraha. Very first manifestation of demonic qualities. I do not know what should be done and what should not be done, what is the right thing to do, what is not right thing to do, what I should be engaging into and what I should refrain from, what I should stay away from if I can decide that Bhagavan said, this is the first quality of your demonic estate.

No Saucam, there is no purity. Purity at the physical level, mental level, intellectual. Now Socham na cha API acharaha na satyam tesu vidyate. Those people with demonic qualities, they do not know what to do, what not to do. They neither have purity nor right conduct. They do not know the truth.

All these things are the manifestation of of demonic qualities. So now we can start looking at and say is that something I should be detecting in myself and correcting it? And with that I'll stop here because rest is continuing of this discussion. Discussing chapter 16 Deva Asura Sampath Vibhag Yoga Yoga of Divine and Devilish Qualities or estate Wealth. So we have started learning Bhagavad Gita from Lord Krishna where he first gave us this scenario of Arjuna. That Arjuna is a broken down hero, the person who has all the strength, all the valor, all the training to fight his situations.
