snippets.title: Day 199: Following Scripture
snippets.sanskrit:
काममाश्रित्य दुष्पूरं दम्भमानमदान्विताः |

चिन्तामपरिमेयां च प्रलयान्तामुपाश्रिताः |

आशापाशशतैर्बद्धाः कामक्रोधपरायणाः |
snippets.transliteration:
kāmamāśritya duṣpūraṃ dambhamānamadānvitāḥ .

cintāmaparimeyāṃ ca pralayāntāmupāśritāḥ .

āśāpāśaśatairbaddhāḥ kāmakrodhaparāyaṇāḥ .
verseTranslations: Giving themselves up to insatiable passions, hypocritical, self-sufficient and arrogant, cherishing false conception founded on delusion, they work only to carry out their own unholy purposes.
Poring anxiously over evil resolutions, which only end in death; seeking only the gratification of desire as the highest goal; seeing nothing beyond;
Caught in the toils of a hundred vain hopes, the slaves of passion and wrath, they accumulate hoards of unjust wealth, only to pander to their sensual desire.
snippets.commentary:
Discussing chapter 16 Deva Asura Sampath Vibhag Yoga Yoga of Divine and Devilish Qualities or estate Wealth. So we have started learning Bhagavad Gita from Lord Krishna where he first gave us this scenario of Arjuna. That Arjuna is a broken down hero, the person who has all the strength, all the valor, all the training to fight his situations. But under the burden of the circumstances, he broke down and did not know what to do and what not to do. So Bhagavan told him that the only cure for your condition is to correct your understanding about what is right and what is wrong, what is permanent, what is impermanent. Since second chapter it clearly says that your mistake is that you are identifying with your limited self and looking at all the other people through their limited equipment.

But they are imperishable when it comes to the soul. Their real being is imperishable, just as yours. So that was the correction Bhagavan wanted Arjuna to make the identification from this limited to unlimited. In Bhagavad Gita, the journey is to change your identification from this limited being that I am to the unlimited soul that myself is. So everything we have discussed so far in Bhagavad Gita is towards that goal. Towards that goal of changing my identification with the limited self to unlimited self.

So entire Bhagavad Gita up to chapter 15 has described that unlimited self and how to identify with that. And in chapter 16 now we are discussing what is that which is binding me to their limited self. So as we have discussed, the first three verses told us about the qualities of the divine being or the divine estate. As we transact in this world, we are going to acquire wealth, we also accumulate other wealth. Respect, recognition, appreciation, and on the other side, disgust, criticism, all that also we accumulate along with accumulating the wealth which is generally our normal endeavor in life. So these become our estate.

Some are divine and some are devilish. Something which are acquired is pure and something we are called impure. So Bhagavan gave us the first 26 qualities of the divine estate. And then in the fourth verse he gave another six qualities of the devilish estate. So he said, the divine is quite obvious. Most of us recognize divinity when we see it.

And as we have discussed last time, it is easier for us to find divinity in us. For my mind to detect good quality in me is easy, very difficult for my mind to detect the negative tendencies in me, but it is very easy for my mind to see negative tendencies in others. That person is very hypocritical. Well, he is doing it for ego only. We can very clearly recognize it, but it is very difficult for us to recognize in ourselves. So this chapter takes upon itself to describe in detail what would be the behavior of a person who is predominated by negative tendencies, which in this case we call asuric tendencies.

So when we see this behavior in others, it is easier to detect. But when I do something similar, I consider that as well very, very minor or well, this is the way the life works. If I don't do it, then people will trample over me, I'll be a doormat. So my behavior I can justify saying that's how you survive in this world. But Bhagavan makes it very clear that if you detect this type of behavior, this behavior is very negative for your evolution, for your goal of liberation. So he said there are two types of one helps you to liberate yourself from the limitation.

Other will be binding you to this limitation. More you try to satisfy your desires to get happiness through the material goals. You will be more binding yourself to this limitations. Pravruttim nivruttim cha janana vidhu asuraha. The first indication is that person does not know what to get engaged in and what to stay away from. I do not know what to do and what not to do, which is what the Arjuna situation was in the very first chapter.

He did not know what is right for him. Bhagawan is not saying the Arjuna is asura, but the behavior he exhibited was clearly of asuric tendency. So something in him which was not allowing him to decide what is right and what is wrong. But once I know that that's a negative tendency Pravrittimcha nivruttimcha janahanna vidhu asuraha those who have the predominant qualities, they will not know what to do, what not to do. Na saucam, na apiyacharah na satyam teshu vidyate they will not have purity, cleanliness also na satyam teshu vidyate. They will not be able to tell the truth.

And Swamiji explains here that it is not to put them down that Bhagavan is saying this. It's actually somewhat of a pity for them that they're incapable of doing so. They're incapable of living an honest life, incapable of telling the truth. Because they're so afraid that telling truth will put them in trouble. In our daily life we call it white lie. Because you know, telling truth is going to put me in trouble.

Well, you really don't want to say what you really think about. They will say generally around looks good. So that basically is my incapacity to tell the truth. These people, when look at overall life, they are just not capable of telling truth because of their desire to protect what they consider is giving them happiness. And then he continues. Asatyam a pratishtam te jagat ahuhu Anishwaram.

This statement relates to what we have learned so far in Bhagavad Gita. In Bhagavad Gita we have learned that the nature of the self is Sat chit in Ananda that Sat is ever existing. We also learned that Sat truth is something which is consistent in all three periods of time. In the past, in the present and future. Something which was true in past has to be true today and will also be true tomorrow. So that is considered Sathya.

But that which is not consistent, something which was true yesterday, which is not true today. At some point it was true. Everybody agreed with each other. Other will all fall down at the edge of the earth. But now we know that that's not true. So that was not true.

Now what we know was true then even though we did not know it. It is true today and will remain true tomorrow. The people with asuric tendencies, they think that this world is asat. In a sense it is impermanent. It came in existence by chance and will perish. That means it's not permanent or pratish.

It just by chance occurring. It happened Te jagat ahuhu an ishwaram. And there is no controller. There is no central authority who govern the laws of nature. Their view is it all came about by an accident. Will remain in this situation for a while and will disappear.

There is no basis for this world to exist. There is no fundamental substratum which supports this universe. Universe came in Existence by accident will get destroyed by accident, basically. Or pratishtham te jagat ahu Anishwam. This is the worldview, Swami is a materialistic view. When I try to analyze the truth in this nature through pure physical science, only then obviously the only thing I can find is these two came together by some accident.

These elements came together by accident and then it happened this. Then other things happened by accident and then this happened this. So starting from the Big Bang, we can say Big Bang occurred. Why it occurred we don't know. But it's an accident. It occurred and after that it started expanding and then hydrogen became helium.

And all this is just an accident without any basis. Anishwaram There is no controller who is controlling the laws of nature. Aparaha paraha sambhutam. By coming together two opposites. Kim annyat kaama haithu kam. So the progeny or the continuing of this life on this planet came out by just accident.

By coming two together and for the only purpose fulfilling desire. There was no master plan, there is no underlying truth, there is no substratum. But it just all chance occurring. This is the view of the materialistic atheistic people. They have no faith in any underlying reality for this world. Etam drastim avastabya nastaatmanaha alpa buddhayaha.

Obviously this is a direct criticism from the Gitacharya that these people are wrong. They are seeing this from a very narrow perspective because they are viewing this world from a very narrow perspective. So when I see my life as a living being and I just analyze from a chemical perspective, electrical perspective, this is just a pure machine. It came together and it is pumping blood through the pumping action. And I can define everything in a mechanical term, in a physical term, in a chemical term, and say this is me. But what is it that keeping all the systems together, I really don't have an answer.

Simply saying it's just all working together. Physics came together, science came together. So basically you can see this life either as something divine which is supporting it, or simply say this is all just chance occurring. There is a book I have read called Brief History of Almost Everything. It's a fantastic book. It explains right from the Big Bang to where we are today in a very succinct manner.

His conclusion is that we as human beings existing on this planet is almost a chance. That one in a million odds that happen thing and it happened and continue happening and we are still existing. But anything could have gone wrong and we wouldn't have been here. So basically you're saying that maybe just a chance that we have become who we are. So here Bhagavan is saying that these people are looking at the world from a material perspective, analyzing what's happening from a material perspective. They're coming to the conclusion it's just chance occurring.

Why I am not tall enough and other guy 7ft tall is just a chance occurring. So Bhagavan said that having such view Nast Atmanah they are destroying their own self because they are negating their own self. They are not even recognizing that there is underlying reality. Called myself Alpa Buddhaya. They have intellect they are obviously analyzing. They are using all the faculties to understand this world.

But from a very narrow perspective. Alpam Buddha Fools it basically says very narrow perspective. Prabhavanti Ugrakarmanah Shayaya Jagato Ahitah. So the actions are very harsh because they are not recognizing the underlying unity of our things and being. You can take example of vegetarianism. The one underlying theme of vegetarianism is that every life has right to survive and live.

So you have to inflict as little harm to a life to support yourself. But if I don't have that view, then obviously killing other animals may be justified. So Bhagawan said that because they have a narrow perspective, their actions are harsh. Shaya Jagato Ahithaha because of the misunderstanding of how this universe work, they are the enemies of the world for its destruction. You can relate to our green movement about saving the planet. Now obviously there are a lot of people coming out saying all this thing is a hoax.

We really don't need to preserve anything. This planet will preserve itself. In fact, I just read that somebody written a book that actually the global warming will be very good for farming. There are more warmer weather and it will make people rich. So you can look at it from any perspective and your perspective will decide how you're going to act in this world.

snippets.sanskrit:
इदमद्य मया लब्धमिमं प्राप्स्ये मनोरथम् |

असौ मया हतः शत्रुर्हनिष्ये चापरानपि |

आढ्योऽभिजनवानस्मि कोऽन्योऽस्ति सदृशो मया |
snippets.transliteration:
idamadya mayā labdhamimaṃ prāpsye manoratham .

asau mayā hataḥ śatrurhaniṣye cāparānapi .

āḍhyo.abhijanavānasmi ko.anyo.asti sadṛśo mayā .
verseTranslations: This I have gained today; tomorrow I will gratify another desire; this wealth is mine now, the rest shall be mine ere long;
I have slain one enemy, I will slay the others also; I am worthy to enjoy, I am the Almighty, I am perfect, powerful and happy;
I am rich, I am well-bred; who is there to compare with me? I will sacrifice, I will give, I will pay - and I will enjoy. Thus blinded by Ignorance,
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 16, Deva Asura Sampada Vibhaga Yoga, Yoga of divine and devilish qualities. And we have seen that these are the qualities of my mind. Even though it seems like it is describing two sets of different people, one are divine and one are devilish. And as if we are dividing this world again into divine and devilish. The purpose of these qualities to be described in Bhagavad Gita is to understand our own mind. Our own mind has this both qualities, the divine and devilish, depending on which one we promote, either we'll be liberated or will be bound more and more into this world of limitations.

So the last verse we had seen last time says Asa Pasas Satayi Baddhaha, the person who is not knowledgeable enough about what will liberate him and what will bind him by depending on this notion that the sense enjoyment is the only purpose of life. By hook or crook, I should achieve what I want. They will be more and more bound by unlimited desire, Asha Pasa, bound by this bondage of desires. You know, satay, that means innumerable desires. And therefore they will do anything which is either appropriate or inappropriate. They will try to achieve, acquire, hoard things which they think will give them the happiness by even illegal means.

Inappropriate means continuing in the same dialogue as we have seen, Bhagavan now describes what will be the tendency or the thinking of these people. Swamiji says there's not really much to elaborate on it. Just as we have seen that the first three verses which describe the divine quality, there is not really much to be discussed about. These are universal qualities. Even cavemen knew what is right and wrong. Somebody should not take the food which I have acquired with my labor.

Therefore, if I do that to others, it will be wrong. I don't want somebody to kill me, and therefore killing somebody is bad. These are universal values which every human being from the dawn of the civilization know. Same way that what we are going to be discussing, the tendencies and thinking of a devilish mind Is also really doesn't require much explanation. You know why we all have experienced this at some point of time or other, at some level or other. Except that at that time I did not know that my thinking is going to create more unhappiness.

When I was thinking about that I was thinking I'm doing this to get more happiness for financial security. I put more and more money into stock market and as it grows I get the statement every month and it says okay, it made 8% and next 10% feeling pretty good. Except when it collapsed. Didn't have courage to open up your statement. But while I was doing that I thought I'll get this and then I'll also get this and also get this and therefore I'll be completely secured. We didn't think we have to do this and we work all life so hard.

I have not come across a single person who says I really need to work hard in my life but I'm enjoying it. Everybody thinks that what I was thinking all the time was Idam Adhya Maya Lavdham I have gained this today. Today, today I can say I have this. I reconcile my statement of what is my assets at the end of the year for taxes or whatever. Boy, that's pretty good. Or well at least I have this.

And then what is my next thought? Imam Prapse Manoratham I have this but I will also get this. What if financial planner says okay well you need to have this and to retire at the age of such and such. Whatever this many times of your current income you will need this and therefore you need to do the following. So you start planning. First time a financial planner was a friend of ours coming to Chinmaya mission in Dallas.

I was pretty young at the time. I was like 30 something. And he looked at them and said you need million something dollar to retire. I don't think I'll ever have a million dollar. At the time I was probably making like $35,000 a year and the guy was trying to tell me I need million dollar to retire. You forget about it, okay?

I'm going to work till I die. No planning required. Because when you see that I have this, I need to achieve this or work hard. Neel, you have to have at least this much when you retire. I have this right now. This is a common thinking.

Nobody will label that as devilish. Bhagavan says that's the quality which binds you to this world of constant changes and disappoints you more times than you think it will. Idham asti idam API me bhavishyati punardhanam. And this wealth shall also also be mine in future. It's planning simple. I acquired this and I'll work a little hard and do this project and then invest here and then I'll get this.

Bhagavan said, but that may be okay for planning purposes, but when that becomes your obsession, then it has a sure capacity to failure. You should be planning. I can never forget this thing in my life. I bought my first house in Dallas, Texas in 1984, just before the election. I guess it was the Reagan second election. And they told me that after the election the prices will go so out of control that you won't be able to buy.

So you should buy before the election. Says, okay, you buy this house, $150,000 minimum, it will have 5% appreciation. You have compounded 5% for 10 years. The value of this thing will be this. Oh boy, that's pretty good. They say that's guaranteed 3 to 5%.

It may go up and it's guaranteed. I sold that house, the one which I bought in 1984, in 2000. Now you apply that formula, 150,000. Should have been at least $350,000, right? I sold it for $10,000 more than what I bought in 1984. And as if I have not learned the lesson yet, I bought a house in Northern Virginia where they say it was Dallas.

You know, that's an oil dependent economy. It goes down or it goes up. We are federal government dependent economy. Guaranteed 20% appreciation every year. You can look at it last five years and you will see it. I bought a house again in 1988, Northern Virginia, in Fairfax.

And again I said, well, they say 20%. I'm going to be on 5%. Okay, at least I'm safe. I projected in about 10 years, eight years, five years. I bought it in 1988, sold it in 1996 for exactly $6,000 more than what I had bought for. I made $6,000 after eight years owning that house in Fairfax, Virginia.

We plan, but what will come out of my actions is not guaranteed. Bhagavan said, there's nothing wrong in planning. That's not in a devilish pursuit. What devilish pursuit is, if this doesn't happen by hook or crook, I will make somebody a Scapegoat and get my money. So therefore it says Idamasti Idham Apimi Bhavishati Punardhanam. This is mine and this will also be mine.

That which I have projected at a 5% appreciation that shall also be mine in 10 years. I can say this is what I have. This is its value today. What will happen 10 years from now only he knows. And whoever after 10 years has to buy this house knows. So it is the attitude of my mind makes the same thing either divine or devilish.

I took care of this competition. Obviously in those days they were enemies and they were killing each other. But in a normal day to day even they say I never have killed anybody. So I never said I killed this person. But we do mentally all the time. I killed this competition.

He was trying to be the VP of the company. But I really manipulated. I went around and talked to all the other bosses and I really pushed him down. And now I got the promotion as vp. That's I who killed him for that purpose. So Asaomaya Hataha Satrahu who was my enemy who is in the path of my happiness.

My enemy is the one who is obstructing me to be united with my happiness. I killed this person, initiator Aparanape and the others who I think will be on my way, I will kill them too. It always gives me a kick. Anytime I read this Rasi Bhavishya we get this South Carolina Sati magazine and only thing I read is honestly the horoscope. Because I have nothing to do with all these businesses in South Carolina. Only thing I can relate to is that last page which says your monthly horoscope.

And this guy constantly warns me. At least the Aries who I am, you know, born in that sign. Be careful about the people around you. They may be planning to harm you. Now what do you think? My thinking would be well look at Meena, Pourvi, Neeraj, little Medha.

They must be all planning something against me or my employees or my friends. This is just insecurity. We bank on people's insecurities. Because if you don't take these annuities the market may go down. You will have no security when you are retiring. You need a guaranteed income.

Annuities will give you this guaranteed income. He fails to tell you that those annuities cost lot more than any other investment you would do. They are making money in your insecurities. What will happen when I return If I don't have money they say okay we'll take care of it. But we'll take part of your money and put it in our pocket and make you feel good that you will have the guaranteed income. I took care of this computation, this enemy, even the others I'll take care of them too.

Therefore I will be secured. When I'm doing this, my state of my mind is I am the Lord of my being. I take care of myself. Not only I take care of myself, I take care of all people around me. What would happen to them had I not been doing what I am doing. All these people are dependent on me.

Bhogihi and I'm enjoying it. All these efforts which I'm putting and gaining this I have got that I'll be getting. I'm the Lord of lord is on whom my existence is dependent on. So in the feudal system whether you live or die, the way you live is dependent on the Lord. He decides how much money there was no unions and nobody decides how much to give it to the workers. He decides whatever he has to give.

So therefore he's the Lord and you're the commoner. Ishwara Same he decides how this world is going to function. So when I decide that I am the Lord of my Sansar I decide in old Indian system the head of the house will tell how everyone should leave in that house. I think that I control everybody and everything. Bhogi and I'm enjoying the fruits of my actions. I'm a successful one.

What you have accomplished in your profession and it's admirable and what you accomplished in your wealth and it's all admirable. Guy doesn't know the other side of the story. What I not accomplished and where I have failed. It is okay for others to think about that. When I start thinking about my own accomplishments that's where the problem starts. It's perfectly okay for us to admire the people who accomplished some great things such as Isaac Newton or Bill Gates or Steve Jobs.

snippets.title: Day 201: Demonic Qualities
snippets.sanskrit:
अनेकचित्तविभ्रान्ता मोहजालसमावृताः |

आत्मसम्भाविताः स्तब्धा धनमानमदान्विताः |

अहंकारं बलं दर्पं कामं क्रोधं च संश्रिताः |
snippets.transliteration:
anekacittavibhrāntā mohajālasamāvṛtāḥ .

ātmasambhāvitāḥ stabdhā dhanamānamadānvitāḥ .

ahaṃkāraṃ balaṃ darpaṃ kāmaṃ krodhaṃ ca saṃśritāḥ .
verseTranslations: Perplexed by discordant thoughts, entangled in the snares of desire, infatuated by passion, they sink into the horrors of hell.
Self-conceited, stubborn, rich, proud and insolent, they make a display of their patronage, disregarding the rules of decency.
Puffed up by power and inordinate conceit, swayed by lust and wrath, these wicked people hate Me Who am within them, as I am within all.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 16, the Evasura Sampada Vibhaga Yoga. The divine and devilish qualities are the estates. This is the only estate you and I will carry with us when we die. All other estates will remain. But these qualities or tendencies of my mind, which are both as some divine tendencies and some devilish tendencies, I will carry that as my estates and I'll start from there. You've seen so far that this divine tendencies will liberate me from my limitations.

The veilings on my mind which is right now is not letting me see the reality as is that myself and the supreme self is one and the same. On the other hand, the devilish qualities or the aspheric tendencies which in reality all it means is it binds me to this manifest world and therefore I will be more covered with ignorance from my own self. And therefore it is very important for me to understand what are these qualities. So in the beginning we have learnt about all the divine qualities and they are universal as we have said. So therefore there is not really much explanation needed. I should treat others just as I would like others to treat me.

Such divine qualities in if I practice it will liberate me from my limitations. But more and more I get bound to this world of manifestation. This is me and this is the world. This I want and this I want to avoid. It binds me more and more to this world. And therefore it is very important to understand how this thing works.

So we have seen so far that asuric tendencies make people believe that there is nothing more to this world than enjoy the sense gratification or satisfying the desires that I have, the lust that I have, and who knows, because I cannot see what was before my birth and I cannot see what was after my birth. Well, let's just consider this life is the only life that I have. And therefore let's make the most out of this life by by hook or crook. So I have now come to the conclusion that hoarding more and more wealth will make me happy. I will achieve that by any means, any unjust means. Even though I know this is not right, I will go ahead and do it anyway.

And once I get into that mode of mind, my situation would be that I will be constantly worried. Chintama Aparimayamcha AP I'll be overwhelmed by the worries. I'm always worried about things which I don't have. Once I acquire it, I'll be always worried about how to safeguard it. Because just as I took it away from somebody, somebody will take it away from me. So this mode of mind will be constantly be engulfed by these worries.

But then at the same token my ego will start rising into its power and start thinking look, I have acquired this. These are the natural tendencies of my ego. Once I accomplish something, I start thinking nobody else could have done but I did it. So then last few verses which you have seen is the mode of my mind. snippets.reflection:
Review the list of divine qualities in this chapter. Without judgment, ask: Which are strong in me? Which need development?

Choose one quality to consciously cultivate today—perhaps kindness, or truthfulness, or patience. Watch for opportunities to exercise it. Growth happens through practice, not through wishing.

Also notice which demonic qualities—arrogance, anger, cruelty—sometimes arise in you. Acknowledge them without shame. Awareness is the first step to transformation.

snippets.sanskrit:
तानहं द्विषतः क्रुरान्संसारेषु नराधमान् |

आसुरीं योनिमापन्ना मूढा जन्मनि जन्मनि |

त्रिविधं नरकस्येदं द्वारं नाशनमात्मनः |
snippets.transliteration:
tānahaṃ dviṣataḥ krurānsaṃsāreṣu narādhamān .

āsurīṃ yonimāpannā mūḍhā janmani janmani .

trividhaṃ narakasyedaṃ dvāraṃ nāśanamātmanaḥ .

So you have no access to your buddhi.

Your memory bank is completely out of your reach. So you cannot access your wisdom when you're angry. Therefore people say, well I, I did it because I was angry. That means it's not appropriate. We all know that Bhagawan said so avoid karma so you don't have to get angry with Crowther. I buy a lotto for the first time and I get a hundred dollar prize. Well, looks like this is an easy pass. So I do it again and again.

snippets.reflection:
Review the list of divine qualities in this chapter. Without judgment, ask: Which are strong in me? Which need development?

Choose one quality to consciously cultivate today—perhaps kindness, or truthfulness, or patience. Watch for opportunities to exercise it. Growth happens through practice, not through wishing.

Lord Shri Krishna replied: Man has an inherent faith in one or another of the Qualities -Purity, Passion and Ignorance. Now listen.

snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter one. Arjuna Vishada Yoga, Arjuna's Grief. We have started the chapter with Dhritarashtra. Dhritarashtra, as we have discussed, is our state of mind. Right now we live in Dhritarashtra state. We are blind to our reality, the.

Supreme reality, the real reality. We are blind to that, that I am part of that supreme being and then leave in the world of Mamakaha I and mine. So that's basically how the Bhagavad Gita started saying this is our problem, all our problem starts with that one misunderstanding that I am this limited being, this Mamakaha is my world, I and mine is my world. And then I separate the rest of the world as something other than me. Then the next few verses focuses on Duryodhana. That is the Duryodhana in us.

This Duryodhana represents the thief in us. That we want to take away something which belongs to somebody else. And I want to make it mine. Then I want it so badly that I will use any means to get it in. All over day to day life we see inequality in our society because obviously there is wealth which is common to all, given by God is natural. When somebody hoarded so much and didn't.

Live enough for the others. So that the Duryodhina wants this thing so badly. He knows it's not his, but he wants it. And therefore he is always very anxious because he has decided I need to have it. I know it is not mine, but I need to have it for my own happiness, to make myself complete. This sense of incompleteness which started out.

With our state of Dhritarashtra where because. We are blind to our reality and then make ourselves limited to this self and that I and mine created incompleteness, that incompleteness has created a thief in us that I want to take away from others and make it mine so that I will feel complete. That's what Duryodhana felt all his life. That I need all this kingdom for myself. He was already Given half the kingdom. After the first match of chess and now he wants all of it.

So his mental state is of any thief who is trying to steal something away from somebody else, one is insecure. When you are trying to steal something, you are insecure. Is somebody watching me? So there is insecurity and then fear. Obviously you are fearful, you are insecure. That's why you want to make sure that I get what I want by any means.

So there are three things in that mentality. I want this so badly that I'll. Be willing to do anything. I'm insecure and I'm fearful. So the next few verses which we have seen is just describing his titi. First six verses we have seen said.

Look at Pandava's army. It looks pretty well protected. Great warriors on their side basically is going to Drona and saying, these are all your Shishyas. Arjun, son of Drupada Drishtadharamna, who is. Now commandering the army. So I'm not sure that we are.

Totally protected having somebody like Drona with us. Because his shishyas on the other side. That'S a fear in him. So he describes all that he feels is the weak points from looking at the other side. And now he realized that he may have gone overboard. When somebody is in that state, he wants to cover both bases.

One side he feels insecure. Other side he feels very powerful that. I have all the shrewdness and smartness and strength to do it. So first looked at his insecurity and his weaknesses that the other side is powerful. Now he's looking at, no, no, I can do it. Because so the verse 7 onwards, he now looks at his strength.

Asmakamtu Visishtaye Tani Bauda Dwijottama. Obviously he's addressing to Drona. And he said Dvijottama. And we have discussed before Dwijottama Dwija Brahmin. Brahmin is considered twice born. One is a physical birth and second is a birth.

In this knowledge of who you are that starts at the time of Upanayam, Guru gives a mantra in his ear. Then he runs to the Gurukul to get that education. So he becomes established in this knowledge. That's why it's called Dwij. Because the first is just for a limited being, it's a physical birth. Second birth is where he takes birth as a wise person.

So therefore they are called Dwijaha Drona. Being A Brahmin is Dwijaha. But he said, Dwijot Tama, you are. Best among the Brahmins. Now this could have been the best. Compliment in a normal situation.

But in this situation it is not because we know or at least the society knew at the time. Brahmins are soft hearted. They are not fighting type. They are not war mongerers. They are not the ones who can be in the situation. They want to avoid this type of conflict.

We have seen that that's how Karna. Was caught by Parasuram. Karna, obviously he went to Parasuram because he realized other than Drona, Parasuram can. Teach him what the other Pandavas are having. Pursuram has taken vow. He will not teach any Kshatriya because.

He wanted to eliminate Kshatriyas from this planet. So he has taken a vow. He will not teach this art of warfare to any Kshatriya. So Karna goes there as a Dvija, as a Brahmin. He disguises himself as a Brahmin or. Lies that I am a Brahmin.

And then obviously he was a good student. One day, teacher was sleeping and his head was in Karna's lap. And then this Brahmar, what do you call it? Okay, bumblebee that comes and sits on Karna's thigh. He realizes that if I move, my. And he does not want to make his Guru uncomfortable at all.

He's in a deep sleep. This bumblebee course through his flesh and the blood is oozing out of that wound. He tolerates all that pain but does not move a muscle. So that his Guru gets disturbed in his sleep. The blood comes running down his thigh. Under the Guru's head.

And he wakes up because of the warm blood he feels. He wakes up and sees what's happening. Then he realizes what has happened. And Karnataka says, I'm fine. And he was angry because Guru said, you lied to me. You are not a Brahmin.

If Brahmin would not have been capable to tolerate this kind of pain. You are a Kshatriya who lied to me. And then obviously, as the story goes, he asked for forgiveness and all of that. But then Parsuram said, you will have. This knowledge but it will not come. Handy to you when you really need.

It in the battlefield. You will lose this knowledge. The relevance here is Dvija is not a positive compliment when you are in a war. So he reminds him that look, I know you are a great teacher and a great archer and great warrior. But in the end you are a. Dvija so don't be soft hearted here.

It's actually his fear that maybe this. Guy will go soft hearted and will. Not fight this battle. Sangartam tan bravi mi te. Therefore I am going to now describe to you who are the great warriors and oversight. Don't go soft hearted on me.

We have also great people on our side. You don't need to worry about it. You just do your job. Bhavan Bismast Chakranastha starting with you Bhavan, you who are on our side so that we feel that we are protected. Bhavan, you Bisma, Karna, Krupastha, Samitin, Jaya and Krupacharya who are victorious. All these people have good track record of resume of winning battle.

Asvathama, Vikranscha, Somadatt, Tatha, Evacharya and then all others like Asvathrama. Last time we have seen Kurupacharya is Dronacharya's brother in law and Aswathrama is Dronacharya's son. Swathama was more like Duryodhana.

He was Duryodhan's best friend and he. Was basically looking for that. If he stays with Duryodhana and Duryodhan. Wins the war then he will have a kingdom of his own. That's where their animosity started. So the long story all weaved into it. But in the end basically Duryodhana said these are all people, the great people on our side and not only the main characters but Anyeche, Baha, Bahasuraha, Madharte, Tyakta, Jeevitaha and there are many others on our side who are ready to give up their life for me. Many, many brave people are on our side. In other words, they're committed to fight this war. Yudwijotama, I'm not sure about you but I'm sure about everybody else.

They are committed to fight. So let's do the right thing here. Nana Sastra Praharanaha, Sarve, Yuddha, Visharadaha. Not only they are ready to fight for me but they are equipped with various types of weapons. So we are well equipped. We have a human capital, we have technology.

So let's not worry about it. Yudda Visaradaha they are expert in warfare. This verse obviously confuses everybody because why. That Apar Yaptu insufficient. Now every translation I have seen does say insufficient Even though it seems that unlimited is more appropriate here. And I had asked Swamiji one time I said Swamiji, all this translation where does that come from?

And Swamiji says we don't get involved in this because you need a Sanskrit pandit to translate this. And he says there are Sanskrit pandits and Kashi who is translated Bhagavad Gita. After all this discussion and looking at. It and that's the translation we use. So even the Chinmaim translation does not really come from Chinmaimita and Swamis it actually came from Pandits who have decided this is the translation of some. So we have to take it as it is and say Apar Yaptam in our vernacular languages.

Aa Pariyapta is insufficient. He's saying insufficient. Now remember his mentality is that of a thief. He always feels that he is incomplete. He always feels no matter how much. That person has he will always feel.

There is something more I should have. And therefore his vision about what we have is not ever we are sufficient. We have plenty then even be fighting this battle. So even army he sees that as insufficient for all these people who went on Pandava's side they actually should have been on my side then it would have been much better. And my army is protected by Bheeshma. Because he knew that Bheeshma has taken a vow that as long as he leaves he will guard the throne of Hastinapur.

Whoever is in the Hastinapur he will be protecting him. He also knows that Bheesma has Ichamritya. He will only die if he wants to die. As long as Bheesma is alive he is protected. So in one hand he knows that as long as Bheesma on his side he obviously does not have to worry. But at the same token he thinks.

If I had more then I would have felt little better about it. So he said Apariyaptam Tadasnakam Balam Vishna Bhirakshitam Our strength protected by Bhishma still feels little insufficient. Whereas on the other side Pariyaptam twidam Etesham Balam Bhima, Bhirakshitam. Now they are protected by Bhima. And then after last time, Sid or somebody pointed out that this is not correct. Bhima was not the commander, but the commander was changing every day in this army.

If you read Mahabharata, and I have never read Mahabharata, so I'm not an authority.
snippets.reflection:
Consider your own faith—not beliefs, but the deep orientation of your heart. What do you truly trust? What do you reach for in moments of crisis?

snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 17, sraddha traya vi bhagiyo, three types of sraddha. The chapter opened with Arjuna's question that if someone has not understood Sastras, or even having understood, he sets aside the prescription in the Shastras, but have faith in what he thinks is right in pursuing his faith, does that face be considered a Sattvik Rajasik or Tamasic? That's a simple question, simply because in the last chapter, the clear advice by Krishna is they follow the prescriptions of the Sastras in deciding what to do and what not to do. And as we have seen that Sastras literally means here the collective wisdom of your culture, collective wisdom of your society, collective wisdom of your ancestors. So unless I really rely on the wisdom of my ancestors, I will have no foundation really to decide what is right and wrong. Any profession, any science, you build on what was already been tried and true and proven in the labs or in workshops and then say, now where do I go from here?

So the clear prescription was not to ignore the wisdom of your ancestors, your civilization, your culture, and then decide what is right and wrong for you. It's not saying that you don't think yourself, but think based on the tried and true wisdom. When we go to high school and learn chemistry and the teacher says H2O makes water, well, you have to have some faith in him. Unless you have faith, you will not learn, because you have faith in the teacher that you will accept that and then you will prove yourself going to the lab. So the prescription was follow the Sastras and decide what to do and not to do. Arjuna's question is, if someone completely sets aside the prescription in Sastras for lack of knowledge or lack of faith in the Sastras, but he has a faith in something he believes in, does that faith to be classified as Sattvik Rajasik or Tamasic?

Because we have seen, everything can be classified Sattvik Raja Segura, Thomas Bhagavan said, I'll tell you, it's not a one label fits all type of an answer. Your faith will be as you are. My faith will be as per my experiences. Every time I walk into the airport and I'm absolutely sure that the plane will be on time. If last few times I went there plane was on time, I'll tell it will be on time. But last few times I'd been going there always late.

What will be my faith? Chances are my flight will be delayed. So anytime I'm going to India, what I do is I leave about six hours of gap between when I go from Richmond to New Jersey airport and New Jersey to Mumbai. We have no faith that the flight from Richmond to New Jersey will take me in time. They say, well keep on two hours gap. No, no six hours gap.

You don't want to miss an international flight. That's my faith in our airline based on my experience. And then the other people may have other things. So Bhagavan said that your faith is Sattva Anurupa. It in accordance with your own self, your own core of your being, core of your mind. So my faith will be what my experiences are.

Faith is something comes intuitively to you. More like a tendency. Why I like music, I don't know that's my tendency. But more I follow my tendency. More I will be following that path. More I have a faith in Gita, more Gita I will read more I read Gita, I have more faith in Gita.

So it's both are wedded together. More faith I have more I will pursue that path. More I pursue that path. My faith increases in that. So Bhagavan said, it is individual who decides whether he will have faith which is Sattvik, faith which is Rajasic or faith which is Tamasic depending on tendencies of his mind. Yajante Sattvika Devan so if overall makeup of my mind is Sattvik, what I will do?

Well, I will follow Satwik beings. I will strive to pursue or worship divine beings. My role models depending on my tendencies. If I am pursuing wealth, my role model Bill Gates. If I want to be Great leader, my role model will be Mahatma Gandhi. If I want to spiritual, my role model will be Swami Chinmayananda.

Depending on my faith will be. My role model would be. That's as simple as that. So Bhagavan said Sattvika Yajante Devan one whose makeup is Sattvik, predominantly Sattvik. These are not exclusive qualities of One person, one thing or one being. Everything is made up of some combination of Sattvik, Rajasik and Tamasic.

But if my mental makeup is predominantly Sattvik, I will be pursuing the Deva, the divine beings, Yaksa, Rakshansi, Rajasaha, those who are Rajasik will pursue or worship Yakshas and Rakshasas. From the Puranas we have the descriptions of Devas and Yakshas and Rakshasas, but it's simply told here is Sattvik will follow the divine beings, Rajasik will follow the one which has wealth and power. Yaksas are supposed to be wealthy beings. There is a story in Mahabharata 1 where Yudhishthir goes to this lake when he wants to drink water. That lake was controlled by a Yaksha. Yaksha said, you can't drink water till you answer all my questions.

If you answer all my questions, I'll let you take water. In other words, he was the controller of that lake. He was wealthy enough to control his lake. These days people own islands because they're wealthy. So the Yaksa that the wealthy beings, and as Swamiji points out here in Purana, I say they're Kubera's brothers or cousins. So they're wealthy beings or Rakshasa's immense power.

There are stories in Puranas about Rakshasas immense power. In other words, in even society there will be people who are Sattvic, people who are wealthy and powerful. So if my tendency Rajase Sikh, then I will be pursuing the wealthy and powerful. My quality is a Sattvik. I'll pursue the divine being, Preta Bhuta, Ganas, Ch' annye, Yajante, Tamasa, Janaha and the others who have Tamasic qualities, they will pursue the Preta and Bhuta Preten Bhut. We obviously know from our vernacular languages are the dead spirits.

Spirits of the dead beings. Now in this society, obviously if there are three people pursuing the same goal of making a million, obviously one with a Sattvik will say let's find some creative way which will help the society in the same time will create the wealth. And that's how I'll make my million. Rajasik will say let's destroy my competition or take over some other and I'll get my million. And the last one will say let's pursue lottery, buy the mega million. All three are the same goal, but all three have a different avenue to reach there.

Now all three are working hard. Satvik is Also working very hard to achieve his goal. Rajasik working as hard and Tamasik working is hard. But their means are different to achieve the same goal depending on where his faith is. The one who's pursuing lottery has the complete faith that he cannot get million in any other way. This is the only way he can make a million.

One who wants to employ himself in a business, he has a complete faith he can do that in that. And the one is Satwik. He's a complete faith that if he comes up with something good for the society, he will also benefit from him. Depending on your own experiences, your mental makeup is made. That mental makeup now defines where I have the faith in. That faith will lead me into my actions.

So Bhagavan said these faiths cannot be labeled because he is not following Sastra. The Rajasik, Tathuka, Tamasika. He may not know the Sastras but he has the Sattvic tendencies. He will follow Sattva. He may not know Sastras but he tended Raja Sikhs. He is following Rajasik and may not know Sastras because he's Tamasaik.

He's following Tamas. So Preta and Bhuta are the dead spirits. In other words, in normal society will consider that to be non starter. Somebody says, well Neil, why don't you buy a lottery? I never want anything in my life. Let's not waste my dollar.

At least I have a dollar. After that I won't have a dollar. But somebody is Faith and say, well, I have $10. I'll put nine of them in the lottery. I'm pretty against of lottery by the way, because we're taxing the people who can afford the least in the society. Lottery is good for the education.

It will reduce your taxes. No, it's a tax on the people who cannot afford that tax. Most lotteries are bought by people who least can afford it. But they are Preta, bhuta, ganans chany, asastra, vihitam, ghoram tapyante yei tapo janaha. Now I have my faith that this is how I can pursue my goal. My faith is dependent on my experiences.

So now I'm pursuing my goal vigorously because I'm as sincere as anybody else. But I'm pursuing in a field which I think is the most conducive for me to achieve that. Not knowing what is right or wrong because I did not take time to do it. But I'm working very hard. As I said last time, I want to go to New Jersey. But I'm driving as fast as I can on 95 south just because I didn't take time to figure out whether New Jersey north or south without knowing what is right or wrong from the tried and true wisdom of my society.

If I had just taken the triptych From AAA or GPS it would tell me New Jersey is the north. But I didn't take it. I didn't want to take that time. They're working very hard. They are pursuing these austerities with vigorously Dhamb ahankara sanyuktaha. Because they're filled with dhamba hypocrisy.

Tapasvaya ahankara ego. Nobody knows better than I do. So who are they to tell me that New Jersey isn't an orph? I know it got to be on this way. Ahankara sanyuktaha Kama rag Balan vitaha they were propelled to do this by what? Kama desire and raga attachment.

Kama and raga is propelling my actions and I think my happiness lies there. My goal is to achieve the happiness just as everybody else is. But I think my happiness lies in these actions where others are saying no. That's where you have the danger that you probably will be unhappy. We tell our kids, don't do that. But at that time he does not think he is going to get hurt.

But if he listens to you, you as an elder person learn from your own experience that jumping from that second floor is going to get you in trouble. Young person, at that age of 8 or 9 or 10, he thinks he can do anything he wants. Therefore he says kama ragaha Propelled by that desire and attachment, he wants to show off to his friend that he can jump from the second story. We have seen that in our childhood. Hypocrisy and arrogance. The ego filled with that and propelled by attachment and desire.

And they are putting vigorous actions in the fields which they consider is appropriate for them. Karshayantaha Sarirastham bhutagramam a Chaita Saha. This is a description of someone who has completely ignored the advice from the Sastras. Bhagavad Gita we read every Sunday. What do we do after that? Bhagavad Gita says, but that's not really.

So now we fall into this category. Knowing fully well, we set aside the prescription in the Shastra. We are propelled by our desire and our attachments. And also we are Dhamba, ahankara sanyukta.

snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 17, Sratraya Vibhaga yoga, yoga of three types of faith. We have seen in last chapter. When Bhagavan ended the chapter, he gave the advice to Arjuna that do everything in life according to the advice given in the scriptures or by the sages. That's how you will incur more divine qualities. And these divine qualities are liberating. They will liberate you from your limitations which are creating sorrows in life.

If you do not follow that, you may incur more negative tendencies which will be more binding. They bind you to this material world. So Bhagavan said that follow the scriptural advice when you decide what to do and what not to do in this world. So obvious question Arjuna had was that what about the people who never had a chance to refer to scriptures? Either by their own choice, that they didn't think it was important, or they never had an opportunity to learn scriptures. And we can imagine in that society, probably the larger mass of people were not allowed to even learn scripture.

Arjuna had a very logical doubt. What happens to all those people? They are working in this world with faith. They have a faith that this is the right way to live life, which will give me happiness. Because at the end of the day we have discussed that the goal of life is to be happy. No matter who we are, our goal in life is very simple.

We all want to be happy. If I look at my entire life, it is divided into two pursuits. One is to achieve happiness and other is to avoid unhappiness. Bhagawan said, we are all working toward the same goal. But those who do not listen to the advice in the scriptures, the books of knowledge, teachers, wise people, ancestors, they suffer by developing wrong tendencies. But those who follow the advice from the wise people, because they've gone through that and come to the conclusion this is the right way to act, they will benefit from that and acquire the divine liberating tendencies.

Arjuna said the people in this world, working in their field, in their life, with faith but having no knowledge of what is prescribed in the scriptures, as I said, either by choice that they decided it's not worth it or they never had a chance to do it. So what is the nature of their sraddha? They have sraddha too, that this is where I'll get my happiness in life. I ask question, is it _Verses_, _Verses_ or _Verses_? Because if it is just out of my ignorance, they said that is tamasic. Bhagavan said it is all of the above.

It can be any of the three. If you have not referred to the scriptures but still have the faith, your faith can be of any of these three or it can be at any given time, one or the other. So it can be _Verses_, it can be _Verses_, it can be, it can be _Verses_. It is predominantly whatever my personality is, my faith will be according to my personality. As the faith, so is the person. As the person, so is the faith.

So it's a symbiotic relationship. Whichever field I choose to work in, I eventually become an expert in that. I go to architecture school, work in architecture field. All that is depending on the mood of my mind.

So now it says what type of yajna, the actions. Yajna basically is a sacrifice. When we sacrifice something we are offering to someone. So afala kangsi behajnah vidhidristo ya ijjyate yastavyam eveti manaha sama Dhaya sasatvikaha. So that is the results of my AA Vidhi Purvakam. And then with a complete faith that this is what I want to do because this is my duty. And see such an action is satvikaha.

Such a yajna is satwik Yajna all my actions if I define and say oh falakanxi bhi in other words no predetermined result I have decided I go for an interview all the time. It is the result you have to worry about.

ABHI Sandayatu Falam. First one we are doing it simply because it is my duty. I don't have a predetermined notion of what is going to come out or what results will be there and I'm firmly established in that action.

ABHI Sindha to falam Next one is okay, it's a slight difference. First one I had no expectance here. I want to make sure that if I do this I want to get this thing out of it before I make a donation. We ask so what kind of a recognition you will have in your organization for me? Can I get a seat on your board or what other things you are going to do for us or any action we can say that which I want to have a predetermined falaam that ABHI Sandhya the Falam Dhambharyam API chay vayat I'm doing it because I want to show off. I say well let me give a concert where I'm going to show off how good a singer I am.

Ijjyatai Bharata Sreshta Vidhirajasam There are only two motivation I have in performing these actions. One is I want to show off and acquire something which is predetermined. Therefore that motivates me.

Can I get a seat on your board or what other things you are going to do for us or any action we can say that which I want to have a predetermined falaam that ABHI Sandhya the Falam Dhambharyam API chay vayat I'm doing it because I want to show off. snippets.sanskrit:
मनः प्रसादः सौम्यत्वं मौनमात्मविनिग्रहः |

श्रद्धया परया तप्तं तपस्तत्त्रिविधं नरैः |

सत्कारमानपूजार्थं तपो दम्भेन चैव यत् |
snippets.transliteration:
manaḥ prasādaḥ saumyatvaṃ maunamātmavinigrahaḥ .

śraddhayā parayā taptaṃ tapastattrividhaṃ naraiḥ .

satkāramānapūjārthaṃ tapo dambhena caiva yat .
verseTranslations: Serenity, kindness, silence, self-control and purity - this is austerity of mind.
These threefold austerities performed with faith, and without thought of reward, may truly be accounted Pure.
Austerity coupled with hypocrisy or performed for the sake of self-glorification, popularity or vanity, comes from Passion, and its result is always doubtful and temporary.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 17, Shraddha vibhagyur yoga three types of Shraddha so we are coming to the concluding portion of Bhagavad Gita and some of us who had started Bhagavad Gita from chapter one and have gone through all 16 chapters and now in the 17th chapter may start wondering what about the people who never get a chance to learn Bhagavad Gita? We are fortunate that we get chance to learn Bhagavad Gita one way or other. But what about the people who never thought about learning Bhagavad Gita or never had a chance to learn Bhagavad Gita? Thought does come to our mind. How do they leave their life in a manner which is appropriate? Similar question Arjuna asked in the beginning of this chapter.

The Bhaiwan says I learned from you all this knowledge which you have given me and I have Shraddha. But how about the people who have never gone through the scriptures or had the guidance from the scriptures? They also have Shraddha. Everyone has Shraddha something that we know. So how is their Shraddha is helping them or how do you classify their Shraddha? What kind of Shraddha is that without any basis of any guidance from any guru or scriptures?

And Bhagavan said each person has a Shraddha according to his or her mental makeup. It as simple as that. Whatever my mental makeup is that will decide what type of things I will be convinced will give me happiness. Bhavan said that there are three types of Shraddha you find in people. One is Sattvik, other is Rajasic, third is Tamasic depending on the texture of the person's mind. We know that texture of our mind changes as the circumstances change.

So depending on my circumstances and the basic nature of my mind, my mind will be either in a Sattvic mode or in a Rajasic mode or a Tamasic mode. But with practice I can control mood of my mind. Even these circumstances are not conducive Bhagawan said that becomes your predominant nature. Some people, no matter what it is, get angry. Some people, no matter what situation has come, they enter the room and people will be all agitated. But one said that because that is your basic nature.

Your basic nature is what is predominantly the life you are living and how you are reacting to the situations. And that makes up your mental texture. And as your mental texture, so is your faith. And as your faith, so will be your mental texture. So we'll go back and forth between who I am, what I have faith in, what my faith in what make me who I am. So what are the three types of Shraddha?

And this Shraddha is so powerful that it will lead your life. It will guide your life. Wherever I have my conviction that this is right. This is what will give me happiness. It will pursue that path. So our life is not really divided.

What I do in one aspect of my life does not affect the other aspect of my life. Even though we think so well, I compartmentalize my life. My professional life is different than my personal life. In reality there is nothing like that. Who you are will permeate through entire life that you live. Whether it is personal, professional, social, sacred.

So Bhagawan said that that's very important. That you control the texture of your mind. Because that will exhibit your qualities no matter what you are doing. And therefore he said that even to something as simple as Ahar food also you will pursue according to the mental makeup of yours. So in the beginning we had talked about three types of people. What type of food they will like.

That is something which will give him nourishment, life giving, health. When you're Rajasic, you will like something which is tasty, feel good food, comfort food. As soon as the word comfort comes, you know it's not really healthy. There is a restaurant in downtown. Basically special comfort food. Finally realized that it's all loaded with calories.

That's why it's good. That's why it's good. I don't know why Bhagavan made it that way. Why not comfort food? I always question that why the fried food is not the healthiest food. So up till now people are saying the low fat milk, skim milk, low fat.

I just read article in New York Times said the whole milk is now rising in popularity. Because now the research says the whole milk is actually healthier than your skim milk. Still he said the American association, whatever the doctors recommend that you should have the low calorie diet. But the low calorie diet is gradually losing its glitter. So Bhagavan said that the person with Sattvic mood will find something which is nourishing and health giving. Rajesh will find something which tastes good and comfort food and it's a tamasic.

Will get anything that is available. Does not matter whether it is good or bad. Then we said even the Yajna they perform in a broader sense. All my efforts are basically offered in the Yajna of my life. My life is a Yajna and I am offering all my efforts into it to achieve something good. Bhagawan saying the Yajna is for the greater good.

Even when I consider that I'm doing something for the greater good it will be all as per my mental makeup. Even though I may have good intentions but I may end up doing something which may not be helpful to others. Road to hell is paved with good intentions. I think the rolling stone or somebody said that. So sometimes even though I have good intention my mental makeup will make me put efforts in place where I feel right. They may not be right.

Therefore he says the Sattvik will put efforts where it is. He has figured out what is the right way to put actions. With faith, with guidance that he will put his effort. Furniture I buy and then I'm so impatient. Let's not worry about it. Let's start putting it together.

Halfway I realized that I missed couple of steps. I have to go back and undo it. He said the Sattvik person will do it. Whatever he does, he'll find out the right way to do it. A Rajasic person will say let's get it done. Right or wrong, let's get it done.

Because I want a result instantaneously. That which gives me result instantaneously. That's what I want to do. You don't have patience to go through this step by step or Vidhi Purvakam. So because we want instantaneous result, I sing a song and people who are just like me who doesn't know what music is say great, you are doing very well. That's what I was looking for.

So that's Rajasic Yajna without any method but have a result, a fruit in mind. And then last one we have seen, Yajna is that without any Vidhi I don't even have faith in it. But it's supposed to Be done as per the society's norm. Or people think I'm not doing right, let's do it anyway. Is this factor of safety before exam go to the temple? I knew that's not really going to help.

But you might as well do it because there is no harm. Just as a factor of safety. Maybe let's go to the temple and say bhagavan, take care. Tomorrow I have an exam without faith and without any method, without any reason. That Yajna Bhagavan says Tamashi Yajna. Then we came to the Tapas.

This faith will affect ahaar, Yajna, tapa and Dana. So now we came to the Tapas part. Tapas austerities or we loosely translate as disciplines which we follow. We discipline ourselves so that we can get some benefit out of it. We exercise routinely because of our good health. I want to run a marathon.

I have to prepare myself. So when we started this discussion, Bhagavan described three types of Tapas. The next is Tapas at the speech level. And third is Tapas at the mental level. There thoughts level. So at the physical level.

In my activities, Bhagawan described that worship of the Devas, Dwijah, Prajnah and guru deities, divine beings, twice born, wise people. And your guru Ahinsa Shaucam considered sari Tapas. All of us at some level or other, we try to do that in our activity. The next speech, whatever I speak is non agitating to others. It is truth but sweet sounding truth. It is beneficial to others.

Then it's a Tapas at the speech level and then Tapas at the mind level. Where my mind is silent and it is not creating unnecessary noise in the background. Then Bhagavan says that at the thought level. So my thoughts are discipline. My thoughts are always about my highest goal which is to achieve that oneness with the God as we call it. Where we fail is at the speech level. But then some people because we think that saying something is not hurting anybody.

But Bhagawan said that's also very harmful. Therefore that's very important. So majority will fall and stop at the physical level this Tapas and actions but fail to do it at speech level.

Nobody has any clue what I'm thinking. Only my outward actions and my speech is the only thing people are noticing or judging me from. Most of our lives we're doing things for others to judge me, right? That's why I said all marketing works very well.

So when we look at Tom Cruise wearing a suit which looks good on him, so I think it looks good on him, it should look good on me. So we try to judge ourselves by reflecting in the mirror of the society. And we think that what I am thinking in my mind nobody knows. And therefore we fail to do Tapas at the thought level.

Rur Bhagawan said all three when performed together will only yield the good results. So the next verse says Shraddhaya Parayant Taptam tapah trivedham Narayan Phalakangsi Phalakangsi Bhi Yuktehi satvikam pari chaksa Daya A man with firm devotion Shraddhaya parayaha with the firm faith. When a person is practicing all these three Tapasat trivedham all three when he's practicing of Falakaanxi vihi and he has no particular gain in mind when I'm doing Tapas also I shouldn't be expecting a particular result. Because I must have a complete faith in the Karma Phaladata that if I put my efforts the results will be there. So I constantly hear from my staff and say Neel, I don't think that we come on Sunday and work that anybody is appreciating. I said, but I don't know that you came on Sunday.

Did you put down your timesheet that you were here on Sunday?

snippets.sanskrit:
मूढग्राहेणात्मनो यत्पीडया क्रियते तपः |

दातव्यमिति यद्दानं दीयतेऽनुपकारिणे |

यत्तु प्रत्युपकारार्थं फलमुद्दिश्य वा पुनः |
snippets.transliteration:
mūḍhagrāheṇātmano yatpīḍayā kriyate tapaḥ .

dātavyamiti yaddānaṃ dīyate.anupakāriṇe .

yattu pratyupakārārthaṃ phalamuddiśya vā punaḥ .
verseTranslations: Austerity done under delusion, and accompanied with sorcery or torture to oneself or another, may be assumed to spring from Ignorance.
The gift which is given without thought of recompense, in the belief that it ought to be made, in a fit place, at an opportune time and to a deserving person - such a gift is Pure.
That which is given for the sake of the results it will produce, or with the hope of recompense,or grudgingly - that may truly be said to be the outcome of Passion.
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 17, Sadhatraya Vibhaga yoga, yoga of three types of faiths. We had been learning in Bhagavad Gita that our goal in life is to find ultimate happiness. Right now, the limitations which I have create sorrows and anxieties and regrets.

So to become ultimately happy, I need to get out of my limitations. Limitations are right now because of my identification with this body, mind and intellect. Mind is the tool I use to decide whether I am happy or unhappy. So my first goal is to purify my mind. So mind remains in a happy mode. So the Mana Prasadah.

So we have seen in this chapter that as my mind, so is my personality, my faith. Bhagavan said that there is someone who has no guidance from the scriptures or from a guru, or from any wise person. But each one of us has faith that I will achieve happiness one way or other. And then wherever my faith is that my happiness lies, those are the pursuit I'll pursue. So Arjuna asked Bhagavan, what kind of a faith is that? Bhagawan said, this faith can be a free, different kind.

This faith also can be Satva, Garajasik or Tamasic, depending your mind being Satvik, rajas, tamasic, you will be convinced your happiness lies in those type of endeavors. So Bhagawan said that your faith, your mental texture, as the faith, so is the person, as the person, so is the faith. So it is very important for me to understand what is making me unhappy, what makes my mind unhappy. And therefore this chapter for us to understand that how Sattva, rajas and Tamas affect my life. So the first thing we have seen, Bhagavan said that everything you do in life will be controlled by your mental makeup, the type of food you like, type of food you will take, the yagnas which you perform. All the effort you put for the greater good.

But that greater good also include myself. So therefore, all my actions which I perform are basically to achieve their ultimate goal of becoming happy. So those actions which I offer as my sacrifice to get my happiness is my yajna. See, those yajnas will be also of three different types. Sattvik, rajasik and tamasic. So we have seen that the ahara, the sattvik people will eat what is good for them.

And nutritious rajasik people will eat whatever is is pleasant, it feels good. And Tamasic will whatever they take, yajnas, sattvik people will perform without any expectations for the fruits. That rajasik will have a goal in mind, what he wants to get out of these efforts. And Tamasic just doesn't care. Then we talked about tapas austerities. But in our life we call it discipline.

I have to discipline myself to do this. I was just reading this morning. Now, the new research says that not doing exercise is as bad as smoking cigarettes every day. I better be careful because I'm the one who obviously does not get motivated for exercise that easily. So now I say, oh, I need to exercise. That's something I'm telling myself.

I need to perform to be in a good shape. I want to be in good shape because I want to be healthy. I want to be healthy because that makes me happy. So ultimately, all the tapas which we do, all the disciplines which we practice, are for my happiness. Bhagavan satisperformed at three different levels. You perform at your physical level in your actions, you perform at your speech level.

And you perform at the mental level. So the actions level, My actions should be helping others and not harming others. All my activities, I keep in mind that my actions are for the greater good. Once I take care of the greater good, I am already included in it. Because any action performed by any one person in this universe affects the entire universe. We know that we are all connected with each other.

If one person in family is unhappy, it makes the whole family unhappy. So we know that that why I should be performing this for greater good. Because it ultimately will affect me if someone is suffering. That suffering will eventually come down to me. The bhagavan said that the tapas are performed at three different levels. My activities should be such that it is for the greater good, then at the speech level, my speech should be such that it is truth but pleasant sounding truth.

All we husbands have good idea. When your wife says, how do I look? Do you really want to be truthful or really you want to be? You can be truthful but has to be pleasant sounding. Satyamvada Priyam Vada Bhagawan said, your actions should be for the benefit of others only it should be beneficial. My speech should be not only truthful, pleasant, but for the benefit.

If I tell somebody a truth, it has to for his or her benefit, not just because I want to be Satya Vadi Harischandra. So it's at the speech level. And then at the mental level I may be acting in a manner that it looks so Satwik. I may be speaking so softly and nicely. But if there is noise in my mind which is completely different from my actions and my speech is eventually affect my speech and my action. Therefore at the mental level, this tapas is Ta Bhagwan saying.

Now when I'm performing, it can also be the same three categories of Sattvik, rajasic and tamasic. Again, my tapas is for not for getting anything out of it, but it is something I need to do. So that's the purification of your internal instrument. My tapas is to purify my internal instrument so that I can experience that happiness in my mind. And the last thing we are seeing is the Dana. Charity is our general idea is it is to help others.

In reality, charity is to help yourself. Therefore, Swami Vivekananda said, if you find somebody who is worthy of helping when you help, thank him to give opportunity to help so that I can help myself. Dhanam is for me to purify my mind and control my ego. So Dana gives me the opportunity to purify my mind by giving away things which are of abundance with me. So Dana is also a social phenomenon to keep the equilibrium in the society. We know that in any given society there will be income unequality.

People are not born with the same resources and therefore there will be inequality. And if I happen to be the one who is fortunate enough to have more than what I need, it becomes my duty and it becomes my means to purify my mind by doing charities. So charities are strictly for me and not for others. So when the I perform charities, I must be very clear why I'm performing these charities. So there Bhagavan said that these charities can be seen as three types. Again, Sattvik Rajasik or Tamarsic.

First one says Datvyam is. Very first requirement for an appropriate Sattvik Dha which will give you the most result of what you're looking for. What you're looking for in your life is to purify your mind to a point that it is always in a sunny bright mood and you're always happy. You do not want to be grouchy and unhappy, complaining and regretful. So to keep my mind in that mode, I'm performing all of this. I'm eating right food, I'm doing right yajna, I'm doing right tapas Bhagavan Chandn.

When I do also, I have to keep in mind I'm doing it for me and therefore I should know how to make these charities. So the first requirement is data vyam idhi. I see a cause and realize there is no other way but for me to help them. You are going on a road and you see a little child is just about to get hit by a car. You don't really sit down and say there is Satvik actor Rajasi character. Is it going to be Tamashek?

At that point you have no other thought than I need to help that child get him or her out of the harm's way. So when you do a charity and you have that attitude, it has to be done, it has to be done then that's the right charity. And then when you give that, not by obliging that person as we were going to, actually you should thank him that you are obliging me to giving me a chance. If there's no one to help, who are you going to help? When we were at the old temple that we were having this annadhanam because every Sunday people who come there as you are feeding, who are already fed, it is not Anadanam. It is just a party you are having.

Every week we all get together. When a person needs food and give him food, that's Anadanam. Person is already fed, you can't give him food and say Bhagavan said, I'm not obliging you by doing this charity. Deshe kale cha patre cha ta danam sattvikam smrutam. When it is given at a right time, at a right place to the right person. So if I want to help somebody and that person is now sitting in a group of his friends and then going say you told me that you need help.

Here is my Hundred dollars which you asked for. You are insulting him in front of his friends and families. He didn't want other people to know his problems. He came to you to ask for help and now you're helping him at the wrong place. Well, everybody's sitting and just having a normal conversation. Everyone say I'm going to help you.

Wrong place, wrong time. You should also not help somebody who you know that does not need any help. Sometimes people say I don't get chance to do all this social work. I want to do social work but people are not making me president of this organization. You shouldn't worry about it. The Bhagavad says that Patra only helps someone who really needs help and seeking help.

When you find that opportunity, take that opportunity that is God's given to you. Consider that as God's blessing that you came across this opportunity to help that person and therefore you're helping. Bhagawan says that's a Sattvik dharam. You're not expecting anything out of it. Just like the example of a child in a harm's way. When you help that child you're not expecting anything, not even thank you from anybody.

At that point your only thought is I need to get that child out of the harm's way. It's exact same emotion you should have when you give somebody any help. Adana, that person needs help and I have means I need to help that person. Bhagwan says that's a satvik dhyana yatu prati upakaraartham falam uddi dash vapunah diya te pariklistam tadanam rajasam smrutam. In contrast to that that gift which is given in view to receive return falam uddasha. I'll make this donation and I can get this tax benefit.

And at least people think that he is a good donor. I am doing this charities so it will help my business. So all companies try to we are connected. We give back all that is actually marketing.

What you're looking for in your life is to purify your mind to a point that it is always in a sunny bright mood and you're always happy. Adana, that person needs help and I have means I need to help that person. Bhagwan says that's a satvik dhyana yatu prati upakaraartham falam uddi dash vapunah diya te pariklistam tadanam rajasam smrutam. snippets.sanskrit:
तदित्यनभिसन्धाय फलं यज्ञतपःक्रियाः |

सद्भावे साधुभावे च सदित्येतत्प्रयुज्यते |

यज्ञे तपसि दाने च स्थितिः सदिति चोच्यते |
snippets.transliteration:
tadityanabhisandhāya phalaṃ yajñatapaḥkriyāḥ .

sadbhāve sādhubhāve ca sadityetatprayujyate .

yajñe tapasi dāne ca sthitiḥ saditi cocyate .

Faith can be Sattvic, faith can be Rajasic, faith can be Tamasic, and depending on that, I may be a Sattvic person, a Rajasic person or a Tamasik person, and my understanding of that will help me how do I change my faith so that my thinking changes, so my behavior changes, my mind changes and ultimately gives me the result which I'm looking for, which is in the end is to achieve happiness. You're all looking for one and one thing alone is to get out of our limitations and sorrows. So Bhagavan has described in this chapter the three types of faith and how it controls our Ahara, our Yagna, our Tapa and our Dana. As we have seen last time, it is what we take from this world, how we interact and connect with this world, how we discipline ourselves for what we want and then what we give back to this world, all dependent on my faith.
