If I detect I'm more Rajasya, make it Sattvik. Eventually I can get to my goal of achieving that happiness. So now our question was, well, I may or may not have that capability, and I may be all filled with Rajasic faith and will not be able to change that. So the last three _Verses_ we have seen says there is One way of mitigating that and that we have seen it says that there is a three fold indicator of that transcendental reality, the ultimate reality, the one unifying entity which binds us all, which is indicated in the Sastras is Om Tatsat. Om is the transcendental form of the Lord that I have learned in the previous chapter. The Astadha Prakrithi, Eightfold manifest Prakriti of the Lord.

So everything which I see and perceive and feel is basically nothing but his manifestation. But then I come to the conclusion, maybe if I put everything together that's Lord, or if I put all the parts together, will it make a machine? The question is how you put it together. So all this part putting together does not still make the identity of the Lord. That is something beyond that. Lower Prakriti and higher Prakriti.

I have all these parts and say if I put all this together, it will be the whole. No, it has to be in a particular manner. Then only that machine functions as it's supposed to be functioning. All these parts, I have to put it together and perceive it in a way that it will reveal the Lord's identity. And that's the transcendental part, is how to see this whole in a manner that I can see Him. I see this world in its parts, but I can't put it together as his identity.

That's the Aum, a transcendental part. Om is the indicator of that. And if I can remember that, that all that I see, perceive and things put together, I will never be able to understand Lord. But Om is the reality. My faith may be Rajasek, it may be even Tamasek, but it will transform into Sattvic faith. That's basically a way out given to us by this last three _Verses_.

Om, Tatsat, ITI Nirdeshaha, Brahmanatrivi, Dasmutah. These are the three indicators of of that supreme reality. I know all the parts right now, but I can't put together the machine. I can't put together its real identity. So Aum is the one indicator. Tat we have seen is another indicator.

That is that that which I constantly keep referring to the God, the Lord, that entity other than this which I can perceive, feel, touch and vouch for it, that it exists. That which I cannot vouch for, that it exists, does exist, but beyond my perception. So that's Tat and Sat, the existence or the truth. Truth is that which exists in all periods of time. In other words, it was true yesterday, it is true today and it will be true tomorrow. That is satisfaction.

So these are the three indicators. And Bhagavan said that those who are Brahmavadi Na. One who are completely convinced about the existence of that ultimate reality. They are the Brahmavadina Muriwad Capitalism, Samajwad socialism. Because they're convinced that this is the only way to help the society. By Mudi Vaad, By Samaj Vaad Vaad means I'm completely on side of that.

Those who are completely convinced that Brahman is the only reality. He says they will start all their activities with uttering Om. Utterance means remembrance. It's indication to me that Om is the ultimate reality. I may be perceiving a difference between you and I right now. And therefore I may have developed a liking or disliking for you.

But Om is the ultimate reality which manifest as me. Which manifest as you. As long as I have that thought in the beginning, whatever I do afterwards will be purified. So the smart Om Ithi Udahrutta Yajna Dana Tapaha Kriyaha. We have discussed all that in the previous _Verses_. That activities we are performing in this world are.

We receive from the world. We interact with the world. We connect with this world. We prepare ourselves to how to interact with the world. And then we give back to the world all this which we are doing. First, those who are Brahmavadi Nam.

We see that those who are seeking liberation. I have come to the conclusion that there is no way that in my present state of limitedness the ultimate goal of infinite happiness is possible. I have come to that clear understanding that no matter how hard I try with my mind and intellect and body that unbroken happiness is not possible at all. It's only possible if I can identify with that. That which is unlimited. That which has no limitations.

That which has no sorrows. That which has no competition. That which all pervading. People who are seeking moksha. And we are all Moksha Kanksi bhi. Believe it or not, we want liberation for anything which we think is our limitation.

So all of us who are aware of our limitations and are not very happy with it. If you're happy with it, you're not a Moksha Kangshi being. If I have some limitations by think this is good enough, then I'm not taking liberation. But we all of us have one limitation. Which we can stand is running into a situation which makes me unhappy that I cannot stand. Therefore I'm constantly trying to avoid the things which are creating sorrows and want to pursue the things which gives me happiness.

So at least I want to get rid of that limitations that runs me into this situation which gives me unhappiness. So Bhagavan says those Moksa kanksi bhi who wants to get rid of those limitations they will start all their activities. The same one that Yajna tapa danak kriyaha with Tat Tat anabisandaya falam Yajna tapah kriyaha. They have come to the conclusion that if I remember him as the Karma Falada he is the giver of the fruits. So I leave it to him and do all my activities. For giving me the result, it will give me that liberation.

So we have learned that as Karma Yoga, the last one Sad Bhavai Sadhu Bhavicha Sad Adhi ITI Etat Prayudyate prasaste Karmani Tatha Sat Shabdaha Partha Yudjate. Sat is used in the sense of reality. Sat, as we have said is only that can be proven true in all three phases. In the past, in the present, in the future. Everything else is unreal. It existed one point of time in time and space, another period of time.

It has no existence whatsoever. It's completely gone. Just like a film on a screen or a hologram. It exists in my perception for a period of time. So the lamp is shut off. The word sat is used in the sense of reality and also for goodness.

Now we are coming back to the world which you and I know. Transcendental unlimitedness. The world of good and bad. Our world is divided by good and bad. Bhagavan said the real and the good is indicated in this world as Satan. Sattvaj is as we say, there are values and there are universal values.

There are values may be applicable to me in this situation which may not be applicable in other situations. Well, those are transitory values. I work for a company and what are the values of the company? It only applies to me as long as I am there. But there are values which applies to me whether I'm working or not. Whether I'm working for this company or not or that company or not.

Those are universal values. Therefore we have said even before the civilization started, human beings knew what is right and what is wrong. Even before any religious were established, they knew what is good and what is bad. Those universal good and those universal truth are indicated as satisfaction. It is not dependent on any culture, not dependent on any beliefs, but those are the universal good and universal reality. So Bhagawan said, the word sat is used in this sense of reality and of goodness and also partha.

The word is used in the sense of auspiciousness. Anything which is good is auspicious. And therefore you start that work, same thing, yajna pohadana kriya with that word sat. Then may this be auspicious. May this act of mine be of goodness and of kindness and of reality. So you start with sat.

So obviously in the Sikh tradition, sat word is given the most important satsriyakaal, that sat, which is akal, which is timeless, no beginning, no end. So that sat is uttered by so yagne tapasi dhane chastityhi sat itiucha de. Therefore, if I am the one who is clearly very aware of the good and bad in this world, I divide my world into this is the good world and this is the evil world. This is good for me, this is bad for me. Then I should start all my activities. Bhagavan says, yagne tapasi dhane cha activities remaining the same.

Whether it is my tamasic faith, my rajasic faith, or the sattvic faith, it is what my mind tells me is good, I'm gonna do. No matter how much I tell you this is good for you, as long as your mind does not tell you it is good, you will not be able to follow. Everybody says, do this. Okay, okay, I'll think about. But the thinking part never comes because I have already decided it is not worth thinking. So Bhagavan said, those of us, that's what say yajne tapasidane chasthiti hi.

To be steadfast in my yajnadananda tapa. I do some yajnas, but occasionally yajna, in a sense, some sacrifice. But occasionally I'm not steadfast. I sometimes get all excited and say, I think we should all do some charitman or some kind of a community service. You know, we organize this, and then after about two weeks, everything kind of gradually dies down.

snippets.title: Day 214: Renunciation
snippets.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच |

श्रीभगवानुवाच |

त्याज्यं दोषवदित्येके कर्म प्राहुर्मनीषिणः |
snippets.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca .

śrībhagavānuvāca .

tyājyaṃ doṣavadityeke karma prāhurmanīṣiṇaḥ .
verseTranslations: "Arjuna asked: O mighty One! I desire to know how relinquishment is distinguished from renunciation.
Lord Shri Krishna replied: The sages say that renunciation means forgoing an action which springs from desire; and relinquishing means the surrender of its fruit.
Some philosophers say that all action is evil and should be abandoned. Others that acts of sacrifice, benevolence and austerity should not be given up.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 17 and we concluded chapter 17. We'll be starting chapter 18. Yoga of Liberation through Renunciation. This is the last chapter in Bhagavad Gita, basically the revision or summary. We are going to review all that we have discussed so far in Bhagavad Gita up to chapter 17. From chapter second through 17, chapter one was introduction, setting of a stage, telling us what situation we are in.

We are in Arjuna situation. We face this battle of life and in that we come across situations which are not clear cut. So that was the scenario. And then Bhagavan gave us the whole discourse about why we are so confused. We are confused because our basic fault, as the Christians will call it, a basic sin or basic misconception about ourselves, who we are. We consider this mortal being is me, whereas I, as I consider myself, is imperishable.

We learnt that once you change that paradigm, that this is not me. This body, mind and intellect is not me. I, who I consider I, is the owner of this body, mind and intellect, this body, my intellect. I are the equipment I use to transact with this world. The mortality is for the body, mind and intellect, particularly for the body. When it comes to this life, this life, the body will survive from the birth to death and then it will decay.

But the mind and intellect will continue its journey till it gives up its own attachment and identification. So we have learned in the first six chapters that the basic technique of detaching oneself from this limited self that I am and then attaching the supreme self is Karma Yoga. We have seen that there are two aspects of Karma Yoga. One is doing actions without any expectations for the fruits, then act for the greater good. So these are the two main thing we have learned. They equate it to Tyaga and sannyasa.

So these two words we have heard over and over again in this discourse, Tyaga. We constantly talk about giving up, abandonment of what is what we have to learn, what to give up is what we have to learn Chapter three said Karma Fala Tyaga is the Tyaga. You should give up the expectations of a particular result from your actions is what you need to give up. Then later chapters 4 and 5 talk about renouncing actions in knowledge. Right now I consider I am the doer and therefore I expect the results. Then I become the enjoyer and the sufferer.

If I give up that I the doership then the sufferer and enjoyer also goes away. As long as I consider I am the doer, all the results are binding to me. Because I take the responsibility, I take the ownership of my actions. Then the results which comes in future. Actions are always in present. Results are always in future.

No matter what a time lag is. By the time I speak and you hear and you respond, there is a time lag. It may be a fraction of a second but there is always a time lag. So the actions are always in present, results are always in future. The future is one which I do not have a control over. I only have control of the present.

I can only live in present. I can only act in present. So how do I make myself more efficient? In present is what we have learned in those chapters. Give up the expectations of the fruits. Because I do not have any control over what the fruits would be.

I am not the judge of what the rewards of my accent should be. Even though I have expectation. Karma Phala Datta is always someone else. Whether we consider the Almighty or the world. I go for an interview for a project. All I can do is make presentation.

The result is always in the hand of the selection committee who I have no control over. But all I can do is make myself as efficient and proficient and effective as possible. The Bhagavan said, if you do not think about the results, you will be more efficient. You are not wasting your energy into thinking about what will come out of actions. Then when we talked about the second set of chapters where we have described the Bhagavan's identity, who the Bhagavan is. Then we say Bhagavan has two aspects.

One is Purusha which is the substratum for all things and beings. What we call it a myself. You call it yourself, he call it himself, she call it herself, it call itself that Self is the Purusha which is permeating through all things and beings as existence. And then there is the manifest aspect of the Prakriti which is the myriads of forms and names and colors. And it's constantly changing. And we have Come to learn that that's because of the Maya.

This Prakriti is the manifest world of plurality, is a product of Maya. Maya is that which is not, but appears to be that. In Newtonian physics, the atom looks so solid, but on further investigation, you found there is no solid material in atom at all. There is nothing that we have found so far which is solid in atom, but it does act as a very solid material. Therefore, I can punch this table. If I punch this table, it will hurt because it is very solid.

This, which appears to be real, but it is not, is the product of Maya. And this Maya has three gunas. As we have discussed, this Maya is supported by the three constituent parts, the Sattva, rajas and tamas. The purity, the reality, the truth, Rajas which is the activity, and Tamas, which is inertia. To remain as an entity in space and time in inertia, it has to remain as it is for you and I to pursue it. Satva, rajas and Tamas are the three aspects which govern our life as part of the Prakriti.

So we have now five things we obviously have to focus on. Kyaga and Sannyasa, the means to achieve the ultimate happiness that I am seeking. And then what is binding me to this world. This identification which I have with this body, mind, intellect, is because of the three Guru, Nada, Prakriti, the Sattva, Raja, Santamas. So this chapter, all the concepts which we have learned in various chapters, combines them into one cohesive teachings in how one should use this knowledge to make your life better and achieve your final goal of liberating yourself from unhappiness and sorrows. So just as we have seen previously, Arjuna time and again asked questions to make sure that he understood correctly.

In chapter eight, he said, these are the following terms. You said, you said Brahman, you said Dharma, you said Karma, you said Adhyatma, you said Adhi Devata. Explain to me all this in detail. Then we had this whole discussion in chapter eight, this chapter, he starts with saying, let's make sure that I understood correctly that use two terms, kyaga and sannyasa. They both seem same thing. When somebody says, give up drinking coffee.

And then I say, I renounce coffee, both one and the same thing. I'm just not drinking coffee. There's got to be difference. Otherwise you won't be talking about caga and Sannyasa in two different contexts. So I would like to know. So the chapter starts with Arjuna saying Sanyasasya Mahabaho tattoom ichami veditum.

I want to know about Sannyasa in its essence. And also I want to know about tyaga in its essence. I want to know what is Tyaga and what is Sannyasa. He addresses Krishna with two different Hrishikesha and Keshini Sudhana. Krishna has various names depending on how you see him. So one is Keshini Sudhana, the slayer of demon Keshini.

So for those who have read Mahabharata or Bhagavadpura, Keshani was a demon was sent to kill Krishna in the form of a horse and Krishna slayed him by splitting him into two. So one who basically separates ignorance from knowledge is Keshini Sudhana. He is also called Hrishikesha. Hrishikesha has several meanings. One of the one where they control over the senses. One who is the master of the sense of Hrishikesha.

Others one who has a short hair. So Arjuna addresses him saying Krishna Hrushiki, explain to me what is the difference between Tyaga and Sannyasa so that I am not confused. He talked about giving up things and also renouncing things. If we reflect back, we have talked about Tyaga is Karma fala Tyaga giving him the sense of agency that I am the doer is Sannyasa. We discussed that previously in the Bhagavad Gita. But Krishna now answers it slightly differently and he says Sri Bhagavanu vacha kamyanam Karmanam Nyasam sanyasam kabayo viduhu Giving up desire prompted actions.

Kavi means sage kavi in Gujarati in many vernacular languages. So in Gujarati we say this Vijayana pomoche ravi dhya pomuche kavi in mother where the sun cannot shine. Poet can take his imagination there. So the Kavi in the Vedic time are the people who are seeing the truth and then put it in poetic language. In rug vedas and sama vedas, those who had the vision of the truth, they are the kavis. So the many kavis kava yo ho.

Many Kavis say that giving up desire prompted actions is sannyasa. Desire prompted actions only come in place if it is driven by my ego. If I think I am the doer and therefore I want something out of my action, so those actions are prompted by my self interest. By my ego are the desire prompted actions. So if I give up the sense of agency as I the doer, there Won't be any desire prompted. All actions become for the greater good.

And that's where we have the concepts of offering all the actions to the Lord. If I come to the conclusion, as we have learnt in Bhagavad Gita that all actions are performed by this body, mind and intellect and the qualities of the body, mind and intellect. Because why Neil, you are not the biggest wrestler in town? Is that because I don't have the equipment? I don't have the body to wrestle. Everything which I do in life is depending on what equipment I have.

What is the proper apparatus I have? I like to sing because I have been given a voice which is appropriate for singing. If it was not, I would have no desire to sing. I don't have desire to dance. Because apparatus is not correct. So Bhagavan says that all actions are performed by the quality of your equipment and your senses which is part of this Prakriti.

But I consider them to be my actions by misconception that this is me. If I correct that conception then all actions will not be for me. And therefore they will not be desire prompted. So he says Sannyasa is simply giving up the desire prompted access. Kamyanam Karmanam Nyasa Sarvakarma Falat Tyagam Prahuhu Tyagam Vichakshanah Vichakshanah. Wise people who have observed how this world works and how the actions are performed.

And how the results of the actions are affected by our expectations. You see, those people have said Sarvakarma Falatyagam. Not some I can give up the falatyagam for the actions which are of no value. But all the actions which I perform if I give up the expectation for the fruits. And we have discussed in detail in chapter three what is Karma Faladhyyagam. Karma Falat Yaga is simply not to expect a particular result.

Result will come in the law of nature. Once I perform action, there will be a reaction. As in physics we say it will be equal and opposite.
snippets.reflection:
The Gita's final teaching is surrender. Not passive resignation, but active trust. Having done what you can, release the outcome.

Today, identify one situation where you're holding on too tightly. Practice opening your hands. Let it be what it will be.

Arjuna's journey from paralysis to clarity, from confusion to conviction, is available to each of us. The teaching has been given. What remains is to live it.

snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 18, Moksa Sannyasa yoga, yoga of Liberation through Renunciation. This is a constant theme in our discussion that to enjoy something, you have to give up something. So all throughout Bhagavad Gita you heard these two words, Tyaga and Sannyasa. Our normal connotation is that if I give up something, I lost something. Upanishadhya and Bhagavad Gita constantly telling us, to gain something you have to give up something. You are giving up something because you want to gain something.

When Upanishads like Isha Vasya, Upanishad says Isha vasyam idam sarvam kimcha Jagatyam jagat teyaktena that this world is pervaded by that one single entity. Everything in this world Jagatyam jagat. That which is you see in this Jagat is all pervaded by the same ishava same entity. Tena jakte na banjita. You protect that entity within you by detachment. If you attach to something else, you'll be detached from your own self.

So the main theme of Bhagavad Gita is that you should give up all attachments to enjoy the bliss which you're seeking. That perennial happiness that you're seeking is only can be enjoined by you giving up the attachments to the world of plurality. So we have been discussing these two terms from chapter two onward, which is Thyaga and sannyasa. We have talked about the Tyaga, Sannyasa, same same. Giving up something and renouncing something. I give up my Sansar or I renounce my samsar. Sing the Kamyanam Karmanam Nyasah, Sanyasam Kabayo Vidhu. The sages who have realized the truth in their meditation and contemplation Then give out that truth in poetry.

In the richas, in Vedas they are called kavis. Those who have written poetry. These sages have said that Karmanam Nyasam it is sannyasam. Giving up the desire prompted actions is sannyas. You don't have to give up your clothes. You don't have to shave your head.

You don't have to run away from this world. Bhagavad said the giving up Karmanam Kamya Naam. But then what is tyaga? He says Sarvakarma Farad Tyagam Prahu Tyagam Vichakshanah. Wise people say that giving up the anxiety for the fruits of actions is tyaga. That I have given all my worries to the Karma Phala Datta.

Karma Phala Datta is always somebody other than the one who is acting. I am always the actor in the present. I act, result comes in future is always in somebody else's hand, not in mine. If something which I don't have any control over to worry about it is seems silly. But we do that all the time. So Bhagavan said that one who has given up that anxiety of the fruits of actions is the tyagi.

And then he said some people say that all actions are imperfect. There is not a perfect action in this world. Everything will have a main result and a side effect. It helps other region. I was watching one of those TV channel. Whatever that fish is migrating upward. So now there were less production in USA but more production in Canada. So what is lost for the USA is gain for the Canada. So there's always something which is contrary to what a popularly understood the result of the action is.

So Bhagawan said that some people say that therefore give up all actions because they are all imperfect. They will never give you perfect result. Your goal is to get the perfect happiness in life by working in this world. Even good actions will not Give you the perfect happiness. That's what we say in this class. Doing good is not good enough.

That still binds you to those good results. You feel good about doing something, you want to continue doing it. World doesn't let you do it and now you're mad. So some people say therefore give up all actions. But Bhagavan says no. My opinion is you should not give up Yajna Dana Tapaha Karma, not Yajyam.

And then we have this confusion about what is Yajnadanand Thapa are for. I'm doing for others, I'm sacrificing well, I'm giving it to somebody else. I'm doing charity, I'm doing it for others. So this verse is clarified there for you. Nischayam Srunume Tatra Tyagay Bharatar Sabha, Tyagohi Purusha Vyagraha Trivedha Sampra Kirti Tah. Listen to me conclusively what Tyaga is.

Tyagahi Trividha Sampra Kirti Tah. Tyaga is also of three types. Two things are very common in our discussion in Bhagavad Gita. One is Tyaga and Renunciation. Second is Trigunas, satv, Rajas and Tamas. So Bhagawan said, let me tell you conclusively what Tyaga is.

And also you should know that Tyaga is also of three types of it can be classified in the same way we have classified Ahara Yagna Tapa. All this in previous chapter Tag also can be classified in three. And Swamiji points out that Bhagavan addresses Arjuna as Purusha Vyagara, a tiger among men boosting his morale that you can do it. Yajna Dana Tapaha Karman Karyam Eva Tat Yagna Dana Tapahachayeva Pavanani Manishina. Here comes why Dana is for you and not for others. He said Yajna Dhana and Tapa Karma should not be given up Because Yajna Dana and Tapa are the purifier for wise is a translation even wise.

But actually there is no even word in Sanskrit here for the wise people. Also that continuing education, any profession that we are in, unless you're continuing education, you get stale. So when I was going for my eye surgery, when I subluxated eye lens, my cataract done four years ago, my lens has moved out. It's actually 90 degree. So obviously I didn't feel anything. So I told my first surgeon that I think I want to go with somebody who has a lot of experience who look like me with gray hair. He said, no, no, no, Neil, don't do that. How many surgeries you have done? I said, I'll go with the stale guy, the guy whose knowledge is 10 years old.

So I went with a guy who said I do it routinely for everybody, like six surgery in a month like this. So we also can say that a wise person also can veer off from his knowledge. He used to constantly be on his toes to keep his mind pure. So he said this will only help wise people who are constantly doing this to keep their knowledge pristine. If you're doing yajnadanand tapa and you have no intention of getting any benefit out of it for you, then obviously it's not going to be of any value. But it will help people who are wise enough to know the value of this.

That keeping my mind and intellect pure, I need to constantly be working on it because there are lots of temptations out there in this world. And when I'll sleep off from my wisdom, nobody will know. Therefore I have to be constantly be vigilant about to keeping my mind and intellect, which is my internal instrument pure so that the knowledge can shine through. So therefore he says, yajna dana tapaacha pavanani manishinam. So wise people, they constantly do yajna dana and tapa to keep their internal instrument pure. Now I'm telling you same knowledge. Here he comes and tells Arjuna, this is my best and final opinion for you. Because he realized that Arjuna is probably at a point where he will listen to me more than Vedas and Upanishads. He said, I'm telling you itana pito carmani sangam tyaktva falanicha. Even these actions of yajna danan tapa should be done with sangam tyaktva by giving up attachment and falanicha and giving up fruits. So two things we constantly hear, you have to detach and you have to give up.

Detach from that which is not real, that which is of not any use. So there are now lots of seminars on how to keep your house healthy and happy. Take out everything from your house which you have not used in last three years, last five years, keep it out and keep what you really need. And that will make you happy. The objects which cannot give you happiness. Be detached from that and fala nature and also detached from the expectations for the fruit. Because even doing good, when I have an expectation of something good coming out of, ties me to the anxiety. The Bhagavan said, yajna dana and tapa should be done for one simple reason. So therefore it's a you do not worry about your actions. Give up the attachment to your actions. Whether I could do it or not, did I do it right or not? Let's not get attached to it. And that means which we consider the punya Karma. Papa, Karma are the ones which are giving negative impressions on our mind. They should be avoided anywhere. verseTranslations: It is not right to give up actions which are obligatory; and if they are misunderstood, it is the result of sheer ignorance.

snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 18, Moksa Sannyasa yoga very title implies that liberation will only come from renunciation. In other words, something which we are holding on to is binding us. When whatever that is which is binding us, if we let go, we'll be released. And as we have discussed many times before, this is a summary of the entire Bhagavad Gita or Bhagavad Gita's teachings so far. And all throughout these chapters which we had been discussing, there is a one central theme that either is Sannyasa, renunciation or tyaga Abandonment is the key to this liberation. So the chapter opened with Arjuna's question of what is sannyasa and what is tyaga?

And Krishna explained that Kamyanam Karmanam Nyasahiti Sannyasa giving up all the desire prompted act activity is Sannyasa and Sarvakarma Falathyagam Vidyaga giving up all the desire from the fruits of actions is tyaga. And then obviously Krishna took up the theme of tyaga as the most important thing because at our level sannyasa is probably not possible. Giving up all desire prompted activities is probably not possible at our level because everything we are doing right now is prompted by some desire. Even the things which I consider I'm doing as a community work or something, selfless activities. When you go to the root cause of why you're doing it, there is some desire which is prompting you to do that. There are people who are involved in a lot of organization which are community activity based.

We know they're very active as long as they have a position, a president or a chairperson or a board member or something. And suddenly he loses that position and the person disappears from that organization. All those were selfless activities. It was helping the community, it was helping the people who intended for it was not helping the person who was performing was not selfless for him. It was not directly benefiting him in terms of a monetary gain or any. There was something which was helping his ego and Bhagavan Constantly said tyaga is give up attachment to the fruits of actions.

And therefore that is something which at our level we can understand and we can practice. So he takes up the theme of tyaga and says, there are philosophers who talks about that all actions should be given up. Because they say any action which you perform is binding to you with its results, whether it is good or bad. Good binds you to good results, bad binds you to bad result. When you're bound by the good results, you want it to be repeated over and over and over again. I want to be successful again and again and again.

I go to a Las Vegas and the beginner's luck. First time I go to the, whatever they call it, the slot machine and win some money. So I think that's how it works. Next time also it should work the same way. So we get bound by this good result. And then sometimes we lose our shirt in Las Vegas and then want to avoid that.

So we are bound by the results. And therefore some philosophers, Bhagavan says, says all actions must be given up. You will never be bound by anything. But Bhagawan said, that's probably not possible for us anywhere. Therefore, he says, I recommend the second opinion which says yajna dana, tapah should not be given up. Yajna the offerings, dana the charity and tapas the discipline, austerities, which is what at our level we can relate to it as what we do as yajna is all our efforts in this life is a yajna.

All that we give back to this world as our results of our efforts is adana. And whatever we do to discipline ourselves is the tapas, Bhagwan said, that should not be given up. So the definitive advice from Krishna, as we have seen so far, he says, this is my best in the firm opinion that yajna dhana, tapa should not be given up. And then obviously he says, how to look at this tyagaha? So now our central theme of Bhagavad Gita as we have seen is Krishna's doctrine is the tyaga. And the tyaga defined is Sarva Karma, Falatyaga, Sarvakarma akhila.

Without living any actions, whether it is desire prompted or selfless. In both cases, do not be in anticipation of a particular result. Because as we have seen, even in doing the selfless actions, if we are bound to the Karma phala, then it is binding your ego. So Bhagavan said, perform this yajna dhana tapa but without attachment and without the expectation for the fruits of actions. Swamiji defines attachment as ego plus egocentric Desire is attachment. I have ines and minus, then I have a desire.

So when I come in contact with an object that can satisfy the desire, I'm attached. And I these days constantly talk about how we are attached to a grandchild. You know, because our ego says that's my grandchild. And also it is enchanting. Rather it's fulfilling, enchanting. So we are attached to.

So attachment is ego plus egocentric desire. And as long as that ego and egocentric desires are there, there will be an expectation for fruits of actions. So we are already worried. She is only 20 months old. We are worried what will happen when she grow up. Will she be smart enough to do all these things?

Will she be doctor or an architect? Or will she be something else? Will be artistic or athletic? We're already looking at the results of our efforts in raising her up at overload. The Bhagavan says as long as these two are there, it will be a problem. So he said, perform all this yajnadana and tapa but without attachment in expectation for the results.

So now I think I'm doing the tyaga. I'm giving up some things and then feel good about it that I gave up this thing. Let's see what kind of tyaga is that. So the next three verses says Niyatasyatu sanyasah Karmano na upopady. What should not be given up? He said obligatory duty.

Those which are the Niyata Karmas should never be given up. So we have learnt in the previous chapter there are three types of karmas. Something which you do daily. You are not obliging anybody by doing so. Then Niyata Karma, obligatory duties. I'm a. I'm a doctor, I'm an architect.

I'm a father, I'm an employer. All those roles which I'm playing, it comes with its own duties. They are Niyata Karma. Those are my Niyata Karmas. I have to fulfill their duties. Then Naymithya Karma are special duties, special occasion, special situations.

verseTranslations: But the fool who supposes, because of his immature judgment, that it is his own Self alone that acts, he perverts the truth and does not see rightly.
He who has no pride, and whose intellect is unalloyed by attachment, even though he kill these people, yet he does not kill them, and his act does not bind him.

snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing Chapter 18, Moksas and Nyasa Yoga. Yoga of Liberation through Renunciation. We are at the end of Bhagavad Gita. We have discussed 17 chapters. This is like a work plan we are making for ourselves. What is work strategy?

Work strategy is capabilities plus opportunity is work strategy. So you've seen our capabilities in chapter two, that this self is indestructible, only the body is destructible. And then we have seen what are our opportunities. If we can align with that supreme self versus right now that I'm identified with this limited being called Ego, this body, mind and intellect, then I have a chance to achieve my goal of a perennial happiness, unlimited happiness. Right now because I am identified with this limited self, my happiness is also limited. There are limited capabilities, limited opportunities, therefore limited outcome.

But I do have an opportunity to align myself with the unlimited self, the unconditioned self. Then my opportunities will be unlimited. Therefore I will have the unlimited happiness. That's what we have learned so far in Bhagavad Gita. Now we are making a work plan. So right from the beginning of this chapter we have seen that Arjuna asked question about what is renunciation Tyaga.

From the overall discourse we have come to the conclusion that the only way to achieve the then Moksha, the liberation is by giving up things, not acquiring things by Tyaga and Sannyasa only. So Arjuna wanted to know what is the difference between the Tyaga and Sannyasa? And Bhagavan made it very clear in a very simple term that Karma Phala Tyaga is Tyaga. When I have no desire for particular result from my action, that's Dhyaga. And when I have no sense of agency, I have no desire for desire prompted actions, that's Sannyasa. When I give up the desire prompted action, it's Sannyasa.

And then it seemed like the Bhagawan is veering off on off tangent on discussion about actions. It seemed like we started the discourse on the Sannyasanthyaga. But now we are talking about action. So in last three verses we have discussed, we talked about what constitute actions. See, there are five constituent part of any action, Adhishtana Karta. Then the organs of actions and all the functions of all my organs of actions and perception.

And then the presiding deity, the five elemental forces. These five has to come together for any action to come into existence. So if any one of them is missing, the action will not take place. So if the body is not there, there won't be any action. If ego is not there, there will not be any action also. So we have learned that action requires the five constituent parts.

And now we'll be talking about what is the anatomy of action. So the question is why Bhagavan is moving from discussion on sannyas and tyaga into actions. If you remember, then chapter four. After learning Sankhya Yoga and after learning Karma Yoga, we talked of Gnana Karma Sannyasa Yoga. This sannyasa from the actions is only possible by knowledge about who is the actor, who is the doer. Right now the sannyas is not possible for me as long as I'm identified with the doer.

If I think I am the doer, giving up action is not possible. Should I give up all the actions? As it seems that action is the root cause of all my problems. Action may be appropriate, inappropriate. It gives either a good, bad or somewhere in between result. Why not I get out of completely and say, well let me not act and therefore there wouldn't be any consequences.

By very nature that we are living entities, it's not possible. We have learned that in previous chapters and in this chapter there is not even for a moment that we can stay without action. Nahi Kastchat Kshanama PI Jatu Tishtadhya Karma Krut. The signature of life is action. So as long as I'm alive, I'll be acting. So giving up action is not the solution.

Then what is the solution? The solution is to renounce actions in knowledge. If I take ownership of my actions, then I'm bound by my actions. It is more like filing bankruptcy. If I have a company and I have taken ownership of the company and I have did everything what is supposed to be done and I end up with a huge debt. What is my out from there?

The American law says the only way you can get out of it, file for chapter 11. First you file for chapter 11. Say let me reorganize myself. So everything I have done right now is null and void. Nobody can come, no creditor come and ask for anything for me. And if that doesn't work out, I can reconstitute myself.

I file for a complete bank. At that point, I disown everything that I owned in that company. I'm no more responsible for the functioning of the company nor for the assets. I'm not the owner of the assets and I'm also not responsible for the debt. Now I'm completely free and clear from that. Therefore, we have the limited liability companies.

We want to compartmentalize our responsibility. So Bhagavan said, you can do this. You can file for bankruptcy in your actions. If you disown your actions, if you say I am not the doer then you are not responsible for any of our actions. If I realize that I am not the doer, I, which I consider I right now is actually the conditioned self, the conditioned ego that is identified with this body, mind and intellectual. And therefore I'm responsible for it.

Well, if you're a doer, then as you have learned, out of the five constituent parts of the action, one is the Karta, the doer. That doer is as much involved in the action as the other four. So Bhagavan said, the only way to get out of it is to realize who the actor is. Which is what the Gnanakanama Sanya. I as an I without any superimposition on it. Superimposition is I am an architect.

Well, that's a superimposition on I. I am a father, another superimposition. I am a brother, another superimposition. If I remove all the superimpositions and what remains is I is that I really is a doer. That is the I I'm concerned about wants to be happy. So Bhagavan said that we need to understand what constitute actions. Then also now we have to understand where our misunderstanding is.

So from these previous verses we have concluded this action belongs to Prakriti, the manifest world. We also Learned in chapter 13. Prakruti is cause for the Karya and Karan action and the cause of actions. But Purusa, Sukhadu Khana Boktrutvi Hetuhu ucha de. But Purusa is the enjoyer of Sukha Dukha Prakriti. My nature in the nature of the world of objects creates this action.

Because I have a vasana for singing, I go to music concert. So this is the interaction between the world of objects and my vasanas. They are all part of this Prakriti. But I, the self is not really involved in it. I as an I has no vasanas, no conditioning. And therefore it's not in war.

If I fail to recognize, Bhagavan said, then you are the doer. As an ego, you're fully involved and vested in that and you will bear the results of it. Tatra evam sati kartaram tmanam kevalam Tu yaha pashati akrut buddhihe. Whose Buddhi is not trained in thinking finer points about what is right and what is wrong, what is reality and what is non reality. Sa pasyati durma tehi. Such a person's mind is perverted.

Perverted in essence is not seeing the reality as it is and getting affected by the wrong notion of what reality is. Dhurma tehi akrad buddhi. Why these words are used? Because he says, because you are seeing. Tatyaam siddhi kartaram atmanam kevalam to yahu consider atma itself to the doer. One who sees that atma is the doer, he's wrong.

Because he does not have the finer intellect to realize what is right and wrong. Also he is influenced by wrong mati. His mind is tilted, polluted by vasanas, his intellect is clouded and therefore he does not do who the doer is. Because we elaborately analyzed and came to the conclusion that the action is only taking place in the realm of the Prakriti and the Purusha is not involved at all. The universal Purusha is not involved. We have used this example over and over again.

The space in this room is not participating in any activity of this room. But because we are identifying it with the walls, floor and ceiling, it becomes a room space. Now it is all the qualities of this room. Height, length, breadth, air polluted in it, clean in it, light there, darkness. All that is associated with this room is actually the conditioning superimposed in the space which was always here, is here and will always remain here. When you remove this building, the space will go back to its original condition.

But it was unpolluted, pristine space. That space is not taking part in any of the activity of this room. The same way the self in me which enables me to do all these activities when it is seen as unconditioned, is not taking any part in. But it seems it's taking part. Because I'm identifying it with my mind, my intellect and my body. Now I'm thinking That I, the conditioned self is the only self and he's the doer bhagwant.

That notion is wrong and therefore we are suffering. So this verse clearly says you need to differentiate between who is the doer and who are you. Are you the conditioned self, the ego? Or you are the unconditioned self, that which is imperishable, indestructible. Yasya na aham kruta bhavah buddhi Yasya na lipya de hatwh iman lokan hanti na ni badyade. So we are coming back to what we want to know.

How should I act in this life? He said, you act as you have to. Because once you understand that yasya naham kuta bhavaha once you realize that I, the self is not the doer, not taking any part in action, I'm just a saxichaitanya. I'm just the enabler. Welfare check comes to the person who is receiving welfare. That check will enable that person to go and buy whatever necessities he has.

What he buys is entirely up to that person. We have heard complaints about people on welfare. Use the welfare checks to go and buy beer or whatever, the alcohol versus buying food. But because that is according to him, welfare department only sends you a check, enables you to buy things in your grocery store. After that, it is entirely up to you how you use that. This life in me is enabling me to act.

But it's not taking part into what field I'm acting in. That comes from my vasanas, my mental makeup, my intellect capabilities in my body. That's how I find my field. So Bhagavan said, yasya na aham kruta bhavah. One with his finer intellect came to the conclusion that I am not the doer. Such a person Buddhi Yasyana Lipyate whose intellect is not clouded by all the experiences of my life.

So right now my Buddhi is clouded by what I experienced. Before pressing on my mind. That impression created what the reality is. So next time when I encounter the similar situation, I'll use that as a reference point and then act accordingly. Some people who start investing in one field get successful in first venture. He continues to do that and he has more positive attitude.

Next guy who does the same thing but fails the very first time, he'll have a negative impression of what to do in that field.

snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 18, moonkanish Sannyasa yoga Yoga of Liberation through Renunciation. So, as we have discussed before, the whole exercise in Bhagavad Gita is to renounce actions in knowledge. We have figured out that the actions are the cause for all my frictions and unhappiness in life. Any action which I perform, whether good, bad or ugly, will have its result. And the result will be either conducive, not conducive, or somewhere in between, mixed. And in this chapter, Bhagawan clarifies that that only applies to a Tyagi, one who has not given up expectation for the fruits.

In this chapter we'll learn the definition of a Tyagi. One who gives up the Karma Fala Tyaga is a Tyagi. The one who gives up all the desire prompted actions is a Sannyasi. I can only give up all my desire prompted actions if I have no desires. At this point, it does not seem that I can reach that point where I hold no desire. So then the exercise is how can I solve this conundrum?

One hand it says the only way you can be free if you have no desires. On the other hand, it clearly seems that living without desires is not possible. It does seem like there is something we are missing out in this equation. That if both are possible then there got to be some kind of a parallax which I have to remove so I can see the truth as it is. And it is something which we have learnt in Vedanta. That same thing can be seen in two different lights.

A rope can be seen as a rope if I'm clear what it is. But it also can give a rise to fear that it's a snake. So the same thing, depending on my mental association, I can create the rope or I can create a snake. Similarly, it seems like because I can't reconcile these two, on one hand Gita keeps telling me to leave without any desires and other hand I see that the desires are unavoidable. It seems like that there are two different People who can achieve this. One who cannot live without desires and one who has no desires.

So to understand that, we have obviously taken this study of Bhagavad Gita. And now we are coming to the conclusion that there are two I. The one I is a conditioned I which is conditioned by my body, my mind, my intellect, associated with my body, my mind, intellect and therefore that I has all the limitations of my body, my mind and intellect. But then there is one I which is always there. No matter whatever the condition of this body, mind, intellectual, body was a baby, then it was a child and then it was a young man and then it was the adult and now it's the old man that I remained the same. So there must be a differentiation between the I which I consider I when I think about my body, my mind, my intellect and that which has no conditioning.

When I remove all the conditioning when I will not be there as this conditioned eye that I will still remain as we learnt in Bhagavad Gita chapter 2, that I is indestructible and the metaphor we use all the time in the room space. Room space is conditioned by its limitations of the size and shape and the type of air in it. Right now once this walls, floor and ceilings are gone the space will remain what it is. So we have learnt in chapter 13 that there is a field and it's knower. As long as there is field, I as the knower will limit myself as the knower of the field. So in this chapter we have started our journey by saying let me define what is Tyagi and what is Sannyasi.

It does not give up the Karmaphalas. Because Karmaphalas are not in his hand. Karma Phala is something Karma Phala Datta. Someone other than me gives me the fruits of my actions. But I want to influence that outcome by my desires. That I want this particular outcome.

That if I give up influencing the outcome by my desires then I will be Karma Falathyagi. If you know this, then the next thing you need to know is that any kind of results which come from your actions are not binding to you. Because you did not expect any result out of it. Whatever comes you accept with the Prasad Buddhi. Just like when you go to the temple and you accept Prasad, you don't really are choosy about what comes in your prasad. Whatever Panditja gives you, accept it with love.

When whatever comes out of my actions is the result, I should accept that. Just as I accept Prasad from Bhagavan. If I develop this Sense Bhagavan said that you will be tyagi once you disassociate this limited I, you will not have desires. That I will not have desires. The smaller I will have desires. The body will have its own demands, mind will have its own demands and intellect will own demands.

For one who is overseeing the three will have no demands whatsoever. It is now up to me to identify either with the lower eye or the higher eye. So we have learned from the beginning that giving up actions is not possible. Therefore, whatever action you perform should be ordained action. Those even when I am performing, I should be not attached. It should be performed without any Ra, without any asakti, without any expectation and any attachment.

I should be performing this action. That's the advice we've heard so far. Then Bhagavan got into the discussion of what is action. Because we need to understand what is action. So we understood that action has five components. Unless those five come together, action never takes place.

So in this five component, one is Karta is the actor. You have to have an actor or an action to come into being. And that's the only one I have control over. Then I need to now define who the Karta is. And that once I figure out, then I will be able to figure out whether I am the sufferer, the enjoyer of my actions or not. Because the Karta is the Bhokta of all the actions.

So in the following _Verses_ we have seen that one who considers that this self is the doer, he does not see the truth alone. Because the truth is the self is not acting at all. In all these actions which I am performing, the self remains as just a witness. Because actions are performed by the gunas of my body, mind and intellect. The nature of my mind, nature of my intellect and nature of my body decide what type of actions I'll perform. When the conducive objects come in my way, I get tempted to act and then I act.

Gnanam, gneam, parignata, Trivedaha, Karma, Chodana. These are the propellers of my actions. Gnanam, knowledge, Gnayam the knowable and Pariganatha the knower. So this is basically going back to chapter 13. In chapter 13 we are seeing there is a field and its knower. So when this gnanam, when there is a knowledge of the field occurs, that's the knowledge.

Once I figure out this is the field of my activity, may I identify the field of my activity. Then the knower comes into being. As long as I'm aware of the field, I become the knower of the field. So this three when the knower of the field identifies the field and when that knowledge takes place the gnanam that becomes the propeller of my action. Starbucks is the field of my knowledge. Passing by I identify Starbucks.

A field of knowledge is there and my knowledge has taken place. The Starbucks is there. I as the knower of the field will have the desire to have a cup of coffee. That knowledge of the field by the knower is the propeller of action. As long as I'm identified as the knower of the field constantly associating with the field that knowledge will create the impulse in me to act in this world. So that's clearly Bhagawan said you should understand that the knower of the field minus the field is just the knower.

Knowledge of the field minus the field is just the knowledge. So that knowledge is I exist in my deep sleep. I have no other knowledge but I still know that I exist. So when I wake up and somebody asks what kind of sleep? You say I had a very nice sleep. I said I don't know, I just had a good sleep.

There is no other experience but just I exist in the experience. The Babawan said know how these actions work. When the field comes in contact with the knower of the field when knowledge takes place that knowledge will be the propeller of your action. And then he says Karanam Karma Karta ITI Trivedha Karma Sangrah what will preserve the action? Three things to come together. Karanamdhi instrument of action.

I see a nice house in a good neighborhood. I really want to buy this house. But then I figure out do I have the means to buy the house? If I don't have the means, all that good idea about that house and my desire to buy that house remains just a dream and a desire. I will put that into action. If I have the means to perform that action that is Karanam.

When the Karana When I have the means, the equipment to perform this action and Karta then the doer. If there is no doer I will have all the means and I have all the desires But I am not available to perform that action then also that action won't come into existence. So these two has to come together. The Karanam and Karta has to come together to karma to take place. We are analyzing what is the impulse of the action or how the action come into being. Because at the end of this discussion we're going to find out what control I have on my action.

We are coming to the conclusion that the person that I really have control over is the Kartha. If I don't have that doership Bhav that notion that I am the doer then no action really takes place. So that I, which we call it the conditioned I Jivatma is thinking that he is the doer. Not only is thinking he is the doer, he is the only doer. When I perform any action and it is successful I feel that I did it and I did it all by myself. There was no help from anybody else.

This is where Bhagavan says you are going wrong. That you think you are the doer and you are the only doer. If I think that I have the control over my actions and I perform my actions then obviously I have a particular result in mind. Because I think I'm performing it correctly. I'm performing right field. The result must be X, Y or Z.

We forget that for any action I have to perform the field of action has to be appropriately configured to drive from my home to here. The whole field of action which is my road from my house to here has to be completely clear. All traffic lights have to work perfectly. All other drivers should drive in the proper lanes. Unless all that come in property configuration I wouldn't be able to come here in time. So when I consider that I did everything myself to come here in time, I'm actually wrong.

There are so many people have to do so many things for me to be here on time.

verseTranslations: The intellect which does not understand what is right and what is wrong, and what should be done and what not, is under the sway of Passion.
And that which, shrouded in Ignorance, thinks wrong right, and sees everything perversely, O Arjuna, that intellect is ruled by Darkness.

snippets.commentary:
We've been discussing chapter 18, Moksa Sannyasa Yoga. Yoga of Liberation through Renunciation. The goal is liberation and the tool is Sannyasa. Liberation is always from some bondage and normally we think the bondage is always imposed on someone else. In this case, Bhagavad Gita says the bondages are imposed by my own self. I myself has imposed these bondages on me by identifying with this material body, material self, that equipment which I used to transact with this world, I falsely understood it to be me.

snippets.commentary:
Chapter 18, Moksha Sanyasa Yoga. This is obviously the last chapter in our studies of Bhagavad Gita. So we had been systematically studying Bhagavad Gita. The goal of that is to figure out how I should act in this world so that I can get the maximum happiness. So we have first understood who we are in the Bhagavad Gita as individuals, how we function in this world. And then we have also talked about who is that?

Who has the control over this entire universe and therefore also over my life. We are coming to the end portion of the Bhagavad Gita. We are synthesizing this knowledge about who we are at the individual level. What is my relationship with this world and the Supreme Being? But the bottom line still remains, how can I be happy? So in this chapter we are analyzing the factors affecting my actions and the outcome of my actions.

So in the beginning, Arjun asked what is sannyas and what is thyaga? Because in all this discussion I picked up these two words which ultimately lead to happiness, ultimately leads you to liberation, freedom from all the sorrows and unhappiness. So I want to understand these two concepts so I can find out how I can act in this world. Number one, very simply said, giving up all desire prompted actions is Sanyas. If you can reach a point where you don't have to do anything to satisfy your desires, then you are a sannyasi. That can only happen when I have exhausted all the desire.

There is no desire left. Therefore I don't have to act for my desires. That can only happen if I have no ego and no individual identification. Sarva Karma Falatyagama stagger. That seems like the goal one can strive for that I can probably work on Tyaga part. But because the Tyaga can be misunderstood, giving up, abandoning something can be misunderstood.

We went into discussion about this. Tyaga also can be of three types. This Prakriti has three qualities. So anything which is associated with the Prakriti will have the same Triguna used example before that every gold ornament will have the same ingredient of gold. Gold ornaments also come in different carats. 18 carat versus 16 carat, 12 carats 24 carat.

I think what that means is there is something else is mixed into gold. You cannot make an ornament out of pure gold. They have to add zinc. It is the proportion of that metal can change. But every gold ornament will have those at a golden zinc, which makes it more malleable, more workable. It is the proportion which makes it the 12 carat vs 18 karat vs 24 karat is also like that.

The first thing come to mind is I should give up all my actions. So we reaffirm that action cannot be given up by anybody. It is not possible for a living being to completely abandon all actions. Therefore, now we need to understand what actions to be abandoned. In the beginning, Bhagawan gave an indication desire prompted actions. So what actions should I perform?

Yajna Dana Tapa should not be given up at any cost. The actions which are purifying your mind and intellect, they should be performed. And then we talked about the anatomy of action. Because we are going to be focused on actions all our life. And we are going to be focusing on how I should act in the right manner and what actions are to be abundant. Or we looked at three propellers of actions.

The knowledge, Gnanam, Gnem, Parignatha, the knowledge, the knower and the knowable. We also seen the Karanam, Karma, Karta, iti, Trivedha, Karma, Sangraha. Action only comes into the existence. If these three are there. The instrument of action, the doer, then the Karma. Then we analyze that Gnana Karmanakarta also can be of three types.

Anything which is part of the Prakriti will have the same three ingredients in different proportions. Gnana, Karma and Karta also the three types. We also say the Buddhyana, Dhruti. The foundation of any action, my intellect and my fortitude. Basically make any action possible or success in any action possible. Even those two also can come in three different varieties.

And in the end our goal was to get Sukham, happiness or Ananda. See this Sukha also can be three types. Sattvik, Sukha, which is at the beginning seems like a poison. But in the end it is like a nectar. Work hard to get somewhere. But when you get there, there is joy there.

So that's a Sattvik sukha. It seems good in the beginning, but in the end it gives pain. That's a rajasik suga. So the pleasures in life which we pursue, they are like Rajasik sukha. It gives you some joy, but in the end it gives you unhappiness. Even going to vacation every time you come back, I'm tired, I can't do anything.

I need a vacation from my vacation, you know. So every pleasure which we seek in the end it ends them into some kind of a misery. So the bhagawan says, that's Rajya Sikh sukha. It starts as very pleasant, ends in unpleasantness. This tamasik sukha is. It is not enjoyable in the beginning, is also not enjoying in the end.

Scratching when we start, it's not really that pleasant. And after you are done with it, it is also very painful. This is why Bhagavan said, that's a tamasikshu. And then we are coming to the segment where Bhagavan said, therefore now understand that everything in this Prakriti is made up of these three gunas. So human beings are also affected by these three gunas. These three gunas affect all the people we come across and ourselves.

And based on those gunas, they can be also classified into Sattvik, Rajasic and Tamasic. But we may get confused. The Bhagawan makes it clear that everybody understands that it is not possible for anything or a being in this Prakriti to not have any one of these three gunas. All three gunas have to be present for a thing or being to exist in space and time. So something to exist in space and time, it has to inertia. Without inertia, the thing just cannot.

Otherwise it vanishes the time it's created. You know, somebody give an example. I think as an MB who gave a story of Brahmaji when he first created this human being. They all completely sattvik. He said as soon as Brahmaji created, they all went back to their true nature. So he said Brahmaji was really baffled.

How can I keep this thing stable? The inertia tamas makes things remain in this time and space. But the thing also cannot remain what it is. And it rajast with activities. We now know from science that even atom which seems stable has intense activity in it. All electrons are circling around that neutral proton.

And the thing needs to know that I exist, which is Sattva. So Sattva raja santamus I exist, I act and I remain in my place. These three are absolutely necessary for anything or being to be in existence. So the verses which we are coming to now says for our own clarification that Na tad asthi prithivyam va divi deveshu va punah Sattvam prakritei muktaha yat yabhi sha tribhigan on this earth and also in the heavens among Devas, there is not a single being who is free from all these three gunas. So thinking yourself without these three gunas is not possible. But at the same time we keep hearing Bhagavan keeps saying Guna teet Bhava Arjuna.

We probably understood that I should go beyond this guna, so I should get rid of all three gunas. Bhagawan said that is not possible. You can stop identifying with this Guna. So my mind is working in Tamasic mode or Rajasic mode. I should be able to introspect and say it's my mind which is a rajasic mode. If I can make him go to Sattvic mode, it will be more comfortable.

But if I identify with my mind, am I obviously identifying with my mind and intellect? So you can be Gunati the only if you're not identifying with your limited self. So Bhagavan said, be clear that these three gunas are present in all beings, divine beings and also the mortals on this planet. They all are affected by these three gunas. And therefore all humanity and all beings can be classified into Sattva, Grajatika, Tamasik depending on their predominant qualities. Brahman, Kshatriya, Vishyam, Shudranamcha, Parantpa, Karmani, Pravibakthani, Swabhava, Prabhavai Gunai.

This is basically a clarification for all of us who have this confusion about what is this caste system. Bhagavan created Brahman, Vishyanshudra and therefore now you are bound by this divisions. It clearly says that Karmani, Pravibakthani, Swabhava, Prabhavai Gunaihe. Their duties are divided among this Brahmakshatriya, Vaishna Sudra for their own nature, Prabhavayi Gunai hi. According to their own nature, their duties are determined for Brahma, Vaishya, Kshudra and Kshatriya. So it is your own nature which makes you Brahman or Kshatri or Shudra or Vaishya.

Bhagavan makes it Clear here it is not by birth, not by association, not by caste, creed, color, texture of your mind and intellect. Your gunas will make you the Brahma Kshatriya, Vishya, Sudra, Shamah, Damah, Tapaha, Shaucham Kshantihi, Arjamam, Evacha, Gnanam, Vignanam, Astikyam, Brahma Karma, Swabhavajam. First he said their duties in life are attributed to them in according to their own nature. You have to give person work or his place in your company, in your society and community what his aptitude is for. That's why I think before going to college you take aptitude test even in a company. Also the two engineers come.

One may be more research oriented and other may be more practical oriented. You put them in right place. In our profession it is much more clearer that we are all architects. But some are more design oriented so they can design, some more creative. Some are more technical minded so they can put things together in a building a little better. And some are more into administrative.

Make sure that things are done right. So we used to have three divisions in companies. There used to go to design department, Production department and Construction Administration department. Suppose more glamorous because it's creative. But depending on your aptitude, you end up going from one to the another. Now sometimes even if you don't have aptitude, you think because design is more glamorous, I want to go there.

But then you would be miserable because you won't be able to perform your task properly. Eventually you end up going where your aptitude is whether you like it or not. Bhagawan said that the duties are distributed among them according to their own gunas. Now how do I know what gunas Bhagavan says know what Brahmana's qualities are? Shamaha, control over the mind, mental control, Shamah Dhammah, physical control, control over your senses, Tapaha austerity. Any discipline which you follow, Shaucham, purity, Shantihi, forgiveness, Arjvam, straightforwardness.

Whatever it is, you can see clearly Gnanam, Vignanam, knowledge and also Vignanam applied knowledge, the application of knowledge, Astikyam, faith in the underlying truth. That this world has its basis. We have learnt in Bhagavad before that those people who are of a devilish qualities, they think there is no basis in this world. The Bhagawan says the Astikyam that faith in their underlying truth, the underlying reality in this nature Brahma Karma Swabajam. This comes naturally to Brahmins in other words, the people who have these qualities are the Brahmins. Now you identified you are that person.

You ask him to run a business. Obviously he is not good at it. So you can't really put somebody in charge of something he is not good at.

snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 18 and we have so far analyzed the actions, knowledge and the actor. Now, as we have seen, everything is kind of classified into three classes depending on the qualities of the actions, knowledge or the actors. Now we are going into the classification of human beings. We also classified the Sukha, the happiness or the pleasure which comes from your actions. Actions are performed for as we said and discussed many times for two purposes only. One is to gain happiness and other is to avoid unhappiness.

There are actions we perform simply to make sure that there is no sorrow. Your retirement planning for avoiding sorrow in the future, when I'm not working, I'm not able to work. I need planning for my retirement. That's for avoiding unhappiness. But I am accumulating money to buy a BMW to get happiness. So there are two reasons we work in this world.

We have identified those. The happiness that comes out of these actions can also be either sattvic happiness. It may take very painful efforts in the beginning, but in the end it will be like nectar. Or it will feel like nectar now, but in the end it turns out to be more painful. Or the last one we have seen is something which in the beginning it is painful, in the end also painful. But I do it because I think that's the only way I can get some comfort.

So now why people act in this manner? The next few verses which we will see said, we are all driven by our qualities. So Bhagavan vastu, pravartate, Beings and things in this world are driven by their own qualities. So if you ask me to go for football match, no matter how hard you try, unless there is some other temptation you give, I won't go to football match. As I said when I was in Dallas, we will have all the social party football matches. The temptation was all the socializing and the food and friends.

Football was least of my concern because it's not in my nature. But you have a music party. I will stay hungry if I need to sing. Obviously you can't really sing with a full stomach. So I'll be the last one to eat while everybody has left. Because I want to make sure that I am at my best when my Tron comes to sing.

So I'm sacrificing something for which my own nature says it's pleasurable. So the next few verses it says. nastih prathivyam vyam va divi deveshu va punah sattvam prakruti jai Muktam Yadebhi sat tribhirgunaih. Now first thing they say, well, if I understood all that, I'm going to get rid of all the Tamas. I'm going to get rid of all the Rajas. I'll be just Sattvik.

Bhagavan said, it is really not possible that there is no being on this earth or again in the heaven. It's our conception that we are the mortal beings on this planet earth and they are immortal beings or devas are in the heaven. These Devas, even you know, Purana says they also have their qualities. Some devas are angry, some manipulate, some do this, you know, that's all the Pura Puranic stories. So it says, there is no being, whether a human being or a divine being, Deva, who is totally liberated from the three qualities. One cannot get rid of these three qualities totally.

Because once you liberate from these Gunas, you're out of the Prakriti, you're out of Maya. These three gunas are the characteristics of Maya, the Prakriti, the manifest world. As long as you are part of the manifest world as a being, these three has to be there. All these three has to be there to make you a being in this world. Therefore, Bhagavan said, there is no being on this planet or anywhere else in this universe who can be liberated completely from these three gunas. The day you transcend all three gunas, there is no Gita class, there is no you, there is no I.

This is not a social commentary on Indian caste system. Bhagavad Gita was not written after the caste system was already has been completely polluted by whatever the social thinking, all the historical influences. So this is not a social commentary. So let's not get confused with what happened in India for last fully few thousand years on the caste system or Varanashram, it simply says Brahmanakshatriya, Vishyam, Shudranamcha, Parantapa Karmani, Pravibhaktani, svabhava, Prabhaivi Gunehi.

Whatever the predominant quality in being, their karmas are assigned accordingly. If my aptitude is to sing, but then you say no, there is no singing here. You're going to dance today. Obviously that's not really something I can do. And that happens to me all the time. We go to a party and then everybody starts dancing.

And I'm the one who has no real interest at all. But why you are not dancing? Because I don't like dancing. That's why I'm not dancing. So Bhagavan said that each one's actions karma is assigned as per the predominant Gunas. The Brahman, Rakshatriya, Vaishyam or Rakshudra.

Now these classifications are not based on what we understand today based on the Gunas. And we tend to conveniently forget the Bhagavan is already said in the Bhagavad Gita, Chaturvaranam, Maya Shrushta Guna, Karma, Vibhaga Saha. Depending on their gunas, their qualities and their actions. I have created four types of people in this world. I'm not a Brahmin and you are not Akshudra. All these people have own tendencies and the work is distributed in the society according to their qualities born of their own nature, not just somebody instilled by force. Says Bhagavad Gita makes a statement of facts how we understand this fact and utilize or misuse our shortcomings and ignorance. So the next verse says Shamah damah Tapaha Shaucham shanti arjavam Gnanam Vignanam Astikyam Brahma Karma svabhavajam Long list. And those who have done that, they are the Brahmanas. In any society the next we say is Sauryam Tejo Dhrutihi Daksham Yudde Chapyapalayanam Dhanam Ishwara Bhavasta, Kshatram karmasu bhavajam. And also not fleeing from battle, battle of life. Some of us run away from any situation when it is threatening and some will face head on. The quality of Kshatriya is to face that situation head on. snippets.commentary:
Chapter 18, moonkanish Sannyasa Yoga. Yoga of Liberation through Renunciation. And we have discussed what this chapter is all about. Whether you can see it as a summary or the final recommendations. You can see it like William Barr's four page summary of 400 page Muller's report. You're trying to make the sense out of it without reading the whole 400 pages.

Before you heard this argument about what is right, one party says it completely exonerate Trump and other parties. There are some issues here.
