But if you read the entire Bhagavad Gita from chapter one through 17 and then read chapter 18, it should make sense to you. So what we have discussed so far is in Bhagavad Gita, the recommendations are made for your betterment, for your growth, for your happiness in general.

We have realized that in this world there are people who are different from each other. But each one is striving for the one and the same goal, which is to achieve happiness. Not only just the happiness in a finite term, but infinite term. I want to get happiness which never ends. So we all learned who we are at this limited self, what is our identity, what when we identify with the supreme, and how can we remove this parallax between the limited self and unlimited self to achieve that infinite happiness. So this chapter now brings it back to our attention that what we have discussed.

So what we have discussed so far is working in this world is absolutely necessary. In this world you will not be able to stand still without acting anything because of our experiences, that anytime I get involved in something and there are conflicts and there are frictions, and therefore it creates unhappiness. Maybe I should stay away from all these things. But once that's not the answer, because you just cannot stay without doing anything. So therefore understand what action is all about. You should not give up actions, but act in accordance with the advice in the Sastra which says that there are actions which are forbidden actions.

It is not that you and I have to invent the will all over again every time. We have the wisdom of our ancestors, our civilization, our culture which tells you that stay away from this. This is not going to help you. Just like you tell a child, don't put finger in the fire, you're going to get burnt. Don't put finger in the electrical outlet, you'll get shot. You don't have to try it out to see whether it works or not.

So the Nidya Karma are forbidden. So that you don't get burnt, you don't get completely destroyed. Now what is left is Niyata Karma. In Naimitya Karma, my daily duties and my special duties, those Bhagavan said you should do it with an attitude of non attachment and thou shall achieve your goal of getting happiness. That's basically a simple advice in the beginning. But then the question occurs that we are all of different temperaments and we all have different goals.

We act in different fields. Is it really applied to all of us or only apply to the great evolved people who have understood all this philosophy of life? And Bhagavan come to the conclusion, a guideline that no. It applies to all of you. Whether you are at the top of the pyramid or at the bottom of the pyramid in the society. Therefore, we have discussed the four types of people.

This classification which we have just learned in previous verses says there are four types of people. They are defined by their own nature, their own gunas. It does not say that because you are a Brahmana, these gunas are yours. Because you have these Gunas, you'll be considered a Brahmana. You should consider yourself a Brahmana because you have these following gunas. Bravery, valor, brightness, Lordliness.

Then you should be Kshatriya, not other way around. Because you are a Kshatriya, you should have these qualities. Because you have these qualities, you are a Kshatriya. And then because you have these qualities, you are a Vaishya or a Kshatra. It did not say that one class is more important than other. He said it's applicable to all of you.

The advice given in Bhagavad Gita, whether you are at the lowest rank, at the Shudra level or the Brahmin level, it all will apply to you. So last time somebody asked me, can you make a reference to the Purusha Sukta in Riga Veda. So in Purusha Sukta the same idea is explained. Purusha Sukta starts with Sahastra, Sirisa, Purushaha, Sahastraksha, Sahastrapad. This Purusha is envisioned, is the universal being. If the entire creation is one being, then how will you view it?

Or the sage who saw this universe as one being, he saw him as a being with thousands of eyes and thousands of legs and thousands of mouths. Very similar to what we have learnt in Bhagavad Gita in that vishwarupadas in chapter 11. So he said, this Purusha is everywhere. Sabhumim, Visvatovratva, atyatistha dash Angalam. He's enveloping the entire universe and is spreading in all ten directions. We have discussed before eight cardinal directions.

Northwest, east, south, northwest, southwest, southeast and northeast. Then eight up and down, 10, he's extending in all 10 directions. And then the question asks, what about his limbs? Brahmano mukha Asita. The first time you hear this Brahmano, Ashya Mukha, Asith, Brahmanas are his mouth. This universal being in his self is envisioned as what coming out of his mouth is Brahmanas.

So Brahmana, the knowledge speech, what we see is Brahmana, Asya Mukham, Asith, Bahuhu, Rajanya, Kritaha. His arms are made up of Rajanya, Kshatriyas, Uru tadasyat, Vaishyah. His thighs are made up of Vaishyas and Padyam Shudrajaya and his feet are made up of Shudras. The shudras constitute his feet, Vaisyas constitute his thighs, Kshatriyas constitute his arms and Brahmanas his mouth. This being cannot be complete if any one of them. You remove the complete picture of the Supreme Being.

It cannot be complete if you just take the Brahmanas and say other three are not necessary. He is who he is because all four parts. And then it continues and says Nabya Asid Antariksha. His navel forms the space between the heaven and the earth. Sishnav dyo Samovar Tathaha, his head sustained in heaven. Padma Bhumir Disaha, your feet are sustaining the earth.

Nakshatra, Tatha, Lokan Akalbayan and his ears the directions. So basically this one single entity is viewed as encompassing every part of the society, every part of our universe. So it's not the intention of the writer of this Purushaktam to put anyone down or so. But basically saying this system just cannot function unless there are all four types of people at any given time, at any given place, in any given society. So therefore we have discussed in this that there are four types of people. You may fall in any one of them depending on your qualities. But if you understand yourself where you stand, at least at your level. This Bhagavad Gita is for the self unfoldment for individuals self development. Therefore, if you understand so the next four verses from 45 through 48 are actually the essence of how to be successful. So if we forget the entire message of Bhagavad Gita, but understand these four verses and contemplate on it and practice Bhagavan guarantees that you will be a happy person and you will be a successful person. These verses are applicable to all four classes of people. Not just for the Brahmins, and not just for Kshatriyas or Vaishyas, but even Kshudras, all four of them.

If they can stick to this formula of success, then success is guaranteed. That's basically what these four verses are all about. Verse 45th, which we have seen, says. The first statement of fact devoted to one's own duty. A man attains perfection. Perfection should not be taken.

Is realization that now I have realized what myself is. Whatever the field you're practicing, if you stay within your own nature, you will achieve perfection in that. If I'm a sweeper, if I focus into it, I'll achieve perfection. They always wonder, well, all these people who have this garbage collection company, I mean, at some point the guy had some interest in garbage collection. Right before he became big businessman. Has lots of trucks running around all over Richmond.

You can't suddenly get interested into garbage collection. I actually had a client one time with one of this recycling business, just passing through his yard, all junk all around it. Then you go to his office, which is an air conditioned. Nice little office, nice little conference room. Bhagavan said, wherever you feel comfortable, according to your own dharma. If you follow the actions. If you perform actions in your own field of interest. Sansiddhim Labate Naraha person gets success. That's as simple as that. If I try to do something which is not my nature, I may get some success here and there.

But I'll never get full success. I tried developing some hotels and lost my shirt. But designing hotels I do very well. So after I lost all my investment, I said, let me go back to what I do best. Keep designing for other people. I can give advice to other people.

Where to build hotels, what is the right location, what will work, what will not work. I tried to do it myself. The Bhagavan said, if you stay within your realm of interest, of your own nature, success is guaranteed. You will achieve success. Swag karma nirataha Siddhim Yatha Vindha di tatsurana. But how that happens?

Bhagawan said, I'll tell you now how working in the field of your own interest, one can get. Siddhim perfections, success, expertise, you know. And we find in this world that all kinds of experts. Every time I come across a new challenge in my profession with something which I never heard about. Somebody says design something and say it requires something so unique. How do I figure this thing out?

And then I realized that there are experts in that even there is a disaster. They will maybe find that suddenly that there are experts in this world who deal with that type of disaster which we have never thought about that. How can you have experts in that field when the disaster only occurs once in a. So there are people who find their niche and they become expert because they pursue field of their interest. As simple as Bhagavanji, how they do it, Bhagavanji, I will explain to you now. So the next three verses.

This simply says how you should view your own field of interest.
snippets.reflection:
The Gita's final teaching is surrender. Not passive resignation, but active trust. Having done what you can, release the outcome.

Today, identify one situation where you're holding on too tightly. Practice opening your hands. Let it be what it will be.

Arjuna's journey from paralysis to clarity, from confusion to conviction, is available to each of us. The teaching has been given. What remains is to live it.

snippets.sanskrit:

सिद्धिं प्राप्तो यथा ब्रह्म तथाप्नोति निबोध मे |

बुद्ध्या विशुद्धया युक्तो धृत्यात्मानं नियम्य च |
snippets.transliteration:
asaktabuddhiḥ sarvatra jitātmā vigataspṛhaḥ .

siddhiṃ prāpto yathā brahma tathāpnoti nibodha me .

buddhyā viśuddhayā yukto dhṛtyātmānaṃ niyamya ca .
verseTranslations: He whose mind is entirely detached, who has conquered himself, whose desires have vanished, by his renunciation reaches that stage of perfect freedom where action completes itself and leaves no seed.
I will now state briefly how he, who has reached perfection, finds the Eternal Spirit, the state of Supreme Wisdom.
Guided always by pure reason, bravely restraining himself, renouncing the objects of sense and giving up attachment and hatred;
snippets.commentary:
We had been discussing chapter 18, Moksha Sannyasi Yoga, Yoga of Liberation through renunciation, renunciation of actions. And therefore up till now we have discussed the nature of actions, nature of actors, the that is you and I and the nature of knowledge. Knowledge that propels my desires and my desires prompts me to act. And I go and act in this world outside. So we have analyzed how we function in this world. We came to the conclusion that depending on the texture of my mind and intellect, whether it is Sattvik, Rajaseek or Tamasvik that's dependent on my tendencies.

If my tendencies are Sattvik, I will have Satwik desires and I will do Satwik actions. If it is Rajasek, the same and the Tamasic appropriately. So my tendencies are driving my actions. And these actions come reactions from the world and I react to that and become my actions. This cycle continues as long as I have the sense of doership. And then Bhakti Bhava, which is the sense of enjoyership.

I am the doer and I'm enjoyer. And therefore we have analyzed in detail what is the nature of the action, which is the nature of the actor. What is the nature of knowledge? So the prescription we have seen in the last verse we had been discussing says Sahajam Karma Kaunteya, do the actions which come naturally to you? Because after analyzing all these actions we get confused. Maybe the only Sattvic actions should be done.

I should give up all the Rajasic and Tamasic actions. But that's not possible for any one of us. Because what we don't have control over is our tendencies. Because the tendencies came from my past experiences. I do not have any control over my past. I have control over my present and I don't have any control over my future.

But my present actions can determine what my future can be. I don't have control of the past. I can control the present to control my future. So therefore Bhagavan says after knowing all this, that the actions and actors can be Satvika, Raja, Sikh and Tamastik and their consequences, the results of those actions. So what am I supposed to do, Bhagavan? Bhagavan said, sahajam Karma Kaunteya.

You do the actions which come naturally to you at this time because you have these accumulated vasanas and tendencies which you cannot get rid of them overnight or just because I read Bhagavad Gita for half an hour in the morning. So Bhagavan said, do the actions which come naturally to you, Sahajam Karma Kaunteya, not the ones which I find to. Be the best actions to perform in this field or in this environment, but that which comes natural to me due to my tendencies of my mind and my intellect. Sadoshamma Pin Natya Jat. Now I come to the conclusion that my desire is to do designs for buildings. But then the clients come to me.

Their actions may have some defects. I had clients which had Togo companies. I have casinos as my client and I even had a strip club as my client. In 2001, we were in downtown Brook Binder building and there was a strip club on Brook Road. And they called us up and said, somebody recommended your name and we need your help in doing some modifications to our club because there's some code violations. So my staff who fielded the phone came to Neil, this is a problem.

I don't think you're going to allow it. I said, of course I'm going to allow you. Client is a form of God. Gandhiji said, Gandhiji said, Grahaka Iti Bhagavan something representative. I said, our job is to fix the code violations, Go and find out what the code violations are, figure out what needs to be done, give them appropriate drawing and make sure the code violations are mitigated. What he does is between him and his Bhagavan.

What I do is between I and my Bhagavan. My Bhagavan says, your job as an architect to make sure if a client comes to you to get his building more in line with the local codes, you need to help him. Even they are with defect should not be given up. Because imagine if all architects say, well, we are not helping any strip clubs anymore, what happens? It will be a building with full of fire violation, code violence, dangerous for the society. So Bhagawan said, even your actions, they seem to have defects but because they come naturally to you, should not be given up.

Sarva Arambahi Doshena Dumena Agnihi Ava Vritaha all actions, aramba in this case means actions. And Swamiji clarifies what is considered as arambha. I'm doing that because of I want to do it to fulfill my desire. Any ayramba will have its own defects. Any medication will have its own side effect. Any action which is prompted by your desire will have its own side effects.

So Bhagavan said that's given that the nature of any action. Therefore even if you find that something you are doing out of your nature and find a fault in it, you should not give up. Because every action if you analyze will have its own defects. Domena agnihi awa vritaha Just as every fire will have smoke, some may have more smoke, some fire, some may have very little. But there is smoke because there is no combustion that we know of in our day to day life which is hundred percent combustion. Therefore there will be smoke.

But that does not mean that you give up lighting fire when you need it. Therefore you should continue to perform actions which comes naturally to you even though they may have defects. Now if I work in this world in that manner, what should I expect? Bhagwant, what happens is when you are aligning your actions with your nature that ego pressure will reduce. And all the problems we see in our life is because that ego egocentric actions. But something which comes naturally to me when I do it, there will not be any ego pressure.

And therefore you will gradually become asaktabuddhehe. Your intellect will become unattached. Something which come naturally to you when you do it. There is very little ego involved in it. And therefore you don't get attached to that. Sarvatra, your intellect become unattached in all actions that you perform which comes naturally to you.

Because now your intellect is not attached. It's not creating more vasanas. Where we create more vasanas is we. Are now getting polluted by the experience in this field. I go to the mall and all I want to do is buy one thing. But while I'm there I get affected by the environment.

I went to the list of 10. Items and I came back with 18 items. Because that's how the environment affect us. If I'm consciously working in tune with my own nature then I will be least affected by the environment. Therefore I will have the least creation of new vasanas. In a new vasana, pressure will be at minimum.

So I will be Jitatma. I Will control over myself. Now anytime we say this self is my. My mind and my intellect and my senses. So jitatma vigathas pruhaha will become without any desires. Now this may be very difficult for us to grasp.

But more and more you are functioning in line with your nature. And therefore you are going to get success in that field. You have a less and less desire of doing something which is not in line with your nature. So therefore you become vigadas prohaha without any additional desire. I'm exhausting my past vasanas which has created my tendencies that has put me into this field of activities. I'm exhausting my past vasanas by doing so.

And therefore I'm getting least and least attached to my actions. And when I exhaust those vasanas, I'll have less and less desires. Because I'm only focused on the what I like. Niskarima siddhiyam paramam sanyasena adigachati. What was my final goal is to renounce actions. But right now, because of my past vasanas and the vasana pressures and my tendencies, I cannot renounce them.

So Bhagavan said, go ahead and act in this field which is in tune with your true nature. By doing so you will get less and less the sense of doership and sense of enjoyership. And therefore those actions you will not take credit or blame for it. You will say this is what I do and this is what I wanted to do and I did it. What came out of it was not in my hand. More and more you give up that sense of doership.

Actions become non actions because you're not taking any credit for it. If you act on behalf of your company and things go completely wrong. But you did it exactly as per your company's. Whatever the policies and what your job description calls for. But things went wrong. Would you be totally worried about that?

That's company's problem. Why did they have this wrong policy? They asked me to do this. I as a project manager or the vp, I did. That happens to be the wrong policies. As long as you thought that you took the decision and I was guiding the company's policy then you are in problem.

You are working on behalf of the company. What you do is strictly company's liability. You do something and something goes wrong, it's still the company's liability. Even though Bhagavan has given all these capabilities, us, we take the responsibility and therefore we suffer for it. So Bhagavan said, when you Reach a point, your actions become natural. And therefore you're not taking the creditor of blame for it and offer everything to him who has given you this talent.

So Bhagavan said, as long as you recognize that most of your ability to function in this world has come in spite of you and that sense will give you a nice Karmya Siddhm that you will reach a state of actionlessness. And if you say that's what we were trying to do in the first place, I was working towards my retirement, right? All this 401k and all this I'm putting together. For my retirement actionless state Niskarma Siddhimparamam. He achieves the highest state of actionlessness. And therefore sanyasena adhi gachadi.

And therefore he renounces all the sense of doership and enjoyership and achieves the highest state of complete bliss. The next verse says Siddhim Prapto Yatha Brahma Tata Apnoti Nibodhame Samase Naivakante Nishtha Gnanasya Yapara. We have come full circle. We have understood who we are, how we work in this world. And we also got the prescription of Bhagavan. So now Bhagavan said, okay, now that he understood all of that.

Now if you follow this advice, then what will happen? Siddhim Prapto yatha Brahma Tatha Apnoti Nibodhame ultimate goal was to reach the state of infiniteness. One with the Supreme Self. Why do I want to be one with the supreme self? Because the limited self is not giving me joy and happiness. Therefore I want to not.

I'm doing a favor to Supreme. I'm joining your party. This state is not giving me joy and happiness which I'm looking for. So I want to achieve a state which can give me joy and happiness. And at that state, by all accounts we have seen is the only one state, the state of the Supreme Being. So everyone is knowingly or unknowingly trying to achieve that.

We are failing and then going in circles. The Bhagavan says, let me tell you, it's a very simple and clear path. Act according to your nature. Do not do anything which is contrary to your nature. Because that will complicate your life, will create more unnecessary vasanas, unnecessary desires and then unnecessary actions.

snippets.title: Day 231: Types of Action

verseTranslations: Enjoying solitude, abstemiousness, his body, mind and speech under perfect control, absorbed in meditation, he becomes free - always filled with the spirit of renunciation.

snippets.title: Day 232: Knowledge and Doers
snippets.sanskrit:
भक्त्या मामभिजानाति यावान्यश्चास्मि तत्त्वतः |

सर्वकर्माण्यपि सदा कुर्वाणो मद्व्यपाश्रयः |

चेतसा सर्वकर्माणि मयि संन्यस्य मत्परः |
snippets.transliteration:
bhaktyā māmabhijānāti yāvānyaścāsmi tattvataḥ .

sarvakarmāṇyapi sadā kurvāṇo madvyapāśrayaḥ .

cetasā sarvakarmāṇi mayi saṃnyasya matparaḥ .
verseTranslations: By such devotion, he sees Me, who I am and what I am; and thus realising the Truth, he enters My Kingdom.
Relying on Me in all his action and doing them for My sake, he attains, by My Grace, Eternal and Unchangeable Life.
Surrender then thy actions unto Me, live in Me, concentrate thine intellect on Me, and think always of Me.

So in the beginning, obviously, we have seen that the goal of life is to achieve permanent happiness. And we have heard from our scriptures that the only way one can achieve that perfect happiness is either one becomes a sannyasi or a yogi. Everyone else is in the rut of life. And therefore, if that's your goal, to achieve that permanent happiness, you have to either become a sannyasi or a yogi.

So the chapter opened with the definition of sannyasi and yogi. The one who has renounced the sense of I am the doer, the agency is the sannyasi, and who is yogi? The one who has given us the fruits of actions. Desire for the fruits of actions is a yogi. So either I have to become a sanyasi or a yogi to achieve that permanent happiness. And then the obviously prescription came.

It is easier for us to give up the fruits of actions than giving up the sense of agency. Ego is so entrenched in my personality right now that for me to think I'm not doing it is more difficult. I must at least give up the expectations for desired results of my actions. I can start with that. If I have to do that, I first have to understand what is action and how it is done, what is my involvement in performing my actions. So we have this detailed analysis of what is action, what is an actor, and what propels that action.

The knowledge propels my actions. My knowledge about myself and this world, my relationship with this world drives me to act in this world. So we have detailed analysis of these three, the action, the actor, and the knowledge. We have seen that all of these three are driven by the texture of my mind. My mind has either a sattvic, Rajasic or tamasic tendencies that will make me either a sattvic actor, Rajasic actor, tamasic actor, that will drive me to the sattvic actions, rajasic actions or tamasic actions. So the texture of my mind is the basis for my life.

Who I am today is a reflection of my mind. With my self introspection I may come to a conclusion. That makeup of my mind is this. Right now I'm 20% sattvic, 60% Rajasic and 20% tamasic. I really don't have a choice to change that overnight. Just because I go to a doctor to get my blood work done which I do every four months and they say your cholesterol is too high, triglycerides are way out of control.

Just knowing that I will not be able to change it right away. Neither there is any magical bullet where I can say I will change that overnight. But I can start on a course of action course of action which my doctors constantly, every four months remind me. I remember first month, but three months I take it easy. And as soon as the fourth month comes, I'm vigilant again. I have to be in that prescribed method consistently.

So the first thing is I have to accept my condition. I have to accept that I have the high cholesterol and high triglycerides and I have this propensity to get a heart attack and all that. If I deny that, if I'm in a denial, that's all, that's not for a long time I'll deny blood pressure. I go to my one doctor, my blood always comes out right. I go to anywhere else, my blood pressure is very high. So I go to the insurance company, they check and say your blood is high.

I said, no, no, you are wrong. Let me go back to my doctor, I'll check it out. For some reason it worked. Every time I go there, my blood pressure is normal. I go anywhere else, my blood pressure is not normal. So I was in a complete denial that I have high blood pressure.

Finally I had to accept that I probably have high blood pressure. So first is acceptance that I may have this condition. Conditioning which I see as myself is not in my control. It was in my control at one point of time, but it has now become past. So I have now become who I am because of all my past experiences and actions. And I accept that now I have to work on it.

So first thing I have to do is what comes naturally to me at this time and then take it from there what my goal would be. So Bhagavan said, now if your goal is to achieve the permanent happiness you have come to the Conclusion. This is the makeup of your mind. The advice is Sahajam karma kaunteya sudo shena pin natya jat. Do the actions which comes naturally to you even though they are imperfect. My chosen field of action may not be the most popular, the most appreciated.

But that's what my nature is. I like carpentry and I want to be a carpenter. I like arts and I want to be an artist. They always have this hungry artists exhibitions because artists go hungry. But that's the chosen field comes naturally to me. The Bhagavan said, sahajam karma kaunteya sadosha bin natya jat.

You cannot give up the field of actions which come naturally to you. First advice, Clear guidance. Stay in the field which comes naturally to you and then go from there. So the next advice is then. Okay, Now I have figured out what my natural field of action is. But how should I act so that I'll get the benefit of that?

The next thing is Asaktah jitatma. Without attachment and without any expectation. We have seen there are only two paths. Either to become a Sanyasi or a yogi. Yogi is the one who gives up Karma Phala. I found field of my actions.

I'm ready to now launch my career in that field or my endeavors. Without any expectation. I will do what I like in the best I can. What comes out of my actions is not in my control. Because I am not the Karma Faladatta. Karma Faladatta is always the word, the ishvara, somebody other than me.

I need to leave it to them their duties to perform diligently. I will perform my duty diligently. The Bhagavan said, perform your actions without attachment expectations in the field which comes naturally to you. Doing so, you will develop devotion for me. You will align your thoughts with the one who empowers you to do these actions. So therefore he said, become one with me.

Offer everything to me. And the last few verses which you have seen. He says, bhaktiya mam abhijanati yavat na aschasmi tatvatah tatomam tattvato gnatva visatei tad anantharam. Just by acting in this manner of offering everything to him. As we have seen in detail the previous verses, once I decided the field of my actions, I decided that I am not really the one who empowers me to act. The consciousness functioning through me as my life empowers me to act.

I'll be only able to conduct Gita classes as long as I'm alive. The day I drop dead, Gita classes will be history. That's because my consciousness in me allows me to understand Bhagavad Gita. So the empowering authority is something other than me. That which connects the electricity in this room is the empowering authority for the electricity. We have lights, we have air conditioning.

Right now we are pretty happy. Things are working fine. They rented the place. Electricity wasn't there. He thought, I am the Almighty for this place. Calls me up and says, not working.

I said, I think the machine is not working. Electricity is not connecting through Dominion Virginia Power. Dominion Virginia Power is the final authority that the electricity comes here. I have a limited power to turn the switch on and off when I need that. But in that limited power, I start thinking because it is always there. I think I am in control and I can turn this thing on and off.

It is only when the power goes out I realize I am just a Nimitta Matra. Virginia Power decides whether I have electricity or not. As long as that electricity is functioning through this space, I can control this space. When Dominion Virginia Power connection is disconnected, no matter how many times I turn the switch on and off, nothing happens. Bhagavan said, you need to recognize this fact that you are connected to me as the supreme consciousness which is functioning through you. If you keep that in mind all the time, they will make sure that that connection never gets disconnected.

See, when I design buildings, most buildings have normal electricity connection. And then when there is power outage, the connection goes out. But I designed the emergency shelter. Actually medical examiner's office in downtown. Well, you can't have the power go out during emergency. That is the time when there's a disaster.

That's the time that office becomes most active. They may have all these disaster victims coming to this place. Those pathologists have to work overnight to deal with them. So you need to have a dual power system for that. We connected that building from two different grids. So even though one grid is out, the other grid is connected.

They will never be out of that electrical connection. That's where you will have this permanent connection. Bhagavan said, if you want eternal happiness, you need to make sure that your connection to me is always connected. And for that, you have to offer everything that you do to me. Remembering constantly that I can only do this because he's functioning through me. With that attitude, you will develop devotion for him.

You will be constantly attached to him. So we both have to have that dual connection. Bhagavan has to have connection with me and I have to have connection with him. That connection when developed, we call it devotion. It's one that devotion takes place. Bhakti mam Avijanati Yavatna Asha asmi Tattvatahara Tatotam tattvoto Gnatva visate tat Anantaram.

By devotion he knows me in essence. Once I become identified completely with someone or something, I know that thing or being in its essence or his essence. He forthwith enters into me the supreme. Once I completely identify myself with the supreme self, I enters into him. In other words, I become one with that supreme being. Sarvakarmani API sada Kurvanaha mat vyapaasrayah mat prasadat avapnothi Saswatam padam avyayam.

The process took place. I gave up identification with my ego. I chose the field of my actions. I started working in the field of my actions without any expectations and offered all my actions to him. Now with that connection I have identified completely with him. So now my life is doing all actions always taking refuge in him with his grace.

Now I have not become happy with my efforts. I have become peaceful and happy with his grace. This space is properly conditioned and littered up right now. Grace of Dominion Virginia Power. When their grace is taken away from me, this light will go away and this air conditioning will go away. As long as I recognize that the lights and air conditioning not because of me, because I'm paying the bills but because of their grace that they have connected their electricity to this space then I will be fine.

Then I'll develop that devotion to Dominion Virginia Power. As soon as the bill comes, pay the bill. Bhagavan said, one who becomes one with me, with this root of actions he has become one with me and therefore he achieves that Saswatam Padam avyayam.

snippets.title: Day 234: Renunciation
snippets.sanskrit:
ईश्वरः सर्वभूतानां हृद्देशेऽर्जुन तिष्ठति |

तमेव शरणं गच्छ सर्वभावेन भारत |

इति ते ज्ञानमाख्यातं गुह्याद्गुह्यतरं मया |
snippets.transliteration:
īśvaraḥ sarvabhūtānāṃ hṛddeśe.arjuna tiṣṭhati .

tameva śaraṇaṃ gaccha sarvabhāvena bhārata .

iti te jñānamākhyātaṃ guhyādguhyataraṃ mayā .
verseTranslations: God dwells in the hearts of all beings, O Arjuna! He causes them to revolve as it were on a wheel by His mystic power.
With all thy strength, fly unto Him and surrender thyself, and by His grace shalt thou attain Supreme Peace and reach the Eternal Home.
Thus have I revealed to thee the Truth, the Mystery of mysteries. Having thought it over, thou art free to act as thou wilt.
snippets.commentary:
Discussing chapter 18, Moksha Sannyasa yoga Yoga of Liberation to Renunciation so we are at the conclusion of Bhagavad Gita and in this chapter Bhagawan stated few simple facts which we already know. We have discussed before and also we experienced in our life something as simple as in this world People have different temperaments. Not all people are alike. Continue functioning. Except keep the Lord in mind that he is Almighty. He is making me do all these things and therefore I am offering everything I do to Him. Tamevasharanam gacha. Take refuge in that Ishvara, that Almighty, all pervading consciousness. Sarva bhavena Bharata in all your being, with all your thoughts, even thinking about your professional thoughts, your relationships, everything.

While you are thinking, put him in the center of it all these things are only possible because of Him. Take refuge in him that you are the ones who is enabling me to function in this world as an individual. Tat Prasada paramsanthim Sthanam prapsi Saswatam. If you take refuge in him with all your being, with all your thoughts, no matter what that is, offer it to him that I can only think this way because of you. I can only act this way because of you. Once you start assigning all credits to him, then you are relieved.

You have no responsibilities. So in the end Bhagavan said this individualized ego which is identifying with this body, mind and intellect and taking credit for what I'm doing, thinking that I'm the doer. If you just keep that aside, do everything that you are doing right now exactly as you are doing. Because you are doing it as per your nature. You are propelled by your nature to do it. If you try to resist your nature, you are a distortion, a mental disease.

So keep doing what you are doing. Just keep in mind Tamevasharanam Gacha, Sarva Bhavya Bharata. Just take refuge in Him. Make your identification with him versus this limited body, mind and intellect. Tat prasadat paramshantin sthan praapasi Saswatam. The grace is when the identification is complete then I obviously become one with him, his qualities become my qualities.

I start thinking I have now an access to his capacities. You joined a company a day before and from next day onwards you're part of the company. All the resources of the company. You take the brochure of the company and go to a new client and say I represent IBM. All the IBM's resources are your resources. Now before that, a day before, when you have not joined the company yet, you didn't have that brochure from IBM with you.

You are just an individual. You can say I can do this and that doesn't really mean much. Once you attached the resources of the Great, all his resources, your resources, all the qualifications of that company become your qualifications. Once you identify with him and take refuge in him Tat Prasad with his grace you will achieve that Santisthanam Propyasi Sastvatam. You will find that eternal peace and a firm abode. All you have to do is just take refuge in him and continue doing what you are doing as per your own nature.

Itite Gnanam Akhyatam Guhyat Guhyatram Maya Vimrushyat Ashe. We have discussed this thing in detail. From chapter two onward. We have analyzed every point. In the end I came down and told you that just follow your own Dharma, your own nature. You will not incur any sin.

Do not worry about other people are doing, do not copy them. Your welfare is in following your own Dharma and give up your ego and attachment. And I will take care of everything else. I told you this very secret of knowledge. Secret means it was right now hidden from me. It was right there but hidden from me.

Because of my own likes and dislikes, my vasanas, my ignorance, I was not able to see this. I took that coverings away from you so that you can see the knowledge as is. I told you in its entirety. Vimrushya Etit Asena. Reflect on it in its totality. Don't take a verse here and there from Bhagavad Gita.

snippets.title: Day 237: The Final Teaching
snippets.sanskrit:
अध्येष्यते च य इमं धर्म्यं संवादमावयोः |

श्रद्धावाननसूयश्च शृणुयादपि यो नरः |

कच्चिदेतच्छ्रुतं पार्थ त्वयैकाग्रेण चेतसा |
snippets.transliteration:
adhyeṣyate ca ya imaṃ dharmyaṃ saṃvādamāvayoḥ .

śraddhāvānanasūyaśca śṛṇuyādapi yo naraḥ .

kaccidetacchrutaṃ pārtha tvayaikāgreṇa cetasā .
verseTranslations: He who will study this spiritual discourse of ours, I assure thee, he shall thereby worship Me at the altar of Wisdom.
Yea, he who listens to it with faith and without doubt, even he, freed from evil, shalt rise to the worlds which the virtuous attain through righteous deeds.
O Arjuna! Hast thou listened attentively to My words? Has thy ignorance and thy delusion gone?
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 18, Moksha Sannyasa Yoga, Yoga of Liberation through Renunciation. This is the last chapter in Bhagavad Gita, and Bhagavan has given his final advice to us. It boils down to Sreyan Swadharma Vigunaha Paradharma Swanashti da. Your own Dharma is better for you than other dharma. And therefore he says, Sahajam Karma Kamateja Sadosham Abhiyana Tej. These are the two basic facts.

He pointed out to us that your welfare is staying within your Dharma, whatever Dharma that you have acquired through your own choice. So my dharma as an architect, I have chosen myself. I decided to go to architecture school and therefore I became an architect. Now Bhagavad said, your welfare is in your Dharma. Don't try to practice something other than what you're good at. There was Sahajam Karma Gandhiya.

Do what comes naturally to you. Because of all your experiences and vasanas and tendencies and your training, there are few things in life which comes easier for you. And others don't stay with what comes naturally to you, even though other things look more glamorous, more glorious. But you say, even if your Dharma, you found it Sadosha Mapi, even there are some defects in it or not very perfect. Do actions in your own field which come naturally to you. There are the only two things he said, doing so you will overcome all your obstacles and you will never incur sin.

Working in the field which come naturally to you, keeping your own goal in mind that I'm doing it to get my ultimate happiness. But once you will never incur sin. Sin, as we have discussed, is negative impression on my mind, which creates agitations. All we are looking for in life is peace. Give me peace of mind. Peace of mind only come when mind is tranquil.

Because the mind will only be tranquil if you're working according to your own Dharma. And then he said the final advice after completing his entire discourse. And he said, now you do whatever you think is right for you. He gave you the complete choice one more time and said, let me summarize what I told you. Manmana Bhava mad Bhaktaha Madhya ji Mam namaskuruhu. In other words, Krishna said, if you want to summarize the entire teachings of Bhagavad Gita in half a verse, this is what I had been telling you.

To get the happiness which you are looking for, fix your mind onto me. Me the all pervading almighty self which is also your self. Focus your mind on that mad Bhaktah worship that identify with that Madhya Ji. Offer all your actions to me. Offer all your actions to the highest goal which you have when you go to the first grade. I'm learning this and that.

Because eventually I want to become a doctor. My granddaughter was telling me yesterday, I have two inventions I want to release before I became a doctor. So there is an ultimate goal in mind. That ultimate goal is to find perfect happiness. Perfect happiness is only there if my mind is tranquil. Bhagawan said, Madhya Ji, offer everything to me Maam namaskurohu and take refuge in me.

Then he clarified say Sarva Dharma and parity. Aham TVA Sarva Papebiha Moksa Kshya minasucha. Right now you think that you are incomplete. You have lots of baggage of all your incompleteness and sins. As you said, the things which you have not done right. I have not done this thing right in my life.

Bhagawan said, no, you can't. You cannot correct yourself. But if you take refuge in me, I can correct that. Sarva Dharma and Parityajya. And we have discussed this Sarva Dharman. Every role that I take, it comes with its own Dharma.

Every role a drama actor plays, it comes with its own requirement. Now if I start identifying with each role, then I'll get confused. I will have a nervous breakdown. I will have a personality disorder. I don't know who I am. Am I a king or a pauper?

Because I play so many different roles. The Bhagawan thing in your life, you take too many of these roles. All those roles come with their own Dharma. My Dharma is a father. My Dharma is an architect. My Dharma is a husband.

My Dharma is a citizen of this country. My Dharma is an employer. All those Dharmas, if I get bogged down into them and think that they will give me my Happiness. Then I'll be completely shattered. I do not really know which role is more important than others. Keep working in that dharma when you are there.

When you are an architect, act as an architect. When you are father, act as a father. But at the end of the day, you realize that you are something other than all the roles which you play. An actor in Beverly Hills knows that he is something other than the roles he plays. So Bhagawanja Sarva Dharma and Paritya Jya. At the end of the day, give up.

All those dharmas are not yours. But they belong to the roles which you play. While you're playing that role, you can't give up those dharmas. But once you're out of that role, leave those dharmas with that role and focus on who you are. Who is there One constant in all these roles which has its own dharma. So Bhagawan says, ma makeam sharam Braja.

Identify with that one single entity which is pervading through all the roles which you play. Ahamtva Sarva Pape bihamoksik Shami Mashu chah. Once you identify with that, all the limitations you have in each one of those roles are of no consequence because it only belongs to the role. You may not have played the role correctly. Fine, let's move on to the next one. One movie gets flopped, the actor doesn't get shattered.

He moves on to another one, waiting for the next hit. Don't get caught up in any of those roles as that's the only thing which is mine. And if I fail there, I have failed in it. Bhagavan said, you don't worry. Once you take refuge in your own self, everything will be alright. Now that you have learnt this knowledge, don't just sit back and relax.

That's not where your duty ends. You have to do your part. Now that you were privileged enough to know what is right, you also have an obligation to teach others what is right. And I, the parent, was a son at one point of time. And I got the advice from my parents and they told me what is right and wrong. I made my life right or wrong according to that.

And now I learned after my experience what is right and wrong. I have an obligation to pass on that knowledge to my children. Ya Imam paramam guhiyam mad bhakteshu abhi dashyathi bhakti mai param kutva Mama eva isyati asansaya. He said, there is one who declares this, teaches this knowledge of mine to my devotees, not to the people who are not interested in it, but those who are inspired themselves to make their life better, make their life appropriate, remove all the negatives from their life, but they still do not know how to do it. When you find those enthusiastic students, that's what you want to teach them. Therefore I said, the one who teaches this sacred knowledge of mind to my Bhakta, those who are devoted to this knowledge, Bhakti mai param kutva maam eva Eshyati asansayaha.

I consider that he is worshipping me. Bhagavan said, you don't have to come to my temple every day and put $1 in the Aarti or to do anything special. The greatest devotion we can offer to our teacher is to carry the torch of his knowledge. That's why we do Pada Puja. Because the platform on which my Guru is standing that the platform which I worship, that knowledge is important. Bhagawan said, one who spread this knowledge of mine which I gave it to you, to others, I consider him to be my devotee and therefore he will come to me without any doubt.

He will become one with me or Sansayah. No other thing needed. Bhagavan said, you just continue. You learn this knowledge, practice it, and then pass it on to the others. That Bhagavan said, I consider to my greatest devotion. So basically it encourages all of us, whatever little we have learned from Bhagavad Gita.

There is an obligation to impart the knowledge to someone else who is curious to know. He may not have the right frame of understanding, but he wants to know. You have an obligation to give him that knowledge. Bhagawan says, Nachatasmat manushesu kaschinmi priyakrutamaha. None other than that person who carries this torch of knowledge is dearer to me than him. But once I He is the closest to me because he's carrying forward the mission that I have that I want to correct the misunderstanding in people.

You were confused, Arjuna. I gave you this discourse so that you can now act in your life correctly. Now you have an obligation to do that to someone else who you will find it in the same situation. And I consider that as my worship that you have appreciated what I have given you. And such a person is dearer to me. Some other people may come and other things for me, but they are of lesser value than you carrying forward my mission.

Bhavita Nachame tasmat anyaha Priyatara Bhuvi, not only now, but even in future, there won't be anyone who is dearer to me than the one who is spreading this knowledge to make this world better and spreading the right knowledge. So Swamiji points out here that we have this misconception in our Hinduism that we obviously don't convert people. We don't encourage people to come to our fore. In fact, we discourage people if someone has to be Hindu. You can't become a Hindu unless you're born Hindu. Swamiji Sri Bhagawan clearly points out that that's not part of our culture.

We do not want forced conversion. We don't want to tell people who have not yet understood to believe in this knowledge. Give him his own time. Because forced conversion, forced imposition, never works in reality anywhere. Therefore you say, find people who are willing to understand this and give this knowledge. That's your obligation.

So that's a missionary work. They never said that this knowledge never be given out to anybody, should not be given to people who are not from this class or other. Simply said, find the right person, right group of people who are anxious to make their lives better. Give this knowledge to them. I'll consider that to the greatest devotion to me. And he said, therefore such a person deals with not only now, but even if this open your mind will never change.

You know it's not right now I'm telling you that, but in future it may be something different. It will hold true all throughout the history that whoever spreads his teacher's knowledge, that the greatest devotee that the greatest Guru Dakshina one can give it to his teacher. If, let's say you consider that you are not capable of spreading this knowledge, well, you don't have resources, you don't have temperament. You don't consider yourself worthy of doing so. But if you just listen to this Adhesya de cha Imam Dharma Samvadam Avayoho. This dialogue of ours, this sacred dialogue of ours which deals with who you are in reality and who you are not, how to act in this world so that you can achieve your ultimate goal.

This dialogue which we had, which is sacred, even if you just study that listening is slightly different than studying one who studies this.

snippets.title: Day 238: Renunciation
snippets.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच |

सञ्जय उवाच |

व्यासप्रसादाच्छ्रुतवानेतद्गुह्यमहं परम् |
snippets.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca .

sañjaya uvāca .

vyāsaprasādācchrutavānetadguhyamahaṃ param .
verseTranslations: Arjuna replied: My Lord! O Immutable One! My delusion has fled. By Thy Grace, O Changeless One, the light has dawned. My doubts are gone, and I stand before Thee ready to do Thy will."
Sanjaya told: "Thus have I heard this rare, wonderful and soul-stirring discourse of the Lord Shri Krishna and the great-souled Arjuna.
Through the blessing of the sage Vyasa, I listened to this secret and noble science from the lips of its Master, the Lord Shri Krishna.
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 18, Moksa Sannyasa Yoga. Yoga of Liberation through renunciation. Liberating yourself from all that is binding you. What is binding me is my limitations. I'm limiting myself by associating with my body, mind and intellectual. So in the end, Bhagavan Samara says, sarva Dharma Parityajya Maam Ekam Sharanam Praja.

Give up your dependence on your body, mind and intellect as the source of your happiness. That eternal happiness which you are seeking, you are right now dependent on your body, mind and intellect. I'll gain through my power, I'll gain through my intellect. I'll gain through my manipulating the others. Bhagavan said, give up all those and just take refuge in me, the source, the self, the consciousness. And I will take care of all your sins.

All the things which you have as negative impressions, I will take care of. I will wipe them out and make you clean so that you can experience the joy which is your nature. This is praptasya pravtvi. This is something which we already have. All we have to do is clear that which is veiling that happiness. So we concluded the discourse on Bhagavad Gita.

Bhagavad Bhagavan also said, who you should not be teaching this knowledge. One who does not have any discipline. One who does not have any devotion towards this knowledge. One who, who has no sense of service to others. One is in other words, so self centered. Such a person will not be able to learn anything from you because he's so self centered about himself.

Then lastly he said, the one who cavils at this knowledge or me, if I do not have any faith in any idea, I will never be able to learn. See, in Gujaratri a child is crying for a long time. Asu ragda tyanay Ragada means raga tana pulling. Why are you pulling all these ragas? You know why they did? There was kind of contempt against the people who perform classical music and they will continue.

So when somebody now you have no appreciation for it. And therefore now you're associating with their babies, crying and saying why are you ragadatthan? Now that's a cavilling towards that art. I have no respect for that art. I have sometimes, you know, people go for the dance program and say so how was was the same though South Indian dancing all the time. Because they were looking for a Bollywood dancing that turned out to be Kathak classical dancing concert.

Because they have no appreciation for their art. I have seen the Ghatapata, the discourse about Vedanta where they are using this analogy. Ghata Patta, Ghatapada, Garbhad Karta in Bombay, right? Gatapata became Gadbar. No appreciation for that discussion or discourse. Now such a person, if you try to teach the same thing, one who says Garbhad Iska you try to teach him Vedanta will not work.

One who says Vairu Ragda, he will not learn music. He has no appreciation for it. So Bhagavan says such a person, you should not be teaching this Bhagavad Gita. He has to come to a level where he has disciplined himself. He has devotion for this knowledge and he has a sense of service. In essence he does not think about his own good but see oneness with others.

That's how we do service. We can only serve somebody whom we revere, appreciate or love for one who has none of this. For this knowledge, you should not be teaching that. On the other hand, Bhagavan said, if you learned this knowledge by God's grace, you got this chance to learn this precious knowledge from your teacher. You should share this with others. Do not be self centered.

If you're a Christian, come and ask me. You don't become just a scholar but share this with others. This is the concept of franchising, right? You have a concept and give it to others. That's how it grows into a huge multinational. Otherwise selling burger, how can that be a big business?

It is the simplest thing in the world. Take a bun and put a patty in between. Put little lettuce, tomato and ketchup, you're done. But it's a multinational entity. Because the concept of franchising. Somebody asked Einstein, is there anything baffles you in this world?

He said the concept of compound interest. And somebody has demonstrated to me, said, if you get one penny first day, then it doubles next Day you keep doubling pennies versus I give you million dollar first hand. Which one in 20 years will be greater and he demonstrates the other one will be like in millions of dollars. The compound interest. So compounding this knowledge for the greater good of the society. It is every student's duty to share this with others.

Those who are interested and are worthy. So therefore Bhagavan said, such a person will certainly will come to me now. Teaching this subject which you have learnt, you become master at it. After a while you become one with that subject. If you learn music, then continue teaching music. You will become a master of it.

Because you are practicing more and more and more by every time you teach to somebody else. So Bhagavan says, such a person will certainly come to me. He will become me in a sense he will attain that oneness he is seeking with his own supreme self. So Bhagavan is actively asking you to go out and teach others. How did Swami Chinmayanda became a Jagat Guru? By introducing the idea of study group.

If he had just said come to my lecture, we would have gone to his lectures and left. I did that for a long time. I obviously met Swamiji when I was 17 years old. First I just went to his lectures because in India I did not know. When I came to USA, first series I attended in 1983, I had no idea about study group. But Swamiji said at the end of the Gita Yajna that those of you are interested now must attend study group and say, what is the study group?

So Gaurang Nanavati from Houston called me up because I filled out that form. And I had no interest really in joining study group. Because I was thinking, who else other than Swami Chinnamanda who can teach me this? But because Swamiji said that head little Shraddha, I must go. And that's how I went to study Guru. This is where I started learning Bhagavad Gita, not from Swamiji's lectures.

So the idea of these study groups has made this Chinmaya mission a great organization. In sharing this knowledge. Idea came from Bhagavan Sri Krishna, share your knowledge. So Bhagavan said, such a person will certainly will achieve the goal he's seeking. Then the next he said, there is no one in this world who is closer to me than the one who is teaching this Bhagavad Gita. With Shraddha, with having the supreme faith in me, in this knowledge.

You cannot teach something if you are not convinced about it. You can only convince others. If you are convinced about it with conviction. One who teaches this Bhagavad Gita, Bhagavan says, I don't think there's anyone who is dearer to me, anyone who is nearer to me than that person. Because he came closest to the goal of becoming one with that universal self. So Bhagavan has glorified the teachers and the teachings.

And then he said, adhesyatecha Imam Dharmayam samvaoho Gnan yagneham istahaam ithi me matehi. Now the student, is there anything beneficial in just learning? One who studies this dialogue of ours about Dharma. This dialogue, Bhagavad Gita, all 18 chapters of Tira. This is dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna. So Krishna is telling Arjuna this, our dialogue about Dharma.

What is right, what is wrong, what is real, what is unreal. Who studies such a person? I consider that such a person is worshipping me through Gnani Yajna. He may not be a Krishna Bhakta. He may not be doing Sri Krishna, Shranham, Sri Krishna, Shrana, Sri Krishna. He may not be going to the temple at all.

He may not bow down at Krishna statue in the temple. But Bhagavan said, I will consider that or not consider. He said, it is my conviction that such a person is worshipping me through Gnana Yoga. So the student who is studying Bhagavad Gita, Bhagavan said he is directly worshipping me. And we have learnt in Bhagavad Gita previously. How do you serve your teacher?

By living the ideal the teacher teaches is the best service to your teacher. Your teacher teaches you music and you don't do anything about it. But just keep giving him fees and never learned music. Is that a service to him? It may make his living. But he is not very proud of you.

But my teacher teaches me something and I excel in it. And then propagate that knowledge even further. He will be very proud when he hears about you. Even today you go and tell Gaurangban we went to Neelkhan's class. You know why he is my teacher? When he hears that he knows after all these years, Nilkant is still into Bhagavad Gita has not given up.

That's a service to your teacher. So Bhagavan said, such a person, I'll consider that he's serving me directly. He's worshipping me directly through Gnana Yoga word Yajna Signifies sacrificial fire is invoked and devotees are offering oblations in it. You see here, the fire of knowledge is kindled by your studies and you are offering your ignorance into it. Up till now what I considered me and now no, it is not me. So my ignorance about myself, which in common language we call ego is what we are offering into this Gnar Yajna.

Therefore, Bhagavan said, I am convinced, I'm convicted that such a person is worshipping me through Gnan Yajna. So when student is glorified here, then the next one says okay. But somebody is not even studying. We have heard this before. There is a difference between reading and studying. Swamiji explained, you read newspaper.

You really have no other interest but to get some information what's going on? So you are reading newspaper, but you study your subject. I have to study because I want to know the knowledge. So not just reading Bhagavad Gita. So just chanting Bhagavad Gita may or may not do much good to you. But studying Bhagavad Gita, Bhagavan said, I'm convinced that you are worshipping me through Gnani Yajna.

But now I'm not studying. Sraddha vana anasuyashcha Srunayat Apiyo naraha. A person who is listening to this knowledge, he may not be studying intently. He may not be reading Bhagavad Gita. But he's listening to the discourse about Bhagavad Gita. About the knowledge about Bhagavad Gita Sadhguru.

But you have to have faith in it. You're not just listening just to find out what it is all about. With Shraddha, we when we listen to somebody like Dalai Lama or Sri Sri Ravi Shankar or somebody whom we have Shraddha and listen to him, we are intently listening what he's saying. So we're trying to understand what is the message behind this. That's the Sarda Saddhavan Anasuya. He's not listening to find out what is wrong in that.

As we had heard before that Max Muller and those scholars were given grant by European powers to go and study Sanskrit. So find out what is all this garbage they are teaching their people. And then tell them that this all wrong. That Anasuya that's cavilling at that knowledge. If you are not doing it because of that and it turns out that Max Muller became probably the greatest scholar because he probably had the real intention, even though his sponsors may not have, that such a person who is just listening to this discourse about Bhagavad Gita, the knowledge of Bhagavad Gita sovapi muktaha, he also will get liberated.

snippets.sanskrit:
राजन्संस्मृत्य संस्मृत्य संवादमिममद्भुतम् |

तच्च संस्मृत्य संस्मृत्य रूपमत्यद्भुतं हरेः |

यत्र योगेश्वरः कृष्णो यत्र पार्थो धनुर्धरः |
snippets.transliteration:
rājansaṃsmṛtya saṃsmṛtya saṃvādamimamadbhutam .

tacca saṃsmṛtya saṃsmṛtya rūpamatyadbhutaṃ hareḥ .

yatra yogeśvaraḥ kṛṣṇo yatra pārtho dhanurdharaḥ .
verseTranslations: O King! The more I think of that marvellous and holy discourse, the more I lose myself in joy.
As memory recalls again and again the exceeding beauty of the Lord, I am filled with amazement and happiness.
Wherever is the Lord Shri Krishna, the Prince of Wisdom, and wherever is Arjuna, the Great Archer, I am more than convinced that good fortune, victory, happiness and righteousness will follow"
snippets.commentary:
So we had been discussing chapter 18, Moksa Sannyas Yoga. We have come to the final concluding portion where Bhagavan has concluded his portion. Arjuna has confirmed that he is now completely in control of himself. His delusion is gone. He regained his memory. In other words, what is right and what is wrong, what needs to be done and what's to be avoided and what his real self is.

I'm now ready to do whatever you have asked me to do. In other words, I'm now ready to follow your instruction in Bhagavad Gita, which I have learnt so far from you. So I will now fight this war. Basically, when we are deluded and somebody gives advice and we are now ready to face the challenges of life, then we say, don't worry, I'm now ready. I will fight this battle. That's where Arjuna is now.

The Gita's final teaching is surrender. Not passive resignation, but active trust. Having done what you can, release the outcome.

Today, identify one situation where you're holding on too tightly. Practice opening your hands. Let it be what it will be.

Arjuna's journey from paralysis to clarity, from confusion to conviction, is available to each of us. The teaching has been given. What remains is to live it.
